column1: title	text	label
You Can Smell Hillary's Fear	"Daniel Greenfield
column2: a Shillman Journalism Fellow at the Freedom Center
column3: is a New York writer focusing on radical Islam.

column1: In the final stretch of the election
column2: Hillary Rodham Clinton has gone to war with the FBI.

column1: The word “unprecedented” has been thrown around so often this election that it ought to be retired. But it’s still unprecedented for the nominee of a major political party to go war with the FBI.

But that’s exactly what Hillary and her people have done. Coma patients just waking up now and watching an hour of CNN from their hospital beds would assume that FBI Director James Comey is Hillary’s opponent in this election.

The FBI is under attack by everyone from Obama to CNN. Hillary’s people have circulated a letter attacking Comey. There are currently more media hit pieces lambasting him than targeting Trump. It wouldn’t be too surprising if the Clintons or their allies were to start running attack ads against the FBI.

The FBI’s leadership is being warned that the entire left-wing establishment will form a lynch mob if they continue going after Hillary. And the FBI’s credibility is being attacked by the media and the Democrats to preemptively head off the results of the investigation of the Clinton Foundation and Hillary Clinton.
The covert struggle between FBI agents and Obama’s DOJ people has gone explosively public.
The New York Times has compared Comey to J. Edgar Hoover. Its bizarre headline
column2: “James Comey Role Recalls Hoover’s FBI
column3: Fairly or Not” practically admits up front that it’s spouting nonsense. The Boston Globe has published a column calling for Comey’s resignation. Not to be outdone
column4: Time has an editorial claiming that the scandal is really an attack on all women.

column1: James Carville appeared on MSNBC to remind everyone that he was still alive and insane. He accused Comey of coordinating with House Republicans and the KGB. And you thought the “vast right wing conspiracy” was a stretch.
Countless media stories charge Comey with violating procedure. Do you know what’s a procedural violation? Emailing classified information stored on your bathroom server.

Senator Harry Reid has sent Comey a letter accusing him of violating the Hatch Act. The Hatch Act is a nice idea that has as much relevance in the age of Obama as the Tenth Amendment. But the cable news spectrum quickly filled with media hacks glancing at the Wikipedia article on the Hatch Act under the table while accusing the FBI director of one of the most awkward conspiracies against Hillary ever.
If James Comey is really out to hurt Hillary
column2: he picked one hell of a strange way to do it.

column1: Not too long ago Democrats were breathing a sigh of relief when he gave Hillary Clinton a pass in a prominent public statement. If he really were out to elect Trump by keeping the email scandal going
column2: why did he trash the investigation? Was he on the payroll of House Republicans and the KGB back then and playing it coy or was it a sudden development where Vladimir Putin and Paul Ryan talked him into taking a look at Anthony Weiner’s computer?

column1: Either Comey is the most cunning FBI director that ever lived or he’s just awkwardly trying to navigate a political mess that has trapped him between a DOJ leadership whose political futures are tied to Hillary’s victory and his own bureau whose apolitical agents just want to be allowed to do their jobs.

The only truly mysterious thing is why Hillary and her associates decided to go to war with a respected Federal agency. Most Americans like the FBI while Hillary Clinton enjoys a 60% unfavorable rating.
And it’s an interesting question.

Hillary’s old strategy was to lie and deny that the FBI even had a criminal investigation underway. Instead her associates insisted that it was a security review. The FBI corrected her and she shrugged it off. But the old breezy denial approach has given way to a savage assault on the FBI.
Pretending that nothing was wrong was a bad strategy
column2: but it was a better one that picking a fight with the FBI while lunatic Clinton associates try to claim that the FBI is really the KGB.

column1: There are two possible explanations.

Hillary Clinton might be arrogant enough to lash out at the FBI now that she believes that victory is near. The same kind of hubris that led her to plan her victory fireworks display could lead her to declare a war on the FBI for irritating her during the final miles of her campaign.
But the other explanation is that her people panicked.

Going to war with the FBI is not the behavior of a smart and focused presidential campaign. It’s an act of desperation. When a presidential candidate decides that her only option is to try and destroy the credibility of the FBI
column2: that’s not hubris
column3: it’s fear of what the FBI might be about to reveal about her.

column1: During the original FBI investigation
column2: Hillary Clinton was confident that she could ride it out. And she had good reason for believing that. But that Hillary Clinton is gone. In her place is a paranoid wreck. Within a short space of time the “positive” Clinton campaign promising to unite the country has been replaced by a desperate and flailing operation that has focused all its energy on fighting the FBI.

column1: There’s only one reason for such bizarre behavior.

The Clinton campaign has decided that an FBI investigation of the latest batch of emails poses a threat to its survival. And so it’s gone all in on fighting the FBI. It’s an unprecedented step born of fear. It’s hard to know whether that fear is justified. But the existence of that fear already tells us a whole lot.
Clinton loyalists rigged the old investigation. They knew the outcome ahead of time as well as they knew the debate questions. Now suddenly they are no longer in control. And they are afraid.
You can smell the fear.

The FBI has wiretaps from the investigation of the Clinton Foundation. It’s finding new emails all the time. And Clintonworld panicked. The spinmeisters of Clintonworld have claimed that the email scandal is just so much smoke without fire. All that’s here is the appearance of impropriety without any of the substance. But this isn’t how you react to smoke. It’s how you respond to a fire.

The misguided assault on the FBI tells us that Hillary Clinton and her allies are afraid of a revelation bigger than the fundamental illegality of her email setup. The email setup was a preemptive cover up. The Clinton campaign has panicked badly out of the belief
column2: right or wrong
column3: that whatever crime the illegal setup was meant to cover up is at risk of being exposed.

column1: The Clintons have weathered countless scandals over the years. Whatever they are protecting this time around is bigger than the usual corruption
column2: bribery
column3: sexual assaults and abuses of power that have followed them around throughout the years. This is bigger and more damaging than any of the allegations that have already come out. And they don’t want FBI investigators anywhere near it.

column1: The campaign against Comey is pure intimidation. It’s also a warning. Any senior FBI people who value their careers are being warned to stay away. The Democrats are closing ranks around their nominee against the FBI. It’s an ugly and unprecedented scene. It may also be their last stand.
Hillary Clinton has awkwardly wound her way through numerous scandals in just this election cycle. But she’s never shown fear or desperation before. Now that has changed. Whatever she is afraid of
column2: it lies buried in her emails with Huma Abedin. And it can bring her down like nothing else has.  "	FAKE

column1: Watch The Exact Moment Paul Ryan Committed Political Suicide At A Trump Rally (VIDEO)	"Google Pinterest Digg Linkedin Reddit Stumbleupon Print Delicious Pocket Tumblr
There are two fundamental truths in this world: Paul Ryan desperately wants to be president. And Paul Ryan will never be president. Today proved it.
In a particularly staggering example of political cowardice
column2: Paul Ryan re-re-re-reversed course and announced that he was back on the Trump Train after all. This was an aboutface from where he was a few weeks ago. He had previously declared he would not be supporting or defending Trump after a tape was made public in which Trump bragged about assaulting women. Suddenly
column3: Ryan was appearing at a pro-Trump rally and boldly declaring that he already sent in his vote to make him President of the United States. It was a surreal moment. The figurehead of the Republican Party dosed himself in gasoline
column4: got up on a stage on a chilly afternoon in Wisconsin
column5: and lit a match. . @SpeakerRyan says he voted for @realDonaldTrump : “Republicans
column6: it is time to come home” https://t.co/VyTT49YvoE pic.twitter.com/wCvSCg4a5I

column1: — ABC News Politics (@ABCPolitics) November 5
The Democratic Party couldn’t have asked for a better moment of film. Ryan’s chances of ever becoming president went down to zero in an instant. In the wreckage Trump is to leave behind in his wake
column2: those who cravenly backed his campaign will not recover. If Ryan’s career manages to limp all the way to 2020
column3: then the DNC will have this tape locked and loaded to be used in every ad until Election Day.

column1: The ringing endorsement of the man he clearly hates on a personal level speaks volumes about his own spinelessness. Ryan has postured himself as a “principled” conservative
column2: and one uncomfortable with Trump’s unapologetic bigotry and sexism. However
column3: when push came to shove
column4: Paul Ryan – like many of his colleagues – turned into a sniveling appeaser. After all his lofty tak about conviction
column5: his principles were a house of cards and collapsed with the slightest breeze.

column1: What’s especially bizarre is how close Ryan came to making it through unscathed. For months the Speaker of the House refused to comment on Trump at all. His strategy seemed to be to keep his head down
column2: pretend Trump didn’t exist
column3: and hope that nobody remembered what happened in 2016. Now
column4: just days away from the election
column5: he screwed it all up.

column1: If 2016’s very ugly election has done any good it’s by exposing the utter cowardice of the Republicans who once feigned moral courage. A reality television star spit on them
column2: hijacked their party
column3: insulted their wives
column4: and got every last one of them to kneel before him. What a turn of events.

column1: Featured image via Twitter"	FAKE
Kerry to go to Paris in gesture of sympathy	"U.S. Secretary of State John F. Kerry said Monday that he will stop in Paris later this week
column2: amid criticism that no top American officials attended Sunday’s unity march against terrorism.

column1: Kerry said he expects to arrive in Paris Thursday evening
column2: as he heads home after a week abroad. He said he will fly to France at the conclusion of a series of meetings scheduled for Thursday in Sofia
column3: Bulgaria. He plans to meet the next day with Foreign Minister Laurent Fabius and President Francois Hollande
column4: then return to Washington.

column1: The visit by Kerry
column2: who has family and childhood ties to the country and speaks fluent French
column3: could address some of the criticism that the United States snubbed France in its darkest hour in many years.

column1: The French press on Monday was filled with questions about why neither President Obama nor Kerry attended Sunday’s march
column2: as about 40 leaders of other nations did. Obama was said to have stayed away because his own security needs can be taxing on a country
column3: and Kerry had prior commitments.

column1: Among roughly 40 leaders who did attend was Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu
column2: no stranger to intense security
column3: who marched beside Hollande through the city streets. The highest ranking U.S. officials attending the march were Jane Hartley
column4: the ambassador to France
column5: and Victoria Nuland
column6: the assistant secretary of state for European affairs. Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. was in Paris for meetings with law enforcement officials but did not participate in the march.

column1: Kerry spent Sunday at a business summit hosted by India’s prime minister
column2: Narendra Modi. The United States is eager for India to relax stringent laws that function as barriers to foreign investment and hopes Modi’s government will act to open the huge Indian market for more American businesses.

column1: In a news conference
column2: Kerry brushed aside criticism that the United States had not sent a more senior official to Paris as “quibbling a little bit.” He noted that many staffers of the American Embassy in Paris attended the march
column3: including the ambassador. He said he had wanted to be present at the march himself but could not because of his prior commitments in India.

column1: “But that is why I am going there on the way home
column2: to make it crystal clear how passionately we feel about the events that have taken place there
column3: ” he said.

column1: “And I don’t think the people of France have any doubts about America’s understanding of what happened
column2: of our personal sense of loss and our deep commitment to the people of France in this moment of trauma.”"	REAL

column1: While Bernie Sanders endorsed Hillary Clinton just before the Democratic National Convention in July
column2: many of his supporters remained adamant in their refusal to support the DNC-anointed candidate
column3: pointing to WikiLeaks’ revelations that top officials at the DNC had been working behind the scenes to tip the scales in Clinton’s favor by coordinating with media figures to circulate anti-Sanders narratives.

column1: Rather than attribute a potential Trump presidency to the GOP nominee’s perceived popularity among voters
column2: the closeness of this election could be credited to Hillary Clinton’s unfavorable ratings. According to RealClearPolitics
column3: anywhere between 51 and 57 percent of voters had a negative opinion of the Democratic nominee.

column1: The Battle of New York: Why This Primary Matters	"It's primary day in New York and front-runners Hillary Clinton and Donald Trump are leading in the polls.
Trump is now vowing to win enough delegates to clinch the Republican nomination and prevent a contested convention. But Sens.Ted Cruz
column2: R-Texas
column3: Bernie Sanders
column4: D-Vt.
column5: and Ohio Gov. John Kasich and aren't giving up just yet.

column1: A big win in New York could tip the scales for both the Republican and Democratic front-runners in this year's race for the White House. Clinton and Trump have each suffered losses in recent contests
column2: shifting the momentum to their rivals.

column1: We have won eight out of the last nine caucuses and primaries! Cheer!"" Sanders recently told supporters.
While wins in New York for Trump and Clinton are expected
column2: the margins of those victories are also important.

column1: Trump needs to capture more than 50 percent of the vote statewide if he wants to be positioned to win all of the state's 95 GOP delegates. That would put him one step closer to avoiding a contested convention.
We've got to vote and you know Cruz is way
column2: way down in the polls
column3: Trump urged supporters.

column1: Meanwhile
column2: Sanders is hoping for a close race in the Empire State. A loss by 10 points means he'll need to win 80 percent of the remaining delegates to clinch the nomination.

column1: Despite a predicted loss in New York
column2: Cruz hasn't lost momentum. He's hoping to sweep up more delegates this weekend while he's talking about how he can win in November.

column1: Because if I'm the nominee
column2: we win the General Election
column3: Cruz promised his supporters. ""We're beating Hillary in the key swing states
column4: we're beating Hillary with Independents
column5: we're beating Hillary with young people.""

column1: For now
column2: Cruz
column3: Kasich
column4: and Sanders have all moved on from New York to other states. Trump and Clinton are the only two staying in their home state to watch the results come in."	REAL

column1: Tehran, USA	"
I’m not an immigrant
column2: but my grandparents are. More than 50 years ago
column3: they arrived in New York City from Iran. I grew up mainly in central New Jersey
column4: an American kid playing little league for the Raritan Red Sox and soccer for the Raritan Rovers. In 1985
column5: I travelled with my family to our ancestral land. I was only eight
column6: but old enough to understand that the Iranians had lost their liberty and freedom. I saw the abject despair of a people who
column7: in a desperate attempt to bring about change
column8: had ushered in nationalist tyrants led by Ayatollah Khomeini.

column1: What I witnessed during that year in Iran changed the course of my life. In 1996
column2: at age 19
column3: wanting to help preserve the blessings of liberty and freedom we enjoy in America
column4: I enlisted in the U.S. Navy. Now
column5: with the rise of Donald Trump and his nationalist alt-right movement
column6: I’ve come to feel that the values I sought to protect are in jeopardy.

column1: In Iran
column2: theocratic fundmentalists sowed division and hatred of outsiders — of Westerners
column3: Christians
column4: and other religious minorities. Here in America
column5: the right wing seems to have stolen passages directly from their playbook as it spreads hatred of immigrants
column6: particularly Muslim ones. This form of nationalistic bigotry — Islamophobia — threatens the heart of our nation. When I chose to serve in the military
column7: I did so to protect what I viewed as our sacred foundational values of liberty
column8: equality
column9: and democracy. Now
column10: 20 years later
column11: I’ve joined forces with fellow veterans to again fight for those sacred values
column12: this time right here at home.

column1: “Death to America!”
As a child
column2: I sat in my class at the international school one sunny morning and heard in the distance the faint sounds of gunfire and rising chants of “Death to America!” That day would define the rest of my life.

column1: It was Tehran
column2: the capital of Iran
column3: in 1985. I was attending a unique school for bilingual students who had been born in Western nations. It had become the last refuge in that city with any tolerance for Western teaching
column4: but that also made it a target for military fundamentalists. As the gunfire drew closer
column5: I heard boots pounding the marble tiles outside
column6: marching into our building
column7: and thundering down the corridor toward my classroom. As I heard voices chanting “Death to America!” I remember wondering if I would survive to see my parents again.

column1: In a flash of green and black uniforms
column2: those soldiers rushed into our classroom
column3: grabbed us by our shirt collars
column4: and yelled at us to get outside. We were then packed into the school’s courtyard where a soldier pointed his rifle at our group and commanded us to look up. Almost in unison
column5: my classmates and I raised our eyes and saw the flags of our many nations being torn down and dangled from the balcony
column6: then set ablaze and tossed
column7: still burning
column8: into the courtyard. As those flags floated to the ground in flames
column9: the soldiers fired their guns in the air. Shouting
column10: they ordered us — if we ever wanted to see our families again — to swear allegiance to the Grand Ayatollah Khomeini and trample on the remains of the burning symbols of our home countries. I scanned the smoke that was filling the courtyard for my friends and classmates and
column11: horrified
column12: watched them capitulate and begin to chant
column13: “Death to America!” as they stomped on our sacred symbols.

column1: I was so angry that
column2: young as I was
column3: I began to plead with them to come to their senses. No one paid the slightest attention to an eight year old and yet
column4: for the first time in my life
column5: I felt something like righteous indignation. I suspect that
column6: born and raised in America
column7: I was already imbued with such a sense of privilege that I just couldn’t fathom the immense danger I was in. Certainly
column8: I was acting in ways no native Iranian would have found reasonable.

column1: Across the smoke-filled courtyard
column2: I saw a soldier coming at me and knew he meant to force me to submit. I spotted an American flag still burning
column3: dropped to my knees
column4: and grabbed the charred pieces from underneath a classmate’s feet. As the soldier closed in on me
column5: I ducked and ran
column6: still clutching my charred pieces of flag into a crowd of civilians who had gathered to witness the commotion. The events of that day would come to define all that I have ever stood for — or against.

column1: “Camel Jockey
column2: ” “Ayatollah
column3: ” and “Gandhi”

column1: My parents and I soon returned to the United States and I entered third grade. More than anything
column2: I just wanted to be normal
column3: to fit in and be accepted by my peers. Unfortunately
column4: my first name
column5: Nader (which I changed to Nate upon joining the Navy)
column6: and my swarthy Middle Eastern appearance
column7: were little help on that score
column8: eliciting regular jibes from my classmates. Even at that young age
column9: they had already mastered a veritable thesaurus of ethnic defamation
column10: including “camel jockey
column11: ” “sand-nigger
column12: ” “raghead
column13: ” “ayatollah
column14: ” and ironically
column15: “Gandhi” (which I now take as a compliment). My classmates regularly sought to “other-ize” me in those years
column16: as if I were a lesser American because of my faith and ethnicity.

column1: Yet I remember that tingling in my chest when I first donned my Cub Scout uniform — all because of the American flag patch on its shoulder. Something felt so good about wearing it
column2: a feeling I still had when I joined the military. It seems that the flag I tried to rescue in Tehran was stapled to my heart
column3: or that’s how I felt anyway as I wore my country’s uniform.

column1: When I took my oath of enlistment in the U.S. Navy
column2: I gave my mom a camera and asked her to take some photos
column3: but she was so overwhelmed with pride and joy that she cried throughout the ceremony and managed to snap only a few images of the carpet. She cried even harder when I was selected to serve as the first Muslim-American member of the U.S. Navy Presidential Ceremonial Honor Guard . On that day
column4: I was proud
column5: too
column6: and all the taunts of those bullies of my childhood seemed finally silenced.

column1: Being tormented because of my ethnicity and religion in those early years had another effect on me. It caused me to become unusually sensitive to the nature of other people. Somehow
column2: I grasped that
column3: if it weren’t for a fear of the unknown
column4: there was an inherent goodness and frail humanity lurking in many of the kids who bullied and harassed me. Often
column5: I discovered
column6: those same bullies could be tremendously kind to their families
column7: friends
column8: or even strangers. I realized
column9: then
column10: that if
column11: despite everything
column12: I could lay myself bare and trust them enough to reach out in kindness
column13: I might in turn gain their trust and they might then see me
column14: too
column15: and stop operating from such a place of fear and hate.

column1: Through patience
column2: humor
column3: and understanding
column4: I was able to offer myself as the embodiment of my people and somehow defang the “otherness” of so much that Americans found scary. To this day
column5: I have friends from elementary school
column6: middle school
column7: high school
column8: and the military who tell me that I am the only Muslim they have ever known and that
column9: had they not met me
column10: their perspective on Islam would have been wholly subject to the prevailing fear-based narrative that has poisoned this country since September 11

column2: I became special assistant to the Master Chief Petty Officer of the Navy and then
column4: I was recruited to serve at the Defense Intelligence Agency. In August 2000
column5: I transferred to the Naval Reserve.

column1: In the wake of 9/11
column2: I began to observe how so many of my fellow Americans were adopting a fundamentalist “us vs. them” attitude towards Muslims and Islam. I suddenly found myself in an America where the scattered insults I had endured as a child took on an overarching and sinister meaning and form
column3: where they became something like an ideology and way of life.

column1: By the time I completed my military service in 2006
column2: I had begun to understand that our policies in the Middle East
column3: similarly disturbed
column4: seemed in pursuit of little more than perpetual warfare. That
column5: in turn
column6: was made possible by the creation of a new enemy: Islam — or rather of a portrait
column7: painted by the powers-that-be
column8: of Islam as a terror religion
column9: as a hooded villain lurking out there somewhere in the desert
column10: waiting to destroy us. I knew that attempting to dispel
column11: through the patient approach of my childhood
column12: the kind of Islamophobia that now had the country by the throat was not going to be enough. Post-9/11 attacks on Muslims in the U.S. and elsewhere were not merely childish taunts.

column1: For the first time in my life
column2: in a country gripped by fear
column3: I believed I was witnessing a shift
column4: en masse
column5: toward an American fundamentalism and ultra-nationalism that reflected a wanton lack of reason
column6: not to mention fact. As a boy in Iran
column7: I had witnessed the dark destination down which such a path could take a country. Now
column8: it seemed to me
column9: in America’s quest to escape the very demons we had sown by our own misadventures in the Middle East
column10: and forsaking the hallmarks of our founding
column11: we risked becoming everything we sought to defeat.

column1: The Boy in the Schoolyard Grown Up
On February 10
column3: three young American students
column4: Yusor Abu-Salha
column5: Razan Abu-Salha
column6: and Deah Shaddy Barakat
column7: were executed at an apartment complex in Chapel Hill
column8: North Carolina. The killer was a gun-crazy white man filled with hate and described by his own daughter as “a monster.” Those assassinations struck a special chord of sorrow and loss in me. My mom and I cried and prayed together for those students and their families.

column1: The incident in Chapel Hill also awoke in me some version of the righteous indignation I had felt so many years earlier in that smoke-filled courtyard in Iran. I would be damned if I stood by while kids in my country were murdered simply because of their faith. It violated every word of the oath I had taken when I joined the military and desecrated every value I held in my heart as a sacred tenet of our nation. White nationalists and bigots had
column2: by then
column3: thrown down the gauntlet for so much of this
column4: using Islamophobia to trigger targeted assassinations in the United States. This was terrorism
column5: pure and simple
column6: inspired by hate-speakers here at home.

column1: At that moment
column2: I reached out to fellow veterans who
column3: I thought
column4: might be willing to help — and it’s true what they say about soul mates being irrevocably drawn to each other. When I contacted Veterans For Peace
column5: an organization dedicated to exposing the costs of war and militarism
column6: I found the leadership well aware of the inherent dangers of Islamophobia and of the need to confront this new enemy. So Executive Director Michael McPhearson formed a committee of vets from around the country to decide how those of us who had donned uniforms to defend this land could best battle the phenomenon — and I
column7: of course
column8: joined it.

column1: From that committee emerged Veterans Challenge Islamophobia (VCI). It now has organizers in Arizona
column2: Georgia
column3: New Jersey
column4: and Texas
column5: and that’s just a beginning. Totally nonpartisan
column6: VCI focuses on politicians of any party who engage in hate speech. We’ve met with leaders of American Muslim communities
column7: sat with them through Ramadan
column8: and attended their Iftar dinners to break our fasts together. In the wake of the Orlando shooting
column9: we at VCI also mobilized to fight back against attempts to pit the Muslim community against the LGBTQ+ community.

column1: Our group was born of the belief that
column2: as American military veterans
column3: we had a responsibility to call out bigotry
column4: hatred
column5: and the perpetuation of endless warfare. We want the American Muslim community to know that they have allies
column6: and that those allies are indeed veterans as well. We stand with them and for them and
column7: for those of us who are Muslim
column8: among them.

column1: Nationalism and xenophobia have no place in American life
column2: and I
column3: for my part
column4: don’t think Donald Trump or anyone like him should be able to peddle Islamophobia in an attempt to undermine our national unity. Without Islamophobia
column5: there no longer exists a “clash of civilizations.” Without Islamophobia
column6: whatever the problems in the world may be
column7: there is no longer an “us vs. them” and it’s possible to begin reimagining a world of something other than perpetual war.

column1: As of now
column2: this remains the struggle of my life
column3: for despite my intense love for America
column4: some of my countrymen increasingly see American Muslims as the “other
column5: ” the enemy.

column1: My Mom taught me as a boy that the only thing that mattered was what was in my heart. Now
column2: with her in mind and as a representative of VCI
column3: when I meet fellow Americans I always remember my childhood experiences with my bullying peers. And I still lay myself bare
column4: as I did then. I give trust to gain trust
column5: but always knowing that these days this isn’t just a matter of niceties. It’s a question of life or death. It’s part of a battle for the soul of our nation.

column1: In many ways
column2: I still consider myself that boy in the school courtyard in Tehran trying to rescue charred pieces of that flag from those trampling feet. It’s just that now I’m doing it in my own country.

column1: Nate Terani is a veteran of the U.S. Navy and served in military intelligence with the Defense Intelligence Agency. He is currently a member of the leadership team at Common Defense PAC and regional campaign organizer with Veterans Challenge Islamophobia . He is a featured columnist with the Arizona Muslim Voice newspaper. (Reprinted from TomDispatch by permission of author or representative)"	FAKE
Girl Horrified At What She Watches Boyfriend Do After He Left FaceTime On	"Share This Baylee Luciani (left)
column2: Screenshot of what Baylee caught on FaceTime (right)

column1: The closest Baylee Luciani could get to her boyfriend
column2: who’s attending college in Austin
column3: was through video online chat. The couple had regular “dates” this way to bridge the 200-mile distance between them. However
column4: the endearing arrangement quickly came to an end after his FaceTime was left on and caught something that left his girlfriend horrified.

column1: Baylee had been discussing regular things with her boyfriend
column2: Yale Gerstein
column3: who was on the other side of the screen on an otherwise average evening. This video chat was not unlike all the others she had with Yale from his apartment near Austin Community College until the 19-year-old girlfriend heard some scratching sounds after FaceTime had been left on.

column1: According to KRON
column2: Baylee was mid-conversation with Yale when scratches at the door caught both of their attention and he got up from his bed
column3: where the computer was
column4: to see who was at his door. He barely turned the handle to open in when masked men entered the room and beat Yale’s face in and slammed him down on his bed while shoving a pistol in his cheek. The intruders didn’t seem to know or care that FaceTime was still on and Baylee’s face
column5: seen in the corner
column6: was watching everything
column7: terrified that she was about to see her boyfriend murdered in front of her
column8: as she watched him fight for his life.

column1: Admitting that she first thought it was a joke
column2: seconds later
column3: she came to the horrid realization that he was being robbed and called her dad
column4: who was at home with her in Dallas
column5: into the room. “I was scared
column6: because they were saying I’m going to blow your head off
column7: I’m going to kill you
column8: ” Baylee explained along with the chilling feeling she got when the intruder finally realized the video chat was running and looked right at her in the camera. “I’m like wow… seriously watching an armed robbery happen to somebody that I care about
column9: ” she added. Screengrabs of intruder forcing Yale down on his bed while Baylee and her father watch on FaceTime in horror

column1: With a clear view of at least one intruder’s face
column2: Baylee began taking screenshots of the suspect in the act as she and her dad called the police to report what was going on. She got the pictures right in time since
column3: seconds later
column4: the intruder decided to disconnect the computer as he and the suspects took off with thousands of dollars worth of Yale’s music equipment. Although the boyfriend’s life was spared in the traumatizing ordeal for the two of them
column5: he said that the thieves took something from him that can’t be replaced.

column1: “I had just finished my first album as a solo artist
column2: ” Yale said. “That’s all lost
column3: ” since they took the recordings on the equipment
column4: which means nothing to the thieves and everything to the victim. It’s not often that you hear of FaceTime solving crimes or potentially saving lives
column5: which is what happened in this case. Although it was difficult to watch
column6: Baylee
column7: being there through technology
column8: was an instrumental part in protecting Yale
column9: who hopefully learned that he better take advantage of Texas’ great gun laws and arm himself with more than just a computer."	FAKE

column1: ‘Britain’s Schindler’ Dies at 106	"A Czech stockbroker who saved more than 650 Jewish children from Nazi Germany has died at the age of 106. Dubbed “Britain’s Schindler
column2: ” Nicholas Winton arranged to transport Jewish youngsters from Prague after Germany annexed Czechoslovakia in March 1939. Though the children were originally set to arrive in Britain by plane
column3: the German invasion forced Winton to transport them by train through Germany before they eventually reached England by boat. Winton arranged eight trains
column4: known as the Kindertransports (children’s transports)
column5: to evacuate the children
column6: and died on the anniversary of the 1939 departure of the one carrying the largest number of children: 241. Winton was knighted by Queen Elizabeth II in 2003 for his efforts
column7: despite keeping it secret for nearly 50 years."	REAL

column1: Fact check: Trump and Clinton at the 'commander-in-chief' forum	"Hillary Clinton and Donald Trump made some inaccurate claims during an NBC “commander-in-chief” forum on military and veterans issues:
• Clinton wrongly claimed Trump supported the war in Iraq after it started
column2: while Trump was wrong
column3: once again
column4: in saying he was against the war before it started.

column1: • Trump said that President Obama set a “certain date” for withdrawing troops from Iraq
column2: when that date was set before Obama was sworn in.

column1: • Trump said that Obama’s visits to China
column2: Saudi Arabia and Cuba were “the first time in the history
column3: the storied history of Air Force One” when “high officials” of a host country did not appear to greet the president. Not true.

column1: • Clinton said that Trump supports privatizing the Veterans Health Administration. That’s false. Trump said he supports allowing veterans to seek care at either public or private hospitals.
• Trump said Clinton made “a terrible mistake on Libya” when she was secretary of State. But
column2: at the time
column3: Trump also supported U.S. action that led to the removal of Moammar Gadhafi from power.

column1: • Trump cherry-picked Clinton’s words when he claimed Clinton said “vets are being treated
column2: essentially
column3: just fine.” Clinton had said the problems in the Department of Veterans Affairs were not as “widespread” as some Republicans claimed
column4: but she went on to acknowledge problems
column5: including the issue of wait times for doctors.

column1: The forum
column2: sponsored by NBC News and the Iraq and Afghanistan Veterans of America
column3: was held Sept. 7 at the Intrepid Sea
column4: Air & Space Museum in New York City. Today show host Matt Lauer
column5: and members of the military and veterans in the audience
column6: questioned the candidates separately.

column1: Trump said he “was totally against the war in Iraq
column2: ” while Clinton claimed that he supported the Iraq War before and after it started. The facts don’t support either candidate’s strong assertions.

column1: Our review of Trump’s statements before and after the Iraq War started found no evidence that Trump opposed the war before it started. In fact
column2: he expressed mild support for invading Iraq when asked about it on the Howard Stern radio show on Sept. 11
column3: 2002 — about six months before the war started.

column1: Stern asked Trump if he supported a war with Iraq
column2: and Trump responded
column3: “Yeah
column4: I guess so.”

column1: In the NBC commander in chief forum
column2: Trump cited an Esquire article that appeared in August 2004 to show his opposition to the war. But that article appeared 17 months after the war started.

column1: As for Clinton
column2: who as a senator voted in October 2002 to authorize the war in Iraq
column3: the Democratic nominee claimed that Trump “supported it before it happened
column4: he supported it as it was happening and he is on record as supporting it after it happened.”

column1: But just as there is no evidence that Trump opposed the Iraq War before it started
column2: the Clinton campaign offered no evidence that Trump supported the war “after it happened.”

column1: The Clinton campaign cited Trump’s interview on March 21
column3: with Neil Cavuto of Fox Business just two days after the war started.

column1: Cavuto asked Trump about the impact of the war on the stock market. Trump said the war “looks like a tremendous success from a military standpoint
column2: ” and he predicted the market will “go up like a rocket” after the war. But Cavuto does not ask Trump whether the U.S. should have gone to war with Iraq or whether he supports the war
column3: and Trump doesn’t offer an opinion.

column1: As early as July 2003
column2: Trump expressed concern on Hardball with Chris Matthews about money being spent in Iraq rather than in the U.S. Two months later
column3: Trump told MSNBC’s Joe Scarborough
column4: “I guess maybe if I had to do it
column5: I would have fought terrorism but not necessarily Iraq.”

column1: Clinton invited her audience to read Trump’s comments on the Iraq War. They can read our timeline
column2: “Donald Trump and the Iraq War.”

column1: Trump said President Obama set a “certain date” for withdrawing troops from Iraq
column2: but that date was actually set by President George W. Bush.

column1: NBC’s Matt Lauer asked Trump about his tendency to respond
column2: when pushed for details on his military proposals
column3: that he’s not going to give details because he wants to be “unpredictable.” Trump responded
column4: “Absolutely
column5: ” and went on to criticize Obama for revealing the withdrawal date.

column1: As we said then
column2: Republicans and Democrats disagree on whether Obama or Bush is to blame for withdrawing all combat troops from Iraq at the end of 2011. But that date was set when Bush signed the Status of Forces Agreement on Dec. 14
column3: 2008. It said: “All the United States Forces shall withdraw from all Iraqi territory no later than December 31

column1: In the NBC forum
column2: Trump also called the withdrawal of troops “a terrible decision.” As we’ve explained before
column3: Condoleezza Rice
column4: Bush’s secretary of State
column5: later wrote that Bush wanted an agreement for a residual force to remain
column6: but Iraqi Prime Minister Nouri al-Maliki objected.

column1: Once Obama took office in January 2009
column2: he had three years to renegotiate the deal
column3: which his administration tried to do
column4: to leave a residual American troop force. But Maliki still didn’t agree. Negotiations broke down in October 2011 over the issue of whether U.S. troops would be shielded from criminal prosecution by Iraqi authorities. Whether Obama did enough is a matter of opinion: His then defense secretary
column5: Leon Panetta
column6: later wrote that the president didn’t press hard enough for a deal. But some experts say Iraq was more closely aligned at the time with Iran and there wasn’t a deal to be made with Maliki.

column1: So
column2: both presidents had a role in the withdrawal of troops. But Trump wrongly said that Obama was the one who set a “certain date” for withdrawal and let U.S. enemies know about it
column3: when that date was set before Obama was sworn in.

column1: It’s worth noting that Trump said in a March 16
column3: interview on CNN that the troops should be withdrawn quickly from Iraq.

column1: Trump said that Obama’s visits to China
column2: Saudi Arabia and Cuba were “the first time in the history
column3: the storied history of Air Force One” when “high officials” of a host country did not appear to greet the president.

column1: That’s not true. Other presidents have encountered similar low-key greetings on foreign trips aboard the presidential aircraft.
Trump referred to the fact that Cuba’s president
column2: Raul Castro
column3: did not greet Obama at the airport on his historic visit to Cuba in March
column4: that Saudi Arabia’s King Salman did not meet Air Force One at the start of Obama’s trip to Riyadh in April
column5: and he referred to China’s handling of the president’s arrival in Hangzhou last Saturday for a Group of 20 meeting.

column1: Whether or not those arrivals constituted snubs of a U.S. president as Trump claims is a matter of debate. But Trump is wrong on the facts when he claims it has not happened before. It has.

column2: for example
column3: Ronald Reagan landed in Beijing and was received by China’s foreign minister rather than the president
column4: whom he met only later. Similarly
column5: on a 1985 trip to West Germany
column6: Reagan was met by the foreign minister and not Chancellor Helmut Kohl.

column1: These and other examples were dug up by our friend Glenn Kessler
column2: the Washington Post‘s “Fact Checker
column3: ” who researched a Trump claim in April that Cuba’s and Saudi Arabia’s handling of Obama’s visits were “without precedent.” Kessler said of Trump
column4: “once again he’s wrong
column5: wrong
column6: wrong.”

column1: Kessler also noted that during Richard Nixon’s historic 1972 visit to China he was greeted at the airport by the country’s number two man
column2: Premier Zhou Enlai. His boss
column3: Chairman Mao
column4: didn’t even agree to meet with Nixon until after he had arrived at a guest house.

column1: Clinton said that her plan to overhaul the Veterans Health Administration would not include privatization
column2: which she said Trump supports.

column1: But Trump refuted that statement when it was his turn to discuss his plan to help veterans. “I would not do that
column2: ” Trump said
column3: referring to Clinton’s claim that he supports privatization.

column1: Trump’s campaign published “The Goals Of Donald J. Trump’s Veterans Plan” on its website last October. It doesn’t call for the VA to be completely privatized.
One of the biggest changes that plan would make to the current VA health care system is allowing veterans to get care at any non-VA medical center that accepts Medicare.
“Under a Trump Administration
column2: all veterans eligible for VA health care can bring their veteran’s ID card to any doctor or care facility that accepts Medicare to get the care they need immediately
column3: ” the plan states.

column1: “The power to choose will stop the wait time backlogs and force the VA to improve and compete if the department wants to keep receiving veterans’ healthcare dollars
column2: ” the plan says.

column1: Trump’s proposal would seemingly go further than the Non-VA Medical Care Program
column2: which allows eligible veterans to access care outside of the VA under certain circumstances
column3: such as when VA medical centers cannot provide services. The program requires pre-approval for veterans to receive care at a non-VA facility in non-emergency situations.

column1: Trump’s proposal would also go further than the bipartisan Veterans Choice Act of 2014 that President Obama signed into law
column2: creating a temporary program
column3: separate from the Non-VA Medical Care Program
column4: that allows eligible veterans to receive health care at a non-VA facility if they would have to wait more than 30 days for an appointment at a VA medical center
column5: or if they live more than 40 miles from the nearest VA hospital.

column1: Trump stuck to the idea of allowing veterans to choose between public and private hospitals when he released his most recent “Ten Point Plan To Reform The VA” in July.
Point 10 of the plan says: “Mr. Trump will ensure every veteran has the choice to seek care at the VA or at a private service provider of their own choice. Under a Trump Administration
column2: no veteran will die waiting for service.”

column1: Trump reinforced that part of his plan during the NBC News forum as well.
To be clear
column2: Trump supports giving veterans a choice between VA hospitals and private ones. That’s not the same thing as supporting the complete privatization of the system that provides care to veterans.

column1: Trump criticized Clinton for making “a terrible mistake on Libya” when she was secretary of State. But
column2: at the time
column3: Trump also supported U.S. action that led to the removal of Moammar Gadhafi from power.

column1: Trump made his claim in response to a question posed by Lauer on whether Trump will be “prepared on Day One
column2: ” if elected president
column3: to tackle “complex national security issues.”

column1: This isn’t the first time Trump has ignored his past support for the U.S. intervention in Libya.
During the 10th GOP debate
column2: Trump said he had “never discussed that subject” when Sen. Ted Cruz called him out on supporting U.S. action in the country. But
column3: as we wrote
column4: Trump said in 2011 that the U.S. should go into Libya “on a humanitarian basis” and “knock [Gadhafi] out very quickly
column5: very surgically
column6: very effectively and save the lives.”

column1: Trump made that comment in a video posted to his YouTube channel in February 2011:
Even though Trump now says Clinton’s support for intervention in Libya was a “terrible mistake
column2: ” it doesn’t change the fact that five years ago he supported Gadhafi’s removal.

column1: Trump twisted Clinton’s words when he claimed Clinton said “vets are being treated
column2: essentially
column3: just fine.” Clinton said the problems in the Department of Veterans Affairs were not as “widespread” as some Republican supporters of privatization of the VA claim
column4: but she went on to acknowledge problems in the VA system — including the issue of wait times for doctors — and what she would do to address them.

column1: Trump highlighted the issue of wait times to see a doctor as “one of the big problems” in the VA
column2: and then suggested Clinton doesn’t think the VA has problems.

column1: Lauer interrupted
column2: noting that Clinton “went on after that and laid out a litany of problems within the VA.”

column1: Trump insisted his version was accurate
column2: adding
column3: “I’m telling you … she said she was satisfied with what was going on in the Veterans Administration.”

column1: That’s not accurate. The comments in question from Clinton came during an interview with MSNBC’s Rachel Maddow on Oct. 23
column2: 2015. Maddow asked about talk among some Republicans of abolishing the VA and privatizing it. “The reason they are able to propose something that radical is because the problems at the VA seem so intractable
column3: ” Maddow said.

column1: Maddow asked if Clinton had any “new ideas for trying to fix” the VA. Here was Clinton’s response
column2: with the part Trump is referring to in bold.

column1: Clinton accused Republicans of underfunding the VA because they “want it to fail” so they can privatize it.
Clinton added
column2: “But we have to be more creative about trying to fix the problems that are the legitimate concern
column3: so that we can try to stymie the Republican assault.”

column1: Indeed
column2: the Clinton campaign website states that Clinton wants to “fundamentally reform veterans’ health care to ensure access to timely and high quality care.” The campaign says Clinton “was outraged by the recent scandals at the VA
column3: and as president
column4: she will demand accountability and performance from VA leadership.” The site specifically mentions Clinton’s dissatisfaction that “[m]any veterans have to wait an unacceptably long time to see a doctor or to process disability claims and appeals” and promises she will “[b]uild a 21st-century Department of Veterans Affairs to deliver world-class care.”

column1: Trump cherry-picked the part of Clinton’s response that said problems in the VA have “not been as widespread as it has been made out to be
column2: ” to make the blanket claim that Clinton is “satisfied with what was going on in the Veterans Administration” and that “vets are being treated
column3: essentially
column4: just fine.” But Trump is leaving out the parts of Clinton’s answer that acknowledged problems in the VA — including the wait time issue Trump highlighted as one of his biggest concerns."	REAL

column1: Iran reportedly makes new push for uranium concessions in nuclear talks	"Iranian negotiators reportedly have made a last-ditch push for more concessions from the U.S. and five other world powers as talks on the fate of Iran's nuclear program come down to the final days before a crucial deadline.
The New York Times reported late Sunday that Tehran had backed away from a tentative promise to ship a large portion of its uranium stockpile to Russia
column2: where it could not be used as part of any future weapons program. Western officials insisted to the paper that the uranium did not have to be sent overseas
column3: but could be disposed of in other ways.

column1: The new twist in the talks comes just two days before the deadline for both sides to agree on a framework for a permanent deal. The final deadline for a permanent deal would not arrive until the end of June.
However
column2: if Iran insists on keeping its uranium in the country
column3: it would undermine a key argument made in favor of the deal by the Obama administration. The Times reports that if the uranium had gone to Russia
column4: it would have been converted into fuel rods
column5: which are difficult to use in nuclear weapons. It is not clear what would happen to the uranium if it remained in Iran.

column1: The Associated Press reported Sunday that Iran's position had shifted from from demanding that it be allowed to keep nearly 10
column2: 000 centrifuges enriching uranium
column3: to agreeing to keep 6
column4: 000. Western officials involved in the talks told the Associated Press that Tehran may be ready to accept an even lower number.

column1: The United States and its allies want a deal that extends the time Iran would need to make a nuclear weapon from the present two months to three months to at least a year. However
column2: The Times reported Sunday that a paper published by Olli Heinonen
column3: former head of inspections for the U.N.'s nuclear watchdog
column4: estimated that Iran could still develop a nuclear weapon in seven or eight months with around 6
column5: 500 centrifuges.

column1: Tehran says it wants to enrich uranium only for energy
column2: science
column3: industry and medicine. But many countries fear Iran could use the technology to make weapons-grade uranium.

column1: Officials told the Associated Press that another main dispute involved the length of an agreement. Iran
column2: they said
column3: wants a total lifting of all caps on its activities after 10 years
column4: while the U.S. and the five other nations at the talks — Russia
column5: China
column6: Britain
column7: France and Germany — insist on progressive removal after a decade.

column1: A senior U.S. official characterized the issue as lack of agreement on what happens in years 11 to 15. The official spoke on condition of anonymity in line with State Department rules on briefing about the closed-door talks.
Limits on Iran's research and development of centrifuges also were unresolved
column2: the Western officials said.

column1: Tehran has created a prototype centrifuge that it says enriches uranium 16 times faster than its present mainstay model. The U.S. and its partners want to constrain research that would increase greatly the speed of making enough weapons-grade uranium for a bomb
column2: once limits on Iran's programs are lifted.

column1: One official said Russia opposed the U.S. position that any U.N. penalties lifted in the course of a deal should be reimposed quickly if Tehran reneged on any commitments.
Both Western officials said Iran was resisting attempts to make inspections and other ways of verification as intrusive as possible.
There was tentative agreement on turning a nearly-finished reactor into a model that gives off less plutonium waste than originally envisaged. Plutonium
column2: like enriched uranium
column3: is a path to nuclear weapons.

column1: Iran and the U.S. were discussing letting Iran run centrifuges at an underground bunker that has been used to enrich uranium. The machines would produce isotopes for peaceful applications
column2: the officials said.

column1: With the Tuesday deadline approaching and problems remaining
column2: U.S. Secretary of State John Kerry canceled plans Sunday to return to the United States for an event honoring the late U.S. Sen. Edward Kennedy. French Foreign Minister Laurent Fabius and Frank-Walter Steinmeier
column3: his German counterpart
column4: scratched planned trips to Kazakhstan.

column1: Kerry has been in discussions with Iranian Foreign Minister Mohammad Javad Zarif since Thursday.
The Associated Press contributed to this report.
Click for more from The New York Times."	REAL

column1: Donald Trump’s Shockingly Weak Delegate Game Somehow Got Even Worse	"Donald Trump’s organizational problems have gone from bad to worse to flat-out embarrassing. Here’s Politico with the play-by-play from this weekend’s Colorado GOP convention
column2: the latest scene of Trump’s delegate-securing failure:

column1: Unlike in most other states
column2: Republicans in Colorado scrapped plans for a more traditional primary or caucus to award its delegates to this summer’s national convention in Cleveland. Instead
column3: the state GOP selected three delegates from each of the state’s seven congressional districts at individual contests in the days leading up to the state convention
column4: and then the remaining 13 delegates at the statewide event this past weekend. It was a rather convoluted process that favored campaigns that understood the rules and that had the ground game necessary to take advantage of them—or
column5: put another way
column6: not the Trump campaign.

column1: At the first two district-level contests
column2: the billionaire’s team showed up without an approved list of delegates to pass out to attendees
column3: leaving supporters unsure of whom to back. And then at last Thursday’s contest
column4: two of the three delegates on the Trump campaign’s list weren’t actually on the official ballot since they failed to pay the necessary registration fees.

column1: This past weekend’s mix-up
column2: though
column3: was an even bigger embarrassment since at least one of the seven misnumbered names on the Trump-sanctioned list lined up with a Cruz-supporting delegate
column4: according to NBC News. (Even without that mix-up
column5: though
column6: Cruz would have likely swept the contest anyway given his well-oiled delegate-selecting machine.) The Trump camp
column7: though
column8: appeared to blame the state GOP for the mistake
column9: pointing to discrepancies between the delegate guides posted on the party's website and the printed materials distributed at the event. “We'll do whatever it takes to protect the legitimacy of our support in Colorado
column10: ” Trump aide Alan Cobb told NBC
column11: suggesting the campaign may challenge the results. “Clearly there are some serious issues with the ballot and balloting.”

column1: Trump remains the favorite to arrive at the convention with the most delegates to his name
column2: but he’s far from assured of the majority of delegates he’d need to win the nomination on the first ballot. Given that reality
column3: the GOP front-runner recently retooled his campaign to address his clear weaknesses in the under-the-radar battle to send loyal delegates to the convention. If those efforts don't start paying dividends soon
column4: though
column5: Trump very well may arrive in Cleveland with the most delegates—and leave without the nomination."	REAL
