column1: How women lead differently	"As more women move into high offices
column2: they often bring a style and approach that is distinct from men. But do they make better leaders?

column1: Democratic women of the US Senate stand on stage during the final night of the Democratic National Convention in Philadelphia (top). There are 20 women in the Senate – 14 Democrats and six Republicans.
Kelly Ayotte and Joni Ernst take the floor
column2: two dynamic young US senators before a town hall of older military veterans. Between them
column3: they represent a raft of firsts: Senator Ayotte is New Hampshire’s first female attorney general and first female Republican senator. Senator Ernst is Iowa’s first woman ever elected to either house of Congress and the first female military veteran to serve in the Senate.

column1: The gender dimension does not go unnoticed. Please welcome “our beautiful senators
column2: ” says the veteran who introduces them. Ayotte mentions Ernst’s military service – she’s also a war veteran. But in most ways
column3: the woman thing doesn’t matter. This is just like any other political town hall in campaign season – one senator trying to help another who’s locked in a tight reelection race.

column1: Yet the stakes are high. Republican control of the US Senate could hinge on Ayotte’s ability to fend off her Democratic challenger
column2: Gov. Maggie Hassan. And across the country
column3: women figure prominently in the Democrats’ strategy to retake the Senate
column4: nominating women in six of the 11 competitive races.

column1: Then there’s Hillary Clinton
column2: the first woman to win a major party’s presidential nomination in the United States.

column1: It’s enough to call 2016 Year of the Woman 2.0
column2: following the original
column4: when female representation in the Senate jumped from two to six. Today
column5: female senators number 20 out of 100
column6: with potential to reach 24
column7: depending on how the political winds are blowing by Election Day.

column1: Gender diversity among major world powers is also rising
column2: with the ascension of Theresa May to the British prime ministership. If Mrs. Clinton wins in November
column3: three of the world’s top five economies will be headed by women. (German Chancellor Angela Merkel is the other.)

column1: But the numbers and the “firsts” invite a deeper question: Do women really lead differently? From the halls of government to corporate boardrooms
column2: it’s a burning question.

column1: “I think we’re good listeners
column2: and I think that helps
column3: ” says Ayotte in an interview. “I don’t want to say my male colleagues aren’t
column4: because plenty of them are. But I think that we listen
column5: and so we’re picking up on where we see the common ground with other people.”

column1: On that point
column2: there is bipartisan agreement.

column1: “There is good research that shows women tend to have different leadership styles
column2: ” Democratic Sen. Jeanne Shaheen
column3: New Hampshire’s other senator
column4: says in an interview. “We tend to be more inclusive
column5: we’re less autocratic in our decisionmaking. We like consensus
column6: we like to get people around the table
column7: and so I think that has made a difference.”

column1: Of course
column2: there’s also the example of Rep. Nancy Pelosi (D) of California
column3: the first woman speaker of the House (2007-11). During her tenure
column4: she was known for her ability to wield power – and in a highly partisan way. More than with previous speakers
column5: major legislation came out of her office
column6: not the committees. She was (and is) a master fundraiser for Democrats writ large
column7: a skill she has used to great effect in keeping her members in line.

column1: And as a Roman Catholic woman
column2: Congresswoman Pelosi demonstrated at a crucial moment the power of networking. In 2010
column3: when House passage of the Affordable Care Act appeared in doubt over the abortion issue
column4: she tapped connections her male colleagues had never heard of – two associations of nuns
column5: whose support for the bill proved pivotal.

column1: The research on women’s leadership style has been extensive – and mixed. One academic study
column2: released in 2013
column3: found that women are more attracted to cooperation than men. The reason is that men tend to have greater confidence in their abilities
column4: while women tend to be more optimistic about their prospective teammates’ abilities
column5: according to the study by Peter Kuhn and Marie-Claire Villeval.

column1: New research
column2: released in August
column3: looked specifically at gender differences in the US House of Representatives and found “little evidence to suggest women are inherently more cooperative or bipartisan.” The only difference came with Republican women
column4: who tend to recruit more cosponsors on legislation
column5: including more from the opposite party. That tendency was most pronounced on so-called women’s issues
column6: such as education and social welfare.

column1: “We interpret these results as evidence that cooperation is mostly driven by a commonality of interest
column2: rather than gender per se
column3: ” write the authors
column4: Stefano Gagliarducci and M. Daniele Paserman.

column1: The study examined 20 years of data ending in 2008. Since then
column2: female representation in Congress has ticked up a notch
column3: reaching 20 percent in the Senate and nearly that in the House – the rough threshold for a perceived “critical mass” of representation in which women can show perceptible influence.

column1: Indeed
column2: since 2013
column3: female legislators point to multiple examples of how the women of the Senate
column4: in particular
column5: have been instrumental in breaking through congressional gridlock. The best-known example is the end of the 2013 government shutdown
column6: when women senators from both parties met privately over dinner and fashioned a compromise that would form the nucleus of the final deal.

column1: More recently
column2: the women of the Senate – all 20 of them
column3: dubbed “the sisterhood” – backed landmark legislation aimed at combating sex trafficking
column4: which President Obama signed into law in May 2015.

column1: When asked for other examples
column2: Senator Shaheen cites the 2013 reauthorization of the Violence Against Women Act. “It was considered dead
column3: ” she says
column4: “and because all the women [senators] got on board and pushed it
column5: we were able to get it through.”

column1: Shaheen also notes the growing number of women who serve in top spots on committees
column2: such as the Senate Energy and Natural Resources Committee
column3: with Sen. Lisa Murkowski (R) of Alaska as chair and Sen. Maria Cantwell (D) of Washington as the ranking member. “It looks like we may get an energy bill done this year
column4: and I think that speaks to their ability to work together
column5: and to be flexible
column6: and move our colleagues in the House
column7: ” Shaheen says.

column1: Behind all this female power are the women senators’ regular dinners
column2: a chance to kick back and talk about whatever – their lives
column3: their work
column4: their male colleagues.

column1: “We go by Mikulski’s rules – that what happens in those dinners stays in those dinners
column2: ” says Shaheen
column3: referring to Sen. Barbara Mikulski (D) of Maryland
column4: the longest-serving woman in congressional history
column5: who is about to retire. “But yeah
column6: they’ve proved to be a great opportunity to build relationships.”

column1: As it happens
column2: Shaheen had hosted 12 of her female colleagues the night before at her office. On the menu: lobsters and clam chowder. That much she will reveal. Sen. Susan Collins (R) of Maine was there
column3: Shaheen says
column4: “and we had a back and forth about whether the lobsters came from Maine or New Hampshire.”

column2: after the Senate’s 20 women helped end the government shutdown
column3: Sen. John McCain (R) of Arizona wondered out loud: “Imagine what they could do if there were 50 of them.”

column1: That may sound logical
column2: but the reality isn’t so simple. While women do bring a distinctive perspective to policy
column3: based on their life experiences
column4: that doesn’t necessarily make them less partisan
column5: experts say. Some of the most polarizing issues are so-called women’s issues
column6: including health care
column7: abortion
column8: and equal pay.

column1: “As long as women’s issues constitute a prominent division between the parties
column2: there will be little bipartisan collaboration among women on these policies
column3: ” Michele Swers
column4: a political scientist at Georgetown University
column5: wrote in The Washington Post in 2014.

column1: Ms. Swers also notes that partisan sorting has made the South – a region less hospitable to women candidates – the stronghold of the Republican Party
column2: while the more moderate brand of Republicanism that predominates in parts of the country more willing to elect women has declined.

column1: And because women tend to occupy the “leftward wing” of their respective parties
column2: Democratic women in particular are less inclined to compromise
column3: the Gagliarducci-Paserman study found.

column1: Still
column2: none of this means women shouldn’t be more rigorously recruited for public office
column3: say leaders of both parties.

column1: “What you need is more good people
column2: and the process of excluding women has excluded good people from service
column3: ” says former Gov. John Sununu (R) of New Hampshire. “So what you need to do is level the playing field.”

column1: In the business world
column2: boosting female representation on corporate boards – now near 20 percent – has been a long-held goal. Advocates cite benefits to the bottom line. In a famous study
column3: Catalyst Inc.
column4: a nonprofit that promotes women leaders in the workplace
column5: found that corporate boards with the highest female representation attained “significantly higher financial performance” than those with the lowest representation.

column1: But whether in the private sector or in government
column2: women as top executives are even rarer than women legislators. Only six of the nation’s 50 governors are women
column3: three Republicans and three Democrats. Among world leaders
column4: fewer than two dozen are female. Among Fortune 500 companies
column5: only 21 chief executive officers – or 4.2 percent – are women.

column1: While legislating is an inherently collaborative process
column2: and therefore seems to play to women’s strength
column3: executive roles hew more toward public expectations of how men should behave
column4: i.e.
column5: authoritatively.

column1: “I think the more people see women in executive positions
column2: the more they will see that as a normal course of business
column3: and it’s taken longer for that not just in politics but in the boardroom
column4: ” says Shaheen.

column1: But that becomes a Catch-22: Women don’t step up because they don’t see other women in those positions. “Some would call it a confidence gap
column2: ” says Liz Shuler
column3: the No. 2 leader at the AFL-CIO. “We need to do more to increase the leadership skills-building opportunities
column4: so that it becomes second nature for women to step up.” (See interview with Ms. Shuler here.)

column1: But do women executives really lead differently from men? Clinton echoes other women leaders on this point: “I just think women in general are better listeners
column2: are more collegial
column3: more open to new ideas and how to make things work in a way that looks for a win-win outcome
column4: ” she told Time magazine in January.

column1: Meta-analyses have found that women leaders
column2: on average
column3: are “more likely to be democratic
column4: collaborative
column5: and participative” than their male counterparts
column6: who are more likely to be “autocratic and directive” in their approach
column7: writes Alice H. Eagly at TheConversation.com.

column1: Of course
column2: there are exceptions. Margaret Thatcher of Britain and Golda Meir of Israel were both known for being tough and assertive. Today
column3: Apple CEO Tim Cook is known for his team-oriented style. But for women aspiring to leadership posts
column4: the challenge is to overcome societal expectations for how women are “supposed to” act – i.e.
column5: nice and nonconfrontational – while still projecting authority. Clinton has faced this “double bind” in both of her presidential campaigns.

column1: New Hampshire has a strong record of female leadership. The governor
column2: both US senators
column3: and one of the state’s two House members are women. The chief justice of the state Supreme Court is a woman. The chair of the state GOP is a woman.

column2: Granite Staters made history by electing the nation’s first majority-female state legislative body
column3: in the state Senate. In 2013
column4: the state made history again by sending an all-female congressional delegation to Washington. That could happen again in January.

column1: What is it about New Hampshire that breeds women leaders? Start with a culture of independent-mindedness
column2: and an enormous “citizens legislature” – 400 in the House
column3: 24 in the Senate – in a state with only 1.3 million people. Members are paid just $100 a year
column4: plus mileage. Sooner or later
column5: the joke goes
column6: everybody ends up serving.

column1: “We have so much local self-governance
column2: women have the opportunity to try things out
column3: to see how they like public service
column4: and then they discover that they like it and that they’re good at it
column5: and one thing leads to the next
column6: ” says Governor Hassan in an interview in the State House.

column1: Hassan got her start advocating for her disabled son
column2: which caught the notice of then-Governor Shaheen
column3: who appointed her to a state educational funding commission. That led to regular interactions with state legislators – and an introduction to her next mentor
column4: state Sen. Sylvia Larsen
column5: who encouraged Hassan to run for state Senate. She spent six years there
column6: eventually rising to majority leader
column7: losing reelection
column8: then staging a comeback by winning the governorship.

column1: The common denominator for most women in politics
column2: it seems
column3: is mentors. Ask Ayotte
column4: New Hampshire’s junior senator
column5: about Ruth Griffin
column6: and her eyes light up. “I love Ruth Griffin. She’s my mentor!” Ayotte gushes
column7: referring to the nonagenarian grand dame of the New Hampshire Republican Party. (See interview with Mrs. Griffin here.)

column1: When Griffin served on the state Executive Council – an elected board that serves as a check on the governor – she advocated strongly for Ayotte
column2: insisting the Democratic governor reappoint the Republican Ayotte as attorney general.

column1: Shaheen
column2: now a mentor to others
column3: cites as her inspiration Marilla Ricker
column4: the first woman to run for governor of New Hampshire – before women even had the right to vote. Shaheen also speaks fondly of the late Susan McLane
column5: a Republican state senator “who was always very good to me.” (Ms. McLane’s daughter is Rep. Ann McLane Kuster (D) of New Hampshire.) Shaheen broke two gender barriers in N.H.
column6: first with her election as governor (1996)
column7: then as a US senator (2008).

column1: Men
column2: too
column3: have championed women politicians here. At a recent Republican women’s chili fest in Stratham
column4: N.H.
column5: Mr. Sununu recalls fighting to make Vesta Roy the first woman state Senate president
column6: in 1983. “There’s that classic picture of me standing at the state Senate door
column7: cracked open
column8: peeking in to make sure the 13 votes I had lined up for her stayed with her
column9: ” Sununu says.

column1: Whether New Hampshire’s success at electing women to higher office can be duplicated elsewhere remains an open question. Only two other states have two female US senators
column2: and five others have female governors. New Hampshire is no longer the champ at electing women state legislators; that crown belongs to Colorado
column3: with 42 percent. The top 10 states for female representation in state legislatures are mostly Northern
column4: and the bottom 10 mostly Southern
column5: suggesting cultural factors.

column1: Overall
column2: women hold a higher percentage of state legislative seats (24.6 percent) than seats in Congress (19.4 percent
column3: House and Senate combined). At least the female “farm team” has more players than the “major league
column4: ” though those numbers still fall far short of matching the overall female population of the country
column5: 50.8 percent.

column1: For many women
column2: reaching parity with men in government – and in business
column3: the judiciary
column4: the labor movement
column5: and other spheres of life – is a deeply held goal. But a quick glance at the graphs charting female representation in state and national legislatures reveals a stark truth: Growth has nearly hit a plateau.

column1: If progress continues at the current rate of change since 1960
column2: women will not achieve equal representation in Congress until 2117
column3: according to the Institute for Women’s Policy Research. Women’s representation in state legislatures
column4: which more than quintupled between 1971 and 2015
column5: has also essentially plateaued. What’s going on?

column1: “It’s not that women are running in droves and losing
column2: ” says Debbie Walsh
column3: director of the Center for American Women and Politics at Rutgers University in New Brunswick
column4: N.J. “We know that when women run
column5: they win at about the same rate as men do.”

column1: Women also do just as well in fundraising as men
column2: even if they have to work harder to raise the same amount. Part of the problem
column3: Ms. Walsh says
column4: comes in the recruitment process. Much of the recruiting is done by white men
column5: and they recruit who they know – other white men.

column1: That is particularly so among Republicans: Only 17 percent of Republican state lawmakers are women
column2: a rate that hasn’t changed since the early 1990s. In contrast
column3: Democrats doubled their rate of female state representation during the same period from 15 percent to 30 percent.

column1: In Congress (both houses)
column2: the disparity is even more stark: Only 9 percent of Republicans are female
column3: versus 33 percent of Democrats. In the Senate alone
column4: only six of the 20 women members are Republican.

column1: Walsh cites several factors behind this gap: Republican women are perceived to be more moderate than their male counterparts
column2: and can have a harder time making it out of the primaries
column3: where turnout is low and skews conservative. The GOP also has no counterpart to Emily’s List – a well-funded political action committee that helps pro-abortion-rights Democratic women get elected. And then there’s the simple fact that more women identify as Democrats
column4: so their recruitment pool is bigger.

column1: In New Hampshire
column2: where both legislative chambers are controlled by the Republicans
column3: Democratic women legislators still outnumber Republican women legislators
column4: 73 to 49. State GOP chair Jennifer Horn says the party – nationally
column5: not just in New Hampshire – needs a message that’s more inclusive.

column1: “I’m being diplomatic – I think there are times when some of the folks in our party are not as sensitive to the fact that men and women see the world differently
column2: ” says Ms. Horn. “When we’re talking about jobs and the economy
column3: for example
column4: we need to be cognizant of the fact that women are an economic engine in and of themselves.”

column1: And then there’s the fact that
column2: in both parties
column3: women are less likely than men to run for office without being recruited.

column1: In the Monitor’s conversations with Ernst and Ayotte
column2: both mentioned how they were asked several times to run for the Senate before saying yes – and both brought up family issues. Without using the word “multitasking
column3: ” they both show that they have mastered that classic skill of the working mom.

column1: “It’s about getting the message out about empowering women and saying
column2: you can do this
column3: ” says Ernst. “It is important that you have a supportive family
column4: even more so for women. I have a teenage daughter right now – we’re looking at colleges – and sometimes it’s hard for a woman to be away. But there are ways of making it work.”

column1: Before running for Senate
column2: Ayotte had been asked a couple of times to run for Congress
column3: but declined – in part
column4: she says
column5: because she was pregnant
column6: but also because she had plans in her work as a prosecutor.

column1: Ayotte then excuses herself. “I’ve got to pick up my daughter before 5:30 or I’m in trouble!”"	REAL

column1: What's in that Iran bill that Obama doesn't like?	"Washington (CNN) For months
column2: the White House and Congress have wrangled over a bill that would give lawmakers a greater say in the Iran nuclear deal the administration is hammering out along with other world powers.

column1: And now
column2: less than two weeks after a framework agreement with Tehran was reached
column3: the Senate Foreign Relations Committee is planning to take up the measure.

column1: On Tuesday
column2: the committee will consider amendments to Tennessee Republican Sen. Bob Corker's Iran Nuclear Agreement Review Act before deciding whether to have the full Senate vote on it.

column1: For many in Congress
column2: it's a very simple premise: Congress should weigh in on the terms of a final nuclear deal with Iran.

column1: But for the White House
column2: and some Democrats in Congress
column3: that's an explosive idea that could derail the talks — and therefore must be stopped.

column1: So what's in the bill?

Supporters of the legislation have emphasized that it would allow Congress to give a thumbs up or down on the deal President Barack Obama is aiming to finalize with Iran by the negotiations' June 30 deadline. Backers think that's only fair since the United States is contemplating a major nuclear pact with a decadeslong enemy.
The bill would give Congress a chance to hold hearings
column2: host briefings and pave the way to a vote on a joint resolution that could express approval or disapproval of the deal. It also requires the Obama administration to quickly report to Congress on details of the deal and regularly assess whether Iran is keeping its commitments. And it spells out what the President needs to do vis-a-vis Congress if Iran is found violating the terms.

column1: But most important
column2: it would keep Obama from waiving any congressional sanctions on Iran during Congress' 60-day review period. And if Congress passes a joint resolution of disapproval
column3: then sanctions could not be lifted even after that time.

column1: Does this hurt the diplomatic effort to reach a final deal?
Iran's primary reason for agreeing to the deal's limits on its nuclear program is to get sanctions relief.

Iranian Supreme Leader Ayatollah Ali Khamenei and President Hassan Rouhani have insisted sanctions must be lifted on Day One of the deal. While the Obama administration has said it would wait several months before lifting sanctions -- to verify that Iran has taken major steps to roll back its program — the President is counting on having some latitude to waive sanctions in order to give Iran an incentive to sign the deal and then keep its commitments.
The Corker bill makes it less likely sanctions would be lifted
column2: and lifted in a timely way
column3: which gives less encouragement to Iran.

column1: Without the bill
column2: could Obama lift all sanctions on Iran?

column1: Not all
column2: but most — at least for a limited time.

column1: Without the Corker-Menendez bill (named after Corker and lead Democratic co-sponsor Sen. Bob Menendez)
column2: Iran could see nearly all nuclear-related sanctions at least temporarily lifted. Those enacted through the United Nations and by presidential executive order could be fully removed
column3: and most of those passed by Congress could be waived by Obama until he leaves office
column4: when they would go back into effect unless the next president continues to waive them.

column1: If the Corker-Menendez bill becomes law and a deal is finalized
column2: Obama wouldn't be able to lift the congressional sanctions for at least 60 days.

column1: During that 60-day review phase
column2: the bill says Obama can't ""waive
column3: suspend
column4: reduce
column5: provide relief from
column6: or otherwise limit the application of statutory sanctions.""

column1: How can Obama waive sanctions passed by Congress anyway?
The biggest sanctions package approved by Congress
column2: widely credited with crippling Iran's economy and bringing the country to the negotiating table
column3: was the 2010 Comprehensive Iran Sanctions
column4: Accountability
column5: and Divestment Act.

column1: It included a provision that gives the President leverage to waive sanctions for a limited time if he determines it's in the U.S. national security interest.
He wouldn't be able to permanently sunset the sanctions
column2: though
column3: unless Iran cuts its ties with and stops funding terror organizations around the world
column4: an aspect not being addressed in the current negotiations with Iran and not predicted to happen any time soon.

column1: The administration says sanctions are where Congress could eventually weigh in on the Iran deal -- by repealing them -- but that would only happen if lawmakers deem the deal a good one.
How would Congress weigh in during the 60-day review period?
Congress could pass a joint resolution approving of the deal or disapproving of the deal and forbidding any sanctions relief. Or it could do nothing
column2: allowing Obama to implement the sanctions
column3: and by implication the deal
column4: after the 60 days are up.

column1: A joint resolution disapproving of the deal would need to muster a two-thirds majority
column2: though
column3: to override the veto Obama has promised -- an unlikely
column4: but not entirely unthinkable
column5: scenario.

column1: Are there other reasons that Obama opposes this bill?
First
column2: he's facing a combative
column3: Republican majority in both houses of Congress. Those Republicans have sought to undermine his negotiations with Iran at every turn. Giving those lawmakers a legislative avenue to slam the terms of an eventual deal would
column4: at best
column5: be a political blow to Obama and his administration's efforts to broker an agreement.

column1: There's also the White House's argument that the executive branch has the power to broker international agreements without Congress meddling
column2: while congressional oversight of the Iran deal would set a dangerous precedent. Most international agreements aren't treaties ratified by Congress
column3: and Obama has argued that U.S. allies need to know they can count on those agreements holding up.

column1: Virtually every Senate Republican supports the bill and nine Democrats have signed on as co-sponsors
column2: including independent Sen. Angus King
column3: who caucuses with Democrats. Several more on the left are leaning toward supporting the bill.

column1: That means backers will likely pass the bill with a filibuster-proof majority. It's unclear
column2: though
column3: if they can muster enough Democrats willing to vote to override Obama's veto.

column1: It's not just the numbers
column2: though. Some powerful Democrats are supporting the legislation. Sen. Chuck Schumer of New York
column3: the No. 3 Senate Democrat
column4: who will become the chamber's Democratic leader when Minority Leader Harry Reid of Nevada retires at the end of his term
column5: is a big proponent of the legislation.

column1: Menendez
column2: of New Jersey
column3: who has been working to rally Democrats around legislation on Iran throughout the negotiations
column4: remains the most vocal Democrat on the issue. He was the top-ranked Democrat on the Senate Foreign Relations Committee until stepping aside to face corruption charges handed down earlier in the month.

column1: Also
column2: Sen. Tim Kaine of Virginia
column3: one of the earliest Obama backers during the 2008 campaign
column4: has been insistent on the need for Congress to weigh in and has worked behind the scenes to make Corker's bill more palatable to Democrats -- and the White House. But so far that effort hasn't succeeded
column5: as the White House remains opposed."	REAL

column1: The 1 chart that explains everything you need to know about partisanship in America	"While paging through Pew's best data visualizations of 2014 (it's awesome)
column2: I came across what I believe to be one of the best and most revealing charts about the state of American politics. Here it is:

column1: The chart
column2: which comes from Pew's amazing political polarization project
column3: shows how partisans of both parties have grown both increasingly unified amongst themselves and increasingly far apart from their partisan others over just the last 20 years. As recently as 1994
column4: seven in 10 Democrats were more consistently liberal than the median Republican.  As of 2014
column5: it's a whopping 94 percent. Same goes for Republicans; 64 percent of GOPers were more consistently conservative than the median Democrat in 1994 while 92 percent are today. In addition
column6: ""the overall share of Americans who express consistently conservative or consistently liberal opinions has doubled over the past two decades from 10 percent to 21 percent
column7: according to Pew.

column1: To me
column2: this chart is so important -- particularly in a week where a new Congress arrives in Washington -- because it reveals that the polarization of our elected officials isn't some sort of ""only in Washington"" thing.  The increasing partisanship of Congress is a direct reflection of the increasing partisanship of the country. After all
column3: that's who elects these people to Congress
column4: right?

column1: So
column2: when you hear people decry the partisanship of their elected officials in Washington
column3: don't believe it.  We have the Congress we want -- even if we aren't totally honest with ourselves all the time about what that is.  And
column4: we get the results -- not many -- from our elected officials that you have to expect when you have a country as polarized as ours."	REAL

column1: The slippery slope to Trump’s proposed ban on Muslims	"With little fanfare this fall
column2: the New York developer who had planned to build an Islamic community center north of the World Trade Center announced that he would instead use the site for a 70-story tower of luxury condos.

column1: Those who had rallied in opposition to the building because of its religious affiliation back in 2010 were exultant. “The importance of the defeat of the Ground Zero Mosque cannot be overstated
column2: ” Pamela Geller
column3: president of the American Freedom Defense Initiative
column4: wrote on the website Breitbart in September. “The Ground Zero Mosque became a watershed issue in our effort to raise awareness of and ultimately halt and roll back the advance of Islamic law and Islamic supremacism in America.”

column1: It’s all well and good that so many Republicans have condemned Donald Trump’s reprehensible call for “a total and complete shutdown of Muslims entering the United States.” House Speaker Paul D. Ryan (Wis.) was particularly forceful
column2: calling proper attention to the “many Muslims serving in our armed forces
column3: dying for this country.”

column1: When he was president
column2: George W. Bush honorably put a lid on right-wing Islamophobia. He regularly praised American Muslims and stressed that the United States needed Muslim allies to fight violent extremism. Once Bush was gone
column3: restraint on his side of politics fell away.

column1: Thus
column2: Trump’s embrace of a religious test for entry to our country did not come out of nowhere. On the contrary
column3: it simply brought us to the bottom of a slippery slope created by the ongoing exploitation of anti-Muslim feeling for political purposes.

column1: You don’t have to reach far back in time to see why Trump figured he had the ideological space for his Muslim ban. Last month
column2: it was Jeb Bush who introduced the idea of linking the rights of Syrian refugees to their religion. He said he was comfortable granting admission to “people like orphans and people who are clearly not going to be terrorists. Or Christians.” Asked how he’d determine who was Christian
column3: he explained that “you can prove you’re a Christian.”

column1: Sen. Ted Cruz (Tex.) took a similar view
column2: saying
column3: “There is no meaningful risk of Christians committing acts of terror.”

column1: Trump took limits on Muslim access to our country to their logical — if un-American and odious — conclusion. Vice President Biden said that Trump was serving up “a very
column2: very dangerous brew
column3: ” but the brew has been steeping for a long time. This is why the “Ground Zero Mosque” episode is so instructive.

column1: The demagoguery began with the labeling of the controversy itself. As PolitiFact pointed out
column2: “the proposed mosque is not at or on Ground Zero. It does not directly abut it or overlook it.” It was “two long blocks” away. And while a mosque was part of the proposed cultural center
column3: the plans also included “a swimming pool
column4: gym and basketball court
column5: a 500-seat auditorium
column6: a restaurant and culinary school
column7: a library and art studios.”

column1: This didn’t stop opponents from going over the top
column2: and Newt Gingrich deserved some kind of award for the most incendiary comment of all. “Nazis
column3: ” he said
column4: “don’t have the right to put up a sign next to the Holocaust museum in Washington.”

column1: When President Obama defended the right of developers to build the project
column2: he was — surprise
column3: surprise — accused of being out of touch
column4: and Republicans were happy to make the Muslim center and Obama’s defense of religious rights an issue in the 2010 campaign.

column1: “I think it does speak to the lack of connection between the administration and Washington and folks inside the Beltway and mainstream America
column2: ” said Sen. John Cornyn (Tex.)
column3: who was then chairman of the committee in charge of electing Republicans to the Senate. Voters
column4: he said
column5: felt they were “being lectured to
column6: not listened to.” Sound familiar?

column1: At the time
column2: John Feehery
column3: the veteran Republican strategist
column4: put his finger on why Republicans were so eager to lambaste Obama’s response to the Ground Zero issue. “This will help drive turnout for the GOP base
column5: ” he said.

column1: The Republican establishment is now all upset with Trump
column2: but he is simply the revenge of a Republican base that took its leaders’ pandering — on Islam and a host of other issues — seriously.

column1: You can’t be “just a little” intolerant of Muslims
column2: any more than you can be “just a little” prejudiced against Catholics or Jews. Once the door to bigotry is opened
column3: it is very hard to shut.

column1: Read more from E.J. Dionne’s archive
column2: follow him on Twitter or subscribe to his updates on Facebook."	REAL

Hillary Clinton Makes A Bipartisan Appeal on Staten Island	"Hillary Clinton told a Staten Island crowd today that she was the candidate who could reach across party lines to get things done as president—pointing to her experience representing the borough in the Senate and even giving public thanks to Republican President George W. Bush.
“I have no time for people who are partisan for the sake of being partisan
column2: ” Ms. Clinton
column3: a Democrat and former secretary of state
column4: told a crowd that welcomed her enthusiastically in a historic building at Snug Harbor Cultural Center.

column1: Ms. Clinton was the second leading presidential candidate to speak on Staten Island today
column2: after Republican Donald Trump delivered a typical stump speech at a Republican brunch. But Ms. Clinton
column3: perhaps sensing or recalling Staten Island’s ever-present desire for politicians to pay attention to the forgotten borough
column4: delivered a speech that seemed to be especially tailored for the borough
column5: which is more conservative than the rest of New York City. The majority of its voters are registered Democrats
column6: but the borough routinely swings Republican.

column1: “When I ran in 2000
column2: I didn’t carry Staten Island. When I ran in 2006
column3: I did
column4: ” Ms. Clinton said today. “I’ve got no problem with people having political disagreements. That’s in America’s DNA
column5: isn’t it?”

column1: Instead
column2: Ms. Clinton decried “deliberate efforts to set Americans against each other.” She harkened back to representing the borough of cops and firefighters on September 11
column4: when nearly 300 Staten Islanders were killed in the terror attacks. She noted the city’s mayor
column5: the state’s governor
column6: and the president were all Republicans.

column1: “I did not for one minute stop and say to myself: ‘Well
column2: I don’t know
column3: can we work together?'” Ms. Clinton said. “How absurd is that?”

column1: Ms. Clinton said with 3
column2: 000 people murdered
column3: people “pulled together” and “politics was totally left behind.” She had criticized President Bush for his handling of a strong economy he “inherited” from her husband
column4: President Bill Clinton
column5: and for other reasons. But she praised him for approving billions of dollars to rebuild lower Manhattan after the terror attacks
column6: even as others in Washington didn’t want to spend it.

column1: “I publicly say
column2: ‘Thank you President George W. Bush
column3: ’ for making sure that we got the money that we needed to rebuild our city
column4: ” Ms. Clinton said.

column1: She also touted her record working for the borough after the attacks
column2: including sounding the alarm on air quality and pushing for the passage of the Zadroga Act. Ms. Clinton went on to discuss her foreign policy experience
column3: saying anyone who wants to president has to be able to offer specifics on what they would do—an allusion to her Democratic rival Vermont Sen. Bernie Sanders—but also has to be able to keep people safe.

column1: “Maybe we take that more seriously here in New York
column2: but we should
column3: ” she said. “And we are going to do everything we can to keep America safe.”

column1: She cited her work building a coalition that “brought Iran to the negotiating table
column2: ” without mentioning how controversial that final Iran deal was for President Barack Obama.

column1: Ms. Clinton’s rally had little in common with Mr. Trump’s Staten Island event
column2: except one thing: the crowd at both seemed to hate Republican Texas Sen. Ted Cruz. Ms. Clinton mentioned his plan to spy on Muslim neighborhoods
column3: which has also been dismissed by Police Commissioner Bill Bratton.

column1: At the mention of Mr. Cruz’s name
column2: the crowd offered a chorus of boos.

column1: The crowd had been hyped up for Ms. Clinton before she even arrived
column2: and gave a nice response to several local pols as they urged people to get out the vote on Tuesday.

column1: “Hillary is the only one with the experience
column2: ” said Councilwoman Debi Rose
column3: a Democrat who represents the borough’s North Shore. “She knows what it’s like to be in the White House. She knows the realities. She knows that living and running the White House in this country is not a reality show.”

column1: Ms. Clinton
column2: at the end of her speech
column3: offered the kind of promise Staten Island always loves—and the kind it holds politicians to
column4: if the way the Staten Island Advance repeatedly agitated and inquired about a town hall Mayor Bill de Blasio will finally hold here on Wednesday night is any indication.

column1: “I want you to hold me accountable
column2: ” Ms. Clinton said. “I will be coming back to Staten Island when I am your president.”"	REAL

column1: New Senate majority leader’s main goal for GOP: Don’t be scary	"Mitch McConnell has an unusual admonition for the new Republican majority as it takes over the Senate this week: Don’t be “scary.”
The incoming Senate majority leader has set a political goal for the next two years of overseeing a functioning
column2: reasonable majority on Capitol Hill that scores some measured conservative wins
column3: particularly against environmental regulations
column4: but probably not big victories such as a full repeal of the health-care law. McConnell’s priority is to set the stage for a potential GOP presidential victory in 2016.

column1: “I don’t want the American people to think that if they add a Republican president to a Republican Congress
column2: that’s going to be a scary outcome. I want the American people to be comfortable with the fact that the Republican House and Senate is a responsible
column3: right-of-center
column4: governing majority
column5: ” the Kentucky Republican said in a broad interview just before Christmas in his Capitol office.

column1: It’s a far cry from his defiant declaration in 2010 that his “single most important” goal was to make President Obama a one-term president
column2: an antagonizing oath that Democrats frequently invoke to embarrass the GOP leader — Obama won reelection comfortably in 2012
column3: and McConnell’s party lost seats.

column1: Now in charge at both ends of the Capitol
column2: Republicans aim to avoid the worst excesses of the past four years and make sure the public isn’t fearful of the GOP’s course.

column1: “There would be nothing frightening about adding a Republican president to that governing majority
column2: ” McConnell said
column3: explaining how he wants voters to view the party on the eve of the 2016 election. “I think that’s the single best thing we can do
column4: is to not mess up the playing field
column5: if you will
column6: for whoever the nominee ultimately is.”

column1: But McConnell
column2: who will become majority leader Tuesday
column3: is not planning to avoid conflict altogether. He wants to use the annual spending bills to compel Obama to accept conservative policy riders that will divide Democrats
column4: similar to the December spending bill’s inclusion of a provision benefiting Wall Street firms involved in risky derivative trades. That rider brought a liberal outcry but did not end up torpedoing the bill
column5: which had Obama’s support.

column1: McConnell has been coaching his members to understand that
column2: in the initial rounds
column3: they will have to almost unanimously support the budget outline and the spending bills
column4: because few Democrats will support their policy riders.

column1: With 54 Republicans in his caucus
column2: McConnell knows that he’s a long way from getting 67 votes to override an Obama veto and that it won’t even be easy getting six Democrats to regularly support legislation so that he can overcome likely filibusters led by the incoming minority leader
column3: Sen. Harry M. Reid (D-Nev.). Still
column4: on some issues
column5: such as energy and taxes on the health industry
column6: McConnell thinks there’s enough bipartisan support to get bills onto Obama’s desk.

column1: “They’d like to be relevant. They’d like to be part of the process
column2: ” he said of discussions with some rank-and-file Democrats. “Assuming we will have on most issues a largely unified conference — I don’t expect that on everything — it wouldn’t take a whole lot of Democrats to actually pass legislation in the Senate.”

column1: But McConnell said those who are “craving some grand deal as a way to measure the next two years” should lower their expectations. He’s very skeptical of such bargains with Democrats on tough issues such as immigration and entitlement reform. Instead
column2: he believes three issues have potential common ground: international trade deals
column3: an overhaul of the tax code and new revenue streams for infrastructure projects.

column1: “Could the country use a lot more? You bet. But there’s no way you can overcome a reluctant president on something really large
column2: ” McConnell said. The best he can do on some of those bigger issues is force Obama to break out his veto pen so there is a clear set of Democratic policy stances Republicans can campaign against in 2016.

column1: Democrats are dubious of McConnell’s pledge to avert edge-of-the-cliff moments. They believe he will run into the same problems that have bedeviled House Speaker John A. Boehner (R-Ohio) during the past four years — including the inability to corral rabble-rousers such as Sen. Ted Cruz (R-Tex.) to support an agenda that conservative critics will probably view as not bold enough in challenging Obama. Appeasing those far-right conservatives will lead to an agenda that Democrats hope to exploit in 2016.
“What Senator McConnell wants people to think and what they will think when they see the results for themselves are two very different things
column2: ” said Reid’s spokesman
column3: Adam Jentleson. “Senator McConnell heads a caucus that is obsessed with rigging the game against working people in favor of wealthy special interests. That’s a scary fact indeed
column4: and he won’t be able to hide it.”

column1: While McConnell’s office is adorned with a portrait of Kentucky’s only other Senate majority leader — Alben W. Barkley
column2: whose tenure was often marked by clashes with his own party’s president
column3: Franklin D. Roosevelt — his model more resembles that of George Mitchell
column4: the Democratic majority leader from 1989 through 1994.

column1: Without ever shutting down the government
column2: Mitchell stared down a president of the opposite party
column3: George H.W. Bush
column4: and won several liberal victories in a 1990 budget showdown. Mitchell also delivered a slew of legislation to Bush’s desk that drew a veto
column5: helping frame the debate for the 1992 election on domestic policy.

column1: McConnell has recently studied other two-term presidents on how often they vetoed legislation in their last two years in office. Obama has issued only two minor vetoes over technical matters
column2: largely because the previously Democratic-run Senate prevented anything from reaching his desk that he opposed.

column1: McConnell suggested that a veto strategy would help clarify issues for voters. “I think his bureaucracy across the board has done a lot of damage to the country. . . . I’d at least like for him to have to personally take responsibility for it
column2: even if he in the end decides to veto the bill over some restriction on EPA regulations.”

column1: McConnell is keenly aware of the challenges of reining in some of the impulses that his fellow Republican lawmakers have developed over eight straight years in the minority.
The first test will come on an energy debate
column2: which could begin by the end of this week. McConnell is trying to keep his side from offering amendments not related to energy issues. In recent years
column3: when some rank-and-file Republicans wanted to stop the Senate in its tracks
column4: they would threaten amendments related to how Congress gets its health care.

column1: “I’ve asked my members to restrain themselves
column2: ” he said.

column1: Restraint has been hard to come by in this political era
column2: particularly because a small army of conservative groups has made it a mission to push Republicans to the most strident stands
column3: even if it means shutting down the government or risking default on the national debt.

column1: McConnell faced some of those groups firsthand when they supported his 2014 primary challenger
column2: and he faced a grinding general election against a Democrat who was well financed.

column1: It cost nearly $30 million from his campaign war chest and tens of millions of dollars more from outside groups. Winning both races handily
column2: McConnell is delivering a message to Republicans on how to behave heading into 2016.

column1: “Don’t try to reinvent yourself. Be yourself
column2: number one. And don’t be afraid of a primary. We will win all the primaries. We did it in ’14. We will do it in ’16
column3: ” McConnell said.

column1: Shortly after Election Day this fall
column2: McConnell sat down with Obama for a rare one-on-one meeting in the Oval Office
column3: a huddle that both sides kept largely secret. In the pre-Christmas interview
column4: McConnell acknowledged that the meeting’s purpose was only to discuss areas where the president and Republicans might find bipartisan agreement — because their disagreements on other issues were too in­trac­table.

column1: That meeting
column2: he said
column3: focused on trade deals
column4: a tax code overhaul and infrastructure funding. “Can we get there on tax reform
column5: trade
column6: infrastructure?” he said.

column1: He eschewed the idea of holding the debt ceiling hostage to gain spending-cut concessions from Obama
column2: a tool Republicans had to use before because they were in the minority.

column1: “We are in the majority. We can pass a budget. We can determine how much we’re going to spend
column2: ” he said.

column1: Avoiding those moments could make for a less “scary” Congress
column2: giving the Republicans a better chance in 2016 to hit the trifecta and gain the White House. His own horse is already chosen
column3: Sen. Rand Paul (R-Ky.)
column4: but don’t expect McConnell to be out on the campaign trail or doing any other favors for his home-state colleague.

column1: “I’m going to be supporting Rand Paul. But he knows that beyond that
column2: I won’t be involved in presidential politics. I’ve got a big job here
column3: ” he said."	REAL

column1: ‘Inferno’ and the Overpopulation Myth	"Mises.org November 1
column2: 2016 Inferno is a great thriller
column3: featuring Tom Hanks reprising his role as Professor Robert Langdon. The previous movie adaptations of Dan Brown’s books ( Angels and Demons and The Da Vinci Code ) were a success
column4: and I expect Inferno will do well in theaters
column5: too. Langdon is a professor of symbology whose puzzle solving skills and knowledge of history come in high demand when a billionaire leaves a trail of clues based on Dante’s Inferno to a biological weapon that would halve the world’s population. The villain
column6: however
column7: has good motives. As a radical Malthusian
column8: he believes that the human race needs halving if it is to survive at all
column9: even if through a plague. Malthus’s name is not mentioned in the movie
column10: but his ideas are certainly there. Inferno provides us an opportunity to unpack this overpopulation fear
column11: and see where it stands today. Thomas Malthus (1766–1834) thought that the potential exponential growth of population was a problem. If the population increases faster than the means of subsistence
column12: then
column13: “The superior power of population cannot be checked without producing misery or vice.” Is overpopulation a problem? The economics of population size tell a different
column14: less scary
column15: story. While it is certainly possible that some areas can become too crowded for some people’s preferences
column16: as long as people are free to buy and sell land for a mutually agreeable price
column17: overcrowding will fix itself. As an introvert who enjoys nature and peace and quiet
column18: I am certainly less willing to rent an apartment in the middle of a busy
column19: crowded city. The prices I’m willing to pay for country living versus city living reflect my preferences. And
column20: to the extent that others share my preferences or even have the opposite preferences
column21: the use and construction of homes and apartments will economize in both locations. Our demands and the profitability of the varied real estate offerings keep local populations in check. But what about on a global scale? The Inferno villain was concerned with world population. He stressed the urgency of the situation
column22: but I don’t see any reason to worry. Google tells me that we could fit the entire world population in Texas and everybody would have a small
column23: 100 square meter plot to themselves. Indeed
column24: there are vast stretches of land across the globe with little to no human inhabitants. Malthus and his ideological followers must have a biased perspective
column25: only looking at the crowded streets of a big city. If it’s not land that’s a problem
column26: what about the “means of subsistence”? Are we at risk of running out of food
column27: medicine
column28: or other resources because of our growing population? No. A larger population not only means more mouths to feed
column29: but also more heads
column30: hands
column31: and feet to do the producing. Also
column32: as populations increase
column33: so does the variety of skills available to make production even more efficient. More people means everybody can specialize in a more specific and more productive comparative advantage and participate in a division of labor. Perhaps this question will drive the point home: Would you rather be stranded on an island with two other people or 20 other people? Malthus wouldn’t be a Malthusian if he could see this data The empirical evidence is compelling
column34: too. In the graph below
column35: we can see the sort of world Malthus saw: one in which most people were barely surviving
column36: especially compared to our current situation. Our 21st-century world tells a different story. Extreme poverty is on the decline even while world population is increasing. Hans Rosling
column37: a Swedish medical doctor and “celebrity statistician
column38: ” is famous for his “Don’t Panic” message about population growth. He sees that as populations and economies grow
column39: more have access to birth control and limit the size of their families. In this video
column40: he shows that all countries are heading toward longer lifespans and greater standards of living. Finally
column41: there’s the hockey stick of human prosperity. Estimates of GDP per capita on a global
column42: millennial scale reveal a recent dramatic turn. The inflection point coincides with the industrial revolution. Embracing the productivity of steam-powered capital goods and other technologies sparked a revolution in human well-being across the globe. Since then
column43: new sources of energy have been harnessed and computers entered the scene. Now
column44: computers across the world are connected through the internet and have been made small enough to fit in our pockets. Goods
column46: and ideas zip across the globe
column47: while human productivity increases beyond what anybody could have imagined just 50 years ago.

column1: I don’t think Malthus himself would be a Malthusian if he could see the world today.

Note: The views expressed on Mises.org are not necessarily those of the Mises Institute. The Best of Jonathan Newman Tags: Jonathan Newman was a 2013 and 2014 Summer Fellow at the Mises Institute and teaches economics at Auburn University."	FAKE

Anti-Trump forces seek last-ditch delegate revolt	"Washington (CNN) The faction of the GOP that is unhappy with Donald Trump as the party's presumptive nominee has one last plan to stop the mogul: staging an all-out delegate revolt at the Republican National Convention.
The far-fetched idea is the latest reflection of a campaign cycle that has been anything but ordinary
column2: and stems from a continuing dissatisfaction among some conservative stalwarts with how Trump is behaving and running his campaign. But two longtime GOP veterans says they wouldn't bet on the effort working.

column1: The effort comes at a rough time for the GOP. As the Democratic Party's heaviest hitters
column2: including President Barack Obama
column3: Vice President Joe Biden and Massachusetts Sen. Elizabeth Warren
column4: line up behind Hillary Clinton and against Trump
column5: Republicans have been forced to criticize their own nominee. Recent comments from Trump about a federal judge's Mexican heritage have drawn widespread rebuke and put GOP leaders in a corner as they defend their endorsement of Trump while disavowing his comments.

column1: One of the vocal advocates for a delegate revolt is conservative commentator and Weekly Standard editor Bill Kristol
column2: who has also been actively seeking a candidate to mount an independent bid against Trump
column3: thus far to no avail.

column1: Kristol tweeted late Thursday that the idea of a ""conscience convention
column2: where delegates are free to vote for whomever they want to
column3: is also appealing.

column1: I've been focused on independent candidacy
column2: & still am. But struck by sudden level of interest in possible delegate revolt at convention
column3: Kristol tweeted. He added: ""A Convention of Conscience in Cleveland would be quite something. Made easier by fact Trump only won minority of total primary votes anyway.""

column1: Bob Vander Plaats
column2: the head of The Family Leader
column3: an influential social conservative group in Iowa
column4: told CNN's Kate Bolduan Friday morning that ""everything does need to be on the table"" at the convention
column5: though he stopped short of calling for a revolt on the convention floor.

column1: We want a principled conservative and disciplined candidate who is the standard-bearer of this party
column2: said Vander Plaats
column3: who backed Texas Sen. Ted Cruz during the primaries. He said Trump has time before the convention to ""have the concerns laid to rest.""

column1: All I'm doing is adapting to the circumstances
column2: Kendal Unruh told ABC. ""I certainly believe Trump's demagogic racist comments are hurting him.""

column1: The rules enacted by the previous convention
column2: which govern in 2016 until delegates pass a new set of rules
column3: state that even if a delegate casts a ballot for a candidate other than one they are bound to
column4: the convention secretary will record their bound vote.

column1: In order to change that rule
column2: the 112 delegates (two from each state and territory) on the Rules Committee would have to pass different rules and bring those to the floor of the convention
column3: where a majority of delegates present would have to approve them.

column1: Rules expert and RNC veteran Jim Bopp
column2: an Indiana delegate who serves as special counsel to the RNC Rules Committee
column3: said he has spoken with people who want to ""keep the option open to manipulate the rules in some way to deny Trump the nomination
column4: but he said he wouldn't bet on any changes.

column1: I would put money on no rules changes that would affect the outcome of the nominating process
column2: Bopp told CNN. ""I think it's highly likely that no rules changes would be adopted that would affect the nomination.""

column1: Bopp said there's also a counter movement within Rules insiders to pass a rule that would prevent any other rules changes from going into effect until the close of the convention.
Rules Committee and Oregon RNC member Solomon Yue is behind that effort
column2: and has been pushing the RNC this year to adopt rules that give less power to the party and more to the delegates. He tried but failed to get the party to adopt rules that would require bigger majorities to pass business at the convention.

column1: Yue says with roughly 80% of the convention delegates being either Trump or Cruz backers
column2: the anti-Trump forces don't have much strength.

column1: The common denominator of the delegates is anti-establishment
column2: anti-Washington
column3: Yue said. ""And if you think about 'Never Trump' people
column4: they are representing Washington and the establishment.""

column1: Part of the philosophy for a delegate revolt comes from longtime RNC veteran Curly Haugland
column2: from North Dakota
column3: and a book he co-wrote with public policy consultant Sean Parnell. ""Unbound"" uses the history of the RNC to make the case that RNC rules dictate that delegates be allowed to vote their conscience.

column1: What Curly and I are contending is that because of RNC rules
column2: there is no such thing as binding
column3: Parnell told CNN
column4: saying the binding rules that currently are in place are in a part of the rules package that govern pre-convention during the delegate selection process.

column1: But Parnell also acknowledged that any effort to make the interpretation stick would require at the very least a handful of state delegations if not a majority of delegates on the floor.
It would be messy. Good television though
column2: Parnell said. ""I would not call it likely. My hope is that delegates are free to vote however they want to vote
column3: and it's going to be up to the chair whether or not to allow that. But I think unless Donald Trump actually does go shoot somebody on Fifth Avenue
column4: I don't think this is going to cost him the nomination.""

column1: Neither the Trump campaign nor Republican National Committee immediately responded to a request for comment on the chatter about a delegate revolt.
There has been intense focus on the Rules Committee for months
column2: going back to when there was a possibility of no Republican candidate getting enough delegates to clinch the nomination outright. With the prospect of a contested convention
column3: the Cruz campaign made a concerted effort to stock the Rules Committee and state delegations with loyalists who would support Rules that would benefit Cruz in a bid to win the nomination on multiple ballots.

column1: But after Cruz lost Indiana soundly and suspended his campaign
column2: the prospect of a contested convention vanished and Trump rolled to the magic number to clinch the nomination.

column1: Meanwhile
column2: the Cruz campaign urged supporters to continue to become delegates and earn leadership spots to influence the platform at the convention.

column1: Though some in the party have never warmed to Trump
column2: the intensity of finding a way to prevent his formal nomination has grown in recent days after Trump's comments about a federal judge inflamed even the leaders of his own party.

column1: Trump questioned the impartiality of the district court judge overseeing a lawsuit related to his venture Trump University
column2: saying the Indiana-born judge's Mexican ancestry could bias him against Trump. The mogul cited his campaign promise to build a wall along the border with Mexico in making the comments.

column1: Donald Trump Is Changing His Campaign Slogan to Prove He’s Not Racist	"After a week of nonstop criticism from Democrats and Republicans alike for comments many condemned as racially charged
column2: Donald Trump claims to be altering his campaign to be a little more inclusive. While the presumptive G.O.P. has long promised to “make America great again
column3: ” Trump now says he’s adding two words to slogan to illustrate just how non-racist he really is.

column1: “You know
column2: I have the theme ‘make America great again
column3: ’ and I've added a couple of things
column4: ” Trump announced to supporters at a campaign rally in Richmond
column5: Virginia
column6: on Friday night. “Right now I’m adding make America great again—I’m adding ‘for everyone
column7: ’ because it’s really going to be for everyone. It’s not going to be for a group of people
column8: it’s going to be for everyone. It’s true.”

column1: The allegedly amended slogan
column2: which has yet to appear on any official signage or Trump merchandise
column3: comes after the presidential candidate spent the first half of June repeatedly denouncing Gonzalo Curiel
column4: the federal judge of Mexican heritage presiding over the Trump University class action lawsuit
column5: as inherently biased against him. (Curiel was born in Indiana.) His comments were widely condemned by the Washington political establishment
column6: including Senate Minority Leader Mitch McConnell
column7: who suggested he may be an idiot
column8: and House Speaker Paul Ryan
column9: who called Trump’s statement the “textbook definition of a racist comment.”

column1: Trump
column2: who hasn’t apologized or taken back any of his comments
column3: indicated on Friday that he realized his words have had a negative effect on his campaign and declared he is not a racist.

column1: “I am the least racist person. The least racist person that you’ve ever seen. I mean give me a break
column2: ” he said at the rally. “I am the least racist person that you’ve ever looked at

column1: Pure chaos: Donald Trump’s campaign management offers a glimpse into his governing style (spoiler alert: it’s terrible)	"If you want a glimpse into a presidential candidate’s governing style
column2: take a look at his campaign. How does he build an organization? How does he manage personnel? How does he delegate responsibility? Does he value loyalty or honesty in advisers? It’s hardly conclusive
column3: but how a candidate deals with these challenges says a lot about what they’d prioritize as president.

column1: The presumptive Republican nominee has managed his campaign the way he manages his casinos or his realty TV program: haphazardly and with an unearned arrogance. Everything’s about the brand and non-sycophants are cast aside. Getting it right is far less important than being right. Thus
column2: when prompted by advisers to dial down the rhetoric and think more about his long-term viability
column3: Trump has resisted. He’s yet to understand how different a primary and a general election are
column4: and he’s too cocksure to listen to anyone who tries to explain it.

column1: Trump isn’t as stupid as he pretends to be
column2: but his confidence seems to scale with his ignorance
column3: and that’s a dangerous trait in a president
column4: given how consequential each decision can be. As a candidate
column5: a confident idiot can make a lot of noise and fool a lot of voters. But you can’t lead that way. As president
column6: Trump would need the sober advice of serious professionals. Considering how little he understands about the job and the world
column7: this is especially true in his case.

column1: Based on the latest behind-the-scenes reports on Trump’s campaign (as well as his entire history in real estate and television)
column2: it’s unlikely he would govern with the humility and self-awareness required. The campaign has undergone several shake-ups in recent months
column3: with key staffers like Corey Lewandowski being demoted to make way for veteran operatives like Paul Manafort. Trump’s approach has remained very much the same
column4: however. Everyone he brings in bends to his will or is replaced by someone who does.

column1: Things have gotten more chaotic in the last week or so
column2: as Rick Wiley was fired as the campaign’s national political director. Wiley was known to assert himself in ways that alienated Trump and his loyalists. The Washington Post’s Sean Sullivan and Robert Costa summarized the broader situation over the weekend: “For the last two months
column3: Donald Trump has presided over a political team riddled with turf wars
column4: staff reshuffling and dueling power centers. But tensions are more than typical campaign chaos: They illustrate how Trump likes to run an organization
column5: whether it’s a real estate venture or his presidential bid. Interviews with current and former Trump associates reveal an executive who is fond of promoting rivalries among subordinates
column6: wary of delegating major decisions
column7: scornful of convention and fiercely insistent on a culture of loyalty around him.” These are the management techniques of a brand-hustling magnate
column8: not a president of the United States. Trump’s dictatorial approach works well on the campaign trail
column9: but it’d be a disaster in office. A president has to persuade and compromise. The capacity to admit ignorance is equally important. Trump
column10: by all accounts
column11: has no interest in any of these things. Trump doesn’t know what he needs to know in order to be president
column12: nor does he care that he doesn’t know. If his campaign is any indication
column13: he’ll hire people to ensure his veil of ignorance is never cracked. That kind of megalomania is why Trump is who he is – it’s part of his outsized persona. It’s also the clearest indicator we have of the kind of president he’d be."	REAL

column1: Why It’s Necessary To Relax Into A Stretch	"In a previous article
column2: I discussed stretching—namely
column3: why stretching is important for the masculine man
column4: and several stretches that you should use in your training to maximize your physical fitness. And while that advice is still valid
column5: I neglected a very important concept in that first article: the techniques that detail how to stretch.

column1: I am not referring to a specific stretch or some sort of hypothetical “stretching mindset
column2: ” but rather a set of techniques that can be utilized for any stretch to increase ones flexibility immediately. But before I can discuss those
column3: I have to discuss the incorrect way of stretching that many people still use.

column1: How Not To Stretch Many people believe that stretching is a literal act of forcing the muscles and connective tissue to stretch— avoid this at all costs ! First and foremost
column2: as I have discussed previously in these pages
column3: you should never apply any stretching pressure to the connective tissue. They evolved solely to “hold fast” and keep things in one piece
column4: they should never be stretched at all!

column1: The muscles are the anatomical feature that stretches
column2: as they evolved to do. When stretching
column3: your body should always be positioned in a way where the connective tissues are stable and the muscles are moving.

column1: Even when you are positioned properly
column2: no part of stretching should involve the athlete forcing his muscles to stretch
column3: as that risks muscular tearing which is a nagging injury that never truly goes away. This is because the human body has naturally evolved what is referred to as the “ anti-stretch reflex ” to prevent muscular tearing-stretching the muscles increases in difficulty the farther and deeper the stretch is
column4: and your body responds to this stress with pain. This is a biological sign telling you that if you go further you’ll be risking muscle tears
column5: and should normally be a heeded warning.

column1: However
column2: if you want to do advanced stretching (such as that nigh-impossible benchmark of fitness the splits)
column3: you will have to find a way to overcome this reflex without hurting yourself. And as luck would have it
column4: there is!

column1: Relax Into Stretching Reflexes can be overcome with gradual and repeated practice—just ask your friendly neighborhood hooker about how she overcame her gag reflex! Similarly
column2: your anti-stretch reflex that keeps your “joints” (actually your muscles) stiff and immobile can be overcome with a few techniques.

column1: The most basic of these techniques is the one that I have had the best results with (as usual
column2: the simple but difficult answer is usually the correct one)
column3: and that is the titular concept of “relaxing into a stretch”—with thanks to Pavel Tsatsouline for naming the concept.

column1: To use this technique
column2: take an easy form of the stretch you want to do: using the splits as an example
column3: you would do a seated groin stretch. Engage the stretch just to the point where you feel tension in the target muscle
column4: and then…sit and wait.

column1: Yes
column2: paradoxically
column3: relaxation is the key to increasing your physical fitness in this context. You are literally going to sit there and wait for your muscles to stop fighting the stretch—in other words
column4: you’re going to exhaust your reflex until it stops being reflexive.

column1: This is not something that happens quickly—from my experience
column2: it will take 5-10 minutes per stretch
column3: so it is perfectly acceptable for you to get a book or watch TV while doing this. As a side note
column4: this is literally the only time where it’s acceptable to have a visual distraction during exercise
column5: in my opinion.

column1: As you might expect
column2: once your muscles have relaxed and the pain has melted away
column3: you can increase the stretch a little bit more
column4: and hold it for another 10 minutes. Repeat this process until your muscles are in pain and you judge that you can’t go any further—this is a personal call that you will have to decide for yourself
column5: as I can’t judge when your muscles are demanding you to stop.

column1: This technique can be utilized for any stretch
column2: and in many cases will give you the progress that you so desire. However
column3: there are other methods in the “Relax Into Stretch” family of exercises that can be utilized as well
column4: such as meditation—mentally relaxing will lead to muscular relaxation.

column1: Or you can try “forced relaxation”
column2: where you flex the muscle simultaneously while stretching
column3: forcing the muscle to relax.

column1: Either way you slice it
column2: don’t just brute force your stretching
column3: utilize these techniques for better results.
