column1: Both parties want to craft populist messages for 2016	"Presidential hopefuls in both parties agree on at least one thing: Economic mobility
column2: and the feeling of many Americans that they are being shut out from the nation’s prosperity
column3: will be a defining theme of the 2016 campaign.

column1: Former Florida governor Jeb Bush last week became the latest Republican to signal a readiness to engage Democrats on what historically has been their turf
column2: putting issues of middle-class wage stagnation
column3: poverty and shared prosperity at the forefront of their political messages.

column1: Bush’s framing of the economic and social challenges facing the country nearly mirrors that of likely Democratic candidate Hillary Rodham Clinton
column2: as well as other possible contenders on the left. Sen. Marco Rubio (R-Fla.) has written a book on the subject
column3: “American Dreams: Restoring Economic Opportunity for Everyone
column4: ” to be published this week
column5: while Sen. Rand Paul (R-Ky.) has proposed policies for distressed communities that he sees as “the ticket to the middle class.”

column1: And Mitt Romney
column2: the 2012 GOP nominee who was portrayed by Democrats as insensitive to and out of touch with the lives of middle- and working-class Americans
column3: has told friends he considers poverty a topic du jour as he weighs another run in 2016.

column1: “You talk to any pollster
column2: on the Democratic side or the Republican side
column3: they’re in complete agreement on the idea that there has to be an economic populist message
column4: ” said Matthew Dowd
column5: a top strategist for former president George W. Bush’s 2000 and 2004 campaigns. “Then it comes down to ‘Are there credible solutions and is there a credible candidate?’ ”

column1: About 45 million Americans live at or below the poverty line
column2: according to last fall’s census estimates
column3: while the median household income in the United States in 2013 was just under $52
column4: 000. Adjusted for inflation
column5: the median is 8 percent lower than it was in 2007
column6: the last full year before the recession
column7: and 11 percent below what it was in 2000.

column1: Wage stagnation has been a persistent problem for low- and middle-income workers. “Since the late 1970s
column2: wages for the bottom 70 percent of earners have been essentially stagnant
column3: and between 2009 and 2013
column4: real ­wages fell for the entire bottom 90 percent of the wage distribution
column5: ” Lawrence Mishel of the liberal Economic Policy Institute wrote in a paper published this month.

column1: Launching his new political action committee
column2: Right to Rise
column3: Jeb Bush asserted last week in the PAC’s mission statement that President Obama’s tenure has been “pretty good” for those at the top of the income scale but a “lost decade” for everyone else.

column1: “Millions of our fellow citizens across the broad middle class feel as if the American Dream is now out of their reach; that our politics are petty and broken; that opportunities are elusive; and that the playing field is no longer fair or level
column2: ” Bush wrote. “Too many of the poor have lost hope that a path to a better life is within their grasp.”

column1: Bush’s focus adds an unexpected element to the coming debate and puts pressure on the entire field
column2: himself included
column3: to come forward with fresh policies that address the nation’s core economic problems.

column1: The shift also highlights a potential vulnerability for Democrats. In his campaigns
column2: Obama twice promised to focus on wealth inequality and middle-class stagnation
column3: but those problems persist even as the economy revs up and unemployment falls.

column1: Clinton could be challenged now from both the right and the left to lay out solutions that go beyond Obama’s — and also to develop a political voice of her own to articulate them. Democrats conceded after last fall’s midterm elections that they had not found a compelling economic message.
Democrats will look to Clinton
column2: should she run
column3: to take the lead in doing that — although they also are looking to Sen. Elizabeth Warren (D-Mass.) and her harder-edged populist rhetoric.

column1: Clinton tested such a message last year. In a major speech at the New America Foundation in May
column2: she said that Americans are “finding it harder than ever to get their footing in our changing economy. The dream of upward mobility that made this country a model for the world feels further and further out of reach.”

column1: The language of Bush
column2: Rubio and other Republicans appears aimed at avoiding the problem that bedeviled Romney throughout his 2012 campaign. The former Massachusetts governor’s memorable comment about the “47 percent” of the population who he said depend on government and feel like victims haunted him during the final months before the election.

column1: Yuval Levin
column2: editor of the conservative journal National Affairs
column3: said the overall shift in emphasis by Republicans is an effort to move away from Romney’s more abstract message of job growth and to focus more specifically on social mobility and solutions for those at or near the bottom.

column1: “It’s a process of letting the light out from under the bushel
column2: ” Levin said. Citing past conservative leadership in reforming welfare
column3: he added: “I think Republican ideas have always held this promise
column4: but conservatives have not always emphasized these elements. . . . A difference in emphasis is not insignificant.”

column1: Democrats
column2: however
column3: argue that revising their rhetoric will not be enough for Republicans — especially if Jeb Bush becomes the GOP nominee — to gloss over former president George W. Bush’s legacy
column4: which Democrats say tightened the middle-class squeeze.

column1: “It’s not like the Republican Party has clean hands on the issue of rising inequality
column2: ” said Neera Tanden
column3: president of the Center for American Progress and an adviser to Clinton on economic policy. “It’s a weird thing to say
column4: ‘I care about how the rest of the country is doing
column5: not just the top earners
column6: ’ when your brother cut taxes for the wealthy and your party’s economic position starts with undoing Dodd-Frank
column7: ” the 2010 law that tightened regulation of Wall Street.

column1: Obama hit the road last week to highlight economic successes of his presidency
column2: from the auto industry bailout to more robust overall growth in the last half of 2014. Still
column3: many Democrats acknowledge that there is a large gap between promise and results on issues of middle-class insecurities.

column1: That is where Bush and some other Republicans are taking aim. Two factors have contributed to the opening they see.

One is the continued problem of stagnating wages for the broad middle class and the income gap between rich and non-rich. The other is new evidence that it has become harder for those at the bottom to rise into the middle class
column2: and that the risk of some born into the middle class — particularly minorities — falling out of it is growing.

column1: Democrats long have been seen as the party more trusted to deal with middle-class economic issues. Republicans long have resisted policies that smack of economic redistribution. Could that be changing?
“How do you tell the middle class
column2: ‘We’re your guy?’ ” said Grover Norquist
column3: a conservative anti-tax advocate. “Republicans feel comfortable saying that now because they feel the guys they’re running against are sufficiently discredited.”

column1: William Galston of the Brookings Institution said that the issue of blocked social mobility is one Republicans will feel more comfortable engaging — and on their own terms. “That’s what Jeb Bush is saying: ‘We can accept a definition of a problem . . . but give unabashedly conservative responses to those challenges
column2: ’ ” he said.

column1: But Galston
column2: a former domestic policy adviser to President Bill Clinton
column3: said Bush’s framing of the issue this way means he has put down a marker that he will be expected to meet.

column1: “I would expect to hear from him over the coming months some of the best and most innovative conservative thinking on opportunity and upward mobility
column2: ” he said. “That will be a fair test on how much gas there is in the conservative ideas tank.”

column1: Other Republicans have been working to reorient their party toward blue-collar economics and to put forward fresh economic ideas. Former senator Rick Santorum of Pennsylvania and former Arkansas governor Mike Huckabee
column2: two former presidential candidates who are looking at running in 2016
column3: long have talked about the GOP’s need to recognize the problems of working families.

column1: House Ways and Means Committee Chairman Paul Ryan (R-Wis.) has focused on policies designed to lift people out of poverty. In 2012
column2: as Romney’s running mate
column3: Ryan wanted to campaign in inner cities and give speeches promoting individual empowerment. He was frustrated that Romney’s campaign team directed him to talk about other topics.

column1: Rubio has proposed a fundamental shift in anti-poverty programs. He has suggested devolving power and responsibility from Washington to the states by consolidating federal monies into a “flex fund.” The senator from Florida has called for significant reductions in federal regulations that he says will spur creation of better jobs. On education
column2: he has offered a series of reforms designed to lessen the burden of student loan debt and expand access to apprenticeship programs. Rubio and others also have proposed changes in the earned-income tax credit to extend its reach to more people.

column1: Democrats are skeptical that Republicans can meet the challenge with policy proposals that are much beyond calls for tax cuts to spur economic growth and further efforts to scale back the size of government.
“It sounds to me like a ­traditional Romney Republican ­trickle-down agenda but with a willingness to engage on inequality and mobility
column2: ” said Jared Bernstein
column3: a former adviser to Vice President Biden who works at the Center of Budget and Policy Priorities.

column1: Democrats say it’s too early to draw conclusions
column2: but they note that if Bush and other Republicans find new ways to engage middle-class voters with populist themes
column3: the pressures on Clinton will mount significantly.

column1: “Voters are going to [say]
column2: ‘Okay
column3: thank you for acknowledging this problem
column4: but what are you going to do about it?’ ” Bernstein said. “I would argue that Democrats are going to have to have more in their toolbox than [raising the] minimum wage and universal pre-K.”"	REAL

220 ‘Significant’ Pipeline Spills Already This Year Exposes Troubling Safety Record	"By Dan Zukowski
Three major U.S. pipeline spills within the last month are just a small part of the 220 significant incidents reported so far this year—and 3
column2: 032 since 2006—that provide a stark reminder of the environmental hazards of an aging pipeline infrastructure carrying fossil fuels. The costs of these leaks since 2006 has amounted to $4.7 billion.

column1: 1. Oklahoma: On Oct. 24
column2: the 30-inch S-1 pipeline carrying crude oil from the critical Cushing
column3: Oklahoma hub to refineries and chemical plants on the Gulf Coast began to leak and was shut down overnight. It was the second release connected with the Cushing storage facility in less than a month.

column1: 2. Pennsylvania: On Oct. 21
column3: 000 gallons of gasoline gushed from a ruptured Sunoco Logistics pipeline in Williamsport
column4: Pennsylvania
column5: just upstream from the Susquehanna River. Carol Parenzan
column6: Middle Susquehanna Riverkeeper
column7: said that witnesses who contacted her office reported that the “smell of petroleum is so thick you can taste it.” The 80-year old pipeline was damaged by a heavy storm that dumped seven inches of rain on the area.

column1: 3. Alabama: Last month
column2: the Colonial Pipeline in Alabama leaked an estimated 336
column3: 000 gallons of gasoline and triggered concerns about gas shortages for drivers in the East. That spill was Colonial’s fifth in the state this year and occurred on a 43-year old section of the pipeline.

column1: Based on data from the Pipeline and Hazardous Materials Safety Administration (PHMSA)
column2: an arm of the U.S. Department of Transportation
column3: the number of significant pipeline incidents grew 26.8 percent from 2006 to 2015. A significant incident is defined as one that results in serious injury or fatality
column4: costs more than $50
column6: releases more than five barrels of volatile fluids such as gasoline or 50 barrels of other liquids
column7: or results in a fire or explosion. In 2015
column8: there were 326 such incidents—almost one per day.

column1: Some 55 percent of the U.S. network of 135
column2: 000 miles of pipeline is more than 45 years old. Technology designed to detect pipeline leaks is highly unreliable
column3: even though companies like Colonial Pipeline tout their use as a way “to insure safe operations.” But a recent Reuters report found that these technologies are “about as successful as a random member of the public” finding a leak. Of 466 incidents studied by Reuters
column4: only 22 percent
column5: or 105
column6: were detected by advanced detection systems. The others were found in different ways
column7: with the public finding 99 of the leaks.

column1: In testimony before a House subcommittee earlier this year
column2: Carl Weimer
column3: executive director of the watchdog group Pipeline Safety Trust
column4: said
column5: “Under the current statutes there is no requirement that a pipeline company obtain any permit or permission to operate a pipeline in this country.” Weimer called on Congress to require PHMSA to issue permits for interstate transmission pipelines and ensure that the company follow all rules and regulations.

column1: “It is important that we not only maintain our aging energy infrastructure
column2: but that we also remain vigilant about new pipelines and energy interests that threaten water quality
column3: ” said Parenzan.

column1: Dan Zukowski — Environmental journalist and nature photographer. Member
column2: Society of Environmental Journalists. Follow me on Twitter @DanZukowski and visit DBZ Photo

column1: Source: EcoWatch

Obama makes the right call to tough it out in Afghanistan	The president now plans to continue a U.S. ground force presence in Afghanistan to help hold off the Taliban until he leaves office. This is an uncommon turnaround for a president who hasn’t changed his mind on foreign policy since drawing his (much-ballyhooed and promptly ignored) “red line” in Syria.
So what does this rare shift have to say about Obama’s foreign policy and America’s future role in Afghanistan? Not much.
Mr. Obama started his presidency hoping to use Afghanistan to demonstrate his willingness to roll up his sleeves and get his hands dirty in the national security business. He asserted that
column2: unlike “Bush’s War” in Iraq

column1: In approving a surge in Afghanistan

column3: even as he sent in more troops

column1: The president gave commanders only half the force and half the time they requested to do the job right. It turned out
column2: the commanders were right.  Mr. Obama
column3: however
column4: had his eye on the next election and wanted to go into the race showing he had put the war on a glide-path to wind down and pull out.

column1: Signaling a limited-time interest in fighting an enemy rarely ends well. The Taliban adopted the logical and predictable strategy of simply waiting out Mr. Obama. Also predictably

column4: and a shaky security situation.

column1: Nevertheless

column1: Which is why Mr. Obama is reportedly backing away from his plan to yank virtually all U.S. troops out of Afghanistan by the end of next year. Instead

column3: 800 troops in place throughout “most” of next year

column1: It’s a good call. With the Taliban flexing its muscles anew and the Islamic State making inroads there

column5: Pakistan

column7: our NATO allies— wants the U.S. to stay and see the job through.

column1: In addition

column3: presidential candidates have devoted about as much time to Afghanistan as they have to defunding Public Television.

column1: It makes complete sense for Mr. Obama to tough it out in Afghanistan

column1: But holding on is probably the best we can hope for with this president.  Here’s hoping the next Commander in Chief’s attitude toward Afghanistan will focus more on solving problems than just wishing they would go away.

column1: American politics has reached peak polarization	"For a long time in American politics
column2: we've been trapped in a cycle of ever-escalating political polarization. As measured by voting patterns in the US Congress
column3: the two parties have pulled apart to distances we've never seen before. As measured by consistent partisan positioning among voters
column4: the split in the electorate has reached a historic level of divisiveness.

column1: But this is about to end. We've now hit peak polarization. The forces that have fueled the widening gap between the two political parties are now fueling fights within the two political parties
column2: fights that will lead to new coalitions in American politics
column3: eventually realigning the two parties. A new era of American politics is about to emerge.

column1: The tautological reason polarization has increased in American politics is that over the past four decades
column2: conflict in American politics has increasingly operated along a single dimension: Republican versus Democrat. A large number of issues that were once nonpartisan or non-ideological have become partisan issues. Almost every policy has now been swept into the maw of partisan jockeying
column3: leaving almost no space for the cross-partisan cooperation our political system relies on to function.

column1: In order for congressional polarization to persist
column2: both parties have to maintain tight enough discipline over their members and the political agenda to ensure consistent party voting. And in order for public polarization to persist
column3: parties have to maintain tight enough message discipline among their elites to ensure that their voters only hear one main message.

column1: This is breaking down. Republicans are now in open warfare between Trump supporters and #NeverTrumpers. Democrats are far less divided
column2: but internal rifts between their ""establishment"" (Hillary Clinton) and ""insurgent"" (Bernie Sanders) wings are also real and likely lasting.

column1: This conflict is emerging on issues of international trade
column2: on questions of corporate (especially Wall Street) power
column3: and in growing anger over money in politics and corruption generally. In short
column4: parties are increasingly divided on a growing range of issues that pit their less-educated
column5: lower-income voters who feel left behind by the current political-economic system against their better-educated
column6: higher-income voter who don't want to mess too much with the status quo. These conflicts are not going away anytime soon.

column1: This moment is the culmination of four interconnected but ultimately unsustainable trends that have turbocharged polarization over the last two decades:
Close competition fueled partisan nastiness and increased the demand for campaign money. The demand for campaign money made the parties more dependent on wealthy donors
column2: which made them less responsive to their voters. This lack of responsiveness provided plenty of evidence for corruption and the felt sense that politics was broken
column3: which fueled anger. Both parties attempted to channel this anger against the other party to distract from their own failures and contradictions and win elections by rendering the other party toxic. This exacerbated the sense that politics was broken and corrupt.

column1: These trends created contradictions
column2: and now these contradictions have created openings. Ambitious candidates who could get past their parties' campaign finance gatekeepers had a lot of angry and left-behind voters eager for their message. And this is precisely what Sanders and especially Donald Trump have accomplished. Now there is no going back.

column1: These are big claims. So let's flesh this story out a little more
column2: this time with expanded detail.

column1: The story could go all the way back to the decisive election of 1932
column2: when Democrats became the dominant party in American politics for a generation
column3: holding together a big-tent New Deal coalition that included Southern pro-segregationists with Northern urban progressives. But it was an uneasy alliance that could only last as long as civil rights legislation was bottled up. Then in 1964
column4: the Democrats decidedly became the party of civil rights. And as Lyndon Johnson allegedly acknowledged upon signing the 1964 Civil Rights Act
column5: the Democrats ""have lost the South for a generation.""

column1: Democrats had controlled the South ever since Republican-led Reconstruction (since Republicans were the party of Lincoln and of Reconstruction). But as Republicans came to be the party better aligned with the South on issues of race
column2: conservative Republicans replaced conservative Democrats in Southern House and Senate seats
column3: starting in the 1980s. By 1995
column4: when Republicans won the House for the first time in 40 years
column5: this transition was mostly complete. By 2011
column6: it was absolute and total.

column1: As this all happened
column2: the ideological center of the Republican Party moved to the South
column3: fusing social and economic conservatism. Northern liberal Republicans were marginalized and soon endangered. Democrats
column4: meanwhile
column5: lost their Southern
column6: conservative wing
column7: and the ideological center of the Democratic Party moved to the coasts and big cities
column8: fusing social and economic liberalism.

column1: As the parties became less internally diverse
column2: individual members of Congress delegated more power to their party leaders. After all
column3: they all now basically agreed on the issues. And they wanted leaders who could punish disloyal dissenters and control the agenda. So when Newt Gingrich took over the speakership in 1995
column4: he centralized power in the position in a way it had not been centralized since 1910.

column1: In the 1990s
column2: American politics entered a somewhat unusual period of remarkably close two-party competition for control of the House and the Senate.

column1: This
column2: as political scientist Frances Lee explains
column3: has been the catalyst for a very nasty brand of partisan fighting.

column1: This seems exactly right to me
column2: and there's lots of evidence to prove it.

column1: But not only has this close competition fueled partisanship by turning legislating into zero-sum trench warfare
column2: it has also turbocharged the fundraising dimension of political campaigning.

column1: Parties are campaigning harder than ever to win over those swing seats
column2: and this has meant raising ever-expanding sums of money. And in order to raise this money
column3: both parties have had to lean more and more on their wealthiest donors.

column1: But relying on these wealthy donors created a problem for both parties. On many issues
column2: particularly economic issues
column3: wealthy elites hold separate opinions from most voters.

column1: Major Republican donors generally want fiscal austerity
column2: and particularly a rolled-back welfare state. They also tend to be much more pro-immigration and pro–free trade than Republican voters
column3: and not particularly worried about social issues. But schemes like privatizing Social Security and voucherizing Medicare have never been all that popular with actual Republican voters. And as the middle classes' wages have stagnated
column4: especially for those without college degrees
column5: and the share of foreign-born residents in the US has reached levels not seen since the 1920s (it hit 13.9 percent in 2015)
column6: the voting constituency for anti-immigration populism has grown considerably.

column1: Democratic donors are somewhat more economically liberal. But they are not about to support Sanders-style socialism. They prefer Clinton's generally pro-market views. They will tolerate some regulation of business
column2: but not that much
column3: particularly when it's the tech and new economy businesses that they run and invest in.

column1: Whereas Democrats once relied on labor unions to get out the vote
column2: by the 1990s unions could no longer provide the support Democrats needed. Democrats instead moved to depend on the ""professional class
column3: deprioritizing workers' concerns to focus instead on the social and environmental concerns that went over much better in Hollywood and San Francisco and Manhattan fundraisers.

column1: For a while
column2: both parties could manage these contradictions
column3: being responsive to their donors while pooh-poohing the economic concerns of their less affluent voters on the bland promise that a thriving economy was good for everyone. And for much of the 1990s and 2000s
column4: the economy was doing okay
column5: which generally kept voters from feeling too angry. And to the extent that individual voters weren't benefiting
column6: it was
column7: of course
column8: the other party's fault.

column1: As long as both sides were focused on the evils of the other side
column2: and the economy was not in a major recession
column3: party leaders could get away with ignoring many of their voters
column4: and using the campaign contribution proceeds to make their case through more and more negative political advertising and aggressive media messaging.

column1: This negativity translated into what political scientists Alan Abramowitz and Steven Webster call ""negative partisanship."" As they explain:
All these interrelated trends have turbocharged polarization over the last two decades. But they relied on both sides being able to control the anger that they were stoking
column2: and on both sides being able to convince their voters that all of the corruption and fecklessness in Washington was because of the other party. This could not go on indefinitely.

column1: In fall 2008 the financial crisis hit
column2: and the government bailed out the big Wall Street banks in a very public way. For many
column3: this served as the decisive proof that things really were rigged: Washington and Wall Street were in a corrupt alliance
column4: a conspiracy of career politicians and crony capitalists and lobbyists who were rolling in the money and laughing about it while everyone else was living paycheck to paycheck. As the economy stumbled through recession and then a jobless recovery
column5: economic insecurity and political resentment increased.

column1: Obama and the Democrats swept the 2008 election on the strength of anti-Bush feeling and the timeless energy of hope and change. For the first time since 1992
column2: Democrats had unified control in Washington; Republicans were now out in the cold.

column1: With their backs against the wall and Democrats as the new Washington establishment
column2: Republicans now turned their anti-government rhetoric up to 11. Obama was Stalin. Obama was Hitler. Obama was a Kenyan-born Muslim bent on destroying America. Democrats responded to the charges with signature big-government legislation that taxed the middle class so that poor people could have government-subsidized health care. The Republican base went crazy. All their worst fears were confirmed.
the Tea Party emerged
column3: representing what felt like new anti-establishment radicalism but was really just the culmination of decades of Republican anti-government rhetoric now freed from any institutional responsibility for actually governing. In 2010
column4: on the strength of Tea Party anti-Obama energy (and the fact that Democrats had won a bunch of majority Republican House districts in 2006 and 2008)
column5: Republicans swept back into control of the House. In the 2014 election
column6: they finally won back the Senate.

column1: But then nothing happened. Obamacare
column2: the devil piñata of every Republican attack
column3: was neither repealed nor replaced. Worse
column4: Republican leaders were negotiating with Obama
column5: Satan himself. They were letting Obama get away with an executive order on immigration. Here was the most corrupt
column6: most crony capitalist administration in history
column7: and what were Republicans in Congress doing? They were rolling over and being just as corrupt!

column1: In June 2015
column2: Donald Trump announced he was running for president and became the immediate frontrunner on the strength of his aggressive anti-immigration stance. Because he had his own money and his own media celebrity
column3: Trump did not need to do the pro-austerity
column4: pro-immigration
column5: pro-free trade dance that other potential frontrunners had done to shake the big donor GOP money tree. He could just run for president
column6: declaring everything was corrupt and he was the only one you could trust because he was the only one who didn't have a super PAC. And he could speak to the working-class Republican voters who had been left behind in this economy
column7: by saying he'd go after China and give them Social Security and Medicare and go after the corrupt hedge fund rip-off artists.

column1: And they loved it. For decades
column2: they had been told
column3: for partisan reasons
column4: to be angry; they had been told
column5: for partisan reasons
column6: that Washington was corrupt
column7: and that all Washington politicians were evil. Now they finally had somebody who could say those things while actually not embodying any telltale signs of the sins. They also had somebody who could finally and authentically call out all the ""corrupt"" things Republican establishment types themselves were doing.

column1: A few months later
column2: in September
column3: Republican Speaker John Boehner announced he would resign from Congress
column4: responding to efforts by the House Freedom Caucus to force him out. This was the first time since 1910 that an insurgent faction in the House had successfully challenged a sitting speaker. The anti-establishment anger that Republicans had courted had now finally turned on its leaders.

column1: On the Democratic side
column2: anti-Clinton progressives were hoping to draft Elizabeth Warren
column3: who had demonstrated her anti-establishment bona fides in December 2014
column4: sinking Obama's appointment of Wall Street banker Antonio Weiss for a top Treasury position (Weiss withdrew his nomination
column5: instead accepting a counselor position to Secretary Jack Lew). Warren had also been a prominent opponent of Obama's major Asian free trade agreement.

column1: But Warren didn't run. Instead
column2: it was self-identified socialist Bernie Sanders who found the opening. Democratic donor gatekeepers had cleared the field for Hillary. This meant Sanders could get attention just for being the only real alternative
column3: attention that he was able to snowball into a following. Sanders won't win the nomination. But he has done far
column4: far better than anybody ever expected
column5: because a sizable number of Democrat voters share his view that politics is a rigged game where the billionaires and the crony capitalists always win. And like Sanders
column6: they are sick and tired of it.

column1: If you briefly scroll back to the top of this article and look at the graph of polarization over time
column2: you'll see a previous peak around 1910 or so. While historical analogies are never perfect
column3: there are some notable similarities between now and around 1910.

column1: For one
column2: 1910 was the last time a sitting speaker of the US House had been effectively challenged from within the party. Second
column3: in 1912 the Republican Party was so divided over its presidential nomination that the party splintered
column4: with about half of Republicans supporting Howard Taft (the incumbent) and about half supporting Teddy Roosevelt (the previous incumbent). Democrat Woodrow Wilson won in a landslide.

column1: Around 1910 was also when the last great anti-establishment movement in America
column2: the progressive movement
column3: emerged in response to growing concentrations of wealth and political power
column4: concentrations that many Americans felt had left them behind. As political scientist Grant McConnell once wrote of ""the progressive legacy
column5: it consisted of a ""charges made against virtually all the institutions of American society"" with ""one common theme — corruption. ... Corruption of such prevalence
column6: disorder of such magnitude could only be explained by something more than the assumption of a slow-spreading decay. The theory of conspiracy was ready at hand and in one way or another it was invoked as an explanation."" This resonates with today's anti-establishment mood.

column1: Political scientist Hans Noel has argued that the emergence of the progressive movement ""crosscut the parties and eventually reshaped them."" Noel notes that progressives opposed existing authority structures
column2: both economically (e.g.
column3: the ""trusts"") and politically (they disliked political parties and other authority structures).

column2: it was progressive Republican George Norris who led the internal House revolt against Speaker Joe Cannon
column3: stripping Cannon of most of his authority and devolving considerable powers back to individual members
column4: who had increasingly chafed under their marginalization. Like John Boehner in 2015
column5: Cannon in 1910 represented the culmination of exactly 20 years of increasingly centralized leadership control in the House speakership. Just as Gingrich had radically centralized control in 1995
column6: Speaker Thomas Reed had radically centralized control in 1890.

column1: Parties depolarized in the 1910s and 1920s because
column2: freed of centralized leadership structures
column3: more legislating happened in committees
column4: where a cross-cutting progressive coalition could more freely operate independently of the two parties. Interestingly
column5: trade policy also became much less polarized in the 1920s
column6: with cross-party coalitions on tariff issues.

column1: Most likely
column2: Trump will be the Republican nominee. Even if the #NeverTrump forces somehow wrest the nomination from him (unlikely
column3: but possible)
column4: the anti-establishment forces in the Republican Party are not going away. If not Trump (though my guess is he will stick around for a while longer)
column5: somebody in the Tea Party
column6: or possibly even Ted Cruz
column7: will find a way to harness the Trump voters by following the Trump issues playbook. Where there are voters to be had
column8: there are politicians to have them.

column1: Meanwhile
column2: in Congress
column3: House Speaker Paul Ryan is already having difficulty building consensus around a budget process. No matter how many speeches he gives about the importance of decorum in politics
column4: it seems increasingly unlikely that he can reconcile the conflicts that Boehner failed to resolve
column5: which means he will have to eventually lean on Democrats to pass a budget and
column6: like Boehner before him
column7: alienate some of his party. Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell
column8: much less beloved even within his party
column9: will face similar problems.

column1: Most likely
column2: Hillary Clinton will become the 45th US president (she has led in every single head-to-head poll against Trump). And most likely she will use her agenda-setting powers to try to force the Republicans into open civil war by pushing many of the issues that already divide them
column3: especially immigration and trade. Clinton's natural home is in the pro-business center
column4: a position that will be advantageous to her and Democrats in the short term at least. But she has to be cautious. Emboldened by Sanders and by Elizabeth Warren
column5: the progressive wing of the Democrats is growing
column6: and will be unhappy with Clinton's pro-business instincts.

column1: The internal fights will continue in both parties. The competing wings of both parties will feel that they are the true Republicans/Democrats. The growing importance of outside
column2: non-party groups in elections will also force ideological diversity onto the parties. Party leaders might instinctually want to wrest power back from these outside groups
column3: but they'd be wiser to open up their tent to allow for different ideas. After all
column4: the party that does best in American politics is always the one that can build the broadest coalition
column5: which means accepting ideological diversity.

column1: Eventually
column2: congressional leaders will realize (or be forced to realize) that the only leadership style that works is a less centralized
column3: more committee-driven approach. This is the only way ideologically heterogeneous parties can effectively govern. A more decentralized Congress
column4: with more fluid coalitions
column5: will function better
column6: assuming that a more committee-driven process is also accompanied by increases in congressional staffing capacity. Partisan control of Congress will mean less
column7: since there will be more cross-party coalitions.

column1: Many issues
column2: like gun rights or affirmative action
column3: will remain very partisan. But other issues
column4: especially those of corporate/Wall Street power
column5: antitrust
column6: interventionist foreign policy
column7: will likely split the parties. Trump Republicans and Sanders Democrats will find common cause against establishment centrists. Big organized interests
column8: like the Chamber of Commerce and other corporate groups
column9: will align less closely with Republicans
column10: realizing that their future success will require the right mix of Republicans and Democrats to advance their agendas.

column1: And as the parties become more ideological diverse
column2: voters
column3: who are generally more ideologically all over the place than the current party alignment would suggest
column4: will identify less reliably with one or the other
column5: since there will be more for them in both parties. They will again sometimes split their tickets
column6: depending on who is running. Many will feel more passionate about individual issues and will align themselves with supporters of those issues in both parties
column7: especially as individual interest groups become cross-partisan in order to achieve policy outcomes. In that respect
column8: politics will come to look more like it did in the 1950s and 1970s
column9: when liberal Republicans existed alongside conservative Democrats.

column1: This is an optimistic scenario.
But it only works if party leaders tolerate diversity within their party and allow disagreements.
Another scenario is that establishment Republicans banish the Trump faction and Democrats banish the Sanders faction after the 2016 elections
column2: and both parties go back to the predictable and intractable trench warfare battle lines that have become increasingly dug in over the past two decades
column3: using nastier and nastier tactics to subvert internal divisions in service of the larger fight against a common enemy. This may be possible for a little while longer (especially if the economy improves significantly)
column4: but it is still probably long-term unsustainable for reasons I've described above. It also may mean that 2020 becomes an even more violent and nasty election.

column1: Another possibility is that the parties realign quickly
column2: with the Trump/Tea Party faction effecting a rapid transformation of the Republican Party into a downscale nationalist populist party
column3: pushing the remaining upper-class moderate Republicans into a more pro-business Democratic Party
column4: which in turn pushes some disaffected Sanders voters into the Republican Party. If this realignment happens too quickly
column5: there is no period of depolarization. But this seems unlikely
column6: given the stickiness of partisan identity and the strong disagreements between the two parties on a whole range of other issues.

column1: Other scenarios are possible as well
column2: especially if there are significant global crises.

column1: But here's the bottom line: Something is different this year in American politics. The logic that has operated for the past two decades or so is breaking down
column2: largely because the factors and trends that propelled it produced unsustainable contradictions. American politics is now entering a new logic
column3: with new trends and forces that will push the lines of political conflict in directions we are only beginning to understand.

column1: This feels like chaos
column2: and it is. But it is also good news
column3: because chaos scrambles the rules. We've hit peak polarization. Politics is slowly coming unstuck. A period of new possibilities awaits.

column1: This post is part of Polyarchy
column2: an independent blog produced by the political reform program at New America
column3: a Washington think tank devoted to developing new ideas and new voices. See more Polyarchy posts here."	REAL

column1: Anti-Muhammad cartoon contest: Free speech or deliberately provocative? (+video)	"Sponsors say that the shootings in Garland
column2: Texas
column3: confirm their view of Islam as violence-prone. But critics say the event was designed to be incendiary and to poison relations at a volatile time.

column1: When Pamela Geller and her controversial organization
column2: the American Freedom Defense Initiative
column3: announced it would hold a cartoon contest in Garland
column4: Texas
column5: their plan to satirize and lampoon the founder of Islam was intended to have both a defiant and provocative free-speech edge.

column1: Sunday’s contest and its $10
column2: 000 prize were prompted in part by the Paris Charlie Hebdo massacre in January
column3: Ms. Geller said in March
column4: as well as the riots in Muslim countries sparked by the publication of satirical anti-Muhammad cartoons by a Danish newspaper in 2005. And indeed
column5: as if on cue
column6: two gunmen with apparent ties to Islamic militants overseas tried to storm the heavily secured event in a similar fashion
column7: before being shot dead by a local police officer Sunday night.

column1: The incident comes at a time when tensions between some segments of American society and Muslims appear to be becoming more fraught – with protests against Muslims in Texas and anti-Muslim social-media attacks after the release of the film ""American Sniper."" In that context
column2: Geller's actions raise questions about speech seen by many as motivated to incite anger and hatred.

column1: It is an issue Geller has faced before. Two weeks ago
column2: she won a federal free-speech case against New York’s Metropolitan Transportation Authority
column3: which had refused to put up one of her ads: “Killing Jews is Worship that draws us close to Allah” – a quote the ad attributes to “Hamas MTV.”

column1: Geller’s organization has often clashed with officials in other cities
column2: including Philadelphia and Washington
column3: over their incendiary ads
column4: some of which compare Islam to Nazism. In 2012
column5: another federal judge ruled that cities could not refuse to post her subway poster that read: “In any war between the civilized man and the savage
column6: support the civilized man. Support Israel. Defeat Jihad.”

column1: Many supporters of Geller and her organization view the violence on Sunday as a vindication of their views of Islam as an inherently violence-prone religion. But for others
column2: her relentless campaign to push the boundaries of free speech with intentionally incendiary messages is only poisoning public discourse at a particularly volatile time.

column1: “And coming as it did right when we
column2: the United States of America
column3: are really facing a time when we have to question what it is that holds us together
column4: I can see this potentially aggravating the already-challenging times for dealing with some of these questions about cultural difference
column5: diversity
column6: and what kind of society we want to be
column7: ” says Gordon Coonfield
column8: director of graduate studies in communication at Villanova University near Philadelphia.

column1: After analyzing some of the submissions to the American Freedom Defense Initiative’s “Muhammad Art Exhibit and Cartoon Contest
column2: ” Professor Coonfield pointed out the similarities of some of the depictions of the prophet Muhammad to posters for “Der Ewige Jude
column3: ” or “The Eternal Jew
column4: ” a notorious Nazi propaganda “documentary.”

column1: In one of the cartoons
column2: the prophet is depicted as contorted and snarling and as a hook-nosed man in a turban holding a bloody knife. The caption reads
column3: “When it comes to religion ... I’ve got the edge.” The face
column4: Coonfield notes
column5: is nearly identical to the contorted face of “The Eternal Jew” poster.

column1: “That strategy for creating a sense of ‘unity’ by lifting up this internal enemy is as old as human civilization and culture
column2: ” he says. “It’s ironic that the kind of thinking that Hitler used
column3: and the Nazis have become famous for using – propaganda to try to create this sense of a collective by creating a strong unquestionably evil Other who is right here in our midst ... so it’s kind of ironic that she’s trying to link some of these things together
column4: when that is in fact her message.”

column1: Despite the fact that images depicting the prophet Muhammad cut deeply to the heart of Muslim identity
column2: Muslim leaders in Texas told their followers not to picket or protest the event on Sunday.

column1: “Her words are not just free speech
column2: ” says Linda Sarsour
column3: executive director of the Arab American Association of New York. “They are inciteful; they incite hate against our whole community. I was very dismayed by the shooting in Garland
column4: Texas
column5: but at the same time
column6: Pamela Geller is not the victim in this situation that we’re in right now.”

column1: “She intentionally put that event together in hopes that she’d get the response that she received
column2: ” Ms. Sarsour says.

column1: “We prayed
column2: but not one Muslim from the state of Texas went out to protest her
column3: ” she added. “Muslim leaders specifically told people
column4: do not go anywhere near her. Let her do whatever she does. We don’t care. And there was no protesting outside – unfortunately
column5: except for these two guys from Arizona
column6: who were already on the radar of the FBI anyway.”

column1: Advocates have tried to counter Geller’s free political expressions with ad campaigns of a different tone. In 2012
column2: a coalition called Rabbis for Human Rights responded to her “support the civilized man” poster with an opposing message that read
column3: “In the choice between love and hate
column4: choose love. Help stop bigotry against our Muslim neighbors.”

column1: And last week
column2: the makers of the satirical film “The Muslims Are Coming!” launched a humorous series of subway and bus ads to counter Geller's. “The Muslims are coming
column3: and they shall strike with hugs so fierce
column4: you’ll end up calling your grandmother and telling her that you love her.”

column1: But in an era in which the Islamic State
column2: the Tsarnaev trial
column3: and the lingering aftermath of 9/11 still inflame fears about Islam
column4: many worry that Sunday’s violence will exacerbate the current tensions.

column1: “Free speech is about being open to listening to the ideas you hate the most
column2: that you disagree with the most
column3: and I feel this group in particular is hiding behind this free speech rhetoric
column4: ” Coonfield says. “This can’t become the poster child for Christianity versus Islam or the West versus the Middle East. We have to maintain a space where groups that have very different ways of thinking and viewing the world can still come together to talk about it
column5: without resorting to this kind of craziness.”"	REAL

column10: it became clear that the Fed was going to raise the FF rate at the December 2015 meeting come hell or high water. And they did. However
column11: take a close look at how gold traded in the days and weeks between the Oct15 FOMC and the December rate hike. Price fell from $1180 to $1050 in about five weeks but note that it bottomed well in advance of the actual “news” of the FF rate hike. column15: 000. Just five weeks later

column18: 911 contracts NET short. We even speculated at the time that there were some days
column19: intraweek

column22: as you know

column27: but it doesn’t seem ready just yet to begin moving consistently higher. In 2015

column1: Closed primaries, 'warped' democracy?	"Political parties choose their presidential nominees. But with more Americans opting out of parties
column2: is the process representative of what America wants? The New York primary – and others ahead – offer insights.

column1: How SNL's 'the bubble' sketch about polarization is all too true

Democratic presidential candidate Sen. Bernie Sanders speaks to supporter Michael Cantalupo while taking a walk in New York's Times Square Tuesday. Mr. Cantalupo said he is unable to vote in the New York primaries
Denise Guardascione
column2: a waitress for nearly three decades at the Shalimar Diner in Queens
column3: thinks the New York primary process was rigged.

column1: She’s a vocal supporter of Republican front-runner Donald Trump
column2: but as a registered Democrat
column3: Ms. Guardascione missed the deadline to switch her registration to become a Republican – which
column4: shocking to her
column5: was more than six months ago.

column1: And now
column2: the independent-minded waitress has become bewildered by what seems to be the complicated
column3: back-room system of electing party delegates both in her own state and across the country.

column1: “It’s antiquated
column2: it belongs in the Smithsonian
column3: next to Archie Bunker’s chair!” says Ms. Guardascione
column4: a Queens native who works six days a week slinging eggs and coffee for this well-known political haunt. “It’s just for the [expletive] bigwigs and muckety mucks
column5: not us
column6: not the people who just want to vote.”

column1: In truth
column2: presidential primaries have never been more open. Since 1972
column3: primaries have gone from being the province of party bosses to vibrant voter-driven contests. But in this year of populist revolt in both parties
column4: “more open” looks to many voters like “still pretty antiquated.”

column1: That is by design. Parties
column2: after all
column3: are not democratic. They can choose their nominees in whichever way they think is best. But at a time when Democrats and Republicans are a shrinking share of the population
column4: closed primaries are shutting more and more of America out.

column1: The irony is that America is no less partisan. Research suggests the growing ranks of independents are just as partisan as the parties. These voters have just abandoned parties because they are ashamed by how the parties act.
The anger over closed primaries
column2: superdelegates
column3: and convention arcana isn’t likely to help. (Nor are allegations of irregularities in the New York primary. On Thursday
column4: the state's Elections Board suspended the top official in charge of Brooklyn after numerous allegations
column5: the most serious of which is that 125
column6: 000 Democratic voters were incorrectly purged from the rolls before polls opened.)

column1: The question is
column2: whether the spotlight of this election could force further change ahead
column3: both in states and in the nation.

column1: “New York and other states have long given power to the parties and to the establishment
column2: ” says Jeanne Zaino
column3: a political scientist at Iona College in New Rochelle
column4: N.Y. “But who has higher voting turnout? States that have early voting
column5: states that have mail in ballots and same day registration. We in New York allow none of that. This was not just a closed primary
column6: this was an ultra-closed primary. Whether you’re running for office or voting
column7: you had to be on top of your game to be a part of it.”

column1: The knock against closed primaries in this election season has been that they hurt insurgent candidates like Trump and Bernie Sanders. But the picture isn’t so simple.
Yes
column2: Senator Sanders of Vermont has done much better among independents. But his biggest wins – in Hawaii
column3: Alaska
column4: and Washington state – all came in closed primaries or caucuses.

column1: Trump
column2: meanwhile
column3: has in many cases actually done better among Republicans than independents.

column1: What is clear is that the primary rules disenfranchise those who most dislike the parties. “So why is Sanders doing so well among independents?” asks Dan Hopkins of the FiveThirtyEight data journalism website. “It appears to be driven not by their ideology so much as their dislike of partisan politics.”
In one respect
column2: that makes sense. Why would parties give vote to someone who doesn’t like them?

column1: Yet those people are a growing share of the American electorate. Some 39 percent Americans now identify as independents; 32 percent say they’re Democrats
column2: and 23 percent say they’re Republicans
column3: according to a Pew Research Center survey last year.

column2: 29 percent were independents
column3: 33 percent were Democrats
column4: and 28 percent were Republicans
column5: Pew found

column1: In Tuesday’s closed primary
column2: “three million people in the state of New York who are independents have lost their right to vote in the Democratic or Republican primary
column3: ” Sanders said. “That’s wrong.”

column1: It almost certainly hurt Sanders. In Michigan
column2: for example
column3: Hillary Clinton won the Democratic vote by 58 to 40 percent – similar to the 58 to 42 percent margin in New York. But since Michigan was an open primary where independents could vote
column4: Sanders won the state by taking 71 percent of independent voters.

column1: Eight of the 16 remaining primary contests – including Pennsylvania
column2: New Jersey
column3: and Maryland – are closed contests.

column1: Sanders and his supporters have also complained about the fact that 15 percent of the delegates to the Democratic National Convention – 712 out of 4
column2: 763 – are party leaders known as “superdelegates
column3: ” who overwhelmingly support Mrs. Clinton.

column1: In short
column2: the deck is stacked against Sanders. And intentionally so.

column1: Sanders isn’t a Democrat; he’s an independent who describes himself as a democratic socialist. It is not illogical that Democratic primaries should favor an actual Democrat.
The same is true
column2: in different ways
column3: for Trump. The GOP front-runner won a solid victory in New York. But he's getting little help from the establishment in navigating the complex delegate rules – rules that he says are rigged. Meanwhile
column4: the well-organized campaign of Sen. Ted Cruz outmaneuvered him in Louisiana and swept Colorado’s state convention contest.

column1: Presidents have always gone through a complex
column2: multilayered processes in which voters
column3: local officials
column4: and party leaders each have their role
column5: scholars say. Party leaders should have no small say in choosing their party’s presidential nominee
column6: the thinking goes.

column1: But even within the parties
column2: there is some restlessness for change. “Closed primaries poison the health of that system and warp its natural balance
column3: ” said Charles Schumer (D) of New York
column4: now the No. 2 Democrat in the Senate
column5: to The New York Times in 2014.

column1: As America’s political balance increasingly settles outside either of the two parties
column2: 2016 is showing how even a more open system can be warped.

column1: “And if part of that story is about disenfranchisement
column2: it is about these younger voters
column3: people who are new to the process
column4: or who disengaged from it and didn’t register
column5: or registered as independent and couldn’t vote
column6: ” says Professor Zaino.

column1: “You’re talking about Sanders supporters who are going to be on the losing end of that.”"	REAL

column3: like
column4: institutions for people that are sickos
column5: he said. ""We have sickos all over the place. And that's the problem.""

column1: Despite his lead in national polls
column2: Trump said he will spend about $2 million per week on advertising in the coming weeks leading to the Iowa caucuses and the New Hampshire primary. ""I think I'm probably wasting the money
column3: he said. ""But I'm $35 million under budget.... I almost feel guilty."""	REAL

column1: Detroit women’s Halloween decorations depict ‘real-life horrors’ … such as shootings police by police	"Print
[Ed. – How to take the fun out of Halloween.]
As Halloween approaches
column2: hair-raising yard displays can often cause people to stop
column3: gawk and whip out their cellphones.

column1: Larethia Haddon is well aware of that
column2: and is using it to shine some light on real-life horrors
column3: rather than typical Halloween themes.

column1: In her yard at the corner of Mendota and Santa Maria avenues in Detroit
column2: there are six dummies portraying police shootings
column3: slain children
column4: the Flint water crisis
column5: and other horrors.

column1: Last year
column2: a single dummy placed face-down in the grass
column3: realistically depicting a dead body in her yard
column4: shocked passersby and caused fearful calls to the police.

column1: This time around
column2: Haddon wants to inspire a broader range of thought
column3: rather than just shock.

column1: “We’re trying to do something positive instead of just having a dead body laying in the yard
column2: ” she said. “Want to get people to be a little more focused on the issues
column3: what’s going on in the world. We need to stick together more. We need to come together. And if we don’t
column4: this scene in my yard is going to be reality every single day.”"	FAKE

column1: Hillary Clinton's declining favorability numbers, in context	"Buried beneath Wednesday's eye-popping headlines about Hillary Clinton's sinking favorability ratings
column2: you'll find the reason that she's still on course to win the Democratic primary.

column1: First
column2: the headline number: A new Washington Post/ABC News poll shows that 53 percent of Americans have an unfavorable view of Clinton
column3: an 8 percentage point increase since July. Her favorable rating has declined by 7 percentage points to 45 percent over the same period of time
column4: and the split among registered voters is even worse for her
column5: at 56 percent unfavorable to 43 percent favorable. A majority of women (51 percent) now view her unfavorably. None of that is good news for Clinton.

column1: She's been on a pretty steady drop from the moment she left the State Department in early 2013. That was a foreseeable outcome of Clinton moving back into domestic partisan politics after four years of representing America's interests abroad. Ellen Tauscher
column2: a former member of Congress and undersecretary of state
column3: warned Clinton that would happen in a private conversation about Clinton's political future in September 2011
column4: when about two-thirds of Americans rated her favorably.

column1: But what's apparent — and of more immediate interest to Clinton — is that she's still better regarded among Democrats than Vice President Joe Biden
column2: who is still weighing whether to run against her. Biden's dead-even 46 percent to 46 percent favorable/unfavorable rating is better than Clinton's
column3: but the edge is based on him having higher numbers with Republicans and independents
column4: the vast majority of whom won't vote in the Democratic primaries.

column1: A full 80 percent of Democrats view Clinton favorably
column2: compared with 70 percent who feel that way about Biden. Her number among African Americans is 79 percent
column3: and it's 68 percent among Hispanics. By comparison
column4: Biden is viewed favorably by just 67 percent of African Americans and 49 percent of Hispanics.

column1: That helps explain why Clinton is blowing her Democratic competition out of the water in national horse-race polls. She was up 35 percentage points in a head-to-head matchup with Vermont Sen. Bernie Sanders in a PPP poll conducted August 28 to 30 and held a 45-22-18 lead over Sanders and Biden in a Quinnipiac survey conducted from August 20 to 25.

She's also doing much better on the favorability scale than either Republican frontrunner Donald Trump or former Florida Gov. Jeb Bush. Trump checked in with a favorable number that has risen to 37 percent
column2: about the same as Bush's 38 percent. Trump had an unfavorable score of 59 percent
column3: while Bush was at 55 percent.

column1: The Clinton ship has taken on water. But
column2: along with other recent surveys
column3: this poll tell us that Clinton is still running away with her party's nomination and remains in better position than any of her Republican or Democratic rivals to advance to the all-important second round of the presidential race. For someone who lost the 2008 primary in part because she looked ahead to the general election
column4: it makes sense to focus on winning the primary first in 2016. On that score
column5: she's still in great shape."	REAL
