column1: Hillary Clinton: The criminal investigation keeps moving forward	"While the country has been fixated on Donald Trump's tormenting his Republican primary opponents and deeply concerned about the government’s efforts to identify any confederates in the San Bernardino
column2: California
column3: killings
column4: a team of federal prosecutors and FBI agents continues to examine Hillary Clinton’s tenure as secretary of state in order to determine whether she committed any crimes and
column5: if so
column6: whether there is sufficient evidence to prove her guilt beyond a reasonable doubt.

column1: What began as an innocent Freedom of Information Act request by Judicial Watch
column2: a D.C.-based public advocacy group promoting transparency in the executive branch
column3: has now become a full criminal investigation
column4: with Clinton as the likely target.

column1: The basic facts are well-known
column2: but the revealed nuances are important
column3: as well. When the State Department responded to the Judicial Watch FOIA request by telling Judicial Watch that it had no emails from Clinton
column4: Judicial Watch filed a lawsuit. When the State Department made the same representation to the court -- as incredible as it seemed at the time -- the judge accepted that representation
column5: and the case was dismissed.

column1: Then The New York Times revealed that Clinton used a private email server instead of the government’s server for all of her work-related and personal emails during her four years as secretary of state. After that
column2: the Judicial Watch FOIA case was reinstated
column3: and then the judge in the case demanded of State that it produce Clinton’s emails.

column1: When Judicial Watch expressed frustration to the judge about the pace at which it was getting emails
column2: the judge ordered Clinton
column3: “under penalty of perjury
column4: ” to certify that she had surrendered all her governmental emails to the State Department.

column1: Eventually
column2: Clinton did certify to the court that she did surrender all of her governmental emails to the State Department. She did so by sending paper copies of selected emails
column3: because she had wiped clean her server. She acknowledged that she decided which emails were personal and which were selected as governmental and returned the governmental ones to the State Department. She has denied steadfastly and consistently that she ever sent or received any materials marked ""classified” while secretary of state using her private server.

column1: All of her behavior has triggered the FBI investigation because she may have committed serious federal crimes. For example
column2: it is a crime to steal federal property. What did she steal? By diverting to her own venue the digital metadata that accompany all emails -- metadata that
column3: when attached to the work-related emails of a government employee
column4: belong to the government -- she stole that data. The metadata do not appear on her paper copies -- hence the argument that she stole and destroyed the government-owned metadata.

column1: This is particularly troublesome for her present political ambitions because of a federal statute that disqualifies from public office all who have stolen federal property. (She is probably already barred from public office -- though this was not prominently raised when she entered the U.S. Senate or the Department of State -- because of the china
column2: silverware and furniture that she and her husband took from the White House in January 2001.)

column1: Clinton may also have committed espionage by failing to secure the government secrets entrusted to her. She did that by diverting those secrets to an unprotected
column2: nongovernmental venue -- her own server -- and again by emailing those secrets to other unprotected and nongovernmental venues. The reason she can deny sending or receiving anything marked ""classified” is that protected government secrets are not marked “classified.”

column1: So her statement
column2: though technically true
column3: is highly misleading. The governmental designations of protected secrets are “confidential
column4: ” “secret” and “top secret” -- not “classified.” State Department investigators have found 999 emails sent or received by Clinton in at least one of those three categories of protected secrets.

column1: Back when Clinton became secretary of state
column2: on her first day in office
column3: she had an hourlong FBI briefing on the proper and lawfully required care of government secrets. She signed a statement
column4: under penalty of perjury
column5: acknowledging that she knew the law and that it is the content of emails
column6: not any stamped markings
column7: that makes them secret.

column1: Earlier this week
column2: my Fox News colleagues confirmed the certain presence of top-secret materials among the 999 emails. Intelligence from foreign sources or about foreign governments is always top-secret
column3: whether designated as such or not. And she knows that.

column1: As well
column2: she may have committed perjury in the FOIA case. When the House Select Committee on Benghazi
column3: in its investigation of her role in the deaths of the U.S. ambassador to Libya and three other Americans
column4: gathered emails
column5: it found emails she did not surrender to the State Department.

column1: Last week
column2: the State Department released emails that give the FBI more areas to investigate. These emails may show a pattern of official behavior by Clinton designed to benefit the financial interests of her family's foundation
column3: her husband and her son-in-law. Moreover
column4: the FBI knows of a treasure-trove of documents that may demonstrate that the Clinton Foundation skirted the law and illegally raised and spent contributions.

column1: Two months ago
column2: a group of FBI agents sat around a conference table and reviewed the evidence gathered thus far. Each agent was given the opportunity to make or detract from the case for moving forward. At the end of the meeting
column3: it was the consensus of the group to pursue a criminal investigation.

column1: And Clinton is the likely target.
Andrew P. Napolitano
column2: a former judge of the Superior Court of New Jersey
column3: is the senior judicial analyst at Fox News Channel."	REAL

column1: Rubio’s parting shot at Trump	"It was not supposed to end like this for Marco Rubio.
Eleven months ago
column2: he launched his presidential campaign in front of Miami’s Freedom Tower
column3: the Ellis Island for his and other Cuban families. In his rapid rise
column4: young Rubio had been a darling of both the tea party movement and the conservative intelligentsia — the Republicans’ best hope of attracting nonwhite voters.

column1: But then came vulgar Donald Trump. Rubio was savaged on everything from immigration to his height. On Tuesday night
column2: Rubio
column3: his campaign fading
column4: lost his home state of Florida to the bigoted demagogue who makes scapegoats of foreigners and minorities. Bowing to the inevitable
column5: Rubio ended his candidacy.

column1: By the time Rubio’s campaign bus rolled to its final pre-primary stop — an outdoor basketball court here where he played as a boy — only a couple-hundred supporters were on hand
column2: nearly equaled by the number of journalists on death watch.

column1: Before Rubio arrived
column2: a prankster hijacked the microphone and was chased off by campaign aides. When Rubio himself spoke
column3: the sound system failed
column4: so he delivered his valedictory with a bullhorn.

column1: [The GOP establishment has failed. It’s up to voters to deny Trump.]
Rubio’s voice sounded tinny
column2: but his words were rich with nostalgia as he recalled knocking on doors when he ran for city commissioner here. “In between sips of sweet Cuban coffee
column3: I heard the stories of their youth
column4: of the dreams they lost
column5: ” he said. “That has carried me every single day throughout this campaign
column6: knowing that my worst days are better than some of the best days that many people in this community have had.”

column1: These are not the best days for Rubio
column2: or for anybody who cares about American democracy. The 44-year-old made mistakes during his campaign: freezing in the New Hampshire debate
column3: failing to take on Trump earlier
column4: then finally attacking Trump by joking about genitalia.

column1: Yet he finished honorably. He spoke reflectively Monday about Trump’s brutal transformation of politics. This message should have been delivered much earlier
column2: but it deserves to be heard even now.

column1: “Leadership is not about going to an angry and frustrated people and saying you should be even angrier and more frustrated
column2: and you should be angry and frustrated at each other
column3: ” Rubio told a gym full of Christian college students in West Palm Beach. “That’s called demagoguery. And it’s dangerous.” It leads
column4: he said
column5: to “where we are today
column6: a nation where people literally hate each other because they’re voting for different candidates. . . . And it leaves us incapable of solving problems.”

column1: Trump tore up the norms of decency that remained in American politics
column2: and Rubio expressed puzzlement that it worked. “My whole life I’ve been told being humble is a virtue
column3: and now being humble is a weakness and being vain and self-absorbed is somehow a virtue
column4: ” he said. “My whole life I’ve been told no matter how you feel about someone
column5: you respect everyone because we are all children of the same God — and now being respectful to one another is considered political correctness.”

column1: Rubio voiced regret for his own role in the vulgarity
column2: saying he “felt terrible” for joking about Trump’s penis size. Such remorse separates Rubio from Trump
column3: who seems to have no shame as he blurts obscenities
column4: delivers insults and winks at violence. “There are people
column5: I know
column6: who like this stuff because he says what they want to be able to say
column7: [but] presidents can’t say whatever they want to say
column8: ” Rubio told the students
column9: mentioning the harm to America’s reputation that Trump has already done. “We’re not a Third World country. We’re the United States of America.”

column1: [Donald Trump just threatened more violence. Only this time
column2: it’s directed at the GOP.]

column1: That’s the welcoming country to which Rubio’s parents immigrated
column2: settling among the shoe-box homes here in Cuban West Miami. “Everywhere I go I tell the story of this community of people
column3: many of whom lost their country in their youth
column4: ” Rubio said Monday night in his boyhood park
column5: his kids beside him in the bed of his Dodge pickup.

column1: He spoke
column2: in English
column3: then in Spanish
column4: with the requisite optimism
column5: telling supporters he looked forward to moving his “caja china” — Cuban barbecue — to the White House.

column1: “If there’s no car
column2: we’ll go in a raft!” a supporter said in Spanish.

column1: Another said in English: “Don’t give up
column2: man!”

column1: But Rubio’s speech to his modest band had the ring of a farewell. “I will always be a son of this community. I will always carry with me the hopes and dreams of generations that made possible the dreams of mine
column2: ” he said. His candidacy
column3: he said
column4: “was possible because you and I happen to live in the one place on Earth where even the son of a bartender and a maid from West Miami can be president.”

column1: Or at least he can lose to a trash-talking rich guy from Queens.
Read more from Dana Milbank’s archive
column2: follow him on Twitter or subscribe to his updates on Facebook."	REAL

column1: Loretta Lynch becomes first African-American woman AG.	"Washington (CNN) Loretta Lynch was sworn in as the new U.S. attorney general on Monday
column2: replacing Eric Holder. Lynch
column3: the country's first African-American woman to serve in the role
column4: had her nomination held up more than five months over politicking in the Senate.

column1: Ladies and gentlemen
column2: it's about time
column3: said Vice President Joe Biden at the swearing in ceremony.

column1: The highly politicized five-month battle to choose Obama's next attorney general came to a close Thursday when the Senate finally voted 56-43 to confirm Lynch

But the delay of her nomination neared record-breaking proportions. Republicans leading the Senate refused to bring her nomination up for a vote until Democrats cut a deal on abortion language in an unrelated bill. That legislation passed Wednesday
column2: setting up Thursday's vote and ending the latest partisan Washington standoff.

column1: Ten Republicans
column2: including Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell
column3: joined Democrats. Texas GOP Sen. Ted Cruz was the only senator not to vote.

column1: Obama tapped Lynch to replace Attorney General Eric Holder in November and her nomination cleared the Senate Judiciary Committee in February. Still
column2: she waited longer than the seven most recent U.S. attorneys general combined for a vote on the Senate floor
column3: after Majority Leader Mitch McConnell insisted on first finishing work on an unrelated bill.

column1: Loretta Lynch's father
column2: Lorenzo A. Lynch
column3: was in the Senate gallery watching when the historic vote took place confirming her daughter as the first African American female attorney general.

column1: The good guys won. That's what has happened in this country all along
column2: Lorenzo Lynch told reporters. ""Even during slavery. Levi Coffin was a founder of the Underground Railroad. Even during slavery. A white man fought against slavery. So all over this land good folks have stood in the right lane
column3: in the right path.""

column1: A two-time U.S. attorney for the Eastern District of New York
column2: Lynch takes on the high-profile job at time when America faces a series of challenges
column3: from dealing with strained relations and deep distrust in some cities between the police and the communities they serve
column4: to criminal justice reform
column5: to confronting the ongoing threat of terrorism.

column1: Lynch
column3: has earned a reputation as a highly qualified
column4: but low-profile prosecutor who has a good relationship with law enforcement and a history of handling tough cases well.

column1: She is a good listener and a skilled consensus builder
column2: qualities that will help her succeed at Justice
column3: said Tim Heaphy
column4: a former U.S. attorney for the Western District of Virginia who served under Lynch on the Attorney General's Advisory Committee
column5: a group that meets regularly to advise the Justice department on policy matters.

column1: In that [attorney general] job you are at the center of so many of the emerging
column2: significant
column3: pressing issues not only in this country but around the world. There's probably no job in government as diverse and challenging as being attorney general of the United States
column4: Heaphy said. He added that building support for initiatives both within and outside the department is an important part of the job.

column1: She will be good at getting people to work well together. I think that's a strength of hers. I saw that on the committee
column2: Heaphy said.

column1: Lynch's portfolio will include addressing voting rights
column2: white-collar crime and policy reviews
column3: as well as public corruption
column4: an area in which she has vast experience.

column1: In a statement
column2: Obama said America will be better off with Lynch leading the Department of Jusice.

column1: Loretta's confirmation ensures that we are better positioned to keep our communities safe
column2: keep our nation secure
column3: and ensure that every American experiences justice under the law
column4: Obama said in a statement shortly after the vote.

column1: Lynch's experience on civil rights case
column2: like helping win the convictions of New York City police officers who sexually assaulted Haitian immigrant Abner Louima
column3: will be important as her office tackles closely watched investigations in recent police conduct cases
column4: including the still unexplained death of a 25-year-old Baltimore man while in police custody.

column1: She's seen and understands the injustices that have taken place in the past and so therefore she's uniquely also equipped to deal with what's going on and do the kinds of investigations that will restore faith to Americans in their justice system
column2: said Rep. Greg Meeks
column3: D-New York.

column1: Born in Greensboro
column2: North Carolina
column3: Lynch grew up 60 miles to the east in Durham
column4: North Carolina. Her father was a fourth-generation Baptist minister; her mother
column5: an English teacher and school librarian. As a child
column6: Lynch rode on her father's shoulders to his church
column7: which served a meeting place for students organizing anti-segregation boycotts in the early 1960s
column8: she told the Judiciary panel at her January confirmation hearing. Lynch eventually graduated from Harvard College and Harvard Law School.

column1: Speaking at her nomination announcement in November
column2: Lynch highlighted the fact that the Justice Department is named for an ideal.

column1: This is actually appropriate
column2: because our work is both aspirational
column3: and grounded in gritty reality
column4: she said. ""Today
column5: I stand before you so thrilled
column6: and
column7: frankly
column8: so humbled to have the opportunity to lead this group of wonderful people who work all day and well into the night to make that ideal a manifest reality.""

column1: At a conference meeting with all the nation's U.S. attorneys a few years ago
column2: Heaphy was put in charge of organizing a presentation showing the attorneys as they were 20 years before. Lynch shared a picture of herself with her college cheerleading squad.

column1: Loretta sent me a picture of her as a Harvard cheerleader in a pyramid
column2: he said. ""She was comfortable sharing this with Eric Holder and other department leaders. She laughed at herself.""

column1: I don't think she's just tough
column2: there's a humanity
column3: there's a human touch that she has that will also serve her well
column4: he said. ""Nobody is going to mistake that she's in charge
column5: but her humility and sense of humor will come through."""	REAL

column1: Why it's funny Republicans are upset with Facebook: Column	"GOP opposes the kind of antitrust regulation that would preserve freedom of expression online.
America’s right wing is in a froth about allegations that Facebook has tweaked its “trending news” feed to reduce the visibility of conservative news sites.
It’s not clear if the allegations
column2: from a Gizmodo report based on anonymous sources
column3: are true and Facebook denies them. But the deeper problem is undeniably real: Facebook is the dominant member of a small number of giant entities — corporate and governmental — that are gaining control over news
column4: freedom of expression and much of our digital lives. The irony is that the conservatives and business-backed Republicans in Congress who howl about Facebook are the same people who have thwarted policies that would encourage the competition we need to challenge that increasingly centralized control.

column1: Almost no one wants to address the fact that Facebook is becoming a monopoly in the antitrust sense of the word. Along with Google
column2: it dominates online advertising; Facebook especially does so on mobile devices
column3: which are the way many people connect to the Internet. If you offer news and information online
column4: you have almost no choice but to play on Facebook’s field because so much of your audience is there. (In some parts of the world
column5: Facebook essentially is the Internet
column6: because mobile devices are pretty much the sole means of online access and in some cases the company has made deals with local telecommunications companies and
column7: or governments.)

column1: Facebook has been buying everything that presents even a whiff of competition: Instagram
column2: WhatsApp
column3: Oculus. This is smart — no one can dispute that Mark Zuckerberg and the others on his team are brilliant technologists and strategists — but it’s also a red flag. As Zuckerberg famously said several years ago
column4: he wants Facebook to be “like electricity.” Well
column5: electricity is a utility. And we regulate utilities.

column1: Monopolies and cozy oligopolies never turn out well in the long run for anyone but the monopolists or cartel members. They end up controlling markets and do their best to thwart genuine competition. It’s their nature. Which is why capitalism
column2: plainly the best system when it’s working right
column3: needs rules to promote competition.

column1: Yet Republicans
column2: in general
column3: think the government should play little to no role in promoting competition. They consider antitrust inquiry and enforcement to be counterproductive
column4: at best — except
column5: of course
column6: when a powerful constituent (a corporation
column7: usually) is in danger from predatory behavior.

column1: That attitude accounts for the GOP’s cheerleading for corporate dominance of Internet access. Republicans
column2: in general
column3: are fine with the idea that one or two companies (say the leading cable provider and another telecom) should control access in most communities
column4: and utterly opposed to a remedy — what we call network neutrality — to ensure that people at the edges of networks
column5: not dominant Internet service providers
column6: should decide what information they want and at what priority.

column1: I don’t want the government to tell Facebook what it can publish and don’t look forward to much more than posturing from Congress. But I do want the government to start paying extremely close attention to the way the company is becoming a monopoly and to what it means for freedom of expression when a single company has so much power over what people say online. I want government to use antitrust and other pro-competition laws to ensure that Facebook doesn’t abuse its dominance in a business sense. I want government(s) to promote open technology and communications
column2: and fierce competition at every level. Kudos to Zuckerberg for making Facebook so appealing to millions of users; that’s an amazing achievement. But we can’t allow Facebook to leverage that success to block the emergence of alternatives to its service
column3: or use its market power to influence or alter the content of publications and others trying to communicate with Facebook users.

column1: We all need to wake up to the potential threat Facebook poses to freedom of expression. Once you are in its enclosed online space
column2: it is the corporation’s terms of service
column3: not the First Amendment
column4: that determines what you can say. If it decides to downplay speech it doesn’t like
column5: Facebook has the right to do so.

column1: So I’m glad that conservatives are concerned
column2: even if the allegations prove overblown. (Facebook has modified its outright denial to a “we’re looking into it” stance; stay tuned.) I’d be even happier if conservatives realized that government does have a role in promoting genuine competition — and that we’re in uncharted information-freedom territory under the new control freaks of Silicon Valley.

column1: Dan Gillmor teaches digital media literacy at Arizona State University. He is the author of Mediactive. He wrote this for Zocalo Public Square.
In addition to its own editorials
column2: USA TODAY publishes diverse opinions from outside writers
column3: including our Board of Contributors. To read more columns
column4: go to the Opinion front page and follow us on Twitter @USATOpinion."	REAL

column1: FBI checking if Orlando shooter's wife knew attack plan but didn't warn police	"The wife of the gunman who carried out the deadliest mass shooting on American soil could face criminal charges if investigators conclude that she knew of the attack in advance but failed to warn police.
Noor Zahi Salman told that FBI that her husband
column2: Omar Mateen
column3: had said he was going out to see friends
column4: but she feared he was going to attack a gay nightclub
column5: NBC News reported on Wednesday. She tried to talk him out of it but did not contact law enforcement agencies.

column1: Wielding an AR-15-style semiautomatic rifle and a handgun
column2: Mateen opened fire at the Pulse club in Orlando
column3: Florida
column4: early on Sunday in a three-hour shooting rampage and hostage siege that ended when a Swat team smashed its way in and killed him. There were 49 people killed and 53 were injured.

column1: Angus King
column2: a member of the Senate intelligence committee
column3: which received a briefing on the attack
column4: told CNN: “It appears she [Salman] had some knowledge of what was going on. She definitely is
column5: I guess you would say
column6: a person of interest right now and appears to be cooperating and can provide us with some important information.”

column1: Peter King
column2: chairman of the House homeland security subcommittee on counterintelligence and terrorism
column3: told MSNBC: “If it’s true that she did know that it was going to happen and she tried to talk him out of it
column4: then it’s possible criminal action (could be taken) against her
column5: and again there might be more involvement by her
column6: so all that has to be investigated.”

column1: The possibility that Mateen
column3: did not act alone but received support from other individuals or groups is now central to the FBI’s inquiry
column4: King added. “If there’s anybody else that he was dealing with
column5: anyone else he was talking with
column6: anyone else who may have known about this
column7: this is all where the investigation is going now.”

column1: Media reports also suggested that Salman was with her husband when he bought ammunition and a holster. She allegedly told the FBI that she once drove him to Pulse
column2: nearly a two-hour drive from their home in Fort Pierce
column3: Florida
column4: because he wanted to scope it out. Mateen is said to have browsed militant Islamist material on the internet for at least two years before the mass shooting.

column1: As detectives tried to piece together Mateen’s last movements on Saturday night
column2: Orlando mayor Buddy Dyer
column3: who opened a family assistance centre in a stadium on Wednesday
column4: said: “What I know concretely is that he was driving around that evening and visited several locations.”

column1: The FBI director
column2: James Comey
column3: has said the agency is trying to determine whether Mateen had recently visited Disney World
column4: one of the Orlando’s celebrated theme parks
column5: to consider it as a potential target.

column1: Disney
column2: which is donating $1m to an official fund for victims of the shooting
column3: installed metal detectors last December but declined to comment on the Mateen case. A spokesperson said: “Unfortunately we’ve all been living in a world of uncertainty
column4: and we have been increasing our security measures across our properties for some time
column5: adding such visible safeguards as magnetometers
column6: additional canine units
column7: and law enforcement officers on site
column8: as well as less visible systems that employ state-of-the-art security technologies.”

column1: Salman will be key to the ongoing investigation as conflicting narratives emerge
column2: including evidence he had been influenced by militant Islamist ideas and reports he might have struggled with his own sexual identity.

column1: A survivor of the massacre
column2: Patience Carter
column3: suggested on Tuesday that Mateen had an overt political motive. Cowering in a bathroom
column4: she heard him demand that Americans “stop bombing his country” and pledge allegiance to Islamic State
column5: she said.

column1: Carter
column3: who is African American
column4: told reporters at Florida Hospital: “He even spoke to us directly in the bathroom. He said
column5: ‘Are there any black people in here?’ I was too afraid to answer but there was an African American male in the stall
column6: where the majority of my body was
column7: who had answered and he said
column8: ‘Yes
column9: there are about six or seven of us
column10: ’ and the gunman responded back to him and said: ‘You know
column11: I don’t have a problem with black people. This is about my country. You guys suffered enough.’”

column1: The account chimed with previous FBI statements that Mateen had called the 911 emergency service and made reference to both Isis and the Tsarnaev brothers
column2: who were responsible for the Boston bombings. Investigators have said Mateen was probably self-radicalised and there is no evidence that he received any instruction or aid from outside groups such as Isis.

column1: Mateen also called a local 24-hour cable news channel
column2: News 13
column3: the station revealed on its website on Wednesday. Matthew Gentili
column4: who was the producer on duty at the time
column5: recalled that Mateen said: “I’m the shooter. It’s me. I am the shooter ... I did it for Isis. I did it for the Islamic State.”

column1: Soon after the attack
column2: Mateen’s father indicated that his son had strong anti-gay feelings. He recounted an incident when his son became angry when he saw two men kissing in downtown Miami while out with his wife and young son.

column1: Several media reports quoted men as saying they had seen Mateen at Pulse many times or that he had contacted them via gay dating apps
column2: such as Grindr and Jack’d. But Pulse denied that he had ever been a patron. “Untrue and totally ridiculous
column3: ” spokeswoman Sara Brady said in an email to Reuters.

column1: Mateen’s ex-wife
column2: Sitora Yusufiy
column3: told CNN she did not know if he was gay but added: “Well
column4: when we had gotten married
column5: he confessed to me about his past that was recent at that time and that he very much enjoyed going to clubs and the nightlife and there was a lot of pictures of him.”

column1: “I feel like it’s a side of him or a part of him that he lived but probably didn’t want everybody to know about.”
Asked by the Guardian about rumours his son was gay
column2: Mateen’s father Seddique Mateen said: “It’s not true. Why
column3: if he was gay
column4: would he do this?”

column1: Seddique Mateen declined to comment specifically on the investigation on Wednesday
column2: saying: “The FBI
column3: they always do a professional job and to the maximum extent of my ability I will support them.”

column1: Mateen
column2: investigated twice by the FBI
column3: was on the government’s terrorist watchlist for 10 months before being taken off. G4S
column4: the security company that employed Mateen
column5: only psychologically evaluated him once
column6: at the start of his nine-year employment with the company and not again after the company was made aware he had been interviewed by the FBI.

column1: Thirty-three people remain in hospital
column2: including six in critical condition. On Tuesday
column3: the first of the seriously injured to speak of their trauma was Angel Colon at the Orlando Regional Medical Center. “He’s shooting everyone that’s already dead on the floor
column4: making sure they’re dead
column5: ” he said
column6: speaking from a wheelchair. “I look over
column7: and he shoots the girl next to me. And I’m just there laying down and I’m thinking: ‘I’m next
column8: I’m dead.’

column1: “So I don’t know how
column2: but by the glory of God
column3: he shoots toward my head but it hits my hand
column4: and then he shoots me again and it hits the side of my hip. I had no reaction. I was just prepared to just stay there laying down so he won’t know that I’m alive.”

column1: The attending trauma surgeon on call that night
column2: Dr Chadwick Smith
column3: said: “It was singularly the worst day of my career and the best day of my career. And I think you can say that of pretty much every person standing up here.”

column1: The atrocity continued to reverberate in Washington DC
column2: where Senate Democrats demanded tighter gun controls. Donald Trump
column3: the Republican presumptive nominee
column4: broke ranks with the party by saying he would meet the influential National Rifle Association lobbying group
column5: which has endorsed him
column6: to discuss an idea for restricting gun purchases by people on terrorism watchlists.

column1: Barack Obama
column2: who will visit Orlando on Thursday
column3: launched a blistering assault against Trump over the candidate’s anti-Muslim rhetoric
column4: which the president described as dangerous and contrary to American values.

column1: “Where does this stop? The Orlando killer
column2: one of the San Bernardino killers
column3: the Fort Hood killer
column4: [they] were all US citizens. Are we going to start treating all Muslim Americans differently? ... Putting them under surveillance?”"	REAL

column1: Handicapping the Hispanic vote for 2016 GOPers	"The last Texas Republican to occupy the Oval Office
column2: George W. Bush
column3: took 49 percent of the state’s Hispanic vote in his 2004 presidential re-election
column4: setting a relatively high bar for the handful of Texas-born or -raised Republicans who might be hoping to follow in his footsteps in 2016.

column1: Republican presidential aspirants with ties to the Lone Star State must figure out how to hold the GOP base and attract conservative Hispanics if they want to be successful in Texas
column2: political observers say.

column1: So how do the party's four most prominent Texas affiliated might-be candidates — former Gov. Rick Perry; Jeb Bush
column2: the son and brother of two former presidents from the state; Texas’ junior U.S. senator
column3: Ted Cruz; and U.S. Sen. Rand Paul of Kentucky — stack up in the early going?

column1: For Republicans to avoid a repeat of 2012
column2: when presidential nominee Mitt Romney took only 27 percent of the Hispanic vote nationwide
column3: they need to nominate a conservative candidate who can go into Hispanic communities and truly connect with voters
column4: said Hector De Leon
column5: co-chairman of the Associated Republicans of Texas
column6: which reaches out to Hispanic voters.

column1: “It’s all about paying attention
column2: ” De Leon said.

column1: Hispanics made up 10 percent of the national electorate in the 2012 presidential election. But in Texas
column2: they make up almost one-third of eligible voters. And there’s plenty room for improvement when it comes to voter turnout. Only 39 percent of Texas Hispanics eligible to vote cast ballots in 2012.

column1: Political observers say candidates would be right to take a page out of George W. Bush’s playbook on Hispanic outreach. He solidified his winning record with Hispanics with help from Latino-media guru Lionel Sosa
column2: who told The Texas Tribune he has been in talks with Jeb Bush about his possible presidential bid.

column1: Sosa helped George W. Bush’s campaign craft several television ads that painted him as the candidate who understood Hispanic culture. The candidate who can mobilize on-the-fence Hispanic voters who usually do not turn out to vote could win the state.
“I do think the primaries will include a concerted effort by some candidates to speak to that constituency
column2: ” said Sylvia Manzano
column3: a senior analyst for the nonpartisan political polling organization Latino Decisions. “In Texas
column4: that’s 10 million people. That’s a number that cannot be ignored.”

column1: Though it's still early in the game
column2: many political observers say Jeb Bush is best positioned at the moment. He grew up in Midland
column3: spent much of his childhood in Houston and is considered friendly to the Hispanic community
column4: both personally and politically.

column1: “Jeb Bush is not going to come in and play mariachi politics
column2: ” Manzano said. “He knows better than that.”

column1: But this far out
column2: all is speculation. As the candidates tiptoe toward the starting gate
column3: here's how several political experts handicap the field.

column1: Already holding a political advantage because he is fluent in Spanish
column2: the former Florida governor has experience winning over Hispanics in a state where they make up a large part of the population. During his 1998 re-election campaign
column3: Bush won an impressive 61 percent of Florida's Hispanic electorate. It's worth noting
column4: though
column5: that Florida’s mostly Cuban Hispanic population differs from Texas
column6: where a majority of Hispanics have roots in Mexico.

column1: What the experts say:
For Bush
column2: reaching out to Texas Hispanics would be an extended family affair. Aside from benefiting from the groundwork his family has done in the state
column3: expect to see Bush campaigning with his Mexican-born wife
column4: Columba
column5: and his son
column6: Texas Land CommissionerGeorge P. Bush
column7: at his side. George P. is also fluent in Spanish and helped found Hispanic Republicans of Texas
column8: a political group that recruits and supports Hispanic Republicans running for public office.

column1: Bush’s record on issues that resonate with Texas Hispanics
column2: particularly immigration reform
column3: could prove attractive to this voting group. He has urged Congress to pass immigration reform and has highlighted it as a key issue in helping Republicans win Hispanics. He also gained national attention last year when he said many of those entering the country illegally do so out of an “act of love” for their families.

column1: As the state’s longest-serving governor
column2: Perry has long courted Texas Hispanics. He has steadily improved his standing since winning only 13 percent of the Hispanic vote when he defeated Hispanic businessman Tony Sanchez of Laredo in 2002. By the time he was re-elected in 2010
column3: Perry pulled in 38 percent of Hispanic voters.

column1: What the experts say:

Perry’s efforts to broaden his appeal were buoyed by the passage of the Texas Dream Act during his 14-year tenure. Though the future of the law granting in-state tuition to some undocumented immigrants is unclear
column2: Perry has stood by it both on the national stage and at home. During a 2011 presidential debate
column3: Perry famously told opponents who challenged his support of the law that they had no heart. More recently
column4: as the state’s new GOP leadership works to overturn the law
column5: Perry has been vocal about his continued support for it.

column1: Because he presided over the state’s economic boom in the last decade
column2: Perry has a unique opportunity to appeal to Hispanics on economic issues. If Perry can convince Hispanic voters that they benefited from the so-called Texas Miracle
column3: he may be able to sway some on-the-fence voters his way.

column1: Though he is the only Hispanic in the group — and the first Hispanic senator from Texas — Cruz has largely avoided making heritage part of his political persona beyond recounting his father’s journey to the United States from Cuban as an exile in 1957. Still
column2: he has done well with Texas Hispanics. In 2012
column3: he outperformed Republican presidential nominee Mitt Romney
column4: taking 35 percent of the Hispanic vote
column5: according to a Latino Decisions poll.

column1: What the experts say:

Cruz arguably faces the toughest challenge courting Texas Hispanics given his divisive tone on immigration and health care. He has been vocal in his opposition to President Obama’s executive order on immigration
column2: which will grant millions of undocumented immigrants work permits and reprieve from deportation proceedings. The order is widely popular among Hispanics. On health care
column3: Cruz has been one of the biggest foes of the federal Affordable Care Act. Texas Hispanics — who make up a large portion of the state’s uninsured population —overwhelmingly support the health law.

column1: Though Paul was elected to the Senate from Kentucky
column2: where Hispanics make up only 3 percent of the population
column3: he grew up in Lake Jackson
column4: Texas
column5: where Hispanics are one-fifth of the population. Paul has spent the last few months preaching a message of Hispanic inclusion within the Republican ranks.

column1: What the experts say:

Paul is someone to watch in the upcoming election when it comes to appealing to Texas Hispanics because of his views on growing the GOP’s number of Hispanic supporters. Because he is largely unknown among Texas Hispanics
column2: Paul also has some room to improve his standing. A November 2014 poll by Latino Decisions found that almost a third of Texas Latino voters have no opinion of Paul."	REAL

column1: Truth Will Out Radio: The Laconia Incident	"Radio Aryan October 28
Sven Longshanks
column2: Dennis Wise and Messerschmitt bring us another episode of Truth Will Out Radio
column3: this week looking at the Laconia incident and the British Freikorps.

column1: Messerschmitt deviates somewhat with his Axis War Heroes series in that the main subject is not a person but the so-called “Laconia Incident”. In September 1942 a German U-boat under the Command of Werner Hartenstein torpedoed the British troopship Laconia. As Hartenstein realized that a lot of Italian prisoners of war and even civilians including women and children were among the survivors struggling for their lives he ordered that as many as possible were to be taken on board the U-boat. Even though he radioed his intentions to all surrounding vessels in plain English and had a Red Cross flag draped across the U-boat he and the survivors they were carrying were attacked by an American B-24. What happened to the survivors and what the response of the German Navy was when it learned of this atrocity is elaborated on by Schmitt and the presentation ends with a letter from a relative of one of the casualties
column2: thanking the U-boat commanders for their courageous and honourable behaviour.

column1: This presentation shows how the Allies were breaking the rules of war while the Germans were keeping to their treaties. During the Nuremberg trials this incident was brought up in the hopes of convicting Admiral Doenitz for advising the U-boats not to pick up survivors
column2: but it had the inadvertent effect of exposing the British and Americans of waging unrestricted submarine warfare
column3: in itself a possible war crime as it breaks the law of the sea that any shipwrecked mariners must be rescued
column4: no matter who they are. Dennis points out the hypocrisy of the British and Americans in this before reminding us that not all the British behaved like this during the war. Some became members of the Freikorps and fought to defend Europe from the Bolshevik menace alongside the other SS Volunteer Legions. These heroes were called traitors by the British establishment
column5: yet their oath was to protect Europe from Communism
column6: not to fight against Britain. It is a testament to the truthful ideology of National Socialism that prisoners of war could be set free to fight against Communism once they had heard the truth about it from their kinsmen in the League of St George.

column1: After giving us a brief history of these brave young British men
column2: Dennis and Sven conclude the podcast by talking about the importance of race and how the Freikorps highlighted this in their propaganda.

column1: Presented by Sven Longshanks
column2: Dennis Wise and Messerschmitt

GOP establishment nightmare? Ted Cruz vs. Donald Trump	"Watch the CNN Republican debate Tuesday
column2: December 15 at 6:00 p.m. ET and 8:30 p.m. ET.

column1: The GOP establishment
column2: confronted by a recalcitrant electorate that refuses to leave Donald Trump
column3: is being forced to take a fresh look at Ted Cruz
column4: a man with grassroots strength in key early primary states and few friends in Washington.

column1: Suddenly
column2: the Republican Party's best hope could be a man hell-bent on transforming it: a senator who openly spars with fellow GOP colleagues
column3: and has campaigned by painting its leaders as spineless and feeble.

column1: Headed into Tuesday's CNN Republican presidential debate
column2: Cruz and Trump have turned Iowa into a two-man race
column3: with the Texan leading in two new polls. Cruz is up 31% to Trump's 21% among likely GOP caucus-goers
column4: according to the Bloomberg Politics-Des Moines Register poll released Saturday. A Fox News poll Sunday has Cruz leading Trump 28% to 26%.

column1: A small and growing number of Republicans allied with the establishment -- the force long thought to quickly consolidate against a surging Cruz bid -- are coming to terms with the idea that he may be palatable in an election cycle where Trump has pushed the envelope well beyond what they considered acceptable.
Oh God
column2: yes
column3: said Ed Rogers
column4: a top Republican lobbyist
column5: when asked if he'd prefer Cruz. ""Compared to Trump
column6: he's OK.""

column1: Establishment Republicans had enough of a problem when Trump began his populist-fueled move to the top of national polls
column2: where he has stubbornly remained for five months. But Cruz's steady rise means that even if Trump were taken out by a well-financed negative campaign
column3: they might have to deal with a stronger Cruz
column4: who has more political polish than the more improvisational Trump.

column1: If you talk to my peers around town
column2: collectively it's an appreciation the guy is smart as hell
column3: explained a senior Washington Republican who is backing another candidate. ""He can be a more acceptable alternative to Trump
column4: if it comes to that.""

column1: The irony hasn't escaped them. Said the Republican: ""It's an interesting life -- and everything's relative.""
The second he starts to look like a winner in Washington
column2: Rogers said
column3: ""he's going to have a bunch of new friends.""

column1: It's a dilemma swatted away on Capitol Hill -- perhaps optimistically.
Asked about choosing Trump or Cruz
column2: 2008 nominee Sen. John McCain would only allow that they are ""smart people."" Bush backer Sen. Susan Collins would just offer that they are ""obviously not my choice.""

column1: And there's no guarantee either one can beat Hillary Clinton.
He's not as outrageous as Trump
column2: but I don't know that he's any more electable than Trump
column3: said Charlie Black
column4: a senior adviser to Republican presidential campaigns for over two decades.

column1: Brian Walsh
column2: a longtime Senate campaign aide
column3: said it's an out-of-control Trump -- not an in-control Cruz -- that explains the Texan's growing appeal.

column1: Trump has gone so far that it has in some ways masked how problematic Cruz would be as the nominee as well
column2: he said.

column1: Despite his background as an Ivy League-educated attorney and his time in the Bush administration
column2: Cruz rose to prominence as a tea party darling who became the national face of the 2013 government shutdown. Cruz has spent the two years since working to salvage his relationship with some potential investors in his campaign
column3: but he has reveled in his image as a Washington bad boy
column4: the only senator willing to do on Capitol Hill what he campaigned on back at home.

column1: It's something that has made him enemies in Washington
column2: where he has not convinced a single Senate colleague to back his campaign. Cruz helped push Republicans to shut down the government in a high-stakes fight over Obamacare
column3: a strategy that failed to get results but didn't cause a predicted electoral meltdown.

column1: On the trail
column2: he has shown no willingness to moderate his positions
column3: bragging about his conservative purity and his rabble-rousing reputation in the Capitol.

column1: But even compared to Cruz's burn-it-down rhetoric
column2: Trump's campaign has been more incendiary and worrisome for party elders determined to beat likely Democratic nominee Hillary Clinton. The mogul had harsh things to say about Hispanics
column3: prisoners of war
column4: women in the media
column5: the disabled
column6: and most recently
column7: Muslims
column8: who he thinks temporarily should not be allowed to enter the United States.

column1: And most concerning for GOP leaders
column2: Trump has frequently floated leaving the Republican Party altogether to mount an independent bid
column3: which would significantly increase Clinton's chances of winning the White House.

column1: The pair appears to be heading toward a clash that Cruz
column2: at least
column3: long sought to delay. On Friday evening
column4: about 24 hours after audio leaked of Cruz questioning Trump's judgment at a private fundraiser
column5: the real estate mogul launched his first attacks on Cruz.

column1: Cruz had attempted to head that off by alleging that mainstream Republicans were trying to sow discord.
The Establishment's only hope: Trump & me in a cage match
column2: he tweeted Friday morning. ""Sorry to disappoint — @realdonaldtrump is terrific. #DealWithIt""

column1: Cruz has done little to woo the Republicans he used as his bogeyman: He has raised the lion's share of his money far from the New York-to-Washington corridor
column2: raced to the party's right flank on every issue of the day
column3: and campaigned loudly on the polarizing social issues that one well-placed Republican said puts some contributors permanently out of reach.

column1: Cruz
column2: on paper
column3: should not be as repellent to the GOP political class as he is. Nurtured by the George W. Bush network in Texas
column4: he served as solicitor general before winning an upset bid in the 2012 Republican U.S. Senate primary.

column1: To Stuart Stevens
column2: the chief strategist for Mitt Romney's 2012 campaign
column3: that resume should theoretically make him attractive to the party's elite.

column1: At a core of Cruz's candidacy is a great phonyism
column2: Stevens said of the self-stylized insurgent. ""You can wear all the plaid shirts and shoot off all the automatic weapons you want
column3: but you're an insider.""

column1: And some of his positions
column2: such as on national security
column3: do hew closely to the party's center. As Cruz held court on MSNBC's ""Morning Joe"" last week
column4: ""you could've sworn he was working for George Herbert Walker Bush on his foreign policy
column5: a senior Republican said.

column1: But a leading Republican in frequent touch with high-level donors
column2: said even though those contributors may despise Cruz
column3: they are learning to live with him. ""If that's what we need to do to beat Trump
column4: the Republican said
column5: ""then that's what you get."""	REAL

column1: Bernie Sanders lost poor voters in South Carolina by a big margin — a problem for his political revolution	"Hillary Clinton didn't just take the vast majority of the available delegates in South Carolina on Saturday night. She also took away one of Bernie Sanders's strongest arguments — that he's the candidate who has the most working-class support.
In Iowa and New Hampshire
column2: Sanders had done better than Clinton among voters in the lowest income brackets. That seemed to bolster his claim that his ""political revolution"" could energize millions of new low-income voters who typically don't turn out to vote.

column1: This argument
column2: however
column3: is much less tenable after tonight. Clinton did best among poor voters in South Carolina
column4: taking 82 percent of those who earn under $30
column5: 000 on her way to a 37-point victory
column6: according to exit polling by the New York Times.

column1: Here are the results by income
column2: according to the Times:

column1: Of course
column2: this discrepancy is largely driven by Clinton's huge 87-13 margin of victory over black voters. But that's the point — outside of states like Iowa and New Hampshire
column3: many low-income and working-class voters aren't white. Unless Sanders is able to win working-class voters beyond the whitest electorates in the country
column4: his revolution may be over almost as soon as it started."	REAL

column1: Jeb Bush Picks Up Endorsement From Lindsey Graham	"Former GOP presidential hopeful Linsdey Graham has announced his endorsement of Jeb Bush for president.
Graham's presidential campaign went nowhere
column2: but as a senator from the early voting state of South Carolina he hopes to still have some clout.

column1: Graham praised Bush's temperament Friday morning
column2: following Thursday night's GOP debate. ""He hasn't tried to get ahead in a contested primary by embracing demagoguery ... he's not running to be commander-in-chief by running people down
column3: he said.

column1: That was clearly a reference to Donald Trump. Bush returned the admiration
column2: calling Graham a ""patriot.""

column1: He loves this country. You just hear it how he spoke from his heart about what's at stake here. What's at stake is our way of life
column2: Bush said.

column1: Jeb Bush — still slumping in polls — has been looking for a way to jump-start his campaign
column2: but an endorsement from a former candidate who couldn't break through either probably won't give Bush the upswing he needs.

column1: With the Iowa caucuses fewer than three weeks away
column2: he's polling behind Trump
column3: Ted Cruz
column4: Marco Rubio and Ben Carson both nationally and in Iowa. Bush was unable to stand out from the field once again at Thursday's Republican presidential debate. And Bush's donors are reportedly getting skittish
column5: saying it's only a matter of time before he drops out. Politico reported that several donors said they are now waiting for what one former George W. Bush administration appointee described as a ""family hall pass"" to switch to another campaign after the New Hampshire primary."	REAL

column1: 2016 Republican race enters a new, volatile phase	"The fight for the 2016 Republican presidential nomination appears to be moving into a new
column2: more fluid phase.

column1: No longer is the question merely whether or how Donald Trump can be stopped.

The recent rise in the polls of retired neurosurgeon Ben Carson — Trump’s low-key stylistic opposite — has shown that the celebrity billionaire may not be the only one who can tap the appetite of many in the party’s angry base for an outsider.
And after Wednesday’s chaotic and freewheeling debate
column2: there also is a new dynamic on the establishment side of the race.

column1: Former Florida governor Jeb Bush’s once-formidable campaign appears to be nearing a state of collapse
column2: made worse by his flailing on the stage in Colorado.

column1: That has provided an opening to his onetime ally
column2: Sen. Marco Rubio of Florida
column3: who is getting a new look from the party establishment — an ironic situation
column4: given Rubio’s roots as an insurgent tea party favorite in 2010.

column1: “Marco Rubio now has probably the best shot to emerge as the mainstream alternative to Trump and Carson
column2: ” said Ari Fleischer
column3: who was press secretary for President George W. Bush.

column1: More broadly
column2: Fleischer
column3: who is not committed to any of the 2016 candidates
column4: predicted that the GOP is about to enter “a condensed version of where it was four years ago
column5: where the party is volatile and shopping around.”

column1: That could help Ted Cruz
column2: who also made a strong showing in the debate. The firebrand senator from Texas
column3: widely despised by the Washington Republican hierarchy
column4: is looking to nudge out Trump and Carson among voters who are looking for a candidate to supplant the old order.

column1: “I don’t think the party is going to nominate anybody who has not been elected before
column2: ” said Stuart Stevens
column3: who was a top strategist for 2012 GOP nominee Mitt Romney.

column1: Also likely to force some clarity in the coming weeks is the calendar. The first contest
column2: in Iowa
column3: is barely more than three months away.

column1: So the focus for all the leading contenders will have to shift
column2: from raising their profiles nationally to refining the strategies and organization it will take to put specific states in their column.

column1: “The campaign is really in a nuts-and-bolts stage
column2: ” said Trump’s campaign manager
column3: Corey Lewandowski. “It’s about getting on the ballot
column4: organizing
column5: and making sure people understand what caucuses are in Iowa and other states and teach them how to participate. It’s about getting people committed and ready.”

column1: Lewandowski said Trump’s campaign is already hiring staff for states that do not hold their primaries until March.
“Our approach is to execute and meet the criteria to get on the ballot in all 50 states
column2: in five territories and in the District of Columbia. That’s a full-time job
column3: ” he added. “This campaign is doing all of the things necessary for long-term success.”

column1: At the same time
column2: Trump seemed to be moderating and refining his message as he campaigned outside Reno
column3: Nev.
column4: Thursday afternoon.

column1: Where he previously has devoted his rallies to slinging insults at his opponents and boasting about his poll numbers
column2: Trump focused instead on describing the professional and life experience he would bring to the White House.

column1: He also cited issues where he claimed to have led before it was a popular thing to do — including opposing the Iraq war and aggressively combating illegal immigration.
“That’s the kind of thinking we need in the country
column2: ” Trump said. “A lot of the people in the audience
column3: maybe in your small way you have that same thinking.”

column1: Bush
column2: campaigning in New Hampshire
column3: insisted that his struggling candidacy should not be counted out. The former Florida governor
column4: who is polling in the single digits almost everywhere
column5: insisted
column6: “We’re doing fine.”

column1: But he appeared to acknowledge that he had not helped his prospects with his showing in the debate.
“Look
column2: there are two types of politicians. There are the talkers and there are the doers
column3: ” Bush told the crowd. “I wish I could talk as well as some of the people on the stage
column4: the big personalities on the stage
column5: but I’m a doer.”

column1: Rubio
column2: meanwhile
column3: must capi­tal­ize — quickly — on whatever interest and momentum may be generated by his debate performance. He spent the morning making the rounds of six network and cable television shows and the remainder of the day fundraising in Denver and Chicago. He will be in Iowa on Friday.

column1: On “CBS This Morning
column2: ” Rubio declined to criticize Bush personally and said the differences between the two will be fleshed out in terms of policy.

column1: “I’m going to continue to tell people who I am
column2: what I’m for. There are policy differences between us — we’ll discuss those. Americans deserve to hear those. But I’m not going to change my campaign
column3: ” he said.

column1: “Jeb is my friend
column2: I have admiration for him. I’m not running against him. I’m running for president.”

column1: Cruz
column2: meanwhile
column3: is building what GOP insiders say is a strong organization. The campaign says that it has 77
column4: 000 volunteers on the ground
column5: with 6
column6: 000 in the first four voting states.

column1: Fundraising has also been robust — and was reignited by the debate
column2: during which the senator trained his fire on the CNBC moderators and the media. A Cruz aide said more than $1 million had poured in since Wednesday night’s debate.

column1: There will be growing pressure on candidates who are getting no traction to get out of the race. On Thursday
column2: for instance
column3: the New York Times editorial board called upon New Jersey Gov. Chris Christie to abandon his bid.

column1: “New Jersey is in trouble
column2: and the governor is off pursuing a presidential run that’s turned out to be nothing more than a vanity project
column3: ” the paper wrote. “Mr. Christie’s numbers are in the basement
column4: and he’s nearly out of campaign cash. This is his moment
column5: all right: to go home and use the rest of his term to clean out the barn
column6: as Speaker John Boehner would say.”

column1: Christie
column2: for his part
column3: tweeted
column4: “Can’t read the article because I don’t have a subscription
column5: but I can tell you this — I am not going anywhere.”

column1: Robert Costa in Colorado and Jenna Johnson in Nevada contributed to this report."	REAL
‘Hands up, don’t shoot’ was built on a lie	"The late evening of Aug. 9
column3: I couldn’t sleep. I was due to substitute-anchor MSNBC’s “UP with Steve Kornacki” and should have been asleep. But after looking at my Twitter feed and reading the rage under #Ferguson
column4: I felt compelled to type a reaction to the killing of Michael Brown by police officer Darren Wilson. Tying the shooting to the inane whine of certain politicians about a “war on whites
column5: ”  I decried the next morning the death of yet another unarmed black man at the hands of a white police officer.

column1: In those early hours and early days
column2: there was more unknown than known. But this month
column3: the Justice Department released two must-read investigations connected to the killing of Brown that filled in blanks
column4: corrected the record and brought sunlight to dark places by revealing ugly practices that institutionalized racism and hardship. They have also forced me to deal with two uncomfortable truths: Brown never surrendered with his hands up
column5: and Wilson was justified in shooting Brown.

column1: The report on the Ferguson police department detailed abuse and blatant trampling of the constitutional rights of people
column2: mostly African Americans
column3: in Ferguson. Years of mistreatment by the police
column4: the courts and the municipal government
column5: including evidence that all three balanced their books on the backs of the people of Ferguson
column6: were laid bare in 102 damning pages. The overwhelming data from DOJ provided background and much-needed context for why a small St. Louis suburb most had never heard of exploded the moment Brown was killed. His death gave voice to many who suffered in silence.

column1: The unarmed 18-year-old also became a potent symbol of the lack of trust between African Americans and law enforcement. Not just in Ferguson
column2: but in the rest of the country. Lord knows there have been plenty of recent examples. And the militarized response to protesters by local police put an exclamation point on demonstrators’ concerns. But the other DOJ report
column3: the one on the actual shooting of Michael Brown
column4: shows him to be an inappropriate symbol.

column1: Through exhaustive interviews with witnesses
column2: cross-checking their statements with previous statements to authorities and the media
column3: ballistics
column4: DNA evidence and results from three autopsies
column5: the Justice Department was able to present a credible and troubling picture of what happened on Canfield Drive. More credible than the grand jury decision to not indict Wilson. The transcript of his grand jury testimony read like so much hand-holding by the prosecution.

column1: What DOJ found made me ill. Wilson knew about the theft of the cigarillos from the convenience store and had a description of the suspects. Brown fought with the officer and tried to take his gun. And the popular hands-up storyline
column2: which isn’t corroborated by ballistic and DNA evidence and multiple witness statements
column3: was perpetuated by Witness 101. In fact
column4: just about everything said to the media by Witness 101
column5: whom we all know as Dorian Johnson
column6: the friend with Brown that day
column7: was not supported by the evidence and other witness statements.

column1: Page 6: Brown then grabbed the weapon and struggled with Wilson to gain control of it. Wilson fired
column2: striking Brown in the hand. Autopsy results and bullet trajectory
column3: skin from Brown’s palm on the outside of the SUV door as well as Brown’s DNA on the inside of the driver’s door corroborate Wilson’s account that during the struggle
column4: Brown used his right hand to grab and attempt to control Wilson’s gun. According to three autopsies
column5: Brown sustained a close range gunshot wound to the fleshy portion of his right hand at the base of his right thumb. column1: Bernie Sanders' call for ouster of two convention co-chairs rejected	"Democratic National Committee officials on Saturday turned down Bernie Sanders' formal request for the ouster of “aggressive attack surrogates” for Hillary Clinton from key national convention committees.

The campaign announced earlier that it wanted to remove Connecticut Gov. Dannel Malloy as a co-chairman of the Platform Committee and former Massachusetts Rep. Barney Frank as head of the Rules Committee. Frank has sharply criticized Sanders’ positions on breaking up big banks and Malloy has criticized Sanders on guns.
“Governor Malloy and Mr. Frank have both been aggressive attack surrogates for the Clinton campaign
column2: ” Sanders campaign counsel Brad Deutsch wrote in a letter to the party’s Rules and Bylaws Committee. “Their criticisms of Sen. Sanders have gone beyond dispassionate ideological disagreement and have exposed a deeper professional
column3: political and personal hostility toward the senator and his campaign.""

column1: But committee co-chairs Jim Roosevelt and Lorraine Miller responded that his challenge ""fails to meet the criteria"" for their dismissal. It did not allege any violations in the conduct of their elections to their posts by the DNC executive committee in January
column2: they wrote.

column1: The Sanders campaign’s Friday letter to Democratic National Committee rules officials marks the latest turn in Sanders’ feud with party officials. It comes a week after Sanders said he would make sure Rep. Debbie Wasserman Schultz of Florida isn’t reappointed to her role as head of the DNC if he becomes president and he began fundraising for her primary opponent
column2: Tim Canova.

column1: Most members of the convention standing committees — rules
column2: platform and credentials — are awarded to candidates based on the results of those primaries and caucuses. But under party rules
column3: Wasserman Schultz recommended co-chairs and a slate of 25 at-large appointments per committee for approval by the party’s executive committee.

column1: In a May 6 letter to Wasserman Schultz

column3: and he expressed no confidence in Malloy or Frank
column4: writing their appointments suggest the committees are being established “in an overtly partisan way.”

“The appointment of two individuals so outspokenly critical of Sen. Sanders
column2: and so closely affiliated with Secretary Clinton's campaign
column3: raises concerns that two of the three Convention Standing Committees are being constituted in an overtly partisan way designed to exclude meaningful input from supporters of Sen. Sanders' candidacy
column4: ” Deutsch wrote.

column1: In April

column3: Sanders’ senior adviser
column4: said Frank is among surrogates for Hillary Clinton who used Sanders’ remarks to a New York Daily News editorial board on April 1 to promote a story line that questions Sanders’ capacity to be president. Devine pointed to Frank’s April 6 statements on MSNBC that Sanders “confused several things” in his responses to questions about his core issue of breaking up big banks. Frank also said Sanders’ responses to the editorial board were not “coherent.”

column1: Frank said in an April interview with USA TODAY that he would step aside from his co-chairmanship if the Democratic nomination is still uncertain in June and if a Rules Committee decision could be the deciding factor. With Clinton's decisive lead in delegates
