column1: To get around Congress, Obama turns to city halls	"WASHINGTON — President Obama has quietly racked up a series of legislative victories during the past few months as lawmakers have enthusiastically embraced his calls for a higher minimum wage
column2: paid sick leave and universal pre-kindergarten.

column1: Instead of Capitol Hill
column2: those victories happened in city halls
column3: state houses and county buildings far from Washington.

column1: At least six major cities — Chicago
column2: Philadelphia
column3: Pittsburgh
column4: Seattle
column5: Tacoma
column6: Wash.
column7: and Washington
column8: D.C. — have passed paid sick leave laws in the four months since Obama called for state and local action in this year's State of the Union Address. Since the 2013 address when Obama called for an increase in the minimum wage
column9: 17 states and six major cities have taken action
column10: including Los Angeles last week.

column1: Obama's state-and-local strategy may be unprecedented in its scope and ambition. Though previous administrations have appointed top advisers to listen to concerns of state and local officials
column2: the Obama White House appears to be the first to aggressively use those same channels to encourage them to adopt Obama's policies.

column1: It is a change in the paradigm
column2: where we used to sit passively by waiting for elected officials to come to us. We think we can have a more substantial impact if we collaborate
column3: said Valerie Jarrett
column4: the assistant to the president for public engagement and intergovernmental affairs.

column1: I think the president has always had the perspective that change always happens from the ground up
column2: and our state and local officials are oftentimes more influenced by the will of the American people than the politics in Washington would seem to indicate
column3: Jarrett said in an interview.

column1: Obama has no formal authority over state and local lawmakers
column2: so his persuasion is a form of soft power — the ""phone"" part of what Obama has described as a ""pen-and-phone"" strategy to take action in the absence of congressional cooperation.

column1: He's found fertile ground in Democratic-run cities such as Seattle
column2: where Mayor Ed Murray helped push for a minimum wage and paid leave laws that have gone into effect since April.

column1: President Obama recognizes that good ideas are being incubated at the local level
column2: and those are ideas that are going to go to scale nationally
column3: Murray said. That recognition can go a long way in a city such as Seattle
column4: which often doesn't get the national attention East Coast cities do. ""The president of the United States recognizing us only helps us. We do other things beside e-commerce and coffee
column5: Murray said.

column1: There's also resistance. Jon Russell is a councilman in Culpeper
column2: Va.
column3: and the director of the American City County Exchange
column4: a year-old initiative of the small-government American Legislative Exchange Council.

column1: Russell said states — not cities
column2: not Congress and not the president — should be the primary regulator of labor conditions. Obama
column3: he said
column4: is ""hop-skipping over the states.""

column1: With the number of states that have now turned to the opposite political party
column2: he doesn't have the allies there that he used to
column3: Russell said. ""To work with the urban areas to push his agenda is not surprising. It's the only allies he really has.""

column1: The strategy has been more effective on some policies than others. Since last September
column2: more than 200 mayors have signed on to the My Brother's Keeper initiative
column3: a commitment to help boys and young men of color. But since Obama called for states to offer free community college in January
column4: only a handful have moved in that direction.

column1: The state-and-local strategy effort has been particularly effective on paid leave policies
column2: which Obama championed in his State of the Union Address this year. ""Forty-three million workers have no paid sick leave — 43 million. Think about that
column3: Obama said. ""So I'll be taking new action to help states adopt paid leave laws of their own.""

column1: That pledge came with a $1 million budget from the Department of Labor to help fund feasibility studies for state and local governments
column2: which will begin to be awarded this summer.

column1: Obama dispatched Jarrett and Labor Secretary Tom Perez on a ""Lead on Leave"" tour of cities that have adopted paid leave policies. Jarrett went to Philadelphia and Chicago; Perez has been to Portland
column2: Ore.
column3: Pawtucket
column4: R.I.
column5: St. Petersburg
column6: Fla.
column7: and Seattle.

column1: Tuesday
column2: Perez will be in Minneapolis
column3: which just adopted a paid leave policy for city employees this month.

column1: Perez said it's a mistake to view the state-and-local strategy as separate from a larger effort. ""Our strategy is an all-of-the-above-and-then-some strategy
column2: he said.

column1: He said Obama will continue to use executive orders
column2: as he did when he increased the minimum wage for federal contractors to $10.10 an hour.

column1: We want Congress to act
column2: and I'm confident that it's a when question
column3: not an if question. But we're also not going to wait around for Congress to act
column4: Perez said.

column1: Although focusing on city councils may seem small compared with the sweeping congressional legislation early in Obama's presidency
column2: state minimum wage laws will raise the pay of more than 7 million people by 2017. (That number
column3: which comes from the White House Council of Economic Advisers
column4: includes people making just above minimum wage who were helped indirectly because their wages are increased accordingly.)

column1: That's nothing to sneeze at. That's progress
column2: Jarrett said.

column1: San Francisco passed the first paid sick time law in the nation in 2006
column2: requiring all employers to grant one hour of paid sick time for every 30 hours worked. Three states and 18 cities now have paid sick leave laws on the books
column3: according to A Better Balance
column4: a New York-based legal advocacy group that tracks such laws.

column1: A year ago
column2: advocates had a hard time breaking through the public consciousness on the issue
column3: said the group's co-president
column4: Sherry Leiwant. After a White House Working Families Summit last year
column5: and again after January's State of the Union Address
column6: there's been an ""explosion"" of interest by state and local lawmakers
column7: she said.

column1: The White House leadership on this issue has been huge. It's had a real impact
column2: Leiwant said. ""That influence on mayors or governors
column3: who are Democrats but haven't paid a lot of attention to this issue
column4: or they want to be pro-business Democrats
column5: this gives them a lot of cover.""

column1: A Better Balance still favors a national law that would cover everyone
column2: but while the government is divided at the national level
column3: ""the best strategy is to go to localities and states.""

column1: A city-by-city strategy can be painstaking and legally complicated. Every state grants different home rule powers to cities — and even different powers to different-sized cities in the same state.
Philadelphia was able to pass a paid leave bill applying to private-sector workers
column2: but Pittsburgh's law applies only to some non-union city workers. Pittsburgh City Councilwoman Natalia Rudiak credits Obama for giving her city's effort ""a lot of momentum
column3: but she said more cities need to put pressure on the state Legislature to adopt statewide law.

column1: There's also pushback from the opposite direction. Last month
column2: the Pennsylvania Senate voted 37-12 to preempt the Philadelphia law
column3: taking the power to regulate sick leave out of the hands of local governments.

column1: That bill's sponsor
column2: state Sen. John Eichelberger Jr.
column3: said it's untenable to have 2
column4: 562 municipalities with different labor standards
column5: forcing businesses to comply with a patchwork of rules.

column1: Philosophically
column2: I have a real problem with President Obama going to a municipality and trying to accomplish an agenda
column3: whether it's liberal or conservative or otherwise
column4: he said. ""It's just not the place to adopt these policies.""

column1: Obama has opened an entirely new frontier of presidential power by turning to state and local governments
column2: said Matthew Eshbaugh-Soha
column3: who studies the effect of presidential persuasion at the University of North Texas.

column1: I'm really struck by
column2: one
column3: why hasn't anybody thought of this before? And two
column4: this could be a very effective strategy
column5: Eshbaugh-Soha said. ""At a time when executive orders are becoming particularly controversial and you're not able to break through the gridlock of Congress
column6: I think it's ingenious.""

column1: He's skeptical that the effort will put much pressure on members of Congress who don't support Obama's policies.

Jarrett said the effort is starting to snowball. She said some city leaders agreed with paid leave on principle but were reluctant to pass what could be seen as burdensome regulations in a difficult economy. As more cities and states have passed those policies
column2: it's emboldened others.

column1: Success begets success
column2: she said. ""What the evidence has begun to show is it's not a burden but an investment that is starting to pay off.""

column1: Indeed
column2: Philadelphia Mayor Michael Nutter vetoed two paid leave bills in 2011 and 2013. But three weeks after Obama's State of the Union Address this year
column3: Nutter reversed course.

column1: What changed? Nutter said the economy was better
column2: and the bill contained key compromises to accommodate small businesses. Nutter spokesman Mark McDonald said he was unaware of any role Obama had in getting the bill passed.

column1: Bill Greenlee
column2: the councilman who sponsored the measure
column3: said Nutter ""completely turned a corner"" on paid leave when the president put it on his agenda. ""I gotta think that when the president mentions sick leave in his State of the Union
column4: and if you're a Democrat and a supporter of the president's agenda in general
column5: that's gotta have an effect
column6: Greenlee said.

column1: Nutter did make a symbolic nod to Obama's influence in signing the paid leave bill: He signed it with a pen Obama gave him — after the president used it to sign an unemployment compensation bill. The only other time Nutter used that pen was on an executive order raising the minimum wage for city contractors to $12 an hour."	REAL

column1: My purpose here today is to assert in my judgment
column2: (ISIS) is responsible for genocide against groups in areas under its control including Yazidis
column3: Christians and Shiite Muslims
column4: he said

column1: Kerry said that in 2014
column2: ISIS trapped Yazidis
column3: killed them
column4: enslaved thousands of Yazidi women and girls
column5: "" selling them at auction
column6: raping them at will and destroying the communities in which they had lived for countless generations
column7: executed Christians ""solely for their faith"" and also ""forced Christian women and girls into slavery.""

column1: Without our intervention
column2: it is clear that those people would have been slaughtered
column3: he said.

column1: This is the first time that the United States has declared a genocide since Darfur in 2004.
The House of Representatives on Monday unanimously passed a resolution labeling the ISIS atrocities against Christian groups in Syria and Iraq ""genocide
column2: a term the State Department had been reluctant to use about the attacks and mass murders by the terror group.

column1: The move
column2: aimed at ramping up pressure on the Obama administration
column3: appears to have worked.

column1: The measure was non-binding
column2: but both Republicans and Democrats in the House joined together 393-0 to back a ""sense of Congress"" saying the crimes committed against Christians
column3: Yazidis and other ethnic and religious minorities in the region amount to war crimes and
column4: in some cases
column5: genocide.

column1: Republican Rep. Jeff Fortenberry
column2: whose Nebraska district is home to the largest group of resettled Yazidis in the U.S.
column3: authored the resolution with California Democratic Rep. Anna Eshoo.

column1: During debate on Monday
column2: Fortenberry noted it was a rare instance of an issue that has ""risen above the petty and difficult differences we often work out on the floor of the House of Representatives.""

column1: Under a deadline set by Congress
column2: the State Department had until Thursday to formally to decide whether it would issue a comprehensive genocide designation.

column1: Kerry
column2: though
column3: had previously alluded to the possibility that the actions of ISIS
column4: also know as ISIL
column5: were genocide.

column1: ISIL's campaign of terror against the innocent
column2: including the Yazidi and Christian minorities
column3: and its grotesque targeted acts of violence
column4: show all the warning signs of genocide
column5: Kerry said in August 2014. ""For anyone who needed a wakeup call
column6: this is it.""

column1: Fortenberry praised the State Department for its decision Thursday.
I commend Secretary Kerry and the State Department for making this important designation. The genocide against Christians
column2: Yazidis and others is not only a grave injustice to theses ancient faith communities -- it is an assault on human dignity and an attack on civilization itself
column3: he said. ""The United States has now spoken with clarity and moral authority.""

column1: That it took so long for the administration to arrive at this conclusion
column2: in the face of unspeakable human suffering
column3: defies explanation
column4: Rubio
column5: who until Tuesday was a GOP presidential candidate
column6: said in a statement. ""At long last the United States is no longer silent in the face of this evil
column7: but it would be travesty if we were to mistakenly take solace in this designation
column8: if the designation did not then yield some sort of action.""

column1: I am very happy to hear that (the U.S.) will recognize the genocide of Yezidi and Christian minorities
column2: he told CNN in an email. ""This is an important step to stop the suffering of the persecuted people under the control of the extremist islamic groups
column3: specially ISIS. And this is also important for my community to trust the international community again
column4: because we were left in the hands of Islamic State.""

column1: He called on the State Department to push the U.N. to establish an international criminal court case on genocide against the Yazidis and Christians in Iraq and Syria.
Furthermore
column2: he said

column1: An international center advocating against hate

column1: The Simon Wiesenthal Center applauds Secretary Kerry's acknowledgement that Christians and Yazidis are targets of Genocide

For the U.S. government to call this savagery by its proper name -- genocide -- is a welcome step in what must now be a more committed effort at bringing peace and security to that beleaguered land
column3: Wuerl said. ""These words must now be translated into action."""	REAL

column1: Mitt Romney's Re-Invention As Anti-Poverty Warrior	"With the shake of an Etch-A-Sketch
column2: Mitt Romney reintroduced himself to the Republican Party on Friday as a man interested in running for president because of his desire to address poverty and income inequality. One only wonders why the former governor of Massachusetts neglected to focus on the growing problems the last time he held the title of GOP standard bearer.

column1: Addressing a gathering of Republican National Committee officials below deck of the decommissioned U.S.S. Midway aircraft carrier in San Diego
column2: California
column3: Romney ticked off three priorities crucial to what he called the ""post-Obama era"": making the world safer with a more muscular foreign policy
column4: providing opportunity to all Americans
column5: and lifting people out of poverty.

column1: It's a tragedy
column2: a human tragedy
column3: that the middle class in this country by and large doesn't believe that the future will be better than the past
column4: he said. ""We haven't seen rising incomes over decades.""

column1: The rich have gotten richer
column2: income inequality has gotten worse and there are more people in poverty than ever before under this president
column3: he added.

column1: Romney stressed his years as an LDS pastor
column2: a topic he and his campaign rarely broached in 2012
column3: and described working ""with people who are very poor to help them get help.""

column1: The governor isn't the only potential Republican presidential candidate to embrace a more populist tone as wage growth continues to lag in an accelerating economic recovery. Former Florida Gov. Jeb Bush recently lamented that ""while the last eight years have been pretty good ones for top-earners
column2: they've been a lost decade for the rest of America."" Former Pennsylvania Sen. Rick Santorum has emphasized reconnecting with blue collar Americans. Even die-hard conservatives like Sens. Rand Paul (R-Ky.) and Ted Cruz (R-Texas) paid lip service to the matter at the Heritage Foundation policy summit
column3: an annual gathering of conservatives in Washington.

column1: While he may be sincere in his pursuit to eliminate poverty
column2: the notion that Romney would be the best candidate to lead his party in doing so is puzzling at best. The former Massachusetts governor didn't have just one misstep that allowed Democrats and Republican primary opponents to paint him as an obscenely wealthy
column3: out-of-touch plutocrat in the 2012 election -- he had a dozen. Here's just a brief sampling:

column1: I'm in this race because I care about Americans. I'm not concerned about the very poor. We have a safety net there. If it needs repair
column2: I'll fix it
column3: he said inelegantly following his victory in the Florida primary. ""I'm not concerned about the very rich
column4: they're doing just fine. I'm concerned about the very heart of the America
column5: the 90 percent
column6: 95 percent of Americans who right now are struggling.""

column1: Corporations are people
column2: my friend ... of course they are. Everything corporations earn ultimately goes to the people
column3: he said before the Iowa Ames straw poll.

column1: And his infamous remarks about ""47 percent"" of Americans: ""My job is not to worry about those people -- I'll never convince them that they should take personal responsibility and care for their lives.""
But it's not just the gaffes. Romney embraced the Paul Ryan budget in 2012 -- a sweeping plan that
column2: if enacted
column3: would have instituted draconian cuts to programs affecting the poor. Millions of low-income Americans benefiting from Medicare
column4: Medicaid and Social Security
column5: as well as other retirement funding
column6: would have been affected under a Romney presidency. Added to his promise to repeal the Affordable Care Act and its subsidies for the poor
column7: it's not hard to see how Romney wouldn't be vexed by some of the same problems should he ultimately decide to run for president."	REAL

column1: King: Fill the Supreme Court vacancy	"""We've got an opening on the court. I think Sandra Day O'Connor made a very practical point. Let's fill the vacancy so the court can fully function and get on with it
column2: he told CNN's Chris Cuomo on ""New Day.""

column1: I don't agree (with Republicans)

column1: Ted Cruz is toast: It’s not just that he won’t be president — his days in the Senate are numbered, too	"I’m not sure when it started
column2: but at some point the Republican Party ceded the business of governance to the Democrats. Maybe it began with the Tea Party movement or Fox News or the larger conservative media-industrial complex – I honestly don’t know. But it’s clear now that the GOP is no longer a legitimate governing party. A party that allows rank neophytes like Herman Cain and Donald Trump and Ben Carson and Carly Fiorina to run for the highest office in the country has lost its way.

column1: If you look at how the Republican Party operates today
column2: it’s hard to avoid the conclusion that governing just isn’t a priority – or internal pressures within the party make it impossible. Instead
column3: the GOP has become what I previously called a self-perpetuating hype machine for conservative political entrepreneurs. Particularly at the national level
column4: Republican candidates and legislators (many of them
column5: at least) show no interest in compromise or serious policymaking
column6: which is what you’d expect from a party of and for purists.

column1: While the new GOP has been bad for the country
column2: it’s been great for political celebrities
column3: people looking to promote their personal brands. Ted Cruz is the most recent and obvious example of this approach to politics. Cruz has been a remarkably ineffective Senator. He has done nothing but bloviate and showboat on the Senate floor. He’s accomplished zero legislatively. His only practical contribution has been to obstruct and draw attention to his martyrdom (read: presidential) campaign.

column1: Ted Cruz will never be elected president. If he manages to win the Republican nomination
column2: he’ll lose in a landslide to a Democrat
column3: whoever that happens to be. And because he’s so eagerly made a spectacle of himself in the Senate
column4: he’s alienated all but the tiniest segment of his own party. Which means he has no political capital in Congress – hardly a concern for someone uninterested in legislating
column5: however.

column1: Cruz’s latest squabble with Rand Paul helps to illustrate Cruz’s intentions. In an interview with Fox News’ Brian Kilmeade
column2: Paul basically wrote Cruz’s political obituary:

column1: Ted has chosen to make this really personal and chosen to call people dishonest in leadership and call them names which really goes against the decorum and also against the rules of the senate
column2: and as a consequence he can’t get anything done legislatively. He is pretty much done for and stifled and it’s really because of personal relationships
column3: or lack of personal relationships
column4: and it is a problem. I approach things a little different
column5: I am still just as hardcore in saying what we are doing
column6: I just chose not to call people liars on the Senate floor and it’s just a matter of different perspectives on how best to get to the end result.

column1: Paul is right
column2: of course
column3: but he omits an essential point: Cruz has been ineffective by design. Managing relationships and respecting decorum only matter to people trying to accomplish things in the Senate – that’s not what Cruz is up to. Like the fanatical Tea Party wing of the House
column4: Cruz is there to obstruct and self-promote. In all likelihood
column5: Cruz will retire after a single term in the Senate. Now that he’s boosted his national profile and endeared himself to the insurgent elements of the base
column6: he can pivot to the private sector and make more money as a professional conservative activist – as
column7: for example
column8: Jim DeMint did in 2012. Cruz ought to be seen as the grifter that he is. It was never about policy for him. When he leaves the Senate
column9: he’ll be a hero to the fringe right. He’ll make a fortune on the conservative lecture circuit
column10: telling rapturous audiences about his willingness to challenge the “Washington cartel.” It won’t matter that he accomplished nothing
column11: changed nothing – it’ll be enough that he pretended to while he was there. The same is true of Carson and Trump and Fiorina and even politicians like Huckabee and Jindal: None of them will be president
column12: but their over-the-top activism will ensure them a profitable career after politics. And that
column13: I assume
column14: is the whole point. The Democrats have their share of bad politicians
column15: but you don’t see this kind of faux activism and exploitation in their party."	REAL

column1: Obama’s speech in Selma was an answer to those who question his love for America	"President Obama's supporters sometimes wonder where the inspirational candidate of 2008 has gone. The answer is to the White House. Obama's presidency is about smaller
column2: less inspiring questions than his 2008 campaign.

column1: Obama's presidency is bounded by the limits of the office and the demands of the moment. It is about what America needs to do right now — the next budget
column2: the next bill
column3: next year's taxes
column4: the last war. Candidates can muse. Presidents must govern.

column1: Obama's 2008 campaign was about what kind of country America is; how to read its past to best guide its future. His speech in Selma — which is really worth reading in its entirety — was among the best of his presidency precisely because it had almost nothing to do with his presidency; it was a return to the central topic of his campaign.
Historians who want to understand Obama will find few better summations than the two paragraphs at the core of this speech:
We do a disservice to the cause of justice by intimating that bias and discrimination are immutable
column2: or that racial division is inherent to America. If you think nothing's changed in the past fifty years
column3: ask somebody who lived through the Selma or Chicago or L.A. of the Fifties. Ask the female CEO who once might have been assigned to the secretarial pool if nothing's changed. Ask your gay friend if it's easier to be out and proud in America now than it was thirty years ago. To deny this progress — our progress — would be to rob us of our own agency; our responsibility to do what we can to make America better. Of course
column4: a more common mistake is to suggest that racism is banished
column5: that the work that drew men and women to Selma is complete
column6: and that whatever racial tensions remain are a consequence of those seeking to play the ""race card"" for their own purposes. We don't need the Ferguson report to know that's not true. We just need to open our eyes
column7: and ears
column8: and hearts
column9: to know that this nation's racial history still casts its long shadow upon us. We know the march is not yet over
column10: the race is not yet won
column11: and that reaching that blessed destination where we are judged by the content of our character requires admitting as much.

column1: Those 230 words are a precise distillation of Obama's view of America
column2: and the role politics must play in it.

column1: The first paragraph is Obama's case for hope: America is improving; it has always been improving
column2: and to deny that improvement is to steal from Americans a belief in their country that they have more than earned. ""To deny this progress — our progress — would be to rob us of our own agency
column3: he said.

column1: The second paragraph is Obama's case for change: America's sins are not vanquished; its hatreds remain real; its racism still breathes. ""We know the march is not yet over
column2: Obama said
column3: ""the race is not yet won
column4: and that reaching that blessed destination where we are judged by the content of our character requires admitting as much.""

column1: Hope and change. These are the two ideas that form the steady core of Obama's politics. But
column2: more than that
column3: they are the two ideas that define
column4: for Obama
column5: what kind of country America is — and what it means to serve it.

column1: Obama's critics question his love for the country he governs. ""I do not believe — and I know this is a horrible thing to say — but I do not believe that the president loves America
column2: former New York Mayor Rudy Giuliani said in February. They look at Obama's steady belief that America is not yet good enough
column3: not yet pure enough
column4: not yet perfect enough
column5: and they see a skeptic
column6: not a patriot.

column1: In this speech
column2: Obama's answer to this criticism was direct:

column1: Fellow marchers
column2: so much has changed in fifty years. We've endured war
column3: and fashioned peace. We've seen technological wonders that touch every aspect of our lives
column4: and take for granted convenience our parents might scarcely imagine. But what has not changed is the imperative of citizenship
column5: that willingness of a 26 year-old deacon
column6: or a Unitarian minister
column7: or a young mother of five
column8: to decide they loved this country so much that they'd risk everything to realize its promise. That's what it means to love America. That's what it means to believe in America. That's what it means when we say America is exceptional.

column1: There is an implicit radicalism in what Obama is saying here. To believe America is good enough is to abandon the tradition of criticism and activism that has made America great.
Obama's answer to Giuliani is that Giuliani has mistaken uncritical adoration for the hard work required of true love. Patriotism is active
column2: not passive. Those who love America prove it by working to perfect America. They continue marching."	REAL

column1: Where Does Bernie Sanders Go From Here?	"NEW YORK - Bernie Sanders is at a crossroads.
The Vermont senator took Wednesday off the campaign trail at home alone with his wife
column2: leaving his top aides behind in Washington to cool their heels.

column1: He wanted an opportunity to think
column2: said Sanders senior strategist Tad Devine. ""It's affording him an opportunity to think about where we are in the campaign
column3: what he wants to say in the weeks ahead. He hasn't had a real chance to do that"" in weeks.

column1: The Sanders campaign poured itself into New York
column2: throwing a hail mary pass to try to change the delegate math while they could. They spent $5.6 million (twice what Hillary Clinton did)
column3: made 3 million phone calls in the final weekend alone
column4: and organized the biggest rallies of a campaign defined by big rallies.

column1: But in the end Sanders came up short - not just of winning
column2: but of the delegate target allies had aimed to hit
column3: which might set them up for a path through California
column4: the campaign's final hope.

column1: Now
column2: with the nomination even further out of reach
column3: Sanders faces the difficult question about what comes next. Does he set a do-whatever-it-takes course to actually win the Democratic nomination? Or does he return to the message campaign his long-shot White House bid was originally seen as?

column1: There's no question that Sanders will stay in the race either way. ""Bernie made a decision after Nevada that he was going to go through this process and finish it up by letting everybody who wanted to vote
column2: vote
column3: Devine said.

column1: Democratic primary voters have shown no sign they're in a rush for the race to settle down
column2: and seem hungry for Sanders' message
column3: if not his presidency.

column1: He'll continue to draw massive crowds from zealous fans
column2: who have almost literally given his campaign a blank check to do as they wish. On Wednesday night
column3: the campaign announced raising $15 million more than Clinton in March
column4: though they also spent much more.

column1: But even some Sanders allies cringed at parts of the candidate's message in New York
column2: where his agenda was sometimes obscured by a focus on Clinton and issues with the election process.

column1: Going forward
column2: what we're encouraging Senator Sanders to do is to continue to keep the campaign focused on the issues
column3: said Neil Sroka
column4: the communications director of Democracy for America
column5: which backs Sanders.

column1: The campaign says they want to return to more substantive issues - but only as long as the Clinton campaign joins them. So far
column2: at least
column3: they believe Clinton forces are keeping up the heat and see it as sign Clinton still views Sanders as a threat.

column1: Privately
column2: some Sanders allies say it's time for the candidate to start to thinking more about how he maximizes his leverage at the Democratic National Convention
column3: and afterwards
column4: and less about beating Clinton at all costs.

column1: One indicator of which kind of campaign Sanders wants to run is how much he and his aides continue to talk about relying on super delegates to hand them the nomination.
The strategy
column2: which calls for wooing the unelected delegates even if Sanders loses more primaries and caucuses
column3: was floated by campaign manager Jeff Weaver with MSNBC's Steve Kornacki late Tuesday night.

column1: MoveOn.org and Democracy for America
column2: both of which have endorsed Sanders
column3: have since 2008 been pressuring super delegates to support whichever candidate gets the most votes.

column1: More than 380
column2: 000 people signed petitions from the group agreeing that ""the race for the Democratic Party nomination should be decided by who gets the most votes
column3: and not who has the most support from party insiders.""

column1: Both groups confirmed to MSNBC Wednesday that they still hold that position.
MoveOn members overwhelmingly endorsed Sanders for president
column2: and we want him to win the most pledged delegates
column3: become the nominee
column4: and become president. But superdelegates shouldn't overrule the will of the Democratic grassroots
column5: said MoveOn Washington Director Ben Wikler. ""If the primary and caucus winner is Hillary Clinton
column6: then Clinton should be the nominee.""

column1: Devine said the campaign's main focus is still to win pledged delegates. But if Sanders falls just short of a majority
column2: it's negligible - ""de minims
column3: Devine said - and the campaign will pitch super delegates that Sanders is the stronger general election candidate.

column1: Another indication of Sanders' intentions will be where he devotes his precious time in the days leading up to Tuesday's contests.
Five states are voting and Maryland is expected to be Sanders' worst showing.

If he invests heavily there it's a sign his campaign is still focused on winning and scraping together delegates. If he spends time in states like Connecticut and Delaware to try to eek out wins despite limited delegate opportunities
column2: it's a sign he's more focused on moral victories than ones that lead to the nomination.

column1: What Sanders decides to do
column2: and how aggressively he decides to continuing pursuing Clinton
column3: will help determine the shape of the rest of the primary and how quickly Clinton
column4: the odds-on nominee
column5: can unite the party.

column1: Clinton's favorability rating has tumbled during the primary
column2: especially among Sanders voters
column3: presumably at least in part due to his attacks.

column1: But as Democratic leaders worry about the damage
column2: the party seem to be enjoying the contest.

column1: National polling between Clinton and Sanders has tightened to a virtual dead heat
column2: suggesting voters are not ready to settle on Clinton. Exit polls showed two-thirds of New York primary voters found the heated contest in the state to be energizing
column3: not divisive.

column1: Mr. Sanders's presence has made this an immeasurably more substantive race
column2: The New York Times wrote in an editorial Wednesday calling on Sanders to ignore calls to leave the race
column3: which was shared by the Sanders campaign. The enthusiasm of his supporters ""should be a wake-up call to leaders of both parties. They are missing something big about their own members' priorities
column4: and their mood.""

column1: Still
column2: Sanders' entire campaign has been about bringing new people into politics and the Democratic party. At some point
column3: he might risk pushing them back out again."	REAL

column1: Give Social Security recipients a CEO-style raise	"(CNN) On Veterans Day we recognize and honor the sacrifices our service members and their families make for our country. We owe our service members the very best
column2: but unless Congress acts
column3: on January 1 more than 9 million veterans who rely on Social Security benefits or pension and compensation benefits will not get their annual cost of living increase.

column1: This freeze in funds
column2: which has happened only two other times since 1975
column3: will be really tough on veterans among the 71 million Americans who depend on Social Security and other benefits to help make ends meet. Two-thirds of seniors depend on Social Security for the majority of their income
column4: and for 15 million Americans
column5: Social Security is all that stands between them and poverty.

column1: While vets and seniors get no raise
column2: CEOs at the top 350 American companies received
column3: on average
column4: a 3.9% pay increase last year. That's a lot of money. The average CEO at one of the top 350 American companies made $16.3 million and got more than half a million in pay raises. So CEOs get huge raises
column5: while seniors
column6: veterans and others who've worked hard don't get an extra dime. Why? It's not an accident. It's not inevitable. It's the result of deliberate policies set by Congress.

column1: Social Security is supposed to be indexed to inflation so that when prices go up
column2: benefits go up
column3: too. But Congress' formula samples the spending patterns of about a quarter of the country
column4: and the formula isn't geared to what older Americans actually spend.

column1: Projections for the costs of core goods and services show inflation is up about 2%
column2: but seniors won't get a cost of living increase -- mostly because of falling gasoline prices
column3: which don't mean as much to millions of seniors who don't commute to work. So seniors
column4: who are already struggling to scrape by to cover rent and exploding prescription drug prices
column5: will be left scrambling.

column1: Sure
column2: companies should make their own decisions about how much to compensate executives
column3: but because of the laws Congress has passed
column4: American taxpayers are forced to subsidize these multimillion-dollar pay packages.

column1: It's time for Congress to make different choices. That's why last week I introduced the Seniors And Veterans Emergency (SAVE) Benefits Act. The SAVE Benefits Act will give seniors on Social Security
column2: veterans
column3: those with disabilities and others a one-time payment in 2016 equivalent to an average increase of 3.9% -- the same as the taxpayer-subsidized raise that CEOs received last year.

column1: We can afford to give seniors and vets a raise. In fact
column2: we can increase pay for seniors and vets without adding a single penny to the deficit simply by closing the bonus loophole for corporate executives. According to the chief actuary of the Social Security Administration
column3: closing this loophole will create enough revenue to help millions of Americans and still have enough left over to help extend the life of the Social Security trust fund.

column1: Seniors and vets would get an increase of about $581 next year — a little less than $50 a month. That $581 increase would cover almost three months of groceries for seniors or a year's worth of out-of-pocket costs on critical prescription drugs for the average Medicare beneficiary. That $50 a month is worth a lot to those 71 million Americans. According to an analysis from the Economic Policy Institute
column2: that little boost could lift more than 1 million Americans out of poverty.

column1: Giving vets and seniors a little help and stitching up these corporate tax write-offs isn't just about economics; it's about our values. For too long
column2: we've listened to a handful of people with money and power who say: Cut taxes for those at the top
column3: cut rules and regulations that keep everyone honest
column4: and let everyone else fight over the scraps. We tried trickle-down economics
column5: and it failed.

column1: But we can make different choices -- choices that reflect our values. We don't have to ignore this problem. We can give a small boost to 71 million Americans who have earned it and who need it.

We can lift over 1 million people out of poverty. We can extend the life of Social Security. And we can do it by shutting down taxpayer giveaways to a handful of wealthy corporations that will do fine without them. For me
column2: this is simple. Our spending should reflect our values
column3: and that means passing the SAVE Benefits Act."	REAL

How Ted Cruz Became Ted Cruz	"In 2008
column2: in the high-profile Supreme Court gun-rights case called District of Columbia v. Heller
column3: a brief was filed from the eighth floor of the Price Daniel Sr. State Office Building in Austin
column4: Texas
column5: specifically from the corner office of the man who was then the state’s solicitor general
column6: Ted Cruz.

column1: The brief took a strong stance on the divisive question of whether the Second Amendment establishes an individual right to own guns
column2: or just protects state and local militias. The brief argued forcefully for the first view
column3: writing that “the individual right to keep and bear arms” is a “fundamental right” and that “an individual right that can be altogether abrogated is no right at all.” Thirty attorneys general from other states signed on.

column1: Today
column2: with the White House pushing new gun restrictions and Cruz's candidacy riding on next month's Iowa caucuses
column3: it's no surprise that the Texas Republican would embrace gun rights as a defining issue
column4: holding an event at a firing range and even raffling off an engraved 12-gauge shotgun as a campaign promotion.

column2: the situation was very different: he was wading into a case that had no immediate connection to Texas at all. But to see the signature of R. Ted Cruz on the brief would not have surprised the nine Supreme Court justices in the least. By that time
column3: Cruz had been solicitor general for five years
column4: and inserting himself into a case of wide prominence and importance regardless of any direct tie to Texas had become part of his playbook. He clearly saw the Heller case as a watershed in gun rights
column5: writing that it would “determine whether the Second Amendment has any modern relevance.” And he was right. The Supreme Court in a 5-4 decision shot down the Washington
column6: D.C.
column7: handgun ban and ruled for the first time in the history of this country that the amendment ensures an individual person’s right to have a gun for self-defense. The National Rifle Association recognized Cruz’s role with a resolution.

column1: As Cruz climbs to the top of the Republican presidential field
column2: the five-plus years he served as the solicitor general of Texas remain the most important period in his public résumé. They’re the record he ran on when he was elected to the U.S. Senate in 2012—and they represent significantly more of his working life than the three years he has served so far in the Senate. They're also a prime source of fodder for liberal and moderate critics
column3: should be become the Republican presidential nominee.

column1: A Politico review of Cruz’s record as solicitor general shows he used the role in a new and far more ideological way than his predecessors
column2: taking a relatively low-profile job that had traditionally been used mostly to defend the state government and turning it into a stage for pushing national conservative causes. Cruz argued eight cases in front of the U.S. Supreme Court—far more than his predecessors and successors—using each of them to advance a position endorsed by conservative thinkers. He also was the counsel of record on some 70 friend-of-the-court briefs
column3: or amicus briefs
column4: weighing in on cases across the country
column5: like Heller
column6: in which Texas had no direct stake
column7: but which similarly offered a chance to argue ideological points.

column1: “He really turned the office into a platform
column2: ” David Bernstein
column3: a George Mason law professor who recently wrote a book about the Obama administration for which Cruz wrote the foreword
column4: said in an interview.

column1: “He built up the national aura of the office
column2: ” said Tom Phillips
column3: who was the chief justice of the Supreme Court of Texas at the start of Cruz’s run as solicitor general.

column1: Cruz’s zealous work served the ambitions of the conservative movement
column2: but he also personally used it to build a bridge between what he was (an elite constitutional law nerd) to what he is today (an ascendant right-wing politician). Yet while pleasing to conservatives
column3: other aspects of his record are sure to attract critics. He argued against leniency for an unjustly sentenced man whose lawyer had made a technical mistake; he invoked 13th-century “Saxon law” and the practice of cutting off testicles to justify harsher punishments in a rape case; and he referred to a late-term abortion technique as “infanticide.”

column1: Although little examined in the race so far
column2: Cruz’s time as solicitor general built him a powerful allegiance among the conservative donors necessary to launch a national campaign. Heading into Iowa
column3: New Hampshire
column4: South Carolina and beyond
column5: he has more money at his disposal than any candidate besides Jeb Bush. And the way he used that Texas office is part of the reason. Toby Neugebauer
column6: who wrote a $10 million check to the Cruz super PAC called Keep the Promise II
column7: told me the reason he did that—the single reason—is what Cruz did as solicitor general. He said other major donors feel the same way.

column1: “We’re backing someone
column2: ” Neugebauer told me
column3: “that had a worldview and went out and executed on it.”

column1: Cruz took the solicitor job as a reboot of sorts after his initial foray into politics had fizzled.
As a debater at Princeton
column2: as a law school student at Harvard
column3: and as a clerk to then-Supreme Court Chief Justice William Rehnquist
column4: Cruz was widely considered brilliant—but he left his first real job as a promising appellate attorney in private practice in Washington to instead toil in 2000 as a domestic policy analyst in George W. Bush’s presidential campaign
column5: then as a legal hand for Bush’s team in the frantic recount in Florida that ultimately won Bush the election.

column1: In return
column2: Cruz “desperately” wanted “a senior post” in the White House
column3: he wrote in his autobiography. On the campaign
column4: though
column5: he had earned a reputation for his outsized ego as much as for his obvious intelligence
column6: and the post-election jobs he got were out-of-the-way roles at the Department of Justice and the Federal Trade Commission. “I just don’t like the guy
column7: ” Bush has said since. The solicitor general role in his home state of Texas
column8: offered to him by Greg Abbott—then the attorney general of Texas
column9: now the governor—was a political lifeline.

column1: From the start
column2: it offered a chance to turn his legal acumen into political potential
column3: because it came with a green light to advance conservative aims in the courts. Abbott’s directive for the solicitor general of Texas
column4: Cruz said in his book
column5: was to “look across the country” and “identify chances to defend conservative principles.”

column1: This is not the traditional definition of a solicitor general’s job
column2: which comes with two main duties. The first: States get sued
column3: attorneys general and their staffs respond
column4: and some of the cases get appealed—and that’s where the solicitor general comes in
column5: representing the state in higher courts
column6: where the cases are the most legalistic and complex. The second: the writing of amicus briefs in cases elsewhere in which a state believes it has an interest even though it’s not a party.

column1: The first part can be seen as defense. The second part is more like offense
column2: selectively advancing the interests of the state. The way Cruz did the job? Even the defense was offense
column3: and the interests being asserted were less those of the state than its conservative leaders.

column1: “Texas is a huge state
column2: and there’s plenty of work for the attorney general’s office to do
column3: ” said Jim Ho
column4: an attorney in Dallas who succeeded Cruz as solicitor general and is a friend and supporter. Cruz
column5: though
column6: “was not content to simply do what was asked and go home.”

column1: When it came to cases that allowed him to argue for things like the forceful application of the death penalty and expressions of religion in the public arena and against things like abortion and gun control
column2: Ho told me
column3: Cruz “was on constant watch for opportunities to press a conservative vision of the Constitution.”"	REAL

column1: Accord reached after Sanders sues the DNC over suspended access to critical voter list	"The presidential campaign of Sen. Bernie Sanders of Vermont filed a lawsuit against the Democratic National Committee on Friday
column2: arguing that the party had unfairly suspended the campaign’s access to key voter information. After several tense hours
column3: both sides announced a deal had been reached.

column1: The suit came shortly after campaign manager Jeff Weaver acknowledged at a Washington news conference that Sanders staffers had improperly reviewed information gathered by rival Hillary Clinton earlier in the week. But he accused the DNC of over­reacting to the breach by suspending the Sanders campaign’s ability to access the computer system containing information about Democratic-leaning voters
column2: including data the campaign has gathered about its own supporters.

column1: After midnight
column2: Sanders and the DNC put out statements that both indicated the impasse had been resolved but that put remarkably different spins on the outcome. Sanders’s campaign said the DNC had “capitulated” and that Sanders would soon regain access to the data. The DNC said what happened was “completely unacceptable” and that it would continue to investigate the circumstances even as Sanders regained access to the valuable information.

column1: Without a quick resolution
column2: the messy public brawl threatened to overshadow Saturday’s third Democratic presidential debate and cast doubt on the DNC’s ability to manage the sophisticated data tools necessary for the party to win the White House next year. And it sparked significant suspicions among Sanders supporters that the party was conspiring to give a boost to Clinton.

column1: DNC Chairwoman Debbie Wasserman Schultz rejected that allegation Friday
column2: alleging that Sanders staffers had exploited a software error to essentially “steal” data from Clinton’s campaign. Wasserman Schultz said the party would not allow Sanders access to the critical database again until his campaign agreed to an independent audit of what happened.

column1: The suit
column2: filed in federal court in Washington
column3: argued that under a contract between the DNC and the campaign governing the data system’s use
column4: formal notice in writing is required if either side believes the other has violated the deal. In addition
column5: each side is supposed to be allowed 10 days to address any concerns
column6: the suit said.

column1: “The DNC may not suspend the Campaign’s access to critical Voter Data out of haste or desperation to clean up after the DNC’s own mistakes
column2: ” the suit says.

column1: The voter data is heavily used to raise money
column2: and the Sanders campaign estimated that it is losing $600
column3: 000 a day in “critical fundraising and publicity opportunities” without access to the files.

column1: The incident strained the relationship between the campaign of an upstart Vermont senator who until this year has run as an independent and a national party his supporters have long accused of favoring Clinton.
Weaver accused the party of purposely sabotaging Sanders by refusing to restore access to the voter information.
“By their action
column2: the leadership of the Democratic National Committee is now actively attempting to undermine our campaign
column3: ” Weaver said. “I think if you look at the pattern of conduct . . . it looks like in this case they’re trying to help the Clinton campaign.”

column1: NGP-VAN
column2: the computer vendor that provides Democrats with detailed information about voters
column3: has said that a computer error on Wednesday briefly allowed the campaigns to review information that had been gathered by their rivals.

column1: The company maintains a master voter list for the DNC and rents it to national and state campaigns
column2: which then add their own
column3: proprietary information gathered by field workers and volunteers. Firewalls are supposed to prevent campaigns from viewing data gathered by rival campaigns.

column1: The Sanders campaign has acknowledged that several of its staffers probed the system during the time of the error cited by NGP-VAN. One operative
column2: data director Josh Uretsky
column3: was fired as a result of the incident. Weaver said the actions of several others are being reviewed.

column1: Landing at the airport in Manchester
column2: N.H.
column3: ahead of Saturday’s debate
column4: Wasserman Schultz said that Sanders himself was unaware of the breach until she called to discuss it 24 hours after it took place. “He was stunned
column5: ” she said. “I know that Sen. Sanders had absolutely nothing to do with this. . . . Unfortunately
column6: he has staff who acted inappropriately
column7: and they need to be held accountable.”

column1: The severity of the data breach itself remained an issue of serious dispute Friday.

Audit data from NGP-VAN and provided to The Washington Post by the Clinton campaign showed that four Sanders staffers conducted 24 separate searches of Clinton data during a 40-minute window Wednesday
column2: targeting early voting states and searching for lists of voters most and least likely to support Clinton. The logs show that in some cases
column3: the staffers saved the search results in new folders created within the system.

column1: “This was a very egregious breach and our data was stolen. This was not an inadvertent glimpse into our data
column2: ” Clinton’s campaign manager
column3: Robby Mook
column4: told reporters.

column1: On CNN
column2: Clinton campaign spokesman Brian Fallon accused the Sanders staffers of acting “like kids in the candy store.”

column1: “They went hog wild
column2: downloading as much data as they could
column3: ” he said.

column1: Later Friday
column2: the Clinton camp struck a more conciliatory tone
column3: issuing a statement in which Fallon said that his campaign was hopeful the matter would be resolved Friday night and that the Sanders team would get access to its voter files “right away.”

column1: Uretsky told The Post that he and the others conducted the searches of Clinton data after they discovered the software glitch only in an effort to discover the extent of their own data exposure. “We intentionally did it in a way that was trackable and traceable so that when they did an audit they would be able to see exactly what we did
column2: ” he said.

column1: Uretsky said there was no attempt to take Clinton information out of the software system.
Weaver blamed the software vendor for the breach
column2: which allowed all campaigns to access one another’s data for a time
column3: insisting that the Sanders campaign had actually quietly alerted the DNC to problems with another vendor system in October.

column1: In the lawsuit
column2: the campaign argued that a “similar security incident” during the 2008 presidential campaign resulted in “unintentional transmission of confidential information” to Clinton’s unsuccessful presidential campaign against Barack Obama.

column1: Weaver said a tick-tock provided to the Sanders campaign by the computer vendor confirmed that staffers were not attempting to remove significant Clinton data from the system.
“We are running a clean campaign
column2: ” he said. “We don’t need dirty tricks.”

column1: Even before this week
column2: Sanders backers had accused the DNC of trying to protect Clinton by limiting the number and prominence of debates — a narrative that plays into his anti-establishment appeal.

column1: “They’ve been sabotaging Bernie’s campaign all along
column2: ” said RoseAnn DeMoro
column3: executive director of National Nurses United
column4: an 185
column5: 000-member union that is backing Sanders.

column1: News of the data breach broke just as Sanders was enjoying a fresh burst of momentum after months in which his campaign appeared to have stalled.
On Thursday
column2: Sanders received his biggest union endorsement to date
column3: from the 700
column4: 000-member Communications Workers of America. He also was endorsed by Democracy for America
column5: a progressive group that claims 1 million members nationwide. That group
column6: founded by former Vermont governor Howard Dean
column7: who is backing Clinton
column8: said it had surveyed its membership and found 88 percent favored endorsing Sanders.

column1: Sanders
column2: who has raised most of his money from small donors over the Internet
column3: also this week celebrated a fundraising milestone: more than 2 million contributions to his campaign. That figure made him competitive with the effort of President Obama’s 2012 re-election effort during the same stretch."	REAL

column1: Why the latest Patriot Act reform won’t be enough to rein in the NSA	"Recent debates over US government spying have focused on one specific program: the National Security Agency's bulk collection of Americans' telephone records — and the Patriot Act provision that supplied the program's legal justification. From that perspective
column2: the partial expiration of the Patriot Act a week ago and the subsequent passage of surveillance reform legislation might seem like a decisive victory against mass surveillance.

column1: But the surveillance debate is actually a lot bigger than the phone records program and the Patriot Act. The NSA has other spying programs with other legal foundations. And the USA Freedom Act
column2: which President Obama signed on Tuesday
column3: doesn't do anything to rein them in.

column1: On Friday
column2: I talked to John Napier Tye
column3: a former State Department official who resigned last year over what he regards as unconstitutional surveillance by the US federal government. He sees the USA Freedom Act as ""a small step in the right direction
column4: but he's hoping the next step will be a broader debate about other ways the US government spies on innocent Americans.

column1: Most people have heard about the Patriot Act
column2: which was signed just weeks after the 9/11 attacks
column3: and was reformed this week by the USA Freedom Act. But Tye argues the real action is elsewhere.

column1: You have to keep in mind that most NSA collection on Americans was not under the Patriot Act. It was under other legal authorities. And none of that surveillance is affected by this new law
column2: he says. ""When you think about all the collection that the NSA has been doing on Americans
column3: a small percentage — 5 or 10 percent
column4: maybe less — was under the Patriot Act.""

column1: Tye points to two other sources of authority for government spying. One is the 2008 FISA Amendments Act
column2: which is the legal basis for a controversial NSA program called PRISM that collects private data from major internet companies like Google and Facebook. The other is Executive Order 12333
column3: a Reagan-era directive that has become the basis for a lot of NSA spying.

column1: Tye says that EO 12333 is ""an executive order
column2: it's not a statute. It was never passed by Congress. It was originally issued by President Reagan in 1981 and has been amended several times since then — including by George W. Bush.""

column1: A huge amount of our data is collected: Gmails and Yahoo messages
column2: Facebook messages
column3: Apple iMessages

column1: EO 12333 ""gives a very broad grant of authority to intelligence agencies to do all kinds of things
column2: Tye says. ""There's one section in there that allows the NSA to collect data on US persons as part of a lawful foreign intelligence investigation. That provision is being used to collect a huge amount of Americans' communications and data.""

column1: When the government collects information overseas
column2: it isn't bound by most US surveillance laws. The NSA has reserved the right to ""incidentally"" collect Americans' private communications overseas so long as Americans are not the target of a particular surveillance effort. But Tye argues that this is a huge loophole in practice.

column1: I don't think most Americans understand that almost all of their internet and phone data is either stored on backup servers overseas or transits outside of our borders
column2: he says. ""A huge amount of our data is collected under this authority outside the borders of the US — Gmails and Yahoo messages
column3: Facebook messages
column4: Apple iMessages
column5: Twitter
column6: every service you can think of.""

column1: Tye says he has firsthand knowledge of the extent of NSA spying programs. That's because he was an official in the State Department's Bureau of Democracy
column2: Human Rights
column3: and Labor in 2013 when Edward Snowden's revelations became public.

column1: My jobs was internet freedom
column2: promoting free and open internet around the world
column3: Tye says. ""When the Snowden leaks happened in June of 2013
column4: I was not surprised. I knew that a lot of stuff had been happening. I knew that a lot of surveillance was going on that no one knew about. And it didn't surprise me that this was finally front-page news.""

column1: Congress should take a more active role in overseeing executive branch activity
Tye says that after the Snowden leaks
column2: ""part of my job was to help develop responses to initiatives within the UN Human Rights Council and the UN General Assembly by Germany
column3: Brazil
column4: and other countries that were very concerned with online privacy. To be able to properly negotiate those efforts
column5: I was briefed on the scope of US intelligence practices. In two different classified briefings
column6: one in the fall of 2013 and one in the first part of 2014
column7: I learned about activities under 12333.""

column1: Tye believed these programs were unconstitutional and began filing complaints inside the government about them. He met with the intelligence committees in both the House and the Senate and filed complaints with the inspectors general of both the State Department and the National Security Agency. He says none of them were very interested in the issue.
So last summer
column2: Tye quit his job and went public with his concerns in an op-ed for the Washington Post. He says he ran the op-ed through government censors to make sure it didn't disclose any classified information. Tye has spent the last year at the public interest group Avaaz and is now starting his own law firm that will focus on civil rights and human rights issues.

column1: Tye would like President Obama to unilaterally revise Executive Order 12333 to better protect the privacy of Americans. If Obama doesn't
column2: Tye would like Congress to hold hearings on the issue. ""I think that Congress should take a more active role in overseeing executive branch activity under 12333
column3: Tye says. ""Congress should hold hearings and find out what protections really exist for Americans and how much our data is being collected.""

column1: He also favors reforms to the FISA Amendments Act
column2: which was passed by Congress in 2008. Whereas some provisions of the Patriot Act were set to expire this year — and have now been renewed until 2019 — the FISA Amendments Act is permanent. The most controversial part of the FISA Amendments Act is Section 702
column3: which allows warrantless surveillance to collect Americans' communications so long as the target is a foreigner located overseas.

column1: Under Section 702
column2: the NSA is collecting a lot of stuff inside the United States that's nominally targeting foreigners but in fact is scooping up innocent communications from hundreds of millions of Americans
column3: Tye says. Even worse
column4: ""the FBI has access to that database and can search it for domestic criminal reasons. So the purpose of the law nominally was to allow the NSA to conduct foreign intelligence investigations. But as it's currently being used
column5: the FBI is using this data for domestic criminal investigations. The protections that we normally want in place for domestic criminal investigations are not necessarily there."""	REAL

column1: FBI expands probe of Clinton emails, launches independent classification review	"The FBI has expanded its probe of Hillary Clinton's emails
column2: with agents exploring whether multiple statements violate a federal false statements statute

column1: Fox News is told agents are looking at U.S. Code 18

column3: which pertains to ""materially false"" statements given either in writing
column4: orally or through a third party. Violations also include pressuring a third party to conspire in a cover-up. Each felony violation is subject to five years in prison.

column1: This phase represents an expansion of the FBI probe

column1: The agents involved are under a lot of pressure and are busting a--

column3: who was not authorized to speak on the record

column1: The section of the criminal code being explored is known as ""statements or entries generally

column1: Fox News judicial analyst Judge Andrew Napolitano said the same section got Martha Stewart in trouble with the FBI. To be a violation

column1: This is a broad
column2: brush statute that punishes individuals who are not direct and fulsome in their answers
column3: former FBI intelligence officer Timothy Gill told Fox News. Gill is not connected to the email investigation

column1: Where is Gary Johnson?	"(CNN) Conservatives dissatisfied with Donald Trump have given the Libertarian presidential nominee a chance to take his third party to center stage
column2: but Gary Johnson has not exactly been a fixture on the campaign trail.

column1: Largely eschewing traditional campaign events
column2: the former New Mexico governor has instead opted to appear almost daily on multiple news programs and appeal to his solid core of online support.

column1: That could soon change as the campaign considers more regular appearances in the real world.
Johnson campaign spokesperson Joe Hunter told CNN Monday the campaign is now undergoing a ""natural evolution
column2: having recently ramped up its fundraising efforts with the stated intention of buying advertisements in key states and beginning to hold rallies across the country.

column1: Despite enjoying a brief surge in the lead-up to the major party conventions
column2: Johnson has generally hovered in the high single digits in national polls. The latest CNN Poll of Polls showed Johnson at 9% support nationwide.

column1: In a race where the majority of voters say they are dissatisfied with their mainstream offerings for president
column2: where the Republican nominee has secured little support from the nation's largest generation -- millennials -- and where digital media has taken an unprecedented place in the political landscape
column3: here's what Johnson is -- and isn't -- doing to make his long shot candidacy a viable bet.

column1: Hunter called the constant interviews ""a critical"" component of the campaign
column2: and after taking scheduling into account
column3: ""We take every opportunity we get.""

column1: Similar to Trump
column2: Johnson and his running mate
column3: Bill Weld
column4: have relied on ""earned media"" in the form of appearances in the press.

column1: Unlike Trump
column2: the two almost always stay on message.

column1: Since winning the nomination at the Libertarian Party's convention in May
column2: Johnson and Weld
column3: a former Massachusetts governor
column4: have used their appearances to cast themselves as the centrist candidates between Trump and Hillary Clinton.

column1: They point out their experience as Republican governors in traditionally Democratic-leaning states. Johnson often touts his laissez-faire approach to drugs and immigration
column2: while Weld has pointed to his record on LGBT rights and his cordial relationship with both sides of the aisle
column3: including the Clintons. Both champion their conservative credos on matters of spending.

column1: But the live television appearances
column2: including two prime-time town hall events on CNN
column3: have not yet afforded the Libertarian ticket national recognition or a strong showing in the polls.

column1: On the digital side
column2: the Johnson campaign has largely stuck to its roots by embracing the Libertarian community online. Reaching supporters through social media and email
column3: the campaign has kept its base abreast of its progress -- and appealed for funds.

column1: The Johnson campaign said Tuesday its August ""money bomb"" fundraising campaign surpassed its goal of $1.5 million based off ""entirely digital"" appeals for money. The campaign said it raised $840
column2: 000 on Monday alone
column3: totaling $2.9 million in donations in the first two weeks of the month.

column1: A number of groups have fallen into place doing some of the heavy lifting that the long shot bid needs doing.

Among the most standout recent entries into the Johnson orbit is a newly minted group called Republicans for Johnson/Weld. The group formed this month to bring the GOP leaders and voters Trump had alienated into the Libertarian fold.
Republican strategist and group spokesperson Liz Mair told CNN Monday the pro-Johnson forces seeking to convert Republicans from a divisive nominee were in uncharted waters.
I don't think anybody's tried to launch an effort like this
column2: Mair said.

column1: Despite the lack of an established path
column2: Johnson has notched a few victories. Rep. Scott Rigell said he will support Johnson in November
column3: and Reps. Reid Ribble and Mike Coffman have said they are considering it.

column1: In separate interviews
column2: Hunter and Mair both said they had heard supportive words from Republican politicians but that many were not ready to come out into the open against their party.

column1: The outside group could be a key factor in the mainstreaming of Johnson. It already holds several well-known Republican staffers. On Monday
column2: it added Joseph Russo III
column3: a former Sarah Palin aide
column4: Mair said.

column1: Given the nature of the group
column2: Mair said a ""number of us have better connections"" to GOP Capitol Hill figures than the Libertarian campaign.

column1: What will Mitt Romney do?
Within the Johnson campaign
column2: Weld has taken the lead on outreach to Republicans. However
column3: his biggest prize still eludes him: 2012 Republican nominee Mitt Romney.

column1: Romney served as governor of Massachusetts after Weld and has said if Weld were topping the ticket
column2: he would be supporting them
column3: but he still needed to hear what Johnson had to say. Months have passed since then without a Romney endorsement.

column1: The Libertarian efforts to sway Republicans have also had to push back against the notion they are helping Clinton.
Johnson has said he is pulling about evenly from both sides and been forceful in his condemnation of Trump.
Mair said Trump was doing the work of helping Clinton on his own and that Clinton's win was at this point ""overwhelming likely
column2: although Johnson still had a chance in an unpredictable cycle.

column1: The Republicans screwed up. That's not Gary Johnson's fault

column2: the campaign said it was looking at radio
column3: billboards and continuing its online efforts.

column2: meanwhile

column8: basically.""

column1: What happens if Clinton drops out?	"Whether an October surprise may have come a month early
column2: it’s too soon to say.

column1: But Hillary Clinton’s weekend health scare already has started to stir speculation about whether Democratic officials should be discussing the possibility of a Plan B
column2: in case they need to hastily arrange for a replacement nominee.

column1: Which raises a basic question: How does that work?
Democratic Party bylaws say the DNC has the power to fill “vacancies in the nominations for the office of the president and vice president” when the national convention is not in session.
Under party rules
column2: the DNC chair – currently Donna Brazile – could call a special meeting
column3: and fill the vacancy by a majority vote of those present.

column1: Analysts still see this scenario as exceedingly unlikely. It appears party leaders have no authority to sideline Clinton
column2: meaning the special meeting would kick in only if she were to step aside voluntarily. The nominee and her aides say she's recovering and feeling much better now.

column1: But after Clinton left a 9/11 memorial Sunday stumbling and being helped into an SUV by multiple aides -- an incident the campaign tied to a recent pneumonia diagnosis and other factors -- some Democrats are at least thinking about that process.
Former DNC Chairman Don Fowler told Politico that the party needs to develop a plan immediately for finding a potential successor candidate.
Former Al Jazeera and MSNBC anchor David Shuster tweeted Sunday that the DNC was considering an “emergency meeting” to talk about a Clinton replacement
column2: although his source emphasized her status as nominee was up to her
column3: not the party.

column1: NPR’s Cokie Roberts said Monday that Democrats already are considering another candidate.
“It has them very nervously beginning to whisper about having her step aside and finding another candidate
column2: ” Roberts said
column3: adding that “it’s unlikely to be a real thing” and describing the talk as likely “an overreaction.”

column1: Perhaps inadvertently feeding that frenzy
column2: former Ohio Democratic Gov. Ted Strickland introduced Clinton running mate Tim Kaine at an event Monday by describing him as “ready to become the president” if necessary
column3: The Columbus Dispatch reported.

column1: But in the
column2: albeit unlikely
column3: scenario of a replacement scramble
column4: Kaine isn’t necessarily a shoo-in.

column1: Vermont Sen. Bernie Sanders
column2: Vice President Joe Biden
column3: Massachusetts Sen. Elizabeth Warren and others could all be possible candidates.

column1: Historian Doug Wead told Fox News’ Neil Cavuto that the votes would tend to go toward whomever the top of the ticket endorses
column2: though it’s not guaranteed.

column1: “Whatever [Clinton] says will likely hold sway
column2: but legally
column3: technically they have their own vote
column4: ” he said.

column1: Replacing a member of a major-party ticket would be exceedingly rare
column2: though not unprecedented. This happened in 1972 when Democratic nominee George McGovern’s running mate -- Sen. Thomas Eagleton -- withdrew from the race in July after it was revealed he had undergone electric shock treatment for mental health issues.

column1: Eagleton was replaced in August by Sargent Shriver as the new vice presidential nominee. The McGovern/Shriver ticket went on to lose the race in a landslide to incumbent President Richard Nixon.
Rick Hasen
column2: who runs the Election Law Blog
column3: told FoxNews.com that the situation could become significantly more complicated if it were to play out later in the calendar.

column1: “The more complicated problem would arise if ballots have already been printed
column2: and people would have started voting. There
column3: the Electoral College would come into play
column4: and electors from the party would be expected to vote for the replacement nominee
column5: ” Hasen said.

column1: The first absentee ballots were mailed out in Sept. 9 in North Carolina
column2: and many other states will soon follow. By mid-September the deadlines for both parties to certify candidates for the general election will have passed in every state – meaning lawsuits might have to be filed to try and get a replacement on the ballot.

column1: The DNC did not respond to a request for comment from FoxNews.com.
This isn’t the first time this election cycle there has been talk of a candidate dropping out. In August
column2: during a particularly rough patch of poll numbers for Trump
column3: some GOP officials were reportedly considering contingency plans in case the Republican nominee dropped out.

column1: Adam Shaw is a Politics Reporter and occasional Opinion writer for FoxNews.com. He can be reached here or on Twitter: @AdamShawNY."	REAL
