Don't blame all immigrants for San Francisco shooting	"Raul A. Reyes is an attorney and member of the USA Today board of contributors. Follow him on Twitter @RaulAReyes . The opinions expressed in this commentary are solely those of the author.
(CNN) As the nation was preparing for the July Fourth weekend
column2: there was grim news from San Francisco. On Wednesday night
column3: Kate Steinle
column5: was fatally shot
column6: apparently randomly
column7: while walking with her father on a busy pier. A Mexican immigrant
column8: who CNN reported was in the country without documentation
column9: was arrested in her death.

column1: Illegally re-entering the country after being deported
column2: as Juan Francisco Lopez-Sanchez is said to have done
column3: is a federal felony . He has also been accused of a horrific
column4: violent crime. And according to immigration authorities
column5: he has seven other felony convictions
column6: including four for drug offenses.

column1: But that doesn't make him a symbol of the estimated 11 million undocumented immigrants in the United States. Nor is he the poster boy for out-of-control illegal immigration across our southern border (illegal immigration from Mexico is at a 40-year low). He does not represent the overwhelming majority of immigrants in this country -- legal or otherwise -- who are productive members of society.
Lopez-Sanchez is simply a dangerous individual who should not have been free and among us.

It is a myth that increased illegal immigration leads to more crime. Research from the Immigration Policy Center shows that crime rates fell in the United States as the size of our immigrant population
column2: including undocumented immigrants
column3: grew from 1990 to 2010.

column1: Most undocumented immigrants come to the United States to work and provide a better life for themselves and their families.
Consider that several mass shootings
column2: from Aurora to Newtown to Charleston
column3: were committed by young white men. Does that mean that all young white men are potential mass murderers? Of course not.

column1: The same news outlets that are now trumpeting Wednesday's murder as proof that undocumented immigrants are criminals often overlook or ignore other stories of undocumented immigrants who are genuine heroes. In 2013
column2: an undocumented immigrant rescued a mother and her child on Staten Island
column3: New York
column4: amidst the storm surge of Superstorm Sandy.

column1: One takeaway from this episode is that deporting as many undocumented immigrants as possible is not the answer to our immigration problems. Lopez-Sanchez had been deported five times
column2: and yet he was still here in the country without authorization.

column1: Back in 2011
column2: the deputy director of Immigration and Customs Enforcement told an immigration subcommittee of Congress that it costs $12
column3: 500 to deport a person. Multiply this by five and that is how much taxpayer money was wasted on a criminal who remained at large to randomly take the life of an innocent young woman.

column1: Another lesson here is our country does not need more immigration enforcement; our country needs smarter and better immigration enforcement. Up to now
column2: immigration authorities have wasted time
column3: manpower and money chasing after people working productively in their communities as
column4: say
column5: gardeners and maids
column6: while felons like Lopez-Sanchez slipped through the cracks.

column1: That's why it was good news last week that the Department of Homeland Security announced it is rethinking its deportation priorities to focus on recent arrivals and serious criminals.
This move is a step in the right direction
column2: because it is time to start seriously targeting those immigrants who are a real threat to public safety. The government will be focusing its enforcement efforts on three categories of people: convicted criminals
column3: recent border crossers and terrorism threats.

column1: True
column2: Lopez-Sanchez should not have been in the country
column3: or he should have at least been behind bars. But Immigration and Customs Enforcement erred in not seeking a warrant or court order for his arrest and he was released in accordance with city law in March.

column1: What's more
column2: President Barack Obama's proposed executive action on immigration
column3: currently tied up in a legal battle
column4: might also have made a difference because it would have freed up resources to go after people like Lopez-Sanchez.

column1: Although Steinle's death was a tragedy
column2: it was the alleged action of one man. All undocumented immigrants do not deserve to be vilified by false association."	REAL

column1: Geo-Engineering Unlikely to Work, Conservation Group Says	"Geo-Engineering Unlikely to Work
column2: Conservation Group Says Posted on Nov 3

column1: By Alex Kirby / Climate News Network Biofilm used in research into carbon capture: Doubts persist about geo-engineering. (ENERGY.GOV via Wikimedia Commons)
LONDON—The global watchdog responsible for protecting the world ’ s wealth of species
column2: the UN ’ s Convention on Biological Diversity (CBD)
column3: has looked at the hopes for reining in climate change through geo-engineering. Its bleak conclusion
column4: echoing that reached by many independent scientists
column5: is that the chances are “highly uncertain”. “Novel means”
column6: in this context
column7: describes trying to reduce greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions by removing them from the atmosphere
column8: and altering the amount of heat from the Sun that reaches the Earth. Some scientists and policymakers say geo-engineering
column9: as these strategies are collectively known
column10: is essential if the world is to meet the goals of the Paris Agreement . This is because current attempts to reduce emissions cannot make big enough cuts fast enough to keep global average temperatures from rising more than 2°C above their pre-industrial levels
column11: the Agreement’s basic goal. But the CBD says in a report that geo-engineering
column12: while it could possibly help to prevent the world overheating
column13: might endanger global biodiversity and have other unpredictable effects. Many independent analysts have raised similar concerns.Attempts to increase the amount of carbon in the oceans
column14: in order to remove GHGs
column15: have so far shown disappointing results. One report doubted that geo-engineering could slow sea-level rise . Another said it could not arrest the melting of Arctic ice . A third study found that geo-engineering would make things little better and might even make global warming worse . Transboundary impacts The lead author of the CBD geo-engineering report is a British scientist
column16: Dr Phillip Williamson
column17: of the UK’s Natural Environment Research Council . He is an associate fellow in the School of Environmental Sciences at the University of East Anglia
column18: UK. The CBD originally became involved in climate geo-engineering in 2008
column19: because member governments were concerned that experiments to fertilise the oceans could pose unknown risks to the environment (they were then unregulated when carried out in international waters). The CBD’s concern expanded to include other geo-engineering techniques
column20: especially atmospheric methods which could have uncertain transboundary impacts. Some scientists argue that “geo-engineering” is a hazily-defined term and prefer to speak instead simply of “greenhouse gas removal”. Dr Williamson and his colleagues say assessment of the impacts of geo-engineering on biodiversity “is not straightforward and is subject to many uncertainties”. On greenhouse gas removal they warn that removing a given quantity of a greenhouse gas would not fully compensate for an earlier ‘overshoot’ of emissions. New risks In some cases
column21: they say
column22: the cure may be worse than the disease: “The large-scale deployment of bioenergy with carbon capture and storage (BECCS) seems likely to have significant negative impacts on biodiversity through land use change.” When it comes to attempts to reflect sunlight back out into space or to manage solar radiation
column23: a familiar theme recurs: “There are high levels of uncertainty about the impacts of SRM [solar radiation management] techniques
column24: which could present significant new risks to biodiversity.” Time and again
column25: it seems
column26: a potential advance is liable to be cancelled by an equally likely reverse: if SRM benefits coral reefs by decreasing temperature-induced bleaching (as it may)
column27: in certain conditions “it may also increase
column28: indirectly
column29: the impacts of ocean acidification.” There could even be a risk in some circumstances of loss to the Earth’s protective ozone layer. Dr Williamson and his colleagues believe that geo-engineering is essential—if it can be made to work—because of the diminishing chances that anything else will. “I’m sceptical. That’s not to say bio-energy with carbon capture and storage is impossible
column30: but it seems extremely unlikely to be feasible” They write: “It may still be possible that deep and very rapid decarbonisation by all countries might allow climate change to be kept within a 2°C limit by emission reduction alone. However
column31: any such window of opportunity is rapidly closing.” Repeatedly
column32: those two words recur: a suggested technique or development will be “highly uncertain”. Most of the report amounts to a very cautious call for more research
column33: coupled with an implicit acceptance that in the end geo-engineering is unlikely to prove capable of contributing much to climate mitigation. Dr Williamson told the Climate News Network: “I’m sceptical. That’s not to say bio-energy with carbon capture and storage is impossible
column34: but it seems extremely unlikely to be feasible (for all sorts of reasons)” at the scale needed. When the CBD member governments meet in December they are expected to call for more research: a safe option in most circumstances
column35: but far from a ringing endorsement of a technology once seen as very promising.

column1: Alex Kirby is a former BBC journalist and environment correspondent. He now works with universities
column2: charities and international agencies to improve their media skills
column3: and with journalists in the developing world keen to specialise in environmental reporting.

column1: Advertisement"	FAKE

column2: global support to the Islamic State blossomed as it began to supplant likeminded terrorist groups

column1: In the wake of the Paris attacks and plots disrupted elsewhere in Europe

column1: The Islamic State continues to recruit extremists in Europe

column1: The United States and all civilized countries need to coordinate our efforts to fight the Islamic State first by cutting them off.  We must counter their message on social media; bolster allies like Iraq and Jordan; and ensure that we prevent suspected terrorists from traveling back and forth between their homelands and places like Syria

The U.S. government should implore American technology companies to cooperate with authorities so that we can better track terrorist activity and monitor terrorist communications as we face the increasing challenge of homegrown terrorists radicalized by little more than what they see on the Internet.
This year

column1: Lofty speeches and half measures do not defeat terrorist groups.  They also do not keep Americans safe in the long term.  The threat from Islamic extremism is only growing and without greater leadership from the United States

column1: Selma 50 years on: John Lewis's recalls the march	"Watch live coverage of ceremonies in Selma commemorating 50 years since ""Bloody Sunday"" starting at 11 a.m. ET Saturday on CNN and CNNgo
(CNN) Fifty years ago this weekend
column2: a 25-year-old John Lewis was beaten so badly by Alabama state troopers that they fractured his skull.

column1: Lewis calls the Edmund Pettus Bridge -- where the troopers and and a group of white men deputized into a posse by the sheriff attacked hundreds of peaceful protesters on Bloody Sunday
column2: March 7
column3: 1965 -- an ""almost holy place.""

column1: Now a Democratic U.S. congressman
column2: Lewis is returning to Selma -- as he has nearly every year since that historic march -- to remember the fight for voting rights and to push voters across the country to participate in the political process. He also wants people to continue to speak up about the problems of racial injustice and poverty that persist in American society.

column1: It is important to come back to remember Selma
column2: Lewis told CNN in an interview at First Baptist Church. ""The vote is powerful. It is the most powerful nonviolent tool we have in a democratic society and I don't want people to forget that people paid a price.

column1: Selma
column2: these churches and these people
column3: gave it everything they had. We wouldn't be where we are today as a nation and as a people (if it) hadn't been for this community.""

column1: Churches -- like Selma's First Baptist and Brown Chapel -- served as important meeting places during the movement
column2: in part because they were run by the black community.

column1: And music was vital as a unifying force.
Without music
column2: the movement would have been like a bird without wings
column3: Lewis said.

column1: He recalled how people would often sing during the marches
column2: sometimes making up songs along the way.

column1: Music helped create a sense of solidarity
column2: and there were people in some communities
column3: in some towns and cities like Selma
column4: saying if the meetings are being held at the church
column5: it must be all right. That's the house of the Lord. They must be doing something that is right.""

column1: Activists had been working for years in and around Selma trying to help people register to vote. At the time
column2: only 2.1% of blacks in Dallas County were registered
column3: Lewis said. When blacks attempted to register
column4: they were often given impossible tasks
column5: like counting the number of jelly beans in a jar or the number of bubbles on a bar of soap
column6: to complete before being allowed to sign up. Black lawyers
column7: doctors
column8: business people
column9: public school teachers and college professors were told they could not read and write well enough to pass the so-called literacy test.

column1: As chairman of the Student Nonviolent Coordinating Committee
column2: Lewis -- along with many others -- would spill blood to change that
column3: not only as a leader of the Bloody Sunday march but in other confrontations across the South.

column1: Lewis was arrested some 40 times during the 1960s as he challenged the segregationist Jim Crow laws that kept blacks oppressed. He spent 44 days imprisoned in Mississippi during the Freedom Rides in 1961. As a student at Fisk University
column2: he organized sit-ins at lunch counters in Nashville
column3: Tennessee
column4: even spending his birthday in jail there in 1961 -- so Lewis was no stranger to run-ins with the law. But the events of Bloody Sunday would prove fateful for the movement.

column1: Television cameras and photographers captured the troopers attacking the marchers with night sticks and whips -- one man in the posse even had a rubber hose wrapped with barbed wire
column2: Lewis wrote in his memoir ""Walking with the Wind.""

column1: The troopers trampled the crowd with their horses and released nauseating tear gas. The pictures horrified citizens across the country. Eight days after the march
column2: President Lyndon B. Johnson spoke before Congress about voting rights. He signed the Voting Rights Act on Aug. 6 to ensure that all citizens would be able to vote regardless of their skin color.

column1: Five decades later
column2: Lewis said a great deal of progress has been made in the struggle for equality. But he added that
column3: despite having twice elected a black man to the nation's highest office
column4: the country still has a long way to go to become the so-called ""Beloved Community"" Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. envisioned ""where we can lay down the burden of race.""

column1: We have a black president. We've made a lot of progress
column2: but we're not a post-racial society yet
column3: he said. ""We still have a distance to go. The scars and stains of racism are still deeply embedded in the American society.""

column1: The need for 'righteous indignation'
Lewis
column2: who has written a trilogy of graphic novels for young adults about his life called ""March
column3: said it was important not to sweep the problems that still plague America under the rug and to instead speak up with a sense of ""righteous indignation.""

column1: You cannot be quiet. You have to speak up. You have to speak out. You have to find a way to get in the way and make some noise
column2: he said
column3: referring in particular to the killings of unarmed black men by police last summer in Ferguson
column4: Missouri
column5: and New York City.

column1: He urged those demonstrating against police brutality and racial injustice to study and model the nonviolent methods of the civil rights activists of the 1950s and '60s.
The poverty affecting people of all races across the country still gnaws at Lewis
column2: as does a lack of access to a good education. He believes people should be outraged about hunger and violence
column3: and fired up to renew and strengthen the Voting Rights Act after a 2013 Supreme Court ruling gutted the key provision requiring certain states with a history of racial discrimination at the polls to ""pre-clear"" any changes to voting laws with the federal government before implementing them.

column1: On Saturday
column2: Lewis and nearly 100 members of Congress from both parties will join President Barack Obama at the bridge in Selma -- a bridge that still bears the name of a Confederate general who was also a Ku Klux Klan leader -- to mark the 50th anniversary of Bloody Sunday. The bipartisan event comes as efforts to update to the Voting Rights Act have stalled in Congress. Still
column3: Lewis is optimistic both parties can come together to fix it.

column1: We must do it. It's the right thing to do
column2: he said. ""There is a deliberate
column3: systematic effort to take us back. We've made too much progress to go back."" He was referring to efforts in some states to do away with early voting and voting on Sunday or on weekends and to require photo IDs
column4: moves he said make it harder for young people
column5: seniors and minorities to vote.

column1: I'm afraid that if we fail to fix it
column2: many of our fellow citizens will not be able to become participants in the democratic process
column3: he concluded."	REAL

column1: Third-party presidential candidates fight for 15% in polls – and a spot in debates	"The former Republican
column2: marijuana-smoking
column3: Everest mountaineering ex-governor of New Mexico and presidential nominee of the Libertarian party has a problem: he’s barred from the presidential debates. To appear on stage with Hillary Clinton and Donald Trump this autumn
column4: Gary Johnson needs to boost his national polling numbers to 15% from around 8% now.

column1: Without that national exposure
column2: and the blockbuster ratings the three scheduled Clinton-Trump dust-ups are likely to produce
column3: it’s hard for anyone to see how Johnson
column5: or either of two other minor-party candidates
column6: the Green party’s Jill Stein or even Evan McMullin
column7: a 40-year-old former CIA counterterrorism officer
column8: could ever become more than mere electoral curiosities.

column1: But the emergence of three independent candidates
column2: during a year of record dissatisfaction with the major party candidates
column3: may still make for an unpredictable twist to the story. Polling data suggests libertarians on both sides of the political divide are giving independent candidates a second look
column4: and in Las Vegas on Friday
column5: Johnson and Stein spoke before a gathering of Asian American and Pacific Islander voters to press their cases.

column1: Soft-spoken and wearing Nikes
column2: Johnson presented a platform of social libertarianism
column3: fiscal conservatism and non-interventionism in foreign affairs. He argued at the gathering that in this
column4: “the craziest election of all time”
column5: he had a chance: “I might be the next president of the United States.”

column1: A just-released WSJ-NBC poll gave Johnson 15% in the crucial swing state of Colorado
column2: and Stein 6%. In Las Vegas
column3: he was asked repeatedly if a vote for him or any third-party candidate was somehow wasted.

column1: “A wasted vote is voting for somebody you don’t believe in. That’s a wasted vote
column2: ” Johnson said. “Vote for the person you believe in – that’s how you bring about change. I hope after having made my pitch today that you’ll realize
column3: if you want to waste your vote on Clinton or Trump
column4: have at it.”

column1: Stein
column2: who spoke separately at the event
column3: similarly argued that many Americans were looking for an alternative to Trump and Hillary Clinton
column4: whom she dubbed as “the most disliked and untrusted” major-party nominees in US history.

column1: “Democracy needs a moral compass
column2: ” she told a gathering of Asian American and Pacific Island groups. “It’s not just about who you don’t like the most or who you are most afraid of.”

column1: Stein
column2: who like Johnson represented her party in 2012
column3: has outlined policy positions that include a “Green New Deal”
column4: focused on renewable energy jobs and aimed at making the United States transition to 100% renewable energy complete by 2030. Stein has also proposed a reduction in the military budget by a third and the creation of a regional food systems based on sustainable organic agriculture.

column1: On the Republican side
column2: Evan McMullin
column3: a beneficiary of the grounded “Never Trump” movement
column4: failed to get on the ballot in 26 states before he’d even sent out his first campaign release. McMullin nonetheless tried to give disaffected conservatives an alternative to the Republican nominee who
column5: he says
column6: has tapped into “people’s darkest prejudices and deepest fears”.

column1: McMullin’s best hope – and likely his only one – to make an electoral dent would require Trump’s departure from the race
column2: though the nominee has made no overt sign that he wants to quit. “Like millions of Americans
column3: I had hoped this year would bring us better nominees who
column4: despite party differences
column5: could offer compelling visions of a better future
column6: ” McMullin said in his announcement.

column1: “Instead
column2: we have been left with two candidates who are fundamentally unfit for the profound responsibilities they seek.”

column1: But can they begin to make a difference? Only once in recent election cycles have third party candidates had any significant influence
column2: when in 1992
column3: Texan businessman Ross Perot took 18% of the vote
column4: carving into the support for incumbent Republican George HW Bush and helping Arkansas governor Bill Clinton to victory. Some Democrats blamed third-party candidate Ralph Nader for delivering George W Bush the election in 2000
column5: but the third-party candidate won a paltry 2.74% of the vote
column6: and his supporters were split between Republicans and Democrats.

column1: Johnson’s running mate
column2: former Massachusetts governor William Weld
column3: said he’d seen interest and fundraising pick up as Trump’s campaign has floundered. Their campaign recently reported a $1m one-week fundraising haul and has reported that more than 40
column4: 000 people have pledged to donate at least $15 to his campaign on 15 August.

column1: But that was in a relatively tight race. With Clinton now leading Trump by double digits in some key battleground states
column2: the impact of any third-party candidate could be limited.

column1: “At the moment it doesn’t look like they can have much impact at all
column2: ” said Hank Sheinkopf
column3: a veteran Democratic adviser. “But if the race gets closer
column4: they could throw it either way.”

column1: Sheinkopf reasoned that this election has become more about personalities and less about what party leaders want. The long-term impact may be a significant shift in how people view Democrats and Republicans
column2: he said. As it now stands
column3: Stein
column4: Johnson and McMullin could act as a convenient parking spot for voters disgusted with both candidates.

column1: Earlier this month
column2: a federal judge rejected a challenge brought by Johnson and Stein arguing that the bar for inclusion is set artificially high. Yet there are signs the ground could be shifting. Mike McCurry
column3: now co-chair of the Commission on Presidential Debates and a former press secretary for Bill Clinton
column4: hinted that a third podium might be needed.

column1: “Some of our production people may have said
column2: ‘Just in case
column3: you need to plan out what that might look like
column4: ’’ McCurry told Politico. “We won’t know the number of invitations we extend until mid-September.”

column1: Ron Faucheux
column2: president of Clarus Research Group
column3: a nonpartisan polling company
column4: said there was broad support for including even minor candidates. “Polls show that voters think third party candidates should be included
column5: ” he said
column6: “and in an election like this
column7: where polls show a majority of voters dislike both main party candidates
column8: there is a good reason to give them the opportunity to at least look at other options.”

column1: But even Johnson and Stein were somewhat wistful about their prospects
column2: casting themselves as agents of change who
column3: at best
column4: could represent the beginning of a break with the current two-party system.

column1: “The biggest message is ‘consider us’ as a very
column2: very viable alternative to this two-party system that has become so polarized that they’re not able to do anything
column3: ” Johnson has said.

column1: Stein advanced a similar argument. “We’re having a political reorganization in this election because the Republicans are kind of falling apart
column2: ” she said
column3: “and the Democrats have kind of split with a lot of the Bernie Sanders supporters just not happy with the alternative.”

column1: She argued that it was by elections about “the lesser of two evils” that the country inherited many of its problems.
But first
column2: the two have to get on TV.

column1: “There’s no way I’m going to win the presidency if I’m not in the presidential debates
column2: ” Johnson said. “I do believe anything is possible given that right now
column3: arguably the two most polarizing figures in American politics today are running for office.”"	REAL

column1: Bush, Rubio and Kasich eye one another in the shadow of Trump	"The Republican presidential contest is not
column2: regardless of what it seems some days
column3: all about Donald Trump. There’s another dynamic unfolding that has almost nothing to do with the businessman-politician currently atop the polls but that will have a major influence on who becomes the party’s nominee.

column1: This other struggle involves the competition among former Florida governor Jeb Bush
column2: Sen. Marco Rubio (Fla.) and Ohio Gov. John Kasich. History suggests that whoever emerges triumphant in this three-way rivalry will be in a strong position to claim the nomination
column3: though admittedly the past has been a poor predictor of events so far in this campaign.

column1: Ever since Trump surged to the top of the polls
column2: the other candidates have been trying to assess both his staying power and the cost-benefit analysis of engaging him. Trump and Bush have clashed almost from the start
column3: with growing intensity. More recently
column4: as Rubio has risen
column5: Trump has taken aim at him
column6: and Rubio has responded in kind.

column1: None of the other candidates has a clear strategy for taking down Trump. But they all think he will look like a different candidate — and in their assessments
column2: a less formidable candidate — once the field narrows to three or four finalists after the voting begins. So they are beginning to focus on one another as much as they are worrying about him.

column1: With the first contests still months away
column2: none of the three yet looks like a front-runner. In the average of recent national polls
column3: Rubio and Bush run fourth and fifth behind Trump
column4: retired neurosurgeon Ben Carson and former Hewlett-Packard chief executive Carly Fiorina. Neither Bush nor Rubio breaks double digits. Kasich doesn’t even break 5 percent.

column1: National polls at this stage are less meaningful than state polls. In Iowa
column2: where the first caucus will take place in early February
column3: Trump and Carson lead
column4: with Sen. Ted Cruz (Tex.) currently third. Bush and Rubio trail the first three
column5: and Kasich is even deeper in the pack. In New Hampshire
column6: Trump also has a big lead
column7: but Kasich is jockeying with Fiorina for second
column8: with Carson and Bush next and Rubio farther back.

column1: [Trump and Bush take on Rubio in New Hampshire]
In recent days
column2: Bush
column3: Rubio and Kasich have shown how much they’re worrying about one another. They’ve been sniping at each other and making other moves that underscore the significance of their competition.

column1: Rubio has long emphasized that the party needs a fresh candidate
column2: not one tied to the past
column3: an implicit criticism of his fellow Floridian who is part of an American political dynasty. Bush
column4: a two-term former governor
column5: has belittled Rubio’s experience
column6: or lack thereof. Kasich
column7: a two-term governor and longtime House member
column8: has claimed that his experience and record are unmatched by any of the other candidates.

column1: Advisers to the three anticipate more attacks ahead. “The Bush campaign is feverishly doing their opposition research on Governor Kasich and Senator Rubio
column2: ” said John Weaver
column3: Kasich’s chief strategist. “An empire like that is not going to go quietly into the night. We’re expecting pretty sharp elbows to be thrown. We’re going to handle it head on.”

column1: Past Republican nomination contests often have devolved into competition between a candidate from the center-right or mainstream conservative wing of the party and a candidate from the hard right or populist conservative wing. Most times
column2: the candidate from the mainstream conservative wing becomes the nominee.

column1: This year
column2: the race is more scrambled because of the added factor of the apparent desire by many Republicans for an outsider or non-politician. That has elevated Trump
column3: Carson and Fiorina and has forced the others to adapt. Rubio has been stressing that
column4: despite being in the Senate
column5: he’s really not of Washington.

column1: Instead of establishment vs. tea party
column2: one GOP strategist describes the race this time as a competition between those in the anger
column3: or anti-Washington
column4: lane
column5: vs. those in the aspirational lane. Bush
column6: Rubio and Kasich all fall more into the aspirational lane.

column1: What will make the difference? Based on how the three candidates are running
column2: it’s clear that they see the path ahead in slightly different ways
column3: though each has handicaps he must overcome to win.

column1: Bush has repeatedly pushed back at Trump by arguing that anger and insults cannot win the presidency. He seeks to be the aspirational candidate
column2: conservative enough because of his record in Florida to be acceptable to a conservative party
column3: while offering a positive and inclusive message that reaches beyond the GOP coalition.

column1: But many Republicans see Bush as least able to appeal across the entire party — not much more able to appeal to the hard right than Cruz would be able to attract mainstream conservatives.
Lodged firmly in the establishment wing as the son and brother of former presidents
column2: he faces resistance on the far right and among those yearning for an outsider. His hope is that he can change perceptions of himself
column3: outlast his rivals with superior resources and persuade Republicans that he’s their best hope to win a general election.

column1: Sally Bradshaw
column2: Bush’s senior adviser
column3: said the key remains what it has been from the start of the campaign: to portray Bush as a conservative reformer by stressing what he did in Florida. “People don’t know that yet
column4: ” she said. “When that message burns in
column5: his numbers are going to change. That’s his path.”

column1: [What the pundits said then and now about Donald Trump]
Kasich is looking to the traditional model. He is the compassionate conservative of 2016 who hopes to strike first in New Hampshire and build from there. His advisers believe that
column2: eventually
column3: he can reach across the divide in the party to become the nominee.

column1: But the party has not only moved right in the past decade
column2: it also has developed a harder edge than when George W. Bush ran as a compassionate conservative in 2000. Kasich’s support for expanding Medicaid under the Affordable Care Act is just one example of a position that will not sit well with many conservatives.

column1: Rubio’s team sees crosscutting appeal as vital
column2: a race that will favor a candidate who can best unite a fractured party. The senator’s goal is to demonstrate skills as a communicator
column3: to show depth on the issues
column4: to turn his personal story into a positive message for the party
column5: to make as few errors as possible and over time generate enthusiasm across the GOP coalition.

column1: Rubio
column2: too
column3: has vulnerabilities. His past support for a path to citizenship for undocumented immigrants
column4: from which he has backed away
column5: remains an obstacle in his path. So too does his personal profile
column6: that of a youthful first-term senator with limited experience trying to become president — a profile not unlike that of President Obama when he first ran eight years ago.

column1: David Axelrod
column2: who was Obama’s chief strategist in both campaigns
column3: often has said that voters look for a replacement rather than a replica in picking a new president. The adviser to one of Rubio’s rivals put it this way: “When was the last time this country elected two presidents with similar attributes?” Rubio will be trying to dissuade his fellow Republicans that he isn’t another Obama.

column1: There are wild cards in the calculations of all three camps. Maybe New Jersey Gov. Chris Christie
column2: who occupies similar space
column3: will catch fire in New Hampshire and elsewhere
column4: although the resistance to him within the party is significant. Fiorina has demonstrated fearlessness that has jarred even Trump and can appeal across the party. Carson remains a candidate of unknown potential.

column1: Last

column1: Russia did hack the Democrats. So all of that email information that the media has been reporting came from a foreign entity that seeks to alter the outcome of the U.S. election.

Did the US Marshal smell his breath for any unusual odor that might suggest poisoning? My gut tells me there is something fishy going on in Texas.”

Scalia’s physician

The following are 10 things that every American should know about Donald Trump’s plan to save the U.S. economy…

column1: The next president can have a big impact on climate policy — even without Congress	"Given that Congress has become so utterly dysfunctional in recent years
column2: it's tempting to think the upcoming presidential election will be fairly low-stakes. Does it even matter what Jeb Bush thinks about tax policy or what Hillary Clinton is proposing on paid leave? Hardly anything will pass.

column1: The next president won't need Congress to tackle global warming
But on global warming
column2: it's a rather different story. Whoever gets elected to the White House in 2016 will have an enormous amount of influence over America’s climate policies — and they won't need Congress to act.

column1: For that
column2: you can thank (or blame) President Obama. Over the past six years
column3: the Environmental Protection Agency has acquired unprecedented authority to regulate the nation’s carbon dioxide emissions. Obama has used that power to enact a slew of new pollution rules
column4: including CO2 regulations on coal plants
column5: all with the aim of cutting US greenhouse gas emissions at least 26 percent between 2005 and 2025.

column1: The EPA will likely keep this authority to regulate carbon dioxide for the foreseeable future — unless it gets altered by courts or repealed by Congress. And many of the biggest decisions on how to use it will be left to the next president.
If
column2: say
column3: Hillary Clinton wanted to expand Obama’s carbon rules to oil refineries or cement plants
column4: she could. Conversely
column5: if a Republican president skeptical of climate change wanted to bog down implementation of Obama’s CO2 rules for coal plants
column6: he'd be able to do that
column7: too. (Though
column8: as we'll see
column9: Republicans may not have unlimited power to scuttle Obama's climate policies.)

column1: Any future administration will have a lot of room to be either more ambitious or less ambitious
column2: explains Michael Wara
column3: an expert on energy and environmental law at Stanford. And how the next president uses the EPA could have ripple effects around the world — and even decide the fate of ongoing international climate talks with China
column4: India
column5: and other countries.

column1: So far
column2: the 2016 candidates have been vague about which way they'd steer the EPA. Clinton has said Obama's climate rules should be ""protected at all cost
column3: but she's given little sign of whether she might expand them further. Meanwhile
column4: Republicans like Marco Rubio and Jeb Bush sound skeptical about tackling global warming
column5: but they haven't said whether they might try to relax or even dismantle Obama's climate policies. So here's a look at what they could do.

column1: First
column2: a recap of how the executive branch acquired so much power over US climate policy. Back in 2007
column3: the Supreme Court ruled that the EPA must regulate greenhouse gases as pollutants under the existing Clean Air Act — if there's evidence that they endanger public health and welfare.

column2: Obama's EPA laid out this evidence
column3: and that ""endangerment finding"" set in motion a series of rules to curtail US greenhouse gas emissions. Since this was being done under the auspices of the Clean Air Act
column4: a law Congress had passed in 1970
column5: no new legislation was required. The EPA could act on its own. The big actions so far:

column1: Add it all up
column2: and the White House claims these rules put the US on pace to reduce greenhouse gas emissions at least 26 percent between 2005 and 2025. But whether that actually happens will depend on the next president.

column1: Okay
column2: now let's assume it's 2017. There's a new president
column3: and Congress is still totally gridlocked on climate change. What happens next?

column1: The next president likely won't be able to dismantle Obama's climate policies entirely — not on his or her own. After all
column2: the Supreme Court has effectively ordered the EPA to regulate greenhouse gases so long as there's evidence that they cause harm
column3: and that evidence is quite solid. Only Congress could undo everything Obama's done
column4: by revising the Clean Air Act.

column1: Still
column2: whoever occupies the White House and EPA will have a lot of say in how to implement Obama's climate rules. That sounds boring
column3: but it's actually a key step. There's tons of leeway to strengthen or weaken these rules. Here are a few ways this could play out:

column1: 1) Fuel-economy standards could be tightened (or weakened) in 2017. Remember
column2: the EPA's fuel-economy standards for new cars and light trucks are on pace to rise from their current 35 miles per gallon to 54.5 miles per gallon by 2025.

column1: Automakers may push to relax the CAFE standards in the midterm review
Yet those numbers aren't set in stone. These CAFE (corporate average fuel economy) rules are scheduled to come up for a midterm review in 2017. At that point
column2: automakers may lobby to allow the standards to rise more slowly — particularly if sales of fuel-efficient vehicles have been sluggish due to low oil prices. Green groups
column3: meanwhile
column4: could push to make the standards stricter
column5: or to have them keep increasing past 2025
column6: to push vehicle emissions down even further.

column1: So the next administration will have to decide. Leave the vehicle standards alone? Make them stricter? Weaker?
The one twist here is that due to a longstanding quirk of the Clean Air Act
column2: California can threaten to create its own stricter standards if it's not happy with what the federal government is doing (and other states can join). Automakers really hate the idea of multiple sets of vehicle standards around the country
column3: so they may prefer not to weaken the federal rules too much and risk having California go it alone.

column1: 2) The Clean Power Plan will live or die based on implementation. The EPA will finalize its rules for reducing carbon dioxide from existing power plants in the summer of 2015. It's a core component of Obama's climate policy — power plants are responsible for 31 percent of the nation's greenhouse gas emissions. But the next president will have enormous influence over how this plan actually works.
Assuming the rule holds up in court
column2: it could prove difficult for the next president to simply hit the kill switch on the plan and start all over. But he or she will get to decide how to implement it — and that's arguably just as significant. After the rule is finalized
column3: states will have another 14 months to submit plans for cutting emissions
column4: though some will request extensions. That process could drag on until 2017 or 2018.

column1: There's a lot of latitude in the review process""
At that point
column2: the EPA will review each state's plans for reducing emissions from its power plants and decide whether the plans are acceptable. An administration that really wants to tackle climate change can make sure states are doing as much as is feasible. By contrast
column3: a president who was less concerned about global warming could allow states that wanted to
column4: like Texas
column5: to submit less-aggressive plans.

column1: There’s a lot of latitude in the review process
column2: says Stanford's Michael Wara. ""The history of the Clean Air Act shows this. If you have a president who doesn’t like climate policy
column3: they could basically signal to the states that they’re going to give a lot of compliance flexibility and allow states to make assumptions in their plan that reduce their costs."" This would likely involve seemingly arcane tweaks to models and baselines that would be harder for green groups to challenge in court.

column1: Meanwhile
column2: some states may outright refuse to submit any plans for reducing emissions. (Sen. Mitch McConnell
column3: R-KY
column4: is already urging states to do exactly this.) If that happens
column5: the EPA has the authority to impose its own federal plan on the states. The agency will unveil the details of this federal plan in 2015
column6: though
column7: again
column8: implementation would be left to the next president.

column1: Meanwhile
column2: industry groups are almost certain to challenge aspects of the rule in court. Adele Morris
column3: the policy director for the Climate and Energy Economics Project at the Brookings Institution
column4: points out that an administration hostile to Obama's EPA rule could defend it weakly in court. And if any parts of the rule get struck down
column5: the next administration will get to decide how to redo it.

column1: It all comes down to preference. ""If you have an administration that's friendly to [Obama's] policy
column2: then you'd have continuity in implementation
column3: says David Doniger
column4: director of the Natural Resources Defense Council's climate and clear air program. ""But if you had an administration that wasn't as friendly
column5: they could try to drag their feet or change the rules.""

column1: 3) The next president will decide whether to regulate other sectors — like refineries. The Clean Air Act doesn't just cover vehicles and power plants. Technically the EPA has the authority to regulate carbon dioxide from other sources
column2: as well. Oil refineries. Cement plants. Trucks. Airplanes. The agency is regulating methane leaks from new oil and gas wells
column3: but it hasn't touched existing wells. And so on. These sources all add up.

column1: The Obama administration is leaving most of the decisions about what to do with these sectors to the next president. If Hillary Clinton comes in and wants to expand the EPA's authority here
column2: she can. If Marco Rubio comes in and doesn't
column3: he may have to fend off lawsuits
column4: but he can likely hold off on doing this for a long time.

column1: At this point
column2: we only have a hazy sense for what most US presidential candidates think about global warming. But given how much power they have at their disposal
column3: they should give more detailed answers.

column1: For instance
column2: Hillary Clinton's campaign chair
column3: John Podesta
column4: claims that she'll put climate change and clean energy at the ""top of the agenda."" And Clinton has said the EPA's climate rules should be ""protected at all cost.""

column1: Hillary says the EPA rules should be ""protected"" — but would she expand them?

Fine. So we know she'll veto any attempts by congressional Republicans to repeal the EPA rules altogether. But what else? Would she try to strengthen the fuel-economy rules during the 2017 midterm review? Would she want to expand the EPA's carbon regulations to oil refineries and chemical plants? Would she try to beat Obama's goal of cutting emissions at least 26 percent between 2005 and 2025?
On the other end of the spectrum
column2: there's Marco Rubio
column3: who says
column4: ""I do not believe that human activity is causing these dramatic changes to our climate the way these scientists are portraying it."" But what does that mean in practice? Would he weaken the vehicle rules? Abandon the US goal of cutting emissions 26 percent?

column1: Then there's Jeb Bush
column2: who says he's ""concerned"" about climate change and that ""we need to work with the rest of the world to negotiate a way to reduce carbon emissions."" But
column3: again
column4: what does this mean? Would he keep Obama's climate rules in place? Strengthen them? Weaken them?

column1: Some green groups have started to focus on these questions. ""We definitely want to ensure that the next president is actually committed on building progress through the Clean Power Plan
column2: Tiernan Sittenfield
column3: senior vice president at the League of Conservation Voters
column4: told me.

column1: For now
column2: many environmentalists have mainly been pressing Clinton on what she thinks of the Keystone XL pipeline. Yet that issue will probably be resolved before Obama leaves office. The EPA rules are far more relevant for the next administration.

column1: It's worth being precise about what the EPA can and can't do here. The executive branch has acquired sweeping authority over the nation's greenhouse gas emissions. The Obama administration estimates that this authority alone could push emissions down 26 to 28 percent between 2005 and 2025.
truly drastic changes to our energy system would likely require Congress
Looked at one way
column2: that's a huge deal — a decisive break from the past
column3: when emissions would go up and up seemingly without end. Looked at another way
column4: it's a pittance.

column1: To help avoid drastic global warming
column2: the United States will probably need to push down emissions 80 percent or more by midcentury. That would require truly staggering changes. It wouldn't be enough for coal and gas plants to get slightly more efficient under EPA rules. We'd have to replace virtually our entire energy system with a new
column3: cleaner one.

column1: That's the sort of thing that only Congress can really do. Only Congress can fund R&D for new technologies or offer subsidies for clean energy. Only Congress can bring about dramatic changes to our grid infrastructure. Only Congress can enact an economy-wide carbon tax. Barring some creative flexibility on regulations
column2: these are things the next president just can't accomplish without cooperation from the House and Senate.

column1: Where the EPA rules could have a more important effect is on the international stage — at least in the near term. Remember
column2: the United States only accounts for about 17 percent of worldwide greenhouse gas emissions. There's also China
column3: India
column4: Brazil
column5: Europe
column6: Russia
column7: and so on. That's why international cooperation on climate change is so crucial.

column1: Right now
column2: the world is groping toward a very
column3: very weak international agreement. The US put forward its pledge to cut emissions at least 26 percent between 2005 and 2025. That spurred China to respond by vowing to get its emissions to peak around 2030. Other countries have started to pitch in
column4: too.

column1: Add all these pledges up
column2: and we're still not close to tackling global warming. The Climate Action Tracker estimates that we're on pace for global average temperatures to rise 3.1°C (or 5.6°F) above pre-industrial levels
column3: give or take — a seriously disruptive change.

column1: What the US has done with China is a big step in changing the dynamics""
Even so
column2: some experts think even these weak promises could lead
column3: iteratively
column4: to stronger action over time. ""You can see how those plans could start to connect together and create a positive negotiating dynamic
column5: David Victor
column6: a political scientist at UC San Diego's School of International Relations and Pacific Studies
column7: told me. ""The encouraging precedent here is in trade ... You build credibility and trust over time and then move to bigger issues.""

column1: The next US president can help decide how this agreement continues to evolve in the years to come. The US can keep pushing its own emissions down and try to persuade countries like China and India to respond in kind. Or it could abandon this budding framework entirely.
Abandoning the US climate targets
column2: says Wara
column3: ""would do real damage to whatever credibility the US has left on the international stage. What Obama has done with China is a big step in changing the dynamics in a very positive way. And if the US were to walk away from that
column4: that would be very damaging for future climate negotiations and commitments."""	REAL

column1: Is the Iran deal unraveling? Think again. | Institution	"Are the wheels coming off the Iran deal? Less than a year after Iran
column2: America
column3: and five other world powers inked a comprehensive nuclear accord
column4: a debate over its terms has erupted anew.

column1: In Washington
column2: the braggadocio of a prominent White House aide is fueling Republican accusations that President Obama deliberately deceived the Congress and the country about Iran and the deal. And in Tehran
column3: frustration over the residual impact of American sanctions has prompted increasingly resentful accusations from Iranian leaders that the United States has failed to live up to its end of the bargain. As a result
column4: some are fretting that the deal is “at risk” and are laying blame on the White House doorstep.

column1: Both claims are spurious
column2: and deserve a more forceful rebuttal from the Obama administration. In the end
column3: however
column4: the ruckus over recent comments by Deputy National Security Advisor Ben Rhodes is largely an inside-the-Beltway drama—one that provides endless entertainment for Washington insiders but has little real significance for deal or American diplomacy.

column1: By contrast
column2: Iran’s dissatisfaction presents a serious diplomatic dilemma for Washington. But it should not be interpreted as evidence that the deal is “unraveling.” Rather
column3: the chorus of complaints from Tehran demonstrates the accord signed in July 2015 is working exactly as it was intended—forestalling Iranian nuclear ambitions while amplifying the incentives for further reintegration into the global economy.

column1: Obama’s handling of this first real test of the nuclear agreement will be crucial for sustaining its credibility. For the sake of the deal
column2: and for any prospect of a durable Thermidor for the revolutionary state
column3: Washington should resist the temptation to assuage Iran’s post-deal growing pains. If Iranians wants wholesale economic rehabilitation
column4: their leadership needs to embrace the kind of policies that would yield that—in other words
column5: meaningful political
column6: economic
column7: and foreign policy reform.

column1: Not surprisingly
column2: Iranian officials are seeking a quicker fix
column3: and they have mounted an intense campaign to wrest supplementary sanctions relief from Washington. Their principal argument is that the theocracy has been stiffed. On an April visit to Washington
column4: Valiollah Seif
column5: the head of Iran’s Central Bank
column6: questioned the benefits of the nuclear agreement
column7: insisting that Tehran has received “almost nothing” of the sanctions relief that was promised as part of the deal
column8: formally called the Joint Comprehensive Plan of Action (JCPOA). Mohammad Javad Zarif
column9: the country’s smooth-spoken foreign minister
column10: has contended that “the United States needs to do way more
column11: ” warning that “if one side does not comply with the agreement then the agreement will start to falter.”

column1: And Iran’s supreme leader
column2: Ayatollah Ali Khamenei
column3: charged recently that “the Americans are engaged in obstruction and deception
column4: adding: “on paper
column5: the Americans say banks can trade with Iran but in practice they act in such an Iranophobic way that no trade can take place with Iran.”

column1: Adding fuel to the fire are changes to U.S. visa policies that are perceived at constraining Iran’s economic rebound
column2: deliberately inflammatory rhetoric from the U.S. Congress
column3: and a recent Supreme Court verdict that paves the way for a $2 billion payout to victims of terrorist attacks attributed to Tehran or its proxies. Iranian President Hassan Rouhani has described the decision as “flagrant theft” and evidence of enduring American hostility toward Tehran.

column1: Tehran’s narrative plays equally well to its essential constituencies: the revolution’s power brokers
column2: steeped in official narratives of American treachery; an Iranian citizenry impatient for its long overdue peace dividend; and a European business community anxious to reclaim its piece of the pie after an unwelcome five years of having to forgo a lucrative market.

column1: And it wouldn’t be the first time Tehran got cold feet about its nuclear obligations out of an unfortunate sense of that the payoff was insufficient. In 2005
column2: two years after a deal with Britain
column3: France
column4: and Germany to suspend core aspects of its nuclear program
column5: Iran’s leadership soured on that deal and reneged. Anxiety about a repeat performance is prompting new U.S. efforts to facilitate business in Iran and a mounting debate in the press and on Capitol Hill around additional American sanctions relief.

column1: But Iran’s campaign is grounded in a fundamental falsehood: that Washington has failed to live up to its end of the bargain. In fact
column2: Washington has delivered fully on the sanctions relief pledged under the JCPOA
column3: and officials in the White House
column4: State Department
column5: and even the enforcement office of the Treasury Department have engaged in extraordinary outreach to clarify remaining restrictions and underscore American commitment to the terms of the deal.

column1: Moreover
column2: the rewards of Iran’s nuclear concessions are actually widely evident—in the volume of new trade and investment that is already underway; in the scope and velocity of diplomatic and commercial reengagement with Iran; in the swifter-than-anticipated revival of oil exports. Heads of state from Italy and India
column3: from South Korea to South Africa are beating a path to Tehran
column4: accompanied by contingents of eager investors. Meanwhile
column5: Iranian officials including Seif—chief of the same Central Bank that was formerly barred by sanctions—headline swanky conferences aimed at wooing European business players. The great Iranian gold rush is on.

column1: The catch is that the money is moving more slowly than Iranian officials seem to have anticipated—and the trickle-down effect has been almost nonexistent for the average Iranian. The explanation for this lag is complex and multi-dimensional.
First and foremost
column2: Iran is hard hit by the decline in oil prices
column3: which have fallen by roughly 60 percent since the interim nuclear deal was signed in November 2013. Even in the best of times
column4: the Islamic Republic was never a particularly easy place to do business
column5: and many of its structural economic problems have been exacerbated by a decade of sanctions and the particularly egregious mismanagement of the 2005 to 2013 tenure of Iranian President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad.

column1: Iran’s designation since 2008 as a “high-risk and non-cooperative” jurisdiction by Financial Action Task Force
column2: a multilateral body established to combat money laundering and terrorist finance
column3: poses additional hurdles for banks. In addition
column4: a host of other market distortions induce investor caution: corruption
column5: a bloated and opaque banking system
column6: an inflexible labor market
column7: unattractive contract terms for energy investments
column8: the traditional dominance of the public sector.

column1: Tehran’s challenges in luring capital is further complicated by its reputation for provocative domestic and regional behavior. Torching embassies
column2: arresting tourists and dual-national businessmen
column3: testing ballistic missiles—none of this provides a conducive context for Iran’s reintegration into the global economy. As the old adage goes
column4: capital is a coward
column5: and the Islamic Republic is a haunted house.

column1: Iran has seen this all before. Similar factors undercut Tehran’s previous efforts to open up to the global economy. In the early 1990s
column2: after the long war with Iraq
column3: then-President Ali Akbar Hashemi Rafsanjani sought foreign trade and investment as part of his massive reconstruction program. Initial outcomes were encouraging
column4: but falling oil prices
column5: excessive short-term debt
column6: and the perpetuation of an ideological foreign policy drove away investors and undermined his economic reforms.

column1: This time around
column2: American sanctions have cast a long shadow. The nuclear deal left intact an array of restrictions: the primary U.S. embargo on Iran as well as financial measures that preclude access to the U.S. dollar and penalize third countries for doing business with Iranian individuals and entities that are involved with terrorism or other malfeasance. The vestiges of the sanctions regime create truly epic compliance issues for any international investor. And the hangover effect of a decade of stringent (and costly) enforcement has generated a culture of overcompliance in the international financial sector
column3: since institutional due diligence is an integral dimension of the industry’s viability.

column1: None of this should come as a surprise to Tehran; American officials were crystal clear throughout the negotiations and in advocating on behalf of the deal that the deal only removed the nuclear-related sanctions and that U.S. measures imposed as a result of Iran’s support for terrorism
column2: its human rights abuses
column3: or other issues would remain intact. And every sensible analyst looked past the inflated rhetoric of the deal’s opponents
column4: who brayed against the deal as a massive “cash bonanza
column5: ” to recognize that the residual sanctions regime would remain a significant factor in Iran’s post-deal economic picture. As I wrote at the time:

column1: So if this was entirely predictable
column2: why is Tehran crying foul now? Unlike in the United States—where the agreement’s shortcomings were oversold (if anything) rather than downplayed—in Iran there was a triumphalism with which the deal was sold domestically. This was mostly because of the peculiarities of Iran’s political system. To avoid the appearance of contravening the “red lines” articulated by Khamenei
column3: the country’s ultimate authority
column4: Iranian negotiators depicted the JCPOA as delivering wholesale sanctions relief. Rouhani described the outcome as a “legal
column5: technical
column6: and political victory” for the country
column7: emphasizing that Tehran achieved “more than what was imagined.”

column1: Iran’s politically motivated embellishments were exacerbated by the hype surrounding the deal
column2: cultivated by entrepreneurs and aspiring middlemen who presented Iran in hyperbolic terms as “the best emerging market for years to come” and “one of the hottest opportunities of the decade.” But while it may offend the Iranian ego
column3: the relative scale of the opportunity in Iran is more modest than other much-heralded economic openings
column4: such as China. It is hardly inconceivable that many banks and other firms have simply chosen to sit this first round out.

column1: Neither Iran’s economic challenges nor the grievances of its leadership are “fraying” the nuclear accord; in fact
column2: they only highlight its underlying logic. While the deal’s scope was finite—it was not a wholesale rapprochement or rehabilitation—many of its supporters argued that its logic would prove self-reinforcing. Iran’s gradual reintegration into the global economy would bolster the case among its leadership for a broader moderation of its domestic and foreign policies precisely in order to boost their benefits.

column1: Tehran’s dissatisfaction with the payout to date suggests this formula is working. A little bit of sanctions relief has whetted the entrepreneurial appetites of the clerical state. Despite official invocations proclaiming a “resistance economy
column2: ” the trickle of new trade and investment from Europe and Asia into Iran since the deal was signed has only intensified pressure for more—and for more tangible dissemination of its benefits among the Iranian population. In other words
column3: it is the success of the nuclear deal—rather than its shortcomings—that is driving the complaints that have emanated from Iran.

column1: The United States is not responsible for the hesitancy of international capital and other economic hiccups that Tehran has experienced in the aftermath of the nuclear agreement. The culpability resides
column2: as it always has
column3: with Iran and the risks that its government’s policies pose for international business. If Iranians want to see their nascent opening to the international community expanded—if they want the peace dividend they have been promised
column4: they need to look to their own leadership and its policies. If Iran’s Central Bank governor wants “normal conditions” and “access to the U.S. financial system
column5: ” as he demanded during his Washington visit
column6: let him return to Tehran and help instill the kind of reforms that would make those goals possible.

column1: There are sensible steps that Washington can take to ensure that the provisions of the nuclear deal are fully feasible
column2: including limited mechanisms for enabling transactions
column3: such as the repatriation of previously frozen assets
column4: that are specifically permitted under the deal. Such exceptional measures are reasonable—not because they help Tehran
column5: but because they help sustain consensus between Washington and its European partners and help preserve the West’s negotiating leverage with any future targets of American or multilateral financial sanctions.

column1: However
column2: it would be profoundly detrimental for Washington to provide significant unilateral relief to Tehran without reciprocal additional Iranian concessions. And the PR blitz by senior U.S. officials to reassure Iran’s prospective foreign investors has taken on an unseemly tone
column3: especially since existing sanctions prohibit U.S. persons from facilitating transactions with Iran by foreign entities.

column1: These measures may be aimed at building confidence
column2: but they ultimately have the opposite effect—eroding Iran’s incentives to abide by the deal
column3: undermining any rationale for broader changes. Iran remains a risky place to do business
column4: and it is in Washington’s interests—as well as those of Iranians and the broader international community—that Tehran focuses on mitigating those risks rather than seeking to subvert their penalties.

column1: The nuclear deal is working; Iran’s nascent reintegration into the global economy is intensifying internal debates and popular expectations. This is all to the good. But to get more
column2: Tehran will have to give more."	REAL

column1: Saturn’s Baffling Hexagon — The Raging Storm Four Times the Size of Earth has Changed Its Colors	"NASA’s Cassini spacecraft discovered a static hexagonal storm four times the size of Earth crowning Saturn’s north pole
column2: including a clearly defined eyewall. Based on its size and movements
column3: scientists have concluded that it’s a vast cloud pattern generated by a gigantic
column4: perpetual hurricane spinning at the center of the planet’s north pole. Scientists estimate that this storm has been raging for decades – maybe even centuries.

column1: Each side on the northern polar hexagon is approximately 13
column2: 800 km long
column3: and the whole structure rotates once every 10 hours and 39 minutes -a day on Saturn. In just four years
column4: Saturn’s hexagon has changed its color from blue to gold when Saturn’s north pole gears up for next year’s summer solstice.Saturn’s hexagon is a six-sided structure that spans roughly 32
column6: 000 miles) in diameter
column7: and extends about 100 km (60 miles) down into the planet’s dense atmosphere. Because Saturn does not have land masses or oceans on its surface to complicate weather the way Earth does
column8: its conditions should give scientists a more elementary model to study the physics of circulation patterns and atmosphere
column9: said Kevin Baines
column10: an atmospheric scientist at NASA’s Jet Propulsion Laboratory
column11: Pasadena
column12: Calif.
column13: who has studied the hexagon with Cassini’s visual and infrared mapping spectrometer. The last visible-light images of the entire hexagon were captured by NASA’s Voyager spacecraft nearly 30 years ago
column14: the last time spring began on Saturn. After the sunlight faded
column15: darkness shrouded the north pole for 15 years. Much to the delight and bafflement of Cassini scientists
column16: the location and shape of the hexagon in the latest images match up with what they saw in the Voyager pictures.

column1: “The longevity of the hexagon makes this something special
column2: given that weather on Earth lasts on the order of weeks
column3: ” said Kunio Sayanagi
column4: a Cassini imaging team associate at the California Institute of Technology. “It’s a mystery on par with the strange weather conditions that give rise to the long-lived Great Red Spot of Jupiter.”

column1: The hexagon was originally discovered in images taken by the Voyager spacecraft in the early 1980s. It encircles Saturn at about 77 degrees north latitude and has been estimated to have a diameter wider than two Earths. The jet stream is believed to whip along the hexagon at around 100 meters per second (220 miles per hour).
Early hexagon images from Voyager and ground-based telescopes suffered from poor viewing perspectives. Cassini
column2: which has been orbiting Saturn since 2004
column3: has a better angle for viewing the north pole. But the long darkness of Saturnian winter hid the hexagon from Cassini’s visible-light cameras for years. Infrared instruments
column4: however
column5: were able to obtain images by using heat patterns. Those images showed the hexagon is nearly stationary and extends deep into the atmosphere. They also discovered a hotspot and cyclone in the same region.

column1: As observed by NASA’s Voyager and Cassini spacecraft
column2: each point of the hexagon appears to rotate at its center at nearly the same rate that Saturn rotates on its axis. Along the rim of the hexagon
column3: a jet stream of air is blasting eastward at speeds of 321 km/h (200 mph).

column1: While we’re pretty confident that we know what Saturn’s hexagon is
column2: the big mystery is how it got there in the first place. Once you have a giant whirlpool of air
column3: it’s relatively easy to keep it spinning – but the force you need to get it wound up in the first place is a whole lot more difficult to explain.

column1: It’s fascinating that the Cassini spacecraft could have observed two completely different colors in the hexagon between November 2012 and September 2016:
The best hypothesis is that this is what it looks like when Saturn changes seasons. With a year that lasts 29 Earth years
column2: Saturn changes seasons only once every seven years
column3: and the increased sunlight over the past three years could explain the golden haze.

column1: “The color change is thought to be an effect of Saturn’s seasons. In particular
column2: the change from a bluish colour to a more golden hue may be due to the increased production of photochemical hazes in the atmosphere as the north pole approaches summer solstice in May 2017.”

column1: “Inside the hexagon
column2: there are fewer large haze particles and a concentration of small haze particles
column3: while outside the hexagon
column4: the opposite is true
column5: ” Kunio Sayanagi
column6: a Cassini imaging team associate at Hampton University
column7: explained back in 2013. “The hexagonal jet stream is acting like a barrier
column8: which results in something like Earth’s Antarctic ozone hole.”

column1: But since Saturn reached its equinox in August 2009 – the point where the Sun is directly over Saturn’s equator – it’s been gradually exposed to more and more sunlight
column2: which means that for the past three years
column3: aerosols have been produced inside of the hexagon and around the north pole
column4: making the polar atmosphere appear hazy and golden when photographed last month.

column1: “Other effects
column2: including changes in atmospheric circulation
column3: could also be playing a role
column4: ” NASA explained this week. “Scientists think seasonally shifting patterns of solar heating probably influence the winds in the polar regions.”

column1: NASA scientists have an investigation underway to figure out what’s actually going.
The Daily Galaxy via NASA/JPL-Caltech/Space Science Institute/Hampton University

column1: Blizzard of charges and countercharges melts away as opinions of Trump and Clinton are frozen	"This has turned into the whiplash election
column2: and it’s virtually impossible to keep up with the head-snapping revelations.

column1: Even the most diligent journalist can get vertigo trying to investigate and evaluate each disclosure
column2: which damages Hillary Clinton or Donald Trump and spawns dire predictions that their campaign is toast
column3: only to fade in a news cycle or two.

column1: Some developments that in a “normal” election would badly wound a presidential candidate get meager exposure in the rest of the media because they are overshadowed by other mega-stories. No one has the bandwidth to do it all.
This is more than a mere campaign; its craziness has become the beating heart of American culture
column2: debated in every cubicle and coffee shop and at every level of the increasingly toxic stew of social media.

column1: Just look at the last few weeks:
Democrats and many members of the media have taken up weapons and stormed a place called Comey Island.
The FBI director shook up the race by revealing a probe of emails that wound up on the laptop of a top aide’s estranged husband under investigation for sending illicit messages to an underage girl.
The New York Times reported that Trump avoided hundreds of millions of dollars in income taxes through a loophole scheme so dubious his own lawyers advised him that the IRS could declare it improper.
The Clinton campaign got advance questions before CNN town halls from a top Democratic Party official who was also a paid contributor at the network
column2: which booted her.

column1: The Washington Post reported that Donald Trump has repeatedly “sought credit for charity he had not given — or had claimed other people’s giving as his own.”
Back on Comey Island
column2: the FBI chief was reported to have argued that the administration shouldn’t accuse Russia of using cyberwarfare to interfere with the presidential campaign because—yes--it would look partisan so close to the election.

column1: Hacked emails revealed that the daughter of the Democratic nominee’s husband
column2: himself a former president
column3: complained that his aides were cashing in on the Clinton Foundation and siphoning money from her parents.

column1: The Trump Foundation was ordered to stop fundraising by the New York attorney general
column2: a Democrat and Clinton supporter.

column1: Clinton’s top advisers
column2: reeling after the email scandal broke
column3: complained that said she had terrible instincts and a pathological aversion to apologizing
column4: according to hacked emails.

column1: Back on Comey Island
column2: the FBI looked into whether Trump’s company had a secret email server communicating with a Russian bank but found no direct link.

column1: A Clinton aide complained in a hacked email that “we…speak in such a tortured
column2: nuanced way when we don’t get any advantage from the nuance
column3: and just wind up looking political.”

column1: Back on Comey Island
column2: the FBI opened a preliminary investigation of Trump’s former campaign manager and his ties to Russian interests
column3: which Paul Manafort said he knew nothing about.

column1: Trump boasted a decade ago on a Hollywood entertainment show that as a celebrity he could grab women by the genitals
column2: which he now dismisses as locker-room talk.

column1: Back on Comey Island
column2: FBI agents were investigating financial and ethical issues at the Clinton Foundation but were told to stand down by top law-enforcement officials
column3: according to the Wall Street Journal.

column1: Eleven women accused Trump of sexually propositioning them or unwanted kissing or touching
column2: all of which he denounced as lies.

column1: Trump held a news conference before a debate with Paula Jones and Kathleen Willey
column2: who have accused Bill Clinton of sexual misconduct
column3: and Juanita Broaddrick
column4: who has accused him of rape
column5: which he has denied.

column1: Hillary Clinton nearly collapsed while getting into a car and belatedly revealed that she had pneumonia.
And
column2: well
column3: I could go on.

column1: Many of these cases prompted media firestorms
column2: complete with predictions that Trump or Clinton would be seriously or even fatally damaged. But then the stories were overtaken by some new allegation or outrage.

column1: In the case of Comey’s renewed email investigation
column2: polls so far suggest that it hasn’t moved the needle much beyond the tightening that was already taking place in the race.

column1: It may well be that we’ve all become numb in this whiplash campaign. The race is so polarized
column2: and public attitudes toward Trump and Clinton so firmly established
column3: that each new front-page headline or cable obsession changes few minds.

column1: Perhaps the only consensus is a sense of relief that this long
column2: strange trip is finally coming to an end.
