column1: Obama Inches Closer to Veto-Proof Support for Iran Nuclear Deal	"Democratic Senator Jeff Merkley of Oregon said he will vote to support the Iran nuclear deal
column2: a pledge that puts President Barack Obama only three votes short of protecting the pact in Congress.

column1: Merkley issued a statement Sunday calling the accord “the best available strategy to block Iran from acquiring a nuclear weapon.”
Merkley’s support brings to 31 the number of senators publicly favoring the deal
column2: which would ease economic sanctions on Iran in exchange for curbs on the country’s nuclear program.

column1: Barring defections
column2: Obama needs three more votes from 13 Senate Democrats who have yet to declare their position
column3: to sustain a likely veto of legislation aimed at killing the pact.

column1: If Obama can assemble 41 Senate votes by getting most of the remaining Democrats on board
column2: the Senate may not vote on the agreement at all.

column1: The Republican-controlled Congress has until Sept. 17 to pass a resolution disapproving the deal reached in July between six world powers and Iran. Obama has pledged to veto that resolution if it gets to his desk.
While Republicans have been united in opposing the deal
column2: only two Democratic senators -- Charles Schumer of New York
column3: the third-ranking Democrat in the chamber
column4: and Robert Menendez of New Jersey -- have joined them so far.

column1: Senator Chris Coons
column2: a Delaware Democrat on the Foreign Relations Committee
column3: plans to announce his decision on Tuesday. Among other Democrats yet to disclose a position are Maryland’s Ben Cardin and New Jersey’s Cory Booker.

column1: The only uncertain Senate Republican vote is that of Senator Susan Collins of Maine
column2: who remains undecided and is expected to make her decision after Sept. 7.

column1: Merkley
column2: in a statement on his website
column3: pledged to vote for the deal even while pointing to “significant shortcomings” that he said the U.S. must address with “a massive intelligence program” and monitoring.

column1: Merkley said he was troubled that the deal allows Iran to import conventional arms after five years and ballistic missile technology after eight years
column2: and sets no restrictions on how Iran can use money it reclaims when sanctions are lifted.

column1: But he rejected a proposal from deal opponents to try to renegotiate the accord for better terms.
If the U.S. rejects the deal and Iran resumes its nuclear program
column2: “the United States would be viewed by the international community as undermining a strong framework for peacefully blocking a potential Iranian bomb
column3: ” Merkley said.

column1: While the Republican-controlled House has enough votes to pass a resolution rejecting the deal
column2: it’s unclear whether the Senate does. Assuming all 54 Senate Republicans oppose the accord
column3: they would need support from six Democrats to get the 60 votes necessary to advance a resolution."	REAL

column1: Shi’ite Militias Join Iraq’s Mosul Attack	"Militia Fighters to Advance on Areas West of City by Jason Ditz
column2: October 28
column3: 2016 Share This

column1: After a week and a half of assuring everyone that their role in the invasion of Mosul would be very limited
column2: and removed from the Sunni population
column3: Iraq’s Shi’ite militias have been announced to have launched an offensive west of Mosul
column4: advancing on Tal Afar .

column1: According to officials
column2: the main goal of this offensive is to cut the city of Mosul off from ISIS territory in Syria
column3: preventing the ISIS fighters within the city from fleeing west if the battle begins to turn sour. The offensive is said to start “within a few days or hours.”

column1: The involvement of Shi’ite militias in the “liberation” of Sunni Arab cities in Iraq has been controversial because they often end up carrying out extrajudicial executions
column2: looting and torture of locals they suspect of being secretly in league with ISIS.

column1: An effort to block flight from Mosul to ISIS territory is Syria would be an obvious step
column2: but the militias’ involvement again risks targeting of civilians
column3: as the population of from Mosul is already overrunning the minimal camps set up for the displaced.

column1: Civilians fleeing these cities are usually not welcomed in Iraqi government-held territory
column2: and wind up fleeing into other ISIS-held territory. With little left in Iraq
column3: this likely means fleeing into Syria
column4: and the militias’ presence means the civilians displaced by the attack are likely to be targeted for fleeing “with” ISIS. Last 5 posts by Jason Ditz"	FAKE

column1: ‘Super PAC’ Gets Early Start on Pushing for a 2016 Clinton Campaign	"In the 2008 presidential primary campaign
column2: Mitch Stewart devoted himself to defeating Hillary Rodham Clinton
column3: overcoming the advantages of a well-funded Democratic front-runner through grass-roots organizing
column4: and propelling Barack Obama to victory.

column1: On Tuesday
column2: Mr. Stewart and a dozen or so other political operatives and 170 donors will gather in New York to plot how to help Mrs. Clinton win in 2016. The meeting is the first national finance council strategy meeting of Ready for Hillary
column3: a “super PAC” devoted to building a network to support Mrs. Clinton’s potential presidential ambitions.

column1: “We’re coming up with plans on how to engage emerging constituencies that will be incredibly important if there’s a primary and in a general — whether that’s women
column2: African-Americans
column3: Latinos
column4: L.G.B.T.
column5: ” said Mr. Stewart
column6: who went on to run Mr. Obama’s battleground-state strategy in 2012.

column1: The all-day meeting at the Parker Meridien hotel will be closed to the news media
column2: but a preview of the day
column3: with panel discussions like “What America Will Look Like in 2016
column4: ” about changing demographics
column5: and “Building the Resources to Win
column6: ” about developing a campaign infrastructure
column7: provided an early look into what supporters consider Mrs. Clinton’s strengths and potential pitfalls in 2016.

column1: Mrs. Clinton has never had a problem raising money from deep-pocketed donors
column2: but her 2008 campaign lacked the grass-roots enthusiasm and modest Internet donations that buoyed Mr. Obama. Ready for Hillary hopes to build that kind of support.

column1: A grass-roots super PAC may seem an oxymoron: such groups can raise and spend unlimited amounts of money on political races as long as they do not coordinate with a candidate. But rather than invest in expensive television ads
column2: Ready for Hillary puts all of its donations into building its email list of supporters.

column1: For every $25
column2: 0000 the group raises
column3: it cuts a payment to Rising Tide Interactive
column4: a firm that helps build online lists of supporters. A social media tool on the website will allow supporters to work together to organize to plan rallies and small-dollar fund-raising events. With no candidate and over a year before a potential campaign
column5: Ready for Hillary has roughly a million names on its email list
column6: about half the size of the Hillary for President campaign list at the time Mrs. Clinton suspended her campaign in 2008.

column1: “It’s not our job to be a campaign and it’s not our job to make decisions to tie any potential candidate’s hands
column2: ” said Craig T. Smith
column3: an aide in the administration of President Bill Clinton and senior adviser to Ready for Hillary. “The goal is to build a list.”

column1: The strategy is an acknowledgment of mistakes made by Mrs. Clinton’s 2008 campaign
column2: but also a recognition that she cannot simply run as the establishment candidate with inside-the-Beltway support without also inspiring young and minority voters who largely favored Mr. Obama in 2008. Mr. Stewart helped Mr. Obama pick up delegates in small but important caucus states and turn states like Arizona
column3: New Mexico and Virginia into battlegrounds by tapping into changing demographics.

column1: A lineup of longtime Clinton backers and aides will attend Tuesday’s meeting
column2: including Susie Tompkins Buell of San Francisco; Ann Lewis
column3: a former adviser to both Clintons; Jennifer M. Granholm
column4: the former governor of Michigan; and Tracy Sefl
column5: a Democratic strategist. Along with Ms. Sefl
column6: two young Ready for Hillary volunteers
column7: Taj Magruder
column9: of Philadelphia
column10: and Haley Adams
column11: a student at Yale
column12: will open the event
column13: signaling that the Clinton world intends to bring in fresh voices
column14: even if it means edging some loyal aides out.

column1: The event signals a turning point for Ready for Hillary. The group
column2: registered just before Mrs. Clinton left the State Department in February by young staff members who worked in junior roles on her 2008 campaign
column3: was largely viewed as a makeshift organization that sold Hillary Clinton buttons and iPhone cases online.

column1: Some longtime supporters had worried that the group emerged too soon and that if it were not well run
column2: it could hurt Mrs. Clinton’s prospects
column3: even though she is not involved or in contact with its organizers. But veteran aides like Mr. Smith
column4: Ms. Sefl and Harold Ickes
column5: a former deputy chief of staff in the Clinton White House
column6: are now signed on as advisers. In recent months
column7: the group has held events in several cities from San Francisco to Houston and has become among the dominant — if not best financed — political action committees on the Democratic side.

column1: The sessions in New York will point to several advantages favoring a Democrat in 2016. “Democrats do have a series of advantages baked into the cake in terms of demographics and the electoral map
column2: ” said Geoff Garin
column3: a pollster who succeeded Mark Penn as chief strategist for Mrs. Clinton’s 2008 campaign.

column1: Fresh off working on behalf of Terry McAuliffe in his successful campaign for governor of Virginia
column2: Mr. Garin will talk about reaching the growing numbers of Hispanics and college-educated white women
column3: and the decline in non-college-educated white male voters
column4: one of the most challenging demographics for Mrs. Clinton. But
column5: he added that some very big odds will work against any Democratic presidential nominee in 2016. “Since World War II
column6: the only time the same party won a third term in the White House was 1988
column7: ” Mr. Garin said.

column1: Supporters are also well aware of the attacks Mrs. Clinton would face. During a lunch session
column2: David Brock
column3: founder of Media Matters for America
column4: will lead the “Ready for the Right Wing” tutorial on how to combat conservative attacks and misinformation in the media.

column1: The future of Ready for Hillary is unclear. Should Mrs. Clinton run
column2: the group would most likely dissolve
column3: after encouraging those on its email list to transfer their support to the official Clinton campaign. The widespread belief is that several Ready for Hillary staff members would take up positions on the campaign
column4: which has made the group somewhat of a way station for hopeful aides. If Mrs. Clinton does not run
column5: the group would likely throw its support behind whoever becomes the Democratic nominee.

column1: Either way
column2: this type of early unity and strategizing around a single candidate is a good thing and a rarity in Democratic politics
column3: said Ronald Feldman
column4: a Ready for Hillary national finance council co-chairman who supported John Edwards in 2008.

column1: “We’ve never been paying this much attention this early on
column2: but this time it seemed like a necessity
column3: ” Mr. Feldman said."	REAL

column1: Christianity under attack: US must do more to promote religious freedom	"Throughout the Middle East and North Africa today
column2: Christianity is under attack.  Terrorist organizations such as the Islamic State of Iraq and Syria (ISIS) are destroying some of the oldest and most sacred Christian communities and relics in the world on the very lands where Christianity was born and first took root. They are committing brutal atrocities against Christian communities in Syria and Iraq
column3: persecuting religious minorities and destroying entire towns and local economies. Christians are fleeing their homes in increasing numbers
column4: creating an exploding refugee crisis that will have grave ramifications on the stability and security of the entire region.

column1: While the world has been rightly outraged by the violence waged by ISIS against people of all sects
column2: ethnicities
column3: and religions
column4: the United States
column5: Europe and other key allies have done little to end ISIS’s systematic efforts to drive-out and eradicate entire religious communities from their historic and sacred homelands. The Obama Administration has repeatedly refused to defend religious freedom abroad and continues to ignore its devastating cost to those religious communities targeted by terrorists because of their religious beliefs.

column1: As a nation founded in the pursuit of religious freedom
column2: America can and must do more to root-out the religious intolerance that is helping to foster much of the political instability and violence we see today. Specifically
column3: we believe the Obama Administration should integrate the protection of religious freedom into its overall response to growing terrorist threats and development efforts around the world. Doing so would help to eliminate the underlying causes of violent extremism
column4: promote increased international economic stability
column5: and foster greater respect for human rights.

column1: Promoting religious freedom would
column2: first and foremost
column3: undermine the efforts of terrorist organizations such as ISIS to capitalize on simmering religious intolerance to build influence and wield power. ISIS has succeeded in tearing apart the social fabric of local communities and exacerbating sectarian and ethnic divisions to recruit supporters from disaffected populations and assert control over wide swaths of otherwise insecure territory. As a result
column4: they have precipitated a breakdown of basic order that has allowed new and unprecedented security threats to the United States and our allies to fester and grow.

column1: The Obama administration can counter this strategy by building alliances with popular local and regional leaders who can expose these radical ideologies’ moral bankruptcy and champion pluralism and tolerance. The Administration should also combat terrorist propaganda about religious minorities and develop programs that promote tolerance and empower minorities to better advocate for their rights and interests. Only by reaffirming the importance of religious freedom and working closely with communities and their governments will we be able to strip away sympathy and support for ISIS and other extremist groups that is bred from deeper political
column2: economic
column3: and social grievances.

column1: Properly designed and implemented
column2: a U.S. foreign policy committed to religious freedom can advance our national security interests
column3: stabilize and consolidate the spread of democracy across the globe
column4: help sustain economic growth
column5: and promote the equality of men and women.

column1: Most importantly
column2: it can help prevent religiously-motivated terrorism and undermine the conditions that have helped spur the rise of groups like ISIS
column3: Boko Haram
column4: and the Shuddhikaran Movement.

column1: Promoting religious freedom would also support the governance structures necessary for economic and political security in developing nations. As recent studies by groups such as the Religious Freedom and Business Foundation have found
column2: higher levels of religious freedom are associated with higher levels of economic productivity and growth. Clearly
column3: sustainable political and economic development is only possible when religious freedom and equal opportunity contributes to a secure environment in which citizens and businesses can operate freely.

column1: Finally
column2: we must remain committed to religious freedom because of the special distinction religious freedom holds as a fundamental human right—a belief that is shared by democratic countries across the globe and protected by numerous international treaties and agreements.

column1: American support for religious liberty sends a potent and unmistakable message to threatened communities around the world: America is your friend. Such support builds enduring good will towards our country among those who could be leading their own nations in the years ahead. And it reminds all observers
column2: whether friendly or hostile
column3: that the U.S. remains committed to a world where justice and human dignity are central to legitimate governance.

column1: Republican John McCain is a Navy veteran. He represents Arizona in the United States Senate.
Tony Perkins is president of the Family Research Council in Washington
column2: D.C."	REAL

column1: U.S. Taxpayers Pay AT&T Millions of Dollars a Year For the Privilege of Spying on Them	"at 10:41 am 2 Comments
On Monday
column2: The Daily Beast published a hugely important story about AT&T’s in house
column3: for profit surveillance operation called Project Hemisphere. The program has nothing to do with information sharing legally required under a warrant
column4: but rather consists of a business line through which the telecom giant stores customer data longer than peers in order to turn around and sell it to government agencies (no warrant required). This allows law enforcement to use secret and never disclosed evidence to build a cases against citizens via a shady and unaccountable practice known as parallel construction.

column1: The article is titled
column2: AT&T Is Spying on Americans for Profit
column3: New Documents Reveal
column4: and is a must read.

column1: Here are some key excerpts:

column2: Hemisphere was revealed by The New York Times and described only within a Powerpoint presentation made by the Drug Enforcement Administration . The Times described it as a “partnership” between AT&T and the U.S. government; the Justice Department said it was an essential
column3: and prudently deployed
column4: counter-narcotics tool.

column1: However
column2: AT&T’s own documentation—reported here by The Daily Beast for the first time—shows Hemisphere was used far beyond the war on drugs to include everything from investigations of homicide to Medicaid fraud.

column1: Hemisphere isn’t a “partnership” but rather a product AT&T developed
column2: marketed
column3: and sold at a cost of millions of dollars per year to taxpayers. No warrant is required to make use of the company’s massive trove of data
column4: according to AT&T documents
column5: only a promise from law enforcement to not disclose Hemisphere if an investigation using it becomes public.

column1: These new revelations come as the company seeks to acquire Time Warner in the face of vocal opposition saying the deal would be bad for consumers . Donald Trump told supporters over the weekend he would kill the acquisition if he’s elected president; Hillary Clinton has urged regulators to scrutinize the deal.
The fact that this deal is even being considered shows what a giant joke this county has become.
As I noted on Twitter earlier this week: Why don’t we just merge the entire S&P 500 into one company called Oligarchy Inc. and get it over with.
— Michael Krieger (@LibertyBlitz) October 24
While telecommunications companies are legally obligated to hand over records
column2: AT&T appears to have gone much further to make the enterprise profitable
column3: according to ACLU technology policy analyst Christopher Soghoian.

column1: AT&T has a unique power to extract information from its metadata because it retains so much of it. The company owns more than three-quarters of U.S. landline switches
column2: and the second largest share of the nation’s wireless infrastructure and cellphone towers
column3: behind Verizon. AT&T retains its cell tower data going back to July 2008
column4: longer than other providers. Verizon holds records for a year and Sprint for 18 months
column5: according to a 2011 retention schedule obtained by The Daily Beast.

column1: The disclosure of Hemisphere was not the first time AT&T has been caught working with law enforcement above and beyond what the law requires.
A statement of work from 2014 shows how hush-hush AT&T wants to keep Hemisphere.
“The Government agency agrees not to use the data as evidence in any judicial or administrative proceedings unless there is no other available and admissible probative evidence
column2: ” it says.

column1: But those charged with a crime are entitled to know the evidence against them come trial. Adam Schwartz
column2: staff attorney for activist group Electronic Frontier Foundation
column3: said that means AT&T leaves investigators no choice but to construct a false investigative narrative to hide how they use Hemisphere if they plan to prosecute anyone.

column1: Once AT&T provides a lead through Hemisphere
column2: then investigators use routine police work
column3: like getting a court order for a wiretap or following a suspect around
column4: to provide the same evidence for the purpose of prosecution. This is known as “parallel construction.”

column1: Parallel construction is a pernicious side effect of all this spying. It’s a very important topic I covered last year in the post
column2: How the DEA Uses “Parallel Construction” to Hide Unconstitutional Investigations .

column1: “This document here is striking
column2: ” Schwartz told The Daily Beast. “I’ve seen documents produced by the government regarding Hemisphere
column3: but this is the first time I’ve seen an AT&T document which requires parallel construction in a service to government. It’s very troubling and not the way law enforcement should work in this country.”

column1: The federal government reimburses municipalities for the expense of Hemisphere through the same grant program that is blamed for police militarization by paying for military gear like Bearcat vehicles.
There’s your government again. Tirelessly working against you from behind the scenes.
“At a minimum there is a very serious question whether they should be doing it without a warrant. A benefit to the parallel construction is they never have to face that crucible. Then the judge
column2: the defendant
column3: the general public
column4: the media
column5: and elected officials never know that AT&T and police across America funded by the White House are using the world’s largest metadata database to surveil people
column6: ” Schwartz said.

column1: Sheriff and police departments pay from $100
column2: 000 to upward of $1 million a year or more for Hemisphere access. Harris County
column3: Texas
column4: home to Houston
column5: made its inaugural payment to AT&T of $77
column7: according to a contract reviewed by The Daily Beast. Four years later
column8: the county’s Hemisphere bill had increased more than tenfold to $940

column1: AT&T documents state law enforcement doesn’t need a search warrant to use Hemisphere
column2: just an administrative subpoena
column3: which does not require probable cause . The DEA was granted administrative subpoena power in 1970.

column1: Just another reason to end the failed war on drugs and close down the DEA. Recall
column2: unconstitutional surveillance was actually pioneered by the DEA a decade before the 9/11 attacks. See: How NSA Surveillance Was Birthed from the Drug War – The DEA Tracked Billions of Phone Calls Pre 9/11 .

column1: AT&T stores details for every call
column2: text message
column3: Skype chat
column4: or other communication that has passed through its infrastructure
column5: retaining many records dating back to 1987
column6: according to the Times 2013 Hemisphere report. The scope and length of the collection has accumulated trillions of records and is believed to be larger than any phone record database collected by the NSA under the Patriot Act
column7: the Times reported.

column1: This summer
column2: I switched my cellphone service away from AT&T and was able to reduce my monthly bill by nearly 50%. You should consider doing the same.

column1: Iran agrees to nuclear restrictions in framework deal with world powers	"Iran agreed in principle to accept significant restrictions on its nuclear facilities for at least a decade and submit to international inspections under a framework deal announced Thursday after months of contentious negotiations with the United States and other world powers.
In return
column2: international sanctions that have battered Iran’s economy would be lifted in phases if it meets its commitments
column3: meaning it could take a year or less for relief from the penalties to kick in.

column1: The framework agreement
column2: a milestone in negotiations that began 12 years ago
column3: is not a final deal. But it creates parameters for three more months of negotiations over technical details and some matters that remain unresolved. Any one of those issues could doom a comprehensive agreement. Among them is the pace at which sanctions will be suspended.

column1: “The political understanding with details that we have reached is a solid foundation for the good deal we are seeking
column2: ” said Secretary of State John F. Kerry
column3: sounding hoarse after an all-night negotiation session.

column1: The key moments in the long history of U.S.-Iran tensions
The agreement includes almost all the restrictions on Iran’s nuclear facilities
column2: laboratories
column3: mines and mills that the United States had sought in recent months
column4: although it initially aimed for even tougher restrictions.

column1: But Iran would get several benefits that may make the deal more palatable to politicians and the public in Tehran. It would not have to close any of its three nuclear facilities
column2: though it would be left with only one that would enrich uranium — at levels low enough to create fuel for power plants but not high enough to create weapons-grade material.

column1: The limitations would produce a one-year “breakout” period
column2: meaning it would take Iran a full year to build up enough material to build one nuclear warhead
column3: compared with current estimates of two to three months
column4: officials said.

column1: Many sanctions initially would be suspended
column2: rather than lifted permanently as Iran sought
column3: so they could be “snapped back” into place if Iran was discovered to be cheating
column4: the officials said.

column1: Iran’s apparent acceptance of so many conditions sought by the United States could give the Obama administration a tool to fend off critics in Congress who want to impose new sanctions to wring more concessions from the Iranians.
The White House fears such steps could scuttle the talks and prompt Tehran to resume its nuclear program at full tilt. Iran claims its nuclear program is for peaceful
column2: civilian uses.

column1: While the negotiations will continue through June
column2: much of the attention will now shift to the White House and its defense of the negotiations
column3: both in classified briefings to Congress and in public arenas.

column1: Obama hailed the agreement as a “historic understanding” and asked whether anyone really thinks that the deal is “a worse option than the risk of another war in the Middle East.”
Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu
column2: a persistent critic of the negotiations
column3: told Obama by telephone that a final deal based on the parameters announced Thursday “would threaten the survival of Israel
column4: ” according to an Israeli statement.

column1: Kerry’s predecessor at the State Department
column2: Hillary Rodham Clinton
column3: called the framework agreement an “understanding
column4: ” saying it was an “important step toward a comprehensive agreement that would prevent Iran from getting a nuclear weapon and strengthen the security of the United States
column5: Israel
column6: and the region.”

column1: The announcement of the agreement was made by weary-looking diplomats from Iran
column2: the European Union
column3: the United States and five other nations. Most had slept only one or two hours after the previous day’s talks
column4: which stretched nearly through the night.

column1: They sounded exuberant even before they arrived at a Lausanne school a few miles from the hotel where the last rounds of talks had been held. Many diplomats had been cautious after the negotiations failed to meet a March 31 deadline. But once the bargaining ended Thursday
column2: there was a flurry of excited tweets.

column1: “Big day
column2: ” wrote Kerry
column3: who shouldered most of the direct negotiations with Iran.

column1: Once the agreement was reached
column2: the diplomats walked onto a stage bearing the flags of the nations involved in the talks — Iran
column3: Germany
column4: France
column5: Britain
column6: Russia
column7: China and the United States.

column1: Then Mohammad Javad Zarif
column2: Iran’s foreign minister and chief negotiator in the talks
column3: and the European foreign policy chief
column4: Federica Mogherini
column5: made statements.

column1: Mogherini said Iran and the world powers were taking a “decisive step” before she listed the main parameters for an eventual deal in which Iran would be permitted to pursue the civilian use of nuclear technology.
[A step-by-step guide to what the Iran agreement actually means]
Under the agreement
column2: Iran’s heavy-water reactor in Arak would be rebuilt so it could not produce weapons-grade plutonium. No nuclear fuel would be reprocessed
column3: and spent fuel would be exported or diluted.

column1: Iran’s underground plant at Fordow would be converted from a uranium-enrichment site into a nuclear physics and technology center. The site was built secretly deep inside a mountain near Qom and would be difficult to destroy by military attack.
As Mogherini was speaking
column2: the State Department was

column1: e-mailing reporters a “fact sheet” outlining more details that it said Iran had agreed to
column2: though it could not immediately be confirmed that Iran was indeed on board with every item.

column1: In one of the most significant points
column2: the number of Iran’s centrifuges would be cut by two-thirds
column3: to about 6
column5: according to the statement. It said they would be first-generation machines
column6: not the more advanced ones that Iran has sought. Keeping the old centrifuges is a key element in establishing the one-year breakout period
column7: a red line for Washington.

column1: The fact sheet said Iran further agreed not to enrich uranium above the level of 3.67 percent for at least 15 years. That level of low-enriched uranium is suitable as fuel for nuclear power plants but not as fissile material for nuclear weapons
column2: which require uranium enriched to about 90 percent purity.

column1: Iran has agreed to reduce its stockpile of about 10
column2: 000 kilograms (22
column3: 000 pounds) of low-enriched uranium to 300 kilograms (660 pounds) for 15 years
column4: the fact sheet said.

column1: The restrictions would be monitored through inspections conducted by the International Atomic Energy Agency
column2: and some of them would last 25 years under the accord.

column1: Zarif seemed to go out of his way to thank Kerry for investing so much time and effort in the negotiations
column2: which he said had been conducted with “mutual respect.”

column1: The preliminary agreement could foretell the beginning of a new chapter in Iran’s relationship with the world
column2: and particularly the United States.

column1: Though six nations negotiated with Iran
column2: much of the heavy lifting was done in meetings between the United States and Iran. The countries have been hostile toward each other for decades
column3: particularly since the 1979 revolution and the seizure of dozens of American diplomats who were held hostage in the U.S. Embassy in Tehran.

column1: But the United States and Iran will remain at odds on many issues.
“We have serious differences with the United States
column2: ” Zarif said. “We have built mutual distrust in the past. . . . So what I hope is that through courageous implementation of this
column3: some of that trust could be remedied. But that is for us all to wait and see.”

column1: William Branigin in Washington contributed to this report.

column1: Should Christians Celebrate Halloween?	"Whether or not Christians should celebrate Halloween has been a controversial topic for decades. Some view dressing up
column2: eating candy and enjoying the festivities harmless and innocent
column3: while others view it as an offense to their faith. Americans spend nearly $6.9 billion yearly making it the second largest commercial holiday in the country. As commercialized as the celebration has become
column4: many of its roots are completely paganist. Is this a cause for Christians to avoid the entire celebration?

column1: This is a time of year filled with debate
column2: but not necessarily politics. Many Christians are convinced that Halloween is a satanic holiday while the rest of the world has found their sweet spot complete with costumes and candy. Children and adults have the opportunity to dress in accordance with their imagination
column3: confirming from its haunted history to modern festivities
column4: this holiday is a big deal. With decorations
column5: candy
column6: parties
column7: and costumes
column8: the average American spends up to $75 in the spirit of celebration.

column1: Halloween is the holiday that links the seasons of fall and winter. Reportedly
column2: it originated with one of the ancient Celtic festivals; an event where people would wear various costumes and light bonfires in hopes of warding off roaming ghosts. However
column3: by the late 1800s
column4: Americans shifted the theory of Halloween into a holiday centered on community and fun events. The focus
column5: for many
column6: has transitioned from witchcraft and ghosts to neighborhood celebratory events. With the evolving of the focal point
column7: should Christians change their stance to celebrate the holiday?

column1: Despite having at least partial roots from a Christian tradition
column2: the relationship between Halloween and Christians has long been complicated. On October 31
column4: Martin Luther essentially started the Protestant Reformation in Wittenberg
column5: Germany
column6: when he nailed his 95 Theses to a door. Many of the early Christian groups that came to America rejected this holiday as pagan. The Protestant Reformation heavily influenced the Pilgrims
column7: Puritans
column8: Quakers
column9: and Baptists causing the great majority to frown upon it. However
column10: that did not prevent Halloween from finding its way to American shores.

column1: In the eighth century
column2: Pope Gregory III dedicated November 1 as a time to honor all saints and martyrs. The holiday became widely recognized as All Saints’ Day. The evening before was known as All Hallows’ Eve
column3: which later became Halloween. The word “hallow” originated from the Old English word for “holy” and “e’en” is an abbreviation of “evening.” As such
column4: Halloween represented the night before All Saints Day.

column1: Over time
column2: Halloween advanced into a secular
column3: community-based holiday branded by child-friendly activities that include costumes
column4: neighborhood trick-or-treating
column5: and more recently
column6: trunk-or-treating. Along with a variety of pumpkin-flavored foods
column7: Parties for both children and adults have become a very common way to celebrate the holiday. Some Christians still choose to lock themselves indoors with the lights off
column8: but others have found freedom in their faith and are at liberty to decide when and how to participate.

column1: In multiple countries around the world
column2: as the days grow shorter and the nights get colder
column3: people continue to escort the winter season in with candy-coated gatherings and a wide range of costumes. Halloween is a celebration that allows people of all ages to participate. Nonetheless
column4: the question remains
column5: “Should Christians celebrate?”

column1: Due to the efforts of community leaders and parents
column2: Halloween has lost most of its illogical and religious undertones and is now more about imagination than spooky interpretation. There is nothing sinful about a Christian dressing up and participating in fun
column3: non-threatening
column4: celebrations. As a result
column5: many Christians find no harm in dressing in costumes
column6: attending parties and festivals as well as allowing their children to participate in school and local activities.

column1: By Cherese Jackson (Virginia)
Sources:
History: Halloween
Kidsville News: Around the World – October 2015
Grace to You: Christians and Halloween

Only Making Matters Worse in Syria	"Only Making Matters Worse in Syria October 28
Exclusive: Washington’s foreign policy establishment is determined to escalate U.S. military attacks in Syria even though that won’t resolve the conflict and will only get more people killed
column2: a dilemma addressed by Daniel Lazare.

column1: By Daniel Lazare
Middle East policy has reached an inflexion point
column2: a moment when Official Washington seems to be caught in the middle between escalation and retreat.

column1: On one hand
column2: the rhetoric has not been more militant since Hillary Clinton’s famous “we came
column3: we saw
column4: he died” moment in October 2011. With Barack Obama halfway out the door and Clinton all but crowned
column5: Washington’s laptop bombardiers are rejoicing that the half-measures are over and judgment day nearly at hand. Samantha Power
column6: Permanent Representative of the United States to the UN
column7: addresses the Security Council meeting on Syria
column8: Sept. 25
column9: 2016. Power has been an advocate for escalating U.S. military involvement in Syria. (UN Photo)

column1: Thus
column2: The New York Times assures us that that the Middle East is “desperate for American leadership” while the Washington Post reports that “the Republicans and Democrats who make up the foreign policy elite are laying the ground work for a more assertive American foreign policy.”

column1: Leading think tanks are publishing “a flurry of reports” urging stepped-up intervention
column2: including U.S.-backed “safe zones to protect moderate rebels from Syrian and Russian forces” and even “limited” cruise-missile strikes. But while differing on the details
column3: all agree something must be done. The time to act is now.

column1: As Vox puts it: “The hot new policy idea in Washington is the hottest old idea: direct US military intervention in Syria’s civil war.”
But reading between the lines
column2: a very different picture emerges
column3: a realization that the U.S. has painted itself into a corner and that there is little it can do after all. Thus
column4: the Times observes that while the Middle East is clamoring for U.S. leadership
column5: it is not clamoring for Bush-style intervention but for some mythical “middle ground” in between him and Obama.

column1: While reporting that pro-escalation sentiment is unanimous in Washington’s vast foreign-policy establishment – sometimes known as “ the blob ” – the Washington Post notes that “even pinprick cruise-missile strikes designed to hobble the Syrian air force or punish [President Bashar al-]Assad would risk a direct confrontation with Russian forces” and wonders whether a war-weary public will support any intervention at all.
“My concern is that we may be talking to each other and agreeing with each other
column2: ” it quotes one expert as saying
column3: “but that these discussions are isolated from where the public may be right now.”

column1: Official Washington in a Bubble
Thus
column2: even the Establishment worries that it lives in a bubble. Washington wants war
column3: it needs war
column4: and yet it admits in practically the same breath that it can’t have it. So what will it do? A heart-rending propaganda image designed to justify a major U.S. military operation inside Syria against the Syrian military.

column1: Then there are the mild liberals over at Vox
column2: the hip and successful Washington website founded by journalistic wunderkind Ezra Klein. Voxers pride themselves on being sharp and practical yet in the end they are sealed off as well. The poster boy for this tendency is Zack Beauchamp
column3: a young writer who stars in a recent Vox video entitled
column4: “ The crisis in Aleppo
column5: explained in 4 minutes .”

column1: As Beauchamp lectures away amid fancy graphics and cool background music
column2: the video faithfully toes the Washington line
column3: both the stirring gung-ho part and the downbeat refrain that inevitably follows. Thus
column4: he describes the Syrian civil war as a “story of flip-flops
column5: ” with Assad seemingly on the ropes until Iran and Russia put him back on his feet
column6: at which point the Saudis and Qataris put the rebels back on their feet so the game can continue.

column1: But the real turning point
column2: he says
column3: occurred in September 2015 when Russia stepped in with airstrikes that allowed the government to besiege the Salafists in eastern Aleppo.

column1: “A siege
column2: ” Beauchamp then explains
column3: “involves trapping a group of people
column4: civilians and fighters both
column5: inside a certain territory and denying them supplies until they can no longer fight. Assad’s strategy has a vicious logic to it. When you deprive people of food and you bomb them over and over again
column6: they’re likely to give in just to make the fighting stop.”

column1: The upshot
column2: he says
column3: is “a humanitarian crisis … roughly 250
column4: 000 people trapped in the city … running dangerously low on supplies
column5: access to clean water and medicine.” So what should the U.S. do in response? The video’s tone at this point turns pessimistic and then pitch black:

column1: “The United States has the military power to break the siege of Aleppo
column2: ” Beauchamp says
column3: “but doing so would be extremely dangerous. For one thing
column4: it would need to coordinate with rebels on the ground
column5: some of whom are extremists. For another
column6: it means that the US would be operating in hostile air space with Russian planes.If the US were to engage with Russian planes
column7: that could theoretically mean direct fire between two nuclear-armed superpowers
column8: a risk that very few people in the United States are willing to take. And three
column9: even if the US did temporarily break the siege
column10: it would have to maintain a commitment to insure that things didn’t get worse. That could mean an open-ended war. And there’s no guarantee that this would make anything better
column11: but
column12: rather
column13: it might just get more people killed over the long run.”

column1: So U.S. options are zero: “Every diplomatic solution tried so far has failed
column2: and failed miserably
column3: and there’s simply no economic tool that can be used to end the fighting or ease the suffering of the people inside besieged territories. There’s no good answer. There’s nothing that anyone has that could simply solve the crisis. It’s a disaster and a disaster without any end in sight.”

column1: Falsehoods and Obfuscations
Beauchamp’s explanation – which is really not an explanation at all
column2: merely an assertion – is studded with falsehoods and obfuscations. By describing Assad’s strategy as uniquely “vicious
column3: ” he ignores obvious parallels between the Russian air campaign in Aleppo and U.S. air assaults on Fallujah
column4: Tikrit
column5: and Ramadi
column6: all in central Iraq and all largely destroyed in the course of “liberating” them from ISIS. U.S.-backed Syrian “moderate” rebels smile as they prepare to behead a 12-year-old boy (left)
column7: whose severed head is held aloft triumphantly in a later part of the video. [Screenshot from the YouTube video] By referring to the events in Syria as a civil war
column8: he fails to acknowledge the degree to which it is actually a foreign invasion by the U.S.
column9: Turkey
column10: Saudi Arabia
column11: and other Persian Gulf states. By repeatedly referring to the Salafists as “rebels” – which suggests that they are Syrians rising up from within – he ignores the fact that large numbers – 36
column13: according to Director of National Intelligence James Clapper – are foreign-born.

column1: While asserting that 250
column2: 000 people are trapped inside east Aleppo
column3: he ignores reports that the real figure is far lower. The Guardian ’s Martin Chulov
column4: for example
column5: estimated in March 2015 that only 40
column6: 000 people remained in rebel-held areas while Vice News reported last July that “most of Aleppo’s residents have fled the city. There are just a handful of civilians and rebel fighters holding on in the shattered ruins.”

column1: Beauchamp also implies that it is the government that has “trapped” people in east Aleppo when reports in the London Independent and elsewhere indicate that Salafists are firing on anyone trying to take the government up on its offer of safe passage. While acknowledging that “some” fighters are “extremists
column2: ” he ignores the fact that the U.S. military has admitted that Al Nusra
column3: the local branch of Al Qaeda
column4: is firmly in charge.

column1: When Salafists launched a short-lived offensive in east Aleppo last summer
column2: for instance
column3: The New York Times reported that they named it in honor of Ibrahim al-Yousef
column4: a Muslim Brotherhood member who led a horrendous massacre of Alawite military cadets in 1979. It was indicative of how anti-Alawite sectarianism of the most bloodthirsty sort is the common denominator underlying all anti-government factions.

column1: One could go on
column2: but the point is clear. The foreign-policy establishment has not only cut itself off from the public but
column3: with the help of sympathetic media outlets like Vox
column4: has cut itself off from its own intellectual history. Incapable of examining the U.S. role in the Syrian debacle in an honest and straightforward way
column5: it can only blunder about in the dark
column6: staggering backward or forward as circumstances dictate. Now seems to be the moment when it is poised between the two.

column1: So how will the United States respond now that Washington is preparing for a transition between Obama-style abstention and Hillary-style neo-conservatism? Here’s is one reporter’s modest attempt at reading the tea leaves:
Washington will continue to fume as the catastrophe deepens in both Syria and Iraq. As the drive to push ISIS (also known as ISIL
column2: Islamic State
column3: and Daesh) out of Mosul in northern Iraq degenerates into ethno-sectarian warfare among Turks
column4: Sunni Arabs
column5: Shi‘ites
column6: and Kurds
column7: the drive to take back Raqqa
column8: ISIS’s capital in north-central Syria will similarly falter as fighting breaks out between pro-Turkish forces and Kurdish People’s Protection Units
column9: or YPG.

column1: The fall of east Aleppo
column2: which now seems to be a foregone conclusion
column3: will drive the foreign-policy establishment to a fury. Obama may be able to hold the hawks off. But by the time he leaves office
column4: “the blob” will be in an uproar and demanding that something be done. Map of Syria.

column1: With that
column2: Zack Beauchamp will star in another Vox video entitled
column3: “U.S. military intervention in Syria
column4: explained in 4 minutes.” In it
column5: he’ll tell how Russian atrocities in Aleppo
column6: plus backhanded Syrian government support for ISIS
column7: leave the U.S. no choice but to launch a swarm of cruise missiles at Syrian military facilities.

column1: When Russian soldiers are killed
column2: he’ll try to shift blame to Vladimir Putin for stirring up trouble in the eastern Ukraine or the Baltics. He’ll note that dissent is limited to a few cranky websites and far-left groups
column3: all of which can be safely ignored since they’re not part of the mainstream. Russia will then counter-attack
column4: leading to … no one knows.

column1: While anything can go wrong with this scenario
column2: one thing is clear. The mood in Official Washington is the opposite of 2003 when all the “experts” agreed that an invasion of Iraq would be a walk in the park. Now they’re filled with trepidation. But they’re still trying to talk themselves into an escalation and may succeed. If the election goes as expected
column3: the Clinton II presidency will be an interesting one.

column1: Daniel Lazare is the author of several books including The Frozen Republic: How the Constitution Is Paralyzing Democracy (Harcourt Brace)."	FAKE
FACT CHECK: Hillary Clinton's Speech To The Democratic Convention, Annotated	"Editor's note: This has been updated at 1:25 p.m. ET Friday with additional fact-checking information.
Hillary Clinton accepted the Democratic nomination for president Thursday night
column2: delivering a speech that lays out her plan to address terrorist threats and create jobs.

column1: NPR's politics team annotated Clinton's speech below. Portions commented on are highlighted
column2: followed by analysis
column3: context and fact check in italics.

column1: Thank you. Thank you so much. Thank you. Thank you all so so much. Thank you. Thank you. Thank you all very
column2: very much. Thank you for that amazing welcome. Thank you all for the great convention that we've had.

column1: And Chelsea
column2: thank you.

column1: I'm so proud to be your mother and so proud of the woman you've become.
Thank you for bringing Marc into our family

column3: it is still going strong.

column1: You know

On Tuesday night

For all of you whose hard work brought us here tonight

We heard the man from Hope

And ... I want to thank Bernie Sanders.
Bernie
column2: Bernie
column3: your campaign inspired millions of Americans

column1: You've put economic and social justice issues front and center

column1: That is the only way we can turn our progressive platform into real change for America.
We wrote it together — now let's go out and make it happen together.
My friends

column1: We all know the story. But we usually focus on how it turned out — and not enough on how close that story came to never being written at all.
When representatives from 13 unruly colonies met just down the road from here
column2: some wanted to stick with the king. And some wanted to stick it to the king.

column1: The revolution hung in the balance.
Then somehow
column2: they began listening to each other

column4: finding common purpose.

column1: And by the time they left Philadelphia

column1: That's what made it possible to stand up to a king.
That took courage. They had courage.
Our Founders embraced the enduring truth that we are stronger together.
Now
column2: now America is once again at a moment of reckoning. Powerful forces are threatening to pull us apart. Bonds of trust and respect are fraying.

column1: And just as with our founders
column2: there are no guarantees. It truly is up to us. We have to decide whether we all will work together so we can all rise together.

column1: Our country's motto is ""e pluribus unum"": out of many

column1: Well
column2: we heard Donald Trump's answer last week at his convention. He wants to divide us from the rest of the world
column3: and from each other.

column1: He's betting that the perils of today's world will blind us to its unlimited promise. He's taken the Republican Party a long way from ""Morning in America"" to ""Midnight in America."" He wants us to fear the future and fear each other.
Well
column2: you know
column3: a great Democratic President Franklin Delano Roosevelt came up with the perfect rebuke to Trump more than 80 years ago
column4: during a much more perilous time: ""The only thing we have to fear is fear itself.""

column1: Now we are clear-eyed about what our country is up against. But we are not afraid. We will rise to the challenge
column2: just as we always have. We will not build a wall. Instead
column3: we will build an economy where everyone who wants a good job can get one.

column1: And we'll build a path to citizenship for millions of immigrants who are already contributing to our economy!
We
column2: we will not ban a religion. We will work with all Americans and our allies to fight and defeat terrorism.

column1: There's a lot of work to do.
Too many people haven't had a pay raise since the crash.
There's too much inequality. Too little social mobility. Too much paralysis in Washington. Too many threats at home and abroad.

But just look for a minute at the strengths we bring as Americans to meet these challenges. We have the most dynamic and diverse people in the world. We have the most tolerant and generous young people we've ever had. We have the most powerful military. The most innovative entrepreneurs. The most enduring values: freedom and equality
column2: justice and opportunity.

column1: We should be so proud that those words are associated with us. I have to tell you
column2: as your secretary of state
column3: I went to 112 countries. When people hear those words
column4: they hear America.

column1: So don't let anyone tell you that our country is weak. We're not.
Don't let anyone tell you we don't have what it takes. We do.
And most of all
column2: don't believe anyone who says
column3: ""I alone can fix it.""

column1: Yes
column2: those were actually Donald Trump's words in Cleveland. And they should set off alarm bells for all of us.

column1: Really? I alone can fix it? Isn't he forgetting?

Troops on the front lines. Police officers and firefighters who run toward danger. Doctors and nurses who care for us. Teachers who change lives. Entrepreneurs who see possibilities in every problem. Mothers who lost children to violence and are building a movement to keep other kids safe.
He's forgetting every last one of us.
Americans don't say
column2: ""I alone can fix it."" We say
column3: ""We'll fix it together.""

column1: And remember
column2: remember: Our Founders fought a revolution and wrote a Constitution so America would never be a nation where one person had all the power. Two-hundred-and-forty years later
column3: we still put our faith in each other.

column1: Look at what happened in Dallas after the assassinations of five brave police officers. Police Chief David Brown asked the community to support his force
column2: maybe even join them.

column1: And you know how the community responded? Nearly 500 people applied in just 12 days.
That's how Americans answer when the call for help goes out.
Twenty years ago
column2: I wrote a book called It Takes a Village. And a lot of people looked at the title and asked
column3: ""What the heck do you mean by that?""

column1: This is what I mean. None of us can raise a family
column2: build a business
column3: heal a community or lift a country totally alone.

column1: America needs every one of us to lend our energy
column2: our talents
column3: our ambition to making our nation better and stronger. I believe that with all my heart.

column1: That's why ""Stronger Together"" is not just a lesson from our history. It's not just a slogan for our campaign.
It's a guiding principle for the country we've always been and the future we're going to build.
A country where the economy works for everyone
column2: not just those at the top. Where you can get a good job and send your kids to a good school
column3: no matter what zip code you live in.

column1: A country where all our children can dream
column2: and those dreams are within reach. Where families are strong
column3: communities are safe
column4: and yes
column5: where love trumps hate.

column1: That's the country we're fighting for. That's the future we're working toward. And so
column2: my friends
column3: it is with humility
column4: determination and boundless confidence in America's promise that I accept your nomination for president of the United States!

column1: Now
column2: sometimes
column3: sometimes the people at this podium are new to the national stage.

column1: As you know
column2: I'm not one of those people.

column1: I've been your First Lady

column1: Then I represented all of you as secretary of state.
But my job titles only tell you what I've done.
They don't tell you why.
The truth is
column2: through all these years of public service

column1: I get it that some people just don't know what to make of me. So let me tell you.
The family I'm from
column2: well
column3: no one had their name on big buildings. My family were builders of a different kind. Builders in the way most American families are.

column1: They used whatever tools they had — whatever God gave them — and whatever life in America provided — and built better lives and better futures for their kids.
My grandfather worked in the same Scranton lace mill for 50 years. Because he believed that if he gave everything he had
column2: his children would have a better life than he did. And he was right.

column1: My dad
column2: Hugh
column3: made it to college. He played football at Penn State and enlisted in the Navy after Pearl Harbor.

column1: When the war was over
column2: he started his own small business
column3: printing fabric for draperies. I remember watching him stand for hours over silk screens.

column1: He wanted to give my brothers and me opportunities he never had. And he did.
My mother
column2: Dorothy
column3: was abandoned by her parents as a young girl. She

column1: ended up on her own at 14
column2: working as a housemaid. She was saved by the kindness of others.

column1: Her first-grade teacher saw she had nothing to eat at lunch and brought extra food to share the entire year. The lesson she passed on to me
column2: years later
column3: stuck with me: No one gets through life alone. We have to look out for each other and lift each other up.

column1: And she made sure I learned the words from our Methodist faith: ""Do all the good you can
column2: for all the people you can
column3: in all the ways you can
column4: as long as ever you can.""

column1: So
column2: I went to work for the Children's Defense Fund
column3: going door-to-door in New Bedford
column4: Mass.
column5: on behalf of children with disabilities who were denied the chance to go to school.

column1: I remember meeting a young girl in a wheelchair on the small back porch of her house. She told me how badly she wanted to go to school — it just didn't seem possible in those days. And I couldn't stop thinking of my mother and what she'd gone through as a child.
It became clear to me that simply caring is not enough. To drive real progress
column2: you have to change both hearts and laws. You need both understanding and action.

column1: So we gathered facts. We built a coalition. And our work helped convince Congress to ensure access to education for all students with disabilities.
It's a big idea
column2: isn't it? Every kid with a disability has the right to go to school.

column1: But how
column2: how do you make an idea like that real? You do it step-by-step
column3: year-by-year
column4: sometimes even door-by-door.

column1: My heart just swelled when I saw Anastasia Somoza representing millions of young people on this stage — because we changed our law to make sure she got an education.
So it's true. I sweat the details of policy — whether we're talking about the exact level of lead in the drinking water in Flint
column2: Mich.
column3: the number of mental health facilities in Iowa
column4: or the cost of your prescription drugs.

column1: Because it's not just a detail if it's your kid — if it's your family. It's a big deal. And it should be a big deal to your president
column2: too.

column1: After the four days of this convention

Lauren Manning

column1: Tonight
column2: tonight we've reached a milestone in our nation's march toward a more perfect union: the first time that a major party has nominated a woman for president.

column1: Standing here
column2: standing here as my mother's daughter
column3: and my daughter's mother
column4: I'm so happy this day has come.

column1: I'm happy for grandmothers and little girls and everyone in between.

column2: too — because when any barrier falls in America

column4: when there are no ceilings
column5: the sky's the limit.

column1: So let's keep going
column2: let's keep going until every one of the 161 million women and girls across America has the opportunity she deserves to have.

column1: But even more important than the history we make tonight

column1: Let's begin with what we're going to do to help working people in our country get ahead and stay ahead.
Now
column2: I don't think President Obama and Vice President Biden get the credit they deserve for saving us from the worst economic crisis of our lifetimes.

column1: Our economy is so much stronger than when they took office. Nearly 15 million new private-sector jobs. Twenty million more Americans with health insurance. And an auto industry that just had its best year ever.
Now that's real progress
column2: but none of us can be satisfied with the status quo. Not by a long shot.

column1: We're still facing deep-seated problems that developed long before the recession and have stayed with us through the recovery.
I've gone around our country talking to working families. And I've heard from many who feel like the economy sure isn't working for them.
Some of you are frustrated — even furious. And you know what? You're right. It's not yet working the way it should.
Americans are willing to work — and work hard. But right now

column1: Democrats
column2: we are the party of working people. But we haven't done a good enough job showing we get what you're going through
column3: and we're going to do something to help.

column1: So tonight I want to tell you tonight how we will empower Americans to live better lives.
My primary mission as president will be to create more opportunity and more good jobs with rising wages right here in the United States. From my first day in office to my last
column2: especially in places that for too long have been left out and left behind.

column1: From our inner cities to our small towns
column2: from Indian Country to Coal Country. From communities ravaged by addiction to regions hollowed out by plant closures.

column1: And here's what I believe. I believe America thrives when the middle class thrives. I believe that our economy isn't working the way it should because our democracy isn't working the way it should.
That's why we need to appoint Supreme Court justices who will get money out of politics and expand voting rights

column1: And if necessary
column2: we will pass a constitutional amendment to overturn Citizens United.

column1: I believe American corporations that have gotten so much from our country should be just as patriotic in return. Many of them are. But too many aren't. It's wrong to take tax breaks with one hand and give out pink slips with the other.
And I believe Wall Street can never

column1: And I believe in science. I believe climate change is real and that we can save our planet while creating millions of good-paying clean energy jobs.

So
column2: whatever party you belong to

column4: if you share these beliefs

column1: If you believe that every man

column1: If you believe that we should say ""no"" to unfair trade deals

column2: then join us.

column1: And yes
column2: yes

column1: Now
column2: you didn't hear any of this
column3: did you
column4: from Donald Trump at his convention. He spoke for 70-odd minutes — and I do mean odd.

But we already know he doesn't believe these things. No wonder he doesn't like talking about his plans. You might have noticed

column4: clean energy

Bernie Sanders and I will work together to make college tuition-free for the middle class and debt-free for all!
We will also
column2: we will also liberate millions of people who already have student debt.

column1: It's just not right that Donald Trump can ignore his debts
column2: and students and families can't refinance their debts.

column1: And something we don't say often enough: Sure

In America
column2: if you can dream it
column3: you should be able to build it.

column1: And we will help you balance family and work. And you know what

column2: corporations
column3: and the super-rich are going to start paying their fair share of taxes.

column2: now I imagine some of you are sitting at home thinking

column2: but Trump

column2: let's take a closer look.

column1: In Atlantic City

column1: Now
column2: remember what the president said last night: ""Don't boo

column1: And you know that sales pitch he's making to be president? Put your faith in him — and you'll win big? That's the same sales pitch he made to all those small businesses. Then Trump walked away

column4: not Michigan. Trump furniture in Turkey

column1: Now
column2: the choice we face in this election is just as stark when it comes to our national security.

column2: anyone
column3: anyone reading the news can see the threats and turbulence we face.

column1: From Baghdad to Kabul
column2: to Nice and Paris and Brussels
column3: from San Bernardino to Orlando

column1: I'm proud that we put a lid on Iran's nuclear program without firing a single shot — now we have to enforce it. And we must keep supporting Israel's security.
I'm proud that we shaped a global climate agreement — now we have to hold every country accountable to their commitments
column2: including ourselves.

column1: I've laid out my strategy for defeating ISIS. We will strike their sanctuaries from the air

column1: We will disrupt their efforts online to reach and radicalize young people in our country.
It won't be easy or quick

column1: Now Donald Trump
column2: Donald Trump says
column3: and this is a quote
column4: ""I know more about ISIS than the generals do."" No
column5: Donald
column6: you don't.

column3: including as a senator on the Armed Services Committee

column1: We entrust our commander in chief to make the hardest decisions our nation faces
column2: decisions about war and peace
column3: life and death.

column1: So just ask yourself: Do you really think Donald Trump has the temperament to be commander in chief?

Donald Trump can't even handle the rough-and-tumble of a presidential campaign. He loses his cool at the slightest provocation. When he's gotten a tough question from a reporter. When he's challenged in a debate. When he sees a protester at a rally.
Imagine
column2: if you dare
column3: imagine
column4: imagine him in the Oval Office facing a real crisis. A man you can bait with a tweet is not a man we can trust with nuclear weapons.

column1: I can't put it

column3: not by big men with self-control and restraint

column1: America's strength doesn't come from lashing out. It relies on smarts
column2: judgment
column3: cool resolve
column4: and the precise and strategic application of power. And that's the kind of commander in chief I pledge to be.

column1: And if we're serious about keeping our country safe
column2: we also can't afford to have a president who's in the pocket of the gun lobby.

column1: I'm not here to repeal the Second Amendment. I'm not here to take away your guns. I just don't want you to be shot by someone who shouldn't have a gun in the first place.
We will work tirelessly with responsible gun owners to pass common-sense reforms and keep guns out of the hands of criminals
column2: terrorists and all others who would do us harm.

column1: You know
column2: for decades
column3: people have said this issue was too hard to solve and the politics too hot to touch. But I ask you: How can we just stand by and do nothing?

column1: You heard
column2: you saw
column3: family members of people killed by gun violence on this stage.

column1: You heard
column2: you saw
column3: family members of police officers killed in the line of duty because they were outgunned by criminals.

column1: I refuse to believe we can't find common ground here.
We have to heal the divides in our country. Not just on guns. But on race. Immigration. And more.
And that starts with listening
column2: listening to each other. Trying
column3: as best we can
column4: to walk in each other's shoes.

column1: So let's put ourselves in the shoes of young black and Latino men and women who face the effects of systemic racism
column2: and are made to feel like their lives are disposable.

column1: Let's put ourselves in the shoes of police officers
column2: kissing their kids and spouses goodbye every day
column3: heading off to do a dangerous and necessary job.

column1: We will reform our criminal justice system from end to end and rebuild trust between law enforcement and the communities they serve.
And we will defend
column2: we will defend all our rights — civil rights
column3: human rights and voting rights
column4: women's rights and workers' rights
column5: LGBT rights and the rights of people with disabilities!

column1: And we will stand up against mean and divisive rhetoric wherever it comes from.
You know
column2: for the past year
column3: many people made the mistake of laughing off Donald Trump's comments — excusing him as an entertainer just putting on a show.

column1: They thought he couldn't possibly mean all the horrible things he says — like when he called women ""pigs."" Or said that an American judge couldn't be fair because of his Mexican heritage.
Or when he mocks and mimics a reporter with a disability. Or insults prisoners of war like John McCain — a true hero and patriot who deserves our respect.
Now
column2: at first
column3: at first
column4: I admit
column5: I couldn't believe he meant it either. It was just too hard to fathom — that someone who wants to lead our nation could say those things. Could be like that.

column1: But here's the sad truth: There is no other Donald Trump. This is it.
And in the end
column2: it comes down to what Donald Trump doesn't get: that America is great — because America is good.

column1: So enough with the bigotry and bombast. Donald Trump's not offering real change.
He's offering empty promises. And what are we offering? A bold agenda to improve the lives of people across our country — to keep you safe
column2: to get you good jobs
column3: and to give your kids the opportunities they deserve.

column1: The choice is clear
column2: my friends.

column1: Every generation of Americans has come together to make our country freer
column2: fairer and stronger.

column1: None of us ever have or can do it alone.
I know that at a time when so much seems to be pulling us apart
column2: it can be hard to imagine how we'll ever pull together.

column1: But I'm here to tell you tonight — progress is possible.
I know
column2: I know because I've seen it in the lives of people across America who get knocked down and get right back up.

column1: And I know it
column2: I know it from my own life. More than a few times
column3: I've had to pick myself up and get back in the game.

column1: Like so much else in my life
column2: I got this from my mother too. She never let me back down from any challenge. When I tried to hide from a neighborhood bully
column3: she literally blocked the door. ""Go back out there
column4: she said.

column1: And she was right. You have to stand up to bullies.
You have to keep working to make things better
column2: even when the odds are long and the opposition is fierce.

column1: We lost our mother a few years ago
column2: but I miss her every day. And I still hear her voice urging me to keep working
column3: keep fighting for right
column4: no matter what.

column1: That's what we need to do together as a nation.
Though ""we may not live to see the glory
column2: as the song from the musical Hamilton goes
column3: ""let us gladly join the fight.""

column1: Let our legacy be about ""planting seeds in a garden you never get to see.""
That's why we're here ... not just in this hall
column2: but on this Earth.

column1: The Founders showed us that. And so have many others since.
They were drawn together by love of country
column2: and the selfless passion to build something better for all who follow.

column1: That is the story of America. And we begin a new chapter tonight.
Yes
column2: the world is watching what we do.

column1: Yes
column2: America's destiny is ours to choose.

column1: So let's be stronger together
column2: my fellow Americans.

column1: Let's look to the future with courage and confidence.
Let's build a better tomorrow for our beloved children and our beloved country.
And when we do
column2: America will be greater than ever.

column1: Thank you
column2: and may God bless you and the United States of America!"	REAL

column1: Connecticut Becomes First State To Boycott Indiana Over LGBT Discrimination Law	"WASHINGTON -- Connecticut Gov. Dan Malloy (D) will sign an executive order on Monday barring state-funded travel to Indiana because of the state's new law that could allow businesses to turn away gay and lesbian customers for religious reasons.
Malloy's move would make Connecticut the first state to boycott Indiana over its Religious Freedom Restoration Act
column2: which Gov. Mike Pence (R) quietly signed into law last week. The law allows businesses in the state to cite religious beliefs as a legal defense. Opponents fear it offers legal protection for businesses to refuse service to lesbian
column3: gay
column4: bisexual and transgender people.

column1: Two cities
column2: San Francisco and Seattle
column3: have imposed similar bans in response to the law. Businesses have also retaliated. Angie's List is pulling a campus expansion project in Indianapolis
column4: and the CEO of Salesforce
column5: a $4 billion software corporation
column6: announced plans to ""dramatically reduce our investment"" in the state because of the law.

column1: Twenty states have RFRA laws
column2: but Indiana's law is substantially different. While other state RFRAs apply to disputes between a person and a government
column3: Indiana's law goes further and applies to disputes between private citizens. That means
column4: for example
column5: a business owner could use the law to justify discrimination against customers who might otherwise be protected under law.

column1: The Indiana law could result in ""employers
column2: landlords
column3: small business owners
column4: or corporations
column5: taking the law into their own hands and acting in ways that violate generally applicable laws on the grounds that they have a religious justification for doing so

column7: their landlord's
column8: their local shopkeeper's
column9: or a police officer's private religious beliefs.""

column1: That's in sharp contrast to states like Connecticut
column2: which has an RFRA but one that pertains only to religious institutions
column3: not private establishments. And unlike some other states
column4: Connecticut also doesn't permit discrimination based on sexual orientation in any private establishment or institution.

column1: Before signing the order
column2: he called the Indiana law ""disturbing and outright discriminatory
column3: and said the National Collegiate Athletic Association should relocate its Final Four tournament from Indiana to another state. Those games are set to begin later this week.

column1: I think that would be a wise choice for them to do if that's possible

column3: or an outright repeal
column4: before deciding whether to keep holding sporting events in the state.

column1: Malloy said his executive order allows for any of the state's current contractual obligations with Indiana to play out
column2: but said he doesn't plan to enter into any new ones.

The landmark deal does not include provisions against missile launches and when it came into effect on Jan. 16
