Why Joe Biden can't get no respect	"On Monday
column2: I made the case that Al Gore should run for president. But there's another obvious contender out there
column3: too: Joe Biden.

column1: Over at Yahoo
column2: Matt Bai makes the case for Biden. ""Biden
column3: he writes
column4: ""is a better candidate than most pundits have ever given him credit for. Yeah
column5: he's sloppy and meandering and says some nutty stuff. But that's all part of being genuine and three-dimensional
column6: which may be the most valuable trait in modern politics and not a bad contrast to Clinton's robotic discipline.""

column1: And Biden's certainly got the resume. When President Barack Obama wanted to make sure stimulus money didn't disappear to fraud
column2: he turned to Biden — ""nobody messes with Joe
column3: he said — and Biden succeeded. When the White House wanted to avoid the fiscal cliff
column4: it was Biden who closed the deal with Minority Leader Mitch McConnell. When Obama flubbed the first debate against Mitt Romney
column5: it was Biden who restored the ticket's mojo by bullying his way past Rep. Paul Ryan. When the Democrats held their 2012 convention
column6: it was Biden's speech that pulled the highest ratings — beating both Bill Clinton and Obama.

column1: Biden's most off-the-reservation moment
column2: meanwhile
column3: is the kind of thing that should help him in 2016. He pushed the Obama administration to embrace gay marriage before it was quite ready. At the time
column4: it looked like a gaffe. Now it looks prescient.

column1: And yet
column2: according to a recent Marist poll
column3: Biden is running 47 points behind Hillary Clinton for the Democratic nomination in 2016 — and only one point ahead of Sen. Elizabeth Warren. A quick scan of RealClearPolitics' round-up of Democratic primary polls shows that's no outlier.

column1: It's not like Biden has been out of the public eye for the last seven years. So why
column2: if he's such a good politician
column3: doesn't he command more support in the Democratic Party?

column1: Here's my guess: there's a cultural gap between Biden and the party he seeks to represent. Biden is an old-school
column2: white
column3: male politician in a party that's increasingly young
column4: multicultural
column5: and female. Biden's gaffes matter because they tend to reinforce the perception among Democrats that he belongs to a different era.

column1: When Biden calls shady lenders ""Shylocks
column2: or says Obama is ""the first mainstream African-American who is articulate and bright and clean and a nice-looking guy
column3: he ends up coming off as
column4: in New York Magazine words
column5: ""your accidentally racist grandma."" That leaves Biden facing something more toxic than opposition: condescension.

column1: What I wrote of Biden in January 2013 is still true today
column2: I think. ""In the continuing drama that is the Obama presidency
column3: Biden often appears as comic relief. He's the zany neighbor
column4: the adorable uncle. As a result
column5: his presidential ambitions
column6: which burn brightly even today
column7: have mostly been laughed off. Somehow
column8: the sitting vice president of the United States
column9: the former chairman of both the Senate Foreign Relations Committee and the Senate Judiciary Committee
column10: a man who's on a nickname basis with many of the world's most powerful leaders
column11: is seen in many quarters as lacking the gravitas to be president.""

column1: There is much that's weird about this. Hillary Clinton is a powerful candidate
column2: but there's nothing about the last few months that makes her look invulnerable. She's shown real rust in interviews
column3: pissed off liberals
column4: and found herself in an email scandal.

column1: But while Biden isn't much older than Clinton
column2: she's somehow been more adept at signaling cultural affinity with young Democrats than he's been (though she's occasionally struggled too
column3: most notably in her interview with Terry Gross on gay marriage). She also has a connection to female voters he can't touch. Even her memes are better.

column1: I don't know exactly how Biden fixes this or even if he can. Clinton isn't inevitable
column2: and Biden should
column3: by all rights
column4: pose a real threat to her. But
column5: though Biden's always been known as a great speaker
column6: he needs to learn to talk to a different party than the one he grew up in."	REAL

column1: Come on, Paul Ryan must be running in 2016, right? Right?	"The Washington game now requires that any unindicted politician with a bit of ambition — even 75-year-old Jerry Brown — let it be known that he is thinking about maybe
column2: just possibly running for president.

column1: But here’s the flip side: the media culture now demands to know whether these pols are quietly plotting a White House bid — and treats it as sort of strange if the answer is no.
What do you mean you’re not feverishly plotting a presidential bid three years before the next election? Is there something wrong with you?
I guess we don’t like to take no for an answer.
Take Paul Ryan. A natural leader of the conservative movement. The Republican VP nominee last year. A man who can translate Beltway jargon into Main Street concerns.

The Wisconsin congressman is in the spotlight because he just hammered out a budget agreement with Patty Murray that passed the Senate yesterday with 64 votes—three fewer than supported a cloture vote—after winning bipartisan approval in the House. The modest deal is noteworthy mainly because it temporarily ends the Washington gridlock and threats of shutdown and default. But it also brought sniping from more militant conservatives who see Ryan as selling out to the Democrats.
The dustup triggered a spate of Whither Paul Ryan pieces in the press.  Is he running? Is he not running? It’s 2013 already — we have to know!
“In interviews The Hill conducted with more than two dozen House Republicans from across the ideological spectrum over the last couple of weeks
column2: many of Ryan’s colleagues said they are doubtful he will run for president in 2016. Most believe that concerns for his young family will lead him to lay claim to the job he’s always wanted: chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee.”

column1: Ryan wants to be a Hill poohbah and not move into the White House.
“Ryan on Tuesday told The Wall Street Journal that he plans to lead the Ways and Means Committee in the next Congress. Ryan and his wife Janna have three children
column2: and his friends say that his concern about the hardship of an 18-month presidential campaign is a genuine factor in his consideration.”

column1: This is the human factor that journalists rarely pause to consider. Running for president is a meat grinder that chews people up
column2: and Ryan got a taste of that as Mitt Romney’s running mate.

column1: I don’t know whether Ryan  is being coy
column2: or whether
column3: with the highest positive rating among Iowa Republicans
column4: he’ll change his mind and jump into the race. But I do think the press ought to take him at his word until there’s evidence to the contrary.

column1: I guess it wasn’t a big story when John Podesta compared the Republicans to a suicide cult.
But now that Podesta is joining President Obama’s inner circle
column2: Politico is asking: “Can John Podesta Save Him?” (Boy
column3: that’s a tall order.)

column1: In its profile of Podesta
column2: who is stepping down as head of the Center for American Progress
column3: this incendiary quote was slipped into the narrative without comment.

column1: White House officials
column2: said Podesta
column3: “need to focus on executive action given that they are facing a second term against a cult worthy of Jonestown in charge of one of the houses of Congress.”

column1: Podesta was comparing John Boehner to Jim Jones
column2: who led his followers to kill themselves? Didn’t that set off any alarm bells?

column1: But the quote caused a stir now that the former Bill Clinton chief of staff is joining the White House
column2: and he tweeted an apology: “In an old interview
column3: my snark got in front of my judgment. I apologize to Speaker Boehner
column4: whom I have always respected.”

Why Bernie Sanders needs to start winning big states — big	"Six days ago
column2: Bernie Sanders pulled off one of the great upsets in modern politics — surging from more than 20 points behind in the polls to edge out Hillary Clinton and win Michigan’s Democratic presidential primary.

column1: It was remarkable! It was historic! And it netted him four more delegates than Clinton in the state. Meanwhile
column2: in Mississippi
column3: Clinton won with more than 80 percent of the vote — and gained 28 more delegates than Sanders.

column1: On the best night of the Sanders campaign to date
column2: he fell 24 more delegates behind Clinton in the race for the Democratic nomination.

column1: That increasingly challenging math is what Sanders must confront Tuesday as voters in several large states — including Florida
column2: Illinois and Ohio — go to the polls.

column1: [Clinton leads Sanders by more than 2 to 1 in Florida
column2: Post-Univision poll finds]

column1: As of today
column2: Clinton has 1
column3: 231 delegates to Sanders’s 576 — a lead of 655. That means that Clinton has 51.7 percent of the 2
column4: 383 delegates she needs to become the Democratic Party’s nominee.

column1: Subtract superdelegates — Clinton is dominating even among this group of elected officials and party luminaries — and she has 766 delegates to Sanders’s 551
column2: a margin of 215. (Worth noting: That is a wider lead than the margin by which Clinton ever trailed then-Sen. Barack Obama in the long slog of the 2008 primary race.)

column1: That lead may not seem momentous. After all
column2: almost 3
column3: 000 delegates are yet to be allocated in the primaries and caucuses to come. The problem for Sanders is that Democrats allocate their delegates proportionally in every state — meaning that between now and when the process ends June 7
column4: there is no state where Clinton will be shut out.

column1: Winning
column2: then
column3: is not enough for Sanders. He has to win by a lot to make up any real ground.

column1: Clinton has already done that. Take
column2: for example
column3: Alabama. She won there March 1 by 59 points and gained 38 more delegates than Sanders. Or Georgia on that same day
column4: beating Sanders by 43 points and netting 55 delegates. Or the aforementioned Mississippi
column5: where Clinton’s 66-point win translated to a net gain of 28 delegates.

column1: [Southern states help Clinton extend her lead over Sanders]
Sanders’s one big win came in New Hampshire’s primary. But his 22-point margin translated to a net delegate gain of zero because six superdelegates pledged to Clinton
column2: bringing her delegate gain up to match his. Similarly
column3: in the Colorado caucuses
column4: Sanders won by 19 points but the superdelegate math meant the candidates each took 38 delegates.

column1: Look at the next set of big contests
column2: to be held Tuesday. Four states have more than 100 delegates to give out: Florida (246)
column3: Illinois (182)
column4: Ohio (160) and North Carolina (121).

column1: Polling released Sunday morning suggests that Sanders has a big hill to climb. Clinton leads the senator 61 percent to 34 percent in Florida and has an edge of 58 percent to 38 percent in Ohio
column2: according to NBC- Marist surveys. The race in Illinois
column3: according to NBC-Marist
column4: is closer
column5: with Clinton at 51 percent and Sanders at 45 percent.

column1: But wait
column2: you say. Polling in Michigan had Sanders down 20 points and he won there. So this polling could be wrong
column3: too.

column1: Sure. It could. The problem for Sanders is this: Let’s say each of the NBC-Marist surveys is off by 20 points in Clinton’s favor. (Note that this is a thought experiment. I very much doubt a credible pollster such as this one would be off by even close to that amount.) That would mean Sanders loses Florida by single digits
column2: essentially ties Clinton in Ohio and wins Illinois by 15 points. The delegate allocation from that trio of results? It would almost certainly favor Clinton.

column1: Sanders is in a position where winning states is not close to enough if he wants to be the party’s nominee. He needs to start winning big states by big margins. As in winning Illinois or Florida by 30 or 40 points.
That seems very unlikely either Tuesday or beyond. If past votes are any guide
column2: it will be a tough road for Sanders. There have been seven election nights in the race so far; Clinton has netted delegates in six of them
column3: while the two candidates fought to a draw in the seventh (New Hampshire).

column1: None of this means that Sanders can’t — and won’t — keep running. Winning states matters in terms of perception and keeps the wolves from his door. But winning states and emboldening your supporters aren’t the same as taking concrete steps to reduce or eliminate Clinton’s delegate lead.
That looks to be a near-impossible task for Sanders unless the numbers in the states to come start changing quickly."	REAL

Leaked: What’s in Obama’s trade deal	"A recent draft of the Trans-Pacific Partnership free-trade deal would give U.S. pharmaceutical firms unprecedented protections against competition from cheaper generic drugs
column2: possibly transcending the patent protections in U.S. law.

column1: POLITICO has obtained a draft copy of TPP’s intellectual property chapter as it stood on May 11
column2: at the start of the latest negotiating round in Guam. While U.S. trade officials would not confirm the authenticity of the document
column3: they downplayed its importance
column4: emphasizing that the terms of the deal are likely to change significantly as the talks enter their final stages. Those terms are still secret
column5: but the public will get to see them once the twelve TPP nations reach a final agreement and President Obama seeks congressional approval.

column1: Still
column2: the draft chapter will provide ammunition for critics who have warned that TPP’s protections for pharmaceutical companies could dump trillions of dollars of additional health care costs on patients
column3: businesses and governments around the Pacific Rim. The highly technical 90-page document
column4: cluttered with objections from other TPP nations
column5: shows that U.S. negotiators have fought aggressively and
column6: at least until Guam
column7: successfully on behalf of Big Pharma.

column1: The draft text includes provisions that could make it extremely tough for generics to challenge brand-name pharmaceuticals abroad. Those provisions could also help block copycats from selling cheaper versions of the expensive cutting-edge drugs known as “biologics” inside the U.S.
column2: restricting treatment for American patients while jacking up Medicare and Medicaid costs for American taxpayers.

column1: “There’s very little distance between what Pharma wants and what the U.S. is demanding
column2: ” said Rohit Malpini
column3: director of policy for Doctors Without Borders.

column1: Throughout the TPP talks
column2: the Obama administration has pledged to balance the goals of fostering innovation in the drug industry
column3: which means allowing higher profits
column4: and promoting wider access to valuable medicines
column5: which means keeping prices down. U.S. Trade Representative Michael Froman has pointed out that pharmaceutical companies often have to invest hundreds of millions of dollars to get a new drug to market
column6: which they would have little incentive to do without strong protections for the patented product. But Froman has also recognized the value of allowing much cheaper generic drugs to enter the market after those brand-name patents expire. In the U.S.
column7: generics now comprise more than five-sixths of all prescription drugs
column8: but only about one-quarter of drug costs.

column1: Advocates for the global poor
column2: senior citizens
column3: labor unions and consumers as well as the generics industry have accused the administration of abandoning that balance
column4: pushing a pharmaceutical-company agenda at the expense of patients and taxpayers. One critic
column5: hoping to illustrate the point and rally opposition to TPP in Congress
column6: gave POLITICO the draft chapter
column7: which was labeled “This Document Contains TPP CONFIDENTIAL Information” on every page.

column1: U.S. officials said the key point to remember about trade deals is that no provision is ever final until the entire deal is final—and that major compromises tend to happen at the very end of the negotiations. They expect the real horse-trading to begin now that Obama has signed “fast-track” legislation requiring Congress to pass or reject TPP without amendments.
“The negotiations on intellectual property are complex and continually evolving
column2: ” said Trevor Kincaid
column3: a spokesman for Froman. “On pharmaceutical products
column4: we are working closely with stakeholders
column5: Congress
column6: and partner countries to develop an approach that aims to make affordable life-saving medicine more widely available while creating incentives for the development of new treatments and cures. Striking this important balance is at the heart of our work.”

column1: The draft chapter covers software
column2: music and other intellectual property issues as well
column3: but its most controversial language involves the rights of drug companies. The text reveals disputes between the U.S. (often with support from Japan) and its TPP partners over a variety of issues—what patents can cover
column4: when and how long they can be extended
column5: how long pharmaceutical companies can keep their clinical data private
column6: and much more. On every issue
column7: the U.S. sided with drug companies in favor of stricter intellectual property protections.

column1: Some of the most contentious provisions involve “patent linkage
column2: ” which would prevent regulators in TPP nations from approving generic drugs whenever there are any unresolved patent issues. The TPP draft would make this linkage mandatory
column3: which could help drug companies fend off generics just by claiming an infringement. The Obama administration often describes TPP as the most progressive free-trade deal in history
column4: citing its compliance with the tough labor and environment protections enshrined in the so-called “May 10 Agreement” of 2007
column5: which set a framework for several trade deals at the time. But mandatory linkage seems to be a departure from the May 10 pharmaceutical provisions.

column1: In an April 15 letter to Froman
column2: Heather Bresch
column3: the CEO of the generic drug company Mylan
column4: warned that mandatory patent linkage would be “a recipe for indefinite evergreening of pharmaceutical monopolies
column5: ” leading to the automatic rejection of generic applications. The U.S. already has mandatory linkage
column6: but most other TPP countries do not
column7: and Bresch argued that U.S. law includes a number of safeguards and incentives for generic companies that have not made it into TPP.

column1: “With all due respect
column2: the USTR has…cherry-picked the single provision designed to block generic entry to the market
column3: ” Bresch wrote.

column1: Generics are thriving in the U.S. despite linkage
column2: saving Americans an estimated $239 billion on drugs in 2013. But the U.S. is the world’s largest market
column3: and advocates fear that generic manufacturers may not take on the risk and expense of litigation in smaller markets if TPP tilts the playing field against them. One generics manufacturer
column4: Hospira
column5: reportedly testified at a TPP forum in Melbourne
column6: Australia
column7: that it would not launch generics outside the U.S. in markets with linkage.

column1: The opponents are also worried about the treaty’s effect on the U.S. market
column2: because its draft language would extend mandatory patent linkage to biologics
column3: the next big thing in the pharmaceutical world. Biologics can cost hundreds of thousands of dollars a year for patients with illnesses like rheumatoid arthritis
column4: hepatitis B and cancer
column5: and the first knockoffs have not yet reached pharmacies. The critics say that extending linkage to biologics—which can have hundreds of patents—would help insulate them from competition forever.

column1: “It would be a dramatic departure from U.S. law
column2: and it would put a real crimp in the ability of less expensive drugs to get to market
column3: ” said K.J. Hertz
column4: a lobbyist for AARP. “People are going to look at this very closely in Congress.”

column1: Drug companies are already pushing for TPP to guarantee them 12 years of exclusivity for their data regarding biologics
column2: although the draft text suggests the other TPP nations have not agreed. Jay Taylor
column3: vice president of the Pharmaceutical Research and Manufacturers of America
column4: said it’s crucial for TPP to protect the intellectual property that emerges from years of expensive research
column5: so that drug companies can continue to develop new medicines for patients around the world.

column1: “These innovations could be severely hindered if IP protections are scaled back
column2: ” Taylor said. “This is especially important in the area of biologic medicines
column3: which could hold the key to unlocking treatments for diseases that have thwarted researchers for years.”

column1: U.S. officials would not discuss the status of the TPP talks. But they suggested the May 10 Agreement did include a milder form of linkage
column2: although it didn’t prevent regulators from approving generics mired in patent disputes.  They also believe a 2009 U.S. law included a form of linkage for biologics
column3: although again
column4: that law's dispute resolution process for patent issues was not as prescriptive as the TPP draft. And they cautioned that any pre-Guam draft would not reflect recent negotiations over “transition periods” that would delay the stricter patent standards in developing countries like Vietnam.

column1: In any case
column2: Kincaid said U.S. negotiators are determined to strike a balance between innovation and access in the final product.

column1: “While this is our touchstone
column2: the negotiations are still very much in process
column3: and the details of a final outcome cannot yet be forecasted
column4: ” he said.

column1: But Malpani of Doctors Without Borders said U.S. negotiators have basically functioned as drug lobbyists. The TPP countries have 40 percent of global economic output
column2: and the deal is widely seen as establishing new benchmarks for some of the most complex areas of global business. Malpani fears it could set a precedent that crushes the generic drug industry under a mountain of regulation and litigation.

column1: “We consider this the worst-ever agreement in terms of access to medicine
column2: ” he said. “It would create higher drug prices around the world—and in the U.S.
column3: too.

column1: John Bel Edwards

column1: The man elected to the most powerful office in the land has no idea what to do with it and no concept of its limitations. He attracts the worst people to him
column2: sycophants and power-hungry strivers who will be placed in positions of authority and who will obey the boss’ diktat above anything else. Every democratic norm he gleefully shredded along the way is gone for good. Every thumb in the eye of transparency will now be official policy.

column1: But right now those things are not what I think about when I contemplate life under President Donald Trump. This will sound trite
column2: but primarily I think about my two boys
column3: a 2-year-old and a 4-month-old. I don’t have to explain this to them because neither would understand. But if I were to tell my 2-year-old what is happening
column4: I’d do it in Spanish because both he and his brother have deep Mexican roots that my wife and I want them to embrace and be proud of. It destroys me to know that they
column5: that we live in a country that seems to have chosen as its leader a person who made frenzied racial attacks on my family’s heritage the launch pad for his successful presidential run. I think about the African-Americans
column6: Muslims
column7: Jews
column8: and Latinos in this country who now face life in a country presided over by a candidate who embodies white nationalism and memorably couldn’t bring himself to disavow a former leader of the Ku Klux Klan. Children of undocumented immigrants who are U.S. citizens by birth have been told by their new president that they’ll be deported. Refugees from Syria who were relocated here to escape war and violence will have another target on their backs. These are the people who will feel the consequences of this failure most acutely. I have one more thing to add: I am sorry. In my capacity as a media figure
column9: I too often treated Trump as a joke
column10: a bumbling incompetent
column11: someone who obviously could not be treated seriously as a legitimate candidate for the presidency. Now I can only think that I was too hidebound by conventional wisdom
column12: too comfortably out of touch to see what was in front of me. I succumbed to the sideshow element of this awful race more times than I can be comfortable with. I own this failure
column13: too."	REAL

column1: Chris Christie losing home-state donors as Jeb Bush makes inroads	"New Jersey Gov. Chris Christie is rapidly losing support among some of his most prominent home-state donors and power brokers
column2: who are either hesitant to back him or shifting allegiance to former Florida governor Jeb Bush.

column1: Bush’s aggressive moves to lock up the Republican Party’s premier fundraisers threaten to undercut the Garden State governor before his expected campaign can get off the ground
column2: while raising questions about how robust of a network of support Christie will be able to muster.

column1: Bush has stopped short of directly confronting Christie by holding a fundraiser on his home turf. But behind the scenes
column2: he has been quietly wooing
column3: via e-mail
column4: a cadre of high-profile Christie backers
column5: including a group that attended a private dinner with Bush at New York’s Union League Club in January.

column1: “I’ve known and admired Jeb for many years and I’m obviously intrigued by his candidacy
column2: or I wouldn’t have had dinner or communicated with him in recent weeks
column3: ” said New Jersey State Sen. Joseph M. Kyrillos Jr. (R)
column4: who chaired Christie’s 2009 gubernatorial campaign and attended the New York dinner. “Time will tell how things evolve.”

column1: New York Jets owner Woody Johnson
column2: a onetime Christie booster
column3: signaled his support for Bush on Wednesday when he showed up at a fundraiser in Chicago for Bush’s political committees.

column1: Former New Jersey governor Thomas H. Kean Sr.
column2: a longtime mentor of Christie who is no longer close to him
column3: said in an interview Thursday that he hasn’t decided whom to back — while offering praise for Bush.

column1: “When [Bush] said he has strong views on issues and won’t change them to win an early primary
column2: it showed me he has real convictions
column3: ” Kean said. “The Republican Party in the past has had problems with people who changed their views in order to win a primary
column4: only to have to scramble back in a general election. Voters don’t find that kind of behavior credible.”

column1: Several Bush donors in New Jersey are also in the initial stages of planning an event in the state in March or April
column2: according to several people with knowledge of the discussions. Bush may not attend
column3: but his backers want to demonstrate his New Jersey support.

column1: Several top Christie backers said Thursday that he still has a strong organization of financial heavyweights both in New Jersey and across the country
column2: and they disputed the notion that he is being undercut by Bush.

column1: “We’re doing fine
column2: ” said Kenneth G. Langone
column3: the billionaire co-founder of Home Depot
column4: who has pledged to devote substantial resources to advance Christie’s bid. “Everybody I’ve called and asked has said yes.”

column1: Christie allies do not expect that he will be able to come close to matching Bush’s current fundraising spree
column2: which is expected to bring in tens of millions. His team has sought to project a sense of calm as it makes daily calls to donors
column3: arguing that much of the movement toward Bush is coming from loyalists who received appointments in the administrations of his father and brother.

column1: Ray Washburne
column2: the Dallas real estate developer leading the national fundraising push for Christie’s political committee
column3: said there is plenty of room for both of them.

column1: “Jeb has grabbed a good bit of the donor base
column2: no question
column3: ” he said. “But there is still a huge amount of the donor base available to get.”

column1: A Christie aide provided a list of two dozen New Jersey major contributors committed to Christie’s new political committee
column2: including investor Finn Wentworth
column3: trucking magnate Jerry Langer and Christie’s brother
column4: Todd.

column1: New Jersey real estate executive Jon Hanson
column2: who served as finance chairman for Christie’s gubernatorial campaigns
column3: said his in-state donor network is “stepping up and contributing.”

column1: “I can see he’s out there doing a good job
column2: ” Hanson said of Bush. “But I don’t think that’s going to hinder our ability to raise money for Governor Christie’s PAC.”

column1: Last week
column2: Christie held a fundraiser at the Greenwich
column3: Conn.
column4: home of former GOP gubernatorial candidate Thomas C. Foley. In the coming weeks
column5: he is planning to headline finance events in California and Texas.

column1: So far
column2: Christie has been raising money solely for his Leadership Matters for America PAC
column3: which can accept up to $5
column4: 000 from individual donors. An affiliated super PAC
column5: which can raise unlimited personal and corporate money
column6: is expected to be launched soon.

column1: Once it is
column2: Langone said he plans to put in significant amounts of money. “Absolutely
column3: ” he said. “I’m waiting for it to start.”

column1: But the investor also noted that he would be squarely behind Bush if Christie’s Florida rival emerges victorious out of the GOP primaries.
“If Jeb Bush is the Republican nominee
column2: I will do everything I can to help him get elected
column3: ” he said. “Jeb Bush is a good man. My preference is Christie for one reason: As I look at what this country desperately needs
column4: I think he comes closest to giving us everything we need and want.”

column1: The reticence Christie has encountered among prominent party financiers is a sharp contrast with the more than $100 million that the Republican Governors Association brought in under his recent chairmanship. While Christie aides have credited the fundraising haul to his efforts
column2: some RGA donors have privately said their giving was driven more by their interest in supporting various governors up for reelection.

column1: Christie’s difficulty in locking down home-state support comes after his remarks about child vaccinations on a recent trip to London drew a wave of scathing criticism and alarmed some of his supporters. The governor had to make a series of calls to assure contributors that he supports vaccination for diseases such as measles.
Spencer Zwick
column2: Mitt Romney’s finance chairman in 2012
column3: said the attitude of former Christie backers at home is telling.

column1: “Kyrillos is a very good bellwether for what’s happening in New Jersey
column2: ” Zwick said of the state senator. “If Christie decides to run
column3: he’s going to need the support from the people closest to him to sustain him until he can get national Republican support.”

column1: Zwick
column2: who has not committed to a 2016 candidate
column3: added
column4: “Personally
column5: I have had my own reservations about what Governor Christie did at a key moment in the last presidential election and let it be known to him and others
column6: ” a reference to extensive public praise by Christie of President Obama for the federal response to Hurricane Sandy in the late stages of the campaign. “But I do not believe he had bad intentions and I have moved on.”

column1: Another former Christie ally
column2: New Jersey attorney Lawrence E. Bathgate II
column3: hosted the Jan. 8 dinner in New York to introduce Bush to some of Christie’s top supporters.

column1: Bathgate had been in Christie’s camp for years
column2: but their relationship publicly soured after Christie’s administration pursued a plan to build protective dunes on the state’s coastline where Bathgate has an oceanfront home.

column1: In an interview
column2: though
column3: Bathgate said his reservations about Christie began when he embraced Obama during his visit to the hurricane-battered state. He also expressed concern about more recent events
column4: including the ongoing inquiry into the closing of traffic lanes leading to the George Washington Bridge.

column1: “I know he wanted to work with President Obama on Sandy
column2: but that doesn’t mean you have to put your arm around him and hug him
column3: ” said Bathgate
column4: a former finance chairman of the Republican National Committee. “That took the election and Mitt Romney off the front page. Then you see him a couple years later flying around on Jerry Jones’s jet
column5: jumping up and down like he is a seventh grader. He’s going to have to answer for all of that
column6: and for Bridgegate.”"	REAL

column1: “Now

column1: The 5 unspoken rules for covering Hillary Clinton	"The reporter's job is to ""comfort the afflicted and afflict the comfortable"" — a credo that
column2: humorously
column3: was originally written as a smear of the self-righteous nature of journalists. And so the justification for going after a public figure increases in proportion to his or her stature. The bigger the figure
column4: the looser the restraints.

column1: After a quarter of a century on the national stage
column2: there's no more comfortable political figure to afflict than Hillary Clinton. And she's in for a lot of affliction over the next year and half.

column1: That's generally a good way for reporters to go about their business. After all
column2: the more power a person wants in our republic
column3: the more voters should know about her or him. But it's also an essential frame for thinking about the long-toxic relationship between the Clintons and the media
column4: why the coverage of Hillary Clinton differs from coverage of other candidates for the presidency
column5: and whether that difference encourages distortions that will ultimately affect the presidential race.

column1: The Clinton rules are driven by reporters' and editors' desire to score the ultimate prize in contemporary journalism: the scoop that brings down Hillary Clinton and her family's political empire. At least in that way
column2: Republicans and the media have a common interest.

column1: I understand these dynamics well
column2: having co-written a book that demonstrated how Bill and Hillary Clinton used Hillary's time at State to build the family political operation and set up for their fourth presidential campaign. That is to say
column3: I've done a lot of research about the Clintons' relationship with the media
column4: and experienced it firsthand. As an author
column5: I felt that I owed it to myself and the reader to report
column6: investigate
column7: and write with the same mix of curiosity
column8: skepticism
column9: rigor
column10: and compassion that I would use with any other subject. I wanted to sell books
column11: of course. But the easier way to do that — proven over time — is to write as though the Clintons are the purest form of evil. The same holds for daily reporting. Want to drive traffic to a website? Write something nasty about a Clinton
column12: particularly Hillary.

column1: As a reporter
column2: I get sucked into playing by the Clinton rules. This is what I've seen in my colleagues
column3: and in myself.

column1: One of my former colleagues
column2: a hard-nosed reporter who has put countless political pelts on his wall
column3: once told me that everyone in public life has something to hide. Who goes down in the flames of scandal? The politicians we decide to go after.

column1: That may not be 100 percent true
column2: but it's true enough. The act of choosing
column3: time and again
column4: to go after the same person has the effect of tainting that person
column5: even when an investigation or reporting turns up nothing nefarious — and it's time not spent digging into his or her adversaries. The original source of alleged malfeasance could come from the other party
column6: within a politician's party
column7: or from the reporter's own observations and industrious digging. But two things are crystal clear: If there's no investigation
column8: there's no scandal. And if there's no scandal
column9: there's no scalp.

column1: The Clintons have been under investigation for about 25 years now. There's little doubt they've produced more information for investigators
column2: lawyers
column3: and journalists about their finances
column4: their business and philanthropic dealings
column5: and their decision-making processes in government than any officials in American history. They've watched countless friends frog-marched into congressional hearings and
column6: in some cases
column7: to jail. They know there's a good chance that any expressed thought will become part of the public record and twisted for political gain.

column1: The most absurd allegations against Hillary Clinton have been bookends on her public career so far: that she had something to do with the suicide of Clinton White House aide Vince Foster
column2: and that she bears responsibility for the terrorist attack that killed US Ambassador to Libya Chris Stevens.

column1: But in between
column2: there was Travelgate
column3: Filegate
column4: and Whitewater. Some were less legitimate than others. When Clinton surprisingly claimed that she and her husband were ""dead broke"" when they left the White House
column5: it was because they had spent all of their money to defend themselves against an eight-year barrage of investigations.

column1: It's understandable
column2: then
column3: why the Clintons have a bunker mentality when it comes to transparency. But their paranoia leads them to be secretive
column4: and their secrecy leads Republicans and the press to suspect wrongdoing. That spurs further investigation
column5: which only makes the Clintons more secretive. The paranoia and persistent investigation feed each other in an endless cycle of probe and parry. Along the way
column6: the political class and the public are forced to choose imperfect sides: the power couple that always seems to be hiding something
column7: or a Washington investigation complex that is overly partisan and underwhelming in its ability to prove gross misconduct.

column1: This is
column2: for Republicans
column3: a reasonable strategy. They know that if they keep investigating her
column4: it will do two things: keep the media writing about scandals that might knock her out
column5: and turn off voters who don't want a return to the bloodsport politics of the 1990s. They leak partial stories to reporters hungry for that one great scoop that will give them the biggest political scalp of them all. But they also err in jumping the gun in accusing her of wrongdoing
column6: which allows Clinton to defend herself by pointing at the folly of her adversaries.

column1: In touring the country to promote our book in 2014
column2: my co-author and I were repeatedly lobbied to assert that Clinton is a lesbian. One gentleman pushed the issue during a Q&A at a Barnes and Noble on the Upper West Side of Manhattan — one of the few places you might expect that kind of thing to get a rest.

column1: The National Enquirer published a story in April alleging that Clinton wiped her personal email server clean because it contained references to her lesbian lovers.
Meanwhile
column2: the conservative media are also convinced Clinton is preparing to wage a war on Christianity if she wins the presidency. But one thing revealed in her State Department emails is that Clinton shared daily religious reflections with her friends.

column1: It's not just the out-of-the-box allegations that keep the media machine spun up. A year before Chelsea Clinton got married
column2: Clinton staffers were kept busy by mainstream journalists who were absolutely sure she had already gone through with secret nuptials.

column1: And
column2: on a more serious note
column3: remember Benghazi flu? Many political opponents and members of the media were unable to accept the idea that Clinton was forced to cancel planned Senate testimony on Benghazi because she'd suffered a concussion. Now
column4: three years later
column5: it seems ridiculous to think that Clinton was making an excuse — she's since testified on both sides of the Hill — or that she suffered
column6: as Karl Rove suggested
column7: brain damage. And if she was making up the concussion to avoid testifying
column8: how did she suffer brain damage from a fake fall?

column1: The conservative media echo chamber
column2: which bounces innuendo from Rush Limbaugh to Fox News and back again
column3: ensures that the most damning story lines — true or not — stay alive. The Benghazi attacks are a perfect example. Terrorists killed four Americans. The conservative echo chamber seems convinced Hillary Clinton is at fault. The reasonable argument to make is that we shouldn't have been in Libya in the first place and the murders were a down-the-chain result of bad policy. But the right wing wants to prove that they happened because of Clinton's actions — or inaction — on security matters.

column1: They've talked about security requests denied for Libya (never mind that the stronger contingent would have been in Tripoli
column2: not Benghazi
column3: and that there's no evidence Clinton herself was aware of the requests)
column4: a stand-down order that prevented reinforcements from arriving in Benghazi (never mind that they wouldn't have gotten there until after the fighting was done
column5: and that even a House Republican committee found that there was no such order) and
column6: most of absurd of all
column7: that Clinton knew the attack was coming. This is how Limbaugh put it in May.

column1: The freedom of the conservative media to make wild allegations often acts as a bulldozer forcing reporters to check into the charges and
column2: in doing so
column3: repeat them. By the time they've been debunked
column4: they're part of the American public's collective consciousness. Or
column5: as it's been said
column6: a lie gets around the world before the truth gets out of bed.

column1: One outgrowth of Clinton's terrible relationship with reporters is that journalists often assume she is acting in bad faith. There's good reason for that. Though she's added some new pros to her press staff for this campaign
column2: her operation's stance toward the media was always a reflection of the way Bill Clinton's White House handled journalists.

column1: Back in the mid-1990s
column2: Bill Clinton relied on a series of Machiavellian spin doctors to keep the press at bay. With the Clinton White House
column3: the modus operandi was to stonewall as long as possible
column4: lie if necessary — or just out of habit — and turn questions around on the questioners. After all
column5: Bill Clinton once wagged his finger at a press conference and told reporters
column6: ""I did not have sexual relations with that woman ... Ms. Lewinsky."" He'd lied in a deposition
column7: too.

column1: So the press has plenty of precedent for believing that when the Clintons aren't forthcoming — and sometimes
column2: even when they are — they're covering something up. And the Clintons
column3: given the history of some-smoke-no-fire investigations launched against them
column4: have plenty of precedent for being mistrustful of the press. The result is a brutally dysfunctional relationship on both sides. The Clintons believe the press acts in bad faith
column5: and the press believes the Clintons' attitudes toward the press are evidence that the Clintons are hiding something.

column1: That attitude carried over to Hillary Clinton's 2008 campaign
column2: and to some degree her tenure as Secretary of State. The standard response to a reporter's question is not an answer. It is to ignore the question or to engage in a Socratic debate by asking a question in return. It's clear Clinton doesn't like the media one bit
column3: as Glenn Thrush and Maggie Haberman reported last year.

column1: At a July Fourth parade this past weekend
column2: Clinton aides used rope to create an impromptu moving barrier for reporters
column3: keeping them away from the candidate and voters. She treated them like cattle
column4: and they responded by putting the video on television for the last three days.

column1: The mistrust among journalists is a problem for Clinton. And as the media is an amplifier for the public
column2: it's also little wonder that so many voters are inclined to believe she's often acting in bad faith. Most Americans say she's not honest and trustworthy.

column1: This view
column2: shared by many reporters and most of the public
column3: makes it much easier to treat Clinton's actions as though they are uniquely sinister. Case in point: She made a ton of money giving paid speeches to people with business before the government. So did Jeb Bush
column4: of course. But until Bush recently released an accounting of some of those speeches
column5: the media had little interest in his dealings. Kudos to Ken Vogel of Politico
column6: who did some digging on that for a story published Thursday.

column1: The imbalance in assumptions about Clinton's motivations is another way in which the Clinton code has a distorting effect on the public perception of her. And it
column2: too
column3: is self-perpetuating: It leads Clinton to assume the press is biased against her
column4: which leads her to treat the press poorly
column5: which leads more reporters to assume she's trying to hide something from them.

column1: When Clinton keynoted an annual fundraiser for David Axelrod's epilepsy charity in June 2013
column2: several major news outlets sent reporters to cover the speech. That was more than three years before the 2016 election. Every word
column3: every gesture
column4: every facial expression is scrutinized.

column1: Video of Clinton ordering a burrito bowl at a Chipotle became the first viral image of her campaign. Reporters gave fodder to late-night comedians earlier this year when they made a mad dash to catch up as her campaign van rolled by.
This coverage of every last detail
column2: of course
column3: isn't a one-way street. It wasn't until a reporter was tipped off to the Chipotle visit that anyone knew about it. She craves the attention even more than she detests it.

column1: But that
column2: too
column3: has a distorting effect. As with the royal family in London
column4: normally private moments become part of a public narrative: her husband's affair
column5: her daughter's wedding
column6: the birth of her granddaughter.

column1: All the attention has the effect of making Clinton seem
column2: to the casual observer
column3: hungrier for press than even the average politician. And there's no doubt that part of the love/hate relationship is an intense desire to attract and manipulate coverage. But Clinton understands that sometimes it's better not to be in the spotlight.

column1: The best example of that was when she declined requests to appear on Sunday political talk shows right after the Benghazi attacks. Susan Rice
column2: then the ambassador to the UN and now Obama's national security adviser
column3: leaped at the chance to stand in for Clinton. Those appearances ended up costing Rice the nomination to succeed Clinton as secretary of state when many senators concluded she had lied about the origin and nature of the attacks.

column1: The press has such fascination with the Clintons that the coverage would be there whether Hillary Clinton wanted it or not.
For someone who lost a big lead in the 2008 presidential primary and is ceding ground to Bernie Sanders right now
column2: Clinton is given a lot of credit for her political acumen. Her detractors see in every move
column3: including the birth of her granddaughter
column4: a grandly conceived and executed political calculation.

column1: And Clinton plays into that by using the positives in her life for political gain.
That doesn't make her different from other candidates for the presidency — it makes her just like them. New Jersey Gov. Chris Christie talked about his grandmothers
column2: his mom
column3: his wife
column4: and his kids when he launched his bid for the presidency last week. Was that calculated to send messages about Christie to the public? Of course!

column1: The best example
column2: though
column3: was the tear — the one that rolled down Clinton's cheek as she campaigned in New Hampshire after having come in third in the Iowa caucuses in 2008.

column1: The New York Times's Maureen Dowd pilloried her for what Dowd saw as a window into the dark part of Clinton's soul.
How far political journalism has come from castigating Ed Muskie for crying to accusing Clinton of calculating that tears would help her win. She's not that good at politics.
I take a dim view of the idea that journalists successfully anoint political winners. The media might have been in the bag for Barack Obama
column2: but he didn't win because he got positive coverage. He won because he had better strategy
column3: a better message
column4: and better skills at delivering that message — in the 2008 primary and in the two general elections he won.

column1: That said
column2: the media can definitely weigh down — and even destroy — a candidate. The emphasis on a candidate's flaws — real or perceived — comes at the cost of the candidate's ability to focus his or her message and at the cost of negative attention to the other candidates. This is a problem for Clinton
column3: and it seems unlikely to go away.

column1: Hillary Clinton is comfortable enough to be a target for a lot of journalistic affliction and powerful enough that no one needs to comfort her from that affliction. But these double standards are an important factor to keep in mind when judging her against her rivals for the presidency. Whether they're fair or not
column2: the Clinton rules distort the public's perception of Hillary Clinton.

column1: Correction: This story has been corrected to remove an erroneous reference to the source of the original report on the Monica Lewinsky scandal. The Drudge Report first broke news that Newsweek had decided to hold a story about the affair."	REAL

column1: Clinton Vs. Trump: Latest Electoral Prediction [Greg Laden's Blog] | Science and Technology	"(Before It's News)
It is fun to look at polls
column2: and using such data
column3: decide which candidate will win which state
column4: and ultimately
column5: which candidate will win the electoral college. A lot of people and organizations do that
column6: and for this reason
column7: I don’t. I do not have access to polls that no one else sees. Were I to use polling data to directly predict outcomes per state
column8: I’d use a method like that used by FiveThirtyEight
column9: and probably come up with similar results. How boring. It would be a waste of my time to try to replicate the excellent work done by Nate Silver and his team.

column1: Back during the Democratic Primaries
column2: I decided that I wanted to get a handle on which candidate was likely to win
column3: fairly early on. The polling based estimates were inadequate because most states simply didn’t have polling data that early in the process. So
column4: I invented an alternative method
column5: which made certain estimates of how voters with different ethnic identities would vote. That method accurately predicted several primary outcomes
column6: outperforming the poll based methods such as those used by FiveThirtyEight.

column1: After a while
column2: enough primaries had been carried out that I could switch methods slightly. Using the same exact model
column3: but primed with the results of prior primaries (that year) rather than my estimates of voter behavior
column4: I used the ethnic distribution data for each state to predict the outcome of upcoming primary contests.

column1: Once again
column2: my method was very accurate
column3: and once again
column4: it out performed the polling based methods.

column1: So
column2: recently
column3: I’ve tried to apply a similar method to estimating the electoral outcome for this year’s presidential race. But
column4: it is impossible to use the same exact method because the entire thing happens all on one day. I can’t use the election results from a handful of states to estimate the likely future outcomes in other states.

column1: I recognize that polling data is very limited on a national level. Things happen during an election season that probably change people’s likely voting behavior
column2: especially among independents. Solid states are rarely polled
column3: and small states
column4: swing or not
column5: are rarely polled. Many polls are of low quality. Right now
column6: for instance
column7: fewer than half of the states have polls that were a) taken fully after the final POTUS debate and b) have an A- or better rating from FiveThirtyEight. If I allow the use of B and occasional C ratings for recent polls
column8: and allow a few polls to include periods of time prior to the last POTUS debate
column9: but only in states that are very strongly in favor of one candidate or the other (and thus likely to not move anyway)
column10: I can find 32 states that have sort of usable polling data. Interestingly
column11: states with some of the more controversial changes happening
column12: like Utah and Iowa
column13: are not adequately polled.

column1: In order to apply a model like the one I used in the Primaries to the current election
column2: I used the 32 states for which there was somewhat acceptable recent polling data to inform the model (to calculate the regression coefficients) in order to then
column3: separately
column4: predict the likely voting behavior (Trump vs. Clinton) in all of the states.

column1: Before I show you the map
column2: however
column3: I need to discuss something else.

column1: About a week ago the press
column2: especially the somewhat more left leaning press
column3: and various commenters
column4: seeing much reaction to a series of events beginning with the NYT release of Trump’s tax return and ending with the final POTUS debate
column5: events which sandwiched the sexual assault tapes and accusations
column6: collectively decided that a huge gap between Clinton and Trump was rapidly opening up and the race would end with a double digit spread
column7: an electoral rout
column8: and a big party.

column1: Soon after
column2: I pointed out that this may not be correct. That polling data seemed to show
column3: rather
column4: that there was an expansion of the difference between the two candidates followed by a re-closing of the gap
column5: with Clinton still leading but by about as much as before this temporary shift. To this I added a concern. If too many people assumed that the race was over and in the double digit range
column6: perhaps there could be a GOTV backlash effect
column7: or a funding effect
column8: that would shift things to within shooting distance for Trump.

column1: I was not alone in thinking this
column2: and I was probably right. The GOP sunk
column3: via pacs
column4: 25 million dollars into Senate races in response to the Democrats shifting from the national race to the Senate
column5: which was followed by the Democrats shifting back to the national race in certain states
column6: presumably recognizing that the polls were artificially spread. Indeed
column7: some who criticized (arguing mainly from incredulity and good wishes) my admonition noted
column8: correctly
column9: that some of that narrowing was because a bunch of right-leaning polls had come out all at once. This is true
column10: but it ignores that a bunch of left-leaning polls had made the formation of the Great Gap of GOP Defeat look a lot bigger than it ever really was.

column1: I say all this as part one of my preparation for what I’m going to tell you below
column2: which is not the news you want to hear. Part two is some logic I’d like to bludgeon you with.

column1: Consider these points:
1) True Trump supporters could give a rat’s ass about sexual assault
column2: poor debate performance
column3: or tax forms. Donald Trump was correct when he said
column4: weeks ago
column5: now forgotten
column6: that he could gun someone down on the streets of Manhattan and he would not lose support form his base. These people did not abandon him when he was heard to talk about sexual assault. If anything
column7: they were energized by it. And
column8: I’m talking about something just shy of 40% of the voters. We live in a barely civilized asshole country.

column1: 2) Please tell me exactly which Hillary Clinton supporters
column2: who were going to vote for Clinton over Trump all along
column3: are NOW going to pick Clinton (if polled or on voting day) that change from not being Clinton supporters to being Clinton supporters? In other words (this is a somewhat subtle point) which people who hated Trump became True Haters of Trump after the sexual assault thing? Almost none. They were already there.

column1: 3) The third category of people
column2: the undecideds (who are only lying about being undecided
column3: in most cases) and the so-called “reasonable Republicans” (of which there are very
column4: very few)
column5: who could conceivably shift from Trump to Clinton are going to divide their voting activities between Johnson
column6: a write in (as they are being advised by Republican leaders in some cases) or simply staying home.

column1: In other words
column2: over the last few weeks
column3: no source has emerged that hands Secretary Clinton more electoral votes than she probably had about a month ago
column4: and Trump is not going to have any
column5: or at least not many
column6: electoral votes go away.

column1: Those observations (part one) and that logic (part two) cause me to be utterly unsurprised to find out that an analysis of the electoral map I did on October 16th and one I did today do not show Clinton pulling farther ahead. In fact
column2: the two analyses have Clinton being less far ahead than Trump now than ten days ago. The difference is in Ohio (shifting from Clinton to Trump) which is almost certainly going to happen
column3: and North Carolina (which shifted from Clinton to Trump in this analysis) which seems much less likely to happen
column4: and Arizona shifting from Clinton (that was probably wishful thinking) to Trump.

column1: The point here is this
column2: plain and simple. An analysis using a technique that has worked very well for me in the past shows that the difference between that moment of Maximal Clintonosity and today is plus or minus a couple of state. In other words
column3: not different. Maybe a little worse. Really
column4: about the same.

column1: Here’s the current map:
Obviously
column2: I will be watching for more data over the next few days. I assume there will be a spate of polls as we approach November 8th (the day Democrats vote. Republicans vote on the 28th of November). If so
column3: then there will be convergence between my method of calibration and my method of calculation
column4: and the model will consume itself by the tail and become very accurate at the same time.

column1: But between now and then
column2: perhaps that very small number of polls that are both recent and high quality will grow a bit more and I can do this again and resolve those closer states.

column1: By the way
column2: the “swing states” according to my model
column3: the states where things are close
column4: are Ohio
column5: North Carolina
column6: Arizona
column7: and Georgia of those now in the Trump column. Those are indeed swing states. Numerically
column8: the close states that are in the Clinton column are Virginia
column9: New Hampshire
column10: and Pennsylvania."	FAKE

column1: Iraq launches operation against ISIS in Anbar province	"The Iraqi government -- supported by Shiite militias from Iran -- launched a large-scale military operation to take out Islamic State militants from Iraq’s western Anbar province Monday.
The operation is under way to recapture Fallujah and Ramadi
column2: a senior defense official at the Pentagon confirmed to Fox News Monday. The efforts are supported by Shiite militias
column3: known as Popular Mobilization Units
column4: from Iran and its proxy Hezbollah.

column1: Photos of Iran’s Quds force Commander Qasem Soleimani visiting Shia militia units inside Iraq have appeared on social media since ISIS took over large portions of Iraq a year ago.
The defense official was unaware of any U.S. air support boosting the operation. It has been longstanding Pentagon policy to support only units aligned with the government of Iraq
column2: but the line can be blurred as the chain of command for units operating in Iraq is not always known.

column1: The spokesman for the Joint Operations Command
column2: Brig. Gen. Yahya Rasool
column3: said in a televised statement that the operation started at dawn Monday and that government forces are backed by Shiite and Sunni pro-government fighters.

column1: The operation met fierce resistance from insurgents
column2: who deployed five suicide car bombs and fired rockets to repel their advance on the city of Fallujah
column3: about 30 miles west of Baghdad
column4: military sources in Anbar told Reuters.

column1: There were also reports of fighting around the provincial capital Ramadi
column2: captured by Islamic State two months ago.

column1: There were also reports of fighting around Ramadi-- captured by Islamic State two months ago. Iraqi forces pushed towards the provincial capital from the west and the south
column2: police sources in the province said. Islamic State supporters said those advances were repelled by the militants.

column1: When Shia militia units launched an operation to retake another Sunni stronghold
column2: Tikrit
column3: in March
column4: they did so without support from the U.S.-led coalition initially.  U.S. warplanes only supported the operation when the Shia militia units backed by Iran departed the area.

column1: According to the latest coalition airstrike report
column2: there were two airstrikes in Fallujah over the weekend.

column1: This is not the first time the Iraqi government has announced an operation to retake Anbar -- where several key towns
column2: including the provincial capital Ramadi
column3: remain under ISIS control. In May
column4: authorities announced an operation to retake Ramadi
column5: but there has not been any major progress on the ground since then.

column1: The forces arrayed against ISIS are varied
column2: according to retired U.S. Army Lt. Col. Ralph Peters.

column1: “This is a real mish-mosh
column2: ” said Peters
column3: a Fox News contributor. “You have Shia militias -- not all of whom get along
column4: by the way
column5: Iraqi troops
column6: police and some Sunni tribesmen. Iran is deeply involved in helping them plan and supervising the operation
column7: but it is compartmentalized. It won’t be Sunni tribesmen and Shia militias standing shoulder-to-shoulder. So coordination is going to be a nightmare.”

column1: Peters said retaking Fallujah
column2: a much smaller city than Ramadi and closer to Baghdad
column3: will be easier. Going into Ramadi
column4: where ISIS has been dug in for two months and likely booby-trapped buildings
column5: will be a dangerous and painstaking process
column6: he said. And there is one more tactic to worry about
column7: according to Peters.

column1: “ISIS is very smart
column2: ” he said. “When they are attacked in one area
column3: they strike in another area. It would not be surprising to see an asymmetric response -- perhaps a new attack on Tikrit or the oil fields in the north.”

column1: Hadi al-Ameri
column2: commander of the largest Shi'ite force
column3: the Badr Organization
column4: told Iraqi television Sunday he expected the main attack on Fallujah to happen after the Eid holiday which starts later this week.

column1: Residents in Fallujah and Ramadi reported heavy bombardment of both cities early on Monday.
In a brief statement
column2: Iraq's Prime Minister
column3: Haider al-Abadi
column4: vowed to ""take revenge from Daesh criminals on the battlefield... and their cowardly crimes against unarmed civilians will only increase our determination to chase them and to expel them from the land of Iraq.""

column1: The Islamic State group
column2: also known by the Arabic acronym Daesh
column3: seized large parts of Anbar in early 2014 and captured Ramadi in May. Iraqi forces
column4: which had been making steady progress against the extremists in recent months with the help of the air campaign
column5: scored a major victory in recapturing Saddam Hussein's hometown of Tikrit last month.

column1: During the past few weeks
column2: the troops have been moving to cut the militants' supply routes and to surround and isolate Ramadi and Fallujah.

column1: Rasool didn't provide any further details on the ongoing operations. By noon
column2: the country's state TV reported government forces recapturing villages and areas around Fallujah.

column1: Meanwhile Monday
column2: the Islamic State group claimed responsibility for Sunday's series of bombings in Shiite areas of the capital
column3: Baghdad
column4: that killed at least 29 people and wounded 81 others
column5: according to the ISIS-affiliated Aamaq news agency.

column1: Iraq is going through its worst crisis since the 2011 withdrawal of U.S. troops. The Islamic State group controls large swaths of the country's north and west after capturing Iraq's second-largest city of Mosul and the majority of Anbar province.
Fox News' Lucas Tomlinson and the Associated Press contributed to this report."	REAL

UKIP MEPs Steven Woolfe & Mike Hookem reported to French police over Strasbourg scuffle	"UKIP MEPs Steven Woolfe & Mike Hookem reported to French police over... UKIP MEPs Steven Woolfe & Mike Hookem reported to French police over Strasbourg scuffle By 0 61
MEPs Steven Woolfe and Mike Hookem have been reported to French police over an altercation at the EU’s Strasbourg parliament
column2: which saw Woolfe hospitalized and plunged crisis-hit UKIP into further turmoil.

column1: European Parliament President Martin Schulz said he had referred the “regrettable” incident to the French authorities “given the seriousness of the reported facts and their possible criminal implications.”
Schulz says he had been recommended to do so by the European Parliament’s advisory committee on conduct
column2: according to the Press Association. Following recommendation of EP Advisory Committee on Code of Conduct
column3: I referred incident involving MEPs Hookem and Woolfe to FR authorities

column3: I will then take a decision about sanctions to be imposed according to EP rules

“The committee concluded that the versions of the facts given by the two members involved diverged substantially and the facts seem to have happened in the absence of direct witnesses
column2: ” he told the parliament.

column1: Read more
“It also stressed that given the seriousness of the reported facts and their possible criminal implications

column1: “As a result I have decided to follow the recommendation of the advisory committee and I have referred this matter to the competent French authorities.

column1: Despite the ruling

column2: and so it is “ reasonable to assume that Mr Woolf opened the door whilst attempting to exit the ante room backwards. ”

Justices Kennedy and Scalia and their divide on gay rights	"Justices Anthony M. Kennedy and Antonin Scalia were born in the same year
column2: chosen by the same president
column3: live on the same Northern Virginia street and
column4: in serving together on the Supreme Court longer than any other current pair of justices
column5: have many times voted the same conservative way.

column1: But one issue — how the Constitution protects gay citizens — divides and defines the two like no other. This week’s historic hearing on same-sex marriage is both the logical extension and ultimate showdown in a decades-long argument that so far Kennedy has always won.
[Here’s what the fallout of a ruling could be in the various states]

Each of Kennedy’s bold and lyrical rulings on behalf of gays — “times can blind us to certain truths and later generations can see that laws once thought necessary and proper in fact serve only to oppress
column2: ” he wrote in Lawrence v. Texas — has been just as reliably followed by a meticulous and fiery denunciation from Scalia.

column1: “The court has taken sides in the culture war
column2: departing from its role of assuring
column3: as neutral observer
column4: that the democratic rules of engagement are observed
column5: ” Scalia answered in the Lawrence case.

column1: Kennedy has written all of the Supreme Court’s most important decisions on gay rights: protecting the civil rights of homosexuals in Romer v. Evans (1996)
column2: abolishing anti-gay sodomy laws in Lawrence (2003) and ruling in United States v. Windsor two years ago that the federal government must recognize same-sex marriages.

column1: Each was a steppingstone to the Supreme Court’s consideration on Tuesday of whether the Constitution forbids states from prohibiting gay couples to marry.
If the pattern continues and the court renders a landmark ruling favoring gay marriage
column2: it will likely once again be Kennedy whose words memorialize that decision and Scalia who will articulate the dissent.

column1: It is not a conflict everyone would have predicted for two of Ronald Reagan’s choices for the court. Scalia ascended to the bench in 1986
column2: and Kennedy followed 17 months later. The two
column3: born on opposite coasts in 1936
column4: are consistent comrades on issues important to corporate America and in dismantling campaign finance laws they see restricting political speech.

column1: After Chief Justice John G. Roberts Jr. sided with liberals to declare the Affordable Care Act constitutional
column2: Scalia and Kennedy united with Justices Clarence Thomas and Samuel A. Alito Jr. in a jointly written
column3: 65-page dissent mocking the majority opinion and saying the entire act should be found invalid.

column1: Kennedy is often the deciding vote when the ideologically divided court splits 5 to 4
column2: but in two-thirds of those cases he sides with the conservatives.

column1: But if they often arrive at the same conclusion — one obstacle for same-sex marriage proponents in the current case is Kennedy’s allegiance to states’ rights — Kennedy and Scalia could not be more different in how they view a judge’s role.
“Their different approach to gay rights reflects their more fundamental disagreement about how to think about the liberties protected by the Constitution
column2: ” said Paul M. Smith
column3: a Washington lawyer who was on the winning side in the Lawrence case.

column1: Scalia believes the only freedoms that should be viewed as protected by the Constitution “are those that have been protected under American law throughout our history
column2: defined at the most specific level
column3: ” Smith said. Otherwise
column4: the people decide.

column1: Kennedy
column2: Smith said
column3: “believes that each generation has the right to conceive of newer and broader forms of liberty that merit constitutional protection. He sees history as a guide but not a straitjacket.”

column1: Their battle is compelling
column2: said Allison Orr Larsen
column3: a William and Mary law professor
column4: because it “brings to the forefront the theoretical question in constitutional law: How should courts respond to change when interpreting the Constitution?”

column1: Michael Dorf
column2: a professor at Cornell Law School and a former Kennedy clerk
column3: said his former boss’s decisions on gay rights were not constructed to lead ultimately to a decision on same-sex marriage. But they provided a foundation for how to view new constitutional rights “if that’s where the country moves.”

column1: Scalia
column2: on the other hand
column3: champions the cause of originalism
column4: and Edward Whelan
column5: a former Scalia clerk and president of the Ethics and Public Policy Center
column6: said his former boss learned quickly that “Kennedy’s judicial approach was not anything close to what Scalia’s is.”

column1: “A basic tenet of originalism is that it’s not the role of judges to impose their own moral philosophies
column2: ” Whelan said. “Scalia understands the Constitution to leave the vast bulk of policy issues to the democratic processes and rejects the notion that it’s his role to read his own views into the Constitution.”

column1: It’s worth remembering the differences among President Reagan’s choices for the Supreme Court.
He fulfilled his campaign pledge to name a woman to the bench with Sandra Day O’Connor
column2: the pragmatic Arizona politician and judge who quickly became the court’s center.

column1: Scalia’s selection was celebrated by conservatives eager to see a new method of constitutional interpretation forcefully advocated on the court.
Kennedy was a compromise
column2: Reagan’s third choice for the seat he once hoped would be filled by conservative Robert Bork
column3: whose nomination was defeated in the Senate. “This was the Bork seat
column4: ” said Smith. “Things could have been much different.”

column1: Kennedy’s views
column2: Dorf said
column3: were those of a “moderate California Republican.”

column1: Although he never ruled for gay rights as a lower court judge
column2: Kennedy expressed concern about the policy even as he upheld the military’s right to dismiss gay servicemen. And Frank J. Colucci
column3: a political science professor at Purdue University who has written a book about Kennedy’s jurisprudence
column4: recalled that Kennedy in a speech criticized the Supreme Court’s 1986 decision in Bowers v. Hardwick that upheld a Georgia statute criminalizing sodomy.

column1: “He came about as close as you can as a lower court judge to saying it was wrongly decided
column2: ” Colucci said.

column1: Once on the court
column2: Kennedy was able to say just that.

column1: In the first gay rights case
column2: Romer
column3: Kennedy wrote for the majority in striking down a Colorado constitutional amendment. After some cities in the state began passing laws protecting gays from discrimination in housing
column4: employment and other areas
column5: voters through a referendum approved the amendment precluding such government protections.

column1: Colorado’s amendment
column2: Kennedy wrote
column3: “classifies homosexuals not to further a proper legislative end but to make them unequal to everyone else. This Colorado cannot do. A state cannot so deem a class of persons a stranger to its laws.”

column1: That began something of a call-and-response on the issue: Kennedy delivering the majority’s opinion
column2: Scalia replying with a scalding dissent
column3: read from the bench for emphasis.

column1: “This court has no business imposing upon all Americans the resolution favored by the elite class from which the members of this institution are selected
column2: pronouncing that ‘animosity’ toward homosexuality is evil
column3: ” Scalia wrote in Romer. “I vigorously dissent.”

column1: In Lawrence
column2: Kennedy got the chance to reverse the court’s decision on sodomy
column3: and did: “Bowers was not correct when it was decided and it is not correct today.” Private
column4: homosexual conduct between consenting adults
column5: he wrote
column6: “involves liberty of the person both in its spatial and more transcendent dimensions.”

column1: O’Connor wrote a concurring opinion to say the ruling did not touch on the matter of whether gays would be able to marry.
Scalia wrote that homosexuals should be free to promote their cause through democratic means
column2: but “many Americans do not want persons who openly engage in homosexual conduct as partners in their business
column3: as scoutmasters for their children
column4: as teachers in their children’s schools
column5: or as boarders in their home.”

column1: “They view this as protecting themselves and their families from a lifestyle that they believe to be immoral and destructive
column2: ” he wrote. “The court views it as ‘discrimination.’ ”

column1: Two years ago
column2: in Windsor
column3: Kennedy wrote that the federal government’s refusal to offer the same government benefits available to heterosexual couples to legally married gay couples tells “all the world that their otherwise valid marriages are unworthy” and “humiliates” their children.

column1: Again
column2: Scalia blasted the decision
column3: saying the majority was merely being coy in saying the decision did not address whether states are required to give licenses for same-sex marriage.

column1: “By formally declaring anyone opposed to same-sex marriage an enemy of human decency
column2: the majority arms well every challenger to a state law restricting marriage to its traditional definition
column3: ” he wrote.

column1: Most federal courts have taken Scalia literally.
“The court agrees with Justice Scalia’s interpretation of Windsor
column2: ” wrote U.S. District Judge Robert J. Shelby of Salt Lake City.

column1: Shelby’s decision to strike a marriage ban in Utah was the first such ruling following Windsor and began the path that continues to Tuesday’s oral arguments
column2: and will end with the court’s decision in June.

column1: 40 years later: “I’ve got the license and the faggot letter”
The right finds a voice on same-sex marriage
Gay rights
column2: religious rights and a compromise in an unlikely place: Utah"	REAL
