column1: Jeb Bush's Foreign Policy Plan: More Military Spending Will 'Encourage Peace'	"WASHINGTON -- Former Florida Gov. Jeb Bush will lay out a vision of American foreign policy on Wednesday aimed at pushing his nascent 2016 presidential campaign out of the shadow of his father and brother
column2: two former presidents who waged overseas wars.

column1: I love my father and my brother … But I am my own man –- and my views are shaped by my own thinking and own experiences
column2: Bush will say in a speech to the Chicago Council on Global Affairs
column3: according to excerpts provided to reporters late Tuesday night.

column1: In his first major foreign policy address
column2: the likely 2016 Republican front-runner will make the case for increased military spending so America can ""project power and enforce peaceful stability in far-off areas of the globe."" He will also criticize President Barack Obama's foreign policy
column3: calling it ""inconsistent and indecisive.""

column1: Having a military that is equal to any threat ... makes it less likely that we will need to put our men and women in uniform in harm’s way
column2: Bush plans to tell attendees
column3: adding that he believes ""fundamentally
column4: that weakness invites war… and strength encourages peace.""

column1: The idea that a bigger U.S. military would act as a bigger deterrent to potential foes is one that reached its apex during the Cold War
column2: but has been repeatedly challenged in the 21st century by the rise of global terrorism and sectarian conflicts.

column1: The Obama administration is currently working to devise responses to a number of unconventional threats to global security. Chief among them are the rise of the so-called Islamic State in the Middle East
column2: and the Russian-backed separatists waging guerrilla war in Ukraine.

column1: From his speech
column2: it appears that Bush would have America play a greater role than it already does in these conflicts. ""America does not have the luxury of withdrawing from the world –- our security
column3: our prosperity and our values demand that we remain engaged and involved in often distant places
column4: Bush will say. ""We have no reason to apologize for our leadership and our interest in serving the cause of global security
column5: global peace and human freedom.""

column1: This vision of America's role in the world directly contradicts the view held by Kentucky Sen. Rand Paul
column2: another 2016 potential candidate
column3: that the U.S. should avoid involvement in foreign conflicts unless they pose a direct threat to American lives.

column1: But even as Bush stressed that he would devise his own way forward
column2: plenty of his foreign policies invite comparisons
column3: not contradictions
column4: with those of his neoconservative brother
column5: George W.Bush
column6: and his realist father
column7: George H.W. Bush.

column1: One reason for this could be that Jeb Bush has consulted many of the same advisers his father and brother relied on to help them craft foreign policy while each was in office. The advisers represent a spectrum of conservative viewpoints
column2: from the pragmatic James Baker
column3: former secretary of state in the George H.W. Bush administration
column4: to the fiercely ideological Paul Wolfowitz
column5: who served as deputy secretary of defense in the George W. Bush administration.

column1: Wolfowitz and Jeb Bush have held similar foreign policy ideas since at least 1997
column2: when they were both signatories to a set of principles devised by the conservative Project for the New American Century
column3: which were described by the group as a ""Reaganite policy of military strength and moral clarity."" Other signatories include former Vice President Dick Cheney and former Defense Secretary Donald Rumsfeld."	REAL

column1: John Kasich: He’s Conservative, but at Least He’s Sane	"I worked for Kasich on Capitol Hill. Yes
column2: he’s very conservative. But there are a few surprises in there
column3: and he’s in Bizarro World.

column1: With his surprising second-place finish in the New Hampshire primary
column2: Ohio Gov. John Kasich has vaulted out of the pack of also-rans to become the latest hope of two distinct groups of people: Republican operatives fearing what Donald Trump’s berserker candidacy might do to their party
column3: and ordinary citizens simply hoping to have a sane presidential candidate to vote for.

column1: Until this past week
column2: Kasich has not attracted much attention
column3: mainly because the current dynamic of media coverage encourages histrionics and preening. But by appearing halfway normal
column4: as he did at last Saturday’s debate in South Carolina
column5: and not engaging in theatrics about carpetbombing
column6: waterboarding
column7: or ripping up treaties
column8: he has become the default choice of those who would worry if Kasich’s opponents ever got their hands on the nuclear switch.

column1: He has the advantage (and disadvantage) of a long record. I had a chance to see him in action as I worked for him for 17 years on budget and armed services issues—although I’ve had no connection to him in over a decade
column2: or to his campaign
column3: and am now a political independent.

column1: In the 1980s
column2: at the dawn of his congressional career
column3: many members of his own party considered Kasich a conservative bomb thrower—he would offer his own budget
column4: something back-benchers weren’t supposed to do in those days. He has not changed ideologically or temperamentally—his 2011 effort to roll back labor protection for state employees was too extreme and Ohio voters overwhelmingly defeated it—but while Kasich has remained a staunch conservative
column5: much of his party has lurched so far right it has entered Bizarro World.

column1: This fact accounts for Kasich’s reputation as a RINO (Republican in name only) and why it may be more difficult for him to win his own party’s nomination than the general election. His apostasy in having Ohio accept Medicaid under the Affordable Care Act is unforgivable to Republicans who consider health insurance for the poor to be an instrument of Satan. Likewise
column2: in 1994 he voted for an assault weapons ban
column3: pure heresy for the burgeoning Ted Nugent wing of his party. Kasich’s practice of occasionally dissing wealthy GOP donors who are accustomed to blind deference is considered a minus among the party’s bigwigs.

column1: Those deeds might help
column2: though
column3: in a general election. So might his national security experience: 18 years on the House Armed Services Committee counts for far more involvement in that field than all his opponents combined. Refreshingly
column4: as a congressman he avoided the kneejerk military interventionism that is now mandatory for GOP candidates. He opposed authorizing the Marines’ mission in Lebanon in 1983; the bombing of the Marine barracks in October of that year and President Reagan’s decision to quickly withdraw vindicated Kasich’s stand.

column1: Similarly
column2: he opposed President Clinton’s bombing of Serbia
column3: which in his view amounted to a drive-by shooting with cruise missiles in a conflict in which no discernible U.S. interests were involved. He was also able to work across the aisle with Democrats to put a stake through the heart of the B-2 bomber
column4: a Cold War anachronism
column5: which at $2.2 billion a copy had become an unaffordable luxury.

column1: As Budget Committee chairman
column2: Kasich was also present at the creation of the first balanced budget since the Eisenhower era. While other factors
column3: such as an avalanche of revenues from the dot.com bubble
column4: set the stage for the achievement
column5: he had a formidable job just to keep his own colleagues on task. The defense hawks were always itching to bust the budget caps with more Pentagon spending. And then-Speaker Newt Gingrich
column6: who appeared to suffer from ADD
column7: occasionally threatened to derail the difficult march to a balanced budget with novel and unvetted policy visions.

column1: The general election downside? Just as there are legitimate questions about Hillary Clinton’s receiving $675
column2: 000 from Goldman Sachs for three speeches
column3: Kasich as a nominee would surely face scrutiny over his eight years as a managing director at Lehman Brothers. The investment bank’s collapse in September 2008
column4: the biggest bankruptcy in U.S. history
column5: nearly pitched the global economy into the abyss. Lawsuits to settle the dismantling of Lehman are still reverberating through the financial world. Ohio voters gave him a pass
column6: but national inspection of his record would be more thorough—certainly if Clinton’s campaign had anything to do with it.

column1: Stories occasionally surface about Kasich’s anger management problem. As a former employee
column2: I can corroborate those allegations
column3: as well as his tendency to preachy self-righteousness that is a constant temptation of professional politicians. These are
column4: perhaps
column5: pardonable sins both in view of the tasteless vaudeville act being played out by several of his GOP competitors
column6: and his own positive accomplishments."	REAL

column1: 2006 Audio Emerges of Hillary Clinton Proposing Rigging Palestine Election	"On September 5
column3: Eli Chomsky was an editor and staff writer for the Jewish Press
column4: and Hillary Clinton was running for a shoo-in re-election as a U.S. senator. Her trip making the rounds of editorial boards brought her to Brooklyn to meet the editorial board of the Jewish Press.

column1: The tape was never released and has only been heard by the small handful of Jewish Press staffers in the room. According to Chomsky
column2: his old-school audiocassette is the only existent copy and no one has heard it since 2006
column3: until today when he played it for the Observer.

column1: The tape is 45 minutes and contains much that is no longer relevant
column2: such as analysis of the re-election battle that Sen. Joe Lieberman was then facing in Connecticut. But a seemingly throwaway remark about elections in areas controlled by the Palestinian Authority has taken on new relevance amid persistent accusations in the presidential campaign by Clinton’s Republican opponent Donald Trump that the current election is “rigged.”

column1: Speaking to the Jewish Press about the January 25
column3: election for the second Palestinian Legislative Council (the legislature of the Palestinian National Authority)
column4: Clinton weighed in about the result
column5: which was a resounding victory for Hamas (74 seats) over the U.S.-preferred Fatah (45 seats).

column1: “I do not think we should have pushed for an election in the Palestinian territories. I think that was a big mistake
column2: ” said Sen. Clinton. “And if we were going to push for an election
column3: then we should have made sure that we did something to determine who was going to win.”

column1: Chomsky recalls being taken aback that “anyone could support the idea—offered by a national political leader
column2: no less—that the U.S. should be in the business of fixing foreign elections.”

column1: Some eyebrows were also raised when then-Senator Clinton appeared to make a questionable moral equivalency.

Regarding capturing combatants in war—the June capture of IDF soldier Gilad Shalit by Hamas militants who came across the Gaza border via an underground tunnel was very much front of mind—Clinton can be heard on the tape saying
column2: “And then
column3: when
column4: you know
column5: Hamas
column6: you know
column7: sent the terrorists
column8: you know
column9: through the tunnel into Israel that killed and captured
column10: you know
column11: kidnapped the young Israeli soldier
column12: you know
column13: there’s a sense of like
column14: one-upsmanship
column15: and in these cultures of
column16: you know
column17: well
column18: if they captured a soldier
column19: we’ve got to capture a soldier.”

column1: Equating Hamas
column2: which to this day remains on the State Department’s official list of Foreign Terrorist Organizations
column3: with the armed forces of a close American ally was not what many expected to hear in the Jewish Press editorial offices
column4: which were then at Third Avenue and Third Street in Brooklyn. (The paper’s office has since moved to the Boro Park section of Brooklyn.) The use of the phrase “these cultures” is also a bit of a head-scratcher.

column1: According to Chomsky
column2: Clinton was “gracious
column3: personable and pleasant throughout” the interview
column4: taking about an hour to speak to
column5: in addition to himself
column6: managing editor Jerry Greenwald
column7: assistant to the publisher Naomi Klass Mauer
column8: counsel Dennis Rapps and senior editor Jason Maoz.

column1: Another part of the tape highlights something that was relatively uncontroversial at the time but has taken on new meaning in light of the current campaign—speaking to leaders with whom our country is not on the best terms. Clinton has presented a very tough front in discussing Russia
column2: for example
column3: accusing Trump of unseemly ardor for strongman Vladimir Putin and mocking his oft-stated prediction that as president he’d “get along” with Putin.

column1: Chomsky is heard on the tape asking Clinton what now seems like a prescient question about Syria
column2: given the disaster unfolding there and its looming threat to drag the U.S.
column3: Iran and Russia into confrontation.

column1: “Do you think it’s worth talking to Syria—both from the U.S. point [of view] and Israel’s point [of view]?”
Clinton replied
column2: “You know
column3: I’m pretty much of the mind that I don’t see what it hurts to talk to people. As long as you’re not stupid and giving things away. I mean
column4: we talked to the Soviet Union for 40 years. They invaded Hungary
column5: they invaded Czechoslovakia
column6: they persecuted the Jews
column7: they invaded Afghanistan
column8: they destabilized governments
column9: they put missiles 90 miles from our shores
column10: we never stopped talking to them
column11: ” an answer that reflects her mastery of the facts but also reflects a willingness to talk to Russia that sounds more like Trump 2016 than Clinton 2016.

column1: Shortly after
column2: she said
column3: “But if you say
column4: ‘they’re evil
column5: we’re good
column6: [and] we’re never dealing with them
column7: ’ I think you give up a lot of the tools that you need to have in order to defeat them…So I would like to talk to you [the enemy] because I want to know more about you. Because if I want to defeat you
column8: I’ve got to know something more about you. I need different tools to use in my campaign against you. That’s my take on it.”

column1: A final bit of interest to the current campaign involves an articulation of phrases that Trump has accused Clinton of being reluctant to use. Discussing the need for a response to terrorism
column2: Clinton said
column3: “I think you can make the case that whether you call it ‘Islamic terrorism’ or ‘Islamo-fascism
column4: ’ whatever the label is we’re going to give to this phenomenon
column5: it’s a threat. It’s a global threat. To Europe
column6: to Israel
column7: to the United States…Therefore we need a global response. It’s a global threat and it needs a global response. That can be the
column8: sort of
column9: statement of principle…So I think sometimes having the global vision is a help as long as you realize that underneath that global vision there’s a lot of variety and differentiation that has to go on.”

column1: It’s not clear what she means by a global vision with variety and differentiation
column2: but what’s quite clear is that the then-senator
column3: just five years after her state was the epicenter of the September 11 attacks
column4: was comfortable deploying the phrase “Islamic terrorism” and the even more strident “Islamo-fascism
column5: ” at least when meeting with the editorial board of a Jewish newspaper.

column1: In an interview before the Observer heard the tape
column2: Chomsky told the Observer that Clinton made some “odd and controversial comments” on the tape. The irony of a decade-old recording emerging to feature a candidate making comments that are suddenly relevant to voters today was not lost on Chomsky
column3: who wrote the original story at the time. Oddly enough
column4: that story
column5: headlined “Hillary Clinton on Israel
column6: Iraq and Terror
column7: ” is no longer available on jewishpress.com and even a short summary published on the Free Republic site offers a broken link that can no longer surface the story.

column1: “I went to my bosses at the time
column2: ” Chomsky told the Observer. “The Jewish Press had this mindset that they would not want to say anything offensive about anybody—even a direct quote from anyone—in a position of influence because they might need them down the road. My bosses didn’t think it was newsworthy at the time. I was convinced that it was and I held onto it all these years.”

column1: Disclosure: Donald Trump is the father-in-law of Jared Kushner
column2: publisher of Observer Media."	REAL

column1: Authorities search for clues after raid thwarts potential 'Belgian Charlie Hebdo' attack	"Belgian authorities were searching for clues early Friday after police killed two in raids aimed at jihadists returning from Syria who were planning to launch a ""Belgian Charlie Hebdo"" attack
column2: officials said.

column1: Police were searching in Verviers
column2: where the raid took place
column3: and the greater Brussels area as part of a weeklong investigation that started well before the terrorism spree last week that led to 17 deaths in the Paris area. The Belgian operations had no apparent link to the terrorist acts committed in France.

column1: And
column2: unlike the Paris terrorists
column3: who attacked the office of a satirical newspaper and a kosher grocery store
column4: the suspects in Belgium were reportedly aiming at hard targets: police installations.

column1: They were on the verge of committing important terror attacks
column2: federal magistrate Eric Van der Sypt said at a news conference in Brussels.

column1: Across Europe
column2: anxiety has grown as the manhunt continues for potential accomplices of the three Paris terrorists
column3: all of whom were shot dead by French police. Authorities in Belgium signaled they were ready for more trouble by raising the national terror alert level from 2 to 3
column4: the second-highest level.

column1: Prime Minister Charles Michel said the increase in the threat level was ""a choice for prudence.""
There is no concrete or specific knowledge of new elements of threat
column2: he said.

column1: The suspects in Verviers opened fire on police when they closed in on them near the city's train station
column2: the magistrate told reporters. There was an intense firefight for several minutes. Video posted online showed a dark view of a building amid blasts
column3: gunshots and sirens
column4: and a fire with smoke billowing up. Two terror suspects were killed in the shootout
column5: and another was arrested.

column1: No police were wounded or killed in the clash
column2: which occurred at the height of rush hour in a crowded neighborhood of this former industrial town of 56
column3: 000 about 80 miles southeast of the capital
column4: Brussels.

column1: Belgian news site L'Avenir
column2: as well as Le Soir and France24
column3: reported late Thursday that the government prosecutor's office said a dozen operations were launched against suspects across Belgium
column4: in Verviers
column5: Brussels and Hal-Vilvoorde. Some of those targeted are known to have returned recently from Syria.

column1: The Belgian news site reported that
column2: based on phone intercepts in the homes and cars of the three individuals involved in a shootout in Verviers
column3: authorities believed the three were in the process of carrying out imminent attacks inside Belgium.

column1: The French daily Le Soir is reporting that the investigations were launched against the Verviers suspects at least two weeks ago after they returned from Syria where they were thought to be involved in the fighting there.
The raids earlier Thursday included one on an apartment above a bakery in the eastern city of Verviers
column2: authorities said. Authorities said the terror cell had ties to ISIS and was planning a major attack.

column1: Earlier Thursday
column2: Belgian authorities said they were looking into possible links between a man they arrested in the southern city of Charleroi for illegal trade in weapons and Amedy Coulibaly
column3: who killed four people in a Paris kosher market last week.

column1: The man arrested in Belgium ""claims that he wanted to buy a car from the wife of Coulibaly
column2: Van der Sypt said. ""At this moment this is the only link between what happened in Paris.""

column1: Van der Sypt said that ""of course
column2: naturally"" we are continuing the investigation.

column1: At first
column2: the man came to police himself claiming there had been contact with Coulibaly's common-law wife regarding the car
column3: but he was arrested following a search of his premises when indications of illegal weapons trading were found.

column1: A Belgian connection figured in a 2010 French criminal investigation into a foiled terrorist plot in which Coulibaly was one of the convicted co-conspirators. The plotters included a Brussels-area contact who was supposed to furnish both weapons and ammunition
column2: according to French judicial documents obtained by The Associated Press.

column1: Several other countries are also involved in the hunt for possible accomplices to Coulibaly and the other gunmen in the French attacks
column2: brothers Cherif and Said Kouachi.

column1: In Spain
column2: authorities said Coulibaly drove his common-law wife from France to Madrid on Dec. 31 and was with her until she took a Jan. 2 flight to Istanbul.

column1: Spain's National Court said in a statement it was investigating what Coulibaly did in the country's capital with his wife
column2: Hayat Boumeddiene
column3: and a third person who wasn't identified but is suspected of helping Boumeddiene get from Turkey to Syria.

column1: France is on edge since last week's attacks
column2: which began at the satirical newspaper Charlie Hebdo. The paper
column3: repeatedly threatened for its caricatures of the Muslim Prophet Muhammad
column4: buried several of its slain staff members Thursday even as it reprinted another weekly issue with Muhammad on its cover.

column1: Also
column2: defense officials said France was under an unprecedented cyber assault with 19
column3: 000 cyberattacks launched after the country's bloodiest terrorist attacks in decades
column4: frustrating authorities as they try to thwart repeat violence.

column1: Around 120
column2: 000 security forces are deployed to prevent future attacks.

column1: Calling it an unprecedented surge
column2: Adm. Arnaud Coustilliere
column3: head of cyberdefense for the French military
column4: said about 19
column5: 000 French websites had faced cyberattacks in recent days
column6: some carried out by well-known Islamic hacker groups.

column1: The attacks
column2: mostly relatively minor denial-of-service attacks
column3: hit sites as varied as military regiments to pizza shops but none appeared to have caused serious damage

DONALD J. TRUMP CONTRACT WITH THE AMERICAN VOTER

column9: and public health); THIRD

column1: On the same day

column1: Next

column7: and the trillions of dollars of American corporate money overseas can now be brought back at a 10 percent rate. 'Spinning up as we speak': Email shows Pentagon was ready to roll as Benghazi attack occurred	"As the attack on the U.S. consulate in Benghazi was unfolding
column2: a high-ranking Pentagon official urgently messaged Secretary of State Hillary Clinton’s top deputies to offer military help
column3: according to an email obtained by Judicial Watch.

column1: The revelation appears to contradict testimony Defense Secretary Leon Panetta gave lawmakers in 2013
column2: when he said there was no time to get forces to the scene in Libya
column3: where four Americans were killed
column4: including U.S. Ambassador to Libya Christopher Stevens.

column1: “I just tried you on the phone but you were all in with S [apparent reference to then-Secretary of State Hillary Clinton]
column2: ” reads the email
column3: from Panetta’s chief of staff Jeremy Bash. “After consulting with General Dempsey
column4: General Ham and the Joint Staff
column5: we have identified the forces that could move to Benghazi. They are spinning up as we speak.”

column1: The email was sent out at 7:19 p.m. ET on Sept. 11
column3: in the early stages of the eight-hour siege that also claimed the lives of Foreign Service Information Management Officer Sean Smith and two former Navy SEALs
column4: Ty Woods and Glen Doherty
column5: private CIA contractors who raced to the aid of embattled State Department workers.

column1: Although the email came after the first wave of the attack at the consulate
column2: it occurred before a mortar strike on the CIA annex killed Woods and Doherty.

column1: “This leaves no doubt military assets were offered and ready to go
column2: and awaiting State Department signoff
column3: which did not come
column4: ” Judicial Watch
column5: a nonprofit government watchdog said in a statement.

column1: Parts of the email from Bash were redacted before release
column2: including details on what military forces were available.

column1: In defending the Obama administration’s lack of a military response to the attack
column2: Panetta told the Senate Armed Services Committee nearly two years ago that “time
column3: distance
column4: the lack of an adequate warning
column5: events that moved very quickly on the ground prevented a more immediate response.”

column1: The first assault occurred at the consulate at 3:40 p.m. ET. The second attack on the CIA annex a little over a mile away began three hours later. Bash’s email was sent approximately 40 minutes after that attack began.
Bash’s email
column2: which bore the subject line “Libya
column3: ” was sent to Clinton’s then-deputy chief of staff Jacob Sullivan
column4: Deputy Secretary of State for Political Affairs Wendy Sherman and Deputy Secretary of State for Management and Resources Thomas Nides.

column1: The attack came in three waves at two locations. It began when a handful of attackers scaled the wall of the diplomatic post at dusk and opened a gate
column2: allowing dozens of armed men inside who then set the building on fire. Stevens and Smith died after breathing in smoke while hiding in a safe room
column3: and later died.

column1: Hours later
column2: a nearby CIA annex was attacked twice. Woods and Doherty died there while defending the annex from the rooftop. A team of six security officials summoned from Tripoli and a Libyan military unit helped evacuate the remaining U.S. personnel who were taken to an airport and flown out of Benghazi.

column1: The Obama administration later falsely claimed that the attack was triggered by an Internet video that insulted Islam.
Lawmakers investigating the events surrounding Benghazi already had acquired the e-mail
column2: along with tens of thousands of others related to the probe
column3: according to Matt Wolking
column4: spokesman for the House Select Committee on Benghazi.

column1: “The Select Committee has obtained and reviewed tens of thousands of documents in the course of its thorough
column2: fact-centered investigation into the Benghazi terrorist attacks
column3: and this information will be detailed in the final report the Committee hopes to release within the next few months
column4: Wolking told FoxNews.com. ""While the Committee does not rush to release or comment on every document it uncovers
column5: I can confirm that we obtained the unredacted version of this email last year
column6: in addition to Jake Sullivan’s response."""	REAL

column1: A Case Study On Why The Obamacare Lawsuit Is Based On Mythical History	"The Bentley administration
column2: the Alabama legislature and the governor’s Alabama Health Insurance Exchange Study Commission weighed many of the same issues their counterparts in other states did. How would they finance the exchange's operations? Should a state agency or some other entity manage a new marketplace? How heavily should insurance companies be regulated? Would it better for Alabama to exert at least a little control over Obamacare
column3: or to just let the U.S. Department of Health and Human Services do the work?

column1: If that was the case four years ago
column2: no one told Alabama state Sen. Jim McClendon (R)
column3: a native English speaker who co-chaired Bentley’s commission while a member of the state House of Representatives
column4: which unanimously passed a bill in April 2012 to establish an Alabama health insurance exchange.

column1: “No. No. No. That was never
column2: never brought up
column3: ” McClendon said in an interview with The Huffington Post last month. “I was unaware of that stipulation in the Affordable Care Act
column4: and I would almost have to guess that anybody involved in this process was not aware of it. I was a little surprised when it came up eventually. Nope. I was the chairman of the commission and I was totally unaware of that.”

column1: “Never. It was never discussed
column2: ” said Carey
column3: who also worked with Delaware and Tennessee on their exchanges at the time
column4: when he was a subcontractor working for LMI
column5: a Tysons
column6: Virginia-based government contractor. “It was never a consideration that they weren’t going to get subsidies if they deferred to the feds. I mean
column7: I was there at every commission meeting and I was presenting
column8: ‘Here are your options
column9: here’s what I think it might cost you
column10: ’ and we did those type of calculations.""

column1: I don’t remember that coming up. I really don’t. I really don’t ever remember that ever being brought up as an issue... I don’t ever remember anybody saying
column2: ‘Well
column3: if we do this and let the feds do it
column4: this is the trade-off down the road'... I’m almost positive somebody would’ve brought it up... During the time
column5: we didn’t know that. After the commission
column6: that’s when all that stuff started coming out. We were like
column7: ‘Oh
column8: wait a minute.’ That could’ve really changed
column9: obviously
column10: the advice to the governor
column11: because I don’t think he would’ve even said we’re not going to do it if it was clear at that point in time
column12: all the way back four
column13: five years ago
column14: that if you don’t do this
column15: here’s the side effect. Because that’s a huge trade-off.

column1: Wren was the author of the health insurance exchange bill the state House passed in April 2012
column2: and he championed a state-run marketplace until Bentley’s final decision in December of that year to forgo a state exchange. Wren told HuffPost he still believes Alabama should have its own exchange.

column1: Wren claimed in an interview that he was aware
column2: early on
column3: of a provision in the law that would restrict subsidies to those who purchased coverage on state exchanges. But in a subsequent email
column4: his account shifted. Wren first said that issue came to his attention in 2009
column5: before Obamacare had even passed. In a subsequent email
column6: he wrote that he had misspoken during the interview
column7: and said he'd actually learned of this phrase in 2011.

column1: “I believed at the time that for many reasons
column2: including the possible favorable premium treatment to individuals purchasing from a state exchange
column3: that Alabama should consider this over a federal
column4: ” he wrote.

column1: Greg Wren
column2: then a member of the Alabama House of Representatives

column1: There is little evidence to back Wren's claim that he was aware of the now-controversial provision in Obamacare during his state’s debate over whether to establish an exchange. The former legislator could not offer an explanation for why his version of events differs from those of McClendon and the others interviewed for this article
column2: or why it isn’t reflected in official documents or media accounts from the time.

column1: “At this point I can only say is [sic] I remembered back as best I could
column2: ” he wrote in an email.

column1: Wren also acknowledged that he has no documentation from 2010 through 2012 to support his assertions that he understood the phrase “established by the state” could mean that subsidies wouldn’t be available in federal exchanges. The Alabama legislature does not transcribe floor or committee proceedings
column2: so no official record exists of the debate on Wren’s bill.

column1: Wren was often quoted in the local and national press speaking about the advantages of state-run health insurance exchanges in 2011 and 2012
column2: but HuffPost couldn’t find any articles that cited him saying the subsidies wouldn’t be available in federal exchanges."	REAL

column1: Donald Trump's GOP civil war	"Panama City
column2: Florida (CNN) Donald Trump is tearing the Grand Old Party apart.

column1: The tension that has simmered in the Republican Party for years -- shutting down the government and nearly bringing the nation to default -- escalated into an outright civil war Tuesday. The conflict not only threatens the party's ability to make any realistic attempt at reclaiming the White House next month
column2: but also previews the conflicts and divides that could consume the GOP for years to come if Trump loses.

column1: On one side is Trump
column2: who spent much of Tuesday lashing out on social media at his GOP foes
column3: such as Speaker Paul Ryan and Sen. John McCain
column4: and lamenting the lack of party unity. He's backed by conservative lawmakers including Iowa Rep. Steve King and the throngs of loyal supporters who attend his rallies
column5: including the one here in Panama City
column6: Florida
column7: Tuesday
column8: where he renewed his call for a government investigation into his opponent
column9: Hillary Clinton.

column1: Some are even raising the potential of denying Ryan the speakership after the election.
On the other side is Ryan
column2: who is devoting the full resources of his stature to maintaining a congressional majority. That dominance of Capitol Hill is suddenly threatened -- and not just in the Senate
column3: where there are many competitive races
column4: but also in the House
column5: where the GOP majority was considered untouchable until recently.

column1: The infighting -- sparked by the release Friday of a 2005 video depicting Trump describing women in vulgar and sexually aggressive terms -- isn't likely to ease in the 27 days before Election Day. Trump made clear Tuesday that if he loses in November
column2: he won't go down quietly -- or alone.

column1: He began the day with a series of shots -- taken over Twitter -- at Ryan
column2: saying it's hard to do well when the speaker isn't supportive. He followed up about an hour later calling Ryan a ""weak and ineffective leader.""

column1: And nearly two hours after that
column2: Trump posed his most explosive tweet of the day.

column1: 'Shackles have been taken off me'
Trump continued his attacks on Ryan Wednesday during a rally in central Florida
column2: where he said he's at a disadvantage when ""you have leadership not putting their weight behind the people.""

column1: He also complained about getting no credit from party leaders for his Sunday night debate performance.

Wouldn't you think Paul Ryan would call and say good job?"" he said. ""It got just about the largest audience for a second night debate in the history of the country. You'd think they'd say great going
column2: Don
column3: let's beat this crook. No
column4: he doesn't.""

column1: Trump's turn on his own party may seem counterproductive -- it hardly allows him to improve his chances of catching Clinton. But it does allow him the satisfaction of vengeance against party leaders he believes have never treated him fairly since his stunning outsider campaign captured the nomination earlier this year.
And by blaming Republican leaders for their failure to wholeheartedly endorse his campaign
column2: Trump also opens up the possibility of a face-saving excuse if he crashes to defeat in November.

column1: But the cost to the Republican Party of Trump's burn-it-down-around-him strategy is already high
column2: could become more extreme and potentially leave the GOP badly damaged long after he has left the political scene.

column1: To begin with
column2: the estrangement between Trump and the party leaders is blowing open a gaping split between the party's grass roots and its establishment leaders that Republican National Committee Chairman Reince Priebus and others worked so hard to bridge over the summer.

column1: It is a divide that will be hard to overcome if Trump loses the election. Forging unity could be impossible if hordes of Trump voters blame party leaders for the defeat of a man who electrified the grass roots supporters in a way no other Republican has managed in decades.
King
column2: the Iowa Republican congressman
column3: warned Tuesday that a purge of party elites might be necessary
column4: saying ""the establishment wing of the party could simply be amputated out in this effort that's going on right now.""

column1: They've gone so far out on this limb
column2: King said on the Laura Ingraham radio show.

column1: The meltdown in the GOP is the culmination of forces that have been building for years. Intense antipathy towards congressional leaders over their failure to more forcefully oppose President Barack Obama gave rise to the Tea Party and sent waves of anti-establishment lawmakers to Washington in successive elections.

Trump's adoption of a factually-challenged style of campaigning would have been impossible without the power of conservative media that has been building for decades and is now fused with the GOP presidential ticket through the role of Stephen Bannon
column2: the head of Breitbart News
column3: who serves as the CEO of the Trump campaign.

column1: Trump's turn against his own party could also reverberate in down-ballot races. Republicans have long known that their hold on the Senate was tenuous -- whoever ran at the top of their ticket -- but Trump's slumping poll numbers now threaten to drag down vulnerable incumbents too.
At the very least
column2: a Trump implosion that cuts deeply into Ryan's majority could complicate the Speaker's already tough task of corralling his volatile majority coalition. If an anti-Trump landslide sweeps away House GOP members in more moderate districts
column3: it could hand more relative power to the ultra-conservative Freedom Caucus and give him the same kinds of fits that it imposed on John Boehner
column4: his predecessor.

column1: The dilemma is especially difficult for Republican senators running for re-election. Some are rejecting Trump because of revulsion at his remarks among more moderate voters. But at the same time
column2: they risk alienating Trump supporters in states's where the former reality star racked up high margins in the primary race.

column1: New Hampshire Sen. Kelly Ayotte fits into this category and her desperate effort to walk the fine line between condemning and embracing Trump during this election has become a symbol of the wider GOP conundrum. Ayotte finally said she could not vote for Trump after the video emerged on Friday.
But another star of the GOP
column2: Florida Sen. Marco Rubio
column3: said Tuesday he's not yet ready to back away from Trump. Rubio looks certain to need Trump voters to maintain his narrow lead in his re-election race. But at the same time
column4: if more explosive video emerges about Trump
column5: Rubio
column6: who has presidential ambitions in his future
column7: risks being tarnished by association with the Republican nominee.

column1: Another lawmaker in a tough re-election race who is hedging his bets is North Carolina GOP Sen. Richard Burr
column2: who said that while Trump's comments were ""indefensible
column3: he still plans to support him.

column1: For her part
column2: the turmoil consuming the GOP would seem to provide a substantial boost to Clinton's White House bid. An NBC News/Wall Street Journal poll released Tuesday found the Democratic nominee enjoying a 9-point lead among likely voters in a four-way race.

column1: But her aides caution against excessive optimism. There's concern inside the campaign that an increasingly negative race -- which could only become darker in the days ahead -- could turn off voters and make them less likely to show up at the polls. In that instance
column2: a lower turnout could create an advantage for Trump.

column1: This seems to be their strategy
column2: disgust everyone with our democratic dialogue so that they won't come out to the polls
column3: John Podesta
column4: Clinton's campaign chairman
column5: told reporters Tuesday. ""I think it is very unbecoming a presidential candidate.""

column1: Clinton said as much herself during an interview with a Florida radio station Tuesday.
Despite all of the terrible things (Trump) has said and done
column2: he is still trying to win this election
column3: she said. ""And we cannot be complacent
column4: we cannot rest."""	REAL

column1: Israel stole classified US information and used it to help congressional Republicans	"The Wall Street Journal's Adam Entous dropped a huge story Tuesday morning: Israel acquired classified US information while spying on the Iranian nuclear negotiations
column2: and leaked the stolen information about the emerging deal to American lawmakers in an attempt to sabotage the Obama administration's outreach to Tehran.

column1: This is yet another disaster for US-Israel relations. But that's not because Israel acquired classified US information
column2: which honestly isn't that surprising. What's really outrageous is that Israel used the information in a deliberate attempt to manipulate American politics.

column1: No one should be shocked that Israel was spying on the talks. A certain degree of espionage is pretty par for the course in world politics
column2: even among allies. Indeed
column3: as Entous' story repeatedly makes clear
column4: American officials expected Israel to snoop on them. In fact
column5: according to Entous
column6: the US found out about the Israeli spying because it was already spying on Israel:

column1: But there is a real scandal here
column2: and that's Israel using stolen intelligence as part of a deliberate campaign of messing around with American partisan politics. That's why the White House is angry: ""It is one thing for the U.S. and Israel to spy on each other. It is another thing for Israel to steal U.S. secrets and play them back to U.S. legislators to undermine U.S. diplomacy
column3: a senior US official told Entous.

column1: If Entous' reporting is correct
column2: the Israeli government used the leaked information to help Republicans build support for new sanctions among Democrats
column3: which would be necessary to overcome Obama's veto. Israel was using stolen information to help Mitch McConnell and John Boehner foment a Democratic rebellion against the president.

column1: This is the same reason Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu's speech to Congress about Iran infuriated so many Democrats this month. The problem wasn't that Netanyahu was invited to Congress; it's that the speech was coordinated with Republicans behind the president's back in a deliberate attempt to undermine his Iran policy.
The spying/briefing allegations suggest the speech was part of a much broader campaign to help Republicans pass new sanctions
column2: a particularly dangerous move by Netanyahu at a time when Israel is at risk of becoming a partisan issue in America.

column1: Allies really aren't supposed to do this sort of thing. Playing partisan domestic politics — and doing it with classified information
column2: no less — positions Israel as the Republican Party's ally
column3: not America's. The fact that Republican interests line up with Israel's in this case doesn't justify crossing these lines.

column1: None of this is to say the Netanyahu government has to just sit down and accept an American Iran policy it opposes. It's perfectly within bounds for Netanyahu to publicly oppose the ongoing negotiations in which international powers are seeking to limit Iran's nuclear capabilities in exchange for relief on its crippling economic sanctions. It's fine for Netanyahu to lobby the French
column2: who have an important role in the negotiations
column3: to push for more stringent limits on Iran's nuclear program. That's all normal international politics."	REAL

column1: "America has a simple ideology": how one of Russia's top US experts explains America	"The United States comes up constantly when you talk to Russians about their country's place in the world. But the conversations tend to go a lot differently than many Americans might expect.
In the US
column2: the common view is that Russians feel aggrieved by the loss of the Soviet Union and all the respect that came with being a global superpower. Russia's acts of aggression in Europe
column3: in this telling
column4: are all about challenging the American-led order as a way to prove Russia's might and importance. This aggression is wildly popular among Russians
column5: many Americans believe
column6: because it makes them feel patriotic and powerful to bully the West
column7: and particularly the US
column8: which they blame for Russia's problems.

column1: Russia took off its ideological blinders in 1991
column2: but America still seems to have them on""

column1: There is certainly truth to this
column2: but it's just a piece of the truth. Rather
column3: when you speak to influential people across institutions and the political spectrum in Russia
column4: as Amanda Taub and I did during a recent reporting trip there
column5: the story you hear over and over is one of Russia's fundamental weakness. And you hear a preoccupation with the United States that goes far beyond what even many Americans
column6: who are famously narcissistic about our country
column7: would expect.

column1: In this telling
column2: Moscow capitulated at the end of the Cold War
column3: and even tried to make itself a friend to the far more powerful United States. But an irrationally aggressive America has instead sought repeatedly to weaken
column4: control
column5: or even destroy Russia. Their country
column6: in this view
column7: is insecure against an overwhelmingly powerful West. Its actions that we see as aggressive are actually defensive. And Moscow is kept safe only by careful vigilance and by the nuclear arsenal that you hear Russians cite over and over.

column1: This is the version of history you hear in Russia from detached foreign policy pragmatists
column2: from pro-Putin ideologues and anti-Putin ideologues
column3: even from members of the pro-Western political opposition who support what they believe be to a Western agenda of weakening Russia.

column1: There's a quote that speaks perfectly to this Russian worldview — and how Americans misunderstand it — in the most recent issue of Russia in Global Affairs
column2: a Russian foreign policy journal that is widely considered to reflect the views of Russia's foreign policy establishment. The quote is from a Q&A with Vladimir Lukin
column3: a prominent Russian diplomat and liberal politician who previously served as ambassador to the US:

column1: Interviewer: In his 1994 book ""Diplomacy
column2: Henry Kissinger writes that ""integrating Russia into the international system is a key task"" for the United States. But as he was saying this
column3: the Americans were actually pushing Moscow away with their policy. Why? Vladimir Lukin: It is in the genes. America has a simple ideology – that there is only one truth in the world
column4: that truth is held by God
column5: and God created the United States to be an embodiment of that truth. So the Americans strive to bring this truth to the rest of the world and to make it happy. Only after that will everything be well. This ideology has a strong influence on their policy. A wise traditionalist and a geopolitical expert
column6: Kissinger had good reason to call such politicians ""Trotskyites"" for advocating a world revolution
column7: albeit in their own way
column8: but always in the front and in shining armor. This is a tempting ideology and has been professed by different countries at different times
column9: not only the United States.

column1: Lukin is hardly seen as an anti-American hard-liner in Russia — rather
column2: he's considered to be an objective expert on the United States and a highly professional diplomat. He is a founding member of the liberal opposition party Yabloko. That he would get the United States so obviously wrong — what Americans would call defending democracy and human rights
column3: he sees as a far more radical and explicitly religious agenda of ""advocating a world revolution"" — is troubling. But his view is a common one
column4: and that tells you a great deal.

column1: The interviewer's response is similarly telling: ""So Russia took off its ideological blinders in 1991
column2: but America still seems to have them on. The Soviet Union is gone
column3: but the policy against it is not.""

column1: This narrative of an inherently aggressive America is one we heard over and over in Moscow
column2: not just from people who support Russian President Vladimir Putin and his aggressive
column3: anti-American policies but even from those who oppose them. In this view
column4: American politics and policies are bent on
column5: and in many ways driven by
column6: a hatred of Russia and desire to destroy or at least control it. Russia has had no choice but to meet American aggression with defensive actions such as putting nuclear-capable missiles in Europe or arming eastern Ukrainian militias at threat of genocidal extermination by American-backed fascists
column7: if only to deter the US from further actions that could lead to all-out war.

column1: It's not hard to poke holes in this Russian worldview. As Stephen Sestanovich
column2: a longtime senior State Department official who helped engineer the Clinton administration's Russia policies
column3: wrote in a recent article for the American Interest
column4: even the ""pragmatic"" Russian case for annexing Crimea in March 2014 makes little strategic sense:

column1: Yet this was the worldview we heard even from professionals and politicians in Russia who oppose anti-Western policies. One foreign policy expert who wished for rapprochement with the West sighed to us that it would be impossible because Hillary Clinton
column2: whom he said was widely viewed as irrationally anti-Russian
column3: would soon take office. At another meeting
column4: a political opposition leader remarked offhand that he hoped the US would be successful in its efforts to engineer regime change in Moscow.

column1: As Sestanovich writes in his essay
column2: ""The idea that the United States aims at a 'color revolution' in Moscow is the single most frequently repeated theme of official Russian rhetoric."" This is more than paranoia or government propaganda; it is the accepted worldview: that Russia is under constant threat from a hostile and irrational United States.

column1: Lukin
column2: at another point in his Q&A
column3: lamented that the US had rejected Moscow's gestures at cooperation in the 1990s and instead sought to surround Russia with a hostile NATO alliance
column4: thus forcing Russia into a defensive crouch and creating today's tensions. ""It was the biggest mistake the West made
column5: he said
column6: ""and gradually led to the current situation.""

column1: These fears about America are likely to worsen in Russia if Hillary Clinton becomes president; many people told us she is seen by many Russians
column2: especially Russian policymakers
column3: as unbendingly hostile to Moscow and bent on the Putin government's destruction.

column1: Hillary is the worst option of any president
column2: Fyodor Lukyanov
column3: an influential Russian foreign policy expert who edits a leading foreign affairs journal and heads a foreign policy think tank
column4: told us.

column1: Many people here believe that [she and her team] will try to come back to the line of the 1990s to encourage Russia into an internal transformation
column2: Lukyanov added. ""Not by force
column3: of course
column4: but to encourage some kind of social development that will upend the current system and will promote a new one.""

column2: he would turn the funds over to charity.

column1: “If I had a choice of making lots of money or imparting lots of knowledge
column2: I think I’d be as happy to impart knowledge as to make money
column3: ” Trump said at the inaugural news conference in the spring of 2005.

column1: The launch of Trump University coincided with two auspicious developments for the real estate mogul: Through his then-year-old hit TV show “The Apprentice
column2: ” the billionaire was developing an image as America’s savviest boss
column3: while the nation’s booming real estate market was giving hope to many who dreamed of striking it rich.

column1: Ads touted Trump University as “the next best thing to being Trump’s apprentice.” Trump
column2: who every week on TV singled out someone to be fired
column3: pledged in a promotional video to “hand-pick” instructors. “Priceless information” would help attendees build wealth in the same real estate game that made Trump rich.

column1: In the end
column2: few if any of these statements would prove to be true.

column1: Trump University was not a university. It was not even a school. Rather
column2: it was a series of seminars held in hotel ballrooms across the country that promised attendees they could get rich quick but were mostly devoted to enriching the people who ran them.

column1: Participants were enticed with local newspaper ads featuring images of Trump
column2: then encouraged to write checks or charge tens of thousands of dollars on credit cards for multi-day learning sessions. Participants were considered “buyers
column3: ” as one internal document put it. According to the company’s former president
column4: Trump did not personally pick the instructors. Many attendees were trained by people with little or no real estate expertise
column5: customers and former employees have alleged in lawsuits against the company.

column1: “I was told to do one thing
column2: ” said James Harris
column3: a Trump University instructor whose sessions have been repeatedly cited in the litigation
column4: in an interview with The Washington Post. “And that one thing was: . . . to show up to teach
column5: train and motivate people to purchase the Trump University products and services and make sure everybody bought. That is it.”

column1: A Trump spokesman said Harris’s comments “have no merit” and accused Harris of “looking for media attention to further his own agenda.”
All told
column2: Trump University received about $40 million in revenue from more than 5
column3: 000 participants before it halted operations in 2010 amid lawsuits in New York and California alleging widespread fraud. The New York attorney general estimated Trump netted more than $5 million during the five years it was active. He has since acknowledged that he gave none of the profits to charity.

column1: This account is based on a review of hundreds of pages of internal company records that have become public as a result of the lawsuits
column2: as well as new interviews with former Trump University employees and customers.

column1: Many of the company’s internal records
column2: including several “playbooks” that advised employees on strategies for pressuring customers
column3: were unsealed in court over the past week in response to a request by The Post.

column1: Trump and his lawyers have vigorously disputed the allegations
column2: predicting that they will win in court and reopen the business. They point to positive customer-satisfaction surveys that have been submitted in the lawsuits and suggest they have been unfairly targeted by trial lawyers and a politically motivated attorney general in New York.

column1: “We continue to believe that people got substantial value and that people were overwhelmingly satisfied
column2: ” said Trump’s general counsel
column3: Alan Garten. “We are not going to be stopping what we are doing. We are going to continue to zealously defend this case because
column4: at the end of the day
column5: we know we are not being tried by The Washington Post or by CNN — but in a courtroom by a jury.”

column1: Garten acknowledged that Trump never gave away the profits to charity. He said it was always Trump’s intention but that the lawyers leading the class-action suits against the company “got a hold of this and . . . whatever profits existed sort of evaporated.” The unfulfilled promise was first reported last year by Time magazine.
In his defense
column2: Trump has often cited the many positive reviews by former customers. A number of them submitted sworn statements in court explaining their positive experiences at Trump University.

column1: The focus on Trump University also reignited a controversy in Texas over the decision there by the state attorney general not to file a fraud case against the business. column2: ” “ready to sell

column1: “If they can afford the gold elite

column1: A 43-page “sales playbook” offered guidance on using psychological tools to convince students that they needed to sign up for the classes to fulfill their own goals — overcoming their worries that they might not need or be able to afford the classes.

column1: In a section devoted to “negotiating student resistance

Harris
column2: the former instructor

column4: Trump’s lawyer

For the four years Trump University operated

column3: 300 people attended the free introductory sessions. Those previews were offered 2

column3: you know

column1: Trump Has Forever Changed American Politics	"Trump Has Forever Changed American Politics > November 7
column3: 9:46 pm A+ | a- Warning

column1: “If I don’t win
column2: this will be the greatest waste of time
column3: money and energy in my lifetime
column4: ” says Donald Trump.

column1: Herewith
column2: a dissent. Whatever happens Tuesday
column3: Trump has made history and has forever changed American politics.

column1: Though a novice in politics
column2: he captured the Party of Lincoln with the largest turnout of primary voters ever
column3: and he has inflicted wounds on the nation’s ruling class from which it may not soon recover.

column1: Bush I and II
column2: Mitt Romney
column3: the neocons and the GOP commentariat all denounced Trump as morally and temperamentally unfit. Yet
column4: seven of eight Republicans are voting for Trump
column5: and he drew the largest and most enthusiastic crowds of any GOP nominee.

column1: Not only did he rout the Republican elites
column2: he ash-canned their agenda and repudiated the wars into which they plunged the country.

column1: Trump did not create the forces that propelled his candidacy. But he recognized them
column2: tapped into them
column3: and unleashed a gusher of nationalism and populism that will not soon dissipate.

column1: Whatever happens Tuesday
column2: there is no going back now.

column1: How could the Republican establishment advance anew the trade and immigration policies that their base has so thunderously rejected?
How can the GOP establishment credibly claim to speak for a party that spent the last year cheering a candidate who repudiated the last two Republican presidents and the last two Republican nominees?
Do mainstream Republicans think that should Trump lose a Bush Restoration lies ahead? The dynasty is as dead as the Romanovs .
The media
column2: whose reputation has sunk to Congressional depths
column3: has also suffered a blow to its credibility.

column1: Its hatred of Trump has been almost manic
column2: and WikiLeaks revelations of the collusion between major media and Clintonites have convinced skeptics that the system is rigged and the referees of democracy are in the tank.

column1: But it is the national establishment that has suffered most.
The Trump candidacy exposed what seems an unbridgeable gulf between this political class and the nation in whose name it purports to speak.
Consider the litany of horrors it has charged Trump with.
He said John McCain was no hero
column2: that some Mexican illegals are “ rapists .” He mocked a handicapped reporter. He called some women “pigs.” He wants a temporary ban to Muslim immigration. He fought with a Gold Star mother and father. He once engaged in “ fat-shaming ” a Miss Universe
column3: calling her “Miss Piggy
column4: ” and telling her to stay out of Burger King. He allegedly made crude advances on a dozen women and starred in the “Access Hollywood” tape with Billy Bush.

column1: While such “gaffes” are normally fatal for candidates
column2: Trump’s followers stood by him through them all.

column1: Why? asks an alarmed establishment. Why
column2: in spite of all this
column3: did Trump’s support endure? Why did the American people not react as they once would have? Why do these accusations not have the bite they once did?

column1: Answer. We are another country now
column2: an us-or-them country.

column1: Middle America believes the establishment is not looking out for the nation but for retention of its power. And in attacking Trump it is not upholding some objective moral standard but seeking to destroy a leader who represents a grave threat to that power.
Trump’s followers see an American Spring as crucial
column2: and they are not going to let past boorish behavior cause them to abandon the last best chance to preserve the country they grew up in.

column1: These are the Middle American Radicals
column2: the MARs of whom my late friend Sam Francis wrote.

column1: They recoil from the future the elites have mapped out for them and
column2: realizing the stakes
column3: will overlook the faults and failings of a candidate who holds out the real promise of avoiding that future.

column1: They believe Trump alone will secure the borders and rid us of a trade regime that has led to the loss of 70
column2: 000 factories and 5 million manufacturing jobs since NAFTA. They believe Trump is the best hope for keeping us out of the wars the Beltway think tanks are already planning for the sons of the “deplorables” to fight.

column1: Moreover
column2: they see the establishment as the quintessence of hypocrisy. Trump is instructed to stop using such toxic phrases as “America First” and “Make America Great Again” by elites who think 55 million abortions since Roe is a milestone of moral progress.

column1: And what do they have in common with a woman who thinks partial-birth abortion
column2: which her predecessor in the Senate
column3: Pat Moynihan
column4: called “ infanticide
column5: ” is among the cherished “reproductive rights” of women?

column1: While a Trump victory would create the possibility of a coalition of conservatives
column2: populists
column3: patriots and nationalists governing America
column4: should he lose
column5: America’s future appears disunited and grim.

column1: But
column2: would the followers of Donald Trump
column3: whom Hillary Clinton has called “racist
column4: sexist
column5: homophobic
column6: xenophobic
column7: Islamophobic … bigots
column8: ” to the cheers of her media retainers

column1: No. Win or lose
