column1: • the Brics; and
• Iran and any other country that manages to escape Western domination.

The TTIP negotiations are struggling to make headway due to a conflict of interests and vast opposition in Europe. But that obstacle is now circumvented through the “Comprehensive Economic and Trade Agreement” (CETA) between Canada and the EU: a TTIP in disguise
column2: given that Canada is already party to NAFTA which also binds the USA. The EU will probably sign off CETA when the Canadian Prime Minister Trudeau visits Brussels this 27 October.

column1: The second weapon: penetrating the target countries from within. Leverage is drawn from the weak points that each country has to varying extents: corruption
column2: a greed for money
column3: political ascent
column4: secessionary movements fed by local power groups
column5: religious fanaticism
column6: the vulnerability of the great masses for political demagogy. Playing as well
column7: in certain cases
column8: on a justified popular dissatisfaction with the actions of their own government. The instruments used to penetrate? The so-called “non-governmental organizations”. These are
column9: in actual fact
column10: the long hand of the Department of State and the CIA. These NGOs
column11: endowed with deep pools of financial resources
column12: have organized the Eastern European “colour revolutions” and replicated the same operation with the so-called “Umbrella Revolution” in Hong Kong
column13: aiming at developing similar movements in other parts of China where the national minorities live. The same organizations operate in Latin America
column14: with the primary objective of subverting Brazil’s democratic institutions
column15: thereby threatening Brics from within. Instruments to achieve the strategy are terrorist groups
column16: such as those armed and infiltrated in Libya and Syria to sow seeds of chaos
column17: contributing to destruction of whole States attacked at the same time from outside.

column1: The third arm: “Psyops” (Psychological operations)
column2: launched through the global media chains
column3: defined as follows by the Pentagon: “Planned Operations to influence
column4: through specific information
column5: the emotions and mindset
column6: and thus the conduct of public opinion
column7: organizations and foreign governments
column8: so as to induce or strengthen conduct favourable to pre-established objectives”.

column1: Such operations
column2: prepare public opinion for warlike escalation and create the impression that Russia is responsible for tensions in Europe just as China is for the tensions in Asia
column3: as well as accusing them at the same time of “violating human rights”.

column1: 1965: Manlio Dinucci
column2: and his wife
column3: Carla
column4: before the ancestral home of Mao Tse Toung. A final consideration: during the sixties
column5: my wife and I worked in Peking
column6: contributing
column7: inter alia
column8: to the publication of the first Chinese journal in the Italian language. I experienced a life-changing learning experience when China – liberated from the colonial
column9: semi-colonial and semi-feudal conditions for at least 15 years – was completely isolated. Neither the West nor the United Nations recognized it as a sovereign state. This period imprinted on my mind
column10: the ability of the Chinese people (at the time totalling 600 million)
column11: to resist
column12: their consciousness and commitment under the guide of the Communist party to constructing a society with a brand new economic and cultural foundation. I think that this capacity is today still needed so that today’s China
column13: that is developing its enormous potential
column14: can resist new plans for imperial domination and contribute to the decisive struggle for the future of humanity: a world free of wars; where peace
column15: inextricably linked to social justice
column16: prevails.

column1: Manlio Dinucci Translation
Anoosha Boralessa"	FAKE
The Daily 202: Many African Americans unenthusiastically ‘settle’ for Hillary Clinton	"RALEIGH
column2: N.C.—Ayana McAllister went to Hillary Clinton’s rally two weekends ago at St. Augustine’s University
column3: the historically-black school where she’s a freshman. She watched the Democratic nominee speak alongside the mothers of Trayvon Martin and Sandra Bland. But on the eve of the election
column4: the 18-year-old is still not 100 percent sold.

column1: “I don’t know
column2: ” said McAllister
column3: a native of Largo
column4: Md. “I feel like I’ve got to settle for Hillary. I feel like I’m going to vote because I know I need to
column5: not because I want to. I feel like neither of them should be president
column6: but I feel like Hillary will be better. Really
column7: it’s like two children arguing back and forth.”

column1: This was a common refrain during interviews at yesterday’s football game here between St. Augustine and crosstown rival Shaw University
column2: another historically-black institution.

column1: -- Early voting numbers and polling suggest that African American turnout is down nationally this year compared to 2012 and 2008. Though there are some signs that the gap has been closing in recent days
column2: alarm bells have clearly gone off inside the Clinton high command.

column1: -- Many students at the schools here in Raleigh regret that they never got to vote for Barack Obama. They are collectively disappointed that their first time forces them to choose between Clinton and Donald Trump
column2: but they plan to vote nonetheless. In fact
column3: teachers have told them that in lieu of class they will march to the polls on Tuesday.

column1: “I am not a fan of either one
column2: but of the two I will probably be voting for Hillary
column3: ” said Anoviua Rush
column4: a freshman from Durham. “She’s just a liar. And Hillary is not even good at backing up her lies. Everyone makes mistakes
column5: but when you try to cover them up it’s a problem.”

column1: As a marching band performed behind her
column2: under a cloudless sky on a perfect fall day
column3: Rush explained that the prospect of electing the first woman president does not motivate her
column4: but Clinton’s support for equal pay legislation does. “She’s more understanding of minorities and what we go through
column5: ” said Rush. “I’m not going to say he’s ‘racist
column6: ’ but he’s said some messed up stuff about minorities. … Donald’s main focus seems to be helping the wealthy and
column7: I’ll say it
column8: possibly Caucasians.”

column1: -- “A lot of people are very discouraged. Very
column2: very discouraged
column3: ” said Felishia McPherson
column5: who was wearing a “Black Lives Matter” t-shirt. “Really
column6: it’s like you’re choosing between a liar and a clown. But who doesn’t lie? We all lie. … I’m a mental health counselor. I know that
column7: psychologically
column8: in order to want to be president
column9: you’ve got to be a little narcissistic to start with. … Trump was never an option for me. I don’t love Hillary
column10: but I don’t have to. She’s not coming to my house. She’s going to the White House.”

column1: McPherson already voted early for Clinton. She brought her seven-year-old niece Malia
column2: named after the president’s daughter
column3: to Obama’s rally in Fayetteville on Friday. “I don’t know if I actually believe in the political system
column4: as far as does my one vote count? But I’m not going to take a chance of it not counting
column5: ” she explained afterward. “If the system really does work
column6: then I’m going to participate. If it doesn’t
column7: then I still did the best I could by my ancestors. … I do believe
column8: with Obama’s encouragement
column9: even though we may not believe in the system
column10: we know we need to do it.”

column1: -- Several elderly African Americans expressed deep concern that millennials
column2: including their grandchildren
column3: do not sufficiently appreciate the importance of voting. Irene Hill-Thomas
column5: is a retired special education teacher who now spends most of her time volunteering at church and a food pantry in Sampson County. “If you’ve been around long enough
column6: your eyes are open
column7: ” she said. “You appreciate it because you fought for it. The younger generation hasn’t been there. They don’t know. The younger generation doesn’t understand there was a time when we had to sit at the back of the bus and had no say so. … I remember the white and the colored fountains. They don’t.”

column1: -- North Carolina was the closest state Obama won in 2008 and the closest state he lost in 2012. African Americans accounted for 23 percent of the electorate both times
column2: and Obama won almost all of them.

column1: Reflecting the importance of the 15 electoral votes up for grabs in North Carolina
column2: and the strategic significance of the Research Triangle specifically
column3: both candidates will return to Raleigh on Monday. Trump will give an afternoon speech at the state fairgrounds
column4: and Clinton will hold the final rally of her campaign here -- at midnight.

column1: -- Another very important explanation for why African American turnout is down in North Carolina: Republicans have worked to limit early voting locations and hours. The executive director of the state Republican Party persuaded GOP county officials to limit early voting in troubling emails that have been unearthed by public records requests. He pushed to limit the number of hours sites were open
column2: especially evenings and Sundays
column3: when many African Americans typically cast ballots (after church services).

column1: In the Democratic-leaning county that includes Greensboro – the state’s third largest – there were 16 early voting sites in 2012 during the first week that polls were open. This year there was just one. So while 61
column2: 000 people voted during the first week four years ago
column3: only 8
column4: 000 did this year. (After that first week
column5: 25 voting sites were opened and turnout records were broken.)

column1: -- I shadowed a field staffer from the AFL-CIO affiliate group Working America as she canvassed in a predominantly black section of Raleigh yesterday afternoon. Walking across lawns in a hilly neighborhood just off Martin Luther King Jr. Blvd.
column2: Andrea Vogler urged folks to go vote.

column1: During a period of just one hour
column2: though
column3: half a dozen African Americans separately complained that they tried to vote early but the lines were too long. So they came home. They all said they hope to still go on Tuesday
column4: but what if the lines are long then too? Will they stick around?

column1: A woman in a nurse’s uniform said she went by the early voting site three times over the past week
column2: but the lines were too long each time.

column1: A younger man named Victor came to his door in red-checkered pajamas. He had gone earlier in the day too but said he was too tired to stand around. He works a night shift
column2: so he said he’s going to try voting on his drive home from work at 6:30 a.m. Tuesday – which he hopes will be before a crowd forms.

column1: “I’ve heard that on a couple of different days now
column2: ” Vogler
column4: lamented as she walked to the next house. “On the one hand
column5: it is good people are trying to vote. On the other
column6: I hope it doesn’t deter anyone from actually voting.”

column1: A woman named Barbara
column2: pulling out of her driveway in a Chevy Trailblazer with her infant son in the backseat
column3: is one of the people who gave up when she saw the lines.

column1: Damien
column2: her husband
column3: was who Vogler had come to talk with. Barbara warned her that he was sleeping. But every vote counts
column4: so the canvasser went to knock on the door anyway. He was nonplussed. “I worked all damn night
column5: 12 hours
column6: ” he said
column7: his eyes bloodshot. “I just want to go back to my bed.” She tried to hand him a piece of paper with bullet points on why he should vote for Clinton. He grimaced and refused to take it.

column1: Working America has about 700 field staffers farmed out across nine states. They have had 573
column2: 400 conversations with voters since launching this summer
column3: including 45
column4: 500 in North Carolina. In the Raleigh area alone
column5: the labor group had seven vans with five to seven people in each hitting doors on Saturday. The group largely targets African American and Latino voters
column6: though some swing white Republicans are in their universe.

column1: An older man sitting in his green Chevy Lumina
column2: picking his teeth with a toothpick outside a row of ground-level studio apartments
column3: told Vogler that he planned to vote later in the afternoon. She informed him that early voting had ended for the day
column4: and that Saturday was the final opportunity until Tuesday. “Damn
column5: ” he replied.

column1: “North Carolina is the most important state
column2: ” Vogler stressed over and over again. “You’ve got to get out to vote!”

column1: -- In an interview late last night
column2: I asked Democratic Senate candidate Deborah Ross – who is in a neck-and-neck race with Sen. Richard Burr that may decide which party controls the majority – about all these people who said they did not vote early because of the lines. “It’s by design
column3: ” she complained. But she argued that this will also galvanize many African Americans on Tuesday. “I don’t think anything is going to keep people from voting this year
column4: ” she said.

column1: Ross
column2: a former state representative who sponsored 2007 legislation allowing for same-day voter registration (which was pivotal to Obama carrying the state a year later)
column3: noted that
column4: for every person who returned home when they saw the crowded early voting sites
column5: many more waited around. “There were people who stood for hours in line
column6: ” she said.

column1: The weather forecast for Tuesday looks good
column2: and she believes this might make the difference in her “razor thin” race. “I think we’re going to see long lines on Election Day
column3: ” Ross predicted
column4: with a southern twang. “We’re going to turn people out.”

column1: A Clinton campaign official
column2: speaking anonymously
column3: said they were worried during the first week of early voting
column4: but the fact that hundreds of additional sites wound up opening for the second week made the situation much better and led to a huge increase in turnout. But allies say Clinton may need to perform especially well on Election Day to offset votes that were lost over the past two weeks.

column1: Surrogates have also streamed into the state to drive African Americans to the polls. Civil rights icon John Lewis headlined a march in Charlotte on Thursday. Cory Booker came Friday night. Other efforts are underway too. The national president of the Sierra Club was outside the St. Augustine’s football game handing out biscuits from Bojangles’ and urging young people to support Clinton in order to advance environmental issues.
-- The president himself has now spoken at five rallies for Clinton in North Carolina. Addressing a crowd of 2
column2: 500 that was probably 95 percent black in Fayetteville on Friday
column3: he made a very explicit pitch. “Right now
column4: Donald Trump is calling on his supporters to monitor ‘certain areas’ on Election Day
column5: ” Obama said. “I don’t know what ‘certain areas’ he’s talking about
column6: but you do.”

column1: He finished his speech with the story of a 100-year-old woman who was purged from the North Carolina voter rolls after a Republican challenged her registration status on flimsy grounds. Grace Bell Hardison was mentioned in an NAACP lawsuit that prompted a federal judge to issue an injunction on Friday. North Carolina election officials are now scrambling to restore the rights of thousands of voters – most black and Democratic -- who had been cut from the rolls under a so-called “individual challenge law.”
“So
column2: young people
column3: I want you to understand this
column4: ” Obama said. “It wasn’t that long ago when folks had to guess the number of jellybeans in a jar (or) the number of bubbles on a bar of soap. It wasn’t that long ago folks were beaten trying to register voters in Mississippi. … If you’ve been marching for criminal justice reform
column5: that’s great. But you still need to vote! … If you vote
column6: we’ll win North Carolina. And if we win North Carolina
column7: Hillary Clinton will be president.”

column1: WHILE YOU WERE SLEEPING:
-- Trump was rushed offstage during a campaign rally in Reno last night after a man reportedly yelled “gun
column2: ” but the GOP nominee emerged back onstage after a brief period to finish his speech. Secret Service officials said agents apprehended the man but found no weapon. The man
column3: who identified himself as Austyn Crites
column5: was reportedly released after the event
column6: telling reporters that he was attacked for holding a “Republicans against Trump” sign. “When I pulled out the sign
column7: people around me were trying to grab the sign
column8: ” Crites said. “And so all that was occurring was booing
column9: of course. That’s what you would expect.” He said that the crowd tackled him
column10: and began “kicking me and grabbing me in the crotch and just
column11: just beating the crap out of me.” (Jose A. DelReal
column12: Anne Gearan and Ed O'Keefe have more.)

column1: -- Donald Trump Jr. and top campaign social media aide Dan Scavino immediately retweeted unsubstantiated claims that Trump had just survived an attack on his life: “Hillary ran away from the rain today. Trump is back onstage minutes after assassination attempt
column2: ” the tweet read.

column1: -- Meanwhile
column2: a man wearing a mask and carrying a gun was arrested near the White House following a struggle with authorities. Immediate details surrounding the incident are unclear
column3: but the Secret Service says he's being charged with carrying a firearm without a license
column4: carrying unregistered ammunition
column5: resisting arrest and committing a crime while wearing a mask. (Martin Weil)

column1: -- A press bus following Tim Kaine in Tampa was hit “at high speed"" on Sunday evening
column2: according to several people onboard. One reporter said the bus was hit by what appeared to be a police car. But there were no reports of injuries and the bus continued. Kaine was several cars ahead of the press bus
column3: according to reporters in his motorcade.

column1: -- Our WaPo/ABC News tracking poll finds Clinton leading Trump nationally by five points -- 48 percent to 43 percent -- widening last week’s tight race as she shows clear advantages on several personal attributes:
-- The Wall Street Journal/NBC poll finds Clinton up a similar four points (44-40). Clinton’s lead is less than half of the 11-point advantage she held in their mid-October survey
column2: taken before the FBI email announcement. A wide swath of Trump’s support also comes from within his own party
column3: as Republican voters rally around the nominee in the final stretch of the campaign.

column1: -- A Des Moines Register/Mediacom poll shows Trump with a seven point lead in IOWA
column2: up three points from last month.

column1: -- A Columbus Dispatch poll shows Clinton eking out a single point lead over Trump in OHIO (48-47). Pollster Darrel Rowland says Clinton will “almost certainly” carry Ohio should enough young and minority voters show up to the polls. The same poll has Rob Portman crushing Ted Strickland by 21 points (58-37).LeBron James will appear alongside Clinton in Cleveland today on the final day of early in-person voting in OHIO.
-- The CBS News battleground tracker has Trump up 46-45 in OHIO and a 45-45 tie in FLORIDA.
THE FINAL SCHEDULES FOR BOTH CANDIDATES:
-- What's with the 11th-hour fluidity? Karen Tumulty and Dan Balz note that four states have dominated the Clinton campaign’s calculation throughout the fall: Florida
column2: North Carolina
column3: Ohio and Pennsylvania. “Obama won those four in 2008 and all of them but North Carolina in 2012. Until recently
column4: it appeared that Trump needed to sweep all four to overcome Clinton’s electoral-map advantage. But as the race has tightened
column5: Ohio seems to have moved into the Republican column
column6: and other states outside those four have potentially come into play. The GOP nominee is looking to states including Michigan (and) New Hampshire … to make up a potential deficit
column7: should he not win Florida
column8: North Carolina and Pennsylvania. ... In Trump’s case
column9: it is an effort to grab what he considers emerging opportunities in the sprint for the finish line; in Clinton’s
column10: as insurance against surprises Tuesday in territory she has considered hers.” (The Post’s politics team lists the 15 states that will decide the election on Tuesday
column11: breaking down the state of the race in each one.)

column1: -- Why is Michigan getting so much late attention? Hillary campaigned in Detroit on Friday
column2: and she’s coming back to Grand Rapids tomorrow while Barack Obama flies to Ann Arbor. Bill is stumping in Lansing at 1 p.m. today. Remember that HRC unexpectedly lost the state’s primary to Bernie Sanders in March
column3: despite every poll putting her significantly ahead. Trump and Pence are also both going there. Fourteen percent of the electorate is African American.

column1: -- The Clinton campaign is trying to downplay its late efforts in Michigan. “Look
column2: if we hold onto Nevada (and) hold onto Michigan
column3: then Hillary Clinton is going to be the next President of the United States
column4: ” John Podesta said on Meet the Press this morning. “Most people vote on election day in Michigan
column5: so our schedule has been oriented to being in the early vote states
column6: in the earlier period of time.” Stephen Neuman
column7: a senior adviser to the Democratic coordinated campaign in Michigan
column8: noted that the campaign already has 35 offices. A Washington Post average of recent polls in the state has Clinton leading Trump in Michigan just 43 percent to 41 percent. Mook acknowledged that polls have has tightened in Michigan
column9: but added: “I feel very confident about how we’re going to do.” (John Wagner and Anne Gearan)

column1: -- Trump seems to have given up on Wisconsin. Aides told me last week that he’d probably go back multiple times
column2: including to the Milwaukee suburbs. He’s not even going to come back once to the Badger State. But now he’s going to Minnesota (where he has absolutely not a snowball’s chance). The campaign said it has done polling there
column3: but Maggie Haberman of the Times tweeted that this is a lie.

column1: -- The latest indignity for the Speaker --> ""Trump cancels Wisconsin rally just as Paul Ryan says he would campaign with him
column2: by Jessie Opoien in the Madison Capital Times: “For the second time in as many months
column3: the possibility of a joint Paul Ryan-Donald Trump campaign appearance was floated and quickly yanked away. The Republican nominee earlier this week scheduled a Sunday afternoon rally in West Allis
column4: just outside Milwaukee. It was to be Trump's sixth Wisconsin event since he lost the state's primary election. ‘We don't know if it's scheduled firm or not yet
column5: but I intend to do it if he's here
column6: ’ Ryan told reporters Saturday when asked if he would attend the Trump rally. … ‘If our nominee comes
column7: we'll campaign with him.’ … Seconds later
column8: a spokesman for Trump's Wisconsin campaign alerted reporters that the event had been canceled.” (Ryan stumped alongside Mike Pence yesterday.)

column1: -- But perplexingly Trump and Pence have not given up on VIRGINIA
column2: adding several stops and deploying key surrogates. “Trump’s decision to appear in a populous
column3: purple Washington exurb cuts against his broader strategy of running up the vote in heavily red
column4: rural areas
column5: ” Laura Vozzella writes. “Much of his last-minute appeals have been in tiny burgs like Selma
column6: N.C.
column7: population 6
column8: 000. His foray into Northern Virginia appears to be a bid to hold down Clinton’s margins in a region that
column9: excluding the exurbs
column10: leans heavily Democratic.”

column1: -- Bigger picture: Trump’s schedule belies the biggest challenge facing him right now. It’s not clear where and how he would win. “Of all of [Trump’s must-win] states
column2: the only one where Mr. Trump has really been close in the polls is Nevada
column3: ” writes The Upshot’s Nate Cohn. “But Nevada is also the state where we know the most about the results because of early voting
column4: and it hasn't brought good news for Mr. Trump. … Perhaps Mr. Trump will mount a huge comeback in Nevada on Election Day. Or maybe Democrats are much weaker among registered Democrats or unaffiliated voters than most analysts believe. But if Mrs. Clinton does indeed have a big advantage in Nevada
column5: then his chances start looking very bleak: He's at a disadvantage in the polls of all of the other states that could put him over the top. What's more
column6: it's not really clear where he has his best chance — something reflected in Mr. Trump's unfocused pre-election push.”

column1: -- A deep dive on the national mood: Fifteen of our reporters traveled the country talking to voters and report on ""deep anxiety – and some lingering traces of optimism"": “Only eight years after millions of Americans poured into the streets in spontaneous
column2: joyful celebration of the election of the nation’s first black president
column3: optimism seems to have been sucked out of the country’s marrow
column4: replaced by a heavy anxiety
column5: a sense that things aren’t right and can’t easily be fixed.""

column1: -- Early voting trends in FLORIDA appear to (narrowly) favor Clinton: “The Democrats’ lead of 7
column2: 280 ballots cast pales in comparison to their advantage of about 104
column3: 000 early and absentee votes four years ago
column4: however the state’s voter rolls have shifted significantly and neither Republicans nor Democrats can lay claim to having a clear advantage
column5: ” Politico’s Marc Caputo writes.

column1: “I think it's trending well for HRC
column2: but it's definitely a toss up state
column3: ” says Democratic consultant Steve Schale
column4: who helped lead Obama's efforts in the Sunshine State in 2008 and 2012. (Read his latest memo on the early vote.)

column1: -- Jon Ralston
column2: the dean of the NEVADA press corps
column3: predicts a deep blue wave in the notoriously-hard-to-poll Silver State: “Trump may have been here this weekend
column4: believing in the polls that show him ahead or competitive here. But like Bruce Willis in ‘The Sixth Sense’ (spoiler alert)
column5: he does not realize he is dead. The Democratic early voting effort
column6: which was much more difficult with a nominee so many Democrats don’t like or trust
column7: has been impressive — a valedictory statement from The Reid Machine. Yes
column8: 2016 is not 2012. Hillary Clinton is not Barack Obama. Plenty of votes will be cast Tuesday. But: About two-thirds of the votes already have been banked. If the past is prologue … The only real question
column9: I think
column10: is how deep the blue wave goes.”

column1: -- The Supreme Court moved to allow an ARIZONA “ballot collection” law barring organizers from picking up ballots and delivering them to election stations. The move is an eleventh-hour blow to Democrats
column2: who argue that the ruling could disenfranchise thousands of minority voters. (CNN)

column1: -- Chris Christie canceled four NEW HAMPSHIRE stops on behalf of Trump yesterday
column2: following the convictions of two former top aides for their role in the 2013 Bridgegate scandal. The New Jersey governor is doing an interview today with Charlie Rose to try cleaning up the mess. Imagine is Christie was the Republican nominee
column3: and those convictions got handed down the Friday before the election? (WMUR)

column1: -- Faithless elector alert: A WASHINGTON state Democratic elector said he is refusing to vote for Clinton even if she wins the popular vote
column2: facing the potential of a $1
column3: 000 fine. He told the AP he “doesn’t care.” This could matter if the election is really close.

column1: -- Some are still Bernie or Bust: Sanders went to Iowa State University in Ames yesterday to lead a rally for Clinton. One of the warm-up speakers was Kaleb Vanfosson
column2: the president of the Young Democratic Socialists group at the school. He was supposed to give a speech about the need for unity
column3: but instead he took the stage and started talking about how ""terrible"" Hillary is. ""She is so trapped in the world of the elite
column4: the sophomore in political science said. ""She has completely lost grip of what it's like to be an average person."" He added that there was no point in voting for the ""lesser of two evils."" It took about a minute of this before a Clinton staffer escorted him off the stage. Here’s the story from the student paper. And here’s the video:

column1: -- Tim Kaine made headlines after suggesting that some inside the FBI are “actively working” to support Trump’s campaign. From Ed O’Keefe: In a Miami interview
column2: Kaine called the FBI a “leaky sieve” and accused Jim Comey of breaking protocol by announcing his email investigation so close to an election. He also dismissed Trump ally Rudy Giuliani’s decision to back off claims that he
column3: Giuliani
column4: had been given advance notice of the FBI's plans to possibly reopen the Clinton investigation. “I don’t think Giuliani’s walk-back is credible
column5: ” the Virginia senator said
column6: referring to Giuliani’s preemptive announcement that the FBI had a “big announcement” to come. “I think the FBI sadly has become like a leaky sieve
column7: ” he added.

column1: -- New York Times
column2: “If Clinton Moves to Oval Office
column3: Aides’ Baggage May Be Heavy
column4: ” by Matt Flegenheimer and Mark Landler: “In the final sprint of her campaign
column5: troubled by an F.B.I. inquiry and narrowing polls
column6: [Clinton] has held tightly to a handful of advisers who have spent their careers protecting her interests
column7: defending her reputation
column8: and at times sullying it — and their own. And if she wins on Tuesday
column9: the most telling test of Mrs. Clinton’s transition back to power will arrive quickly: After a campaign season often defined by voters’ weariness with and distrust of her
column10: which old hands will — or should — follow her into the Oval Office? Almost no top adviser has been left untouched by the two central firestorms of Mrs. Clinton’s candidacy: the inquiry into her use of a private email server … and the WikiLeaks hack of [campaign chairman John Podesta]. The unvarnished view of infighting in the stolen documents is unlikely to bother Mrs. Clinton much
column11: friends say. The political wisdom of importing excess baggage to the executive branch is another matter.""

column1: -- Boston Globe A1
column2: “9 moments that molded the campaign
column3: ” by Matt Viser and Annie Linskey: “When planning the Democratic convention in Philadelphia
column4: Clinton campaign officials didn’t initially include Michelle Obama as a featured speaker
column5: according to a Democratic strategist familiar with the plans. … For Clinton’s campaign
column6: it made sense to put her on the rostrum on the tumultuous opening day — when Bernie Sanders and Elizabeth Warren were both to speak. ‘We thought it would be hard for Sanders’ people to boo Michelle Obama
column7: ’ said the person
column8: who isn’t authorized to talk about the first lady’s deliberations.” Another revelation: The Trump campaign was warned months in advance to be ready for Clinton’s attack over Alicia Machado but did nothing.

column1: -- New Yorker
column2: “Meet Maya Harris
column3: Hillary Clinton’s Progressive Link
column4: ” by Emily Greenhouse: “To speak with those who have worked with Harris is to be bulldozed with superlatives. Mary Kay Henry
column5: the president of the Service Employees International Union
column6: who worked with Harris recently on the Democratic Party platform
column7: told me that ‘she lives her life on a moral crusade on all of those justice issues … She carries her peeps
column8: our peeps
column9: with her in everything she does.’ Beyond policy
column10: Harris seems to offer
column11: in her very person
column12: solutions to some of Clinton’s image problems.""

column1: -- The owners of the National Enquirer reportedly paid to shield Trump from allegations of a former Playboy model who claims they had an affair
column2: paying $150
column3: 000 for rights to her story before declining to publish it. From the Wall Street Journal’s Joe Palazzolo
column4: Michael Rothfeld and Lukas I. Alpert: “The tabloid-newspaper publisher reached an agreement in early August with Karen McDougal
column5: the 1998 Playmate of the Year. American Media Inc.
column6: which owns the Enquirer
column7: hasn’t published anything about what she has told friends was a consensual romantic relationship she had with Mr. Trump in 2006. At the time
column8: Mr. Trump was married to his current wife
column9: Melania. Quashing stories that way is known in the tabloid world as ‘catch and kill.’ In a written statement
column10: the company said it wasn’t buying Ms. McDougal’s story for $150
column12: but rather two years’ worth of her fitness columns and magazine covers as well as exclusive life rights to any relationship she has had with a then-married man.” Trump and American Media Owner CEO David Pecker are longtime friends.

column1: -- Melania stumped alongside her husband in North Carolina
column2: calling him a ""compassionate
column3: giving ... loving"" man
column4: she said
column5: who ""cares so deeply about this country.""

column1: -- “In America’s democratic showcase
column2: the world sees a model of what not to do
column3: ” by Griff Witte: “In the seaside cafes of Beirut
column4: the whole thing looks ‘like a bad joke.’ To persecuted journalists in Burundi
column5: it amounts to ‘a total loss of dignity.’ The government-scripted press of Beijing diagnoses ‘an empire moving downhill.’ And the spin doctors of the Kremlin see cause for pure and unambiguous delight. The U.S. presidential election — America’s quadrennial chance to showcase for the world how democracy works in the most powerful nation on Earth — has become instead an object lesson in everything that ails a country long seen as a beacon of freedom and hope. People in small and distant countries who count on the U.S. to stand up for democratic values have been astonished to see essential components … trammeled. Long-standing allies have been left to wonder … whether the U.S. can be relied on when it counts. And even though the campaign still has days to go — with the outcome very much in doubt — the damage to American moral standing may already be done.”

column1: Quote du jour: “America always spoke to Arab countries as if they had so much to learn
column2: ” said a 27-year-old Beirut café worker
column3: who says he has been closely watching the election ever since he read about Trump’s sexual assault boasts. “And now we see their own democracy involves choosing between a woman from a dynasty and a man who says the system is manipulated. If that’s democracy
column4: then we don’t want it.”

column1: -- The New York Times’ Farah Stockman and Nick Corasaniti explore how this loss of luster could affect the American brand: “In interviews
column2: Americans who travel overseas and foreign observers say that tourists who once felt themselves the envy of the world now feel the sting of embarrassment. Businesses that once marketed their jeans and fleece jackets internationally as tiny pieces of the American dream are being advised to revamp their ad campaigns."" An Australian public relations consultant noted that state lawmakers in Sydney recently adopted a resolution – by unanimous consent – describing Trump as ""a revolting slug” unfit for office.

column1: -- The idea that Tuesday will end our partisan rancor is a “naïve fantasy
column2: writes Frank Bruni:“There’s no end here
column3: just a punctuation mark
column4: a measly comma between the rancor that has built until this point and the fury to come. And there’s no way to un-see what all of us have seen over these last 18 months
column5: to bottle up what has been un-bottled. Election Day will redeem and settle nothing
column6: not this time around. Whether balloons fall on [Clinton] or [Trump]
column7: there will be bolder divisions in America than there were at the start of it all and even less faith in the country’s most important institutions … Even putting Trump’s angry troops aside
column8: it feels as if we’re coming out of this election with four parties: the Paul Ryan Republicans
column9: the Freedom Caucus
column10: the establishment Democrats and the Elizabeth Warren/Bernie Sanders brigade … Meet the new paralysis
column11: same as the old paralysis. Potentially
column12: worse. From elections past
column13: I don’t recognize this terrain. How can I assume that it’s navigable?”

column1: -- “If [Trump] loses
column2: the party faces a daunting reconstruction challenge
column3: ” says conservative columnist Peter Wehner
column4: who served in the Bush and Reagan administrations: “Policies that promote economic growth
column5: social mobility and greater opportunity are important. But in some respects the party’s stance [here] is a secondary priority. Republicans need to wrestle with more fundamental questions first: Will their party choose as its leaders people who respect democratic institutions and traditions
column6: or not; who conceive of America as a welcoming society or as one that is racially and religiously closed … who abhor ignorance or embrace it? In a post-Trump world
column7: Republicans need to ask themselves if their party will be characterized by its aspirations or its resentments. Can it make its own inner peace with living in an increasingly diverse and nonwhite America? Does it conceive of its role as tamping down or inflaming ugly passions? Does it believe in a just social order or not? The next few months will tell us a lot about whether Mr. Trump and Trumpism were an anoma"

column1: ugly and dispiriting campaign … the epic dark saga will unfold this way: A man	 filled with fear and insecurity	 created a hatemongering character and followed it out the window. And a woman	 filled with fear and insecurity	 hunkered down and repeated bad patterns rather than reimagining herself in an open	 bold way	” Maureen Dowd writes. “Before he jumped into the presidential race	 Trump was seen as bombastic	 vulgar	 a bit of a buffoon and a cave man	 but [also] ‘a cheeky brio.’ He was not regarded as a bigot or demagogue. He was seen as a playboy	 not a predator … But he created another character for the Republican primaries	 playing to the feral instincts of angry voters	 encouraging violence at his rallies	 hatred toward journalists and disrespect for democracy itself. ‘He’s so used to playing a role in different areas of his life	’ said [TV personality] Donny Deutsch … ‘He saw the crowd’s adulation and it drove him. He started to get the biggest cheers for saying the most offensive things.’”

part two”: “Bill Clinton’s Presidency was defined	 for the most part	 by criminal and congressional investigations	” he writes. “The subjects of those probes sound like entries in a nineteen-nineties time capsule: Whitewater	 Filegate	 Travelgate … It may be that Republicans spent so much time in pursuit of Bill Clinton’s scalp because things were mostly going well otherwise. The economy boomed	 and the nation was at peace. So Congress took a vacation from its responsibilities to investigate a decade-old Arkansas land deal in which the Clintons lost money. But real dangers abound in the unstable world of today. The economy is only tenuously prosperous. And a warming planet	 notwithstanding the lack of interest among debate moderators	 threatens apocalyptic change. A politics based on pursuit and accusation	 rather than on reason and compromise	 will address none of these problems. And the prospect of four years of governance that resemble the last days of this campaign is one that would drive anyone to drink.”

” says the New York Times’ Editorial Board. “For many voters that will mean defying Republican efforts to jam the electoral machinery through lies	 legal obstructions and the threat of violence. We hope the voters hold out	 however intimidating the process and long the lines. For Americans who may feel unmoved or unwilling to vote for Mrs. Clinton	 here is a question from the future: In 2016 we were closer than ever to electing an ignorant and reckless tyrant — what did you do to stop him? There’s no sense complaining anymore. The hurricane is three days from landfall. The urgent thing now is to avert the worst	 minimize the damage	 save the foundations	 clear the mess.”

and if we didn’t endorse Ronald Reagan we aren’t about to revive the practice for Mrs. Clinton or Mr. Trump	 the Journal’s board declares. “A broken Washington needs to be shaken up and refocused on the public good	 and who better to do it than an outsider beholden to neither political party? If only that reform possibility didn’t arrive as a flawed personality who has few convictions and knows little about the world.”

widening an investigation into the bizarre “shadow president” scandal that has stoked outrage across the country. On Saturday	 tens of thousands of people gathered in the capital to demand she step down. (AP)

U.S. backed force in Syria launched an offensive to retake control of Raqqa	 seeking to drive out Islamic State militants from their northeastern stronghold. The operation with the U.S.-supported military effort to seize the Mosul from ISIS militants	 Hugh Naylor writes. And the impending assault represents an “intensified international effort” to increase pressure on the extremist group as it loses control of territory in the countries.

police are solving fewer cases than they have in decades. Officers today clear just 26 percent of cases – a drastic reduction from years such as 1991	 where levels averaged 80 percent. (Kimbriell Kelly	 Wesley Lowery and Steven Rich)

authorities said. Police said they discovered at least one body on the man’s property	 and he confessed to a string of other homicides. The gruesome revelations come as a stark contrast to the man’s professional image – appearing to be a successful realtor who ran his own firm upstate. (Amy B Wang)

” by Kevin Sullivan:  “More than 250 people	 mostly conservative Christians	 clap and whoop as [KrisAnne] Hall takes the stage in the ballroom of a suburban Minnesota hotel … Hall	 a radio host	 former Florida prosecutor and Army veteran	 tells the crowd that the Southern Poverty Law Center	 a civil rights group that tracks extremism	 has included her on its list of 998 anti-government groups in the U.S. She just loves that. Hall	47	 started firing up rage at the federal government six years ago	 driving around the southeast in her old Saturn car … [Now] in this era of [Trump]	 her message fits the moment	 and her popularity has exploded. She is a chief circuit rider for liberty	 spending more than 260 days a year preaching against federal government overreach.  She says those who disagree with her reading of history are either ignorant of the founders’ intentions or ‘federal supremacists’ who ignore the Constitution. ‘The problem with her approach is that it ignores 240 years of history	’ said Georgetown professor David Cole.”

” by Jim Tankersley: “Voters up and down the West Coast are quietly poised to extend a massive economic experiment this Election Day	 probing the limits of how much states can soak the big guys to help the little guys. Their efforts — in three of the hottest state economies in the country — defy decades of conservative arguments about cutting taxes to spur economic growth. The new West Coast Model is higher taxes on the rich	 higher spending by the state and wide-scale efforts to lift the working poor. … It is on the ballot in three states: Californians are set to essentially make permanent an income tax surcharge on millionaires in order to fund education. Washington voters appear likely to raise their minimum wage statewide to $13.25 an hour … In Oregon	 it will be a down-to-the-wire battle to see if voters will bolster their state budget by taxing large corporations. Advocates are already planning how to export them to the rest of the country.”

” by William Booth and Aaso Ameen Shwan “’They’re everywhere	’ said the Iraqi intelligence officer	 sweeping his arm from this ancient Christian village toward the horizon. The Iraqi captain was searching for tunnels dug by Islamic State fighters. The officer stomped on the ground. ‘Here. We found one	 then three	 now six. Right here.’ … Villages recaptured from ISIS over the past three weeks … have been honeycombed with tunnels	 many of them booby-trapped. In the past three days	 commanders say Iraqi forces have faced the hardest fighting of the offensive as they entered Mosul	 made worse by extensive tunnels that are allowing ISIS fighters to appear seemingly out of nowhere	 attack	 then retreat to the hidden bunkers. An Iraqi armored commander who drove his Abrams tank into eastern Mosul recalled seeing dozens of fighters scrambling on the street in front of his guns. ‘Then they disappeared	’ he said. Into the ground. ‘It’s like we are fighting two wars in two cities	"’ said Col. Falah Al-Obaidi of the Iraqi counterterror forces. ‘There’s the war on the streets and there is a whole city underground where they are hiding.’"""""

” by Paul Kane: “The battle for the Senate might well come down to a contest in which neither candidate has broken through the much-louder noise of other political fights. For months	 U.S. Rep. Joseph J. Heck and former state attorney general Catherine Cortez Masto have slugged it out in the most expensive Senate race in this state’s history	 locked in a tight contest that gives Republicans a chance to steal a Democratic crown jewel: the seat of Senate Minority Leader [Harry Reid]. A Heck victory would make the tenuous path for Republicans to hold the Senate majority easier to navigate. Democrats need four seats to capture the majority if [Clinton] … wins the White House. Yet despite those high stakes	 the Senate race here has often felt like an undercard boxing match on the Las Vegas Strip as everyone awaits the main event between the presidential candidates	 Clinton and [Trump]	 who have campaigned and spent heavily in this key swing state.”

100,000 people have come to recent Bernie Sanders rallies. How does he do it?	"The overflow crowds showing up to hear Bernie Sanders these days are a testament not only to his current popularity and the campaign’s social-media savvy but also to the promotional abilities of an alchemy of like-minded interests: progressive activists
column2: labor unions and even Sarah Silverman.

column1: The comedian took to Twitter to let her nearly 6.7 million followers know she would be at a rally for the Democratic presidential hopeful here Monday. That event drew an estimated 27
column2: 500 people — about five times as large as any crowd that has turned out for Democratic front-runner Hillary Rodham Clinton.

column1: “Bernie always seems to be on the right side of history
column2: ” Silverman told the boisterous audience at the Los Angeles Memorial Sports Arena
column3: noting that the 73-year-old was a civil rights activist in the 1960s
column4: supported gay rights in the 1980s and strongly opposed the Iraq war before most other Americans.

column1: [To his old socialist allies
column2: Sanders has sold out]

column1: All told
column2: Sanders has attracted more than 100
column3: 000 people to his rallies in recent weeks
column4: riding a wave of Facebook shares
column5: retweets and old-fashioned word-of-mouth to become by far the biggest draw on the campaign trail.

column1: Such turnout is no guarantee that Sanders will perform well in the crucial early-nominating states — fellow Vermonter Howard Dean preached to similarly large and frenzied audiences in mostly liberal enclaves in 2003
column2: only to collapse as the Iowa caucuses approached.

column1: But it is drawing energy and attention away from Clinton — whose aides peg her largest crowd to date at 5
column2: 500 — and exposing a lack of enthusiasm for her candidacy among some facets of the Democratic Party. And it is creating a network of small-scale donors and volunteers that could provide Sanders with the resources he will need to compete with the former secretary of state and first lady in the weeks and months ahead.

column1: Roughly 28
column2: 000 people showed up for a recent Sanders rally in Portland
column3: Ore. The self-described democratic socialist drew 15
column4: 000 in Seattle; 11
column5: 000 in Phoenix; 10
column6: 000 in Madison
column7: Wis.; 8
column8: 000 in Dallas; and 4
column9: 500 in New Orleans.

column1: [The Sanders predicament: Where do you fit all those people?]
This weekend
column2: Sanders will host a couple of town hall meetings in Iowa and attend events with other candidates. His campaign has not yet said where his next large-scale rally will be.

column1: In Los Angeles
column2: Sanders’s campaign estimated that 27
column3: 500 people were jammed inside and outside the 16
column4: 000-seat arena — a figure impossible to independently verify. Nearly every seat appeared to be taken
column5: and the arena floor was packed. Outside
column6: thousands more watched the rally on large screens.

column1: The throngs were greeted by Dante Harris
column2: the leader of a flight attendants union local that had helped promote the rally.

column1: “Did all of you make the trip out here on a Monday night because everything is going well for you and your family?” he asked.
Harris nodded and shouted back. “Workers’ lives matter! . . . Black lives matter! . . . The truth matters!” Struggling to be heard over the ensuing ovation
column2: he said
column3: “We can build a movement with Bernie!”

column1: The audience was noticeably more diverse than those at recent Sanders rallies in Portland
column2: Seattle and other majority-white cities. Los Angeles is majority-minority
column3: with about 44 percent of its population Latino.

column1: [Sanders needs to court black voters. Now he is.]

There were young hipsters and graying hippies. Some wore black T-shirts with red hammers and sickles; others wore black T-shirts that read “Black Lives Matter.” They sang along as the loudspeakers blasted songs by Willie Nelson
column2: Tracy Chapman and Neil Young. One man carried a handmade sign that said “Bernie: Our Only Hope for Change.”

column1: About a week before each Sanders rally
column2: his campaign sets up a Web page announcing the location and blasts out an e-mail to supporters in that geographic area
column3: asking them to RSVP. There are no paid advertisements.

column1: The events are promoted on Facebook
column2: with the campaign enlisting progressive groups and other “friends and allies” to help spread the word
column3: said national field director Phil Fiermonte. From there
column4: things tend to take on a life of their own.

column1: Like Harris
column2: climate-change activist Joe Galliani got a speaking slot in Los Angeles because his union had spread the word about the rally. He earned some of the loudest cheers as he denounced construction of the Keystone XL oil pipeline and touted the benefits of solar roofs.

column1: Then there was Maria Barrera
column2: the 31-year-old leader of the Coalition for Humane Immigrant Rights of Los Angeles
column3: who tearfully noted that Congress has not enacted comprehensive immigration reforms since the 1980s. “For the last 25 years
column4: families have been separated
column5: ” Barrera said.

column1: [Activists drove Sanders from a stage
column3: 000 people awaited him at the next]

column1: The turnout and enthusiasm have been similar at Sanders events across the country.
For the Portland rally
column2: a local group lobbying for a $15-per-hour minimum wage in the city — a cause Sanders supports nationally — drove a sizable contingent of people to the event. In addition
column3: the Oregon Democratic Party sent an e-mail to people in its database letting them know about the event (with the disclaimer that the party is not taking sides in the presidential primary).

column1: Local Democrats who attended the rally said it appeared to draw lots of newcomers to party politics.
“I hardly ever go to these events without running into friends
column2: and I didn’t see many people I knew
column3: ” said Sue Hagmeier
column4: the communications officer for the Democratic Party in Multnomah County
column5: which includes Portland.

column1: Hagmeier said she probably received 15 to 20 digital notifications in advance of the event
column2: counting forwarded e-mails and Facebook posts. Sanders supporters also posted fliers on telephone poles and promoted the event by “chalking the sidewalks
column3: ” a tradition in a city known for big political rallies. (In 2008
column4: an estimated 75
column5: 000 people came to see then-Sen. Barack Obama on the banks of the Willamette River as he closed in on the Democratic presidential nomination.)

column1: Sanders is striving to harness the energy to help him in states such as Iowa and New Hampshire
column2: where his crowds have been much smaller but still relatively robust. Volunteers hand out donation envelopes to rally attendees and carefully take down their contact information so they can be solicited for money later.

column1: In Los Angeles
column2: anyone who gave on the spot received a Sanders campaign T-shirt. Speakers asked the crowd to text “Bernie” to a five-digit number. In reply
column3: they would receive text messages seeking money and volunteer time.

column1: When Sanders came onstage
column2: the cheers were deafening. His voice hoarse
column3: the senator told the crowd
column4: “This campaign is not a billionaire-funded campaign — it is a people-funded campaign.”

column1: “There is no president who will fight harder to end institutional racism
column2: ” he said. “Or for a higher minimum wage. Or for paid parental leave. Or for at least two weeks of paid vacation. . . . Whenever we stand together
column3: when we do not allow them to divide us up by the color of our skin or our sexual orientation
column4: by whether a man or a woman is born in America or born somewhere else
column5: whenever we stand together
column6: there is nothing
column7: nothing
column8: nothing we cannot accomplish.”

column1: Mike Jelf
column3: said he spent the day before the rally leafleting for the campaign in nearby Torrance. He brought his Saint Bernard
column4: Munro
column5: to the arena
column6: wearing a shirt that said “Saints for Sanders.”

column1: “I want to see a country that’s returned to the people
column2: rather than a plutocratic oligarchy
column3: ” Jelf said. “I would like to have a planet that’s habitable for future generations.”

column1: Jean-Luc St. Pierre
column3: said he flew from Maryland to attend the rally. He started a “Baltimore for Bernie” Facebook group targeting people in the home town of former Maryland governor Martin O’Malley
column4: another Democratic presidential candidate.

column1: Gloria Rios
column2: from Eagle Rock
column3: Calif.
column4: said she joined Sanders’s e-mail list a month ago. “I feel very strongly about him
column5: ” she said
column6: adding that she has concerns about Clinton.

column1: What are those concerns? She paused. For a really long time.
“There’s — too much conflict around her
column2: ” Rios said. “I’m the kind of person who feels that what you say and do has to match up.”

column1: Sanders
column2: she added
column3: “resonates more closely to me.”

column1: After the rally
column2: the Sanders campaign tweeted a photo showing some of the thousands who had watched from outside the arena.

column1: “Apologies to the large crowds who couldn’t fit indoors at tonight’s rally
column2: ” the tweet said. “We’re gonna have to get bigger venues!”"	REAL

column1: Trump The President: What Does That Mean For The World? - CounterCurrents.org	"in World — by Mirza Yawar Baig — November 10
Whew! Finally
column2: the charade is over. Donald Trump is now the President of the United States of America. What does that mean? It means that Simpsons prediction came true: https://www.thesun.co.uk/news/2146815/the-simpsons-correctly-predicted-a-donald-trump-presidency-16-years-ago-in-episode-set-in-the-near-future/

column1: So now you know who to refer to for accurate predictions about the future. Goodbye Tarot cards
column2: et al. In 1995 I recall reading a survey which concluded that America was not likely to be ready for a woman president for the next twenty years. Twenty-one years later
column3: it looks like that prediction was true. Given that women in America to this day are paid 80% of what men are paid
column4: it is not surprising that Americans find it tough to visualize a woman in the White House in any place other than the President’s bed.

column1: So
column2: what does Trump mean for America
column3: for American Muslims
column4: for Muslims worldwide
column5: for non-whites in America and globally? I am asking this rhetorical question as I see all kinds of doomsday predictions flying around. I apologize for taking a different view. I see the Trump presidency as an opportunity for those who believe in the opposite of everything that Donald Trump promoted in his campaign to put their actions where their mouths are and show that they are as willing to stand up for what they believe in as he was.

column1: What does Trump mean for America? I hope he will be the best thing that happened to America ever. I hope that he can truly make ‘America Great Again’. I say that because though I am not American (should I say
column2: ‘Thank God?’)
column3: I am one who believes that a truly ‘Great America’
column4: can make this world great. The world truly needs to change. We need someone to lead the way to make the world compassionate
column5: caring
column6: fighting against injustice
column7: corruption and poverty; disease and ignorance. Which nation is better suited to lead that fight? America has the resources
column8: the intelligence
column9: the education and the leadership ability which I hope it chooses to exercise. Trump won on the anti-establishment platform. I support that fully. The establishment has shown that what it can do is to fail spectacularly. The economy crashed and Obama rewarded those who crashed it. People were and are homeless when there are empty homes on foreclosed loans enough for every American to have two homes
column10: not only one. Yet they are on the streets. I hope Trump can put Americans back in their own homes.

column1: Bush father and son
column2: started never ending wars. Obama continued them adding his own flavor to it of drone strikes – using technology to create bug splats (the arrogance is incredible) – thereby escalating the global threat level that comes from driving people to desperation. Obama’s dabbling (what else to call it?) in Middle Eastern politics resulted in continuing the misery for people of Afghanistan and Iraq and new misery for people of Syria and by inference for the rest of the world. And to top it all ISIS came into being because of all of the above. The credit can be shared by all of them. So
column3: Trump standing against the establishment means that he is against all of this. I sincerely hope so.

column1: All the jingoism that he rode on will get tempered when it comes to facing reality. It is easy to talk about kicking out the Mexicans and so on. But the day he does that
column2: reality will dawn on him and his cohorts like it did on those who voted Pro-Brexit; that the rich need the poor to survive while the poor don’t need the rich. When nice white Americans get to pay $3 per potato
column3: they will realize the value of cheap labor. Meanwhile some contractor will get the contract to build the Wall
column4: which he will do from the Mexican side
column5: no doubt as otherwise his margin will not make it worthwhile. So also
column6: the wonderful idea to outlaw the H-1 visa. I don’t think it will take very long for Trump and his gang to realize that there is a reason there are blond jokes. And that Indians are not blond. Go figure that.

column1: The good news is that Trump made public what was private – racism
column2: misogyny in a country that never stops ‘trumpeting’ about women’s equality
column3: support for genocide
column4: wars and weapons sales
column5: the evils of unbridled capitalism
column6: locker-room conversations which indicate attitudes – have all come out of the closet and locker-room. Now it is up to those who like to say that they believe in the opposite of all these things
column7: to get off their backsides and bring about change. They can no longer live the lives of pretense and lies that they had become used to
column8: saying
column9: ‘It is not happening here.’ Trump proved that it is happening and has trumpeted it from the top of Trump tower. Sorry for so much bad punning in one breath. But there you go.

column1: As for Muslims and Trump
column2: believe me Trump is far better than what Muslims have seen in the past. He is far better than what we have today. Take Sisi
column3: the Oily royals who are personal friends of every weapons dealer
column4: the Paki leadership and I can think of several more and Trump begins to look like a choir boy. What will he do that is not already happening? Frankly I don’t know and don’t care to speculate because the prime movers behind Muslim affairs and how they are
column5: are Muslims themselves. Our leadership or more correctly its spectacular failure. Ordinary citizens pay the price
column6: but what’s new about that? The fact remains that until we sort that out and do something about taking charge of our destiny
column7: we must remain satisfied with others writing the script we are compelled to live by. Play endings depend on the script
column8: not on the players.

column1: India is a classic example where a so-called minority of 200 million is kicked around like a football and used at will by every mercenary politician for his own ends. But Indian Muslims seem to be satisfied with that
column2: so who is anyone else to complain. If you disagree and tell me that they are not satisfied
column3: then I must ask you what it is that prevents them from doing what is glaringly obvious; get their act together
column4: change their leaders and write their own script. 200 million is not a minority. It is a nation. But only if it chooses to be. Same story for Muslims globally. No point in blaming Trump or looking up to him to find solutions. It is our problem and we must solve it
column5: so let us start doing that.

column1: Two other points: what about wars
column2: global warming and such issues? Well
column3: when you have a nation that lives on perpetual warfare and is supported in that by all the other major industrial nations who either manufacture and sell weapons or buy them
column4: how can you pin it all on Trump? If weapons are made and sold
column5: there will be wars. Wars will happen if they continue to make profits for those who run them. That people die is incidental. Those at the top who laugh all the way to the bank
column6: don’t. Those that do
column7: don’t count. They are ‘collateral’
column8: who are necessary to prove the efficacy of the weapons that were used to vaporize them. If it wasn’t for the bugs who splatted
column9: how would you assess the drones or their operators? The fact that the bugs were innocent or that they had families and so on; well
column10: bugs are bugs. And that’s all that there is to it.

column1: Global warming? America decided on that when it chose Bush instead of Al Gore. For a minute I thought that was because they got confused because his name is Al Gore like Al Ghurair. But then I realized that it was because he had a terminal problem; he had a brain. See his famous movie
column2: An Inconvenient Truth
column3: and you will see what I mean. https://www.algore.com/library/an-inconvenient-truth-dvd If you do nothing else
column4: buy this and see it. At least you will know why you died. Since you chose that
column5: especially Americans
column6: I believe it is only fair that you understand what you did. With Trump
column7: that came out in the open
column8: so get used to summer all year long. You won’t need to go to the French Riviera for a tan. You can get it at home. That is not inconvenient.

column1: Add to this the effect ofunending wars
column2: refugee movement
column3: changing cultures
column4: security nightmares coming true
column5: widening gap between the rich and the poor
column6: global poverty and hunger
column7: preventable disease which is not prevented because there’s no profit in it – when I think about all this and Trump’s election
column8: Nero comes to mind. Renewing our link with tradition. Let us dance to the tune. What’s the use of fiddling otherwise?

column1: Final question that everyone is asking
column2: ‘How safe is it to have someone like Trump with his finger on the nuclear button?’

column1: My answer is
column2: ‘The one who actually pressed that button was as different from Trump as could be. Yet he did it.’ Let me leave you to figure out the rest.

column1: Meanwhile it is midnight where I live
column2: far away from Trump and America and time to go to bed. Truly it is said that there is solace in sleep. So
column3: good night
column4: world. Sleep well. As long as you stay asleep you can escape responsibility.
