column1: 'You've been fleeced': Congress grills Kerry, Obama officials on Iran nuke deal	"Secretary of State John Kerry found himself on the defensive Thursday at a Senate hearing where he was hard-pressed to find support for the Iran nuclear deal from either side of the aisle -- and sharply sparred with Republicans who accused him of being ""fleeced"" and ""bamboozled.""

The Senate Foreign Relations Committee hearing was the first on the controversial deal to lift economic and other sanctions in exchange for concessions of the Islamic state's nuclear program. With Congress taking up the deal and expected to vote on it sometime in September
column2: the hearing underscored the deep resistance the Obama administration faces from both parties.

column1: From my perspective
column2: Mr. Secretary
column3: I'm sorry ... I believe you've been fleeced
column4: Committee Chairman Bob Corker
column5: R-Tenn.
column6: told Kerry
column7: claiming the agreement paves the path for Iran to eventually develop a nuclear bomb.

column1: Critics repeatedly suggested the Obama administration's negotiating team gave in to pressure from the Iranians on key points. They question whether sanctions indeed can be reinstated once they're lifted; whether Iran might be able to stall international inspectors; and whether Iran might be closer to a weapon once the deal expires.
Sen. James Risch
column2: R-Idaho
column3: said: ""You guys have been bamboozled.""

column1: Kerry
column2: though
column3: vigorously defended the agreement
column4: calling it ""fantasy
column5: plain and simple
column6: to think the United States failed to hold out for a better deal at the bargaining table.

column1: Let me underscore
column2: the alternative to the deal we've reached isn't what I've seen some ads on TV suggesting disingenuously
column3: he told the Senate Foreign Relations Committee. ""It isn't a quote better deal
column4: some sort of unicorn arrangement involving Iran's complete capitulation.""

column1: Energy Secretary Ernest Moniz also said the deal is not ""built on trust.""
Some lawmakers tried to play referee when the hearing got heated. Sen. Barbara Boxer
column2: D-Calif.
column3: said the remarks from Corker and Risch were ""disrespectful and insulting.""

column1: If you were bamboozled
column2: the world has been bamboozled -- that's ridiculous
column3: Boxer told Kerry.

column1: Kerry still had to contend with skeptical Democrats
column2: notably Sen. Bob Menendez
column3: D-N.J.
column4: who questioned whether the language in the deal is tough enough and like Corker said the deal aids Iran in building an ""industrial-scale"" nuclear program.

column1: Kerry earlier warned that Iran will not come back to the negotiating table to pursue a new deal
column2: voicing frustration that: ""We've got 535 secretaries of state.""

column1: The hearing comes as lawmakers raise new concerns about alleged secret ""side deals"" struck with Tehran over its nuclear program.
Sen. Tom Cotton
column2: R-Ark.
column3: and Rep. Mike Pompeo
column4: R-Kan.
column5: first brought attention to them Tuesday
column6: saying they learned from the International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA) that there were two ""side deals"" between Iran and the IAEA.

column1: According to the lawmakers
column2: one agreement covers inspection of the Parchin military complex
column3: and the other concerns potential military aspects of Iran's nuclear program. On the former
column4: they said
column5: Iran would be able to strike a separate arrangement with the IAEA concerning inspections at Parchin.

column1: House Speaker John Boehner and Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell joined Cotton and Pompeo in sending a letter to President Obama on Wednesday requesting that the agreements be made available to Congress so that they can be reviewed.
We request you transmit these two side agreements to Congress immediately so we may perform our duty to assess the many important questions related to the JCPOA [Joint Comprehensive Plan of Action]
column2: the letter says.

column1: National Security Adviser Susan Rice
column2: while defending the overall nuclear agreement
column3: appeared to acknowledge the existence of the side deals on Wednesday. She said the matter of the Iran nuclear program's ""possible military dimensions"" (PMD) has long been an issue between Iran and the IAEA. She said they ""negotiated and concluded an agreement to deal with this issue of PMD
column4: which was one of the major sticking points in our dealings.""

column1: She added: ""These documents are not public
column2: but nonetheless
column3: we have been briefed on those documents
column4: we know their contents
column5: we're satisfied with them and we will share the contents of those briefings in full in a classified session with the Congress. So there's nothing in that regard that we know that they won't know.""

column1: Pompeo also asked Kerry about the secret deals in a briefing Wednesday and said afterwards that Kerry ""confirmed that there were in fact side deals and himself had not seen the agreement.""
I was incredibly surprised to learn there were components of the deal that Congress was not going to be privy to
column2: Pompeo said
column3: adding that he had expected that American negotiators would have demanded to see the side deals being cut.

column1: Kerry said after Thursday's hearing
column2: though
column3: ""there are no side deals.""

column1: The letter to Obama expressed concern that Congress was being kept in the dark.
Most troubling
column2: Iran and the IAEA reached agreement to resolve issues related to research at Parchin
column3: but Congress will not have the ability to review this agreement
column4: nor will we know the results of the IAEA's assessment until December 15
column5: the letter says.

column1: It goes on to request access to the side deals so that Congress can effectively review the deal as a whole:

Failure to produce these two side agreements leaves Congress blind on critical information regarding Iran's potential path to being a nuclear power and will have detrimental consequences for the ability of members to assess the JCPOA
column2: the letter says.

column1: The Associated Press contributed to this report."	REAL
What 20,000 pages of hacked WikiLeaks emails teach us about Hillary Clinton	"Hillary Clinton told a joke. Speaking to a roomful of Goldman Sachs bankers in June 2013
column2: Clinton said that Goldman CEO Lloyd Blankfein could leave the Wall Street firm that’s made him a billionaire to start a soup kitchen:

column1: This exchange was written down by Clinton’s aides as they gathered information on what parts of her paid Wall Street speeches could prove damaging should they leak to the press. Her team filed it under the heading
column2: ""AWKWARD.""

column1: This ""AWKWARD"" quote and hundreds of other previously hidden nuggets about Clinton have spilled out into public view recently. Over the last two weeks
column2: Julian Assange’s whistleblower platform WikiLeaks has published about 20
column3: 000 pages of emails illegally stolen from John Podesta
column4: Clinton’s campaign chair.

column1: The strangest thing about the ensuing uproar is that none of the Podesta emails has so far actually broken any fresh scandals about the woman on track to be the next president. Instead
column2: they’ve mostly revealed an underbelly of ugliness to the multiple Clinton controversies that we’ve already known about: the questionable relationship between the Clinton Foundation and its donors
column3: Clinton’s ease with powerful interests on Wall Street
column4: her ties to wealthy campaign contributors.

column1: The Goldman soup kitchen joke is a perfect example. If there’s one thing to really get mad about here
column2: it’s something we’ve known for years — that Clinton took millions from big Wall Street banks right before running for president. Seeing her and Wall Street titans share a laugh about helping the hungry might turn your stomach
column3: but the most important question — was it wrong for Clinton to take big checks from Goldman right before running? — is in no way new. (Clinton’s campaign refused to comment on individual emails
column4: instead blaming the Russians for hacking the emails and providing them to WikiLeaks.)

column1: This is
column2: from what we’ve seen so far
column3: the real story of WikiLeaks’ Podesta emails. Yes
column4: they have not found any major ""bombshells."" No
column5: they’re not going to sink Clinton’s campaign. But by filling in the storylines that have long dogged her campaign with new and vivid detail
column6: we are getting our clearest picture yet of how the sausage — or
column7: if you prefer
column8: the creamy risotto — gets made in Clinton-world.

column1: It can be an ugly sight.
I’ve now read hundreds of the Podesta emails
column2: as well as upward of 60 stories from across left-wing
column3: mainstream
column4: and conservative media outlets about what they entail.

column1: I should stress that what I’ve found is far from all bad. Dozens of these emails show Clinton’s team genuinely striving to discover the correct position on an issue. Many of them show real
column2: determined efforts to find the right solution to some public policy crisis. In general
column3: especially compared to the vicious infighting that characterized her 2008 presidential run
column4: you come away from the Podesta emails thinking that Clinton has assembled an admiringly loyal group of aides that believes in the candidate and the mission of the campaign. There’s some backbiting
column5: but you could imagine far
column6: far worse.

column1: Then there’s the other stuff — the emails Podesta presumably wish never leaked. To help make sense of what we’ve learned
column2: I’ve broken out the interesting new bits into what I think can be more-or-less characterized as four distinct categories:

column1: Vox reached out to the Clinton campaign for comment
column2: and spokesperson Glen Caplin replied that they are ""still not authenticating any individual emails."" The campaign also referred foundation-related questions to the foundation itself
column3: and referenced several times that the leaks were tied to a ""Russian attempt to influence our election."" As it has to other reporters
column4: the Clinton campaign did not dispute the accuracy of any of the individual emails.

column1: We should be clear that these Podesta email leaks have nothing to do with the multiple other ""Clinton email"" scandals percolating over the past few years. So they aren’t
column2: as some news outlets have incorrectly reported
column3: related to the FBI investigation into Clinton’s private server or allegations that she went around transparency laws.

column1: Instead
column2: since these emails emerge from the private account of Clinton’s campaign chair
column3: they tend to tell us far more about candidate Clinton than they do about Secretary of State Clinton.

column1: There is
column2: however
column3: one exception to that general rule: the Clinton Foundation.

column1: Since the campaign began
column2: the Clinton Foundation has been at the center of an intense debate. The most extreme critics
column3: like Donald Trump
column4: have alleged that Clinton used the state department to transactionally reward the charity’s donors (there’s no evidence for that). Meanwhile
column5: the campaign and foundation have fallen back on one consistent defense — that there’s been no proof of a quid pro quo between donor and foundation.

column1: The Clinton Foundation really did do inarguably life-saving work. But good government experts have argued that the Clintons accepted private donations in a way that they should have known would have created dangerous conflicts of interest. This more nuanced attack faults the Clinton Foundation for dangerously blurring the distinction between private and public.
The Podesta leaks back up that story.

One way it does so is by uncovering a private audit conducted by a widely-respected New York City law firm. The review concluded that the Clinton Foundation’s board had failed to oversee potential conflicts of interest
column2: and that some donors expected ""quid pro quo benefits."" ""Interviewees reported conflicts of those raising funds or donors
column3: some of whom may have an expectation of quid pro quo benefits in return for gift
column4: the audit found.

column1: It’s not clear they received them. but either way the audit is a striking confirmation that even the attorneys hired by Clinton recognized the danger in the relationship between donor and foundation.

Then there’s another disclosure emerging from the Podesta emails: that Qatari officials sought to present Bill Clinton with a $1 million gift on his birthday on during his wife’s tenure as secretary of state. As the New York Times noted
column2: this revelation suggests that foreign governments were able to gain an audience with Bill Clinton in exchange for a check. (The Times couldn’t confirm if the $1 million check was ever cashed.)

column1: The last revelation in the leaks about the foundation may also be the most unusual: Chelsea Clinton apparently was running around raising the alarm bell over possible conflicts of interest
column2: suggesting the Clintons themselves were aware of the potential problems. (Politico’s Kenneth Vogel has a detailed blow-by-blow of Chelsea’s concerns over the overlapping roles of a consulting firm named Teneo.)

column1: Nothing here represents a major revelation. If you weren’t bothered by the Clinton Foundation before
column2: this probably isn’t going to trouble you. But if you were
column3: having an audit and Chelsea Clinton share your fears will fuel the sense that something suspicious was afoot here.

column1: Over the course of the election
column2: Donald Trump and Bernie Sanders leveled a similar critique of Clinton: that she’s too wedded to the ""political establishment.""

column1: For Sanders
column2: that usually meant that Clinton didn’t have the independence to challenge powerful actors on Wall Street and in Washington
column3: DC. Trump has used similar rhetoric
column4: going after ""Crooked"" Clinton for her big dollar campaign contributors.

column1: Whatever you think of the merits of those attacks
column2: it’s clear that the majority of the American people think it’s correct
column3: at least in broad strokes. Seven in 10 voters consider Clinton part of the establishment. Just 30 percent trust her to take on special interests.

column1: It’s an impression that the Podesta emails only deepen — even if they don’t provide ground-breaking new controversies around it.
Again
column2: none of this is revelatory. Nobody who has closely followed Clinton will be shocked to find her campaign was attuned to the wishes of donors. Her affinity for Israel is well known. Critics of her approach to campaign finance are mad about the decision to take money from big donors — not the internal discussion over whether or not to do so.

column1: But watching how all of this unfolded — seeing for yourself how Clinton spoke gently to Wall Street — won’t make the disclosures any easier for her detractors to swallow. It’s a confirmation of what we already know
column2: but that doesn’t make it any less astonishing
column3: at least for Clinton’s critics.

column1: Clinton’s close ties to Wall Street and big donors are certainly part of the story revealed by the Podesta leaks. But only one part.
Indeed
column2: dozens of interesting tidbits have also emerged that allow us to see inside the Clinton campaign’s infrastructure. They have showed that
column3: at some times
column4: the Clinton campaign openly discussed the ""political"" implications of her deciding to get behind one policy or another. They also show the Clinton campaign at other times responding to more high-minded policy concerns.

column1: In one leak
column2: for instance
column3: Clinton’s team discussed at length whether they should endorse the reinstatement of the Glass-Steagall Act
column4: which would restrict commercial banks’ ability to engage in some investment activity.

column1: Clinton aide Mandy Grunwald worries that reversing course and backing the law would lead to ""phoniness charges
column2: while not doing so could lead Sen. Elizabeth Warren to endorse Bernie Sanders. (""Jake"" in the following exchange is Jake Sullivan
column3: a top Clinton adviser):

column1: Then there’s a lengthy exchange in Clinton-world about a carbon tax proposal. As Vox’s Brad Plumer explains
column2: the emails show how fears of embracing an unpopular idea dominated the internal discussion. Robby Mook
column3: a top Clinton aide
column4: said that embracing the carbon tax would prove ""lethal"" in the general election:

column1: But other revelations have pointed to how the Clinton campaign got behind positions it found genuinely worthwhile. In one exchange highlighted by the Washington Post
column2: the Clinton team talked about forming the ""signature pillars of a future progressive agenda"" like a ""significant middle-class tax cut.""

column1: The exchange about the carbon tax did involve frank political talk. But as Plumer also noted
column2: Podesta elsewhere makes genuine efforts to convince his colleagues about the menace posed by climate change and the need for genuinely huge solutions to address it:

column1: There are other examples. A debate over the ""Cadillac Tax
column2: which taxes the most expensive health insurance plans
column3: showed twin impulses fighting against each other. As Vox has written
column4: the tax is widely seen as an essential way to raise revenue for Obamacare. But it’s also hated by unions
column5: whose votes and endorsements Clinton wanted to cultivate during the primary.

column1: The emails reveal Clinton’s policy advisers arguing for a ""fix it"" strategy
column2: while the ""political team"" pushed harder for her to call for a full repeal. (They ultimately came down fully on the political side):

column1: None of Clinton’s critics will be surprised to find her team debating political ramifications of certain policies — it’s certainly widely understood that this is how almost all politicians make their decisions.
But a fair appraisal of the emails doesn't reduce Team Clinton to opportunism. Even behind closed doors
column2: they appear motivated by a genuine embrace of progressive beliefs and causes. At least much of the time
column3: that is. But not always.

column1: Let's be honest: Everyone who has worked in a big enough office has said or written something about a co-worker he or she wouldn't say to that co-worker’s face.

Clinton-world is no exception. But most offices don’t have to deal with essentially all of their internal communications being dumped unceremoniously on the web. Team Clinton’s internal gossip and snipings have been neatly organized into a searchable database that the whole world can use.
These are
column2: understandably
column3: the best catnip for reporters. Like the other revelations
column4: they also don’t tend to reveal anything genuinely earth-shattering. But by laying bare the bitter grievances we (generally) already knew about
column5: these emails are fueling added frustration and old grudges. For instance
column6: the emails include:

column1: This kind of stuff
column2: of course
column3: has the least to do with public policy or the positions of the campaign.

column1: But this category of emails is perhaps most interesting to people who work for Clinton. In a terrific article in Politico
column2: Annie Karni and Glenn Thrush detailed the psychological impacts it’s having on the Clinton campaign:

column1: As Karni and Thrush note
column2: this should be a heady time for Clinton-world. She’s cruising to victory in the polls. Donald Trump has sunk in the polls
column3: and Clinton has trounced him in three consecutive presidential debates.

column1: In general
column2: the critics most upset about the Podesta emails are the ones who have confirmed what Clinton’s inner-circle thought about them. Ironically
column3: that dynamic now appears to apply to Clinton’s own team as well.

column1: Two clear conclusions jump out when trying to determine what these emails tell us about a future Clinton presidency.
One is that Clinton appears genuinely responsive to pressure from outside groups. Her team has clear goals
column2: but they’re also closely attuned to polls and to winning over the organizations (union backers
column3: environmentalist groups
column4: Black Lives Matter activists) whose support they think they need. In private conversations
column5: Clinton tells the audiences in front of her more or less what they want to hear.

column1: But while this appreciation for her listeners may reflect political savvy
column2: it also suggests a flexibility that may worry those on her left. What happens if President Clinton gets polling suggesting a majority of voters support slashing entitlements? What if the country clamors for a war in Iran? What if she can win over Republican voters by tacking to the center?

column1: And second
column2: more than anything
column3: the Podesta emails show how Clinton is the transactional politician many have long suspected. That’s a dispiriting conclusion for some who may wish she was a pure progressive. But it also helps clarify the battle lines for what looks like the coming Clinton administration — persuade her team they need you
column4: and you might have a shot at getting them on your side."	REAL

column1: FOX News Just Admitted It Made Up Story About Hillary Being “Indicted” For Foundation	"Comments

The alt-right and other Trump supporters were flush with excitement yesterday as their online echo chamber resounded with stories that Hillary Clinton was about to be indicted on the basis of the newly discovered emails on Anthony Weiner’s computer. Today
column2: of course
column3: we learned that this was nothing but a bold-faced lied. While many of the more obscure right -wing blogs named nothing but imaginary sources to support their outrageous claims
column4: the most legitimate source of the false story was none other than Fox News.

column1: On November 2 Fox News’ Bret Baier claimed that
column2: according to two anonymous sources within the FBI
column3: the agency’s investigation of Clinton would “continue to likely an indictment.” The very next day reality forced him to walk back those claims
column4: which he called “inartful
column5: ” acknowledging that “that’s not the process.”

column1: Nonetheless
column2: Baier did not entirely disavow his ruse of an imminent Clinton indictment
column3: maintaining that “there is confidence in the evidence.” Given that Clinton’s indictment has been impending for months in the right-wing universe one would think that these shameless schemers would have wised up to the fact that it’s not going to happen – and for good reason . Instead
column4: every time there is the slightest mention of Clinton’s emails
column5: no matter how vague and clearly inconsequential
column6: the alt-right rumor mill kicks into overdrive on its vicious crusade to smear the potential first female president in any way possible.

column1: In reality
column2: there is absolutely nothing so far to suggest that there is anything incriminating in the most recent batch of Clinton emails
column3: and it has become increasingly clear that FBI Director James Comey’s announcement of the renewed investigation was nothing but a cynical and hypocritical political ploy. In part the announcement was designed to fuel a new Republican storyline that Clinton is unfit for the presidency because she is under federal investigation. The demagogues making these claims conveniently ignore the fact that Trump is under investigation in no fewer than 75 cases
column4: including the rape of a 13 year-old girl.

column1: Another disconcerting storyline in yesterday’s firestorm of right-wing rumors is the political interference of Trump supporters in the FBI. If Baier’s so-called anonymous sources really were FBI agents
column2: it would represent yet another recent example of meddling in the presidential election by Trump supporters at the supposedly impartial agency. In any case
column3: the endless lies and distortions of the right-wing pseudo-media
column4: from Fox News down to the lowliest blog
column5: are doing a tremendous disservice to the American people."	FAKE

column1: A Hillary Clinton indictment is now likely .

column1: Alas

column4: therefore
column5: that in the near term (if not longer)

column1: A Trump Contribution?
By all indications
column2: Clinton will win the election on November 8th
column3: and virtually every political commentator will rejoice at the apparent demise of the Donald Trump phenomenon. As strange as it may seem
column4: however
column5: some of the passion of the Trump movement could provide fuel to the fire of reformist politics in the US. To be sure
column6: Trump's campaign has gone far towards legitimizing and normalizing bigotry and ignorance
column7: and this residue will persist. But Trump has also galvanized powerful resentment against an insular
column8: self-serving political class. This sentiment dovetails with a major thrust of Bernie Sanders's advocacy of social democratic policies and empowerment of the population to reverse the accumulation of all power in the hands of wealthy campaign donors and corporations.

column1: Further
column2: let us not forget
column3: Trump has consistently promoted the idea of shelving antagonism towards Russia in favor of cooperation
column4: together with reducing the role of the US military around the world. The point is not whether Trump genuinely means what he says (although one of his advisors who spoke with us insists that he does). The point is that Trump brought these positions out into the light
column5: which has allowed increasing numbers of Americans to question the nation's reflexive reliance on military might
column6: expansion
column7: and aggression as a pillar of its foreign policy. If the left is truly serious about unseating Washington's neoliberal status quo
column8: it should make every effort to harness some of the frustration that coalesced into the Trump movement towards broadly shared goals – getting the money out of politics being the most obvious.

column1: The Gullible Left
For the moment
column2: of course
column3: the huge majority of the left is consumed with the impending election
column4: and with the perceived imperative of defeating Trump by supporting Clinton as the «lesser evil» candidate. At first glance this seems eminently reasonable. But the certitude that has swept the country regarding the preferability of Clinton over Trump ought to give us pause. For those paying close attention
column5: it is not necessarily clear which candidate is the lesser evil. The flaws marring each candidate are so grotesque
column6: and the variables confronting the next administration are so uncertain
column7: that one can easily support a case in either direction. A small segment of the left will reject both Brahmins and cast affirmative votes for Green Party candidate Jill Stein
column8: of course. But the readiness of much of the left – the gullible left – to ignore Clinton's corruption
column9: crimes
column10: and cynicism is preemptively sapping the strength of the resistance that will be needed to push Madame President to pursue even half-baked progressive reforms on any issue.

column1: Meanwhile
column2: as the gullible left and center coalesce meekly around Clinton
column3: the real election is taking place behind the scenes: Clinton and her inner circle are lining up the key personnel who will largely determine the course of policy in her administration. Thanks to Wikileaks' publication of Clinton's current campaign chairman
column4: John Podesta
column5: we know very well that this process is far advanced by now. As David Dayen put it recently in « The New Republic »:

column1: If the 2008 Podesta emails are any indication
column2: the next four years of public policy are being hashed out right now
column3: behind closed doors.... Who gets these cabinet-level and West Wing advisory jobs matters as much as policy papers or legislative initiatives. It will inform executive branch priorities and responses to crises. It will dictate the level of enforcement of existing laws. It will establish the point of view of an administration and the advice Hillary Clinton will receive. Its importance cannot be stressed enough
column4: and the process has already begun. This is a fight over who dominates the Democratic Party’s policy thinking in the short and long term.

column1: Dayen adds that «...if liberals want to have an impact on that process
column2: waiting until after the election will be too late». Well
column3: one wonders why Dayen is so optimistic. Another Wikileaks release revealed that Clinton had more or less decided on Tim Kaine as her running mate all the way back in mid-2015 (!). Surely many of the top positions have long since been scripted
column4: and for those still in play
column5: can anyone – even David Dayen -- imagine public pressure making a difference in the selection?

column1: In short
column2: the world should prepare itself for a Hillary Clinton administration that is full of Washington establishment clones and is diligently protected from criticism by a like-minded media establishment. Moreover
column3: and more important
column4: we can already see the Clinton administration maneuvering to avoid the gridlock that minimized President Obama's effectiveness by pushing key foreign and domestic policies further to the right
column5: into the arms of the Republican Party. It is not difficult to locate telling indications on this score... «Sorry
column6: I can't vote for Mrs. Strangelove» – commenter «natureboy»
column7: renouncing Clinton for her hawkishness

column1: The implications of Clinton's ascendancy on US foreign policy are already coming into view
column2: and they are more than a little disturbing. An article from Washington Post White House correspondent Greg Jaffe on October 20th delivered news just as bad as we expected:

column1: The Republicans and Democrats who make up the foreign policy elite are laying the groundwork for a more assertive American foreign policy via a flurry of reports shaped by officials who are likely to play senior roles in a potential Clinton White House.... the bipartisan nature of the recent recommendations
column2: coming at a time when the country has never been more polarized
column3: reflects a remarkable consensus among the foreign policy elite. This consensus is driven by a broad-based backlash against a president who has repeatedly stressed the dangers of overreach and the need for restraint
column4: especially in the Middle East… Taken together
column5: the studies and reports call for more-aggressive American action to constrain Iran
column6: rein in the chaos in the Middle East and check Russia in Europe.

column1: Clinton is preparing a foreign policy more aggressive than Obama's
column2: in other words. And – take note – she'll enjoy bipartisan support for it. «The entire concept is a form of corporate blackmail» -- David Dayen
column3: characterizing Clinton's preparation of a tax repatriation policy that will permanently lower the tax obligations of large corporations.

column1: As far as domestic policy is concerned
column2: meanwhile
column3: all recent revelations point to a posture even more friendly to large corporate interests than that which has obtained under Obama. For example
column4: an important investigation from David Dayen just a few days ago exposed the Clinton circle's coordination with top Democrats and Republicans in preparing an enormous and permanent reduction on taxation of profits corporations earn abroad. As journalist Matt Taibbi once described a similar proposal: «Let's give a big tax break to the biggest tax cheats».

column1: Yes
column2: we can expect a few corporate-written trade deals to follow the tax reduction on profits earned overseas. And Wall Street will not be left out. Clinton has many options to assist her finance sector sponsors

column1: What do Americans really think of election coverage?	"More Americans think that the media are too easy on candidates than in 2012 or 2008
column2: according to a Pew Research Center poll. But they're also more likely to say that 'their' candidates are treated too harshly.

column1: Republican presidential candidate Donald Trump (l.)
column2: is interviewed by co-hosts Matt Lauer and Savannah Guthrie on the NBC 'Today' television program
column3: in New York
column4: on April 21

column1: Both presidential campaigns have been outspoken in saying that they think the media are too hard on them. But do Americans agree?
More Americans think the media are letting presidential candidates off easy than in previous years
column2: according to a poll released by the Pew Research Center on Thursday. In the case of Republican presidential nominee Donald Trump
column3: 27 percent of Americans think the media is too easy on him
column4: compared to 20 percent who reported feeling that way about coverage of the 2012 Republican nominee
column5: Mitt Romney
column6: and 15 percent for John McCain in 2008. Some 33 percent of Americans think coverage of Democratic nominee Hillary Clinton is too easy
column7: compared to 28 percent and 31 percent for President Obama in 2012 and 2008
column8: respectively
column9: according to the survey.

column1: Positive attitudes toward the media have reportedly been declining since the 1970s. Less than one-third of people now say that they have a “great deal” or “fair amount” of trust in the media. Scholars say this is part of a larger trend in poor attitudes toward institutions generally
column2: compounded by a rise in the number of media outlets and the polarization of these outlets.

column1: When people ""go into their newsfeed or turn on the TV and they're getting information from a wide array of sources
column2: and some of them are less than reputable ... it contributes to the sense"" that all media is untrustworthy
column3: David Jones
column4: a professor of political science at James Madison University
column5: told The Christian Science Monitor’s Gretel Kauffman earlier this month.

column1: A question about Americans’ attitude toward “the media” could refer to information expressing all kinds of opinions
column2: in forums as large as a TV network or national newspaper or as small as a Twitter feed.

column1: This polarity and range of sources could help explain why rising numbers of Americans also think that “the media” is being unnecessarily harsh – on their chosen candidates
column2: that is. Pew reported that three-in-ten Democrats and independents who lean Democratic are likely to see coverage of Mrs. Clinton as too tough. Nearly half of Republican surveyed – 46 percent – believe that coverage of Mr. Trump has been too tough.

column1: Finding the middle ground certainly isn’t easy. And nowhere is this clearer than in the high-stakes world of interviews and presidential debates. The Associated Press highlighted the demands placed on moderators with these guidelines offered during the 2012 election cycle:
Craft sharp questions to get the candidates to talk
column2: while being meticulously fair not to challenge one more than another. Keep an eye on the clock so one candidate doesn't get to hog the time. Don't be bullied; be firm in forcing the candidates to move on. But be flexible enough to keep a productive discussion flowing. Know the difference. Keep the focus off yourself. And do it all on live television before some 60 million people.

column1: Matt Lauer’s performance at NBC’s Commander-in-Chief forum earlier this month was widely panned
column2: with critics saying that he focused too heavily on Clinton’s email server and failed to fact-check some of Trump’s statements. Candy Crowley
column3: whose moderation of a 2012 debate Rush Limbaugh described as “an act of journalistic terror
column4: ” later told the Associated Press that she knew from the beginning that “somebody is always going to be unhappy no matter what you do.”

column1: For some
column2: the media’s election coverage – and Americans’ trust in the media on the basis of this coverage – is critical to American democracy.

column1: Citizens need information
column2: they need to get it from the media. The First Amendment was set up to create a media that served as a surrogate role for the public
column3: and if the public is not engaged and they move on and they're not consuming news ... it's really a disservice and it hurts our democracy a lot
column4: Jeff McCall
column5: a professor of communication at DePauw University
column6: told Fox News's Bill O'Reilly following a 2014 Gallup poll."	REAL

column1: Imran Khan (IK) and his partner Sheikh Rashid pursuing politics of agitation since mid-2014 are once again on a rampage and are determined to lock down Islamabad (Isbd) and seize power by force. Their tantrums have shot up the political temperature to a boiling point and has intensified uncertainty and insecurity. The Khyber Pakhtunkhwa (KP) Chief Minister Pervez Khattak along with PTI workers is exultantly moving in a convoy from Peshawar to reach Bani Gala and participate in the already declared November 2
column2: D-Day for the final showdown with the government (govt) at D-chowk. He has puerilely given an ethnic color to his march by playing the Pashtun card. He and his convey has been greeted by the Punjab Police with tear gas shells at Attock Bridge and Hazro interchange. The PML-Q
column3: PAT and PSP have pledged support to IK but from a distance. The PPP is gearing up to add fuel to fire. Maulana Fazlur Rahman led JUI-F has stood up in support of the beleaguered PML-N and has warned PTI that its march to Isbd will be contested. ANP
column4: NP
column5: QWP and MQM (P) sympathies are also with the ruling party.

column1: The fires of agitation lit by the PTI has spread to other cities as well. Containerization has taken the life of one army officer and one child and is causing great inconvenience to the dwellers of twin cities. Media is playing its usual negative role to keep the pot sizzling. One-seater Sheikh Rashid is being glorified and so is the bellicosity of IK
column2: while govt’s defensive acts are demeaned. Anchors and analysts are busy upping the ante and none seem to be interested in defusing the volatile situation. Hate campaign against NS and his family by the social media has touched new heights of slander. Political wrangling and filibustering is further damaging the image of Pakistan in the world and the cause of Kashmir.

column1: The master planners sitting in London
column2: Washington
column3: Tel Aviv and New Delhi are keeping their fingers crossed and are excitedly watching the gathering storm and hoping that the govt machinery in Isbd will be paralyzed and will force Nawaz Sharif (NS) to resign
column4: or the Army to intervene and take over. India is incessantly throwing logs into the fire by heating up the LoC
column5: while RAW-NDS are continuing with their covert operations in selected zones. Their major interest is to disrupt work on CPEC.

column1: Followers of IK are bubbling with enthusiasm and have gone hyper. Some were caught carrying weapons
column2: ammunition
column3: tear gas shells and bullet proof jackets. Most are carrying batons and young girls are equally aggressive. PTI’s armed Tiger Force has been tasked to battle with the Police/FC if stopped. They are already seeing their charismatic leader wearing the crown and with Aladdin lamp in his hand removing all the chronic ailments of Pakistan in a flash. They are convinced that once he seizes power
column4: milk and honey will start flowing in the rivers of Pakistan and miseries of the downtrodden will be alleviated. One reason of their euphoria is the apparent estrangement of the Army leadership over the security leak scandal. Their joys knew no bounds when Information Minister Pervez Rashid was sacked. It was seen as the beginning of the demise of NS Empire. It has further energized the PTI workers and they seem fully charged up to execute the orders of their Captain to lock down the capital city on November 2. IK has taken it as a last ditch battle. For him it is a do or die battle. He is once again expectantly looking towards Gen Raheel Sharif to raise his finger.

column1: Undoubtedly the security leak has suddenly become a bigger challenge for the govt than the IK threat. A high powered committee comprising of members from ISI
column2: MI and IB will carry out in-depth investigation to trace out the culprits responsible for feeding the story and that too in twisted form to the Dawn newspaper
column3: who were behind it
column4: what was the motive
column5: apportion blame and prescribe punishment. It is to be seen where the trail ends. Absence of the author of the controversial story Cyril Almeida will make things difficult for the investigators.

column1: Unlike its defensive stance to the 2014 sit-in
column2: which had lingered on for 126 days without any outcome
column3: this time the govt is in a defiant mood and is flexing its muscles to go to any length to defeat the sinister plans of the invaders. Containers have been placed on all entry points of Isbd and along Peshawar-Isbd road and along Bani Gala road. Large contingents of the police and paramilitary troops have been deployed while the army has been alerted to be prepared to defend Isbd under Article 245. At the moment
column4: the entire leadership of PTI have got stranded in IK residence at Bani Gala. NS has addressed two public meetings in KP and his tone and tenor gave no sign of nervousness. Rather he was quite confident to win next elections in 2018 on the strength of his achievements and dismal performance of PTI in KP and PPP in Sindh. The govt side is of the view that there is no reason for IK to agitate when the Supreme Court has accepted his petition and NS has been summoned on account of Panama scandal. They say
column5: PTI youth wing violated the curfew imposed under Section 144 CrPC and also defied Isbd High Court restraining order not to create mayhem.

column1: Pervez Rashid was in bad books of IK and his colleagues due to his counter jibes whenever IK lambasted NS. But he was not the most sought target. His unceremonious exit or an in-house change doesn’t fulfil the ambition of IK to become the PM. He desires that NS should be booted out or he quits voluntarily irrespective of the fact that his name does not appear in the list of account holders in Off Shore Company. He has no idea what is in store for him if NS is forced to throw in his towel. In all likelihood
column2: the ruckus in the aftermath of NS departure will drown IK’s ambitions. It cannot be denied that NS is still the most popular leader and he has many feathers in his cap. His 3 rd time premature boot out will make him a political martyr and will not be taken lightly by his fans in Punjab. Baluchistan govt and JUI-F would also not welcome his ouster particularly when he had presented him and his family for accountability and the matter was with the courts.

column1: The situation will become ripe for chaos which outside powers have all along been trying to foment. The Army may have to grudgingly step in to restore semblance of order. In the wake of tense geo-political environment
column2: terrorism
column3: acute polarization
column4: feudal mindset
column5: partisanship
column6: parochialism and secular-Islamic divide
column7: it will not be possible for the Army to restore order and hold elections within three months as prescribed in the constitution. Supposedly
column8: if elections do take place within 3 months
column9: PML-N will surely win the race and perhaps PTI may lose KP as well.

column1: Elections without reforms will otherwise be an exercise in futility. The Army will perforce have to stretch its rule to 3-5 years if not more to be able to take Operation Zarb-e-Azb
column2: Rangers operation in Karachi
column3: FC operation in Baluchistan and ongoing combing operation to their logical ends; to implement the National Action Plan in letter and spirit
column4: and to complete the vital project of CPEC. Additionally it will have to carry out following reforms for a better morrow and for enabling environment for true democracy to flourish: 1. Electoral
column5: political
column6: police
column7: bureaucracy
column8: judicial
column9: education
column10: media reforms. 2. Breaking the nexus between crime
column11: politics
column12: terrorism and corruption. 3. Effective accountability system. 4. Cleansing the Aegean Stables.

column1: All this will be possible only when there is strict martial law and politicians of all hues are kept at bay. Will this arrangement be acceptable to IK? If he is prepared to wait for 5 years
column2: why not hold on for 1 ½ years and contest the 2018 elections and win the coveted crown!! Moreover
column3: what is the guarantee that the Army will be able to put everything right since it was not able to do so in the past? Things may become messier. Memory of our people is very short lived. Soon they will forget the ills of NS and his good deeds will be recalled with fondness and the Army will be put on the mat with a vengeance as had happened during the four military rules. True to their tradition
column4: anti-Pakistan foreign powers will be behind the anti-Army campaign. Political destabilization suit the conspirators since it makes it easier for them to exert pressure and dictate terms. It is indeed most unfortunate that our politicians are fighting for power among each other
column5: while the media and so-called educated lot are supporting their favorite political leaders and feel no qualm in passing lecherous and insulting remarks against their opponents. Preferably
column6: all our guns should be collectively firing at our enemies who are bent upon breaking up Pakistan.

Attkisson
column4: however
column5: resigned from CBS News because she felt the entire network was biased in favor of the Obama administration and refused to allow her to pursue the scandals she just knew were there. (These were scandals like Benghazi and Fast and Furious — scandals that have been investigated approximately 756 times under every committee in the Congress and have turned up zilch.) Somehow they’ve managed to morph this professional dispute into a story of Attkisson being victimized by the authoritarian police state.

column1: It would have been interesting to hear testimony about the government’s pursuit of leaks and reporters over the past few years
column2: which really is a scandal and which should form the basis of questioning for the new attorney general. But since both parties are generally in favor of this practice
column3: that wasn’t to be. Instead the Republicans called one of their celebrity martyrs to testify about how hard it is for a conservative to live in this world.

column1: The next activist they called to testify about Loretta Lynch was a man who admittedly has absolutely no knowledge of her but had something to say about how Eric Holder was very mean to police officers around the country. He is an African-American sheriff from Wisconsin named David Clarke who up to this point is best known for his appearances on “Fox and Friends” in which he says things like
column2: “the NAACP is nothing more than a propaganda entity for the left” and that the behavior of black people is the reason they are getting shot so often. He suggested that the federal government is waging a war on police and should butt out of local business.

column1: The final activist of the day was a citizen who has been working her heart out trying to protect our electoral system from the scourge of nonexistent voter fraud. That would be a woman named Catherine Englebrecht
column2: who runs a far-right-wing group called True the Vote
column3: which sends out groups of “observers” to African-American and Hispanic polling places to make sure they’re not stealing the votes of decent Americans. Upon Eric Holder’s resignation
column4: her group put out a press release stating that Holder had carried out a “radical
column5: racialist assault on voting rights.” She was there to complain about the Department of Justice failing to immediately interview her over the alleged IRS scandal and to excoriate them over the “nightmare of citizen targeting.” She then testified that Loretta Lynch was wrong in saying that laws had been passed throughout the South to prevent some people from voting. Sen. Jeff Sessions pointed out that an Alabama Tea Party leader had been victimized by the IRS and nobody at the IRS cares. Sen. Orrin Hatch expressed his deepest sympathy for what she’s been through and assured her that they were going to get to bottom of it. Her voice cracked with emotion as she said
column6: “Thank you
column7: sir.” This was the first committee hearing of the new Senate Judiciary Committee under GOP rule
column8: a hearing to determine the fitness of a presidential nominee to the most powerful law enforcement office in the land
column9: and they called a group of partisan crackpots and grass-roots loons to relitigate moldy pseudo-scandals and complain about nonexistent government persecution. And it’s not as if they couldn’t have found some real scandals to talk about. The Obama Justice Department is hardly perfect. But they are married to their Foxified version of reality and simply can’t see the forest for the trees. The whole spectacle was a nostalgic trip back in time to the days of Clinton madness when the judiciary committees were able to leverage any public hearing into a scandal fest. The press seems less inclined to go along these days
column10: a fact that Sharyl Attkisson would surely attribute to its political bias. But the truth is that these “scandals” are just sad echoes of the scandal-mongering of the 1990s. The energy is gone
column11: the issues seem pale and lifeless. Not that there was ever any “there” there
column12: but they are now just going through the motions. But I hope Democrats don’t get too complacent. President Obama has never been able to get their scandal mojo rising. But there’s every reason to suspect that this is just an off-season workout for what they see as a return to the big leagues. If Hillary Clinton wins the presidency you can be sure there will be a return to the fiery investigations whenever the Republicans hold either house of Congress. And if history serves
column13: the press will likely be eager to join the team. But this sad little show reveals just how much they are in need of some spring training. Loretta Lynch may be a genial public servant in the mold of Ernie Banks
column14: but when it comes to scandal management
column15: Clinton is Babe Ruth. They are going to need to up their game significantly."	REAL

TRUMP ADVISORS TRY TO PIVOT NOT FISHTAIL
HOLLYWOOD
column2: FLA. – It’s a fine line between a general election shift and the dreaded ‘Etch A Sketch.’

column1: Donald Trump’s supporters give him broad latitude on issues and even his promise of an attitudinal change. For example
column2: his suggestion that the Republicans should become a pro-choice party likely wrinkled few brows among his core supporters.

column1: The idea that Trump would change his attitude and approach along with his opinions wouldn’t trouble many who have faith in him as a man and a leader. For those who believe the Trump is the only person who can make America great again
column2: putting on a new guise for the general election would be nothing troubling.

column1: Remember
column2: these are people who believe him when he describes himself as the new Reagan and the person more presidential than anybody since Lincoln.

column1: But can Trump create a habitat that is healthy for both his backers and the kinds of folks that his newly expanded campaign are schmoozing here in Hollywood without further antagonizing the substantial chunk of his party that ranges from resentful to outright outraged about Trump’s surprising success in overtaking the GOP?
Trump had a very good day here Thursday. Aside from turning back a Rules Committee vote that might’ve helped Sen. Ted Cruz win a floor fight at the convention
column2: delegates and other members of the establishment were very impressed by Trump’s campaign’s effort to start sucking up to them.

column1: Promises of Trump’s flexibility when served alongside seafood platters and open bars from his new K Street handlers went a long way toward convincing the GOP elite that Trump is ready to play ball.
Little could be more comforting to them than the pledge from Trump’s campaign boss that the wildness of the frontrunner to this point has been a put on.
Consultants and party elders are not uncomfortable with the idea of tricking rubes or profit and or patriotism. And for those facing general election oblivion
column2: anything that sounds like avoiding a savage showdown in Cleveland and not losing the general election by 40 states sounds good.

column1: But even if Trump and his new handlers can keep the GOP elite and his existing populist base happy
column2: the current maneuvers do pose a risk.

column1: The most important thing for the Republican frontrunner right now is for his detractors and enemies on the conservative side of the party to just give up.
There are enough Republicans who loathe Trump to still stop him. But they have to go vote and they have to be willing to blow up their conventions to do it.
When Trump’s new Sherpa suggests that it has all been a fake so far
column2: that gives new cause for alarm to the conservatives who already deeply mistrust Trump and see him as more of a Democrat than Republican.

column1: All Trump needs in order to win is for the resistance to just lay down for a couple of weeks. When they wake up it will all be over.
But if Trump starts fishtailing in his turn towards conventionality it will reinvigorate the #NeverTrump movement.
It’s great to suck up to the party
column2: even belatedly
column3: but doing in such a transparent manner could be hazardous to Trump’s nomination.

WHAT HAPPENED TO WORKING MAN’S LIBERALISM?

Vox’s Emmet Rensin takes a deep dive into a concept he dubs “smug style” liberalism in America and how the political concept changed from an ideology of the working class to that of the elite. How did this happen and what has the smug style done to American liberalism? This lengthy piece goes into the origins and results of the shift in American political thought:
“The smug style is a psychological reaction to a profound shift in American political demography. Beginning in the middle of the 20th century
column2: the working class
column3: once the core of the coalition
column4: began abandoning the Democratic Party…In 1964
column5: it was 55 percent of working-class voters. By 1980
column6: it was 35 percent…The smug recognize one another by their mutual knowing…It is the smug style’s first premise: a politics defined by a command of the Correct Facts and signaled by an allegiance to the Correct Culture…So long as liberals cannot find common cause with the larger section of the American working class
column7: they will search for reasons to justify that failure. They will resent them. They will find
column8: over and over
column9: how easy it is to justify abandoning them further.  They will choose the smug style.”

column1: Christians drop, 'nones' soar in new religion portrait	"WASHINGTON — The United States is a significantly less Christian country than it was seven years ago.
That's the top finding — one that will ricochet through American faith
column2: culture and politics — in the Pew Research Center's newest report
column3: ""America's Changing Religious Landscape
column4: released Tuesday.

column1: This trend ""is big
column2: it's broad and it's everywhere
column3: said Alan Cooperman
column4: Pew's director of religion research.

column1: Christianity still dominates American religious identity (70%)
column2: but the survey shows dramatic shifts as more people move out the doors of denominations
column3: shedding spiritual connections along the way.

column1: Atheists and agnostics have nearly doubled their share of the religious marketplace
column2: and overall indifference to religion of any sort is rising as well. Only the historically black Protestant churches have held a steady grip through the years of change.

column1: Remember the familiar map of American religion? The South: A bastion of white evangelicals. The Northeast: Cradle of Catholics. The Midwest: Nest of Mainline Protestants. The West: Incubator of ""nones"" — people who claim no religious brand label.
Well
column2: scratch all that in the new topography.

column1: The shrinking numbers of Christians and their loss of market share is the most significant change since 2007 (when Pew did its first U.S. Religious Landscape survey) and the new
column2: equally massive survey of 35
column3: 000 U.S. adults.

column1: The percentage of people who describe themselves as Christians fell about 8 points — from 78.4% to 70.6%. This includes people in virtually all demographic groups
column2: whether they are ""nearing retirement or just entering adulthood
column3: married or single
column4: living in the West or the Bible Belt
column5: according to the survey report.

column1: Massachusetts is down on Catholics by 10 percentage points. South Carolina is down the same degree on evangelicals. Mainline Protestants
column2: already sliding for 40 years or more
column3: declined all over the Midwest by 3 to 4 percentage points.The Southern Baptist Convention and the United Methodist Church
column4: the country's two largest Protestant denominations
column5: are each down roughly the same 1.4 to 1.5 percentage points.Every tradition took a hit in in the West as the number of people who claim no religious brand continues to climb.

column1: Christian faiths are troubled by generational change — each successive group is less connected than their parents — and by ""switching"" at all ages
column2: the report shows. While nearly 86% of Americans say they grew up as Christians
column3: nearly one in five (19%) say they aren't so anymore.

column1: Overall
column2: there are more than four former Christians for every convert to Christianity
column3: said Cooperman.

column1: Although evangelicals are part of the decline
column2: their slide has been less steep. They benefit from more people joining evangelical traditions
column3: but they're hurt by generational change and by America's increased diversity.

column1: According to the survey
column2: white ""born-again or evangelical"" Protestants — closely watched for their political clout within the GOP — now account for 19% of American adults
column3: down slightly from 21% in 2007.

column1: Politicians should take note
column2: said Mike Hout
column3: a sociologist and demographer at New York University who is also a co-director of the General Social Survey.

column1: Traditionally
column2: we thought religion was the mover and politics were the consequence
column3: he said. Today
column4: it's the opposite.

column1: Many of today's formerly faithful left conservative evangelical or Catholic denominations because ""they saw them align with a conservative political agenda and they don't want to be identified with that
column2: Hout said.

column1: Catholics dropped both in market share and in real numbers. Despite their high retention rate for people reared in the faith
column2: they have a low conversion rate. Today
column3: Cooperman said
column4: 13% of U.S. adults are former Catholics
column5: up from 10% in 2007.

column1: Generational shifts are also hurting Catholic numbers. Greg Smith
column2: Pew's associate director of research
column3: said ""just 16% of the 18-to-24-year-olds today are Catholic
column4: and that is not enough to offset the numbers lost to the aging and switching.""

column1: Where are they going? To religious nowhere.

The ""nones"" — Americans who are unaffiliated with brand-name religion — are the new major force in American faith. And they are more secular in outlook — and ""more comfortable admitting it"" than ever before
column2: said John Green
column3: director of the Bliss Institute of Applied Politics at the University of Akron.

column1: Their growth spans the generations
column2: as well as racial and ethnic groups
column3: said Green
column4: a senior fellow in religion and American politics for the Pew Research Center.

column1: Nones
column2: at 22.8% of the U.S. (up from 16% just eight years ago) run second only to evangelicals (25.4%) and ahead of Catholics (20.8%) in religious market share.

column1: The ""nones"" numbers are now big enough to show noteworthy diversity:
Atheists rose from 1.6% to 3.1%
column2: and agnostics from 2.4% to 4%. Combined
column3: there are more ""nones"" than Evangelical Lutherans
column4: United Methodists and Episcopalians all together.

column1: It's because we're right
column2: crowed David Silverman
column3: president of American Atheists. He hadn't yet seen the Pew findings
column4: but commented based on other surveys he said showed nones rising numbers. Indeed
column5: it's the public attention given to ""nones"" in the last decade
column6: combined with the wide-open access to anti-religious discussion on the Internet
column7: that drives the change
column8: Silverman said.

column1: More people know the facts
column2: and more people realize they are not alone
column3: Silverman said. And with these shifts
column4: the stigma of coming out as an atheist is lessening.

column1: It's now impossible for an atheist to think he is alone in this world. They are automatically empowered
column2: said Silverman.

column1: The bulk of the ""nones"" (15.8%
column2: up from 12.1% in 2007) don't even commit to any view on God. Instead
column3: they say they believe ""nothing in particular.""

column1: But among the ""nothings
column2: there's a distinct split between ""spiritual"" and totally indifferent ""nones.""

column1: Thirty percent of all ""nones"" still showed ""a sort of religious pulse"" by saying that religion is still at least somewhat important to them
column2: said Cooperman.

column1: However
column2: the bulk of this group (39%) are not agnostic
column3: atheist or vaguely spiritual — they're just not interested. Religion is not even somewhat important to them.

column1: That same level of disinterest cuts into their social and political clout
column2: said Hout.

column1: The nothing-in-particular folks ""don't vote
column2: don't marry and don't have kids
column3: at the same rate as other Americans
column4: said Hout. ""They are allergic to large
column5: organized institutions — mass media
column6: religions
column7: big corporations
column8: and political parties.""

column1: None"" is the winning category for religious switchers across society
column2: particularly among gay and lesbians — 41% of gay or lesbian Americans say they have no religion. Cooperman said. ""This suggests the degree of alienation and discomfort and sense of being unwelcome that they may have felt in traditional religious groups.""

column1: Intermarriage is rising with each generation. Among Americans who have gotten married since 2010
column2: nearly four-in-ten (39%) report that they are in religiously mixed marriages
column3: compared with 19% among those who got married before 1960
column4: according to the report.

column1: There's an identity gender gap. Most Christians are women (55%) and most ""nones"" are men (57%). However
column2: women's unbelief numbers are growing: nearly one in five (19%) now say they have no religious identity.Diversity makes a difference. Racial and ethnic minorities now make up 41% of Catholics (up from 35% in 2007)
column3: 24% of evangelicals (up from 19%) and 14% of mainline Protestants (up from 9%). ""The share of Americans who identify with non-Christian faiths also has inched up
column4: rising 1.2 percentage points
column5: from 4.7% in 2007 to 5.9% in 2014. Growth has been especially great among Muslims and Hindus
column6: the report said.

column1: The latest survey was conducted among a nationally representative sample of 35
column2: 071 adults interviewed by telephone
column3: on both cellphones and landlines
column4: from June 4-Sept. 30
column5: 2014. The margin of error on overall findings is plus or minus 0.6 percentage points."	REAL

column1: Comment on Brother of Clinton’s Campaign Chair is an Active Foreign Agent on the Saudi Arabian Payroll by marlene	"Posted on October 27
column2: 2016 by Claire Bernish

column1: Tony Podesta — brother of the now-disgraced Hillary Clinton campaign chair John Podesta
column2: whose files Wikileaks has been publishing — is not only a powerful Democratic Party lobbyist
column3: but a registered foreign agent receiving a hefty monthly paycheck from the nefarious government of Saudi Arabia.

column1: No — as tinfoil-hat conspiracy theorist as it might sound — that scenario is the absolute truth.

column2: John and Tony Podesta formed the Podesta Group and have used their bigwig party-insider status to lobby and influence government policies — while
column3: at various times
column4: simultaneously holding positions of power — which has created a number of glaring conflicts of interest.

column1: According to the March 2016 filing made in accordance with the Foreign Agents Registration Act of 1938
column2: Tony Podesta is an active foreign agent of the Saudi government with the “ Center for Studies and Media Affairs at the Saudi Royal Court
column3: ” and acts as an officer of the Saudi Arabia account.

column1: At this point
column2: the web of pay-for-play between the Washington
column3: political heavyweights
column4: and foreign governments comes lurching into the spotlight.

column1: For starters
column2: the Podesta brothers’ lobbying firm receives $140
column3: 000 every month from the Saudi government
column4: which
column5: in no uncertain terms — and despite a status as privileged U.S. ally — wages a bloody campaign of censorship
column6: murder
column7: suppression
column8: human rights abuse
column9: and worse against its civilian population
column10: while bombing hospitals
column11: schools
column12: and aid convoys in neighboring nations.

column1: John Podesta previously served as President Bill Clinton’s chief of staff
column2: founded the think tank Center for American Progress (which oh-so-coincidentally touts the need to reframe Saudi Arabia’s hopelessly tarnished image)
column3: counseled President Obama
column4: and now chairs Hillary Clinton’s campaign.

column1: Tony Podesta acts as a foreign agent for the Kingdom of Saudi Arabia — lobbying to influence government policy in favor of the Kingdom — while also contributing to and bundling for Hillary Clinton’s campaign.
Think about that for a moment.

One brother uses the influence of money to both affect United States foreign policy and infuse the Clinton campaign with cash — while the other wields the influence of power as a political insider for the same entities.
As the Washington Post reported months ago in July
column2: Tony Podesta’s lobbying efforts “raised $268
column3: 000 for the campaign and $31
column4: 000 for the victory fund.”

column1: “The Saudis hired the Podesta Group in 2015 because it was getting hammered in the press over civilian casualties from its airstrikes in Yemen and its crackdown on political dissidents at home
column2: including sentencing blogger Raif Badawi to ten years in prison and 1
column3: 000 lashes for ‘insulting Islam
column4: ’” Alternet reported . “Since then
column5: Tony Podesta’s fingerprints have been all over Saudi Arabia’s advocacy efforts in Washington DC. When Saudi Arabia executed the prominent nonviolent Shia dissident Sheikh Nimr al-Nimr
column6: causing protests throughout the Shia world and inflaming sectarian divisions
column7: The New York Times noted that the Podesta Group provided the newspaper with a Saudi commentator who defended the execution.”

column1: Notably
column2: the Saudis’ reputation has only worsened as further atrocities pile up — concerning not only a record number of barbaric beheadings this year
column3: but suspiciously reckless and errant U.S.-backed coalition bombings of civilian sites in several regions of active conflict.

column1: Additionally
column2: Tony Podesta’s status as a registered foreign agent for Saudi Arabia is at least obliquely discussed in an email from April 15
column3: 2015 — ironically revealed by Wikileaks’ publishing of his brothers personal communiques — in which former Clinton Foundation chief development officer and now campaign national finance director Dennis Cheng wrote to a small group of insiders:

column1: “Hi all – we do need to make a decision on this ASAP as our friends who happen to be registered with FARA [Foreign Agents Registration Act] are already donating and raising.
“I do want to push back a bit (it’s my job!): I feel like we are leaving a good amount of money on the table (both for primary and general
column2: and then DNC and state parties)… and how do we explain to people that we’ll take money from a corporate lobbyist but not them; that the Foundation takes $ from foreign govts but we now won’t. Either way
column3: we need to make a decision soon.”

column1: To which general counsel to the Clinton campaign
column2: attorney Marc Elias
column3: replied [all errors original and emphasis added]

column1: “Responding to all on this. I was not on the call this morning
column2: but I lean away from a bright line rule here. It seems odd to say that someone who represents Alberta
column3: Canada can’t give
column4: but a lobbyist for Phillip Morris can. Just as we vet lobbyists case by case
column5: I would do the same with FARA. While this may lead to a large number of FARA registrants being denied
column6: it would not be a flat our ban. A total ban feels arbitrary and will engender the same eye-rolling and ill will that it did for Obama.”

column1: As the exchange continues
column2: how to precisely handle the campaign’s image with potentially controversial donors — while
column3: at all costs
column4: maintaining the flow of cash — becomes even more apparent. As strategist and campaign manager Robby Mook responds

column1: “Where do we draw the line though?”
Elias suggests a particularly intricate solution:
“If we do it case by case

column1: There could be ten or more Republican candidates by this summer. That might be when Hillary Clinton gets around to officially moving toward a campaign

column3: who are privately arguing for an announcement in July to coincide with the start of the third fundraising quarter. Delaying until the summer is an idea that is said to be gaining momentum against those who want to stick to the plan for an April start date.

I would say it's 40 percent
column2: in the direction of those arguing for a delay

column1: Democrats on both sides of the debate spoke to CNN on the condition of anonymity so they could make their case without upsetting Clinton or those close to her for talking openly about internal deliberations.

column3: ""People don't give that kind of money on speculation.""

column1: In France, a growing debate over why some speech is protected and some isn’t	"They tease terrorists. The prophet Muhammad cries. A devout Muslim woman shows some leg
column2: and more. They take on Pope Francis
column3: German Chancellor Angela Merkel
column4: French Prime Minister Manuel Valls. There are nuns
column5: priests
column6: rabbis and imams. They laugh at death itself.

column1: The latest edition of Charlie Hebdo
column2: the satirical newspaper attacked last week by Islamist extremists for lampooning the prophet Muhammad
column3: became a symbol of freedom of expression as soon as it hit newsstands Wednesday — selling out millions of copies before dawn. Yet
column4: in a country that mobilized Sunday by the millions in support of the paper’s right to mock
column5: France also found itself facing a mounting debate over the limits of free speech within its borders.

column1: French authorities on Wednesday detained and charged a notorious comedian
column2: Dieudonné M’bala M’bala
column3: with “glorifying terrorism” for an ambiguous Facebook post Sunday that
column4: to some
column5: appeared to show support for the gunman who killed four people in a kosher market Friday.

column1: Since last week’s attacks
column2: at least 54 people have faced similar charges — including several underage pranksters and drunken louts who were mouthing off. Authorities have used a beefed up anti-terrorism law passed last year to expedite their cases and issue harsher jail sentences — with one offender arrested Saturday already receiving a four-year sentence. The Justice Ministry has also issued fresh orders for prosecutors to crack down on “anti-Semitic and racist acts or speech.”

column1: Laurent Léger
column2: an investigative journalist for Charlie Hebdo who survived the attack
column3: said there was no comparing the newspaper to Dieudonné — a French showman of Cameroonian descent who popularized a Nazi-like salute and who jokes about the Holocaust.

column1: “Dieudonné does not know the Charlie spirit
column2: ” Léger said. “Charlie never glorified terrorism. Dieudonné is a bit too quick when he claims that his freedom of speech is being hampered. His attitude is just making things worse by continuing the confusion that is destroying this country.”

column1: Yet others disagreed
column2: saying France was in danger of trouncing the very right it is aiming to protect: freedom of expression.

column1: “We can definitely talk about hypocrisy here
column2: ” said Adrienne Charmet
column3: campaign coordinator for La Quadrature du Net
column4: a Paris-based Internet rights group. “In the past days
column5: we have seen a lot of people condemned for putting out words
column6: no matter how condemnable those words
column7: and receiving sentences that seem quite exaggerated.”

column1: “French opinion is split in two
column2: ” she added. “Some see it as the worst possible response to last week’s attack
column3: because many of those who have said these things were drunk
column4: or teenagers
column5: who did not know the weight of their words. But there is another segment of the population that does agree
column6: because they feel these people are making themselves accomplices to terror. Either way
column7: this crackdown on freedom of speech is a betrayal of last Sunday’s march.”

column1: Charlie Hebdo was undoubtedly the hottest property in town Wednesday
column2: with lines snaking for blocks as Parisians clamored for copies that sold out within minutes. An initial print run of 3 million copies was expanded to 5 million when kiosks across the country ran out.

column1: Surviving staff members
column2: who worked day and night after the Jan. 7 attack to ensure the issue came out on time
column3: produced the paper. With their offices still roped off as a crime scene
column4: the staff worked out of a conference room at the left-wing daily Libération. The offices there are being guarded around the clock by an extraordinary number of police officers and private security guards.

column1: There was plenty inside the paper to stir controversy. The 16-page edition brims with the sort of irreverent
column2: off-color humor that made Charlie famous — and infamous. No one is spared ridicule.

column1: In one cartoon
column2: two hooded terrorists are pictured in heaven
column3: with one asking the other
column4: “Where are the virgins?”

column1: “They’re with the Charlie staff
column2: loser
column3: ” his accomplice replies.

column1: Another pictures a harried and exhausted cartoonist hunched over his desk
column2: with a caption that reads
column3: “Cartooning at Charlie Hebdo
column4: it’s 25 years of work.” The next panel shows hooded gunmen mowing people down with a Kalashnikov
column5: accompanied by the words
column6: “For a terrorist
column7: it’s 25 seconds of work.”

column1: As ever with Charlie Hebdo
column2: the goal is to provoke
column3: to stir debate and to make people laugh — while also reminding anyone who might think otherwise that reading Charlie can be distinctly discomfiting.

column1: The paper’s lead editorial offers a vigorous defense of secular values
column2: saying that staffers laughed when they heard that the bells of the Cathedral of Notre Dame would ring in their honor.

column1: “The millions of anonymous people
column2: all the institutions
column3: all the world leaders
column4: all the politicians
column5: all the intellectuals and media figures
column6: all the religious dignitaries who proclaimed this week that ‘I am Charlie’ need to also know that that means
column7: ‘I am secularism
column8: ’ ” the editorial says.

column1: Delphine Ravion-Casalta
column3: spent an hour and a half visiting three newsstands Wednesday morning before she found her Charlie. She sipped coffee at a cafe
column4: her copy proudly spread out before her
column5: eagerly taking in every word.

column1: “In France
column2: we’re still fighting for our freedom
column3: ” she said. “We had revolution for our freedom. A lot of revolutions. And great men like Voltaire and Rousseau. The fight for those ideas continues.”

column1: The rush for copies of Charlie Hebdo came as French authorities detained and charged Dieudonné
column2: 48. After the unity march that brought 1.5 million people onto the streets of Paris on Sunday
column3: the comedian wrote: “After this historic
column4: no legendary
column5: march
column6: a magic moment equal to the Big Bang which created the Universe
column7: or in a smaller way comparable to the crowning of the [ancient king] Vercingétorix
column8: I am going home. Let me say that this evening
column9: as far as I am concerned
column10: I feel I am Charlie Coulibaly.”

column1: Charlie Coulibaly is a reference to both Charlie Hebdo and Amedy Coulibaly
column2: the gunman who killed four people in a Paris kosher market on Friday. The comedian
column3: in a second Facebook post Monday
column4: sought to clarify his remark
column5: saying his purpose was “to make people laugh
column6: and to laugh at death
column7: since death makes fun of us all
column8: as Charlie very well knows.” He concluded by saying
column9: “They consider me to be Amedy Coulibaly when I am no different from a Charlie.”

column1: Valls
column2: speaking in the National Assembly
column3: sought to draw a distinction between the creative caricatures of Charlie Hebdo and the comedian’s hate-based humor
column4: while insisting that France was not compromising freedom of speech.

column1: “There is a fundamental difference between the freedom to be impertinent
column2: and anti-Semitism
column3: racism
column4: glorification of terrorist acts and Holocaust denial
column5: all of which are offenses
column6: all of which are crimes
column7: that justice should punish with the most severity
column8: ” he said."	REAL

During a Wednesday Security Council meeting

column3: which has been in place for the last eight days.
