column1: Lieutenant General Sergei Rudskoi of the Russian military's General Staff said that Russian and Syrian jets had stayed 10 kilometers away from Aleppo since October 18
column2: and that humanitarian corridors out of Aleppo remained open.

column1: Rudskoi further expressed Moscow’s readiness to organize more ceasefires on the ground in Aleppo to allow wounded civilians to be evacuated. Smoke rises from buildings hit by militant shelling in a government-held neighborhood of the Syrian city of Aleppo on October 20
Aleppo
column2: Syria’s second largest city
column3: has been divided between government forces in the west and the militants in the east since 2012. In an attempt to free the trapped civilian population and to end the militants’ reign of terror in the east
column4: the Syrian army

column1: Representative Government or Thugocracy?	"Print
I feel strongly that the Supreme Court needs to stand on the side of the American people
column2: not on the side of the powerful corporations and the wealthy. For me
column3: that means that we need a Supreme Court that will stand up on behalf of women’s rights
column4: on behalf of the rights of the LGBT community
column5: that will stand up and say no to Citizens United
column6: a decision that has undermined the election system in our country because of the way it permits dark
column7: unaccountable money to come into our electoral system. ”

column1: – Hillary Clinton
The first salvo from Democratic presidential nominee Hillary Clinton (or rather
column2: her answer to the first question posed by Fox News’ Chris Wallace to her and Donald Trump at the third presidential debate) was as chilling as it was an exemplar of hypocrisy.

column1: Those on the left are quite fond of leveling the accusation against conservatives of employing “dog whistle politics
column2: ” rhetoric that allegedly contains hidden or esoteric derogatory messaging which targets a specific subgroup within the opposition. Ms. Clinton’s response to Wallace’s question (where they wanted to see the Supreme Court take the country
column3: and their views on how the Constitution ought to be interpreted) however
column4: was representative of this tactic.

column1: While women’s rights and those of the LGBT community may seem to be a curious focus for the high court (since objectively
column2: women wouldn’t appear to be particularly oppressed given that one has been nominated to run for president
column3: and the LGBT community accounts for less than 5 percent of the American population)
column4: Clinton’s answer revealed the focus she believes the court should have once she becomes empress.

column1: “Women’s rights” is of course “dog whistle” for unfettered abortion
column2: even late-term abortion
column3: which is essentially infanticide via dismemberment. “LGBT rights” is “dog whistle” for disenfranchising the majority of Americans who hold traditional values
column4: primarily Christians. Leveraging a vocal minority of homosexuals
column5: bisexuals and transgender individuals whom the left has whipped into a froth against Christians is the methodology that was employed to negate the political power of Christians in Europe and Canada. A direct assault via legislation in this area would not work in the U.S. (at least not at present); however
column6: judicial rulings could effectively bring about the same result.

column1: Let us leave aside for a moment the fact that judicial activism is unethical and skirts the Constitution and that Clinton’s overall objectives are manifestly evil. Hillary Clinton’s stated priorities for the Supreme Court are a clear indicator of her desire to use the court as a bludgeon against the Constitution and individual liberties
column2: rather than allowing it to perform its designated function. The hypocrisy attendant to Clinton citing the rights of women and homosexuals when she is beholden via financial contributions to nations that institutionally persecute and murder members of these groups remains plain for all to see
column3: despite being conveniently ignored by the press.

column1: Clinton’s reference to “powerful corporations and the wealthy” and the malign influence of that sinister conservative organization
column2: Citizens United
column3: was of course another exercise in blatant hypocrisy. Clinton is quite wealthy
column4: and corrupt or otherwise compromised powerful corporations have been instrumental in bringing about the designs of American socialists. Even if Citizens United were a vehicle for “dark
column5: unaccountable money
column6: ” the scope of its influence would pale next to the subversive designs of the Muslim Brotherhood
column7: with which Bill and Hillary Clinton have been partnered for decades
column8: or the myriad tentacles of organizations funded by George Soros
column9: the former Nazi collaborator dedicated to advancing oligarchical collectivism in America
column10: someone with whom the Clintons also have a long association.

column1: One need not attempt to decipher the thinly veiled intent behind Clinton’s debate rhetoric to discern what a Hillary Clinton presidency might look like. Her actions to date – and particularly those in the pursuit of seeking that office – should suffice quite nicely. Despite the craven complicity of the establishment press (mainstream media)
column2: there is ample evidence for even the most indolent news consumer to reach the conclusion that she and the Democratic leviathan supporting her
column3: and which facilitated Barack Obama’s rise to power
column4: are fundamentally malignant.

column1: In recent days
column2: we’ve become aware of all manner of unethical conspiracies and outright criminality that’s been brought to bear in getting Clinton elected
column3: from Democratic officials tampering with the outcome of the illegal email server investigation
column4: to the oversampling of key demographics in polling in order to enhance the public perception of Clinton’s popularity
column5: to the recent revelation of criminally prosecutable actions on the part of the Clinton campaign
column6: the Democratic National Committee and the White House.

column1: The bottom line here is that Hillary Clinton represents a class of people who transcend even the loathed archetypal modern politician in their rapaciousness and amorality. What all Americans – not just voters
column2: and not just Republicans – need to realize is that leaders at the highest levels in the Republican Party are every bit as culpable as the gutter operatives of the Democratic Party who pay miscreants to dress up as ducks
column3: instigate fistfights at opposition rallies and
column4: yes
column5: even vote for their candidates.

column1: The burning question is this: In the end
column2: are we to be governed by the will of the people
column3: or are we going to continue pretending that we have a representative government
column4: when we are in effect being ruled by abject thugs operating behind a faux veneer of government?"	FAKE

column1: Gay rights and religious liberty: Can Americans have both?	"From an Indiana pizzeria to a Washington State florist
column2: America is grappling with a clash between gay rights and religious liberty. But there are paths forward.

column1: Why climate scientists are taking fact-checking into their own hands
Arkansas state Rep. Warwick Sabin (D) cheers with others protesting the state's religious freedom law at the state Capitol in Little Rock last month.

The recent backlash against “religious accommodation” laws in Indiana and Arkansas is evidence of an increasingly bitter confrontation that is dividing the country and threatens to diminish the scope of religious liberty in America.

That is the conclusion of a number of scholars and experts who are urging the United States Supreme Court to consider this confrontation when it hears oral argument on April 28 in a potential landmark case involving same-sex marriage.
On one side are gay couples who are seeking the full benefits of equal treatment and dignity in a society that has long forced them into second-class status
column2: or substantially worse.

column1: On the other side are religious conservatives
column2: who say they are being coerced to support and/or participate in activities that offend their religious beliefs.

column1: Gay rights activists
column2: sensing an approaching victory at the Supreme Court
column3: are growing more aggressive in challenging the conservatives. Many argue that any accommodation of religious beliefs in the context of gay rights would amount to a “license to discriminate.”

column1: Conservatives counter that the issue is freedom of conscience. Religious accommodations traditionally have been provided to avoid the prospect of coercion against one’s faith
column2: they say.

column1: Indiana and Arkansas were just the latest flashpoints in what could become a major turning point. For the first time in US history
column2: a sizeable social and political force seems intent on sharply restraining or eliminating religious accommodations
column3: according to scholars who study religious freedom.

column1: Now with the Supreme Court poised to take up same-sex marriage
column2: some advocates are hoping the high court will offer much-needed guidance to a nation torn between conflicting values.

column1: Some states
column2: like Indiana
column3: have tried to address the religious accommodation side of the equation
column4: while others
column5: like Utah
column6: have taken a more comprehensive approach – addressing religion accommodations and antidiscrimination laws together.

column1: The stakes involve more than just whether same-sex couples will be able to obtain a cake
column2: or photographs
column3: or flowers for their wedding. Ultimately at stake is a quintessential requirement of life in America: tolerance – on each side for the other.

column1: Douglas Laycock
column2: a leading scholar of religious liberty
column3: has staked out a middle ground position in the looming confrontation between gay rights and religious rights. He calls his approach “liberty and justice for all.”

column1: “Same-sex civil marriage is a great advance for human liberty. But failure to attend to the religious-liberty implications will create a whole new set of problems for the liberties of those religious organizations and believers who cannot conscientiously recognize or facilitate such marriages
column2: ” writes Mr. Laycock
column3: a professor at the University of Virginia School of Law
column4: in a friend-of-the-court brief.

column1: He is urging the high court to recognize a constitutional right to same-sex marriage. And he believes states should pass laws barring discrimination based on sexual orientation.
But he also favors robust religious freedom restoration laws at the state level
column2: and he is urging the justices to make clear in their opinion that religious conservatives retain broad freedom to live their lives in accord with their highest sense of morality and faith.

column1: “The gain for human liberty will be greatly undermined if same-sex couples now force religious dissenters to violate conscience in the same way that those dissenters
column2: when they had the power to do so
column3: forced same-sex couples to hide in the closet
column4: ” Laycock said.

column1: “That is what will happen
column2: unless this Court clearly directs the lower courts to protect religious liberty as well as same-sex civil marriage
column3: ” he told the justices.

column1: In a speech last fall
column2: Sen. Orrin Hatch (R) of Utah warned that religious liberty was under attack – and losing ground. “What was once a broad consensus here in the United States that religious freedom deserves special protection has recently crumbled
column3: ” he said.

column1: The senator said that gay rights organizations and other advocacy groups were increasingly opposed to religious exemptions that a few years ago would have passed without dissent.
“From my perspective
column2: it appears that now these groups believe they are ‘winning’ the argument and therefore have no need for religious accommodations
column3: ” he said. “Whereas in the past they were willing to respect religious freedom
column4: now that they believe they have the upper hand they are ready to disregard religious liberty altogether.”

column1: Last June
column2: the Supreme Court pushed back against this trend in a 5-to-4 decision upholding a religious accommodation for the owners of Hobby Lobby.

column1: Within weeks of that ruling
column2: 56 senators voted to overturn the decision and eliminate the accommodation. The tally
column3: only four votes short of the 60 needed to advance the bill
column4: included every Senate Democrat and three Republicans.

column1: The uproar sparked by Indiana’s passage of its own Religious Freedom Restoration Act (RFRA) in late March illustrates the potential high stakes for religious conservatives.
Indiana lawmakers and Republican Gov. Mike Pence encountered a swift and unrelenting backlash by a well-organized gay rights campaign supported by major business leaders
column2: Democratic governors
column3: and others threatening to unleash an economic boycott against an entire state.

column1: Those threats prompted Republican leaders in Indiana and Arkansas to quickly retreat and water down their religious freedom laws.
It also directed a national spotlight on the intersection of gay rights and religious rights.
It did so in part by focusing on an eight-table pizza shop in Walkerton
column2: Ind.

column1: Memories Pizza owner Kevin O’Connor and his daughter
column2: Crystal
column3: said they would serve any gay or lesbian customers in the shop. But they added that they would refuse to cater a same-sex wedding because such a ceremony would offend their religious beliefs about marriage.

column1: The store closed for eight days after receiving threats and hate mail. At the same time
column2: supporters on a fundraising website contributed more than $840
column3: 000 to the shop.

column1: The action against Memories Pizza erupted not from an actual request for service from a gay couple. It resulted from a hypothetical question from a local television news reporter.
Other well-known cases involve a Colorado bakery’s refusal to bake a wedding cake for a same-sex marriage ceremony
column2: a New Mexico photographer’s refusal to photograph a same-sex commitment ceremony
column3: and a Washington florist’s decision not to design floral arrangements for a same-sex wedding.

column1: In each case
column2: the Christian business owner said the refusal was based on a sincerely-held religious belief about the sanctity of marriage. And in each case
column3: the courts ruled that the Christian owners violated laws prohibiting discrimination based on sexual orientation.

column1: “In the last year or so
column2: with the rise of the push for gay rights
column3: it is beyond wanting there to be an appreciation and respect for gay rights. Now a segment of our population is seeking to have that right trump religious freedom
column4: ” said Jeffrey Mateer
column5: a lawyer with Liberty Institute in Plano
column6: Texas.

column1: “We are seeing people of faith being attacked
column2: discriminated against
column3: and losing their jobs because they are speaking out on the marriage issue
column4: ” Mr. Mateer said.

column1: Among other cases cited by conservatives:

It isn’t just a matter of filing lawsuits or challenging the award of government benefits to certain businesses. The broader campaign often portrays religious conservatives as bigots. The strategy appears aimed at discrediting any claim to the American tradition of solicitude to religious adherents involving sincere matters of faith.
“That’s one way of looking at it
column2: ” says Yale Law School Professor William Eskridge. “Here’s another way. What counts as a religious reason is highly dynamic.”

column1: In the 1960s
column2: opponents of the Civil Rights Act used the Bible to try to justify continued discrimination against African-Americans
column3: notes Professor Eskridge
column4: a leading scholar of gay rights. It didn’t work. The tactic was swept aside as the tide of public opinion embraced the principle of equality for African-Americans.

column1: Eskridge suggests it is only a matter of time before gay rights become normalized across the country
column2: and religious and moral arguments are swept aside and discarded.

column1: “One of the lessons of history unfortunately is that very often the line between bigotry and religious doctrine or religious faith is not a clear-cut line
column2: particularly when public opinion is swiftly changing
column3: ” Eskridge said.

column1: The professor predicted that as the nation’s rapid embrace of gay rights continues
column2: public norms and the law will also change. So will religious practice and belief
column3: he said.

column1: “We’ve already seen it. And we are going to continue to see it
column2: ” he said. “Some religions are literally changing their doctrine.”

column1: So where does that leave the state of interplay between gay rights activists and religious conservatives?
The legal landscape is a patchwork. Even if the US Supreme Court rules in late June that all 50 states must issue marriage licenses to same-sex couples
column2: only 22 states currently have laws prohibiting discrimination based on sexual orientation.

column1: That means that gay men and lesbians are vulnerable to discrimination in 28 states.
Among those 28 states: Indiana and Arkansas.
Some observers view the recent ugly flare-up in the culture war in both states as a missed opportunity.
Had officials in Indiana and Arkansas sought to pass their new religious freedom restoration laws in concert with new legal protections for the lesbian
column2: gay
column3: bisexual
column4: and transgender (LGBT) community
column5: the energy invested in threatened boycotts and waging heated protests would have been expended instead on celebrations of leadership and progress
column6: these analysts say.

column1: Robin Fretwell Wilson knows how to get this done. She was an adviser to the effort do it in one of the most conservative states in America.
“At a time of great change
column2: people have to know what the rules are
column3: ” says Ms. Fretwell
column4: a professor at the University of Illinois College of Law. The idea is to get the relevant parties around a table and negotiate a set of rules acceptable to all.

column1: It employs a common sense approach: If you are sensitive to our concerns
column2: we’ll be sensitive to yours.

column1: The result was the Utah Compromise. It passed the Republican-controlled state legislature and was signed into law last month with the blessing of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints.
When it takes effect on May 11
column2: it will mark the first time in state history that gay men
column3: lesbians
column4: bisexuals
column5: and transgender people have specific legal protections prohibiting discrimination in housing and employment because of sexual orientation or gender identity.

column1: “Utah gets it right on every single score
column2: ” Wilson says. “They did something good and decent for the LGBT community
column3: but they did not make it come at the expense of religious believers. I think that’s huge.”

column1: The workplace protections apply to all businesses with 15 or more workers
column2: including state agencies
column3: local governments
column4: and school districts. It does not apply to religious organizations
column5: religious schools
column6: and wholly-owned subsidiaries of religious organizations. It also exempts the Boy Scouts.

column1: The compromise has its critics. Some say it does not go far enough.
For example
column2: the Utah Compromise does not address the thorny issue of public accommodations – whether a small business such as a bakery
column3: wedding planner
column4: or florist must participate in same-sex wedding ceremonies if they have religious objections.

column1: But within the compromise are the seeds of a solution to that problem
column2: as well
column3: Wilson says.

column1: The agreement establishes a right for any qualified person in Utah to get married at a county clerk’s office. But under the agreement
column2: no official in any clerk’s office can be fired or otherwise forced to officiate a same-sex wedding if they have a religious objection.

column1: Instead
column2: every clerk’s office in Utah – including in rural counties – must have a process that provides a willing celebrant to any same-sex couple seeking to marry at the clerk’s office.

column1: There is a term for this kind of approach. It is called religious accommodation.

Wilson says she is developing a similar model that may offer a compromise for religious business owners who are worried about getting sued over their religious objections to participating in a same-sex wedding.
In the medical field
column2: there are recognized abortion conscience clauses that exempt certain medical professionals from involvement in that procedure because of their religious beliefs. In effect
column3: someone else takes their place through a prearranged process.

column1: “When that happens
column2: no one says you are being mean to the lady who wants an abortion
column3: ” Wilson said. “We don’t even think about it that way.”

column1: The same prearranged process could be set up at a Christian-owned bakery or flower shop. In essence
column2: those parts of the business serving same-sex marriages would be handled by workers (in-house or by contract) who do not have a religious objection to such ceremonies.

column1: “The idea that you show up in the moment and get refused by a religious person is really
column2: really hard to choke down. I don’t think the gay rights people are going to be able to bargain to that
column3: ” Wilson says. “And the idea that you suddenly let gay rights run roughshod over every religious person in the community is also hard to choke down.”

column1: She adds: “So if we can find a model where everybody gets served and religious people don’t have to leave those jobs
column2: I think we’d do a really good thing.”

column1: Wilson’s approach holds great promise
column2: particularly in conservative red states looking for solutions or to avoid economic boycotts. But not everyone is ready and willing to negotiate a cease-fire in the culture war.

column1: That’s where the concept of a RFRA may become essential as an increasing number of cases move into the courts.
Much of the controversy last month in Indiana and Arkansas was premised on misinformation and misconceptions on both sides of the debate
column2: according to legal experts.

column1: Some conservatives were under the false impression that a RFRA would offer guaranteed protection against lawsuits by same-sex couples. And some gay rights activists argued
column2: incorrectly
column3: that the Indiana RFRA would be a “license to discriminate.”

column1: Uncritical press reports parroted this line
column2: over and over.

column1: The debate kicked up gobs of dust and fury
column2: but shed almost no light on the real purpose of passing a state RFRA
column3: analysts say.

column1: “I don’t think it is right to view RFRAs in light of gay rights specifically
column2: because RFRA has always protected religious minority groups
column3: ” says Eric Rassbach
column4: a lawyer at the Becket Fund for Religious Liberty in Washington.

column1: He says RFRAs have helped protect a Santeria priest seeking an exemption from a local ordinance outlawing goat sacrifices; it is being invoked to help native Americans who need an exemption from federal law to possess eagle feathers. The law has been used to uphold the right of a Sikh accountant to pass through security at a federal building in possession of her religious “kirpan
column2: ” a small dull dagger that is as symbolic to Sikhs as the cross is to Christians.

column1: In January
column2: the US Supreme Court applied a RFRA-like statute and ruled that the Arkansas prison system must allow a Muslim inmate to grow a short beard in compliance with his religious faith. That ruling was 9 to 0.

column1: “If people want to go around stopping RFRAs or neutering RFRAs
column2: the people who are going to be hurt will be the religious minorities – the Sikhs
column3: the native Americans
column4: the Muslims
column5: the Orthodox Jews
column6: ” Mr. Rassbach said.

column1: “I think that is a real problem for our society because we are not getting less religiously diverse
column2: we are becoming more heterogeneous
column3: ” he said.

column1: The purpose of passing a religious freedom restoration law is not to grant a right to engage in anti-gay discrimination
column2: Rassbach and other analysts say. The law isn’t designed to work that way
column3: and it hasn’t worked that way in practice.

column1: No religious exemption sought under RFRA has ever been granted in any case involving alleged sexual orientation discrimination.
That doesn’t mean there won’t be an accommodation granted in the future. But these results suggest RFRA is no “license to discriminate.”
The real license to discriminate in Indiana was the state’s lack of a statute prohibiting discrimination because of sexual orientation. That is a license to discriminate
column2: legal experts say.

column1: In contrast
column2: the purpose of a RFRA is different. The law is designed to allow a neutral judge to weigh the competing interests when a law that is applied broadly imposes a significant burden on sincerely-held religious beliefs.

column1: When that happens
column2: there must be proof that the provision advances a compelling government interest and that it is tailored to do that in a way least restrictive of religious faith.

column1: This approach was not dreamed up in some backroom legislative chamber in Indiana. It is a legal standard that was recognized as a constitutional guarantee for the entire country and was enforced by the US Supreme Court from 1963 to 1990.
Despite this broad
column2: constitutional protection of religious conscience
column3: religious adherents didn’t always prevail. In 1983
column4: Bob Jones University argued for a religious exemption from a federal regulation prohibiting tax-exempt organizations from discriminating on the basis of race. The university had a rule barring interracial dating.

column1: The high court held that the government had a fundamental – and overriding – interest in ending any vestige of racial discrimination in education.
Though the decision did not diminish the importance of religious accommodations in general
column2: it put religious adherents on notice: fighting discrimination is a compelling government interest that can outweigh a claim for religious accommodation.

column1: Then
column3: the high court abruptly changed course. The justices were presented with a case involving two drug counselors who were fired for their sacramental use of peyote as members of the Native American Church. They were also denied unemployment benefits. The two sued the state of Oregon
column4: seeking a religious accommodation that would allow them to collect the benefits.

column1: A divided Supreme Court ruled that the free exercise clause of the Constitution did not authorize a religious exemption from laws of general applicability.

This was a major constitutional shift that made it more difficult for religious adherents – particularly those in minority religions – to seek accommodations from general laws that imposed significant burdens on their faith.
Congress responded in 1993 by passing the Religious Freedom Restoration Act. (It passed the House by voice vote
column2: and the Senate 97 to 3.) The statute reestablished the same national legal standard of religious accommodation that had been enforced by the high court from 1963 to 1990.

column1: Then in 1997
column2: the Supreme Court ruled that the federal RFRA only applied to federal law
column3: not at the state or local level.

column1: In response to that decision
column2: states began enacting their own religious freedom restoration acts. Currently
column3: 22 states – including Indiana and Arkansas – have enacted RFRAs.

column1: In addition
column2: 11 other states have interpreted their state constitutions as providing guarantees of religious liberty consistent with the standard enforced by the US Supreme Court from 1963 to 1990.

column1: Thus
column2: 33 of the 50 states have in some fashion embraced the broad concept of offering religious accommodations.

column1: How the approaching legal battles will play out is uncertain.
Some cases will be preempted by automatic exemptions from discrimination laws that have long been granted to religious organizations and affiliated groups.
But the stage is now set for litigation over public accommodations related to same-sex marriages. Ironically
column2: most of those cases will be litigated not in conservative “red” states
column3: but in liberal “blue” states that have already accepted gay marriage. That’s because there are no antidiscrimination statutes in most red states that would allow a same-sex couple to file a lawsuit.

column1: “It is that middle area of the small business
column2: individual proprietorship
column3: the mom and pop enterprise; that’s the area where this is going to bite
column4: ” Eskridge says. “That is in play and it is highly dynamic.”

column1: The professor sees the legal landscape shifting against accommodation claims.  “Accommodations that would have been given in courts 10 years ago are not going to be given in courts 10 years from now
column2: or even today in some cases.”

column1: In courts across the country the critical question is going to be whether it is possible to strike a balance between discrimination and religious accommodation.
What is at stake is more fundamental than cakes
column2: and photographs
column3: and flowers. It is whether at some point politicians and judges begin to look for ways to defuse disputes so that both sides can start moving forward together toward tolerance and acceptance.

column1: The alternative is more Indiana-style protests and boycotts.

“What was so devastating for the religious community was to be seen as saying we have to have our religious freedom so that we can knock down your gay rights. When they say stuff like that – which is just ugly – they lose
column2: ” Wilson says.

column1: “But on the other side
column2: if the gay rights guys say I have to run you out of business in order for me to win
column3: that is just as ugly
column4: and they will lose
column5: ” she says."	REAL

column1: As Rand Paul stalls, Ted Cruz seeks to pick up support among libertarians	"Sen. Ted Cruz (R-Tex.) came to a convention of libertarian-leaning Republicans and talked about shrinking government
column2: slashing regulations
column3: fighting against the bulk collection of phone data and his great affinity for a rival in the presidential race.

column1: Paul
column2: Kentucky’s junior U.S. senator and scion of one of the country’s most famous libertarian families
column3: was expected to lock down the support of libertarian voters in the presidential campaign. But as Paul’s poll numbers have sagged nationally — and in such libertarian-minded places as New Hampshire — Cruz is trying to pick off what is sometimes called the liberty vote.

column1: Cruz essentially crashed what was supposed to be Paul’s big libertarian party here
column2: the biennial meeting of the Republican Liberty Caucus. Cruz stood in a hotel here on a dreary Friday morning
column3: surrounded by supporters and curious attendees who held signs and jostled for photos.

column1: “I was elected with tremendous support from the liberty movement
column2: ” Cruz said of his 2012 Senate campaign
column3: noting that Rand Paul and his father
column4: former representative Ron Paul (R-Tex.)
column5: both endorsed him in that race.

column1: The Texas Republican’s presidential campaign has been making the case that as Paul’s campaign has floundered
column2: Cruz is viable — flush with cash and able to go the distance.

column1: On the trail
column2: Cruz has invoked the Fourth Amendment’s privacy protections and railed against the Federal Reserve. Last month
column3: the campaign rolled out a video showing eight supporters of Ron Paul’s 2012 presidential campaign who are backing Cruz for 2016.

column1: “The liberty movement has been integral to our campaign since Day One
column2: ” Cruz said.

column1: Cruz breaks down the Republican electorate into four brackets of support: tea party conservatives; evangelical Christians; establishment Republicans; and libertarians. He sees his base in the tea party and evangelical wings
column2: but he also is trying to siphon off libertarian voters with a message of limited government.

column1: Cruz tailored his speech here in New Hampshire to those voters. He took a less hawkish tone when discussing foreign policy
column2: saying that the United States “shouldn’t engage in nation-building” and calling for armed Kurdish ground troops to fight the Islamic State.

column1: “There’s no reason for us to get in the middle of the Syrian civil war
column2: ” he said.

column1: Cruz praised the liberty movement as an “amazing thing” and vowed that the size of government will be “materially smaller” if he is elected president. He promoted a bill he co-sponsored to end the bulk collection of phone metadata — an issue that Rand Paul championed this year with a nearly 11-hour Senate floor speech.
“This is the battleground between Cruz and Paul
column2: ” said Dave Nalle
column3: a former chairman of the Liberty Caucus. He said Paul appeals to privacy-minded libertarians while Cruz appeals to those who want a strict adherence to the Constitution.

column1: “I was impressed” with Cruz
column2: said Louis Colavecchio Sr. of Wakefield
column3: R.I.
column4: who also said he has not decided whom he will support in the primary.

column1: The scramble for supporters seems to have somewhat strained the cordial relationship between the onetime Senate allies. Last month
column2: Paul said Cruz was “pretty much done for” in the Senate after Cruz tried to disrupt the passage of a government funding bill because it would give money to Planned Parenthood.

column1: “Ted has chosen to make this really personal and chosen to call people dishonest in leadership . . . which really goes against the decorum and also against the rules of the Senate
column2: and as a consequence he can’t get anything done legislatively
column3: ” Paul said on Fox News Radio. On Friday
column4: Cruz called Paul “a friend” and “good man.”

column1: Paul gave an animated speech here and appeared to be in his comfort zone
column2: saying he wants a government that leaves him alone. He reminded his audience of his marathon Senate speech to defend that principle. He called for reform of the criminal-justice system
column3: and he knocked other candidates for saying they would not hold talks with rival nations. Paul also rapped Congress
column4: labeling a just-passed bill that temporarily funds the government “a bunch of crap” and the body itself “impotent and inconsequential.”

column1: “I’m embarrassed that I’m even a part of it
column2: ” said Paul
column3: sporting a bright-blue belt with the University of Kentucky’s logo on it.

column1: Paul played down the threat from Cruz.
“Both here and Iowa
column2: we know where our support is and where my dad’s support was
column3: and we feel comfortable that the overwhelming majority of it is with us
column4: ” Paul said.

column1: Some libertarians here were uncomfortable with Cruz making religion such a large part of his campaign.
“I don’t think he’s going to have as much sway on Rand Paul’s electability as people think he will
column2: because he’s a religious zealot. It’s too much
column3: ” said Austin Sekel
column5: who is supporting Paul. Cruz “needs to stop grandstanding on the Senate floor
column6: ” he said.

column1: Sekel and others said they do not think Paul’s sagging poll numbers will change anything. Sekel thinks Paul has a base of support that has not yet become engaged in the campaign.
Bob Pyle
column2: a pastor from Harrisburg
column3: Pa.
column4: said Paul has a “solid

column1: “A dream come true for Hillary Clinton”: Wall Street Journal editorial board rips Ted Cruz	"In a Tuesday editorial
column2: the paper’s opinion editors cast significant doubt on the Texas Republican’s ability to assemble a winning coalition
column3: arguing that Cruz’s assumption that he can win by turning out more white conservative voters is fundamentally flawed and warning that the Tea Party firebrand’s hardline stance on immigration makes him “a dream come true for Hillary Clinton
column4: ” the likely Democratic nominee in 2016.

column1: Blaming Cruz for “plunging” the GOP’s favorability by leading the 2013 government shutdown — part of a botched attempt to derail health care reform — the Journal depicts Cruz as a polarizing figure all too willing to reflexively oppose anything the Obama administration proposes. The editors castigate Cruz as an “opportunist” for seeking to pare back government surveillance and for opposing the administration’s abortive effort to authorize air strikes in Syria in 2013 — stances that Cruz took despite a generally hawkish worldview.
As for Cruz’s claim that Republicans like 2012 nominee Mitt Romney have lost because they failed to galvanize the right-wing base
column2: the Journal allows that “Romney in particular failed to motivate enough conservatives.” However
column3: the editors posit
column4: Cruz “is probably wrong to think that conservatives alone
column5: especially white conservatives
column6: can elect the next President
column7: ” adding that the party’s 2016 nominee “must broaden the GOP’s electoral appeal.” Part of that
column8: the editorial suggests
column9: entails a softer line on immigration; continued opposition to reform will only prove a boon to Democratic efforts to keep Latino voters solidly in the blue column.

column1: This being the Wall Street Journal editorial board
column2: the piece is not without pot-shots at Democrats. Indeed
column3: the editorial is framed around the notion that Cruz is the Republican version of Barack Obama. There are areas of overlap: Both began their presidential bids as 40-something first-term senators
column4: both graduated from Harvard Law School
column5: both are perceived as dynamic speakers
column6: and both boast appeal among key segments of their parties’ respective constituencies. Although the similarities largely end there

column8: the Journal would have us believe that Obama harbors “contempt” for Republicans and for the very idea of “work[ing] across the aisle.”

column1: In the latter half of his second term

column3: but the president reached this conclusion only after the failure of his assiduous efforts to woo GOP support. His 2008 campaign rested on the notion that he
column4: not Hillary Clinton
column5: would bridge Washington’s partisan divide
column6: and he spent much of his first term negotiating against himself in the vain hope that his proposals would garner Republican backing. There was the largely fruitless effort to secure GOP support for the 2009 stimulus package
column7: for instance
column8: and the months-long
column9: ill-fated bid to get then-Sen. Olympia Snowe (R-ME) to vote for health care reform. Obama’s Kumbayaism was doomed literally from the start; just as Obama took office
column10: top congressional Republicans decided in a closed-door meeting that the next four years would be ones of knee-jerk opposition to the president’s policies. Six years later
column11: Cruz is telling Republicans that the obstructionists who run his party aren’t intransigent enough. That view may be held by a large segment of the Tea Party
column12: but even some of the nation’s most conservative voices find it laughable — and politically perilous."	REAL

column1: Trumka: Disappointment with Obama, a warning for Hillary	"WASHINGTON — The nation's most powerful labor leader
column2: vowing to defeat President Obama's key trade legislation in the House next month

column1: Richard Trumka
column2: president of the AFL-CIO
column3: predicted that no more than 20 House Democrats would vote for Trade Promotion Authority
column4: the ""fast-track"" bill that on Friday passed the Senate.

column1: Thirteen Democrats left their base
column2: he said of the Senate vote in an interview with Capital Download. ""They decided to pass something that was going to cost jobs and lower wages
column3: and they're going to have to answer to their constituencies for that."" He added: ""They'll be held accountable; there's no question about that.""

column1: Organized labor has been waging a fierce battle against the legislation
column2: which would require Congress to approve or reject without amendments the Trans-Pacific Partnership
column3: a trade deal among the United States and 12 other Pacific Rim nations. Many labor unions have frozen campaign donations as they lobby against it.

column1: The battle between two customary allies — a Democratic president and the country's biggest labor federation — underscores the complicated politics of Obama's attempts to pass legislation through a Republican-controlled Congress during the final two years of his tenure. It also exposes challenges ahead for Clinton
column2: who praised the emerging Pacific pact as ""the gold standard"" in her memoirs as secretary of State but has avoided declaring her view of it since becoming a presidential candidate.

column1: Unfortunately
column2: it falls far short of being the gold standard
column3: Trumka told USA TODAY's video newsmaker series in an interview at AFL-CIO headquarters
column4: just across Lafayette Square from the White House. ""It's not silver. I'm not sure it's copper or some other form of metal
column5: but it's not gold
column6: because it's going to cost us jobs and it's going to lower wages in this country.""

column1: Trumka said he didn't know where Clinton now stood on the issue.
She's going to have to answer that
column2: he said. ""I think she won't be able to go through a campaign without answering that and people will take it seriously and it will affect whether they vote for her or don't vote for her.""

column1: If Clinton backs the trade pact and the fast-track authority
column2: there will be costs
column3: he cautioned. ""It will be tougher to mobilize working people. It'll be tougher to get them to come out excited and work to do door-knocking and leafleting and phone-banking and all the things that are going to be necessary if she is the candidate and we endorse her to get elected. It will make it far more difficult.""

column1: It even is ""conceivable"" that the AFL-CIO wouldn't endorse a presidential candidate
column2: he said
column3: ""if both candidates weren't interested in raising wages and creating jobs.""

column1: Asked whether Obama's presidency had been good for working Americans
column2: Trumka paused.

column1: The president's been seriously handicapped in his ability to deliver things for the American public
column2: because you've got a determined opposition in the Republican Party that will actually hurt the country to deny him a victory
column3: he began. But he added
column4: ""I wish he would have fought for some of the things that are needed as hard as he's fighting for fast track and TPP.""

column3: Chris Coons of Delaware and Patty Murray of Washington state. When the interviewer commented that it's hard to defeat a president

column1: Lifting weights could ward off dementia and make you smarter	"Lifting weights could ward off dementia and make you smarter
by: Vicki Batts Tags: weight lifting
column2: dementia
column3: brain health (NaturalNews) There are many reasons to partake in strength training; weight-baring exercises are known for their health benefits. But
column4: could lifting weights also boost your brain? Recent research indicates that may just be the case.To begin the study
column5: researchers asked a group of people aged 55 to 86 to engage in a mix of weight lifting and brain training exercises. All of the people who partook in the study had been diagnosed with mild cognitive impairment
column6: which is a precursor to Alzheimer's disease
column7: and is an early sign of dementia.While this particular study did not examine whether the benefits of exercise could be extended to the general population
column8: the results were quite impressive. Published in the Journal of the American Geriatrics Society
column9: the study found that weight-baring exercises could indeed provide some brain benefits. The researchers found a casual relationship between an increase in muscle strength and an increase in brain function. On that basis
column10: the team recommended that more people begin a strength training regime so that the world's aging population can hopefully be a little healthier. It is currently projected that about 135 million people will have dementia by the year 2050.The same team behind this most recent research also published a paper in 2014 that revealed that weight training provided cognitive benefits to just about every area of the brain – something cognitive training failed to do.While discussing their most recent data
column11: one of the study's researchers
column12: Dr. Yorgi Mavros of Sydney University
column13: commented
column14: ""What we found in this follow-up study is that the improvement in cognition function was related to their muscle strength gains. The stronger people became
column15: the greater the benefit for their brain.""For the strength training
column16: study participants were asked to lift weights that were equivalent to about 80 percent of their maximum capacity
column17: twice a week for six months – similar to the way in which many athletes train. And
column18: as the participants got stronger
column19: the amount of weight they lifted went up as well
column20: in order to maintain the desired 80 percent of their maximum effort.Brain scans revealed that certain regions of the brain actually increased in size for those who took part in the exercise regime. Dr. Mavros says that the benefits were profound enough to warrant recommending weight training for everyone.""The more we can get people doing resistance training like weight lifting
column21: the more likely we are to have a healthier ageing population
column22: he told the Independent . Dr. Mavros also added that the best way to ensure that you get the most benefit from exercise is by maintaining a regular routine. Exercising frequently
column23: and with some intensity
column24: is key to getting the most out of what you're doing.This new research is not the first to suggest that exercise can provide benefits to brain health . The body of research linking physical exercise to better cognitive function has only continued to grow over the last several years. Science has indicated that in addition to better mental health
column25: exercise can also promote both better memory and concentration.Dr. James Pickett
column26: head of research at the Alzheimer's Society
column27: also had a few things to say about this new study. He noted
column28: ""New research is beginning to unravel how physical exercise may have benefits for the brain as people get older. This study suggests that people with minor memory and thinking problems
column29: known as mild cognitive impairment
column30: may benefit from weight training to improve their brain health.""Pickett also noted that while it is not yet clear if exercise can reverse dementia
column31: they do know that it is one of the most important factors in its prevention. Along with being active
column32: he says that not smoking and eating a healthy
column33: balanced diet are all essential to reducing the risk. Sources:"	FAKE
