column1: Who Lost Iraq?	"For a brief
column2: happy—and misguided—moment
column3: most Americans stopped thinking about Iraq. After withdrawing the last U.S. troops in 2011
column4: President Barack Obama declared the country “sovereign
column5: stable and self-reliant.” No such luck. Iraq plunged back into chaos as the Islamic State stormed the region last year
column6: and the fall of Ramadi in May revived questions about how
column7: and whether
column8: the country can be salvaged.

column1: As Americans try to understand what $2 trillion and nearly 4
column2: 500 American lives really accomplished
column3: partisans are battling over how much blame falls on Obama
column4: who left Iraq
column5: and on President George W. Bush
column6: who took us there. “If you fought in Iraq
column7: it worked
column8: ” 2016 presidential candidate Lindsey Graham recently said. “It’s not your fault it’s going to hell. It’s Obama’s fault.” Naturally
column9: Democrats see it differently: “This represents the failed policies that took us down this path 10 years ago
column10: ” House Minority Leader Nancy Pelosi has said.

column1: Who’s right? Could Iraq have remained stable if Obama had left behind a small troop contingent? Did Bush’s “surge” really stabilize the country? In June
column2: Politico Magazine assembled a dozen experts—including veterans of both administrations from the State Department
column3: White House
column4: Pentagon and the CIA—and asked a simple question: Who lost Iraq? —Michael Crowley

column1: Michael Crowley: Ambassador Khalilzad
column2: you were in Iraq from 2005 to 2007. Describe the trajectory Iraq was on when you left
column3: and the Iraq that Obama inherited when he was inaugurated in January 2009.

column1: Zalmay Khalilzad: It was a very difficult period. Especially in the aftermath of the al-Askari Mosque bombing in 2006
column2: the sectarian violence became front and center—a very large number of fatalities and causalities
column3: both Shia and Sunni—and the rise of Al Qaeda in Iraq. We began a more concerted effort training Iraqi troops
column4: which resulted in significant growth in their size and capabilities. The new Iraqi government led by Prime Minister Nouri al-Maliki showed more willingness to use force against the Shia militias in Basra and Baghdad’s Sadr City. Additionally
column5: the excesses committed by Al Qaeda in Iraq against the Sunni community was beginning to turn some Sunnis against them. With increased outreach to the Sunnis
column6: we began to have significant numbers of them work with us.

column1: There were still some issues unresolved—there was no oil law for the distribution of resources
column2: there still was no reform of de-Baathification. These were self-inflicted wounds
column3: if you like—mistakes we made
column4: in my judgment
column5: at the very beginning. But I think the Iraqis were heading in the right direction. You had a government that acquired greater national legitimacy. There was a greater Sunni participation in government compared to an earlier period. The level of violence
column6: by the end of the Bush administration
column7: was significantly down compared to 2006
column8: early 2007.

column1: We’re still talking about Iraq
column2: but relatively speaking
column3: I would say it was on a positive trajectory with some big issues still unresolved.

column1: MC: Kim
column2: tell us more about the security situation when President Obama arrived.

column1: Kim Kagan: The security situation in Iraq was dramatically improved by operations conducted by surge troops—violence in Baghdad and in Iraq fell dramatically over the course of 2007. And in 2008
column2: U.S. forces partnered with the Iraqi security forces
column3: pushed AQI out of Baghdad
column4: out of Diyala and all the way to Mosul
column5: where the Al Qaeda elements were greatly reduced over time by follow-on operations and special forces operations. The Shia militias
column6: which posed a threat to the sovereignty of the Iraqi government
column7: had been greatly diminished by the operations that Prime Minister Maliki and U.S. forces undertook in 2008 and were no longer militarily viable within Iraq.

column1: The two main threats to Iraqi state security had been significantly diminished by 2008 and over the course of 2009. Our U.S. forces were handing over security to Iraqi security forces
column2: such that U.S. forces came out of the major cities of Iraq
column3: and handed responsibility for those cities back to the Iraqi security forces. One of the principles behind the way that the U.S. had constructed its surge operations was that the U.S. had special tie-in capabilities that the Iraqi security forces did not have
column4: because they were still growing
column5: still developing skills. So clearing cities was something the U.S. did with Iraqi security forces’ support.

column1: As those cities became more peaceful
column2: as the population returned
column3: as AQI left
column4: the Iraqi security forces could handle the security environment in the urban centers. But AQI was not destroyed. It had not lost the will to fight. It was potentially reduced from an organization that had high-end terrorist capabilities that could threaten the state
column5: to an insurgency
column6: a group that had very limited capacity to act as a terrorist organization
column7: but still had some will to fight
column8: and still had some organization
column9: some command and control left over
column10: primarily in the Mosul area.

column1: MC: John
column2: what did the threat to the U.S. or western interests in the region emanating from Iraq look like at the time Obama took office?

column1: John McLaughlin: If you go all the way back to 2008
column2: the Arab Spring or Awakening was still years away. In 2008
column3: Al Qaeda central was on the run but not defeated. We were still very much on guard against attacks on the United States; we were just two years after detecting the attempt by Al Qaeda-related people to put together an operation over the Atlantic out of London—the planes plot. So Al Qaeda in that period is still very dangerous but not particularly noteworthy insofar as its capability in Iraq was seen.

column1: MC:  Ambassador Hill
column2: you get to Iraq at the start of Obama’s first term. What does that Iraq look like—is it on a trajectory to a place where it can stand on its own?

column1: Chris Hill: There was perhaps more optimism than the facts might have justified. For example
column2: there was a view that somehow Maliki had gotten in the saddle
column3: that he understood the need for outreach to the various groups and was prepared to continue the payments to the so-called Sons of Iraq. There was an overall kind of optimistic mood
column4: but I must say
column5: in talking to the Sunni leaders who were part of his cabinet
column6: you certainly didn’t get the sense there was any reason to be optimistic. You certainly got the impression when you talked to people that it wasn’t going well. Going out to Anbar
column7: for example
column8: and talking to Sunni sheiks out there
column9: they were all prepared to work together in a kind of all-in Sunni party
column10: but you certainly didn’t get the impression they were cutting Baghdad any slack or cutting Maliki any slack."	REAL

column1: Pope Francis implores Congress to accept immigrants as their own	"Pope Francis
column2: making history’s first papal address to the U.S. Congress
column3: on Thursday implored America’s leaders to accept those born in other countries as their own children
column4: urging lawmakers to set aside political differences and embrace people who “travel north in search of a better life.”

column1: The pope wrapped traditional Catholic teachings into a celebration of American icons including Abraham Lincoln and Martin Luther King Jr.
column2: drawing lessons from their work to gently but firmly push Congress to move beyond the partisan paralysis that has blocked progress on immigration reform
column3: climate change and other issues.

column1: “Each son or daughter of a given country has a mission
column2: a personal and social responsibility
column3: ” the 78-year-old pontiff said in heavily accented English. “Your own responsibility as members of Congress is to enable this country
column4: by your legislative activity
column5: to grow as a nation.”

column1: President Obama watched the speech on television
column2: according to White House press secretary Josh Earnest. “Pope Francis made the appropriate observation for the United States to live up to the high standards that we set for ourselves
column3: ” Earnest said.

column1: [LIVE UPDATES: The latest on Pope Francis in America]
The Capitol Hill call to action kicked off a second full day of gleeful crowds and emotional visits to Catholic institutions. The faithful gathered at the Apostolic Nunciature
column2: or Vatican embassy
column3: to greet the pope when he emerged. More lined the streets as his motorcade traveled to the Capitol
column4: where thousands waited on the Mall to watch his speech on giant screens.

column1: After his address to Congress
column2: the pope went directly from the grandeur of Capitol Hill to the spare St. Patrick’s Catholic Church in a neighborhood that has flipped over the past decade from marginalized to magnet. He prayed with people who variously wore suits and torn T-shirts
column3: and he blessed the meals of more than 300 homeless people.

column1: Upon arrival at John F. Kennedy International Airport in New York
column2: the pope traveled by helicopter and motorcade to a very different St. Patrick’s
column3: the soaring cathedral on Manhattan’s Fifth Avenue
column4: for an evening service.

column1: There
column2: the pontiff began his homily by expressing “my sentiments of closeness” with Muslims after the tragic stampede that killed more than 700 pilgrims near Mecca on Thursday
column3: the first day of Eid al-Adha
column4: one of the holiest Muslim holidays. “I unite myself with all prayers to Almighty God
column5: the merciful
column6: ” he said.

column1: He spoke directly to nuns and women in the church
column2: saying
column3: “What would the church be without you?” He also referenced the clergy sex scandal for the second time on this visit
column4: lamenting “the shame” caused by “brothers who harmed and scandalized the church in the most vulnerable of her members.”

column1: The pontiff will carry his message to world leaders Friday when he speaks at a meeting of the United Nations General Assembly.
In his speech to Congress
column2: Francis crafted an address saturated in American references
column3: with special praise for the nation’s role as “a land which has inspired so many people to dream.”

column1: He was pointed at times
column2: urging the abolition of the death penalty and the end of arms trading
column3: and warning of the dangers of religious extremism worldwide. And he was oblique at points
column4: never directly mentioning abortion or the United States’ rapid embrace of same-sex marriage
column5: saying only that the family is being threatened and that “fundamental relationships are being called into question
column6: as is the very basis of marriage and the family.”

column1: He saved his most specific prescription for combating climate change
column2: a cause on which he said the United States has a special obligation to lead.

column1: “I call for a courageous and responsible effort to redirect our steps
column2: and to avert the most serious effects of the environmental deterioration caused by human activity
column3: ” the pope said. “I am convinced that we can make a difference — I’m sure. And I have no doubt that the United States — and this Congress — have an important role to play. Now is the time for courageous actions and strategies.”

column1: The pope
column2: who helped broker a diplomatic opening with Cuba
column3: offered himself and his example as a pastoral link between opposing points of view. “It is my duty to build bridges and to help all men and women
column4: in any way possible
column5: to do the same
column6: ” he said. “A good political leader is one who
column7: with the interests of all in mind
column8: seizes the moment in a spirit of openness and pragmatism.”

column1: Although members of Congress largely avoided the ostentatious displays of partisan cheering that have come to characterize the president’s annual State of the Union addresses
column2: an ideological divide was apparent at times. In response to Francis’s passage about climate change
column3: Democrats mostly stood and cheered
column4: while some Republicans stayed seated and applauded mildly
column5: if at all.

column1: But the response to the pope’s passionate words about embracing immigrants seemed to strike a bipartisan chord. Sen. Marco Rubio (R-Fla.)
column2: a presidential candidate and son of Cuban immigrants
column3: wiped away tears as the pope called himself “the son of immigrants.”

column1: [Pope Francis: ‘I always was interested in politics’]
Pope Francis tempered his call for action with a statement of support for the role that business plays in society
column2: calling it “a noble vocation
column3: directed to producing wealth and improving the world.”

column1: “The creation and distribution of wealth
column2: ” he said
column3: is a vital element in the fight against poverty and climate change.

column1: Those looking for signs of this pope’s political direction could find evidence in the speech’s repeated references to a pantheon of liberal heroes
column2: from Dorothy Day
column3: who dedicated her life to a battle against poverty and war
column4: to Thomas Merton
column5: whose “Letters to a White Liberal
column6: ” written in 1963
column7: urged Christians to follow their faith and join the fight for civil rights for black Americans.

column1: The pope praised King for his focus on “liberty in plurality and non-exclusion
column2: ” Day for “social justice
column3: ” and Merton for “dialogue and openness to God.”

column1: [6 reasons the pope’s speech could be awkward for some lawmakers]
Francis implored Congress to “reject a mind-set of hostility” and embrace the immigrants who come “to this land to pursue their dream of building a future in freedom.”
The pope
column2: noting that many in Congress are also children of people who made the risky journey to America
column3: said the nation must follow the golden rule and “treat others with the same passion and compassion with which we want to be treated.”

column1: “We must not be taken aback by their numbers
column2: ” he said
column3: “but rather view them as persons
column4: seeing their faces and listening to their stories
column5: trying to respond as best we can to their situation.”

column1: Francis’s emphasis on immigrants is a matter of self-interest for a U.S. church that is rapidly becoming majority Latino. Parishes across the white Northeast are shuttered while many in the West and South are bursting with ­Spanish-language Masses.
That focus also dovetails with the major theme of his American trip so far
column2: a series of reminders that his papacy is very much about renewing the church’s focus on the poor and the powerless. The pope this year opened a 30-­bedroom homeless shelter just steps from the Vatican. He had showers set up for homeless people in St. Peter’s Square
column3: and he invited about 150 homeless people to a private viewing of the Sistine Chapel.

column1: In New York
column2: he will get a direct look at inner-city Catholic education when he visits a school in East Harlem and meets with immigrants and refugees. In Philadelphia
column3: where he will end his U.S. visit
column4: the pope will visit a prison to meet with inmates. In Washington
column5: his visit at St. Patrick’s immediately — and pointedly — followed his hour in the majestic House chamber. The plain sanctuary of the 220-year-old downtown church was filled with people who need basic life services. But as Francis noted
column6: “In prayer
column7: there is no first or second class.”

column1: “I need your prayers
column2: your support
column3: ” the pontiff said
column4: standing at a simple wooden podium before a reverentially silent flock. “Would you like to pray together?”

column1: The hush broke like the uncorking of a bottle: “Yes!”
Americans are largely supportive of the pope’s engagement on economic
column2: social and environmental issues. But American Catholics
column3: who make up about one-fifth of the U.S. electorate
column4: remain deeply divided over their church’s directives.

column1: [Poll: Americans love this pope. His church? Not as much]
One Catholic congressman
column2: Rep. Paul A. Gosar (R-Ariz.)
column3: skipped the pope’s appearance to protest Francis’s advocacy for strong action against global climate change and what Gosar sees as the pope’s failure to speak out “with moral authority against violent Islam.”

column1: The many lawmakers who were inside the chamber on Thursday emerged with bipartisan agreement that the pope’s central message was simple: Just get along.
On the Capitol lawn
column2: many of those who watched the pope’s congressional address on giant video screens came away convinced that Congress should — but probably won’t — take his message to heart.

column1: “I was not expecting him to address the bipartisan divide
column2: ” said Emily Warn
column4: a writer from Seattle. “It’s as if he was trying to heal Congress.”

column1: In a country where the old-line Catholic population is diminishing because many families are having fewer children — though a wave of Hispanic immigrants is partly making up for that decline in numbers — the pope spoke to young Catholics
column2: especially those who are “disoriented and aimless
column3: trapped in a hopeless maze of violence
column4: abuse and despair.”

column1: They will have children
column2: he said
column3: only if the nation provides them with a greater sense of “possibilities for the future.”

column1: After the address
column2: Francis walked through the Capitol’s second floor to Statuary Hall and paused at the statue of Junípero Serra
column3: the California missionary whom he had canonized on Wednesday.

column1: The pontiff then joined Vice President Biden
column2: House Speaker John A. Boehner (R-Ohio) and other congressional leaders on the speaker’s balcony overlooking the West Front of the Capitol
column3: greeting an enthusiastic crowd that numbered in the thousands. He said a few words of thanks in Spanish and then
column4: to great cheers
column5: switched to English: “Thank you very much
column6: and God bless America!”

column1: Sarah Pulliam Bailey
column2: DeNeen L. Brown
column3: Pamela Constable
column4: Jessica Contrera
column5: Ed O’Keefe
column6: Michael E. Ruane and Kelsey Snell contributed to this report."	REAL

column1: Poll: Trump gains in Iowa, still dominates in New Hampshire	"With just over a week until the first 2016 election contest
column2: Donald Trump takes the lead in Iowa -- and maintains his big advantage in New Hampshire.

column1: That’s according to the latest round of Fox News state polls on the Republican presidential nomination contest.
CLICK HERE TO READ THE IOWA POLL RESULTS
CLICK HERE TO READ THE NEW HAMPSHIRE POLL RESULTS
Trump bests Ted Cruz in Iowa and now receives 34 percent support among Republican caucus-goers.  Trump was at 23 percent in the Fox News Poll two weeks ago (January 4-7).
Cruz is second with 23 percent -- down a touch from 27 percent.  Marco Rubio comes in third with 12 percent
column2: down from 15 percent.  No others garner double-digit support.

column1: Among caucus-goers who identify as “very” conservative
column2: Cruz was up by 18 points over Trump earlier this month.  Now they each receive about a third among this group (Cruz 34 percent vs. Trump 33 percent).

column1: There’s been a similar shift among white evangelical Christians.  Cruz’s 14-point advantage is now down to a 2-point edge.
A lot has happened in the intervening two weeks.  Fox Business Network hosted a Republican debate where Trump questioned Cruz’s eligibility to be president
column2: and Cruz attacked Trump’s liberal “New York values.”  On Tuesday
column3: Gov. Terry Branstad urged his fellow Iowans to vote against Cruz because of his opposition to ethanol -- and former Vice-Presidential candidate Sarah Palin endorsed Trump.

column1: Republican pollster Daron Shaw says
column2: “We tend to over-interpret every little thing in a presidential race
column3: but here we actually have solid evidence Trump didn't just win last week in Iowa -- he won it by enough to put some distance between himself and Cruz.”  Shaw conducts the Fox News Poll with Democratic pollster Chris Anderson.

column1: But a lot can change before Iowans caucus February 1.
A third of Republican caucus-goers say they may change their mind (33 percent).  Even one in four Trump supporters says they may ultimately go with another candidate (25 percent).
Cruz tops the list when GOP caucus-goers are asked their second-choice candidate.  When first and second-choice preferences are combined
column2: it’s extremely tight between Trump (48 percent) and Cruz (45 percent).

column1: That’s because 20 percent of Iowa Republican caucus-goers are so negative on Trump they say they would “refuse” to vote for him over the Democrat in November
column2: while fewer say the same of Cruz (11 percent).  Another 14 percent say they would stay home if the nominee is Jeb Bush.

column1: Here’s how the rest of the field stands:  Ben Carson is at 7 percent
column2: Rand Paul is at 6 percent
column3: Bush and Chris Christie each get 4 percent
column4: Mike Huckabee
column5: John Kasich and Rick Santorum tie at 2 percent
column6: and Carly Fiorina gets 1 percent.

column1: More than a third who say they will attend a Republican caucus this year have never gone before (38 percent).  Many of these first-time attendees
column2: 43 percent
column3: are supporting Trump
column4: while 19 percent favor Cruz and 14 percent Rubio.  The poll can’t predict how many from this group will actually show up.

column1: Among just those Republicans who have caucused before
column2: it’s a 3-point race:  Trump 28 percent vs. Cruz 25 percent.  Another 10 percent go for Rubio.

column1: True conservative values is the top characteristic GOP caucus-goers want in their party’s nominee (27 percent)
column2: closely followed by telling it like it is (24 percent) and being a strong leader (23 percent).  Those traits outrank nominating someone who can win in November (9 percent) or has the right experience (7 percent).

column1: Unlike Iowa
column2: there has been little movement in the New Hampshire Republican race. Trump continues to garner more than twice the support of his nearest competitors.

column1: The Fox News poll shows Trump at 31 percent (down 2 points)
column2: Cruz at 14 percent (up 2 points) and Rubio at 13 percent (down 2 points).

column1: Kasich is at 9 percent
column2: Bush and Christie each receive 7 percent
column3: Carson and Paul tie at 5 percent
column4: while Fiorina gets 3 percent
column5: and Huckabee 1 percent.

column1: Despite dominating the NH race
column2: Trump also tops the list as the nominee who would make Republicans stay home in November:  26 percent say they would refuse to vote for Trump against the Democrat.  Fifteen percent say the same of Bush
column3: 14 percent feel that way about Cruz
column4: and 12 percent about Rubio.

column1: Over half of likely Republican primary voters in the Granite State say they are certain to vote for their candidate
column2: while 36 percent could still shift their support.

column1: Granite Staters also want slightly different traits in their nominee than their Iowa counterparts.  NH GOP primary voters want a strong leader (27 percent) and someone who tells it like it is (21 percent) more than a nominee who has true conservative values (15 percent)
column2: is electable (13 percent)
column3: or has the right experience (12 percent).

column1: The Fox News Poll is conducted under the joint direction of Anderson Robbins Research (D) and Shaw & Company Research (R).  These polls were conducted January 18-21
column3: by telephone (landline and cellphone) with live interviewers.

column1: The New Hampshire poll was among a sample of 801 registered voters selected from a statewide voter file.  Results based on the sample of 401 Republican primary voters have a margin of sampling error of plus or minus five percentage points.
In Iowa
column2: the poll was among a sample of 801 registered voters selected from a statewide voter file.  Results based on the sample of 378 Republican caucus-goers have a margin of sampling error of plus or minus five percentage points."	REAL

column1: Rand Paul Goes on Senate Floor to Protest NSA Spying Measure	"Congress faces a June 1 deadline for the law's expiration
column2: and Paul's speech underscored the deep divisions over the National Security Agency's (NSA's) bulk collection of Americans' phone records
column3: which was revealed by former contractor Edward Snowden.

column1: There comes a time in the history of nations when fear and complacency allow power to accumulate and liberty and privacy to suffer
column2: the Kentucky senator said at 1:18 p.m. EDT when he took to the Senate floor. ""That time is now
column3: and I will not let the Patriot Act
column4: the most unpatriotic of acts
column5: go unchallenged.""

column1: He finished at 11:49 p.m.
column2: having not sat for more than 10 hours.

column1: The House overwhelmingly passed a bill to end the bulk collection and Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell
column2: R-Kentucky
column3: has said the Senate will act on the issue before beginning a Memorial Day recess scheduled for week's end.

column1: But McConnell
column2: along with presidential hopefuls Sens. Marco Rubio
column3: R-Florida
column4: and Lindsey Graham
column5: R-South Carolina
column6: favors extending the law. Final congressional approval of the bill before the deadline is no certainty.

column1: Paul plunged into a lengthy speech declaring the Patriot Act unconstitutional and opposing renewal of the program. With a hefty binder at his desk
column2: he spelled out his objections
column3: occasionally allowing Republican and Democratic senators to pose questions and getting support from a handful of House members seated at the back of the chamber.

column1: I don't think we're any safer looking at every American's records
column2: Paul said.

column1: Paul's campaign sent out a fundraising appeal while his longstanding opposition to bulk collection
column2: a pillar of his campaign
column3: stirred social media.

column1: Throughout the night
column2: several Democratic senators and a few Republicans gave his voice occasional breaks by speaking several minutes to ostensibly ask him questions. Paul kept control by yielding for questions without ""yielding the floor
column3: and by not sitting.

column1: The surveillance issue has divided Republicans and Democrats
column2: cutting across party lines and pitting civil libertarians concerned about privacy against more hawkish lawmakers fearful about losing tools to combat terrorism.

column1: As Paul made his case
column2: a Justice Department memo circulated on Capitol Hill warning lawmakers that the NSA will have to begin winding down its bulk collection of Americans' phone records by the end of the week if Congress fails to reauthorize the Patriot Act.

column1: After May 22
column3: the National Security Agency will need to begin taking steps to wind down the bulk telephone metadata program in anticipation of a possible sunset in order to ensure that it does not engage in any unauthorized collection or use of the metadata
column4: the department said.

column1: If Congress fails to act
column2: several key provisions of the law would expire
column3: including the bulk collection; a provision allowing so-called roving wiretaps
column4: which the FBI uses for criminals who frequently switch cellphones; and a third that makes it easier to obtain a warrant to target a ""lone wolf"" terror suspect who has no provable links to a terrorist organization.

column1: Last week
column2: the House backed the USA Freedom Act
column3: which would replace bulk collection with a system to search the data held by telephone companies on a case-by-case basis. The vote was 338-88
column4: and House Republican and Democratic leaders have insisted the Senate act on their bill.

column1: But McConnell and several other top Republicans prefer to simply reauthorize the post-Sept. 11 law. McConnell has agreed to allow a vote on the House bill
column2: but has indicated there may not be enough votes to pass it in the Senate.

column1: The Justice Department also said that if Congress allows the law to expire and then passes legislation to reauthorize it when lawmakers return to Washington the week of June 1
column2: it would ""be effective in making the authorities operative again
column3: but may expose the government to some litigation risk in the event of legal challenge.""

column1: The White House backs the House bill and has pressed for the Senate to approve the legislation and send it to President Barack Obama for his signature.
The House bill is the result of outrage among Republicans and Democrats after Snowden's revelations about the NSA program.
Although Paul called his action a filibuster
column2: it technically fell short of Senate rules since the bill the Senate was considering was trade
column3: not the Patriot Act."	REAL

column1: China Airport Security Robot Gives Electroshocks	"China Airport Security Robot Gives Electroshocks 11/02/2016
ACTIVIST POST
While debate surrounds the threat of autonomous “killer robots
column2: ” the mechanized replacement of humans continues across the workforce.

column1: The industrial robotics industry is logging record sales worldwide
column2: and there appears to be no sign of a slowdown. As you can see in the graphic below
column3: 2015 sales surged 12% over a previous record year to reach almost 1/4 million units.

column1: There are many factors driving this growth
column2: which you can read about here; but one point worth noting is that the two leading countries are the US and China
column3: with China leading the way.

column1: The nature of robotics is also changing
column2: as new developments in artificial intelligence are giving robots an increasing range of potential uses. One key area
column3: of course
column4: is security. Robot security guards have already begun appearing at prisons
column5: care facilities
column6: and schools
column7: in various locations around the world.

column1: One U.S. robot company
column2: Gamma 2 Robotics
column3: has designed several models for mass production. Their latest – RAMSEE – can be seen in the video below. A true mass roll-out of this fully autonomous security guard could significantly impact the 1.5 million humans that are currently employed in some form of security patrol.

column1: RAMSEE advertises the following capabilities: Is a physical presence that autonomously patrols without supervision Provides real-time data: intruders
column2: motion
column3: heat
column4: fire
column5: smoke
column6: gases & more Is a human-machine interface that creates a powerful force multiplier

column1: Significantly
column2: Gamma 2 Robotics has partnered with Hexagon Safety & Infrastructure: “the global leader in public safety and security solutions.”

column1: However
column2: RAMSEE is missing one thing: weapons. For that
column3: we have to travel to China
column4: where they seem to have embraced police robots full throttle.

column1: In late 2015
column2: I covered an announcement from China’s Xinhua news agency where they announced the development and deployment of 3 weaponized “anti-terrorism” robots that would be far more active than a mere patrol:

column1: “The toy-sized robots can coordinate with each other on the battlefield
column2: ” said the report
column3: following their unveiling at the 2015 World Robot Conference in Beijing.

column1: The first model is known as a “reconnaissance” robot
column2: which scouts for poisonous gases
column3: dangerous chemicals and explosives before transmitting its findings back to base.If this initial investigation detects a simple bomb is the source of danger
column4: the second robot model – a small explosive ordnance disposal (EOD) machine – would be sent in to diffuse it.

column1: But with other
column2: more complicated threats
column3: an attacker robot would start its mission
column4: armed with “minor-caliber weapons
column5: recoilless rifles and grenade launchers”.

column1: “With a sighting telescope
column2: a trigger and a safe installed
column3: the attacker can hit its target from a long distance
column4: ” Xinhua said.

column1: The local police force in Beijing was reported to be among the buyers for the three robots
column2: which are priced at 1.5 million yuan (£156
column3: 000) for the set by manufacturers HIT Robot Group
column4: who are based in the northern city of Harbin.

column1: “Apart from anti-terror operations
column2: they can also be applied in fire fighting
column3: public security
column4: forestry and agriculture
column5: ” the company’s sales manager Chen Deqiang said
column6: according to Xinhua.

column1: If we have learned anything about anti-terrorism efforts
column2: authorities consider front-line deployment to be areas of public travel. We were given the TSA based on such notions
column3: and have since witnessed its intrusive role in airports
column4: and soon-to-be at other public transportation if authorities have their way.

column1: China has gone to the next level with a robot TSA of sorts called AnBot that is equipped with what is essentially a taser-like device that is being fittingly compared to a cattle-prod.
Image Credit
It was first introduced at a tech show earlier in the year
column2: and was speculated to have been designed for protest suppression. For now
column3: its first job is to patrol China’s Shenzhen airport.

column1: Most alarming
column2: however
column3: is that it is tied to one of the most powerful supercomputers on the planet.

column1: The back end of this “intelligent security robot” is l inked to China’s Tianhe-2 supercomputer
column2: where it has access to cloud services . AnBot conducts patrols
column3: recognizes threats and has multiple cameras that use facial recognition.

column1: These cloud services give the robots petascale processing power
column2: well beyond onboard processing capabilities in the robot. The supercomputer connection is there “to enhance the intelligent learning capabilities and human-machine interface of these devices
column3: ” said the U.S.-China Economic and Security Review
column4: in a report released Tuesday that examines China’s autonomous systems development efforts . [emphasis added]

column1: ( Source )

This link to “cloud services” is a new trend in robot artificial intelligence that also has been referred to as the Wikipedia for Robots – essentially an Internet Cloud Brain. Through robot-to-robot information sharing they can speed up their learning process … autonomously. Examples have included robots that can learn to cook
column2: and robots that can learn the tasks involved in care-giving. However
column3: when applied to policing
column4: things become much more ethically troubling.

column1: People were outraged in the U.S.
column2: for example
column3: when a robot in Dallas was used to deliver a pound of C-4 explosive to a U.S. citizen whom the police deemed a sufficient threat worthy of immediate execution. At least
column4: in that case
column5: a human made the decision. But it is being viewed as a tip-toe along the path to the widespread use of “killer robots” much as we have seen with the use of drones. Discussion was once limited to overseas – egregious enough – but there has been a growing voice of those who are urging weaponized domestic police drones.

column1: As John Vibes wrote
column2: it might be inevitable:

column1: The Taser corporation is planning on building a drone that is equipped with a stun gun
column2: according to a recent report by the Wall Street Journal.

column1: Not only will the drones be equipped with tasers
column2: but there is also talk of them being autonomous
column3: meaning that an actual human won’t necessarily be needed to fly the drone.

column1: This is actually already being done in India
column2: the first country to have approved the use of drones attached with “non-lethal” weapons. And
column3: just this week
column4: British tabloid
column5: The Sun
column6: had a feature entitled “Vladimir Putin’s Russia is preparing an army of robots and drones to take on its enemies
column7: Deputy PM Dmitry Rogozin admits.” Given the available facts
column8: this title no longer seems so deliberately sensational.

column1: Clearly we are entering a potentially dangerous convergence of expanding robotic artificial intelligence along with the political will to continue allowing robots more and more autonomy as they carry out the traditional duties of the military and police. Some experts argue that the precision of robotics will curb many of the abuses we have seen from our military and police. But is that the trend we are actually seeing? Or will automated systems of violent control inevitably lead to even greater industrial-level suppression and killing?
Nicholas West writes for ActivistPost.com . This article may be republished in part or in full with author attribution and source link ."	FAKE

column1: Reality Check: First Clinton v Trump presidential debate	"The first televised presidential debate between Hillary Clinton and Donald Trump was a bonanza for fact checkers. Here are some of the candidates' statements and how they compare with the facts.
Claim: Donald Trump repeated his insistence that he was against the 2003 invasion of Iraq
column2: claiming Clinton's assertions to the contrary were ""mainstream media nonsense put out by her"".

column1: Reality Check verdict: Trump did not publicly speak out against the war before it started. On 11 September 2002
column2: radio host Howard Stern asked Trump if he supported a potential invasion of Iraq. He replied: ""Yeah
column3: I guess so"". During the debate
column4: he tried to explain that away by saying the comment had been made ""lightly"". He said he had been arguing in private
column5: to Fox News's Sean Hannity
column6: that war would destabilise the Middle East
column7: but we have no evidence to support that so far. He did start to express doubts after the invasion.

column1: Claim: Clinton attacked Trump over his boasts about his business acumen. ""You know
column2: Donald was very fortunate in his life and that's all to his benefit
column3: Clinton said. ""He started his business with $14m
column4: borrowed from his father.""

column1: Reality Check verdict: Trump says he received a $1m loan from his real estate mogul father. He also got loan guarantees and money from his future inheritance and inherited a share of his father's property holdings.

Claim: Trump alleged that Clinton called the Trans-Pacific Partnership trade deal the ""gold standard"" of trade agreements. Clinton denied this but added: ""I did say I hoped it would be a good deal.""

Reality Check verdict: We give this one to Trump. Clinton did more than express hope that the deal would turn out well and in a 2012 trip to Australia said it would be the ""gold standard"": ""This TPP sets the gold standard in trade agreements to open free
column2: transparent
column3: fair trade
column4: the kind of environment that has the rule of law and a level playing field.""

column1: Claim: Clinton said: ""People have looked at both of our plans
column2: have concluded that mine would create 10 million jobs and yours would lose us 3.5 million jobs.""

column1: Reality Check verdict: Clinton has made this claim before. It is based on an optimistic reading of a report by Moody's Analytics
column2: which says that most of the 10 million new jobs would be created anyway by an expanding economy. If all of Clinton's economic policies became law - which the report says is unlikely - they would account for 3.2 million of the 10 million jobs. The same company analysed Trump's plans and suggested they would tip the US into recession and lead to 3.5 million job losses - something strongly disputed by the Trump campaign.

column1: But the two reports cover different time frames. The author Mark Zandi told CNN Money a more accurate comparison to the 10 million jobs created under Clinton would be 400
column2: 000 jobs lost under Trump
column3: not 3.4 million.

column1: Claim: Trump has frequently tried to blame the rise of Islamic State militants on Secretary of State Hillary Clinton. This is his latest attempt.
Reality Check verdict: Possibly the strangest claim of the night. Clinton is 68 years old. The so-called Islamic State can trace its roots back to 1999
column2: although it did not start referring to itself as the Islamic State of Iraq and Syria (ISIS) until 2013. Read more here.

column1: Claim: Clinton accused Trump of calling calling climate change a hoax invented by the Chinese. He insisted ""I did not say that"".

Reality Check verdict: This claim relates to a 2012 tweet which Trump later said was a joke. He said: ""The concept of global warming was created by and for the Chinese in order to make US manufacturing non-competitive.""
Claim: Clinton said race determines how people are treated in the criminal justice system.

Reality Check verdict: This is a tough one to prove as there are no figures on the percentage of crimes that result in arrest. What we do know is that black people are locked up five times more frequently than white people. African-American people make up about 13% of the United States population. White people make up 64%. But black people make up 40% of the prison population
column2: and white people 39%. It does not mean that black people
column3: who tend to live more in urban
column4: heavily policed areas
column5: are five times as likely to commit crime however.

column1: Clinton also claimed that African American men are more likely to be killed by guns than other demographics
column2: something that is largely borne out by the statistics.

column1: Claim: Murders in New York city are up.
Reality Check verdict: As so often with crime statistics it depends how you slice it. The murder rate in New York city is close to record lows but did increase slightly between 2014 and 2015
column2: according to FBI figures. But the very latest figures from the New York Police Department show murder rates are down 4% on 2015.

column1: Murder rates across the US as a whole went up 10.8% in 2015
column2: the biggest single-year percentage jump since 1971
column3: with a big spike in a handful of cities including Chicago
column4: Washington DC and Baltimore.

column1: Trump also claimed that ""stop and frisk"" tactics ""worked very well in New York"" and brought crime rates down. This is hotly disputed by researchers and commentators . Violent crime rates have continued to decline in New York
column2: as part of a long term trend
column3: even though the number of ""stop and frisk"" searches has gone down dramatically in recent years. Research by Jeffrey Fagan of Columbia University found indiscriminate searches had little effect on crime
column4: although his research also found crime was reduced when police stopped and frisked civilians after observing someone acting violently
column5: selling drugs or ""casing a joint"".

column1: Claim: Trump says he can't release his tax returns because he is in the middle of a tax audit. He also says publishing them would not reveal much.
Clinton suggests he will never publish them as they might reveal he is not as rich as he says he is
column2: does not pay Federal tax and does not give as much to charity as claimed.

column1: Reality Check verdict: Being audited by the Internal Revenue Service does not prohibit the release of tax returns. They would reveal Trump's annual income
column2: how much he pays in tax and how much he gives to charity. Trump claims he has given $102m to charity in the past five years
column3: but a Washington Post investigation could not find any cash donated by Trump's businesses after 2008. Trump's actual wealth has been assessed by Forbes at $4.5bn
column4: compared with the $10bn he claims.

column1: Interestingly
column2: Trump has never provided evidence that he is actually under audit by the tax authorities. According to Associated Press
column3: a letter released by his tax lawyers never used the word
column4: merely describing his tax returns as under continuous review."	REAL

column1: Doomsday Election	"Here's
This is what it must feel like to be on Death Row
column2: to be waiting for the moment when the iron door clangs open for the last time and four burly guards escort you arm-in-arm to the room where your life will be extinguished. That same sense of dread hangs over the presidential election of 2016.

column1: No one is happy about the election and no one anticipates better days ahead. America’s ‘glory days” appear to be in the rearview mirror while the steady downward slide seems to be gaining pace. This year’s presidential campaign has brought all the anger
column2: anxiety and frustration bubbling to the surface. Nerves are raw
column3: people are on edge
column4: and the trepidation is so thick you could cut it with a knife. All the recent surveys tell the same story: Americans are sick of the mudslinging
column5: sick of the scandals
column6: sick of the recriminations
column7: sick of the two party duopoly
column8: and sick of the two candidates
column9: the two most distrusted and reviled candidates in the country’s 230 year history. This is from the New York Times:

column1: “An overwhelming majority of voters are disgusted by the state of American politics
column2: and many harbor doubts that either major-party nominee can unite the country after a historically ugly presidential campaign
column3: according to the final pre-election New York Times/CBS News Poll…

column1: With more than eight in 10 voters saying the campaign has left them repulsed rather than excited
column2: the rising toxicity threatens the ultimate victor. Mrs. Clinton
column3: the Democratic candidate
column4: and Mr. Trump
column5: the Republican nominee
column6: are seen as dishonest and viewed unfavorably by a majority of voters…

column1: After weeks of Mr. Trump’s accusations that the election is “rigged
column2: ” a little more than six in 10 of his supporters say they will accept the results as legitimate if he loses. More than a quarter of Mr. Trump’s supporters say they will probably not accept the outcome if Mrs. Clinton is declared the winner
column3: and nearly 40 percent of them say they have little or no confidence that Americans’ votes will be counted properly.” ( Voters Express Disgust Over U.S. Politics in New Times /CBS Poll
column4: New York Times)

column1: The growing sense of desperation in America today is palpable and it goes far beyond this one
column2: isolated election cycle. The steady erosion of confidence in the nation’s main institutions is evident in Congress’s public approval ratings which seem to be stuck in single-digit territory. The public probably feels equal contempt for the Loretta Lynch Justice Department which is loaded with Clinton toadies that have done their best to quash any investigation into the illicit pay-to-play machinations at the Clinton Foundation. And
column3: let’s not forget the media which has lost whatever shred of credibility it managed to salvage after its myriad of war-promoting lies about WMD
column4: mobile weapons labs
column5: aluminum tubes and Assad’s imaginary chemical weapons attacks
column6: attacks that were invented from whole cloth at one of Washington’s many neocon think tanks where these fake ideas are typically hatched. The Forth Estate’s latest gambit is an idiotic attempt to prove that Vladimir Putin is trying to hack our thoroughly-corrupted Third World voting system to achieve some nebulous political gain. What a joke.

column1: No
column2: Hillary
column3: Putin is not gaming the system like you did in the primaries with Bernie Sanders
column4: nor did he put a gun to your head and force you to delete the 33
column5: 000 missing emails from your private server. That was your handiwork Ms. Clinton
column6: although you have a done a masterful job in deflecting attention from yourself and passing the buck for your own sleazy
column7: criminal activities onto Moscow.

column1: But
column2: back to the media. This from Gallup:

column1: “Americans’ trust and confidence in the mass media “to report the news fully
column2: accurately and fairly” has dropped to its lowest level in Gallup polling history
column3: with 32% saying they have a great deal or fair amount of trust in the media. This is down eight percentage points from last year.

column1: Gallup began asking this question in 1972
column2: and on a yearly basis since 1997. Over the history of the entire trend
column3: Americans’ trust and confidence hit its highest point in 1976
column4: at 72%
column5: in the wake of widely lauded examples of investigative journalism regarding Vietnam and the Watergate scandal. After staying in the low to mid-50s through the late 1990s and into the early years of the new century
column6: Americans’ trust in the media has fallen slowly and steadily. It has consistently been below a majority level since 2007…

column1: Bottom Line:…the slide in media trust has been happening for the past decade. Before 2004
column2: it was common for a majority of Americans to profess at least some trust in the mass media
column3: but since then
column4: less than half of Americans feel that way. Now
column5: only about a third of the U.S. has any trust in the Fourth Estate
column6: a stunning development for an institution designed to inform the public.” ( Americans’ Trust in Mass Media Sinks to New Low
column7: Gallup)

column1: “Designed to inform the public”???

You gotta be kidding? Droopy confidence in the media is a triumph for ordinary working people who have begun to see through the charade of “unbiased coverage” and realize that the corporate owners of the press manipulate the news to shape perceptions and maintain their stranglehold on power. That’s what’s really going on
column2: and that’s why a growing number of people have swarmed to Donald Trump’s campaign. They see Trump’s lack of political correctness as a sign that he is not owned by the Washington oligarchy of racketeers who invent teleprompter candidates like Obama and Clinton who are never certain what they actually believe until they see it printed in bold letters on the screen in front of them. ORDER IT NOW

column1: To large extent
column2: Trump owes his shocking rise to the top of the GOP ticket to the fact that he shoots from the hip and that the media hates him. What was once a liability
column3: has become an asset as trust for the despised media has plunged to depths never seen before.

column1: But that doesn’t explain what’s really driving this election and why are the American people so overcome by desperation?
It’s all about economic insecurity. It’s all about the fact that standards of living are slipping
column2: that an entire generation is bogged down with student debt
column3: that all the good-paying jobs have been shipped to other countries
column4: that family incomes are shriveling
column5: that a good portion of the population feel threatened by immigration
column6: that health care costs have skyrocketed
column7: that retirement plans have been postponed
column8: and that the great bulk of the nation’s wealth has been transferred to the 1 percent plutocrats and Wall Street landsharks who dictate policy through their Congressional lackeys and their allies at the Federal Reserve. That’s what the election is really all about.

column1: People are waking up to the fact that the American dream is dead
column2: that the US is no longer the land of opportunity
column3: and that the lives of their children are going to be worse than their own
column4: far worse. This is why everyone is so upset
column5: so frustrated
column6: so hopeless. They are looking for a political ally who will address their needs
column7: and instead they get bromides on transgender bathrooms or “glass ceilings” or any of the other soothing slogans the Democrats use to pacify the masses and to keep them in the flock. Only now it’s not working as well. Now a sizable portion of the blue collar vote has shifted into Trump’s camp mainly because they see through the phony Democrat rhetoric and all the job-eviscerating free trade deals they’ve pushed for years. Trump has skillfully tapped into the collective psyche of millions of working people who feel the Democratic Party tossed them under the track-hoe 30 years ago and never looked back. And
column8: he’s right
column9: too. The Dems have sold out their supporters
column10: and it’s only going to get worse under Clinton
column11: or should we say
column12: Madame TPP. Here’s how Nile Bowie summed it up in a recent article at CounterPunch:

column1: “Economic disempowerment and political disenfranchisement have accelerated under President Obama
column2: to the detriment of the American middle class. White
column3: blue-collar Americans have witnessed the offshoring of their jobs and the erosion of their status in society
column4: and Trump has masterfully stroked their resentment and discontent by playing on their fears of Muslims
column5: immigrants and minorities…

column1: Trump’s real problem with the Washington establishment is that he isn’t part of it. His campaign represents an insurgent faction of the oligarchical class that aims to displace and replace the standing political elites. Bipartisan opposition to Trump is grounded in the belief that he would be an unreliable proxy and a liability
column2: someone too narrow and unpredictable to manage the common affairs of the ruling class and the US deep state.

column1: Moreover
column2: the US establishment is not interested in being led by such a contentious figure
column3: who would draw protest and public opposition in a way that more conventional establishment candidates largely do not. For example
column4: Trump’s rhetoric on immigration seems to engender more public outrage than the immigration policy under Obama
column5: who has deported more people than any other president in history.” ( Election 2016: A Political System In Crisis
column6: Nile Bowie
column7: CounterPunch)

column1: The big money guys don’t like Trump
column2: and they make no bones about it. But Trump isn’t going away and neither are his followers
column3: a vast number of whom will not respect the results of the election if Hillary wins. That’s a big problem for elites who like to manage the population through the popular election sham. Now all that’s at risk.

column1: And it’s not like Trump hasn’t bent over backwards to ingratiate himself with the deep-state powerbrokers either. He has. His first olive branch to the elites was the selection of Mike Pence as his running mate. Pence is a died-in-the-wool establishment Republican neocon who can be trusted to pursue the same extremist agenda the GOP has followed since the Gingrich revolution. But there was another big move that Trump made that escaped the notice of the media and which really underscores his willingness to “play by to the rules.” Here’s the story from Zero Hedge:
“Six months ago
column2: Steven Mnuchin became finance chair for the Trump campaign. Having successfully helped to raise 10s of millions of dollars for the campaign
column3: the former Goldman Sachs partner and Soros Fund management employee is now positioned for something much larger as Donald Trump reportedly told his aides today that he wants Mnuchin to serve as his Treasury Secretary.

column1: Ironically
column2: Trump has often criticized Clinton (and his former competitor Ted Cruz) for their links to the big banks: “I know the guys at Goldman Sachs. They have total
column3: total control over him. Just like they have total control over Hillary Clinton
column4: ” Trump said in one debate. But as we noted previously
column5: he had no qualms
column6: however
column7: in hiring one of the most prominent Goldman alums to raise money for him. …for Trump
column8: a self-professed “anti-establishment” candidate
column9: who has repeatedly stated he is not “for sale to special interest groups”
column10: his sudden call for the seemingly most “Wall Street” of Wall-Streeters to become Treasury Secretary may come as a big surprise to some and will leave many of his supporters demanding an explanation.” ( Trump Wants Former Goldman Partner And Soros Employee To Serve As Treasury Secretary
column11: Zero Hedge) Another head of Treasury from G-Sax?

column1: That figures.

Trump is great with the rabble-rousing “take back your country” tirades and all the gibberish about the “rigged” system. But he also knows how to cave in when it suits his interests. He knows he’s not going to be president without Wall Street’s nod
column2: so he’s enlisted a trusted insider to take care of business at Treasury. It’s a signal to the bigwigs that they don’t have to worry about the Donald going off the reservation. (wink
column3: wink) So much for Trump’s independence
column4: eh?

column1: And what can we say about Hillary Clinton that hasn’t been said a million times before?
Clinton
column2: who still holds a slim lead in most of the polls
column3: is clearly the establishment candidate in a year when hatred for the corrupt Washington oligarchy
column4: has reached levels not seen in the last hundred years. The fact that Hillary can run for the nation’s highest office while being investigated by the FBI
column5: while being savaged by the daily releases of new
column6: incriminating emails (from WikiLeaks)
column7: and while promoting a hawkish
column8: neocon-driven foreign policy that portends a direct military confrontation with Russia
column9: speaks to the fact that traditional liberal Democrats are either still hoodwinked by the Democratic Party’s manipulation of identity politics or simply terrified of the alternative
column10: Donald Trump.

column1: And that’s why everyone is so utterly dejected and depressed about the election
column2: because instead of voting for a candidate they really want or admire
column3: most people are simply voting for the candidate that either disgusts or scares the hell out of them the least. What kind of choice is that?

column1: In less than 48 hours
column2: the most agonizingly-wretched campaign of all times will be over
column3: the ballots will be counted
column4: and the new president will be named. The only thing that is certain is that
column5: whoever wins
column6: we lose.

column1: The system set Boehner up for failure	"On Friday
column2: Speaker John Boehner announced that he will resign from the speakership and the US House at the end of October. Here
column3: the Mischiefs of Faction writers offer their quick reactions.

column1: I think Boehner's resignation is more notable for when it occurred than for that it occurred. He had been speaker or minority leader for almost a decade
column2: and clearly no longer relished his job. I think that the next speaker will face the same obstacles that confronted Boehner
column3: particularly a ""no compromise"" faction of conservatives. They cannot be satisfied with policy substance
column4: since they mostly care about tactical extremism. They have also made it clear that they have little interest in the sort of ""pork barrel"" politics that members traditionally have seen as a means to reelection.

column1: I don't think this situation will change until there is a Republican in the White House
column2: since the Tea Partiers object to the slightest accommodation of President Obama or any Democratic successor. There's also a whole industry now devoted to feeding conservatives' belief that their leadership has sold them out. This includes talk radio
column3: bloggers
column4: and groups such as Heritage Action. Perhaps a leader with a warmer relationship with movement conservatives might be a more effective speaker. I'm skeptical that much will change soon.

column1: John Boehner has finally decided to take his ball and go home. Of course
column2: I understand why he is resigning: The House GOP is ungovernable right now. Thus
column3: while it is an understandable decision
column4: it is not a ""selfless"" one
column5: as several members have described it. No
column6: this is Boehner's coup de grace
column7: executed with deftness. Now free to rely on Democratic votes when necessary
column8: he will be able to keep the government open. In the same way
column9: he might be able to pass other legislation in the next month. More importantly
column10: he presents his fractured caucus with a parting ""gift"" of their own making: selecting their next leader. Beyond the obvious question of who will be the next speaker (probably Majority Leader Kevin McCarthy of California)
column11: really interesting questions raised by Boehner's decision include how the process will work out: Will other Republicans step forward and challenge McCarthy for the job? Will the GOP caucus ultimately come together behind a single candidate? If not
column12: what will the Democrats do? As unexpected and exciting as today's surprise announcement is
column13: this is probably going to get much more interesting before all is said and done.

column1: John Boehner's resignation as speaker of the House is a good illustration of how American political parties are strong and how they are not. US political parties are not strong in the top-down sense. Neither presidents nor congressional leaders have a lot of control over backbenchers in their parties. The main reason is that these leaders don't control party nominations. While parties have become ""stronger"" since the 1970s
column2: they have become stronger from the bottom up
column3: not the top down.

column1: Presidents don't have much better ability to force legislators to do what they want now (when party line votes are the norm) than they did in the 1950s
column3: and '70s (when party line votes were rarer). What changed? The power to shape legislative behavior comes from the bottom up. Not just from ordinary voters (although those are influential)
column4: but also from organized interest groups and wealthy donors in the legislator's district and in their party's national constituency. These factions are what really influence legislators and create party unity
column5: not their party leaders in Washington.

column1: So why is there so much party unity now
column2: when there wasn't in the 1970s? Now the parties are sorted ideologically. All the legislators who come from conservative districts and are backed by conservative interests groups are Republicans
column3: while all those from liberal districts and backed by liberal interest groups are Democrats. So
column4: unlike the 1970s
column5: a party leader now presides over an ideologically unified caucus that usually votes together. Yet that doesn't mean that he or she has much more direct power over them than leaders did in the decades after World War II.

column1: Speakers' jobs were actually more secure in the post–World War II era when they led ideologically diverse parties and party control rarely changed hands. The last speaker of the House to retire by choice because of age was Tip O'Neill
column2: who left in 1986. All subsequent speakers have left because of internal party revolts
column3: personal scandals
column4: or electoral disappointments. It is a challenging job
column5: because while US political parties are strong
column6: the power largely does not rest in the congressional leadership. Politicians are loyal to their parties' voters and organized factions
column7: not to their legislative leaders in DC.

column1: The longstanding tension within congressional parties is that legislators need to cooperate with their parties to accomplish their shared goals
column2: but to do so they must overcome the inherent diversity of American parties.

column1: Since 2010
column2: the House GOP has provided a brilliant demonstration of this tension. The rules of the House
column3: and the Republican conference
column4: provided Boehner with a great deal of power. But his ""majority"" included a sizable number of legislators who would not or could not cooperate with their party. They had campaigned against the party status quo. They promised not to vote for compromises. They promised outcomes they could not realistically achieve with a majority in one chamber (e.g. repealing Obamacare). They feared a primary challenge from the right more than losing to a Democrat.

column1: It is likely that the next speaker will suffer from the same challenge because the challenge is systemic. The best chance to end the cycle
column2: however
column3: would be for the House GOP to select someone who is trusted by the Tea Party faction both inside and outside of Congress
column4: so that when s/he says
column5: ""That's a stupid strategy that will fail
column6: resulting in a drop in the polls and a humiliating acceptance of the Democrats' demands
column7: they will actually trust the speaker.

column1: The nationalization of congressional politics has changed what it means to try to lead a congressional party. What we like to call leadership — for speakers
column2: for presidents
column3: whatever — often amounts to reading the interests and preferences of different actors and figuring out how to bring them into a coalition to support policy that includes a little something for everyone. Pet projects and distribution of resources (that is
column4: what we used to know as ""pork"") can help this process along. But if legislators' preferences are driven by national issues like defunding Planned Parenthood and opposing the president
column5: then the job of coalition building becomes that much more challenging. Boehner may not have been the most talented legislative leader
column6: but his problems
column7: as Greg indicates
column8: are also structural and systemic. And to the extent that they reflect the infusion of national — and often symbolic — issues into congressional elections
column9: they may run deeper than the Tea Party-establishment split.

column1: This post is part of Mischiefs of Faction
column2: an independent political science blog featuring reflections on the party system. See more Mischiefs of Faction posts here."	REAL

column1: Gay marriage victory at Supreme Court triggering backlash	"Corrections and clarifications: An earlier version of this story misidentified the Alabama official leading efforts against same-sex marriage in the state. It is the state's chief justice.
WASHINGTON — When the Supreme Court declared a constitutional right to same-sex marriage last June
column2: the man who won the leading case warned that opponents would find new ways to push back.

column1: “We will have to continue the fight
column2: ” Jim Obergefell said then — and he was right.

column1: For nearly a year
column2: seesaw battles over religious exemptions and transgender rights have replaced what had been the gay rights movement's steady progress in winning protections against discrimination in states and cities. Legislative and legal skirmishes have been triggered by an intransigent Alabama chief justice and a defiant Kentucky county clerk
column3: a Colorado baker and a Washington State florist
column4: and most recently a conservative backlash that has traveled east from Texas to Mississippi to North Carolina.

column1: We never thought this had to do with just marriage
column2: says Kristen Waggoner
column3: senior vice president of legal advocacy at Alliance Defending Freedom
column4: which represents many gay rights opponents in court. ""This is about more than marriage.”

column1: It's also about more than bathrooms
column2: although a North Carolina law that denies transgender people the right to use public restrooms corresponding to their gender identity has dominated the LGBT rights debate for the past two months:

column1: Across the country
column2: the gay rights movement has been met with local opposition — sometimes where it was least expected
column3: such as Houston
column4: which had three times elected a lesbian mayor. That has forced the movement back on the defensive less than a year after its greatest success: the Supreme Court's 5-4 decision in Obergefell v. Hodges that extended same-sex marriage nationwide.

column1: “To some
column2: this is the next front in the war
column3: says David Stacy
column4: government affairs director at the Human Rights Campaign
column5: the nation's largest gay rights organization. “Some of the intensity on the other side
column6: some of the emotional intensity
column7: comes from that.”

column1: Both sides in the battle say it's about individual rights — LGBT rights to live free from discrimination
column2: and religious or moral rights to live free from government interference. It extends to education
column3: employment and housing — and it may not be long before a lawsuit is headed back to the Supreme Court.

column1: “I think this moment is going to be short-lived
column2: but a lot of damage can be done in this moment
column3: says Shannon Minter
column4: legal director at the National Center for Lesbian Rights. “It will ultimately be up to the Supreme Court to decide whether Title VII (of the Civil Rights Act) and Title IX (of the Education Amendments Act) fully protect transgender people
column5: and for that matter gay people.""

column1: Justice Anthony Kennedy's historic ruling on same-sex marriage included a single paragraph warning of the war to come.
The First Amendment ensures that religious organizations and persons are given proper protection as they seek to teach the principles that are so fulfilling and so central to their lives and faiths
column2: and to their own deep aspirations to continue the family structure they have long revered
column3: Kennedy conceded. ""The same is true of those who oppose same-sex marriage for other reasons.""

column1: Those battles had begun long before the Supreme Court's decision. In states where same-sex marriage already was legal
column2: merchants who refused to participate in gay and lesbian weddings based on religious objections were the targets of lawsuits. Most of them lost the early rounds and have appealed.

column1: The first major sign of resistance after the high court's ruling came out of left field. Voters in Houston
column2: where Mayor Annise Parker in 2010 became one of the first openly gay mayors of a major U.S. city
column3: rejected a City Council-passed ordinance to protect residents based on characteristics that included sexual orientation and gender identity. The simple slogan: ""No Men in Women's Bathrooms.""

column1: They identified an opening and exploited it
column2: says James Esseks
column3: director of the American Civil Liberties Union's LGBT efforts.

column1: Then this year
column2: state legislatures in South Dakota
column3: Georgia
column4: Mississippi and North Carolina passed laws pushing back against LGBT rights. The bills were vetoed by Republican governors Dennis Daugaard in South Dakota and Nathan Deal in Georgia but signed by Mississippi's Phil Bryant and North Carolina's Pat McCrory.

column1: Mississippi's law protects those who deny services based on religious objections to gay marriage or transgender people. North Carolina's prevents the state and its municipalities from establishing civil rights protections based on sexual orientation or gender identity.
You're seeing an explosion of religious liberty legislation in the wake of Obergefell
column2: says Mat Staver
column3: chairman of Liberty Counsel
column4: a conservative law firm and think tank involved in the effort. He calls it ""just the tip of the iceberg of what we will see as Obergefell begins to settle on the rest of the country.”

column1: The fight reached the floor of the House of Representatives this month over an amendment intended to ban federal contractors from firing workers who are gay
column2: lesbian
column3: bisexual or transgender. The measure was blocked
column4: then passed
column5: then blocked again.

column1: Beset by such conflicts
column2: gay rights advocates have made little progress in the past year on their major post-gay marriage agenda: passing state laws protecting the LGBT community against discrimination in employment
column3: housing and public accommodations.

column1: Utah was the 22nd state to pass such a law in March 2015. Since then
column2: gay rights activists have met a wall of opposition in the remaining 28 states
column3: mostly led by Republican governors and legislatures.

column1: “People are using Obergefell now to say 'I can get married on a Sunday
column2: but then I can go into work and get fired on the next day
column3: ” says Travis Weber
column4: director of the center for religious liberty at the conservative Family Research Council.

column1: Even so
column2: he says
column3: ""There’s a need to protect religious dissenters.”

column1: The two sets of legal skirmishes — over religious exemptions and transgender rights — ""have made it difficult for us to move forward
column2: Esseks says. He calls them ""responses to the reality of the freedom to marry nationwide.""

column1: There have been some victories for LGBT rights. Last month
column2: a federal appeals court in Richmond ruled in favor of a transgender boy's right to sue a Virginia school district over its bathroom policy. A handful of states
column3: led by New York
column4: have banned the use of controversial conversion therapy on minors.

column1: “It’s not as though we’re not making any legislative progress. We are
column2: Minter says. Even the prospect of passing non-discrimination laws in 'red' states
column3: he says
column4: ""is actually much less daunting after Obergefell than it was before.”

column1: But energized by their loss at the Supreme Court last June
column2: religious objectors are fighting back amidst a presidential election that has divided the country along geographical
column3: ideological and cultural lines.

column1: What’s at stake right now is so much bigger than whether someone has to shower with someone of the opposite sex
column2: ” Waggoner says. ""I think Obergefell opened that door more broadly than it had been before. It not only jeopardizes religious freedom
column3: but it jeopardizes all of our religious liberties.”"	REAL
