McCarthy drops out of speaker race as House asks: Who wants this job? (+video)	"The speakership is one of the toughest jobs in Washington
column2: especially when it includes trying to contain a Republican civil war.

column1: Two Sunday attacks add to recent rise in fatal shootings of US police
House majority leader Kevin McCarthy (R) of California speaks during a new conference on Capitol Hill in Washington Thursday after dropping out of the race to replace House Speaker John Boehner.

Shortly after Republican Rep. Kevin McCarthy stunned Washington with another development in the race for speaker of the House – the front-runner announced Thursday that he was dropping out – names of new candidates began circulating.
Inevitably
column2: the chatter quickly reached Rep. Paul Ryan (R) of Wisconsin – former vice presidential candidate
column3: chairman of the powerful Ways and Means Committee
column4: and budget hawk who many members believe is the person most capable of uniting the deeply divided and turbulent House Republican conference.

column1: But Chairman Ryan promptly put down this second attempt to draft him. As his Texan GOP colleague
column2: Rep. Blake Farenthold tweeted:

column1: Can you blame him? The speakership is one of the toughest jobs in Washington – especially this speakership
column2: which is tasked with trying to end or contain a Republican civil war in the chamber.

column1: “It’s going to take a lot of gumption and a lot of finesse and talent to bridge the gap. So yeah
column2: it’s a difficult chore that very few people are willing to take on
column3: ” Rep. Harold Rogers (R) of Kentucky told a scrum of reporters Thursday afternoon.

column1: Just hours earlier
column2: majority leader McCarthy
column3: an affable Californian known for his listening skills and outreach
column4: capitulated in the face of revolt from the hard-line House Freedom Caucus. Its 40 or so members were set to vote against him in secret balloting.

column1: His unscripted comments about the political nature of the Benghazi special committee
column2: which is calling Democratic presidential candidate Hillary Clinton to testify later this month
column3: also played a role in his decision
column4: he said. McCarthy was attacked from all sides for that comment
column5: from Democrats
column6: Republicans
column7: and the media
column8: when he was tagged as a future speaker who can’t speak.

column1: McCarthy was likely to survive the hard-liner defection Thursday
column2: and win the majority support from his GOP conference needed to nominate him for the speakership. But it was not at all clear that he could win the 218 votes needed to elect the speaker on the House floor later this month.

column1: Standing before cameras in the brightly lit marbled lobby of the Longworth House Office Building
column2: his wife beside him
column3: the leader capitulated. “We need a new face.… If we're going to be strong
column4: we gotta be 100 percent united
column5: he said.

column1: “There’s too much anger
column2: ” McCarthy told Congressman Rogers
column3: after taking himself out of the running at the closed-door balloting session
column4: according to  Roll Call. The Washington Post reported members crying at the news.

column1: “Who knows what’ll happen. People are crying
column2: they don’t have any idea how this will unfold
column3: at all
column4: ” Rep. Peter King (R) of New York
column5: told the Post.

column1: What most people see of the speakership is what shows up on television. But the job carries awesome responsibility: second in line to the presidency
column2: manager of the Capitol complex
column3: presiding officer of the House. And that’s the easy part.

column1: Then there’s the role of chief messenger of your party
column2: shaping the agenda
column3: and trying to keep your members in line every day to cross the 218-vote threshold – the number of votes it takes to pass a bill in the 435-member body. And don’t forget incessant fundraising
column4: which takes up most weekends. Oh
column5: and negotiating with the White House and Senate.

column1: Then add the “hell no” caucus of 40 to 50 right-wingers to this mix.
The hard-liners drove Speaker John Boehner (R) of Ohio to announce his early retirement for Oct. 30. In light of the decision of his No. 2 to withdraw
column2: Speaker Boehner says he will stay on “until the House votes to elect a new speaker.” McCarthy says he is willing to stay on as leader. No date has been set for another leadership election.

column1: Some Republicans want Boehner to finish out his term as a congressman and speaker.
“It’s a very difficult job and having someone like John Boehner there who has a lot of experience and has the courage to do what’s right … is a good thing
column2: ” says Rep. Carlos Curbelo (R) of Florida.

column1: Congressman Curbelo
column2: who describes the speakership as “more difficult than being the president
column3: ” says he doesn’t see any candidate from either party able to get 218 votes.

column1: That hasn’t stopped new names from being floated
column2: even while the other two candidates – Rep. Daniel Webster of Florida
column3: backed by the Freedom Caucus
column4: and Rep. Jason Chaffetz of Utah
column5: the chairman of the House Oversight and Government Reform Committee – kept their hats in the ring.

column1: Right-wingers were pleased to see McCarthy drop out. They see him as ""Boehner 2.0."" In a statement
column2: the Freedom Caucus said it respects his decision to ""put the conference ahead of himself"" and said the next speaker ""needs to yield back power to the membership.""

column1: The Republican caucus is going through a period of transition
column2: says John Feehery
column3: former spokesman to Dennis Hastert (R) of Illinois
column4: the longest serving Republican speaker. McCarthy represented a new generation of leaders in the House
column5: where nearly half of the members have served four years or less.

column1: “They’re going to have to chart their own course and they’re going to have to figure out how the House works together
column2: and they’re going to make mistakes
column3: he says.

column1: That’s one way to learn."	REAL
Democrats, Republicans in tight races as Iowans prepare to caucus	"As Iowans prepare to cast the first votes in the presidential nominating process Monday
column2: Texas Sen. Ted Cruz and Vermont Sen. Bernie Sanders hoped to defy the polls and pull off upset victories in Monday night's caucuses.

column1: After months of campaigning and more than $150 million spent on advertising
column2: the race for supremacy in Iowa is close in both parties.

column1: Among Republicans
column2: the latest polls show real estate billionaire Donald Trump holding a slim edge over Cruz. Cruz
column3: who became the first major candidate from either party to enter the presidential race 315 days ago
column4: has pinned his hopes to a sophisticated get-out-the-vote operation. Cruz has also modeled his campaign after past Iowa winners
column5: visiting all of the state's 99 counties and courting influential evangelical and conservative leaders.

column1: If you had told me 10 months ago that the day before the Iowa caucuses we'd be in a statistcal tie for first place I would have been thrilled and exhilarated
column2: Cruz told Fox News late Sunday.

column1: The Republican caucus is also the first test of whether Trump can turn the legion of fans drawn to his plainspoken populism into voters. The scope of the billionaire's organization in Iowa is a mystery
column2: though Trump himself has intensified his campaign schedule during the final sprint
column3: including a pair of rallies Monday.

column1: ""I don't have to win it
column2: Trump said on CBS' “Face the Nation"" Sunday. ""I'm doing really well with the evangelicals in Iowa. But I'm also doing tremendously well all over the country with the evangelicals. … I think we have a good chance of winning Iowa.""

column1: By contrast
column2: Cruz told Fox News
column3: ""We're not finding Trump's troops on the ground. ‎They don't have an organization that is perceptible.""

column1: Cruz has also spent the closing days of the Iowa campaign focused on Marco Rubio
column2: trying to ensure the Florida senator doesn't inch into second place. Rubio is viewed by many Republicans as a more mainstream alternative to Trump and Cruz
column3: though he'll need to stay competitive in Iowa in order to maintain his viability.

column1: On the Democratic side
column2: Sanders has rallied to close a 40-point polling deficit against former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton
column3: reviving memories of her disappointing showing in Iowa eight years ago.

column1: Stick with me
column2: Clinton said as she rallied supporters Sunday in Council Bluffs. ""Stick with a plan. Stick with experience.""

column1: Sanders
column2: whose crowds have been large and generally younger than Clinton's
column3: urged voters to help him ""make history"". In a show of financial strength
column4: Sanders' campaign announced Sunday it had raised $20 million in January alone. While Sanders has a large team in Iowa
column5: his operation got off to a later start
column6: particularly compared with Clinton
column7: who has had staff on the ground in the state for nearly a year.

column1: I think we have a shot to win it
column2: if people come out
column3: Sanders told ABC's ""This Week."" The self-described democratic socialist's message that the U.S. economy is “rigged” against the middle class has appeared to resonate with an electorate that has grown frustrated with Washington and given rise to insurgent candidates like Sanders and Trump.

column1: The campaigns were anxiously keeping an eye on the weather
column2: but a snowfall forecast to start Monday night appeared more likely to hinder the hopefuls in their rush out of Iowa than any potential voters. Republican John Kasich already had decamped to New Hampshire Sunday
column3: with New Jersey Gov. Chris Christie and former Florida Gov. Jeb Bush scheduled to follow Monday afternoon
column4: hours before the caucuses start.

column1: The trio of governors has had a light footprint in Iowa
column2: banking instead on strong showings in New Hampshire's Feb. 9 primary to jumpstart their White House bids. Yet some Republican leaders worry that if Trump or Cruz pull off a big victory in Iowa
column3: it would be difficult to slow their momentum.

column1: Unlike in primaries
column2: where voters can cast their ballots throughout the day
column3: the caucuses begin across Iowa at 7 p.m. CST.

column1: Democrats will gather at 1
column2: 100 locations and Republicans at nearly 900 spots.

column1: Turnout was expected to be high. The Iowa Republican Party expected GOP turnout to top the previous record of 120
column2: 000 people in 2012. Democrats also expect a strong turnout
column3: though not nearly as large as the record-setting 240
column4: 000 people who caucused in the 2008 contest between Clinton
column5: Barack Obama and John Edwards.

column1: Iowa has decidedly mixed results in picking the parties' eventual nominees. The past two Republican caucus winners -- former Arkansas Gov. Mike Huckabee and former Pennsylvania Sen. Rick Santorum -- faded as the race stretched on. But Obama's unexpected 2008 victory was instrumental in his path to the nomination
column2: easing the anxieties of those who worried the young black senator would struggle to win white voters.

column1: While both parties caucus on the same night
column2: they do so with different rules.

column1: Republicans vote by private ballot. The state's 30 Republican delegates are awarded proportionally based on the statewide vote.
Democrats take a more interactive approach
column2: with voters forming groups and publicly declaring their support for a candidate. If the number of people in any group is fewer than 15 percent of the total
column3: they can either choose not to participate or can join another viable candidate's group.

column1: Those numbers are awarded proportionately
column2: based on statewide and congressional district voting
column3: as Iowa Democrats determine their 44 delegates to the national convention.

column1: Fox News Channel's Carl Cameron and the Associated Press contributed to this report."	REAL
Iran: Why the best outcome now is to keep negotiating without reaching a deal	"
Another deadline lapsed Thursday in the seemingly endless negotiations over Iran’s nuclear weapons programs.  From Vienna Secretary of State John Kerry warned ""if the tough decisions don’t get made
column2: we are absolutely prepared to call an end to this process.”  That would be a mistake.  We should instead keep negotiating without reaching a deal — it’s the best outcome available now.

column1: Iran’s inability to say yes to several very good deals it has been offered suggests the negotiations may be a satisfactory end in itself for the government of Iran.  They have already achieved some sanctions relief.  They get the stature of being Secretary of State Kerry’s full-time job.  Their regional enemies are publicly feuding with Washington and questioning our commitment to their security.  It’s not a bad outcome for Ayatollah Khameni
column2: especially if he fears the domestic political repercussions of reintegrating with the world.

column1: The agreement being haggled over in Vienna by Iran
column2: Russia
column3: China
column4: Britain
column5: France
column6: Germany
column7: and the United States will not eliminate Iran’s nuclear weapons program.  What is under discussion is how much nuclear infrastructure to let Iran keep
column8: how extensive will be our inspections of what remains
column9: and how much to give them for the privilege.

column1: Inspections are the key to any agreement focused on reducing the threat of Iran’s nuclear weapons programs.  Technically
column2: the agreement is seeking to increase “break out time”: how long it would take Iran using the known equipment and nuclear materials to construct a nuclear bomb.  These negotiations are seeking to increase Iran’s break out time from it’s currently estimated 2-3 months to a year.

column1: It is important to emphasize that we don't honestly know how long it would take Iran to make a nuclear weapon.  Not for lack of effort by our intelligence services
column2: but most of what we do know about Iranian nuclear weapons programs was revealed to us
column3: and there remains much we do not know about past and current Iranian programs.  We should be deeply skeptical that we know the extent of Iran’s nuclear weapons work or have accounted for all its facilities.

column1: The Congress has long been a force for good on Iran policy
column2: erecting sanctions for which the Obama administration now takes credit.

column1: Senators Corker and Cardin have ensured that if there is an agreement in Vienna
column2: the Congress will now have 60 days to review the president’s handiwork
column3: which is something the administration had desperately tried to avoid.

column1: Secretary Kerry published his understanding of the framework for agreement concluded in April; any further concessions will be carefully scrutinized. Many of the arguments made by the White House so far in defense of the agreement will not hold up under careful questioning.
Any agreement reached will ease sanctions on Iran
column2: and Russia will surely never agree to reinstate them
column3: no matter how outrageous Iranian cheating on the deal.  So sanctions will be unrecoverable.  Since much of the Iranian economy is organized to benefit the Revolutionary Guards and citizen militia
column4: they will be the primary beneficiaries of the $100 billion in revenue resulting from lifting just the nuclear weapons related sanctions.

column1: An Iran deal would solve a political problem for President Obama: he committed to prevent Iran acquiring a nuclear weapon yet so very clearly does not want to have to use military force against Iran. A nuclear deal solves his problem as a political matter
column2: but has already created security problems as regional allies hedge against his intentions.

column1: A continuing negotiation not harried by deadlines might vitiate some of the insecurity.  It prevents us lifting sanctions that will be impossible to put back once removed.  It provides exposure we did not have to Iranian leaders and perhaps intelligence on their nuclear infrastructure.  It keeps us aligned with the three European Union states whose sanctions have been an essential constraint on the Iranian government.  It makes more difficult Russian and Chinese support to Iran.  And it leaves us free to conduct espionage of the kind that has prevented Iran from crossing the nuclear threshold so far as we know.
Iran doesn’t appear to have made the fundamental choice to give up its nuclear weapons programs.  Until it does
column2: continuing negotiations is a better outcome than an agreement.

Furious parents slam ‘damaging’ BBC sex change show aimed at six-year-olds	"By wmw_admin on October 31
column2: 2016 Sanchez Manning — Daily Mail Oct 29

column1: The BBC has been accused of acting recklessly after targeting children as young as six with a programme about a schoolboy who takes sex-change drugs.
Parents are angry that the show
column2: available on the CBBC website
column3: features a transgender storyline inappropriate for their children.

column1: And concerned campaigners said it could ‘sow the seeds of confusion’ in young minds. The programme
column2: Just A Girl
column3: depicts an 11-year-old’s struggle to get hormones that stunt puberty
column4: making it easier to have sex-change surgery in the future.

column1: One mother
column2: writing on the Mumsnet website
column3: said her daughter had become worried after seeing the video. She said her girl
column4: who likes wearing boys’ clothes and playing football
column5: had ‘asked me
column6: anxiously
column7: if that means she was a boy’.

column1: Tory MP Peter Bone said: ‘It beggars belief that the BBC is making this programme freely available to children as young as six. I entirely share the anger of parents who just want to let children be children.
‘It is completely inappropriate for such material to be on the CBBC website and I shall be writing to BBC bosses to demand they take it down as soon as possible.’
Former Culture Secretary Maria Miller voiced her concerns over the BBC tackling the subject in ‘an age-appropriate way’
column2: saying such issues should be raised ‘where children can have support from parents’.

column1: And Tory MP Julian Brazier said: ‘This programme is very disappointing and inappropriate. Children are very impressionable and this is going to confuse and worry them.’

Family campaigner Norman Wells said: ‘It is irresponsible of the BBC to introduce impressionable children as young as six to the idea that they can choose to be something other than their biological sex.’
Just A Girl is the fictional video diary of a child who calls herself ‘Amy’ and dresses as a girl. It is hosted on the CBBC website
column2: aimed at children aged between six and 12.

column1: In the half-hour programme
column2: Amy – played by an actress – reveals she was born a boy called Ben but has already started using puberty-halting drugs.

column1: Such hypothalamic blockers provoked a furore two years ago when The Mail on Sunday revealed an NHS clinic was willing to give them to children as young as nine.
Critics cited research claiming that most teenagers confused about their gender never go through with surgery
column2: with many realising they are gay. The BBC row comes amid growing controversy over gender issues
column3: fuelled by a number of high-profile cases. In one
column4: a Christian couple were threatened with having their 14-year-old daughter taken away because they oppose her plans to become a boy.

column1: In another
column2: a seven-year-old boy was ordered to be removed from his mother’s care as ‘she was raising him as female’
column3: causing him ‘a great deal of emotional harm’.

column1: In Just A Girl
column2: Amy says: ‘When I was born
column3: Mum said Dad was so pleased that he had a boy to take to the football. But Mum knew I was different. She realised early on that I was born in the wrong body.’

column1: She adds: ‘My Mum supported me when I did a PowerPoint presentation to my class about transitioning and that I wasn’t going to come to school in boys’ clothes any more
column2: but girls’ clothes. I wasn’t Ben
column3: I was Amy.’

column1: Later Amy is shown telling a friend
column2: Josh – a boy who wants to be recognised as a girl – that she is on hormone blockers
column3: saying it took ‘ages’ to get them after ‘loads of tests and talks at the clinic’. ‘Once they realised I was trans for real
column4: [I] got them
column5: ’ she says. In another entry
column6: Amy tells viewers she has developed a crush on a boy called Liam
column7: but confides: ‘Liam thinks I’m just a girl
column8: but I’m not. I’m trans. And what’s he going to say if he finds out? Stop being my friend? Why? I’m still me
column9: aren’t I?’

column1: Child psychotherapist Dr Dilys Daws said the programme could confuse children. She said that
column2: while it was natural for youngsters to wonder what it would be like to be the opposite sex
column3: the BBC was irresponsible to feature the ‘extreme’ step of gender change for six-year-olds because they were too young to grapple with such issues.

column1: The programme generated hundreds of comments on Mumsnet.
One mother
column2: who said her seven-year-old had watched the show
column3: asked: ‘Am I being unreasonable to think this is an inappropriate topic for a young age group?’

column1: Another replied: ‘Don’t think this is remotely suitable for a seven-year-old. To start suggesting that children can be transgender when they’re far too young to actually have a gender is reckless and damaging. A small boy who is told that he can become a girl may take this as meaning that sex changes are possible
column2: that sometime in the future he’ll wake up with a girl’s body.’

column1: Another user added: ‘I don’t think hormone therapy should be normalised any more than 12-year-olds drinking or doing recreational drugs should be normalised.’
Other critics slammed the BBC. Mr Wells
column2: director of the Family Education Trust
column3: said: ‘The more we promote the idea that a boy can be born into a girl’s body and a girl can be born into a boy’s body
column4: and that drugs and surgery can put things right
column5: the more children will become utterly confused. Respecting and preserving a child’s birth sex should be seen as a child protection issue.’

column1: But some parents on Mumsnet were more positive. One wrote: ‘I don’t believe there is “too young” for stuff like this. The earlier you teach your children that everyone is different and that nobody is “normal” the better.’
Dr Polly Carmichael
column2: a clinical psychologist specialising in transgender children
column3: said: ‘Raising awareness of these issues is the best way to challenge stigma and discrimination associated with identity issues. Programmes like Just A Girl can contribute to a healthy and informed public discussion.’

column1: The BBC said: ‘Just A Girl is about a fictional transgender character trying to make sense of the world
column2: deal with bullying and work out how to keep her friends
column3: which are universal themes that many children relate to
column4: and which has had a positive response from our audience.

column1: ‘CBBC aims to reflect true life
column2: providing content that mirrors the lives of as many UK children as possible.’"	FAKE

column1: Nurse Chris Christie Quarantined For Ebola Goes After Governor On Vaccines	"New Jersey Gov. Chris Christie (R) came out as a vaccine choicer Tuesday
column2: saying it should be up to parents to decide whether to inoculate their children against deadly diseases that could infect the rest of the population.

column1: His stance was looser than the one he took last year against Kaci Hickox
column2: the nurse Christie forcibly quarantined over Ebola fears when she returned to the United States after helping patients in West Africa. There was never any evidence that Hickox had symptoms of Ebola
column3: a far less contagious disease than the measles
column4: which is currently spreading across the country due to parents who refuse to vaccinate their children.

column1: On Monday night
column2: Hickox went on ""All In with Chris Hayes"" on MSNBC and blasted Christie for his vaccination comments.

column1: I think this is a good example of Gov. Christie making some very ill-informed statements. We heard it a lot during the Ebola discussion
column2: and now it seems to have happened again

column1: We know that vaccines are safe
column2: and we know that vaccines save lives
column3: she said. ""I have worked in a measles outbreak in northern Nigeria before. We were seeing about 2
column4: 000 children a week with measles. It is a scary disease. I know that these families of these 100 people who have the disease now could tell you a little bit about what the disease looks like and how much misery it causes. After the vaccine was implemented in 1963
column5: there was a large reduction in cases
column6: about 98 percent. And I believe it was 1989 to '91
column7: there was a resurgence. ... The stakes are high. We have to protect our most vulnerable populations.""

column1: Christie made his controversial vaccination comments to reporters during his three-day trip to London
column2: as he weighs whether to jump in the 2016 presidential field. Christie said he and his wife had vaccinated their children but understood ""that parents need to have some measure of choice in things as well
column3: so that’s the balance that the government has to decide.""

column4: which is why he was calling for balance in which ones government should mandate."""	REAL

column1: Can Paul Ryan and Donald Trump coexist within the Republican Party?	"House Speaker Paul D. Ryan attempted to lift the horizons of his party with a speech last week in which he called for a competition of ideas rather than insults
column2: and constructive political debate rather than the politics of demonization.

column1: Ryan’s speech was aimed at pulling the Republican Party away from Donald Trump’s embrace — though he never actually mentioned Trump by name. Events quickly showed what he is up against. The speaker was quickly drowned out by a snarling argument between Trump and Sen. Ted Cruz of Texas over their wives that almost eclipsed the terrorist attacks in Brussels in the U.S. media.
By week’s end
column2: the Republican race had gone into the gutter over tabloid charges of infidelity
column3: which the senator vehemently denied and for which he blamed the New York billionaire
column4: who called it unfounded. A race that seemed already at the bottom managed to find another low.

column1: Ryan’s speech was a relatively high-minded moment in the middle of this mud fight of a Republican nominating contest. His effort to rescue the party from a coming crisis is laudable
column2: but the root causes of the condition go far beyond Trump.

column1: The front-runner for the nomination of the Republican Party is as much a reflection of the condition as a cause
column2: a reality that Ryan (R-Wis.) touched on only lightly in calling for a more positive and uplifting approach to politics by all sides. Which means stopping Trump alone won’t necessarily solve all of the party’s problems.

column1: Four years ago
column2: scholars Thomas Mann
column3: then with the Brookings Institution
column4: and Norman Ornstein
column5: then and now with the American Enterprise Institute
column6: published a book examining the breakdown in American politics. It was titled “It’s Even Worse Than It Looks.”

column1: The authors took aim at the gridlocked and dysfunctional politics of Washington and the broader issue of political polarization that has become endemic in recent years. They were unsparing but not even-handed in their critique. They were ahead of others in describing the underlying causes of polarization as asymmetrical
column2: with the Republican Party — in particular its most hard-line faction — as deserving of far more of the blame for the breakdown in governing.

column1: Mann and Ornstein are back again with a second and updated paperback edition
column2: called “It’s Even Worse Than It Was.” The paperback arrives in the middle of the most raucous presidential campaign in memory
column3: one that has exposed even more the fissures
column4: fractures and divisions within the Republican Party coalition.

column1: What played out primarily in the party’s congressional wing has come to consume the presidential nominating contest. In their own ways
column2: Trump and Cruz have brought to the surface the economic and cultural anger among many of those in the party’s base as well as the distrust of the party leadership — the same motivating forces behind the Freedom Caucus rebels in the House Republican conference.

column1: The current campaign only adds fuel to the Mann-Ornstein thesis of a Republican Party at war with itself in ways that have helped cripple the governing process. Trump and Cruz reflect the yearning within the Republican base for anti-establishment outsiders to topple the insiders in Washington.
Ohio Gov. John Kasich
column2: the third remaining candidate for the nomination
column3: is a dissenting voice
column4: calling for cooperation and compromise. At this point
column5: he is not just a dissenting voice; he is a minority voice in the presidential competition
column6: unless he can start winning more primaries.

column1: Trump and Ryan represent bookends in a political debate that has considerable consequences for the Republican Party and for the country. Trump’s position as front-runner not only highlights the degree to which the party is being taken over by anti-establishment forces but also foreshadows the possibility of a significant defeat in November if
column2: as the GOP nominee
column3: Trump is unable to reverse his standing among women
column4: Hispanics
column5: African Americans and other voting groups.

column1: Ryan represents something far different
column2: politics grounded in ideas and policies and an attitude of goodwill toward the opposition that he inherited from his mentor
column3: Jack Kemp
column4: the former House member from Buffalo who prodded his party to be more open and inclusive.

column1: Yet Ryan’s speech left unanswered key questions about his capacity to change the behavior of his party’s conference in the House and in particular the degree to which he is willing to find a governing coalition apart from the hard-liners in the Freedom Caucus.
As the country’s highest-ranking Republican elected official
column2: Ryan symbolizes the establishment’s backlash to Trump’s candidacy
column3: a backlash that has so far failed to stop the New York businessman’s march to the nomination. The resistance might yet succeed. Whether it does or doesn’t
column4: it raises the question of whether this presidential campaign ultimately will produce a true course change for the party or merely end up intensifying the forces that have brought it to this moment.

column1: I put that question to Ornstein in an email exchange Friday: “This really is
column2: I believe
column3: an existential crisis for the Republican Party
column4: ” he wrote. “Will it be a Ryan-style conservative
column5: problem-solving party
column6: or will it be either a Trump-style
column7: authoritarian
column8: nativist and protectionist party
column9: or a Cruz-style radical anti-government party content with blowing things up as they now stand? Or
column10: just as possible
column11: will the party break apart
column12: with no clue as to what will replace it or how the pieces will fit into the broader political system?”

column1: The prospects for a crackup are real
column2: given what Trump’s candidacy has revealed about the party’s fractured coalition. Trump’s views on issues
column3: outlined on the campaign trail and in a recent interview with The Washington Post editorial board
column4: represent a fundamental break with many of the conservative ideas that have been at the party’s core for years.

column1: Trump’s constituency finds his support for protecting rather than transforming Social Security and Medicare appealing. His words of praise for the work of Planned Parenthood
column2: apart from performing abortions
column3: are anathema to many religious conservatives. His views on trade run counter to the free-trade philosophy of the GOP elites. His comments about reevaluating the U.S. role in NATO shocked many in the Republican foreign-policy establishment.

column1: That’s the threat Ryan and others in the party see as they watch the nominating contest move into the next rounds of primaries. But it isn’t clear that what the speaker advocated in his speech would be enough to put the Republican Party in a better place
column2: even absent Trump. House Republicans are still an unruly group and
column3: with some exceptions
column4: the GOP still prefers to try to do business with itself.

column1: The Republican Party remains a party of protest. It continues to struggle to demonstrate that
column2: on the national level
column3: it can be a true governing party."	REAL

column1: The Rise of Mandatory Vaccinations Means the End of Medical Freedom	"The Rise of Mandatory Vaccinations Means the End of Medical Freedom   Source: The Antimedia
Mandatory vaccinations are about to open up a new frontier for government control. Through the war on drugs
column2: bureaucrats arbitrarily dictate what people can and can’t put into their bodies
column3: but that violation pales in comparison to forcibly medicating millions against their will. Voluntary and informed consent are essential in securing individual rights
column4: and without it
column5: self-ownership will never be respected.

column1: The liberal stronghold of California is trailblazing the encroaching new practice and recently passed laws mandating that children and adults must have certain immunizations before being able to attend schools or work in certain professions. The longstanding religious and philosophical exemptions that protect freedom of choice have been systematically crushed by the state.
California’s Senate Bill 277 went into effect on July 1st
column3: and marked the most rigid requirements ever instituted for vaccinations. The law forces students to endure a total of 40 doses to complete the 10 federally recommended vaccines while allowing more to be added at any time. Any family that doesn’t go along will have their child barred from attending licensed day care facilities
column4: in-home daycares
column5: public or private schools
column6: and even after school programs.

column1: Over the years
column2: California has developed a reputation for pushing vaccines on their youth. Assembly Bill 499 was passed in 2011 and lowered the age of consent for STD prevention vaccines to just 12 years old. Included in the assortment of shots being administered was the infamous Gardasil
column3: which just a few years later was at the center of a lawsuit that yielded the victims a $6 million settlement from the U.S. government
column4: which paid out funds from the National Vaccine Injury Compensation Program .

column1: The Vaccinate All Children Act of 2015 is an attempt to implement this new standard nationwide
column2: and although it has stalled in the House
column3: it will likely be reintroduced the next time the country is gripped by the fear of a pandemic.

column1: The debate surrounding vaccinations is commonly framed as a moral struggle between the benefits to the collective and the selfish preferences of the individual. But since the outbreak scares of Zika
column2: measles
column3: and ebola
column4: the rhetoric has taken a turn toward authoritarianism.

column1: It’s commonly stated by the CDC and most mainstream doctors that the unvaccinated are putting the health of everyone else at risk
column2: but the truth isn’t so black and white . The herd immunity theory has been consistently used to validate the expansion of vaccine programs
column3: but it still doesn’t justify the removal of choice from the individual.

column1: The classic exchange of freedom for perceived safety is a no brainer for the millions of Americans who are willing to use government to strap their neighbors down and forcibly inject them for the greater good. Anyone who expresses concern about possible side effects is immediately branded as conspiratorial or anti-science. Yet controversial claims that certain vaccine variants cause neurological disorders like autism have led some people to swear off inoculations altogether. This all-or-nothing dynamic has completely polarized the issue and prevents any reasonable discussion from taking place. Either you accept all of the CDC’s recommended 69 doses of 16 vaccines between birth and age 18
column2: or you want to bring back measles
column3: polio
column4: and probably the black plague.

column1: On the other extreme side of the debate
column2: if you fail to acknowledge all vaccines as dangerous
column3: you’re an ignorant sheep. Through the internet
column4: disinformation has become widespread and created a movement of people that have written off all the benefits accomplished through immunizations. These individuals are unable or unwilling to separate the science from the shady institutions that develop and distribute new vaccines. Even if thimerosal and mercury based preservatives cause adverse reactions in some patients
column5: it doesn’t detract from the advantages vaccine technology provides. In this debate
column6: like most others in the US
column7: both sides are swept up in emotion and ignorance.

column1: Regardless
column2: the public’s trust in vaccinations has been eroded by the reputations of those companies producing them. Pharmaceutical giants like Merck and Pfizer make billions from the distribution of these shots
column3: and the potential profits after a mandate are enough to corrupt the morals of almost anyone. In one example
column4: former CDC director Dr. Julie Gerberding left her post at the government agency in 2009 to work in Merck’s vaccine division. An investigative report published by the British Medical Journal last year found the CDC downplays its ties to the pharmaceutical industry.

column1: Further
column2: by buying the support of politicians like Hillary Clinton — who received more donations from pharmaceutical companies and their employees than any other candidate this year — these huge companies are able to expand their influence in directing government policy .

column1: Maintaining control over what we put into our own bodies is a fundamental right
column2: but for now
column3: standing up to these government decrees only means ostracism from the education system and criticism from peers. In the future
column4: however
column5: the punishments for disobedience will likely only grow stricter.

column1: An Orange County doctor named Bob Sears is already in the crosshairs of California’s medical board after excusing a two-year-old from future vaccinations. The mother expressed concern that her daughter had an adverse reaction to a previous shot
column2: describing the child as becoming limp “like a ragdoll” for 24 hours after the last dose. Dr. Sears’ alternative treatment recommendations break from the rules dictated by S.B. 277
column3: and now his reputation
column4: as well as his career
column5: are in jeopardy. This new authority to strip doctors of their medical licenses for simply going against the state-imposed standards opens the door for the persecution of medical professionals who resist any government regulation.

column1: A vaccination is an invasive medical procedure that can have different effects on each and every individual. The Nuremberg Code’s first principle is voluntary consent
column2: but it seems the lessons of history have been completely forgotten by today’s leaders. The transition of these shots from “recommended” to “required” is well underway
column3: and those who think the ends justify the means are willing to forcibly make sure everyone else complies.

column1: The new benchmark set by California symbolizes a precedent that could be mimicked across the nation. Without having the discretion to choose which medications are injected into your body — or your child’s — how can anyone convince themselves they are free? This overreach and collusion can often be dismissed as a trivial issue
column2: but the fact that voluntary consent is under attack speaks volumes to the extent that state power has metastasized."	FAKE

column1: Scientists Fascinated By Lake Under The Sea: Those Who Enter Never Come Out [Watch]	"This underwater lake is actually helping scientists deal with a much bigger mystery. Credit: EVNautilus
It may seem impossible
column2: but scientists have discovered what can only be deemed as a lake under the sea. Dubbed the “Jacuzzi of Despair
column3: ” the brine-filled pool is deadly for the majority of creatures that dare enter it but is proving to be highly informational for those that are studying it.

column1: Located in the Gulf of Mexico
column2: the lake rises about 12 feet off of the ocean floor and is four to five times saltier than the surrounding ocean. It’s also twice as warm
column3: rich with methane
column4: which is what makes it bubble like a jacuzzi
column5: and is dense with hydrogen sulfide. This makes it incompatible with the sea water and a completely separate entity.

column1: Dr. Erik Cordes
column2: associate professor of biology at Temple University in Philadelphia who discovered the pool with several colleagues
column3: told Seeker

column1: “It was one of the most amazing things in the deep sea. You go down into the bottom of the ocean and you are looking at a lake or a river flowing. It feels like you are not on this world.”
Since the conditions of the pool are so foreign to humans and most of the creatures living under the sea
column2: it’s allowing scientists to get a glimpse of what life might be like in extreme circumstances. What started as an interesting lake in the middle of the ocean has now become the heart of experimentation for one of the most mysterious subjects known to man: space. Dr. Cordes said

column1: “There’s a lot of people looking at these extreme habitats on Earth as models for what we might discover when we go to other planets.The technology development in the deep sea is definitely going to be applied to the worlds beyond our own.”
What makes the pool even more unique is that it has a lively ecosystem that has evolved throughout the centuries to include more species. While larger animals
column2: such as deep-sea crabs
column3: die as soon as they enter the pool
column4: other creatures have adapted to the atmosphere of the water and even thrive on it. Giant mussels formed symbiotic bacteria in their gills to feed off of the hydrogen sulfide and methane gas from the pool and specially adapted shrimp and tube worms were able to survive the harsh conditions. Any other animals that entered were immediately killed
column5: pickled by the salt
column6: and preserved forever.

column1: Watch the video below to see the beautiful lake for yourself and the creatures who did and did not survive the conditions.

column1: Our real police/race problem: Diverse forces, white resentment, and America’s persistent divides	"Yet the problems do remain “black and white” for reasons of economic exploitation and isolation that run deeper than race itself and that are gathering force
column2: despite rising numbers of white/Asian and white/Hispanic marriages and of multiracial children
column3: even in the families of police officers themselves. Unless we can face the reasons why more “diversity” in police ranks is a far-from-sufficient condition of justice
column4: American society will remain more racist than many others
column5: and thereby hangs my tale.

column1: Shortly before Christmas 1996 in the lower-middle-class Queens neighborhood of East Elmhurst
column2: robbers killed Officer Davis as he tried to protect Ira Epstein
column3: the white owner of a check-cashing store where Davis was moonlighting as a security guard to earn extra money to buy holiday gifts for his 6-year-old daughter
column4: Arielle.

column1: Because Davis was off-duty at the time
column2: it’s unclear if his assailants knew that he was a police officer. But because he was one and was murdered for doing what police officers do
column3: his Episcopal funeral Mass in Garden City
column4: Long Island
column5: was a familiar “tableau of pomp and grief
column6: ” as the New York Times put it
column7: with thousands of saluting
column8: white-gloved
column9: white-ethnic officers and a flyover by police helicopters.

column1: “Arielle
column2: your daddy
column3: who loved you
column4: who adored you…will always be a hero of New York City
column5: ” Mayor Rudolph Giuliani told Davis’ daughter from the church pulpit. He asked the congregation to give Arielle something she would remember
column6: and all present responded with a long
column7: wrenching ovation. Noting that Ira Epstein’s widow had called Davis a role model for the city’s youth
column8: Giuliani said
column9: “She was right
column10: ” adding that
column11: “When [Davis] died Saturday morning he was doing what he was trained to do – he was trying to protect another man.”

column1: Many funerals of New York City police officers killed in action have been tableaus not only of pomp and grief but of the chasm that yawns between an “occupying army” of mostly white-ethnic officers and an “underclass” of inner-city
column2: black and Hispanic men. I spent enough time there in the late 1970s to have wished that the sea of blue around Davis’ funeral — and now those of officers Ramos and Liu — would signify something better than a chasm.

column1: But does it? Or have the examples set by Davis
column2: Liu and Ramos on police forces given the rest of us excuses to rationalize the continuing
column3: calculated
column4: heavily policed and seemingly bottomless isolation of millions of black and Hispanic men and women? Are economic isolation and social stigmatization still driving some of the isolated — and those who police them — so crazy that it’s a wonder there aren’t even more police killers like those who killed Davis
column5: Liu and Ramos?

column1: Ramos and Wu’s killer
column2: Ismaaiyl Brinsley
column3: was a perversely politicized
column4: vengeance-crazed black man. Even the slaying in Ferguson of an unarmed black man
column5: Michael Brown
column6: by white officer Darren Wilson has a symbolic but no less telling opposite (Wilson’s nightmare) in another Ferguson – Colin Ferguson
column7: a perversely politicized
column8: vengeance-crazed black man who
column9: shortly before Christmas
column11: boarded a suburban Long Island commuter train and shot 23 white passengers
column12: killing six.

column1: Although he killed no cops
column2: many New York officers live on Long Island
column3: whose suburban towns their parents or grandparents chose over New York City’s tenements and row homes in the 1960s while seeking greener pastures in the booming
column4: postwar economy and insulation from racially changing inner-city neighborhoods and rising black crime. As Newsday’s Jimmy Breslin put it a day after Ferguson’s train massacre: “Last night
column5: Brooklyn followed them home.”

column1: Are these officers and prosecutors to blame for provoking their killers’ isolation and rage? Or are they really doing only what our democracy seemingly wants and expects them to do: keep the lid on blacks and Hispanics who are cheated and sidelined
column2: as the rest of us look the other way and disclaim responsibility – an evasion that seems easier to some whenever a Brinsley or a Colin Ferguson explodes?

column1: In a strange irony
column2: Charles Davis probably reinforced white innocence because he was a generous cop
column3: popular with other officers and with residents of the Queens neighborhood where he supervised youth basketball games and a club for kids who might want to join the NYPD. His large presence
column4: sharp eye and caring strengthened the community policing that had helped to cut New York City’s murder rate in half in less than five years
column5: to below 1
column6: 000 for the first time in three decades. (By 2013
column7: that number would plummet to just over 300
column8: and this year it may be even lower
column9: notwithstanding predictable predictions of doom 11 months ago by Rupert Murdoch’s New York Post and the Patrolmen’s Benevolent Association that Mayor Bill De Blasio’s curbing of excessive NYPD “stop and frisk” practices would unleash mayhem.)

column1: But if Davis’ blue uniform and the blue sea at his funeral signified something better than black-versus-white
column2: that equation took a perverse turn as Queens District Attorney Richard Brown orchestrated the indictment of 19-year-old George Bell
column3: a stock boy at Old Navy who lived with his mother and had no criminal background
column4: and two other black men
column5: as Davis’ killers. A recent Nation magazine review of the case by Hannah Riley
column6: a former researcher at the Innocence Project and a student of criminology at the University of Cambridge
column7: raises serious doubts that the men convicted and still in prison for killing Davis were really his murderers.

column1: D.A. Brown’s zeal in convicting them may have been fortified by the fact that Davis’ wife had been an assistant district attorney
column2: albeit in another jurisdiction. But all prosecutors who face high-profile
column3: highly charged cases have other
column4: more-powerful incentives to “resolve” them irresponsibly. New Yorkers would be reminded of that in 2002
column5: when the four black men and one Hispanic man who’d been convicted and imprisoned in 1989 amid public outrage over the infamous assault and rape of the Central Park Jogger were released after years of unjustified incarceration after the real assailant confessed.

column1: Such things happen partly because D.A.s win reelection by pandering to angry
column2: frightened voters’ hunger for revenge and because police officers are literally the prosecutors’ comrades in arms and their witnesses before grand juries and in open trials. (The over-zealous assistant prosecutors and detectives complicit in both the Central Park jogger and Davis cases were women
column3: by the way.) But Hannah Riley has found a would-be whistle-blower in retired NYPD detective Pete Fiorillo
column4: who had been pleased at first to see Giuliani touting the work of other detectives in the case and who’d had
column5: as he put it
column6: “no intention of looking at it for the purpose of taking it apart.”

column1: “But the more he learned
column2: ” Riley explains
column3: “the more his doubts grew until he became convinced that the investigation and trial were irredeemably flawed. ‘This case represents a total breakdown of the criminal justice system from the bottom to the top: the police that investigated this case; the DA that prosecuted the case; the judge that tried all three cases
column4: ’ said Fiorillo. ‘They just didn’t have the courage to do the right thing.’”

column1: Giuliani
column2: himself an infamously zealous former prosecutor
column3: told the public after Davis’ murder that
column4: “If you shoot and kill a New York City police officer
column5: the Police Department is going to catch you
column6: they’re going to find you
column7: usually in a short period of time
column8: and then at a minimum you’re going to spend the rest of your life in jail. And in this particular situation
column9: it’s quite possible you’ll get executed.”

column1: The word “execution” had a dark double-entendre here
column2: giving the “blue over black” equation another perverse twist: Prosecutorial railroading involves not only beguiling or coercing helpless and apparently hopeless young black and Hispanic men into confessions and eventual convictions
column3: and not just complicity by grand juries whose secrecy sanitizes such orchestrations. It also involves finding excuses for officers who are spared indictment time and again — even after summarily executing unarmed and even unresisting black and Hispanic men and
column4: in some cases
column5: women.

column1: Like most New Yorkers watching the Central Park and Davis cases
column2: I was inclined to trust prosecutors and to assume the justice of the convictions. When reporters on the Davis murder were told that the 19-year-old Bell had been heard humming the song
column3: “Have Yourself a Very Merry Christmas” during a break in the questioning at the 109th Precinct and that remorse seemed never to enter his mind
column4: I assumed that he was yet another half-crazed casualty of inner-city isolation
column5: the kind of casualty I’d encountered more than once.

column1: In the late 1970s I ran a weekly newspaper serving poor neighborhoods just across Brooklyn’s Broadway and Flushing Avenue from Bedford-Stuyvesant
column2: where Officers Ramos and Liu were killed; I made more than a few visits to the Tompkins Houses along Myrtle Avenue
column3: outside of which the murders occurred
column4: and to Woodhull Hospital
column5: where they were brought with Brinsley
column6: who committed suicide nearby. Just to the northeast lay Bushwick
column7: a once-tidy
column8: German and Italian white-ethnic neighborhood that had become mostly Hispanic and black in the 1960s in ways and for reasons I knew intimately and that I portray in my book “The Closest of Strangers
column9: ” two of whose chapters chronicle North Brooklyn’s ravaging by absentee landlords’ “block-busting” welfare-subsidy scams
column10: rampant arson for profit and for revenge
column11: and massive looting during a huge 1977 power blackout.

column1: On two occasions I navigated the devastation all night with officers of Bushwick’s 83rd Precinct
column2: accompanying them into scenes of domestic violence where terrified toddlers sucking on teething rings crawled across shattered plates and splattered dinners to hide behind sofas as their mothers told us why they’d called 911 out of desperation and sometimes for revenge. Sometimes the man was still there
column3: and officers had to take him outside. Out on the street in the noisy
column4: sulfurous darkness
column5: a black-Hispanic youth sauntered up to the patrol car’s open window and taunted one of my hosts by asking
column6: “You Officer Torsney? Gonna shoot me?” — referring to Robert Torsney
column7: who on Thanksgiving Day in 1976
column8: for no apparent reason
column9: had fired a bullet into the head of Randolph Evans
column11: a ninth grader at Franklin K. Lane High School
column12: outside the Cypress Hills housing project
column13: near where Officer Rafael Ramos was buried last Saturday. As New York Times columnist Bob Herbert noted years later
column14: “Torsney would later claim he had been afflicted with a rare form of epilepsy that
column15: remarkably
column16: had never been noticed before the killing and was never seen after it. The ‘epilepsy’ defense worked. Officer Torsney was acquitted of any wrongdoing.” Herbert’s column
column17: “The Sickness in the NYPD
column18: ” is worth reading
column19: if only for the experience of rubbing your eyes in disbelief. Another of its offerings: “One April morning in 1973 a veteran police officer named Thomas Shea pulled his service revolver and blew away a young black boy on a street in Jamaica
column20: Queens. He shot the kid in the back. There was no chance of survival. Afterward
column21: no one could figure out why the officer had done it. There was no reason for the shooting
column22: no threat to Officer Shea of any kind. The boy’s name was Clifford Glover and he was 10 years old. Officer Shea was charged with murder but of course he was acquitted.” For every young man whom killers in uniform execute as unambiguously as they did Randy Evans
column23: Clifford Glover
column24: Eric Garner and many others without being indicted for it
column25: still more essentially hapless
column26: helpless people are packed off into the vast archipelago of incarceration that employs thousands of “corrections” officers. Either way
column27: for the rest of us
column28: it’s out of sight
column29: out of mind
column30: as were the hundreds of homeless people and derelicts about whom few New Yorkers asked when they disappeared from Manhattan’s streets during Giuliani’s mayoralty. If at the bottom of it all is the calculated isolation and impoverishment of blacks and Hispanics that I chronicled while climbing stairwells in Brooklyn’s Bushwick-Hylan and Borinquen Plaza housing projects to distribute our paper
column31: next to that bottom are the cops we assign to keep the lid on it. Is it a wonder that they sometimes say that they feel like “garbage collectors” and that
column32: when the “garbage” call them something worse
column33: some of them explode? In the 1960s
column34: insouciant
column35: pseudo-insurgent
column36: middle-class white youths called cops “pigs.” A police union took out an ad saying
column37: “Next time you really need help
column38: try calling a pig.” But
column40: spectacular exceptions like the Brinks armored car robbery
column41: the worst thing that white kids did to cops in those days was call them names. Is it really surprising that some cops and corrections officers feel as trapped in neighborhoods like Bushwick as the people they’re charged with containing? Is it surprising that some of the young white men who are drawn to such work grew up marinating what I described here three weeks ago as ressentiment
column42: the social pathology of a society that has begun to countenance torture abroad and the militarization of police at home against a decadent
column43: demoralized populace that has come to include themselves? Or that
column44: at the funeral of Rafael Ramos
column45: stunted citizens like these would turn their backs on the chief executive of the democracy that employs them
column46: and that they would thereby dishonor the fallen officer and flout civilian leadership of the police and the military as if they would prefer a police state? The surprise is that so many police officers are still as good as Davis and as the relatives of Salon’s own Joan Walsh
column47: as she recounted here vividly this week and in her book “What’s the Matter With White People?” I
column49: can testify that there are many officers
column51: as generous and effective as Charles Davis. In the mid-1990s
column56: introduced me to other impressive colleagues while I was a columnist for the New York Daily News
column57: a paper many cops read while sitting in their patrol cars. The officers I met were better
column58: more proactive citizen-leaders than moralists who simply cluck their tongues at them. On the other hand
column59: whenever I wrote columns like this one praising their reform efforts
column60: I got some unexpected visits from the New York Fire Department
column61: whose firefighters banged loudly on my door at 3 a.m. because someone had called in a false alarm a day or two after the column ran. Soon after the chokehold killing of Eric Garner
column62: but before the assassinations of Liu and Ramos
column63: another retired police officer sent me this video
column64: distributed by anonymous officers who seem to be preparing for race war
column65: that depicts black men maiming and murdering cops in realistic street scenes. Some of the scenes look staged
column66: but if Brinsley’s real deed had been filmed it would have fit perfectly into this alarmist
column67: racist montage. The officer who shared it with me calls it “almost a counter-training device. Its message is
column68: ‘Never mind what we are about to tell you the law says; here is what you are up against at any moment.’ After seeing it
column69: I can better understand that young Housing Division Officer opening stairwell doors with his gun in his hand [and
column72: innocent 28-year-old black man two floors below him]. I’m wondering if he saw the video or something like it.’” (Before calling 911 to aid the man he’d shot
column73: the housing officer called his union.) Officers’ testimony in cases like this and Eric Garner’s and Randy Evans’ and Clifford Glover’s and the rest is almost transparently scripted by the union. Another irony. Even as the rogue video and the real deeds of Brinsley and Colin Ferguson alarm us
column74: and even as some officers’ turning their backs on the mayor at a funeral and a police graduation ceremony disgust us
column75: many black leaders have been ascending a far-better learning curve from the demagoguery of the 1980s and ‘90s to more sophisticated
column76: humane strategizing. Where now are the Louis Farrakhans
column77: the Vernon Masons and Alton Maddoxes (lawyers of Tawana Brawley infamy) and the Johnnie Cochrans
column78: whose verbal threats and courtroom tactics sent chills down whites’ spines? Al Sharpton
column79: whom I knew well in those years and described here in November
column80: has climbed that learning curve: He said that the Ferguson
column82: protest movement “was not about Darren Wilson’s job. It was about Michael Brown’s justice…. We are not anti-police. If our children are wrong
column83: arrest them. Don’t empty your gun and act like you had no other way.” Sharpton also led Eric Garner’s family in protesting Brinsley’s deed and mourning the deaths of officers Ramos and Liu. Sharpton is a flawed leader
column84: but efforts by Fox News’ flunkies to blame him and recent protesters for bad relations with police prove only that black leadership’s learning curve has been offset by some white male degeneration along the lines I sketched here. The glorious funerals given officers Davis
column85: Liu and Ramos don’t dispel these white men’s growing bewilderment
column87: less of it generated by black men than by economic and cultural riptides that would still dispossess and disorient many of them even if the U.S. were white from coast to coast. To overcome racism
column88: we’ll have to reach past “black and white” story lines and find strategies that free the oppressed by freeing the oppressor. Police are trapped in the swamp I navigated in Brooklyn because all of us are trapped in a political economy that’s no longer legitimate or sustainable. Unless we confront what Joan Walsh is telling us has happened to the white working  and middle classes
column89: and what AlterNet editor Don Hazen
column90: economist James Galbraith and historian Eli Zaretsky are trying to tell us about the real roots of America’s white male problem
column91: “black and white” explanations will fall short
column92: on both sides of an enduring race line that leads us nowhere."	REAL

column1: The Supreme Court cannot hide on Obamacare	"The Supreme Court
column2: it would seem
column3: did not want you to see what it was up to on Wednesday.

column1: The robed nine were hearing oral arguments in King v. Burwell
column2: a legal effort by conservatives to dismantle Obamacare and probably the most politically charged case to appear before the high court since Bush v. Gore. But
column3: as always
column4: there was no video of the proceedings and
column5: curiously
column6: the court chose not to release same-day audio of the argument
column7: as it did in Bush v. Gore and has done in other high-profile cases since then.

column1: I went to the argument
column2: as I have for the last decade
column3: to attempt to paint for readers a verbal picture of the atmospherics in the room
column4: such as Samuel Alito’s eye rolls
column5: Sonia Sotomayor’s hectoring and Clarence Thomas’s states of repose. But this time
column6: court staff placed me in the back corner
column7: three feet from the door; blocking my view of the justices were two red-velvet curtains
column8: a marble pillar
column9: another marble pillar
column10: and a closed brass gate carved with images of acorns
column11: oak leaves
column12: dolphins
column13: helmets and plumes
column14: animal heads and the Ten Commandments.

column1: Ultimately
column2: though
column3: there will be no hiding what happened in that chamber Wednesday morning. Ninety minutes of lopsided argument in favor of the Obama administration’s defense cast significant doubt on what had been a plausible challenge to Obamacare’s legality. The conservative majority could still knock down the law
column4: of course
column5: but given the ambiguity exposed Wednesday
column6: it would now be a breathtaking surprise for the justices to cause such massive upheaval — taking health-care immediately from 8 million and causing a death spiral for the rest of Obamacare — based on such a slender legal reed.

column1: The four liberal justices furiously picked apart the arguments of Michael Carvin
column2: who had also argued
column3: unsuccessfully
column4: in a 2012 challenge to the health-care law. Alito and Antonin Scalia were not as aggressive as usual in their questioning of the Obama administration’s lawyer
column5: and Chief Justice John Roberts was almost as silent as Thomas. Anthony Kennedy
column6: perpetual swing vote
column7: had some serious doubts about the argument against Obamacare.

column1: Kennedy said that while “perhaps you will prevail in the plain words of the statute
column2: there’s a serious constitutional problem if we adopt your argument
column3: ” along with a violation of federalism
column4: because states would be coerced to embrace Obamacare exchanges or enter an insurance “death spiral
column5: ” he said.

column1: “Sometimes we think of things the government doesn’t
column2: ” Kennedy informed him.

column1: At issue: whether the language in the Affordable Care Act calling for each state to establish a health-care exchange means that people are not eligible for subsidies in states where the federal government created the exchanges because the state refused to do so. Take away those subsidies
column2: and Obamacare collapses.

column1: One part of the law favors the critics’ interpretation
column2: but other parts of the law
column3: and the broader context of the law
column4: contradict such an interpretation. Given this Talmudic dispute over the text
column5: it’s almost inconceivable that the justices
column6: supposed practitioners of judicial modesty
column7: would consider that justification sufficient to tear apart the nation’s social fabric.

column1: Opponents of the law went through great contortions to bring this case. They’re arguing against tax credits — and thus in favor of tax increases. They had trouble finding people who had sufficient injury to have standing in the case — and in Wednesday’s arguments it became apparent that only one of the four plaintiffs clearly qualified. More difficulty came when Carvin argued that states would still get the benefit of exchanges even without subsidies. Justice Elena Kagan pointed out that he argued the opposite in his last appearance.
Whichever legal argument the law’s opponents were relying on at the moment
column2: it was secondary to the political argument against Obamacare. Scalia
column3: in his attempt to justify the social upheaval that would come if the court jettisoned the law
column4: asked the government’s top lawyer
column5: Donald Verrilli: “You really think Congress is just going to sit there while all of these disastrous consequences ensue? . . . Congress adjusts
column6: enacts a statute that takes care of the problem. It happens all the time.”

column1: There was laughter in the courtroom.
After the argument
column2: hundreds of activists
column3: whipped up by some members of that very Congress
column4: waved signs and traded taunts as if they were rival fans at a basketball game.

column1: “Stand up! Fight back! Health care under attack!” chanted one side.
“Liberty! Follow the law!” the other side shouted back.
In the unlikely event the Roberts court uses an ambiguous textual dispute to overturn the most significant social legislation of the era
column2: there will be no place to hide from the national conflagration that follows.

column1: Read more from Dana Milbank’s archive
column2: follow him on Twitter or subscribe to his updates on Facebook."	REAL

column1: Donald Trump says his presidential campaign is revoking The Washington Post’s press credentials
column2: and the Post isn’t the first major news outlet to be barred from Trump’s rallies and events. Trump previously banned Politico
column3: BuzzFeed News
column4: The Huffington Post
column5: and others from his campaign events
column6: according to The New York Times.

column1: Trump called The Washington Post “phony and dishonest” in a Facebook post where he explained that he decided to pull the press credentials due to the paper’s “incredibly inaccurate coverage and reporting” of his campaign.
Trump took issue with a headline the Post wrote Monday that read
column2: “Donald Trump suggests President Obama was involved with Orlando shooting."" The headline was changed Monday afternoon to read
column3: “""Donald Trump seems to connect President Obama to Orlando shooting.""

column1: The Post story covered Trump’s statements during a Fox News interview on Monday. When asked to explain why he called for Obama to resign after the shooting
column2: he answered
column3: in part
column4: ""He doesn't get it or he gets it better than anybody understands — it's one or the other
column5: and either one is unacceptable.""

column1: Washington Post spokeswoman Kristine Coratti Kelly told the Associated Press in an email that the Post changed the headline shortly after posting the story ""to more properly reflect what Trump said.""
We did so on our own; the Trump campaign never contacted us about it
column2: ” Kelly said.

column1: Washington Post editor Martin Baron said in a statement Tuesday that the decision to revoke the paper’s press credentials ""is nothing less than a repudiation of the role of a free and independent press."" Baron defended the Post’s coverage of Trump’s campaign so far and vowed to continue with honest
column2: honorable and accurate reporting.

column1: Trump has said that if he were to become president
column2: news organizations that have criticized him “ will have problems.” He threatened to sue The Washington Post in January over an article about the bankruptcy of his Atlantic City casino. This would be a very difficult suit to win
column3: thanks to the First Amendment's historically strong protection of journalists
column4: but Trump has said as president he hopes to weaken the libel law that protects journalists covering public figures.

column1: Under American libel law
column2: which the Supreme Court has repeatedly endorsed under the First Amendment
column3: it is difficult for public figures to sue reporters who criticize them because they must demonstrate that factually inaccurate statements were made with actual malice or reckless disregard for the truth.

column1: Legal experts doubt Trump as president could change libel law through executive order; the change would likely require a constitutional amendment.
Nonetheless
column2: denying reporters access to his campaign events is within Trump’s current power.

column1: Chris Cillizza wrote for The Washington Post on Tuesday that politicians and journalists inevitably have a tense relationship
column2: “The job of journalists – at The Post and everywhere else – is to give voters the fullest and most accurate picture of the two people who want to represent all of us as president. That is a task that is
column3: inherently
column4: at conflict – at least at times – with the story the candidates want to tell about themselves. That tension is natural and often leads to uncomfortable relationships between the candidates and the media who cover them.”

column1: This report contains material from the Associated Press."	REAL

How Jeb Bush can avoid being the Jon Huntsman of 2016	"It seems increasingly likely that Jeb Bush will run for president. (Even his son is talking up the prospects.) What remains to be seen is whether Jeb Bush can actually win.

A lot of GOP establishment types are excited about a Bush candidacy. But don't expect the grassroots to eagerly embrace a former Florida governor who has made a habit of moderately breaking from conservative orthodoxy on big issues like immigration
column2: or who recently (mildly) singled out Fox News for criticism. As the editor of the Washington Free Beacon said:

column1: It's not hard to understand the Huntsman comparison. The former Utah governor — among the most conservative in the country during his tenure — was tarred as a base-betraying moderate before his campaign even officially began. To say he flamed out would be inaccurate in that he never lit up in the first place. Huntsman's much-hyped campaign was basically over as soon as it began.

Jeb already has the baggage of his brother to contend with. The last thing he needs is to invite are comparisons to the ill-fated Huntsman campaign. So how can he avoid this fate? Here are four pieces of unsolicited advice.

1. Toughen up. There are basically two ways that voters judge candidates. One is on the issues and the candidate's record on them. The other is based on temperament — our rather subjective sense of who this person is. For conservative voters who might be uneasy about Bush
column2: his stance on some issues is problematic. Support for things like Common Core and immigration reform aren't exactly red meat for the GOP base. But Bush can balance this by being tough.

column1: Huntsman was seen as ideologically moderate and temperamentally weak. That's a horrible combination. Ted Cruz is seen as ideologically stern and temperamentally tough
column2: a better combination as far as the base is concerned
column3: but probably one that catches up to him with the general electorate. Who has a good combination? Chris Christie's tough persona covers a multitude of sins on the issues — and indeed allows him to be a bit more ideologically moderate. Another example is John McCain. Moderate on some issues (including immigration reform)
column4: his tough-guy image helped provide balance — enough to win the 2008 nomination
column5: at least.

column1: Base voters on both sides of the aisle tend to conflate toughness with ideological purity. I'm probably more conservative than Ann Coulter
column2: who backed Chris Christie for president in 2012 and defended RomneyCare. But I'm willing to bet everyone would suspect that Coulter
column3: who is never afraid to take the knives out
column4: is way more conservative than me. Style sometimes trumps substance.

column1: Most candidates have a natural proclivity to be hard or soft. Mike Huckabee might be the best modern politician at playing nice and tough — but even here
column2: the latter often comes across as inauthentic
column3: and
column4: ironically
column5: as mean.

column1: The problem for Jeb is that he seems to be temperamentally moderate as well as ideologically moderate. He needs to overcome this by getting tough. This is the most important thing he can do.
2. Don't flip-flop. Being tough sometimes mean sticking to your guns and standing up to the base (see Bill Clinton's Sister Souljah moment). Now
column2: you might think that the smart move for Jeb would instead be to pander to the base and change his positions. This is almost always a terrible idea
column3: and only compounds a candidate's image problem. The conservative base now not only distrusts you ideologically
column4: but also sees you as a wimp — which is essentially the same as some caricature of an effete liberal. Yes
column5: there may be ways to massage these things
column6: to stress some issues and downplay others. But the answer for Jeb isn't to shed his moderate positions — that will only compound his problems. He cannot change his positions
column7: no matter how tempting it may be. Doing so will make him look weak. And remember what we said about being tough?

column1: 3. Don't try to change the GOP base. This one probably seems obvious
column2: but Jeb Bush isn't some backbencher running to ""get a message out"" or pull the other candidates toward him on certain issues (as Elizabeth Warren might if she challenged Hillary Clinton). If he runs
column3: it should be to win. That means his purpose isn't to lecture the base or shame the base or change the base — it's to win the election. If he wants to win an argument instead of an election
column4: he should stay home and write blog posts. Like me.

column1: People can tell if you don't like or respect them. This is true of almost every profession. In Jerry Maguire
column2: the title character's sports agent mentor tells him
column3: ""Unless you love everybody
column4: you can't sell anybody."" The same is true in the writing world: E.B. White said
column5: ''No one can write decently who is distrustful of the reader's intelligence."" If Jeb harbors any resentment toward the Republican base
column6: he either needs to sit this one out (because it will show)
column7: or overcome it by flipping a psychological switch and reminding himself constantly that these are good people and that he loves them.

column1: 4. Don't lamely suck up to the GOP base
column2: either. I realize this might seem contradictory. But it's not. And while Jeb cannot and should not be in the business of overtly pandering — doing so would make him look inauthentic and weak — he absolutely must reach out to conservative opinion leaders. He must be accessible. And this will be a problem for him
column3: because he is a bit cloistered. And because of the star-power associated with being a Bush
column4: he can already seem intimidating
column5: and likely already has a team of handlers charged with isolating him from the masses (Rudy Giuliani suffered from this
column6: as well).

column1: How to overcome this? The best model I've witnessed was McCain
column2: who in 2008 was incredibly accessible to conservative writers. In that regard
column3: he probably over-performed. Jeb should read this.

column1: Jeb Bush doesn't have to be Jon Huntsman. In fact
column2: he might well be the next president of the United States. But to win
column3: he'll have to toughen up
column4: stay true to himself
column5: and walk a tricky path between alienating and bowing before the GOP base. It won't be easy — but he can do it."	REAL

column1: The Daily 202: The presidency is Hillary Clinton’s to lose. Here are 12 ways she could lose it.	"The elites in Washington almost uniformly believe Hillary Clinton will be elected president in November. column3: but: Six months is an eternity in politics
