With Clinton struggling to sew up the Democratic nomination against a socialist septuagenarian –— she’s expected to lose tomorrow’s Kentucky primary –— we cannot foreclose the possibility that she will botch the fall campaign against the billionaire businessman.

column1: The presidency is hers to lose
column2: but here are a dozen ways Clinton can snatch defeat from the jaws of victory:

column1: Remember the Michigan primary? Every poll showed Clinton up double digits
column2: but she lost to Bernie Sanders. One reason is that supporters and field staffers believed she had it in the bag.

column1: The campaign has been using last week’s Quinnipiac polls showing tight races in Ohio
column2: Florida and Pennsylvania to shake a greater sense of urgency into donors and activists.

column1: Clinton is at her worst when she thinks she’s at her best. She tends to rise to the occasion only when her back is against the wall. Remember 2008? Or recall last summer
column2: when Sanders looked like nothing more than a nuisance and polls showed her ahead by more than 50 points
column3: how she joked about wiping her server clean with a cloth and how her handlers literally used ropes to corral journalists at a parade. Over time
column4: she found herself neck-and-neck with Sanders
column5: who is a weak candidate by most traditional measures. Under heavy pressure in the days before Iowa
column6: when it looked like she could lose the caucuses
column7: she temporarily became a much better campaigner –— then backslid after her wins in Nevada and South Carolina.

column1: When Hillary goes off her carefully scripted message
column2: she has a tendency to gaffe. One reason she is expected to lose Kentucky tomorrow is her declaration at a town hall this spring that
column3: “We’re going to put a lot of coal miners and coal companies out of business.”

column1: Don’t forget about her other gaffes
column2: like when she invoked 9/11 to defend her coziness with Wall Street
column3: when she called Republicans the enemy or when she said she and her husband were “dead broke” when they left the White House in 2001.

column1: And there was the time Clinton incensed the gay community by praising the Reagans for starting “a national conversation” about HIV/AIDS
column2: prompting a quick retraction.

column1: Clinton cannot just make this election a referendum on Trumpism. She must outline a compelling vision for where she wants to take the country to fully activate the coalition that powered Barack Obama.
“I am not a natural politician
column2: in case you haven't noticed
column3: like my husband or President Obama
column4: Clinton said at The Post’s debate in March.

column1: The presumptive Democratic nominee campaigns in prose
column2: not poetry. And she does not always try to be uplifting in her speeches.

column1: It’s part of the explanation for why so many millennials
column2: including young women
column3: have spurned her for Bernie. While Sanders promises tuition-free college
column4: she talks about extending an obscure tax credit. As my colleague David Fahrenthold explained in a story about Clinton’s wonkiness last week
column5: this credit can be worth up to $2
column6: 500: “But only if students find their Form 1098-T
column7: then fill out the relevant portions of Form 8863
column8: then enter the amount from lines 8 and 19 of Form 8863 in lines 68 and 50 of their Form 1040.” That is not going to send a thrill up Chris Matthews’s leg….

column1: My colleagues Dan Balz and Anne Gearan spoke with more than a dozen Clinton allies about her biggest weaknesses for a piece on today’s front page. “I bring it down to one thing and one thing only
column2: and that is likability
column3: ” said Peter Hart
column4: a Democratic pollster who has conducted a series of focus groups for the Annenberg Public Policy Center at the University of Pennsylvania. Hart said this is “about the lowest bar” for a candidate
column5: and yet Clinton has lower likability numbers today than she did when the campaign began.

column1: Balz and Gearan report that Clinton advisers are working to soften her stiff public image by highlighting her compassion and playing up her problem-solving abilities. “I mean
column2: we can’t give her an injection to make her an energetic candidate
column3: ” one longtime Clinton family supporter and donor said on background. (Read the full piece here.)

column1: 5. Moving too far to the right
The Sanders campaign has circulated stories about Clinton forces reaching out to top Jeb Bush donors to convince them that “that she represents their values better” than Trump.
Clinton
column2: who used to brag about being a Goldwater Girl in 1964
column3: will be very tempted to appeal aggressively to moderate Republicans who are turned off by Trump. On paper
column4: the Democrat will actually be more of a hawk and more willing to use military force than the Republican. The Donald is all over the place on policy
column5: but Clinton is presently to his right on trade and campaign finance.

column1: She needs Sanders supporters to unite behind her. If it looks like she’s shifting rightward to win votes
column2: she will look inauthentic and many Bernie people will stay on the sidelines.

column1: 6. Moving too far to the left
Clinton has treated Sanders with kid gloves recently. She wants him and his people to fall in line after the July convention in Philadelphia
column2: and she calculates that antagonizing him is not worth sewing up the nomination earlier.

column1: The Vermont senator has made clear he wants significant concessions
column2: including very liberal policy planks in the party platform. The Clinton people will be inclined to give on a lot because the platform is not binding. Just last week
column3: for instance
column4: she embraced several reforms to the Federal Reserve that are sought by the progressive wing of the party.

column1: But
column2: if Hillary continues to lurch leftward to satisfy the Bernie people
column3: it will be harder to win those in the middle and woo disaffected Republicans.

column1: You might think it’s unfair to say Clinton cannot go too far left or too far right. But everyone running for president has this problem. It is a difficult needle to thread
column2: yet the Clintons have proven deft at triangulation. Now
column3: Hillary needs to be Goldilocks.

column1: There’s no perfect pick
column2: and candidates who look great on paper might turn out to fall flat –— or have skeletons in their closet.

column1: Citing four people close to the campaign
column2: USA Today reports this morning that “Clinton is considering a running mate who could make a direct appeal to supporters of Sanders
column3: bridging a generational and political divide” and that “Clinton’s chief requirements include a candidate’s resume and a fighter capable of hand-to-hand combat with Trump. The campaign’s vetting also prioritizes demographics over someone from a key swing state as she seeks to unify the Democratic voting base.”

column1: There are parts of every would-be number two’s record that will upset at least some portion of the Democratic Party. Take this story that just posted on Politico: “Targeted by progressive activists hoping to kill his chances of being picked as Clinton’s running mate
column2: Julián Castro is set this week to announce changes to what’s become a hot-button Housing and Urban Development program for selling bad mortgages on its books.”

column1: 8. Allowing herself to get defined as an insider
Clinton lost to Obama in 2008 by underestimating the electorate’s hunger for change. Once again
column2: Hillary risks coming to represent the status quo in the eyes of voters who want a renegade.

column1: “Right now
column2: about 6 in 10 Americans have an unfavorable view of Trump.… But the country is faring even worse. … 64.9 percent think we are heading down the wrong track
column3: ” The Post’s Editorial Page Editor Fred Hiatt noted last week in a column warning Democrats not to celebrate Trump. “So what if even voters who respect Clinton’s competence reject her as the embodiment of business as usual? And what if even voters who do not like Trump’s bigotry or bluster care more that he will
column4: in their view
column5: shake things up? … I do have faith in the American voter
column6: I really do. But when two-thirds of the country is unhappy
column7: a rational outcome can’t be taken for granted.”

column1: In trying to stay above the fray
column2: Clinton could find herself defined by Trump. Remember the Swift Boat Veterans for Truth? John Kerry didn’t push back forcefully enough early on
column3: and he paid a price.

column1: Last week
column2: Trump called Clinton an “enabler” of her husband’s behavior. While objectively offensive
column3: the Democratic front-runner steadfastly refused to respond. “I’m going to let him run his campaign however he chooses
column4: ” she told reporters. “I have nothing to say about him.”

column1: Trump gives a whole new meaning to term “bully pulpit.” And there is very conventional logic in not responding to every insult and attack: it leads to more repetition of the original charge and keeps it in the news.
Hillary dislikes the media. Her impulse is to keep the press away
column2: to only give the appearance of access and to focus her attention on friendly outlets that will engage in puffery.

column1: Trump
column2: to his credit
column3: talks to basically everyone. It gets him in trouble
column4: like when he told Chris Matthews that women who get abortions should be punished. But the tradeoff is that he has often gotten to set the terms of the debate. If he repeats something enough times
column5: however preposterous
column6: some may come to believe it.

column1: “I have a lot of experience dealing with men who sometimes get off the reservation in the way they behave and how they speak
column2: ” Hillary recently said on CNN. A few days later
column3: she clarified on MSNBC that she was not referring to her husband –— but Rick Lazio and Vladimir Putin.

column1: The former president has caused fewer headaches for his wife’s campaign than he did in 2008
column2: when he called Obama’s bid “the biggest fairy tale I’ve ever seen
column3: ” said the other side was playing the “race card
column4: ” and downplayed a loss in South Carolina by noting Jesse Jackson Jr. had won there too.

column1: That does not mean he has not ruined news cycles for his wife in 2016 –— or has the ability to.
Remember his outburst on the eve of the New Hampshire primary when he accused Sanders of being dishonest and his supporters of being sexist?
Or when he got into an on-stage argument with Black Lives Matter protesters in Philadelphia last month
column2: defending his crime bill and his wife’s 1996 comment about bringing “super-predators … to heel”? The next day
column3: he said: “I almost want to apologize.” But then didn’t.

column1: The campaign must manage WJC appropriately. It’s hard to control any spouse; a former president – especially “The Big Dog” – is even harder.
Trump will try to make Hillary own all the unpopular elements of the Clinton era. Expect to hear a lot about Marc Rich’s pardon and the Lincoln Bedroom.
Hillary will take credit for the popular elements of her husband’s tenure and take umbrage when Trump tries to pin the unpopular parts on her
column2: as she already has with the crime bill and Wall Street deregulation.

column1: Clinton is not widely seen as trustworthy. Her refusal to release the transcripts of her speeches at Goldman Sachs will continue to dog her. Asked during a debate why she received $675
column2: 000 for three short appearances
column3: she replied: “Well
column4: I don't know. That’s what they offered.”

column1: But Trump’s refusal to release his tax returns –— along with his evolving answers and lame excuses –— neutralizes this potential problem for the Clinton campaign.
It is unlikely
column2: but the FBI investigation into Clinton’s possible mishandling of classified information hangs like a cloud over her campaign.

column1: “Investigators have found scant evidence tying Clinton to criminal wrongdoing
column2: although they are still working on the case and charges have not been ruled out
column3: ” my colleague Ellen Nakashima reported last week. “They have also been interviewing former aides to Clinton
column4: including Cheryl Mills
column5: who served as chief of staff while Clinton was secretary of state. Prosecutors and FBI agents hope to be able to interview Clinton as they try to wrap up the investigation.”

column1: Among other potential problems identified by supporters in Balz and Gearan’s story today: “Clinton’s unpopularity with white men
column2: questions about whether her family philanthropic foundation helped donors and friends
column3: and lingering clouds from her tenure at the State Department
column4: including … the Benghazi attacks in which four Americans were killed and her support for military intervention in Libya.”

column1: -- Don’t forget
column2: history is not on Hillary’s side. Since World War II
column3: only once has a party controlled the White House for three consecutive terms. (George H.W. Bush succeeded Ronald Reagan by beating Mike Dukakis in 1988.)

column1: -- Bottom line: Clinton is more likely than not to be president at this time next year
column2: but the election will probably be closer than you think and Trump could actually win if she doesn’t play her cards right.

column1: -- President Obama delivered an aggressive refutation of Trumpism during his commencement address at Rutgers University
column2: calling on graduates to reject politicians who “hark back to better days.” From Greg Jaffe: “He mocked Trump’s call to ‘Make America Great Again
column3: ’ saying that there was never a better time to be alive on the planet and in America. College graduation rates were up
column4: he said. Crime rates had dropped
column5: and more women were in the workplace than ever before in the country’s history … [He also] slammed Trump’s proposal to build a wall along the country’s southern border
column6: saying the world is becoming ever more interconnected and ‘building walls won’t change that.’ At one point
column7: clearly referring to Trump and other congressional Republicans who have decried efforts to combat global warming
column8: Obama warned that
column9: 'In politics and in life ignorance is not a virtue. ... That’s not challenging political correctness. That’s just not knowing what you are talking about.’”

column1: -- “Obama is expected to begin campaigning for Clinton in earnest as early as June
column2: when she is expected to lock up the nomination
column3: ” Balz and Gearan report.

column1: -- Trump and Vice President Biden both went to the University of Pennsylvania's commencement ceremony yesterday. David Weigel was there: “For Trump
column2: the ceremony was all about Tiffany Trump
column3: his daughter with ex-wife Marla Maples
column4: who also attended the commencement. Biden was there for his granddaughter Naomi Biden
column5: the first of the family's third generation to graduate from college. … When some unexpected rain fell
column6: Trump disappeared beneath an umbrella
column7: while Biden kept shaking hands.”

column1: MORE ON THE REPUBLICAN RACE:

-- A band of exasperated Republicans is actively plotting to draft an independent presidential candidate to keep Trump from the White House BUT those involved concede that such an effort at this late stage is probably futile. Philip Rucker and Robert Costa: “These GOP figures are commissioning private polling
column2: lining up major funding sources and courting potential contenders … The effort has been sporadic all spring but has intensified significantly in the 10 days since Trump effectively locked up the Republican nomination. ... But these Republicans — including [Mitt Romney
column3: ] commentators William Kristol and Erick Erickson and strategists Mike Murphy
column4: Stuart Stevens and Rick Wilson — are so repulsed by the prospect of Trump as commander in chief that they are desperate to take action. ... and they think they have only a couple of weeks to launch a credible bid.""

column1: Their top recruits are Sen. Ben Sasse [who denies interest] and former presidential candidate John Kasich [who today will give his first TV interview since dropping out]. Earlier prospects included former Sen. Tom Coburn
column2: Condoleezza Rice
column3: and even reality-television star and businessman Mark Cuban."" Many dismissed the idea as political fantasy: “Again and again
column4: though
column5: these anti-Trump Republicans have heard the same tepid response. ... 'I don’t see it happening
column6: ' Cuban wrote in an email.""

column1: A potential third-party candidate faces enormous risk. No one wants to be the next Ralph Nader. ""The career of the individual would come to an end
column2: and he would have a difficult spot in history for being responsible for putting Clinton in the White House
column3: said Patrick J. Buchanan. There are also formidable logistical hurdles
column4: with deadlines to get on state ballots fast approaching.

column1: Spoiler alert: Some anti-Trump Republicans are downsizing their ambitions to a more focused
column2: state-specific effort. Mike Murphy
column3: who ran the Jeb Bush super PAC
column4: is pushing one such proposal. ""Murphy envisions an independent candidate on what he termed ‘an honorable mission’ in Colorado
column5: New Hampshire and Ohio — three battleground states with relatively lax ballot-access rules. 'Running an anti-Trump protest candidate in a handful of swing states really appeals to me
column6: ' Murphy said. 'You could deny Trump the presidency and perhaps help important Senate and other down-ballot races­ by giving another choice to Republican voters who abhor Hillary Clinton and can’t cross the moral line to vote for Trump.'""

column1: -- Reince Priebus said drafting a third-party candidate to run against Trump would be a “suicide mission” that could wreck the party for “generations.” ""They can try to hijack another party and get on the ballot
column2: but
column3: look
column4: it's a suicide mission for our country because what it means is that you're throwing down not just eight years of the White House but potentially 100 years on the Supreme Court and wrecking this country for many generations
column5: the RNC chairman said on ""Fox News Sunday."" ""I think it's very dangerous
column6: and there's other ways to get assurances on the things that they're worried about."" Priebus praised the approach taken by Paul Ryan
column7: adding that he would be surprised if Ryan did not endorse Trump soon: ""I'd be surprised if we didn't get there
column8: not too much longer in the distant future.""

column1: -- Meanwhile
column2: Republican activists chose unity over resistance this weekend
column3: with party leaders pressuring the rank-and-file to fall in line behind the presumptive nominee – and even punishing those who refused. Politico’s Kyle Cheney: In all
column4: nearly 400 delegates were selected Saturday – about one in every six that will fill Cleveland’s convention center in July.

column1: -- Trump warned of another 9/11-like attack if refugees continue to be admitted into the U.S: ""Our country has enough difficulty right now without letting the Syrians pour in
column2: Trump said in an interview on the National Border Patrol Council podcast. He also suggested ISIS is “paying for refugees’ cell phone plans”: ""Who pays their monthly charges
column3: right? They have cell phones with the flags
column4: the ISIS flags on them.""

column1: -- Trump and Clinton are statistically tied in Georgia
column2: according to a general election poll conducted by the Atlanta Journal-Constitution: He leads her 45 to 41 percent
column3: within the poll’s 4.26 margin of error
column4: while 13 percent said they were undecided or did not support either candidate.

column1: -- A family grieving the death of an Alabama-born woman has a request for friends and relatives: Don't vote for Trump. From the AP: “Relatives of 34-year-old Katherine Michelle Hinds published an obituary Friday in the Opelika-Auburn News that includes the line: ‘In lieu of flowers
column2: do not vote for Donald Trump.’ Hinds' mother
column3: Susan Pool
column4: says her daughter … feared for the future of her three young children if he's elected.”

column1: -- John Boehner will spend late July and all of August on a cross-country bus trip raising money and campaigning for House Republicans
column2: per Politico’s Jake Sherman: “The trip — on Boehner’s bus
column3: dubbed ‘Freedom One’ — will begin after the Republican National Convention in Cleveland and end Labor Day weekend.”

column1: -- Rep. Peter King (R-N.Y.) defended his use of a derogatory term toward Japanese in a cable-news appearance
column2: saying that he was trying to critique the “uninformed” views that Trump espouses. From Paul Kane: “King
column3: who supports Trump nominally but is refusing to campaign for him
column4: said that his use of the word ‘Japs’ was meant to criticize the presidential candidate’s policy positions as out of line with the ‘nuance’ required to be the leader of the free world and more in line with a working-class man at the end of a bar espousing his worldview.”

column1: -- “Is Ben Carson the worst or the best surrogate of all time? Yes.” By Ben Terris: “Ben Carson
column2: the neurosurgeon turned presidential candidate turned unfiltered pitchman for Trump
column3: now part of his vice presidential search committee
column4: sat in the back of a town car with his wife
column5: Candy. He had just explained that he wanted no role in a Trump administration when news arrived of a new poll naming him as the best-liked of a list of potential running mates. “The most favorably regarded contenders after himself
column6: he was told
column7: were John Kasich
column8: Marco Rubio
column9: Ted Cruz
column10: Sarah Palin and Chris Christie. ‘Those are all people on our list
column11: ’ he said. That the Trump campaign might want its potential VP picks held close to the vest didn’t seem to occur to Carson. He’s not the type to keep his candid thoughts to himself.”

column1: Carson says he has no plan to pull a Dick Cheney and suggest himself. Carson understands he’s a lightning rod for controversy
column2: and Trump doesn’t need help sparking fires. “He’s not interested
column3: ” said business manager Armstrong Williams. And then: “But miracles can happen … we’ve seen stranger things
column4: right?” Yes
column5: yes we have. Not the least of which has been watching Carson say things that would get any other surrogate benched
column6: only to be elevated within the campaign.”

column1: MORE ON THE DEMOCRATIC RACE:
-- CONVENTION CHAOS: Tensions ran high at the Democratic state convention in Nevada
column2: a foreboding signs for Clinton as she prepares for the national convention in Philadelphia. With Sanders partisans pushing to include delegates who had been ruled ineligible
column3: party leaders adjourned the convention for the day. ""But Sanders supporters refused to concede
column4: remaining in the [Paris] casino's ballroom after the event had ended. Eventually
column5: casino security and law enforcement officials entered to force the Democrats out of the space
column6: even turning off the lights to get them to depart
column7: Philip Bump reports.

column1: Why the Sanders supporters were angry: The rules were seen as less favorable to the Vermont senator by his backers
column2: as was the process for picking 12 up-for-grabs delegates to Philadelphia. Sanders supporters were outraged over the exclusion of 56 delegates – enough to swing the majority – who were denied mostly because they weren't registered as Democrats by the May 1 deadline. (Eight Clinton delegates reportedly suffered a similar fate
column3: Las Vegas Sun notes.)

column1: Here are some live tweets from the dean of the Nevada press corps:
-- On the trail in Kentucky
column2: Clinton got more specific about what Bill Clinton’s White House role could be. From Abby Phillip: ""I'm going to put [him] in charge of revitalizing the economy because you know
column3: he knows how to do it
column4: she told supporters. ""And especially in places like coal country and inner cities and other parts of our country that have been really left out."" Clinton
column5: who has long made it clear she looks to her husband’s presidency as a model for how to manage the economy
column6: often notes the job creation and increases in median household income during his administration. ""When my husband was president
column7: incomes rose for everybody
column8: she said in Louisville.

column1: -- Many young Black Lives Matter protestors are not voting
column2: according to exit polling analysis from 25 primaries. From Vanessa Williams and Scott Clement: African Americans account for a larger share of Democratic primary voters than they did in 2008
column3: but that is because of OLDER black voters. Comparing exit polls in 25 states from 2008 and 2016
column4: “black voters older than 45 grew from 12 percent of the electorate on average in 2008 to 16 percent this year. In those same states
column5: black voters younger than 45 made up 11 percent of voters in 2008 vs. 10 percent this year.”

column1: President Obama
column2: in his commencement address last weekend at Howard University
column3: praised young black activists for bringing new energy to the movement for racial justice and equality
column4: but he said: “You have to have a strategy. Not just awareness
column5: but action. Not just hashtags
column6: but votes.” Obama’s comments echoed continuing concerns that some young black activists involved in the current wave of political action do not share the belief in the critical importance of the right to vote:

column1: Younger Americans are the least likely to turn out in elections: The share of eligible voters ages 18 to 29 who cast ballots fell from a record high of 48 percent in 2008 to 41 percent in the 2012 presidential election
column2: according to the U.S. Elections Project.

column1: Interviews with activists inspired by the Black Lives Matter movement revealed a nuanced view of electoral politics: “None advocated a total boycott of elections … At the same time
column2: many were not enthusiastic about the value of voting
column3: particularly in this year’s presidential election cycle. These activists argued that neither candidate had adequately addressed the issues affecting black communities. ‘Voting is definitely one way … but there are other ways of reimagining and restructuring the world
column4: and that lies in organizing our communities
column5: ’ said Ashley Williams
column6: a 23-year-old activist.”

column1: -- The RNC chairman defended Trump’s refusal to release his tax returns: ""People don't look at Trump as to whether he releases his taxes
column2: Priebus said on ABC. ""People look at Trump and say
column3: 'Is this person going to cause an earthquake in Washington
column4: D.C.
column5: and make something happen?' That is it. I don't think the traditional playbook applies … We've been down this road for a year … He's rewritten the playbook."" (Elise Viebeck)

column1: -- Newt Gingrich again said he’s open to being Trump’s running-mate: ""I don't think it's an automatic yes
column2: Gingrich said on ""Fox News Sunday."" But “I’d be hard-pressed not to say yes."" The former Speaker suggested his decision would be based largely on what duties Trump would expect from a running-mate
column3: as well as how “seriously” he takes the role.

column1: -- Sen. Sherrod Brown (D-Ohio) demurred when asked if he would serve as Clinton's running-mate. “I love the job I’m doing
column2: ” Brown told CNN’s Jake Tapper. “I will put real effort into electing Hillary … but as I said
column3: I love this job
column4: and I'm just not going to give you a different answer.""

column1: -- Trump senior adviser Paul Manafort denied that Trump ever posed as his own publicist to speak with reporters
column2: saying he believes a 25-year-old audio recording that is clearly Trump is not actually Trump. ""I couldn't tell who it is. If Donald Trump says it's not him
column3: I believe it's not him
column4: Manafort said on CNN’s ""State of the Union."" Manafort also touted the “crossover support” that his boss has attracted in traditionally Democratic states
column5: arguing that they will “expand the map” and can win in Michigan
column6: Pennsylvania and Ohio.

column1: Trump and Manafort's denials directly contradict testimony that The Donald gave under oath in a 1990 lawsuit.
On Friday afternoon
column2: Washington Post reporters who were 44 minutes into a phone interview with Trump about his finances asked him a question about Miller: “Did you ever employ someone named John Miller as a spokesperson?” The phone went silent
column3: then dead. When the reporters called back and reached Trump’s secretary
column4: she said
column5: “I heard you got disconnected. He can’t take the call now. I don’t know what happened.” (Read the original story.)

column1: Via Zignal Labs
column2: here is a word cloud of all Trump mentions on Friday:

column1: -- “China killed thousands of Maine jobs. Now it’s eating up the state’s lobsters
column2: ” by Ylan Q. Mui: “Little Cranberry
column3: an island of 70 inhabitants
column4: and China
column5: a nation of 1.4 billion people
column6: increasingly find themselves connected by the shifting currents of the world economy. The rise of China’s middle class has coincided with a boom in Maine’s lobster population
column7: resulting in a voracious new market for the crustaceans’ succulent
column8: sweet meat. Exports of lobsters to China
column9: nonexistent a decade ago
column10: totaled $20 million last year. … The lobster’s tale is a testament to the complexities of the global marketplace — and a reminder that the line between economic winners and losers is not always clear. China has played the villain (in 2016)
column11: blamed for … the disappearance of blue-collar jobs
column12: including in Maine
column13: where the closure of lumber and pulp factories have left thousands of workers unemployed. Yet the reality is more nuanced. Even as foreign competition has devastated parts of the U.S. economy
column14: China ranks among the biggest international customers for a vast array of other industries
column15: from ginseng to airplanes to pork. Maine lobsters are just a tiny sliver of the $116 billion in annual exports to China
column16: a figure that has nearly tripled in the past decade.”

column1: -- “Al-Qaeda affiliates are threatening West Africa’s most peaceful cities
column2: ” by Kevin Sieff in Dakar: “In a city where nightclubs and mosques coexist peacefully
column3: Islamist violence long felt like a foreign problem—something residents watched on news clips from the Middle East or other parts of—Africa. But Senegal and its neighbors are facing a new threat from extremists moving far from their traditional strongholds in northwest Africa. Since November
column4: militant groups have killed dozens of people in assaults on hotels
column5: cafes and a beachside resort in West Africa
column6: passing through porous borders with impunity. The attacks have occurred in countries that had been rebounding from political turbulence
column7: such as Ivory Coast and Burkina Faso. Now fears of such bloodshed are growing in this pro-Western democracy
column8: which serves as a regional hub for international organizations. ... Senegal
column9: a former French colony that has never suffered a major terrorist incident
column10: is now taking unprecedented security measures.""

column1: -- “Filipino children of U.S. sailors and soldiers have mixed feelings on American return
column2: ” by Emily Rauhala: “There’s a taunt that hangs over this former U.S. naval base
column3: looming over kids who look a little different
column4: shadowing single moms: ‘Left by the ship.’ The term is used to shame the offspring of U.S. servicemen and local women ... Nearly 25 years ago
column5: Philippine lawmakers expelled the U.S. warships that had docked here for almost a century
column6: vowing to ‘unchain’ the country from its colonial past …” But for decades
column7: tens of thousands of children of U.S. military men have been fighting not to be forgotten. “Now China’s claims to most of the South China Sea have put the Philippines back at the heart of U.S. strategy in Asia. A new defense pact allows the U.S. military to build facilities at five Philippine bases
column8: and a growing number of ships will be stopping by Subic Bay. Their return is renewing questions about what the U.S. owes Filipino Amerasians — and stoking worries that there will be more neglected children when the ships leave harbor once again.”

column1: -- “Disagreements slow Pentagon’s plan to allow transgender service members
column2: ” by Dan Lamothe: “Months before Defense Secretary Ashton B. Carter said the Pentagon would take steps toward allowing transgender people to serve openly in the military
column3: Army Staff Sgt. Patricia King last year became what she believes is the first openly transgender member of the infantry. While official Pentagon policy still forbids openly transgender personnel
column4: her commanders have been supportive
column5: she said. King even purchased a female dress Army s"

column1: anticipating that she would be able to wear it soon. But four months after a deadline set Carter set for a working group to finish evaluating the change	 transgender service members are still waiting. Officials say disagreements remain in the Defense Department about how to move forward	 suggesting that the Pentagon isn’t close to wrapping up the review	 let alone instituting any changes.”
Lithuania	 is going viral:
noting that they interviewed more than 50 women:
it's worth remembering how close he lives to the studios:

“In Koch World ‘Realignment	’ Less National Politics	” by Tim Alberta and Eliana Johnson: “In February	 a team of political operatives arrived in Kansas hoping to turn the tide of the presidential campaign. They’d set aside $150 million to be spread across campaigns. Yet they had not been authorized to spend a dime on the White House race. Marc Short wanted to change that. He led a faction inside the Koch network that had become convinced of the need to neutralize Trump before his momentum made him unstoppable. Short had come to Wichita to present Charles Koch a detailed	 eight-figure blueprint for derailing Trump on Super Tuesday when 11 states would vote	 hoping to get the green light to hammer him with ads in states where he was most vulnerable. But there was an unwelcome surprise awaiting the delegation: A number of top executives from the Koch enterprise had been invited. They represented the so-called ‘corporate side’ of Koch World	 which had long warred with the ‘political side’ of the empire. The meeting confirmed what some Koch insiders had begun to suspect: That the brothers’ political decision-making was increasingly being influenced by their business and public-relations interests.”

“Roz Wyman	 L.A.'s secret weapon in luring Dodgers west	 is still cheering	” by Chris Erskine: “If Los Angeles has a grande dame of sports	 it is Roz Wyman … At 85	 she still sits in her Dodgers season seat near the umpires tunnel	 cheering on players young enough to be her great-grandsons. Wyman was about their age when she helped bring the Dodgers to Los Angeles almost 60 years ago … The Dodgers' patron saint had just finished at USC when in 1953 she became the youngest person	 and only the second woman	 elected to the L.A. City Council	 on a campaign platform that included	 of all things	 acquiring a major league team. At the time	 baseball's far-western foul pole was St. Louis. The Brooklyn Dodgers were stacked and poised to win their first World Series	 in 1955 …. [But] odds never mattered much to Wyman.  ‘It all reflects Roz's courage	 brilliance and tenacity	’ says former Dodgers owner Peter O'Malley … These days	 L.A. could use a few more movers and shakers like the Wizard of Roz.”

“The Americans: 15 Who Left the United States to Join ISIS	” by Richard Engel	 Ben Plesser	 Tracy Connor and Jon Schuppe: “American law enforcement officials estimate that roughly 250 Americans have tried to join IS. Most of them never left the U.S … But a few dozen of those American recruits have made the trip to ISIS's heartland in Syria and Iraq. In March	 NBC was given a thumb drive by a purported ISIS defector	 containing names and biographical snippets of thousands of fighters who entered Syria	 including at least 15 Americans who left the U.S. to join ISIS overseas.”

don’t be shocked to awaken to some frost. So grab the fleece and the ice scraper when you head out. But the May sun should help temperatures recover fairly quickly	 as they should be near 60 midday. Then	 afternoon highs reach the mid-60s to near 70.”

Trump or a Democrat?

column2: Or Just What Bernie Has?

column1: For some weeks now
column2: as Bernie Sanders has extended his remarkable and improbable run as a presidential candidate
column3: people have been asking: ""What does Bernie want?""

column1: That question is a distant echo of ""What does Jesse want?"" a relic of the 1988 runner-up candidacy of Jesse Jackson
column2: another ""outsider"" challenger with a dedicated hardcore following. But more about Jackson in a moment.

column1: This week
column2: the question took a different form. After a rowdy convention in Nevada prompted death threats against that state party chair
column3: the question suddenly became: ""Are the Democrats coming apart?""

column1: Uniting for the fall has always been an issue for both parties. But this year
column2: it was supposed to be the Republicans
column3: with their 17 candidates and their frustrated #NeverTrump rearguard action
column4: who broke up over their differences.

column1: Now
column2: it's working out quite differently. So we hear again that old nostrum: ""Democrats want to fall in love
column3: Republicans want to fall in line."" A remarkable number of Republicans have accepted
column4: if not embraced
column5: Donald Trump as their nominee. But a large contingent of Democrats continue to feel the Bern
column6: or at least remain very much out of love with Hillary Clinton.

column1: Which brings us to this past weekend
column2: which proved that sometimes what happens in Vegas does not stay in Vegas.

column1: The ""Nevada fracas"" has created a media meme and a conversational focus for the conflict roiling the Democratic Party. That is because it encapsulates the grievances felt on both sides.

Sanders supporters see that some of their number were not seated in Las Vegas and see evidence that the system is rigged against them. Clinton supporters hear the epithets hurled at women on that stage
column2: including the state party chair and Sen. Barbara Boxer
column3: and perceive evidence of something else.

column1: Others will adjudicate what happened in Las Vegas
column2: where both candidates' camps seem to think they were entitled to a majority of delegates. (Although Clinton won the initial round of caucuses back in February
column3: Sanders had the upper hand in an intermediate round at the county level on April 2.)

column1: One camp wanted an open process; the other wanted respect for the rules. A voice vote was gaveled to a conclusion despite an uncertain outcome
column2: which is bound to cause trouble. But in the end
column3: the party chair herself has come to seem the principal victim — ""more sinned against than sinning"" — because of extreme phone and online harassment.

column1: Nevada's convention seems to have been an egregious case
column2: an outlier. In other states where actual delegates are chosen in several phases
column3: regular order has been followed without a similar outburst.

column1: But exceptions to the rule often make news. And in this case
column2: cable TV and social media have endlessly repeated the raucous video shot at the convention and the toxic harassment that followed. As Nevada became a national story
column3: Sanders was pressured to respond.

column1: The candidate has condemned violence generically
column2: but has not apologized for his backers. Instead
column3: Sanders and his retinue have denied responsibility for what happened and doubled down on their long-simmering resentments against Democratic Party officials.

column1: They say the entire process has been rigged against them
column2: even parts that have been in place for decades. And the implicit message has been: Treat us fairly or expect there to be consequences. When this message is combined with Sanders' vow this week to ""carry our fight to the convention
column3: it darkens the portents for the national convention in Philadelphia.

column1: So what does Bernie want?
Let's start with the obvious: He wants to be nominated and elected. That's understood. Every candidate has a perfect right to continue fighting until the last ballot is cast
column2: as Sanders vows to do.

column1: But even if he wins California
column2: and several other states on June 7
column3: Sanders would need vertiginous victory margins to win enough delegates to close the pledged delegate gap with Clinton. (The Democrats divide delegates proportionally according to the popular vote
column4: which is just about as democratic a method as you can imagine.)

column1: So Sanders' one path is to persuade superdelegates to prefer him over Clinton
column2: even though they currently prefer Clinton by more than 10-1. (The only superdelegate to flip so far deserted Sanders for the front-runner.)

column1: Sanders and his spokespersons say superdelegates should now ignore the overall vote and the pledged delegate totals and look at how much better Sanders does against Trump in hypothetical November matchups.
The only problem is that hypothetical tests six months before the election are notoriously unreliable. Just ask President Perot.
Moreover
column2: many of the poll respondents who create this November differential right now are Sanders supporters who say they will shift to Trump in November. The likelihood of their actually doing so is problematic
column3: given past experience with disgruntled backers of other candidates who fell short. (The most recent example would be the Clinton backers in 2008 who swore they would not vote for the man who beat her
column4: Barack Obama
column5: but wound up doing so in the fall.)

column1: So the ""path to the nomination"" for Sanders is not just uphill
column2: it is essentially vertical.

column1: So what else might Sanders want?
No one seems to think Sanders wants to be vice president or have any other role in a Clinton administration. He would return to the Senate
column2: where he would be in a wholly new weight class of political influence.

column1: But he clearly wants to make a difference
column2: to alter how the Democrats go forward in the fall campaign and beyond.

column1: And that is what the Clinton camp must manage. It is entirely possible that the Democratic convention in Philadelphia this July will vote to change party rules
column2: shrinking the number of superdelegates or requiring them to follow the voting results in their states.

column1: It is also possible
column2: if less likely
column3: that the party would agree to allow more independents a role in its nominating process (although this would still depend on the will of the various states).

column1: Sanders supporters will also strive to make the party platform more progressive
column2: raising the minimum wage to $15 an hour and expanding Medicare to cover people of all ages and perhaps calling for free tuition at public colleges. (The platform already calls for much of Sanders' program regarding the campaign finance system and other issues.)

column1: This might fall far short of the ""political revolution"" Sanders says his campaign is about. But it could still matter. And it could still point the party toward a far more progressive future.
That is one way in which the 1988 precedent is relevant. Jesse Jackson arrived in Atlanta with about 30 percent of the delegates (not nearly as many as Sanders will have this summer). At the time
column2: it was easily the best showing for an African-American presidential candidate. And although Jackson was not going to be nominated (Massachusetts Gov. Michael Dukakis had a first-ballot majority)
column3: his message of racial and economic inclusion was popular and powerful within the party's base.

column1: The Dukakis forces recognized this and turned the proceedings over to Jackson on the second night of the convention. Thousands of Jackson supporters jammed the arena while delegates
column2: alternates and journalists waited outside — unable to enter. Jackson gave an hourlong oration on the theme of common ground
column3: a siege gun speaking for unity.

column1: Jackson did his part in the fall
column2: helping Dukakis carry nearly 90 percent of the black vote and 70 percent of the then-minuscule Hispanic vote. Unfortunately for Dukakis
column3: minority voters cast only about one ballot in seven in 1988.

column1: But by 2012
column2: the share of the vote cast by people of color had nearly doubled. That stunning growth has turned a dozen states that were red in 1988 to blue in 2012 (California
column3: Illinois
column4: Pennsylvania
column5: Michigan
column6: New Jersey
column7: Virginia
column8: Maryland
column9: New Mexico
column10: Connecticut
column11: New Hampshire
column12: Delaware and Vermont).

column1: The same demographic trends have made Florida
column2: Ohio and Colorado toss-ups in presidential elections. All had been solidly Republican in 1988.

column1: Sanders' hard base is not among minorities
column2: of course
column3: but among younger voters. His success has been built on winning three-fourths or even more of the voters under age 30. That is a group Clinton will need in the fall just as much as Dukakis needed Jackson's base in 1988.

column1: Sanders may not want a Jackson-style prime-time convention session all his own. He might be willing to settle for platform and rules revisions that would validate his campaign. But if he wants a Bernie night in Philadelphia when he can bring his political revolution to life — even for a few hours — it might be a small price to pay for peace."	REAL
