Critics Pounce on Madeleine Albright’s Exhortation to Women to Back Clinton	"CONCORD
column2: N.H. – Former Secretary of State Madeleine Albright offered a warning to young women who aren’t inclined to elect the first female president. “Just remember
column3: ” Ms. Albright told the crowd at a get-out-the-vote rally for Mrs. Clinton’s campaign. “There’s a special place in hell for women who don’t help each other.” The familiar phrase was […]"	REAL

column1: Clinton doubles down on disputed claim FBI found her email remarks 'truthful'	"Hillary Clinton has doubled down on her assertion that the FBI declared her public remarks on her email scandal “consistent and truthful
column2: ” despite independent fact-checkers concluding otherwise.

column1: “And as the FBI said
column2: everything that I’ve said publicly has been consistent and truthful with what I’ve told [the FBI]
column3: ” Clinton said Wednesday in an interview with Brandon Rittiman of KUSA News.

column1: Washington Post fact-checker Glenn Kessler swiftly chided the Democratic presidential candidate for repeating the ""roundly debunked"" claim.

Clinton first cited the FBI in her defense last Sunday when “Fox News Sunday” host Chris Wallace noted Director James Comey had contradicted her claim she never sent classified material from her home server.
“That's not what I heard Director Comey say … Director Comey said that my answers were truthful and what I've said is consistent with what I have told the American people
column2: that there were decisions discussed and made to classify retroactively certain of the emails
column3: ” she said.

column1: Several fact-checkers
column2: however
column3: called her out on that claim.

column1: The Washington Post's Kessler awarded her “four Pinnochios
column2: ” and noted
column3: “Comey has repeatedly not taken a stand on her public statements.”

column1: PolitiFact gave her a “Pants on Fire” rating for a lack of truthfulness and FactCheck.org declared her claims “false.”
Comey did tell Congress: “We have no basis to conclude she lied to the FBI.” But he did not say the same about her public statements.
During testimony before a House committee
column2: Comey said it was “not true” that nothing Clinton sent or received was marked classified. To the contrary
column3: he said
column4: “there was classified material emailed.

column1: Donald Trump also doubled down Thursday on his claim he saw video of Iranians taking $400 million in cash off an airplane on the same day American hostages were released. His campaign earlier said he meant that he saw television coverage of the hostages
column2: not the cash
column3: leaving an airplane.

column1: Afterward
column2: Trump once again clarified
column3: this time via Twitter."	REAL

column1: How the Clintons’ Haiti development plans succeed — and disappoint	"Deep in the Haitian countryside
column2: peanut farmer Wismith Moricette epitomizes the success of Bill and Hillary Rodham Clinton’s charitable work: Through an innovative program backed by the Clintons
column3: the 23-year-old has doubled the yield from his one-acre plot. Along with all those peanuts
column4: Moricette said
column5: have come visions of a brighter future for his wife and young son.

column1: Fifty miles away on Haiti’s north coast
column2: Anelle Germinal exemplifies another reality of the Clintons’ work here: disappointment. The 33-year-old mother of four has been standing in the baking sun every day for months waiting for work in the struggling Caracol Industrial Park
column3: which the Clintons have touted as a model that would change the economy of this impoverished country.

column1: “They said we would have work
column2: ” Germinal said
column3: “but I have nothing.”

column1: Moricette and Germinal are two faces of the Clintons’ increasingly complicated relationship with Haiti
column2: where their high-profile development efforts after a devastating earthquake in 2010 have produced both success and disillusionment.

column1: As Hillary Clinton moves toward a second run for the White House
column2: her family’s global charitable work
column3: mostly through the Clinton Foundation
column4: has come under intense scrutiny. The foundation has accepted large donations from corporations and foreign countries
column5: raising concerns that the Clintons are creating conflicts of interest by blurring the lines between their political
column6: business and charitable interests.

column1: The Washington Post reported last month that the foundation’s donors include seven foreign governments that contributed millions during Hillary Clinton’s tenure as secretary of state. Among those donations was a $500
column2: 000 contribution from the Algerian government for earthquake relief in Haiti that the foundation has acknowledged violated the terms of an ethics agreement with the Obama administration.

column1: The Clintons’ defenders have dismissed concerns about the donations as political sniping
column2: saying the test of the foundation is not where it gets its money but how it spends it. They said their work has created economic opportunity
column3: improved lives for women and girls
column4: raised health standards and fought the effects of climate change across the developing world.

column1: The work has been especially visible in Haiti
column2: where the Clintons first traveled as young newlyweds in 1975 and where many people credit them with drawing the world’s attention immediately after the earthquake
column3: which killed more than 200
column4: 000 people.

column1: With former president Clinton assigned by the United Nations to head up the emergency recovery effort and Hillary Clinton guiding official U.S. assistance as secretary of state
column2: the couple helped a relief effort that has included some of the world’s richest people
column3: biggest celebrities and most successful businesses. The Clintons also helped mobilize an effort in which international donors pledged $10.4 billion
column4: including $3.9 billion from the United States.

column1: Greg Milne
column2: director of the Clinton Foundation’s Haiti Program
column3: said projects include efforts that have helped more than 2
column4: 000 small farmers
column5: an artisan-goods company that employs more than 300 people
column6: a fish-farming operation
column7: a cholera treatment center and improvements to schools in some of Haiti’s poorest slums.

column1: Clinton supporters also point out that their successes have come amid Haiti’s chaotic political situation — parliament is not functioning and President Michel Martelly
column2: dogged by scandal
column3: is ruling with virtually no checks on his power — which is marked by endemic corruption
column4: weak institutions
column5: poverty
column6: poor public education
column7: terrible roads and other factors that have historically made it extremely difficult for development efforts to succeed.

column1: The country has long had a fraught relationship with foreigners who come to invest and provide aid. Haitians often regard them with gratitude for desperately needed resources and
column2: at the same time
column3: with suspicion that their motives are more to make a profit in Haiti than to help it.

column1: Nevertheless
column2: the Clintons are facing a growing backlash that too little has been accomplished in the past five years and that some of the most high-profile projects they have backed — including a just-opened Marriott
column3: another luxury hotel and the industrial park — have helped foreign investors and Haiti’s wealthy elites more than its poor.

column1: “Bill Clinton is a good guy and well-intentioned
column2: but the people here don’t think so — they think he’s here making money
column3: ” said Leslie Voltaire
column4: a former government official who worked with Clinton on post-earthquake reconstruction. “There is a lot of resentment about Clinton here. People have not seen results. . . . They say that Clinton used Haiti.”

column1: In January
column2: Haitian expatriates picketed the Clinton Foundation’s New York headquarters
column3: demanding to know why more progress has not been made with the billions in international aid pledged after the quake.

column1: Said Raymond Joseph
column2: a former Haitian ambassador to the United States: “People are asking
column3: ‘What has Bill Clinton done for us?’ ”

column1: The Clintons’ long influence in Haiti is hard to overstate.
As president in 1994
column2: Bill Clinton deployed about 20
column3: 000 U.S. troops to Haiti to restore President Jean-Bertrand Aristide
column4: who had been ousted in a coup in 1991. Clinton’s trade policies as president
column5: which he later called a “mistake
column6: ” were devastating to Haiti’s rice production and made it harder for the country to feed itself.

column2: Clinton was named U.N. special envoy for Haiti
column3: and he has visited the country 37 times since then.

column1: After the earthquake
column2: Clinton united with former president George W. Bush to create the Clinton Bush Haiti Fund
column3: which distributed $54.4 million in the two years after the earthquake. Separately
column4: the Clinton Foundation has spent more than $30 million in Haiti and led efforts through the Clinton Global Initiative to persuade private companies to spend vastly more.

column1: “What I think most people don’t know
column2: even if they’ve been on the ground there
column3: is these people are immensely talented
column4: ” Bill Clinton said in a 2010 interview with NPR. “They have suffered from 200 years of outside and inside abuses and neglect and misgovernment. And a lot of the people who’ve gone there even to help them in the best of faith have done so in a way that would never have allowed them to support themselves and to lift themselves up. And now there is a true consensus for and determination for a sustainable
column5: comprehensive
column6: long-term
column7: modern society in Haiti. And they can do it.”

column1: But as the initial emergency response has evolved into efforts to ensure Haiti’s long-term development
column2: Haitians increasingly complain that the Clintons’ most ambitious plans are disconnected from the realities of most people in the poorest country in the Western Hemisphere.

column1: For instance
column2: the Clinton Bush Haiti Fund invested more than $2 million in the Royal Oasis ­hotel
column3: where a sleek suite with hardwood floors costs more than $200 a night and the shops sell $150 designer purses and $120 men’s dress shirts.

column1: One recent afternoon
column2: the hotel appeared largely empty
column3: and with tourism hardly booming five years after the quake
column4: locals fear it may be failing. A spokeswoman for Occidental Hotels
column5: the chain that runs the hotel
column6: said that ­occupancy is up this year and that the project will “mature in the long run.”

column1: Bill Clinton also introduced Marriott officials to Denis O’Brien
column2: an Irish telecom billionaire who has contributed millions to the Clinton Foundation. The result is a $45 million Marriott hotel that opened this month in central Port-au-Prince. O’Brien said no Clinton money was invested in the project.

column1: The ultra-modern hotel is adjacent to the headquarters of Digicel
column2: a communications giant owned by O’Brien. When The Post visited recently
column3: many
column4: if not most
column5: guests seemed to be foreign businessmen connected to Digicel.

column1: Clinton defenders argue that hotels that cater to well-heeled foreign guests can still buy local products and provide local jobs
column2: and those guests are often involved in business investments or aid projects that benefit the neediest Haitians.

column1: O’Brien said his hotel employs 200 Haitians
column2: is filled with locally purchased art and serves food from Haiti. O’Brien leads the Haiti Action Network
column3: a collection of private businesses that have committed through the Clinton Global Initiative to spend $500 million on projects in Haiti. He and his company just built 150 schools and rebuilt Port-au-Prince’s historic Iron Market.

column1: “I don’t know any modern leader that has spent more time helping a country and being so effective
column2: ” O’Brien said of Bill Clinton. “He works like a demon in the developing world. Nobody is doing that. Is Tony Blair doing that?”

column1: Other Clinton-backed projects have not delivered on lofty promises: A 2011 housing expo that cost more than $2 million
column2: including $500
column3: 000 from the Clinton Foundation
column4: was supposed to be a model for thousands of new units but instead has resulted in little more than a few dozen abandoned model homes occupied by squatters.

column1: Controversy surrounding the Clintons only deepened with the recent revelation
column2: contained in an upcoming book by Peter Schweizer
column3: that Tony Rodham — Hillary Clinton’s younger brother — serves on the advisory board of a U.S.-based company that in 2012 won one of Haiti’s first two gold-mining permits in 50 years. After objection from the Haitian Senate
column4: the permits have been placed on hold.

column1: “Neither Bill Clinton nor the brother of Hillary Clinton are individuals who share the interests of the Haitian people
column2: ” said Samuel Nesner
column3: an anti-mining activist who thinks mining poses great environmental risks and will mainly benefit foreign investors. “They are part of the elite class who are operating to exploit the Haitian people.”

column1: Clinton Foundation officials said Bill Clinton had been unaware of Rodham’s involvement in the mine project. A spokesman for Hillary Clinton said she does not know the chief executive of the mine.
“I strongly believe the Clintons came to Haiti in good faith and they wanted to have an impact
column2: ” said Jean-Max Bellerive
column3: who was Haiti’s prime minister at the time of the earthquake and served as co-chairman with Bill Clinton on the Interim Haiti Recovery Commission. (Bellerive is also on the mining company’s advisory board.)

column1: But
column2: Bellerive said
column3: the former president was hampered by a “weak” staff of American aides who were “more interested in supporting Clinton than helping Haiti.” Echoing a common sentiment in Haiti
column4: Bellerive also said Clinton should have listened more carefully to the opinions and needs of ordinary Haitians: “How do you want a guy coming from Davos or Dubai to get the real feeling for what’s happening downstairs?”

column1: Milne
column2: of the Clinton Foundation
column3: said the criticism is wrong and unsurprising.

column1: “President Clinton is one of the most dedicated and highest-profile advocates for Haiti
column2: and he is still engaged while others have moved on
column3: ” he said. “So it’s not surprising that
column4: for some
column5: he is an easy target for natural frustration that the change we all want isn’t happening faster.”

column1: Milne said the country has experienced strong economic growth in recent years
column2: with more Haitians employed and more children in school.

column1: “Is Haiti building back better?” Milne said
column2: using a phrase that the Clintons frequently quote. “In many ways
column3: yes
column4: though challenges remain.”

column1: Paul Farmer
column2: a doctor whose Partners in Health has helped provide medical care in rural Haiti since the 1980s and whose health network has received more than $1.8 million from the Clinton Bush Haiti Fund for a medical residency program
column3: also praised the Clintons’ work. He said he forged partnerships at CGI meetings with private businesses and other charities for a variety of projects he said would not have taken place without the Clinton connection.

column1: He said that by any objective measure
column2: Haiti has been improving
column3: in part because of the Clintons’ efforts.

column1: “Is the whole country built back better? I doubt it
column2: ” Farmer said. “Water insecurity and food insecurity are very pressing problems. But if you look at the health statistics for Haiti . . . infant mortality
column3: child mortality — they’re all improving.”

column1: Still
column2: even some who have benefited from Clinton-backed programs have grown disillusioned.

column1: “I read that Bill Clinton is the most popular politician in America
column2: but he couldn’t get elected mayor in Haiti today
column3: ” said Jacky Lumarque
column4: rector of Quisqueya University
column5: a private school that was damaged in the earthquake and received $914
column6: 000 from the Clinton Bush Haiti Fund to create an entrepreneurship center.

column1: Lumarque said the program has helped hundreds of Haitians turn their informal street businesses into formal entities that keep records
column2: pay taxes and have potential for growth.

column1: He said it has been a huge success — but stands apart from the usual strategy of foreign groups
column2: including the Clintons
column3: who tend to favor projects imposed by well-meaning foreigners that are more “about Haiti” than “for Haiti.”

column1: The entrepreneurship center
column2: Lumarque said
column3: “is an example of what Clinton can do
column4: in spite of himself.”

column1: When Bill Clinton came here late last month to help inaugurate the new Marriott
column2: he made a side trip by helicopter to Haiti’s central plateau to have a look at a Clinton-backed program that is revolutionizing the peanut-farming industry.

column1: The Acceso Peanut Enterprise Corp. was started with a $1.25 million grant from the Clinton Giustra Enterprise Partnership
column2: which is headed by Bill Clinton and Canadian mining executive and philanthropist Frank Giustra
column3: as well as the charitable foundation of Mexican billionaire Carlos Slim.

column1: Acceso buys feed
column2: fertilizer and fungicide at bulk rates
column3: then sells them to farmers for far less than normal prices. Acceso also hires tractors for farmers who otherwise would be using an ox and plow.

column1: Robert Johnson
column2: an American who runs the program
column3: said the improvements are vastly increasing yields
column4: quality and farmers’ profits.

column1: He said Acceso worked with about 1
column2: 000 farmers last year and bought about 120 metric tons of peanuts. This year
column3: it expects to triple the number of farmers and buy almost five times as much peanut tonnage.

column1: At least half of Acceso’s sales have gone to two large Haitian factories that produce a peanut-based paste that is given to malnourished children. Most of the rest goes to local peanut-butter producers
column2: he said. The program’s success
column3: Johnson said
column4: comes from its market-driven approach: It’s not a charity
column5: it’s a business with a charitable purpose.

column1: “We’re building something that is going to be sustainable
column2: ” he said. “We talk to the farmers. We’re not going to just bring in something that someone thought up in ­Davos.”

column1: The program is branching out into lime-growing
column2: and Clinton visited a site last month where thousands of seedlings are being cultivated by dozens of workers.

column1: Benel Auguste
column3: is one of the small landowners who rented his plot
column4: about a third of an acre
column5: to Acceso to plant limes. “It’s a good idea; it’s going to work
column6: ” he said. “We know limes and we need them. We can do this.”

column1: The Clintons also were enthusiastic backers of the Caracol Industrial Park
column2: which was built on 600 acres of farmland just east of ­the port city Cap-Haitien.

column1: They agreed with economists
column2: particularly Oxford University development specialist Paul Collier
column3: who concluded that Haiti is an ideal place to create mass jobs in garment factories because of its proximity to the United States
column4: favorable trade agreements and cheap labor.

column1: The Clintons helped Haitian officials identify Sae-A Trading Co.
column2: which operates factories across the developing world and sews garments for giants such as Target
column3: Gap and Wal-Mart
column4: as a potential major investor.

column1: As secretary of state
column2: Hillary Clinton
column3: along with top aide ­Cheryl Mills
column4: lobbied for the project with South Korean officials and hosted Sae-A executives in Washington to press the plan.

column1: Bill Clinton attended the Sae-A contract-signing ceremony in Port-au-Prince on Jan. 11
column2: 2011 — a day before the first anniversary of the earthquake. He later laid the first stone of the park’s construction. And then in October 2012
column3: the Clintons
column4: Martelly and other officials attended the ribbon-cutting.

column1: Speaking to a group of investors at the ceremony
column2: officials and celebrities that included actors Sean Penn and Ben Stiller
column3: as well as business moguls Donna Karan and Richard Branson
column4: Hillary Clinton said it represented “a new day for Haiti and a new model for how the international community practices development.”

column1: “Haiti is truly open for business
column2: and we want your help
column3: ” she said. “We see this partnership between governments like our own and the private sector as absolutely essential in promoting and supporting long-term prosperity in Haiti. We know very well that long-term prosperity cannot come from just the provision of aid. There must be trade and investment like we have seen here today.”

column1: Today
column2: Sae-A employs about 4
column3: 500 people. Company spokesman Lon Garwood said the operation has been steadily growing and will open a new facility next month. Henri-Claude Müller-Poitevien
column4: a Haitian government official who works in the apparel industry
column5: said the Caracol project is on schedule and continues to expand.

column1: A power plant was built
column2: but plans for a new port at the industrial park to carry finished goods to the United States have been shelved. Residents of the plant’s housing project say their land floods when it rains
column3: and few said they think the plant will ever create the number of jobs originally promised.

column1: “I believe that the momentum to attract people there in a massive way is past
column2: ” said Bellerive
column3: the former prime minister. “You can do interesting things with Caracol
column4: but you have to reinvent the concept. Today
column5: it has failed.”

column1: Each morning
column2: crowds line up outside the park’s big front gate
column3: which is guarded by four men in crisp khaki uniforms carrying shotguns. They wait in a sliver of shade next to a cinder-block wall
column4: many holding résumés in envelopes. Most said they have been coming every day for months
column5: waiting for jobs that pay about $5 a day.

column1: From his envelope
column2: Jean Mito Palvetus
column4: pulled out a diploma attesting that he had completed 200 hours of training with the U.S. Agency for International Development on an industrial sewing machine.

column1: “I have three kids and a wife
column2: and I can’t support them
column3: ” he said
column4: sweating in the hot morning sun. “I have a diploma
column5: but I still can’t get a job here. I still have nothing.”

column1: Tom Hamburger in Washington contributed to this report."	REAL
Of Course Facebook Is Biased. Its Real Problem Is That It Won’t Admit It.	"Facebook must have thought the online news game was pretty easy. Two years ago
column2: it plucked a small team of about a dozen bright
column3: hungry twentysomethings fresh out of journalism school or entry-level reporting jobs. It stuck them in a basement
column4: paid them contractor wages
column5: and put them to work selecting and briefly summarizing the day’s top news stories and linking to the news sites that covered them. It called them curators
column6: not reporters. Their work appeared in the “Trending” section of the Facebook home page and mobile app
column7: where it helped to define the day’s news for millions of Facebook users.

column1: On Tuesday
column2: Facebook became the subject of a Senate inquiry over claims of anti-conservative bias in its Trending section. Senate Commerce Committee Chairman John Thune
column3: a South Dakota Republican
column4: sent Mark Zuckerberg a letter asking a series of pointed questions about how Facebook chooses stories for the section
column5: how it trains its curators
column6: who’s responsible for their decisions
column7: and what steps it’s taking to investigate the bias claims. He also asks for detailed records of stories that the company decided not to include in the Trending section despite their popularity among Facebook users.

column1: The inquiry followed a report by Gizmodo’s Michael Nunez on Monday
column2: in which anonymous former Facebook “curators” described the subjective process by which they assembled the Trending section. Facebook had publicly portrayed the section—which you can find near the top right of Facebook.com or under the search tab on the Facebook app—as an algorithmically driven reflection of the most popular stories its users are reading at any given time. But the ex-curators said they often filtered out stories that were deemed questionable and added others they deemed worthy. One
column3: a self-identified conservative
column4: complained that this led to subtle yet pervasive liberal bias
column5: since most of the curators were politically liberal themselves. Popular stories from conservative sites such as Breitbart
column6: for instance
column7: were allegedly omitted unless more mainstream publications such as the New York Times also picked them up.

column1: None of this should come as a surprise to any thoughtful person who has worked as a journalist. Humans are biased. Objectivity is a myth
column2: or at best an ideal that can be loosely approached through the very careful practice of trained professionals. The news simply is not neutral. Neither is “curation
column3: ” for that matter
column4: in either the journalistic or artistic application of the term.

column1: There are ways to grapple with this problem honestly—to attempt to identify and correct for one’s biases
column2: to scrupulously disclose them
column3: to employ an ideologically diverse staff
column4: perhaps even to reject objectivity as an ideal and embrace subjectivity. But you can’t begin to address the subjective nature of news without first acknowledging it. And Facebook has gone out of its way to avoid doing that
column5: for reasons that are central to its identity as a technology company.

column1: For that matter
column2: you don’t get that big by admitting that you’re a media company. As the New York Times’ John Herrman and Mike Isaac point out
column3: 65 percent of Americans surveyed by Pew view the news media as a “negative influence on the country.” For technology companies
column4: that number is just 17 percent. It’s very much in Facebook’s interest to remain a social network in the public’s eyes
column5: even in the face of mounting evidence that it’s something much bigger than that. And it’s in Facebook’s interest to shift responsibility for controversial decisions from humans
column6: whom we know to be biased
column7: to algorithms
column8: which we tend to lionize.

column1: Human values shape the Trending section
column2: too. The algorithm that surfaces the stories might skirt questions of bias by simply ranking them in order of popularity
column3: thus delegating responsibility for story selection from Facebook’s employees to its users. Even that—the notion that what’s popular is worth highlighting—represents a human value judgment
column4: albeit one that’s not particularly vulnerable to accusations of political bias. (That’s why Twitter isn’t in the same hot water over its own simpler trending topics module.)

column1: The problem with an algorithm that simply harnesses the wisdom of the crowd is that the crowd isn’t always wise. The most popular stories at any given time might well be misleading
column2: or sensationalist
column3: or even full of lies. That’s why Facebook felt the need to hire humans to oversee it. This is in keeping with the company’s broader push for what it calls quality content
column4: another term that entails value judgments without copping to them.

column1: But Facebook instead opted to hire cheap contractors and went on to claim that their role is simply to “confirm that the topics are in fact trending news in the real world and not
column2: for example
column3: similar-sounding topics or misnomers.” That’s a dubious claim
column4: even if you think the allegations of liberal bias are trumped up. If the curators’ job was really just about cleaning up the data
column5: Facebook seems to have forgotten to tell that to the curators themselves
column6: who described their mandate very differently to Gizmodo. They said they were encouraged to prioritize stories from certain outlets deemed reputable; to avoid news about
column7: among other topics
column8: Facebook itself; and to replace the word Twitter in headlines with something more vague
column9: like social media. That may not be political bias
column10: but it’s bias all the same. They also described choosing stories for the Trending section that may not have been surfaced by the algorithm but that seemed to them to be important or worthwhile
column11: like stories about conflict in Syria or the Black Lives Matter movement.

column1: The problem will not be solved by firing bad apples or instituting tougher guidelines. The only way for Facebook to extricate itself from this mess is to admit that journalism isn’t as simple as it thought. It’s to stop treating “curators” like drones and stop treating news like a data set to be optimized. It’s to build a real human curation team with a real editor in charge and an ethos and a mission and an understanding of the responsibilities involved in shaping how the news is framed to 1.6 billion people. Surely a company that pays its interns $11
column2: 000 a month in salary and benefits can afford it."	REAL

column1: Tax Calculator: The federal debt	"The federal government must make regular interest payments on the money it has borrowed to finance past deficits – that is
column2: on the national debt held by the public.

column1: The Congressional Budget Office has estimated that the federal government’s net interest payments on that debt will total $229 billion in the 2015 fiscal year. Working Americans end up having to foot that very large bill to varying degrees based on each individual taxpayer’s adjusted gross income.
Click here to see your share of the federal debt.

And the CBO expects that this challenge will accelerate over the next decade. Current interest rates are low by historical standards and higher interest rates means higher interest payments. It’s projected that net interest costs will more than triple over the next decade
column2: reaching $808 billion in 2025.

column1: These numbers pose a real threat. The CBO has issued warnings about the serious negative consequences that such high and rising debt and interest payments on the debt could have on both the economy and the federal budget.
“The large amount of debt might restrict policymakers’ ability to use tax and spending policies to respond to unexpected future challenges
column2: such as economic downturns or financial crises
column3: ” the CBO said in a recent report.

column1: In the same report
column2: they also cautioned that continued growth in the debt could lead investors to doubt the government’s willingness or ability to pay its obligations
column3: which would require the government to pay much higher interest rates on its borrowing going forward."	REAL

column1: Trump and advisers remain split on how far to move toward the middle	"Ten days after he appointed new campaign leadership
column2: Donald Trump and many of his closest aides and allies remain divided on whether to adopt more mainstream stances or stick with the hard-line conservative positions at the core of his candidacy
column3: according to people involved in the discussions.

column1: Trump has been flooded with conflicting advice about where to land
column2: with the tensions vividly illustrated this week as the GOP nominee publicly wrestled with himself on the details of his signature issue: immigration.

column1: A particular flash point has been whether to forcibly deport an estimated 11 million illegal immigrants from the country
column2: a move Trump long advocated but is now reconsidering.

column1: “He has been listening to a wide range of opinions on that
column2: ” said former New York mayor Rudy Giuliani
column3: who has been at Trump’s side nearly constantly over the past week. “As you might imagine
column4: there are different opinions on this
column5: even in his campaign. In a very thoughtful way
column6: he’s trying to figure what the right position is.”

column1: “By the way
column2: ” Giuliani added
column3: “that’s what everybody criticized him for in the past: that he’s not able to do that. He actually is able to do that.”

column1: The conversations in recent days have featured voices from a range of Republican views
column2: all jockeying to tilt the businessman’s politics in their direction
column3: according to those involved. Trump tends to echo the words of the last person with whom he spoke
column4: making direct access to him even more valuable
column5: the people said
column6: speaking on the condition of anonymity to talk about internal campaign discussions.

column1: Those pushing Trump to soften his stances and tone — and who have gained immense influence in recent days — include Giuliani
column2: New Jersey Gov. Chris Christie and former Fox News chief Roger Ailes
column3: a longtime ally who has no formal role with the campaign but talks to the candidate frequently and attended a strategy session last weekend. At recent private fundraisers
column4: many Republican donors have also urged Trump to adopt a different pitch and rethink his priorities.

column1: [Trump ‘softening’ on immigration? Many supporters don’t seem to mind]
Meanwhile
column2: Trump continues to discuss immigration policy with Sen. Jeff Sessions (Ala.)
column3: who is seen as the populist force behind much of his candidacy. While he has defended and encouraged Trump’s deliberations
column4: Sessions is considered a balancing force against more centrist appeals. So is new campaign chief executive Stephen Bannon
column5: the former head of Breitbart News
column6: the hard-charging conservative website.

column1: Trump was joined on the trail this week by Giuliani and Sessions
column2: along with Stephen Miller
column3: a former aide to Sessions who has become a well-trusted confidant. His New York-based children continue to play an outsize role.

column1: But any suggestion of change has alarmed some conservatives and ardent backers. Firebrand commentator Ann Coulter declared this week that it was “a mistake” for Trump to consider abandoning his support for mass deportations and said his tone “sounds very consultant to me.”
The back-and-forth over immigration comes amid broader efforts by Trump to reach out to voters beyond the disaffected whites who compose his base
column2: including events such as a roundtable Friday with Hispanic business leaders in Las Vegas. Trump also lashed out this week at his Democratic rival
column3: Hillary Clinton
column4: for accusing him of appealing to racist elements
column5: repeatedly labeling her a “bigot” because he says her policies don’t help minorities.

column1: Last year
column2: Trump cast illegal immigrants as being mostly violent criminals
column3: and he rolled out an immigration plan that embraced ideas that had long dwelled at the fringes of the GOP: no longer granting citizenship to children born in the United States to illegal immigrants
column4: constructing a massive wall along the border with Mexico and perhaps restricting some legal forms of immigration. In interviews
column5: Trump added that he would form a “deportation force” to remove the millions of immigrants living in the country illegally.

column1: But Saturday
column2: Trump asked a panel of Hispanic advisers for alternate ideas and made clear that he was willing to change on the issue. The next day
column3: newly installed campaign manager Kellyanne Conway
column4: who has advised GOP candidates for years on how to win over swing voters
column5: said in a CNN interview that Trump’s position on creating a deportation force was “to be determined.”

column1: Over the next few days
column2: Trump took a variety of positions that created a frenzy of confusion over where exactly he stands. On Tuesday
column3: Trump said he was open to “softening” the rules for the millions of immigrants who came to the country illegally but are living peaceful and prosperous lives
column4: only to say Thursday that his position is “hardening.”

column1: At an immigration-focused town hall in Texas on Tuesday
column2: which was later broadcast on Fox News
column3: Trump repeatedly polled his audience on what he should do
column4: allowing his internal conflicts to play out publicly.

column1: “Can we go through a process? Or do you think they have to get out?” he asked the audience. “Tell me. I mean
column2: I don’t know
column3: you tell me.”

column1: Trump provided the crowd a sympathetic portrait of a theoretical illegal immigrant who has been in the country more than a decade
column2: building a life with children and a stable job. He repeatedly asked if that sort of person should be allowed to stay or be kicked out of the country
column3: getting results that were often difficult to measure. At one point
column4: Trump asked who in the crowd wanted all illegal immigrants thrown out
column5: even the law-abiding ones
column6: and a man stood up and bellowed: “I do!”

column1: Fox News’s Sean Hannity then asked Trump: “You heard from the audience. What does your gut tell you you want to do?”
“Well
column2: look
column3: this is like a poll
column4: this is like a poll
column5: ” Trump said. “And I love the guy that stood up and said — where is that guy? I love this guy. That’s my guy. I mean
column6: I get it. I get it. And I understand what you’re saying. But this is sort of like a poll. And this is what I’m getting all over the country.”

column1: Trump’s often contradictory comments on deportations came during interviews with Fox News or CNN
column2: not during his campaign rallies. For two weeks
column3: Trump has been reading prepared remarks from a teleprompter
column4: a machine he had long cursed. As the week progressed
column5: his control slipped and he went off-script more often — saying at a rally in Ohio on Monday that some urban areas are more dangerous than war zones and making a joke in Tampa on Wednesday about Clinton being medicated.

column1: This week the campaign twice started to plan an event where Trump could give an immigration speech — an opportunity for him to settle on a position and document it — only to cancel without a clear explanation.
[Inside Donald Trump’s new strategy to counter the view of many that he is racist]
Trump’s comment about being open to “softening” laws to help illegal immigrants came Tuesday
column2: the same day Coulter released her new book
column3: “In Trump We Trust
column4: ” in which she writes that anything Trump does could be forgiven
column5: “except change his immigration policies.” During an MSNBC interview that night
column6: Coulter was obviously frustrated and threatened to cancel her book tour if the candidate clearly changed his position.

column1: “I think this is a mistake. I’ve thought he’s made other mistakes
column2: and I’ve given him constructive criticism when I think he makes a mistake
column3: ” she said. “I think this is a mistake.”

column1: MSNBC’s Chris Matthews asked: “Does he take your criticism?”
“Um
column2: ” Coulter responded. “I haven’t had a lot
column3: but yeah. No
column4: he does listen to people. And I’m not advising him or anything
column5: but I did write this magnificent book.”

column1: By Wednesday
column2: Coulter seemed confident again in Trump’s candidacy as she attended a book party in Washington and told Bloomberg News’s Joshua Green: “My worship for him is like the people of North Korea worship their Dear Leader — blind loyalty. Once he gave that Mexican rapist speech
column3: I’ll walk across glass for him. That’s basically it. . . . I’ll criticize him
column4: and I have
column5: but it’s all minor stylistic stuff. We all want to shoot him at various times.”

column1: Thursday
column2: Trump took a different tone in an interview with CNN’s Anderson Cooper and said that he foresees “a lot of people being deported
column3: ” although he admitted such deportations could not all happen at once. Trump also doubled down on the notion that a majority of illegal immigrants are violent criminals who will be the first to go.

column1: “And there are probably millions of them
column2: but certainly hundreds of thousands
column3: ” he said. “Big numbers. They’re out. They’re out.”

column1: At one point
column2: Cooper asked Trump
column3: “So if you haven’t committed a crime and you’ve been here for 15 years
column4: and you have a family here
column5: you have a job here
column6: will you be deported?”

column1: “We’re going to see what happens once we strengthen up our border
column2: ” Trump replied
column3: describing that strength in detail. “And then we’re going to see what happens. But there is a very good chance the answer could be yes. We’re going to see what happens.”"	REAL

column1: Clinton in the final stretch: winning over anti-Trump contingent may be best play	"Hillary Clinton’s summer ends abruptly on Monday. For several weeks
column2: the presidential frontrunner has toured the homes of America’s rich and famous
column3: hosted by Justin Timberlake
column4: welcomed by Magic Johnson and serenaded by Jimmy Buffett
column5: Jon Bon Jovi and Paul McCartney.

column1: It all helped swell Democratic coffers by a record $143m in August
column2: crucial ammunition for the 64 days of TV advertising left between now and the general election. It also allowed an exhausted campaign to recharge its batteries following months on the road and July’s convention in Philadelphia.

column1: But on Labor Day
column2: Clinton swaps the beaches of Cape Cod and Long Island for the rust-belt towns of Ohio and Iowa
column3: scenes of her bruising primary race against Bernie Sanders and home to a stubbornly loyal pockets of blue-collar support for Donald Trump.

column1: She won’t be alone. Monday’s events in Cleveland and the Quad Cities
column2: industrial towns bordering Iowa and Illinois
column3: will debut a new campaign plane
column4: large enough to carry the traveling reporters who were hitherto consigned to tagging along behind.

column1: Journalists have complained for months about a lack of access to Clinton
column2: who has not held a conference for 276 days. Her campaign has accused the media of fixating on that daily tally and ignoring the interviews she gives to select cable anchors or local news stations.

column1: “This 257 days nonsense is ludicrous. When has it been the norm that a presidential candidate regularly does press conferences?” spokesman Nick Merrill askedreporters on Thursday. He then promised one “soon”.
The new aircraft is nothing if not symbolic: it launches the start of an intense period of travel and scrutiny during the debates and rallies before election day on 8 November.
The plane also provides room for key Clinton aides to escape their headquarters in Brooklyn and gain important time with the boss. Her loyal gatekeeper Huma Abedin will likely stand guard
column2: returning to the plane after a period of absence that aides insist has nothing to do with the very public break-up of her marriage to former congressman Anthony Weiner.

column1: Campaign manager Robby Mook and chairman John Podesta have their own challenge: working out where to direct the plane. Some campaign destinations are obvious
column2: such as the swing states of Ohio
column3: Florida
column4: New Hampshire
column5: Nevada
column6: Iowa and North Carolina. Some in rust-belt states such as Pennsylvania
column7: Wisconsin and Michigan are getting more attention this time thanks to Trump’s appeal to the white working class. Colorado and Virginia look well out of his reach.

column1: The bigger question is whether to take the battle into enemy territory. Trump has proved so unpopular among some Republican voters
column2: minorities and women
column3: that deep red territory is perhaps in play. States such as Arizona
column4: Utah and Georgia
column5: which haven’t voted Democrat in decades
column6: could be vulnerable in the winner-take-all electoral college system – and Clinton has superior fundraising and a vastly more organised network of campaign offices.

column1: Her campaign is at least testing the waters. On Friday
column2: Clinton began airing TV ads in Arizona
column3: where Mitt Romney beat Barack Obama by nearly 10 points. Clinton’s husband is the only Democrat to have won the state in a presidential election since 1952.

column1: Her campaign is also spending money in Nebraska
column2: one of two states that splits electoral college votes and therefore offers Clinton a chance to peel off electors from the relatively liberal city of Omaha. Even Utah
column3: where Trump has riled conservative Mormons
column4: has seen the Clinton campaign open a field office.

column1: Whether these moves amount to a radical new strategy or clever feints to trick Trump is not clear. Some inside Clinton’s Brooklyn headquarters are reportedly cheering that moves into Republican heartlands appear to have Trump spending time and money in places he ought to take for granted – for instance
column2: by staging a major immigration speech in Arizona.

column1: Yet the confidence could easily become complacency too. Clinton’s healthy lead following the party’s convention has eroded in recent weeks
column2: slipping down to the low single digits in some key states. Not only are the headline polls too close for comfort
column3: but Americans still stubbornly dislike Clinton and Trump by enormous margins. A record number of Americans now say they dislike Clinton
column4: according to a Washington Post-ABC News poll that showed 41% of Americans have a favorable impression of her
column5: while 56% have an unfavorable one.

column1: Though she enjoys a powerful coalition of support in Washington
column2: particularly from the Obama administration
column3: political surrogates cannot necessarily translate her shower their popularity on friends.

column1: “This ain’t over man. This is not over
column2: ” Joe Biden warned at a rally for Clinton in Cleveland on Thursday
column3: where one supporter confessed he was actually planning to vote Trump but came along because he just liked the vice-president.

column1: The scepticism of many independent voters may also help explain the decision by Clinton’s communications director Jennifer Palmieri to shield the candidate from the rough-and-tumble of open press conferences
column2: where generally risks are high and rewards low.

column1: Clinton’s campaign has expressed frustration with the questions of trustworthiness
column2: particularly over her private emails system that appear to reinforce a reputation of favoritism and privilege built up by the Clintons. Aides also complain that she does not get the recognition she deserves for developing many more new policy ideas than most candidates.

column1: “People criticise me for having so many plans
column2: ” Clinton told a lukewarm audience of military veterans in Cincinnati on Wednesday. “People say
column3: Oh there she goes with another plan about mental health
column4: or whatever
column5: ” she added. “But I have this old fashioned idea that if you are going to ask to be president if you have to have a plan.”

column1: Yet the campaign is under no illusion about the nature of this year’s fight. If hunkering down away from the press while outspending Trump – she has raised more money than the GDP of small Pacific nations – is what it takes to beat him
column2: then so be it.

column1: “This is not a normal election
column2: ” Clinton said at the American Legion convention in Cincinnati. “This election shouldn’t be about ideology
column3: it’s not just about differences over policy. It’s about who has the experience and temperament to serve as president and commander and chief.”

column1: “The stakes this fall are as high as any election in our lifetimes.”
Huma Abedin
column2: Clinton’s right-hand woman and gatekeeper. Robby Mook
column3: the campaign manager in charge of her election machine. John Podesta
column4: family friend
column5: campaign chairman and former chief of staff to Bill Clinton. Jennifer Palmieri
column6: former Obama communications director now fielding flak for Clinton. Neera Tanden
column7: key figure in transition team preparing the clan for power.

column1: The campaign slogan “stronger together” captures Clinton’s broad belief in a more socially inclusive America
column2: but the underlying policies range widely from a jobs program and infrastructure spending
column3: to making college more affordable and tackling climate change. On trade and social security
column4: she has moved to the left
column5: rhetorically
column6: at least.

column1: Clinton’s experience as secretary of state
column2: senator and activist first lady make her one of the most qualified candidates to run for office. Supporters also point to her resilience in the face of setbacks
column3: long track record of social activism and historic achievement as the first woman nominee of a major party.

column1: The biggest handicap according to opinion polls is a perceived lack of trust among voters
column2: something exacerbated by years of attacks on Clinton family “scandals” and an ongoing controversy over her private email server. Voters sometimes also talk about finding her inauthentic and lacking warmth.

column1: African Americans
column2: women
column3: Latinos
column4: college-educated men – in short
column5: a vast swath of the increasingly diverse US electorate. Geographically
column6: the strongest support for Democrats is heavily concentrated on the coasts however."	REAL

column1: Vatican Ends Scrutiny Of U.S. Nuns	"Updated at 10:04 a.m. ET

The Vatican has announced an end to an overhaul of the Leadership Conference of Women Religious — an abrupt conclusion to a five-year doctrinal overhaul of the main umbrella group for nuns in the U.S. that began in 2012.
The Vatican said Thursday that it has accepted a report on the overhaul of the LCWR ""marking the conclusion of the Doctrinal Assessment"" of the umbrella group.
NPR's Sylvia Poggioli tells our Newscast unit the unexpected announcement is seen as a sign of Pope Francis' focus on a more merciful church.
LCWR leaders met with Pope Francis later Thursday
column2: during their annual visit to Rome. David Gibson of Religion News Service described the meeting as ""another indicator of the thaw in relations."" He added:

column1: The Rev. James Martin
column2: SJ.
column3: editor at large of the Jesuit magazine America
column4: said in a Facebook post that the LCWR agreed to implement some changes
column5: ""mainly regarding speakers and liturgies at its annual conventions. But overall
column6: the operations of the LCWR remains intact.""

column1: Joshua J. McElwee
column2: writing in the National Catholic Reporter
column3: said the ""news seems to bring to an end what had been an especially contentious period between the women religious and the Vatican.""

column1: At issue was an investigation of the LCWR that began in 2012 under Cardinal William Levada
column2: the previous head of the Vatican's theological watchdog. As NPR's Scott Neuman reported at the time
column3: ""the Vatican issued a report declaring that the umbrella group representing most American nuns had strayed from church doctrine and adopted 'radical feminist' views. The Disappearing Middle: Electorate Way Less Moderate Than Past Primaries	"The Disappearing Middle: Electorate Way Less Moderate Than Past Primaries
One of the biggest stories of the election cycle is turnout (as we've reported a few times now): Republican turnout has spiked far beyond 2012 levels
column2: and Democratic turnout has fallen off after the party's mammoth 2008.

column1: The tone and the turnout are vastly different between Republicans and Democrats this year
column2: but oddly enough
column3: both sides have something crucial in common: their voters are far less moderate than they were in their last primaries.

column1: Let's start with the Republican numbers. The below chart shows the ideological difference between the Republican electorate this year and in 2012. Each dot represents one state — so
column2: for example
column3: 33 percent of Vermont Republican primary voters in 2016 said they considered themselves moderate or liberal
column4: compared to 53 percent in 2012. That puts Vermont at negative-20 for ""somewhat conservative"" — the most extreme result we found among the 15 GOP states for which there was sufficient exit-poll data.

column1: It's true exit polls can have a margin of error
column2: but there's no mistaking a pattern here. In no state did the share of ""moderate"" and ""liberal"" GOP primary voters grow from 2012 to 2016. (The exit polls lumped moderate and liberal together in 2012
column3: so they're not separated out here.)

column1: Altogether
column2: an NPR analysis finds that the share of ""somewhat conservative"" voters on the GOP side climbed by nearly 10 percentage points in 2016 over 2012's primaries. (That is
column3: among the states with exit polling data for both years). The share who were moderate or liberal
column4: meanwhile
column5: fell by around 9 percentage points
column6: and the share who were ""very conservative"" held relatively steady.

column1: Something similar is at work on the Democratic side
column2: as well:

column1: The share of moderate and conservative Democratic voters was down — sometimes dramatically so — in most states that have voted thus far. Meanwhile
column2: the share of people who are somewhat or very liberal is way up.

column1: This year
column2: around 60 percent of Democratic primary voters said they considered themselves ""somewhat"" or ""very liberal
column3: up from around 45 percent in 2008 (once again
column4: among states with sufficient exit polling data for both years).

column1: So interestingly
column2: though voters on both sides are less moderate than in the last contests
column3: Democrats this year have more decidedly moved toward the ""very liberal"" end of the spectrum. Republican voters
column4: meanwhile
column5: are way more ""somewhat conservative"" than in 2012
column6: but don't appear to be more ""very conservative.""

column1: One thing to keep in mind: Republican turnout across the board is higher this year. That means there are still a few more moderate and liberal Republican primary and caucus voters this cycle than there were in the 2012 primaries — it's just that the number of somewhat conservative Republicans shot up way more.
Likewise
column2: Democratic turnout is down almost entirely across the board. Interestingly
column3: even with the sharp drop off in turnout
column4: multiplying the exit poll data by the turnout numbers suggests that the raw number of ""very liberal"" Democratic voters is
column5: in fact
column6: up slightly from 2008. However
column7: the number of moderate and conservative voters dropped off steeply. And even though the share of ""somewhat liberal"" voters is up
column8: the raw number is also down.

column1: But anyway: all of this could mean that a bunch of moderate and conservative Democrats who voted in 2008 stayed home this year
column2: while a lot of those somewhat and very liberal Democrats from 2008 came out again. Likewise
column3: it could mean that the Republican wave of turnout is driven largely by a bunch of ""somewhat conservative"" voters who weren't there in 2012.

column1: And looking at the results so far
column2: there are simple explanations to why this might be happening. The very-liberal Bernie Sanders is probably driving some of the turnout among very-liberal voters. It's likewise possible that the somewhat-conservative Trump is behind the bump in somewhat conservative voters in Republican primaries (while Ted Cruz does better among very conservative voters
column3: and John Kasich gets more votes among moderates).

column1: But then
column2: it might not just be candidate-driven: it's possible that lots of people have simply become more conservative or liberal than they were four or eight years ago. This is also to some degree plausible
column3: as there is evidence that Americans are getting more polarized.

column1: In other words
column2: there's a chicken-egg question here
column3: with no clear answer — chances are
column4: they're both right. To the degree that voters are more polarized
column5: they're gravitating toward more extreme candidates. And Sanders and Trump also both happen to be very good at energizing people to turn out and vote for them."	REAL

column1: AP FACT CHECK: The Republican debaters and the facts	"Ben Carson pitched a tax plan with numbers that didn't add up. Donald Trump boasted that he's paying his own way in the campaign
column2: but he isn't. Chris Christie accused the government of stealing Social Security money that it has actually borrowed -- and has been paying back with interest.

column1: Even the price of hamburger got a bad rap in the latest Republican presidential debate
column2: thanks to Ted Cruz.

column1: A look at some of the claims Wednesday night and how they compare with the facts:
CRUZ: ""If you look at a single mom buying groceries
column2: she sees hamburger prices have gone up nearly 40 percent. She sees her cost of electricity going up. She sees her health insurance going up. And loose money is one of the major problems.""

column1: THE FACTS: Americans may be facing many economic challenges
column2: but rising inflation isn't one of them. And ""loose money
column3: a way of describing the Federal Reserve's low interest rate policies
column4: isn't to blame for expensive hamburgers.

column1: Beef prices rose 21 percent in January of this year compared with a year earlier. That reflected a Midwest drought that had caused some cattle ranchers to cull their herds. Beef prices have since settled down and were up just 1 percent in September from a year earlier.
Electricity costs have actually fallen 0.4 percent during that period. Those are national averages
column2: so some local areas will have different figures. Overall
column3: inflation has remained below even the Fed's 2 percent target for the past three years. In fact
column4: the government's primary inflation measure
column5: the Consumer Price Index
column6: has actually been unchanged in the past 12 months.

column1: CARSON: His proposed flat-rate tax
column2: which would have everyone pay an income tax rate of about 15 percent
column3: ""works out very well"" in budget terms because it would spark enough economic growth to offset the lower rate.

column1: THE FACTS: Carson says his proposed tax would not increase the budget deficit because he would tax the entire economic output of the U.S. -- the gross domestic product -- plus corporate income and capital gains.
Carson has not laid out a detailed plan
column2: so it is difficult to measure how it would affect revenues or the economy. But based on what he said
column3: he's double-counting because corporate revenues are part of the GDP.

column1: A tax rate of 15 percent would be a huge tax cut for the wealthy. The top income tax rate for individuals is now 39.6 percent. The corporate tax rate for corporations is 35 percent.
To help offset the rate cuts
column2: Carson said he would ""get rid of all the deductions and all the loopholes."" That's a bold proposal
column3: considering how popular many tax breaks are
column4: including deductions for interest on home mortgages and charitable contributions
column5: as well as exemptions for health insurance and retirement savings.

column1: CHRISTIE: FBI Director James Comey said police officers are holding back ""because of a lack of support from politicians like the president of the United States.""
THE FACTS: That's not what Comey said.
In a speech last week about an alarming rise in crime
column2: Comey said some officers feel under siege because of the spread of viral videos taken by young people with cell phones. Comey said he'd heard about one police official who told his force ""their political leadership has no tolerance for a viral video.""

column1: But Comey never mentioned Obama or blamed politicians for failing to support police. And Comey made clear he didn't have data to back up his gut impression.
Christie also said when Obama was asked to speak about the issue
column2: he declined to support police. In fact
column3: Obama gave a firm defense of police Tuesday
column4: telling a police chiefs convention that ""this country is safer because of your efforts.""

column1: TRUMP: ""I'm putting up 100 percent of my own money.""
THE FACTS: No
column2: he's not.

column1: Of $3.9 million raised for his campaign in the latest fundraising quarter
column2: only $100
column3: 000 came from his own pocket. That was one major revelation from the latest batch of presidential fundraising reports
column4: filed Oct. 15 with the Federal Election Commission.

column1: That's a drastic shift from his springtime fundraising report
column2: when he loaned his campaign nearly all of the $1.9 million it had.

column1: BUSH: ""Marco
column2: when you signed up for this
column3: this was a six-year term
column4: and you should be showing up for work.""

column1: RUBIO: ""Barack Obama missed 60 or 70 percent of his votes"" when running for president while he was in the Senate.
THE FACTS: Bush correctly cited Rubio's spotty attendance record in the Senate since running for president
column2: but ignored the fact that this is common when someone in public office runs a White House campaign --and previous candidates were absent far more often. Bush himself is free to run for president as he pleases
column3: because he doesn't have a day job from which to be absent.

column1: For his part
column2: Rubio didn't offer a fair comparison when comparing his Senate voting rate with Obama's.

column1: From Oct. 27
column3: to Oct. 26
column5: Rubio was absent for 26 percent of Senate votes
column6: a worse attendance record than other senators running for president
column7: according to an analysis by GovTrack.us
column8: which tracks congressional voting records.

column1: But in a comparable period in the 2008 race -- from Oct. 23
column3: to Oct. 22
column4: 2007 -- Obama was absent for 29 percent of votes
column5: a bit more than Rubio's absences
column6: but not as much more as Rubio charged. Republican John McCain was absent for 51 percent of Senate votes in that period.

column1: Both Obama and McCain went on to miss an even bigger share of Senate votes as the election progressed -- an expected development bound to be seen again in 2016.

CHRISTIE: The federal government has ""stolen"" the Social Security taxes paid by workers and spent it on other things. ""It isn't their money any more. ... It got stolen from them. It's not theirs anymore. The government stole it and spent it a long time ago.""
THE FACTS: The money is not stolen
column2: it's borrowed.

column1: Over the past 30 years
column2: Social Security has collected about $2.7 trillion more in payroll taxes than it has paid in benefits. By law
column3: the Treasury Department has invested the surplus in U.S. Treasury bonds.

column1: Over that same time period
column2: the federal government has run budget deficits in all but a few years. To finance the deficits
column3: the government has borrowed money
column4: from other government agencies as well as public debt markets.

column1: The money from Social Security has been spent
column2: but Social Security holds Treasury bonds worth $2.7 trillion
column3: backed by the full faith and credit of the U.S. government. Saying the money has been stolen assumes that the federal government will not honor the bonds.

column1: Social Security has been paying out more in benefits than it collects in taxes since 2010. The program has been able to pay full benefits because the federal government has honored the bonds.

TRUMP: Asked about his criticism of Rubio for his support for increasing the number of high-skilled foreign workers given visas to work in the U.S. -- calling Rubio Facebook CEO ""Mark Zuckerburg's personal senator"" -- Trump denied ever making the comment. ""I never said that. I never said that
column2: he said.

column1: THE FACTS: He did say it
column2: on his own website. Trump's immigration policy calls for a different approach -- raising the prevailing wage for the jobs that attract high-skilled foreign workers
column3: in hopes that they'll be filled by more Americans.

column1: Trump's policy statement said doing that ""will improve the number of black
column2: Hispanic and female workers in Silicon Valley who have been passed over in favor of the H-1B program. Mark Zuckerberg's personal Senator
column3: Marco Rubio
column4: has a bill to triple H-1Bs that would decimate women and minorities.""

column1: SEN. RAND PAUL: The new budget agreement ""will explode the deficit
column2: it will allow President Obama to borrow unlimited amounts of money.""

column1: THE FACTS: The agreement allows $80 billion more spending over the next two years
column2: which is only a small addition to the $3.67 trillion the government spends every year. The government's annual budget deficit has declined to $439 billion
column3: about 2.5 percent of GDP
column4: below the average for the past 40 years.

column1: Overall
column2: whatever its faults
column3: most economists have responded to this week's budget deal between Congress and the White House with a sigh of relief. The agreement
column4: approved by the House earlier Wednesday
column5: sets funding levels and extends the government's borrowing limit for two more years
column6: thereby taking the threat of a government shutdown and debt default off the table.

column1: A 2013 budget fight led to a 16-day partial government shutdown that was widely blamed by most economists for sharp drops in consumer and business confidence that dragged on the economy.
GEORGE PATAKI: ""Hillary Clinton put a server
column2: an unsecure server
column3: in her home as secretary of state. We have no doubt that that was hacked
column4: and that state secrets are out there to the Iranians
column5: the Russians

column1: THE FACTS: The former New York governor
column2: speaking in the undercard debate
column3: exaggerated what's actually known about what happened to the emails of Clinton
column4: the Democratic front-runner for her party's presidential nomination. While Clinton's email server was poorly configured and therefore more susceptible to hacking
column5: there is no evidence of intrusion.

column1: The FBI is studying the server
column2: which was subjected to a phishing attack by Russian-linked hackers while she was secretary of state. It's not known whether she clicked on any attachments
column3: which would have exposed her account. Her account was also apparently the subject of cyberattacks originating in China
column4: South Korea and Germany after she left office in early 2013. Determining whether a hack was sponsored by a nation
column5: rather than just originating from that country
column6: is notoriously difficult."	REAL

column1: Why the drop in income inequality?	"Even as it rises in many countries
column2: income inequality has fallen worldwide
column3: a result of pro-poor trends in places from Africa to China. A better focus on growth
column4: innovation
column5: and greater opportunities can help countries close the income gap.

column1: For many in the US and elsewhere
column2: it has become easy to see red or feel blue about income inequality. The Panama Papers revelations about hidden riches feeds this global glum. So does a focus in the US presidential race on charges of a “rigged” economy. Indeed
column3: within many countries
column4: inequality has risen. But not everywhere.

column1: Worldwide
column2: in fact
column3: inequality is actually going down.

column1: Humanity
column2: it seems
column3: is not leaving its poorest behind.

column1: This conclusion comes from the work of an eminent expert on inequality
column2: Branko Milanovic. He spent decades studying data at the World Bank and now works at City University in New York. In a new book
column3: “Global Inequality: A New Approach for the Age of Globalization
column4: ” he makes a case that the rapid growth of poorer countries since 1988 has brought the first decline in inequality since the Industrial Revolution.

column1: Mr. Milanovic is pessimistic about the US reducing its inequality soon. But he finds many pro-equality trends will continue to grow the world’s new middle class. One trend is what he calls “pro-poor” innovation
column2: such as the ability of African farmers to use cellphones to check on farm prices. Another is the use of online courses to educate poor people in skills sought by global companies.

column1: China and other Asian countries have led the way in forging development policies that have helped close the global income gap. The best inequality-buster is economic growth
column2: Milanovic says
column3: but other efforts are needed
column4: such as equality in opportunities. In Brazil
column5: for example
column6: inequality has gone down because of better education.

column1: Milanovic’s findings are reinforced by new research from Tomáš Hellebrandt and Paolo Mauro of the Peterson Institute for International Economics. They find global inequality fell between 2003 and 2013. And they project the number of people in poverty will fall from 12.3 percent of the total population to 3.6 percent by 2035.
“The ability to participate in and benefit from economic growth has immediate and tangible impacts on the lives of the bulk of the world’s population
column2: ” the two economists conclude.

column1: The very rich or the very corrupt may still hide their wealth in tax havens. Politicians in developed countries may decry rising inequality. But global trends and new data tell an alternative story about the progress already made to lift the poor."	REAL

column1: Obama took the executive action in November after Congress failed to pass comprehensive immigration reform.
