column1: Manhunt for escaped killers expands to Vermont	"(CNN) A pair of convicted killers who escaped from an upstate New York prison may have headed across the border to Vermont
column2: fearing the pressure of an intense manhunt in the neighboring state
column3: authorities said Wednesday.

column1: New York State Police Superintendent Joseph D'Amico said authorities are looking ""behind every tree
column2: under every rock and inside every structure"" for fugitives Richard Matt
column4: and David Sweat
column5: 34. The pair made a brazen escape over the weekend from the Clinton Correctional Facility in Dannemora. The search -- now in its fifth day -- involves more than 400 law enforcement officers. The state is offering a $100
column6: 000 reward.

column1: In a news conference outside the maximum-security prison about 20 miles south of the Canadian border
column2: Vermont Gov. Peter Shumlin said the search area had expanded to his state based on information the inmates believed ""New York was going to be hot and Vermont ... cooler in terms of law enforcement.""

column1: Vermont state police vessels and additional troopers will conduct patrols on Lake Champlain
column2: which cuts across the states. In addition
column3: searches will include campsites and public campgrounds.

column1: We have information that would suggest that Vermont was discussed as a possible location
column2: New York Gov. Andrew Cuomo said at the same news conference. ""If they are headed toward Vermont ...Vermont is engaged and Vermont is mobilized and we are working hand in glove
column3: and we will be coordinating several times a day to make sure every lead we have
column4: every piece of information is shared.""

column1: Under an agreement with Vermont
column2: New York state troopers will be allowed across state lines if needed
column3: officials said.

column1: But D'Amico said authorities had no hard information the men had left New York state.

Law enforcement personnel were going door-to-door in both homes and seasonal residences and conducting checkpoints in hamlets and towns surrounding Dannemora. Cuomo said the inmates may have gotten a head start of several hours before the manhunt began.
These men are nothing to be trifled with
column2: Cuomo said.

column1: For the first time since the escape
column2: law enforcement officials acknowledged publicly that a woman who worked with the convicts in the tailoring shop at the prison may have played a role in the elaborate breakout.

column1: D'Amico
column2: without elaborating
column3: said Mitchell had befriended the men and ""may have had some sort of role in assisting them.""

column1: She has not been arrested or charged in connection with their escape
column2: nor has anyone else. The source added that Mitchell is cooperating with police
column3: having provided information as needed.

column1: Her cell phone was used to call several people connected to Matt
column2: according to another source with knowledge of the investigation. It's not clear who made these calls
column3: when they were made or if Mitchell knew about them.

column1: Mitchell went to the hospital this weekend because of panic attacks
column2: according to one of the sources. By then
column3: authorities had discovered during a 5:30 a.m. Saturday bed check that Matt and Sweat had escaped.

column1: Mitchell has worked at Clinton for seven years as an industrial training supervisor
column2: according to Jennifer Freeman
column3: a spokeswoman for the New York State Comptroller. Her salary was $57
column4: 697 a year.

column1: Mitchell's son Tobey Mitchell told NBC News his mother was in a hospital Saturday evening because ""she was having severe chest pains and she was concerned about that."" He added that his mom
column2: who works at the prison with her husband
column3: ""worries a lot about everything"" but strongly challenged suggestions she had done anything wrong.

column1: She is not the kind of person that's going to risk her life or other people's lives to let these guys escape from prison
column2: he said.

column1: His wife
column2: Paige Mitchell
column3: told CNN on Wednesday that ""95% of what is being said"" about her mother-in-law is not true.

column1: They don't have the facts to prove this
column2: she said. ""This is just slander and rumor.""

column1: Paige Mitchell said she believed Matt may have persuaded her mother-in-law to contact people for him who knew about art.
He was interested in art
column2: Paige Mitchell said of Matt. ""Her heart was in the right place.""

column1: Paige Mitchell denied that her mother-in-law was to be the getaway driver or helped provide the power tools used in the escape. Saturday's hospital visit stemmed from the fact that Joyce Mitchell is a ""very nervous person
column2: she said.

column1: Rural area is rough and 'can be deadly'
If the escapees did indeed have a designated driver
column2: imagine their horror when they popped out of a manhole sometime late Friday or early Saturday and found no accomplice waiting.

column1: That must have been just a complete panic on their part ... 'Now what? Where are we going to walk to -- this small
column2: rural area?' "" said CNN law enforcement analyst Tom Fuentes
column3: a former FBI assistant director. ""It's going to be hard to hide day or night for very long
column4: and they wouldn't have been prepared to deal with the elements.""

column1: They'd have to find food
column2: water and money
column3: while also trying to get their hands on weapons or a vehicle.

column1: That would put every family in that rural (area) in extreme danger
column2: Fuentes said. ""If they're feeling like cornered animals out there
column3: they are going to do something drastic to try to ensure their physical survival and their continued freedom out of that prison.""

column1: Without any help like a getaway driver
column2: someone who escapes from Clinton can easily get lost
column3: said Jeff Hall
column4: who teaches at the City University of New York and did his dissertation on northern New York prisons.

column1: The environment is formidable
column2: said Hall
column3: who grew up near the Dannemora prison
column4: where his father worked. ""It's rough terrain and
column5: if you're not familiar with it
column6: it can be deadly.""

column1: Warning: Tell police if you spot anything unusual
The first came in Dannemora after midnight Friday
column2: about five hours before authorities discovered the men had escaped.

column1: Another focus is about 40 miles southeast in Willsboro
column2: a town of about 2
column3: 000 people along Lake Champlain.

column1: That's where a resident spotted two men overnight Monday walking in a torrential rainstorm on a rural road
column2: Willsboro Town Supervisor Shaun Gillilland said. As the witness' car approached them
column3: they took off.

column1: Both reports could be false leads
column2: as often happens in manhunts. Former U.S. Marshal Service regional commander Lenny DePaul said he thinks it's important that people be on the lookout.

column1: Still
column2: authorities are clearly focusing on the rural swath of New York near Vermont and the Canadian province of Quebec.

column1: Matt and Sweat's escape was so extraordinarily complex that experts say the two must have had help.
Using power tools
column2: they cut through a cell wall that included a steel plate
column3: maneuvered across a catwalk
column4: shimmied down six stories to a tunnel of pipes
column5: followed that tunnel
column6: broke through a double-brick wall
column7: cut into a 24-inch steam pipe
column8: climbed through the steam pipe
column9: cut another hole so they could get out of the pipe and finally surfaced through a manhole.

column1: Aside from the mystery of how they got the necessary power tools
column2: many wonder how they could have used them without detection.

column1: The hole in the cell's steel wall suggests they used a cutoff wheel
column2: ironworker Ernesto ""Ernie"" Peñuelas said. But using that tool would have produced a loud sound and detectable odor.

column1: Their time on the lam is also remarkable. Most escapees in New York are captured within 24 hours
column2: according to data compiled by the state. Of 29 inmates who fled between 2002 and 2013
column3: only one was free for more than two days.

column1: Escaping from detention happens thousands of times each year
column2: federal statistics show. But most are from minimum security facilities
column3: where prisoners just walk away. In 2013
column4: there were 2
column5: 011 cases of prisoners who escaped or were absent without permission.

column1: Sweat was serving a life sentence without parole for fatally shooting and then running over Broome County Sheriff's Deputy Kevin Tarsia in 2002.
Matt was convicted for kidnapping a businessman for 27 hours and -- when he didn't comply with his pleas for money -- killing him.
Torture is probably an understatement
column2: Lee Bates
column3: who drove a car carrying one of Matt's victims
column4: told CNN's Anderson Cooper of the 1997 killing. He said Matt shoved a knife sharpener in his victim's ear
column5: broke his neck and then dismembered the body.

column1: Despite his violent past
column2: Matt is capable of getting others to help him
column3: Bates said."	REAL

column1: The Path To Total Dictatorship: America’s “Shadow Government” And Its Silent Coup	"By John W. Whitehead
“Today the path to total dictatorship in the U.S. can be laid by strictly legal means
column2: unseen and unheard by Congress
column3: the President
column4: or the people . Outwardly we have a Constitutional government. We have operating within our government and political system … a well-organized political-action group in this country
column5: determined to destroy our Constitution and establish a one-party state….

column1: The important point to remember about this group is not its ideology but its organization… It operates secretly
column2: silently
column3: continuously to transform our Government…. This group … is answerable neither to the President
column4: the Congress
column5: nor the courts. It is practically irremovable. ”— Senator William Jenner
column6: 1954 speech

column1: Unaffected by elections. Unaltered by populist movements. Beyond the reach of the law.
Say hello to America’s shadow government.
A corporatized
column2: militarized
column3: entrenched bureaucracy that is fully operational and staffed by unelected officials who are
column4: in essence
column5: running the country
column6: this shadow government represents the hidden face of a government that has no respect for the freedom of its citizenry.

column1: No matter which candidate wins the presidential election
column2: this shadow government is here to stay. Indeed
column3: as recent documents by the FBI reveal
column4: this shadow government— also referred to as “The 7th Floor Group” —may well have played a part in who will win the White House this year.

column1: To be precise
column2: however
column3: the future president will actually inherit not one but two shadow governments.

column1: The first shadow government
column2: referred to as COG or Continuity of Government
column3: is made up of unelected individuals who have been appointed to run the government in the event of a “catastrophe.” COG is a phantom menace waiting for the right circumstances—a terrorist attack
column4: a natural disaster
column5: an economic meltdown—to bring it out of the shadows
column6: where it operates even now. When and if COG takes over
column7: the police state will transition to martial law.

column1: Yet it is the second shadow government —also referred to as the Deep State—that poses the greater threat to freedom right now. Comprised of unelected government bureaucrats
column2: corporations
column3: contractors
column4: paper-pushers
column5: and button-pushers who are actually calling the shots behind the scenes
column6: this government within a government is the real reason “we the people” have no real control over our government.

column1: The Deep State
column2: which “ operates according to its own compass heading regardless of who is formally in power
column3: ” makes a mockery of elections and the entire concept of a representative government.

column1: So who or what is the Deep State?
It’s the militarized police
column2: which have joined forces with state and federal law enforcement agencies in order to establish themselves as a standing army. It’s the fusion centers and spy agencies that have created a surveillance state and turned all of us into suspects. It’s the courthouses and prisons that have allowed corporate profits to take precedence over due process and justice.

column1: It’s the military empire with its private contractors and defense industry that is bankrupting the nation. It’s the private sector with its 854
column2: 000 contract personnel with top-secret clearances
column3: “a number greater than that of top-secret-cleared civilian employees of the government.” It’s what former congressional staffer Mike Lofgren refers to as “ a hybrid of national security and law enforcement agencies ”: the Department of Defense
column4: the State Department
column5: Homeland Security
column6: the CIA
column7: the Justice Department
column8: the Treasury
column9: the Executive Office of the President via the National Security Council
column10: the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Court
column11: a handful of vital federal trial courts
column12: and members of the defense and intelligence committees.

column1: It’s every facet of a government that is no longer friendly to freedom and is working overtime to trample the Constitution underfoot and render the citizenry powerless in the face of the government’s power grabs
column2: corruption and abusive tactics.

column1: These are the key players that drive the shadow government.
This is the hidden face of the American police state that will continue long past Election Day.
Just consider some of the key programs and policies advanced by the shadow government that will continue no matter who occupies the Oval Office.
Domestic surveillance No matter who wins the presidential popularity contest
column2: the National Security Agency (NSA)
column3: with its $10.8 billion black ops annual budget
column4: will continue to spy on every person in the United States who uses a computer or phone. Thus
column5: on any given day
column6: whether you’re walking through a store
column7: driving your car
column8: checking email
column9: or talking to friends and family on the phone
column10: you can be sure that some government agency
column11: whether the NSA or some other entity
column12: is listening in and tracking your behavior. Local police have been outfitted with a litany of surveillance gear
column13: from license plate readers and cell phone tracking devices to biometric data recorders. Technology now makes it possible for the police to scan passersby in order to detect the contents of their pockets
column14: purses
column15: briefcases
column16: etc. Full-body scanners
column17: which perform virtual strip-searches of Americans traveling by plane
column18: have gone mobile
column19: with roving police vans that peer into vehicles and buildings alike—including homes. Coupled with the nation’s growing network of real-time surveillance cameras and facial recognition software
column20: soon there really will be nowhere to run and nowhere to hide.

column1: Global spying The NSA’s massive surveillance network
column2: what the Washington Post refers to as a $500 billion “ espionage empire
column3: ” will continue to span the globe and target every single person on the planet who uses a phone or a computer. The NSA’s Echelon program intercepts and analyzes virtually every phone call
column4: fax and email message sent anywhere in the world. In addition to carrying out domestic surveillance on peaceful political groups such as Amnesty International
column5: Greenpeace and several religious groups
column6: Echelon has also been a keystone in the government’s attempts at political and corporate espionage .

column1: Roving TSA searches The American taxpayer will continue to get ripped off by government agencies in the dubious name of national security. One of the greatest culprits when it comes to swindling taxpayers has been the Transportation Security Administration (TSA)
column2: with its questionable deployment of and complete mismanagement of millions of dollars’ worth of airport full-body X-ray scanners
column3: punitive patdowns by TSA agents and thefts of travelers’ valuables. Considered essential to national security
column4: TSA programs will continue in airports and at transportation hubs around the country.

column1: USA Patriot Act
column2: NDAA America’s so-called war on terror
column3: which it has relentlessly pursued since 9/11
column4: will continue to chip away at our freedoms
column5: unravel our Constitution and transform our nation into a battlefield
column6: thanks in large part to such subversive legislation as the USA Patriot Act and National Defense Authorization Act. These laws completely circumvent the rule of law and the rights of American citizens. In so doing
column7: they re-orient our legal landscape in such a way as to ensure that martial law
column8: rather than the U.S. Constitution
column9: is the map by which we navigate life in the United States. These laws will continue to be enforced no matter who gets elected.

column1: Militarized police state Thanks to federal grant programs allowing the Pentagon to transfer surplus military supplies and weapons to local law enforcement agencies without charge
column2: police forces will continue to be transformed from peace officers into heavily armed extensions of the military
column3: complete with jackboots
column4: helmets
column5: shields
column6: batons
column7: pepper-spray
column8: stun guns
column9: assault rifles
column10: body armor
column11: miniature tanks and weaponized drones.

column1: Having been given the green light to probe
column2: poke
column3: pinch
column4: taser
column5: search
column6: seize
column7: strip and generally manhandle anyone they see fit in almost any circumstance
column8: all with the general blessing of the courts
column9: America’s law enforcement officials
column10: no longer mere servants of the people entrusted with keeping the peace
column11: will continue to keep the masses corralled
column12: controlled
column13: and treated like suspects and enemies rather than citizens.

column1: SWAT team raids With more than 80
column2: 000 SWAT team raids carried out every year on unsuspecting Americans by local police for relatively routine police matters and federal agencies laying claim to their own law enforcement divisions
column3: the incidence of botched raids and related casualties will continue to rise. Nationwide
column4: SWAT teams will continue to be employed to address an astonishingly trivial array of criminal activity or mere community nuisances including angry dogs
column5: domestic disputes
column6: improper paperwork filed by an orchid farmer
column7: and misdemeanor marijuana possession.

column1: Domestic drones The domestic use of drones will continue unabated. As mandated by Congress
column2: there will be 30
column3: 000 drones crisscrossing the skies of America by 2020
column4: all part of an industry that could be worth as much as $30 billion per year. These machines
column5: which will be equipped with weapons
column6: will be able to record all activities
column7: using video feeds
column8: heat sensors and radar. An Inspector General report revealed that the Dept. of Justice has already spent nearly $4 million on drones domestically
column9: largely for use by the FBI
column10: with grants for another $1.26 million so police departments and nonprofits can acquire their own drones.

column1: School-to-prison pipeline The paradigm of abject compliance to the state will continue to be taught by example in the schools
column2: through school lockdowns where police and drug-sniffing dogs enter the classroom
column3: and zero tolerance policies that punish all offenses equally and result in young people being expelled for childish behavior. School districts will continue to team up with law enforcement to create a “schoolhouse to jailhouse track” by imposing a “double dose” of punishment: suspension or expulsion from school
column4: accompanied by an arrest by the police and a trip to juvenile court.

column1: Overcriminalization The government bureaucracy will continue to churn out laws
column2: statutes
column3: codes and regulations that reinforce its powers and value systems and those of the police state and its corporate allies
column4: rendering the rest of us petty criminals. The average American now unknowingly commits three felonies a day
column5: thanks to this overabundance of vague laws that render otherwise innocent activity illegal. Consequently
column6: small farmers who dare to make unpasteurized goat cheese and share it with members of their community will continue to have their farms raided.

column1: Privatized Prisons States will continue to outsource prisons to private corporations
column2: resulting in a cash cow whereby mega-corporations imprison Americans in private prisons in order to make a profit. In exchange for corporations buying and managing public prisons across the country at a supposed savings to the states
column3: the states have to agree to maintain a 90% occupancy rate in the privately run prisons for at least 20 years.

column1: Endless wars America’s expanding military empire will continue to bleed the country dry at a rate of more than $15 billion a month (or $20 million an hour). The Pentagon spends more on war than all 50 states combined spend on health
column2: education
column3: welfare
column4: and safety. Yet what most Americans fail to recognize is that these ongoing wars have little to do with keeping the country safe and everything to do with enriching the military industrial complex at taxpayer expense.

column1: Are you getting the message yet?
The next president
column2: much like the current president and his predecessors
column3: will be little more than a figurehead
column4: a puppet to entertain and distract the populace from what’s really going on.

column1: As Lofgren reveals
column2: this state within a state
column3: “concealed behind the one that is visible at either end of Pennsylvania Avenue
column4: ” is a “hybrid entity of public and private institutions ruling the country according to consistent patterns in season and out
column5: connected to
column6: but only intermittently controlled by
column7: the visible state whose leaders we choose.”

column1: The Deep State not only holds the nation’s capital in thrall
column2: but it also controls Wall Street (“which supplies the cash that keeps the political machine quiescent and operating as a diversionary marionette theater”) and Silicon Valley.

column1: This is fascism in its most covert form
column2: hiding behind public agencies and private companies to carry out its dirty deeds.

column1: It is a marriage between government bureaucrats and corporate fat cats.
As Lofgren concludes:
[T]he Deep State is so heavily entrenched
column2: so well protected by surveillance
column3: firepower
column4: money and its ability to co-opt resistance that it is almost impervious to change … If there is anything the Deep State requires it is silent
column5: uninterrupted cash flow and the confidence that things will go on as they have in the past. It is even willing to tolerate a degree of gridlock: Partisan mud wrestling over cultural issues may be a useful distraction from its agenda.

column1: In other words
column2: as I point out in my book Battlefield America: The War on the American People
column3: as long as government officials—elected and unelected alike—are allowed to operate beyond the reach of the Constitution
column4: the courts and the citizenry
column5: the threat to our freedoms remains undiminished.

column1: So the next time you find yourselves despondent over the 2016 presidential candidates
column2: remember that it’s just a puppet show intended to distract you from the silent coup being carried out by America’s shadow government.

column1: Constitutional attorney and author John W. Whitehead is founder and president of The Rutherford Institute. His new book Battlefield America: The War on the American People (SelectBooks
column2: 2015) is available online at www.amazon.com . Whitehead can be contacted at johnw@rutherford.org .

column1: To the Youth a Day After the Election: Another World Is Possible	"By Tai Amri Spann-Wilson / 400yearsinbabylon.blogspot.com
Dear Youth
On this day after the election
column2: many are asking themselves how this could have happened. Regardless of who anyone close to you voted for
column3: and regardless of how you yourself might vote
column4: in a democratic country
column5: the questions still remain: How could so few be allowed to vote? Why do so few who are eligible vote? How can we call ourselves a country when there seems to be so much hatred between those with differing ideologies? Do we care at all for people who are not like us? These questions can be maddening
column6: but I beg you
column7: don’t give up hope. I promise you that just the thought of you gives so many of us so much hope. Especially me. And also
column8: please don’t fall into the temptation to hate those who may hate you. These times we are living in are reminding me
column9: oddly enough
column10: of the Empire Strikes Back. Luke
column11: reacting to the violence of the world tries to combat it with more violence and ends up getting his hand cut off. It’s only after he goes and studies the intricacies of justice that he is able to confront Darth Vader and the Emperor in triumph. If I were to pick a Grandmaster Jedi of our world
column12: it would be Dr. Howard Thurman
column13: the “pastor” of Martin Luther King. Dr. Thurman wrote of hate
column14: “The logic of the development of hatred is death to the spirit and disintegration of ethical and moral value.” While hatred is a natural emotion
column15: acting from it and allowing it to take root will never accomplish the goals we want them to. I call you StillSpeaking Youth to combat what I have seen older generations do to younger generations throughout my lifetime and into history. Each generation seems to think that their generation was the one that knew how best to fight. I’m afraid that the older I get the more I might start saying to younger folkx
column16: “At least MY generation had the Occupy Movement.” or “At least my generation was involved in the Black Lives Matter Movement.” But the truth of the matter is that every generation gets their chance to shine and be a part of creating what Dr. Martin Luther King
column17: Jr. called
column18: The Beloved Community. We hear a lot about Dr. King’s Dream
column19: but what we hear are the little specifics
column20: white children and Black children holding hands and blah
column21: blah
column22: blah. We often miss the big picture. The big picture was that Dr. King believed
column23: as I do
column24: that there is a world possible right here that is far different than the world we live in today. In that world: there is no hatred over religious and political differences; everyone is loved and cherished for who they are
column25: no matter the color of their skin
column26: their sexual orientation
column27: their gender expression; and people aren’t treated differently because of how much money they make or what job they work. That Dream is possible
column28: but only when we all put our hands into making this Beloved Community come true. I love each and every one of you so much
column29: even when you get on my nerves I want to protect you from every harmful oppression. But the best way I know how to do that
column30: is to try and help you be survivors in a world of hate. I always want to show you the survival tools I learned
column31: and also the tools I’ve learned to help create a Beloved Community. Because I know
column32: that just as I will someday be among the eldest generation of this world and that I hope to eventually be an ancestor that you call upon in your struggles
column33: you will someday have to step up to the responsibilities of creating the Beloved Community in your own world just as me and my generation have. You don’t have to do it like us
column34: in fact I really hope you don’t
column35: we’ve made a lot of mistakes
column36: but I want you to be those Love Warriors
column37: I need you to be those Love Warriors
column38: and I vow to be the Elder that you need. Just keep holding on and know this
column40: including Dr. Thurman and Dr. King
column41: are ALWAYS there when you call. You know I love you
column42: Tai Amri (Baby Pastor and Jedi Master) Spann-Wilson 4.0 ·"	FAKE

column1: Protester charged with shooting officers in Ferguson	"A 20-year-old protester has been charged with shooting two police officers in Ferguson
column2: Mo.
column3: last week
column4: authorities said Sunday.

column1: County Prosecuting Attorney Robert McCulloch said Jeffrey Williams was charged with two counts of assault in the first degree
column2: one count of firing a weapon from a vehicle and three counts of armed criminal action.

column1: McCulloch said Williams admitted firing the shots but said he was shooting at someone else.
We're not sure we buy that part of it
column2: McCulloch said
column3: adding that the handgun used in the shooting has been recovered.

column1: He said Williams was involved in the demonstration that was wrapping up when the incident took place. Williams
column2: he said
column3: was being held in lieu of $300
column4: 000 cash bail.

column1: McCulloch said information provided by the public was key to the arrest. He encouraged anyone who knows anything about the shooting to contact police
column2: saying the investigation was continuing.

column1: Williams has had several minor run-ins with police and one felony arrest in St. Louis
column2: court records show.

column1: He spent two days in jail last March for failing to appear for court hearings for traffic infractions
column2: including driving without a valid license and operating a motor vehicle without maintaining proper insurance. He also spent two days in jail in January 2014 for speeding.

column1: Police arrested Williams in June 2013 for receiving stolen property
column2: a felony
column3: and credit card fraud. He was sentenced in March 2014 to two years probation.

column1: Bishop Derrick Robinson of the Kingdom Destiny Fellowship International
column2: who has been an organizer of Ferguson protests
column3: later told CNN he spoke with Williams -- and that Williams said he was not involved in protests. He said Williams told him the shooting occurred after he had been robbed by an unknown assailant.

column1: The officers were shot during a protest just after midnight Thursday. One was shot in the face
column2: the other in the shoulder. They were released from the hospital later Thursday.

column1: Ferguson has been the scene of sometimes violent protests since the shooting death of unarmed black man Michael Brown
column3: by a white police officer in August. The shooting and subsequent investigation brought national attention and a Justice Department probe to the St. Louis suburb.

column1: The Justice Department investigation found systemic racism in the police department
column2: prompting the resignation of the city manager
column3: a local judge and the city's police chief.

column1: Attorney General Eric Holder issued a statement lauding the investigative cooperation between federal authorities and St. Louis County officials.
This arrest sends a clear message that acts of violence against our law enforcement personnel will never be tolerated
column2: Holder said in the statement. ""In the days ahead
column3: we will continue to partner with the authorities in St. Louis County to secure justice for all those affected by this heinous and cowardly crime. And we will continue to stand vigilant in support of public safety officers and the communities they serve.""

column1: The officers wounded Thursday were from St. Louis County and Webster Groves. After the shootings
column2: the highway patrol and county police took control of security duties from the Ferguson department.

column1: Hours after the shooting
column2: Holder and Obama condemned the attack.

column1: They're criminals. They need to be arrested

column3: good-spirited people on both sides -- law-enforcement who have a terrifically tough job and people who understand they don't want to be stopped and harassed because of their race -- that we're able to work together to try and come up with some good answers."""	REAL

column1: Comment on U.S. war with Iran has already begun by جنگ ارزی آمریکا علیه ایران / مورد مطالعاتی سال 1390 - کدآمایی	"Posted on January 23
column2: 2012 by Dr. Eowyn | 10 Comments While we were transfixed and distracted by the Newt vs. Mitt drama in South Carolina
column3: Obama has quietly begun war with Iran — without informing the American people (or Congress?).

column1: This is the startling assertion made by James Rickards in an interview on January 13 with King World News.
Rickards is a Senior Managing Director of Tangent Capital in New York
column2: whose advisory clients include government directorates around the world. He is the author of Currency Wars: The Making of the Next Global Crisis (Penguin/Portfolio
column3: 2011). Rickards is also the man who had negotiated the release of American hostages from Iran in 1981
column4: and continues to be involved in US national security issues and the Department of Defense.

column1: This is what Rickards told King World News about the situation in Iran: “The fact that we
column2: meaning the United States
column3: are on a path to a war with Iran is very clear at this point. It does seem the countdown has begun and it’s coming to a head sooner rather than later. Things are moving very quickly. General Martin Dempsey
column4: who is the Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff has arrived in Israel and Israel is integrating itself with the U.S. European Command or EUCOM. So
column5: at this point
column6: the integration of the Israeli and the US operational capability
column7: including NATO based in Europe
column8: is very far along. There are an enormous number of US troops in Israel. I don’t know if people realize that
column9: but they are operating the THAAD system (Terminal High Altitude Area Defense). They oversee weapons that will shoot down incoming Iranian missiles. There are joint exercises going on between the US and Israel. At the same time Iran is conducting war games. There are a lot of moving pieces on the chessboard at this point. This is not just war gaming or thinking about what might happen
column10: the pieces have actually begun to move on the chessboard. For Israel this is really existential. The US would really like to see a world where Iran did not have nuclear weapons
column11: but for Israel it is not a preference. If Iran gets nuclear weapons
column12: Iran has said they will burn Israel to the ground. So
column13: this is not just a strategic rebalancing
column14: this is life or death for the Israelis….. All of the information I have is that the US is going to do it (attack Iran). So the tension between Israel and the United States is being resolved in favor of letting the US actually launch the attack. Part of the reason for this is the retaliation vector. If the US attacks and Israel keeps out
column15: then Iran has no justification for attacking Israel. They (Iran) will attack US targets in the Middle-East
column16: but we’re ready for that
column17: we’re prepared for that. We will suppress the missiles and their air force is a joke
column18: we’ll take that out in the first day. But they do have a serious missile capability. We’ll need anti-missile warfare and we will need to strike those bases. We will need to do a lot of other damage to Iran
column19: cyber warfare
column20: take down the power grid
column21: take down the command and control structure. Do whatever we can to stop them from attacking our assets in the Middle-East. This war will be fought with air power
column22: sea power
column23: cyberwarfare
column24: financial warfare
column25: sabotage
column26: special operation
column27: assassination
column28: things like that. This is already going on. As an example
column29: yesterday a prominent Iranian nuclear scientist had an unlucky encounter with a magnet bomb. So this war is already being fought. The other day the United States sanctioned the Central Bank of Iran. By the way
column30: we’ve been sanctioning them for years
column31: but we’ve been dialing it up little by little. It’s like the frog that’s boiled in a pot of water and doesn’t know until it’s too late that the water is getting hot. President Obama sanctioned the central bank about a week ago. The Iranian currency
column32: the rial
column33: dropped 30% in a single day. Hyperinflation has broken out in Iran. This is financial warfare. My point to the listeners is this is not theoretical
column34: this is not a war game
column35: not an exercise
column36: it’s happening now and the clock is ticking.” USS Abraham Lincoln

In defiance of Iran’s threat to close the critical Strait of Hormuz
column2: the United States

column4: and France have deployed six warships to the Strait
column5: led by the USS Abraham Lincoln. The 100

It’s not the ‘locker-room’ talk. It’s the ‘lock her up’ talk.	"The second presidential debate — bloody
column2: muddy and raucous — was just enough to save Donald Trump’s campaign from extinction
column3: but not enough to restore his chances of winning
column4: barring an act of God (a medical calamity) or of Putin (a cosmically incriminating WikiLeak).

column1: That Trump crashed because of a sex-talk tape is odd. It should have been a surprise to no one. His views on women have been on open display for years. And he’d offered a dazzling array of other reasons for disqualification: habitual mendacity
column2: pathological narcissism
column3: profound ignorance and an astonishing dearth of basic human empathy.

column1: To which list Trump added in the second debate
column2: and it had nothing to do with sex. It was his threat
column3: if elected
column4: to put Hillary Clinton in jail.

column1: After appointing a special prosecutor
column2: of course. The niceties must be observed. First
column3: a fair trial
column4: then a proper hanging. The day after the debate at a rally in Pennsylvania
column5: Trump responded to chants of “lock her up” with “Lock her up is right.” Two days later
column6: he told a rally in Lakeland
column7: Fla.
column8: “She has to go to jail.”

column1: [Fareed Zakaria: The GOP is history. What about the country? ]
Such incendiary talk is an affront to elementary democratic decency and a breach of the boundaries of American political discourse. In democracies
column2: the electoral process is a subtle and elaborate substitute for combat
column3: the age-old way of settling struggles for power. But that sublimation only works if there is mutual agreement to accept both the legitimacy of the result (which Trump keeps undermining with charges that the very process is “rigged”) and the boundaries of the contest.

column1: The prize for the winner is temporary accession to limited political power
column2: not the satisfaction of vendettas. Vladimir Putin
column3: Hugo Chávez and a cavalcade of two-bit caudillos lock up their opponents. American leaders don’t.

column1: One doesn’t even talk like this. It takes decades
column2: centuries
column3: to develop ingrained norms of political restraint and self-control. But they can be undone in short order by a demagogue feeding a vengeful populism.

column1: This is not to say that the investigation into the Clinton emails was not itself compromised by politics. FBI Director James B. Comey’s recommendation not to pursue charges was both troubling and puzzling. And Barack Obama very improperly tilted the scales by interjecting
column2: while the investigation was still underway
column3: that Clinton’s emails had not endangered national security.

column1: But the answer is not to start a new process whose outcome is preordained. Conservatives have relentlessly
column2: and correctly
column3: criticized this administration for abusing its power and suborning the civil administration (e.g.
column4: the IRS). Is the Republican response to do the same?

column1: Wasn’t presidential overreach one of the major charges against Obama by the anti-establishment GOP candidates? Wasn’t the animating spirit of the entire tea party movement the restoration of constitutional limits and restraints?
In America
column2: we don’t persecute political opponents. Which is why we retroactively honor Gerald Ford for his pardon of Richard Nixon
column3: for which
column4: at the time
column5: Ford was widely reviled. It ultimately cost him the presidency. Nixon might well have been convicted. But Ford understood that jailing a president for actions carried out in the context of his official duties would threaten the very civil nature of democratic governance.

column1: [Michael Gerson: Donald Trump is right: The GOP is utterly pathetic]

What makes Trump’s promise to lock her up all the more alarming is that it’s not an isolated incident. This is not the first time he’s insinuated using the powers of the presidency against political enemies. He has threatened Amazon’s Jeffrey P. Bezos
column2: owner of The Post
column3: for using the newspaper “as a tool for political power against me and other people. . . . We can’t let him get away with it.”

column1: Trump has gone after others with equal subtlety. “I hear
column2: ” he tweeted
column3: “the Rickets [sic] family
column4: who own the Chicago Cubs
column5: are secretly spending $’s against me. They better be careful
column6: they have a lot to hide!” And after National Review editor Rich Lowry made a particularly cutting remark about him on Fox News
column7: Trump tweeted
column8: “He should not be allowed on TV and the FCC should fine him!”

column1: Trump also promises to “open up” libel laws to permit easier prosecution of those who attack him unfairly. Has he ever conceded any attack on him to be fair?
This election is not just about placing the nuclear codes in Trump’s hands. It’s also about handing him the instruments of civilian coercion
column2: such as the IRS
column3: the FBI
column4: the FCC
column5: the SEC. Think of what he could do to enforce the “fairness” he demands. Imagine giving over the vast power of the modern state to a man who says in advance that he will punish his critics and jail his opponent.

column1: GOP braces for Trump loss, roiled by refusal to accept election results	"A wave of apprehension and anguish swept the Republican Party on Thursday
column2: with many GOP leaders alarmed by Donald Trump’s refusal to accept the outcome of the election and concluding that it is probably too late to salvage his flailing presidential campaign.

column1: As the Republican nominee reeled from a turbulent performance in the final debate here in Las Vegas
column2: his party’s embattled senators and House members scrambled to protect their seats and preserve the GOP’s congressional majorities against what Republicans privately acknowledge could be a landslide victory for Democratic nominee Hillary Clinton.

column1: With less than three weeks until the election
column2: the Republican Party is in a state of historic turmoil
column3: encapsulated by Trump’s extraordinary debate declaration that he would leave the nation in “suspense” about whether he would recognize the results from an election he has claimed will be “rigged” or even “stolen.”

column1: The immediate responses from GOP officials were divergent and vague
column2: with no clear strategy on how to handle Trump’s threat. The candidate was defiant and would not back away from his position
column3: telling a roaring crowd Thursday in Ohio that he would accept the results “if I win” — and reserving his right to legally challenge the results should he fall short.

column1: For seasoned Republicans who have watched Trump warily as a general-election candidate
column2: the aftermath of Wednesday’s debate brought a feeling of finality.

column1: “The campaign is over
column2: ” said Steve Schmidt
column3: a Trump critic and former senior strategist on George W. Bush’s and John McCain’s presidential campaigns.

column1: Calling a refusal to accept the election results “disqualifying
column2: ” Schmidt added: “The question is
column3: how close will Clinton get to 400 electoral votes? She’ll be north of 350
column4: and she’s trending towards 400 — and the trend line is taking place in very red states like Georgia
column5: Texas and Arizona.”

column1: [At third debate
column2: Trump won't commit to accepting election results if he loses]

column1: Clinton and Trump appeared together and traded jabs in delivering mostly lighthearted roasts Thursday night at the Alfred E. Smith Memorial Foundation dinner
column2: a white-tie gala benefiting Catholic charities. The candidates used searing humor to taunt each other
column3: reflecting the personal animus on display in the debates. Trump’s routine was at times unsettling
column4: drawing some rare boos from the audience. Held at the Waldorf Astoria hotel in New York
column5: the dinner is a traditional event on the calendar for presidential nominees.

column1: Meanwhile
column2: top Democrats fanned out to battleground states on Thursday to hammer Trump for what they described as an unprecedented attack on the country’s political system and to attempt to yoke Trump to Republican candidates down the ballot.

column1: Campaigning in Miami
column2: President Obama said Trump’s doubts about the election outcome are “not a joking matter. That is dangerous.”

column1: The president eviscerated Republicans who have stood by Trump
column2: singling out Sen. Marco Rubio (R-Fla.)
column3: who called Trump “a dangerous con artist” and condemned his more controversial comments during the GOP primaries but now plans to vote for him.

column1: “Marco just seems to care about hanging on to his job
column2: ” Obama said
column3: calling the senator’s positioning “the height of cynicism.”

column1: And in Arizona
column2: where polls show an unexpectedly tight presidential race
column3: first lady Michelle Obama said Trump “is threatening the very idea of America itself” by suggesting he would not honor the election results.

column1: “You do not keep American democracy ‘in suspense
column2: ’ ” Obama said in Phoenix.

column1: [Rubio
column2: once a shoo-in
column3: fights the anti-Trump tide in Florida]

column1: Sen. Tim Kaine of Virginia
column2: Clinton’s vice-presidential running mate
column3: held a rally at a downtown Charlotte brewery
column4: where he said Trump’s claims of a “rigged” election reminded him of the Third World politicking he had seen as a young missionary in Honduras.

column1: “The bigger we can win by
column2: the harder it is for him to whine and have anyone believe him
column3: ” Kaine said
column4: trying to galvanize supporters on the first day of early voting in North Carolina.

column1: On the debate stage
column2: Trump amplified what he had been saying for weeks at his rallies: that the election is “rigged.” Questioned directly as to whether he would accept the results should Clinton prevail
column3: Trump said
column4: “I’ll keep you in suspense.”

column1: Clinton called Trump’s answer “horrifying
column2: ” both in the debate and to reporters overnight on her flight home to New York.

column1: Trump’s advisers and surrogates struggled to explain the candidate’s position. Campaign manager Kellyanne Conway said it was too early to determine whether voting irregularities could make the difference between winning and losing. She and other Trump backers drew a parallel to then-Vice President Al Gore’s concession call to then-Texas Gov. George W. Bush
column2: which he later withdrew as he awaited a recount in Florida.

column1: “I’m going to keep reminding everybody about the 2000 election when Al Gore said he would accept the results of the election and then did not
column2: ” Conway said. “He retracted his concession.”

column1: Reince Priebus
column2: chairman of the Republican National Committee
column3: contended that Trump and the party would stand by the results unless the margin is small enough to warrant a recount or legal challenges. Priebus said Trump is merely preserving flexibility in the event of a contested result.

column1: “All he’s saying is
column2: ‘Look
column3: I’m not going to forgo my right to a recount in a close election
column4: ’ ” Priebus said. “We accept the results as long as we’re not talking about a few votes where it actually matters. I know him. I know where his head’s at. . . . I promise you
column5: that’s all this is.”

column1: Other Trump surrogates took a different interpretation. Keith Kellogg
column2: a retired Army lieutenant general
column3: accused the media of “splitting hairs” and insisted that Trump was “not threatening democratic norms
column4: ” while former New York mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani argued that any Republican would be “stupid” to accept the integrity of results before they are known.

column1: “Suppose she wins Pennsylvania by 50 votes
column2: ” Giuliani said. He speculated
column3: without evidence
column4: that Democrats would “steal a lot more than 50 votes in Philadelphia. I guarantee you of that. And I’ll tell you how they will do it — they’ll bus people in who will vote dead people’s names four
column5: five
column6: six times . . . or have people in Philadelphia paid to vote three
column7: four and five times.”

column1: Democrats expressed dismay that the Republican nominee and his backers were advancing the idea of widespread voter fraud.
“He is just trying to find an excuse for the fact that he’s going to lose
column2: and perhaps the fact that he’s going to lose to the first woman president stings a little sharper than it might otherwise
column3: ” said Jennifer Palmieri
column4: the Clinton campaign’s communications director.

column1: Prominent Republican senators in tough reelection bids distanced themselves from Trump’s posture. “Donald Trump needs to accept the outcome
column2: ” Sen. Kelly Ayotte (R-N.H.) said in a statement.

column1: McCain (Ariz.)
column2: who lost to Obama eight years ago
column3: said in a statement: “I didn’t like the outcome of the 2008 election. But I had a duty to concede. A concession isn’t just an act of graciousness. It is an act of respect for the will of the American people.”

column1: As of Thursday afternoon
column2: neither House Speaker Paul D. Ryan (R-Wis.) nor Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell (R-Ky.) had offered any comment
column3: underscoring the party’s unease with its own nominee and the political dangers of tangling with him.

column1: Benjamin L. Ginsberg
column2: a lawyer at Jones Day who has been national counsel for several Republican presidential campaigns
column3: said Trump’s stance puts the party in “quite a difficult position.”

column1: “There will be Republican candidates who are winning by narrow margins and losing by narrow margins
column2: ” Ginsberg said. “The party as a whole has a collective interest in having the results upheld.”

column1: Republican pollster Whit ­Ayres said that at the Las Vegas debate
column2: Trump “blew his last chance to turn it around.” But
column3: he said
column4: “I am not convinced that the rest of the party will have as bad a night [on Election Day] as Donald Trump is going to have
column5: because the Trump brand is so distinct from the Republican brand.”

column1: Escalating the Republican angst was Trump’s rally Thursday in Delaware
column2: Ohio
column3: where he advanced conspiracies swirling around far-right websites about Clinton. He referred to reports that Democratic operatives with no direct connection to the Clinton campaign hired people to violently disrupt Trump events.

column1: “This criminal behavior that violates centuries of tradition of peaceful democratic elections
column2: a campaign like Clinton’s that will incite violence is truly a campaign that will do anything to win
column3: ” Trump said
column4: going on to call Clinton “a candidate who is truly capable of anything
column5: including voter fraud.”

column1: Trump also mentioned an email
column2: which surfaced on WikiLeaks through an illegal hack that U.S. authorities blame on the Russian government
column3: in which interim Democratic National Committee chairwoman Donna Brazile seemed to suggest to the Clinton team that she had knowledge of a question that would come up in a primary forum earlier this year. While Brazile has denied that CNN provided any questions in advance
column4: Trump called her actions “cheating at the highest level.”

column1: Even as his party loses faith
column2: Trump proclaimed that he was poised for victory.

column1: “Bottom line
column2: we’re going to win
column3: ” he told the boisterous Ohio crowd. “We’re going to win. We’re going to win so big. We’re going to win so big.”

column1: Jenna Johnson in Delaware
column2: Ohio; David Weigel in Charlotte; Krissah Thompson in Phoenix; and Juliet Eilperin
column3: Jose A. DelReal and Karoun Demirjian in Washington contributed to this report."	REAL

column1: If You Have One Of These Old VHS Tapes It May Be Worth Over $1000	"posted by Eddie Got VHS tapes collecting dust on a shelf somewhere? Maybe you already reclaimed the space and they’re sitting in an attic long-forgotten. Hopefully you didn’t throw them out
column2: though
column3: as it turns out there might be quite the market for some old tapes. Modern directorial practice for movie releases and re-releases tends to include adding or editing the film from the theatrical version. While some people don’t mind or even enjoy these changes
column4: for others
column5: the original cut is worth a hefty price tag. This translates to listings on eBay for certain tapes at astronomical prices
column6: like one particular Beauty and the Beast tape going for $9
column7: 999. The original Beauty and the Beast did not include the song “Human Again”; it was cut for space reasons
column8: then re-added to the 2002 special edition. However
column9: Disney tapes in particular might be valuable to collectors for other reasons. Reddit user Reddit_Executive speculates that
column10: because of the specific branding on original releases
column11: these movies could go for quite a bit: “On the spines of some VHS (and BetaMax) tapes is a black diamond with Walt’s signature on it. This was Disney’s first attempt to market their videos to homes. Because of this
column12: certain Disney collectors are convinced that these VHS tapes are worth something.” While it’s possible some tapes are indeed worth quite a bit
column13: many of the movies listed are actually selling for much less. Still
column14: if your plan for your old VHS tapes begins and ends with “trash them
column15: ” there’s no harm in doing your research on what they might be worth.

column1: Pope Francis met Kim Davis: why it matters in fight over religious freedom (+video)	"The decision by Pope Francis to give his personal blessing – and a rosary – to Rowan County clerk Kim Davis thrust the pontiff into one of America’s most volatile cultural battles.
In his meeting with controversial county clerk Kim Davis last Thursday
column2: Pope Francis reportedly told Ms. Davis to “stand strong” as she stands up for her religious beliefs in rural Kentucky.

column1: The meeting between the pontiff and a woman who went to jail for five days for defying a Supreme Court order to allow same-sex couples to marry came before Francis made comments about “conscientious objection” as a human right
column2: even for government officials.

column1: In some ways
column2: the meeting fit with the pope’s focus on the “spirit of encounter” as well as his unorthodox meetings with people he calls on the “peripheries.” And it also came days after he met with nuns fighting an Obamacare mandate on contraceptives
column3: another front in the American cultural wars.

column1: But the 15-minute tête-à-tête at the Vatican Embassy in Washington also jarred a number of narratives from the pope’s historic visit
column2: suggesting to some critics that the pontiff condoned Davis’ actions – which critics say amount to imposing her personal religious beliefs
column3: in violation of the Constitution
column4: on same-sex couples seeking marriage licenses.

column1: The decision by the pope to give his personal blessing – and a rosary – to Davis thrust the pontiff into one of America’s most volatile cultural battles.
In other ways
column2: however
column3: Francis focused Rome’s gaze on the changing dynamics of religious freedom in the progressive era
column4: offering a moment of pause for many Americans to consider growing questions about how the United States handles religious objections to same-sex unions.

column1: “I think both sides have either tried to vilify or champion Kim Davis in one way or another
column2: but what they’re forgetting is that the central issue here is of religious freedom in the US
column3: and how we treat it. What does it mean
column4: and what are its boundaries?” says Joe Valenzano
column5: an expert on religious rhetoric at the University of Dayton in Ohio. “The fact is
column6: both sides have made just a colossal mess out of this to further their own perspective
column7: rather than focusing on what could be a productive conversation for society.”

column1: The Vatican confirmed the meeting
column2: but gave no further commentary
column3: potentially suggesting that it didn’t want to get into the political details of the struggle over same-sex marriage in Rowan County
column4: Ky. For some Vatican observers
column5: it wasn’t surprising that the pope
column6: a religious figure
column7: met with someone who has become a lightning rod for her religious beliefs.

column1: The pope “took somebody on the front of the newspapers for faith-related concerns and met with her
column2: ” says Professor Valenzano. “[The pope told Davis that] you don’t lose faith because you lose a battle. That’s not the pope weighing in on the culture wars or endorsing Kim Davis’s position. That’s the pope endorsing the idea that religion is important to people.”

column1: Yet for all the pope’s focus on moral values
column2: the meeting with Davis and the nuns could have a political impact
column3: writes John Allen Jr.
column4: on Crux
column5: a Catholic news site. For one
column6: he writes
column7: the meeting “means that Francis has significantly strengthened the hand of the US bishops and other voices in American debates defending religious freedom.”

column1: The meeting also could give more direct encouragement to other US officials who have declined to offer marriage licenses to same-sex couples. A number of clerks and other government officials have followed Davis’s lead
column2: refusing to abide by the Supreme Court’s June ruling declaring same-sex marriage a constitutional right.

column1: The problem with that strategy
column2: however
column3: is that Davis
column4: for one
column5: represents what Doug Laycock calls a poor example of a religious martyr. He points out that Davis didn’t just want an opt-out from signing marriage licenses for same-sex couples. Instead
column6: after her release from jail
column7: she changed the Rowan County license form to take the name of the county off the form – a change the plaintiffs argue violates the judge’s order.

column1: “Kim Davis gives religious liberty a bad name
column2: and endangers it for everybody
column3: ” says Professor Laycock
column4: a religious liberty expert at the University of Virginia Law School in Charlottesville. “She does not have to issue marriage licenses. But the county is not entitled to exemption
column5: because the county does not have a religion. That’s the fundamental distinction.”

column1: Those nuances may have been lost on the pope
column2: Mr. Laycock suggests.

column1: “If you come here from Rome
column2: if you’re not closely following this
column3: you don’t have any sort of deep understanding of US law
column4: ” he says.

column1: The pontiff made waves in the US during his visit for his attempt to expand the Catholic church’s influence beyond the culture wars. He weighed in on climate change and the death penalty
column2: bolstering his bona fides among US liberals. But he also buckled down on church doctrine on abortion and threats to the sanctity of marriage
column3: to the applause of conservatives.

column1: “I can’t have in mind all the cases that can exist about conscientious objection
column2: ” the pope said on the papal plane last week
column3: “but yes
column4: I can say that conscientious objection is a right that is a part of every human right. It is a right.”

column1: “And if a person does not allow others to be a conscientious objector
column2: he denies a right
column3: ” he said
column4: adding
column5: in what may have been a reference to Davis
column6: “It is a human right
column7: and if a government official is a human person
column8: he has that right.”

column1: For American political operatives
column2: the pope’s message may ultimately be frustrating for its nuance. And that may be just fine with the pontiff. As Elizabeth Buerlin writes in the New Republic
column3: “Pope Francis maintains a conservative position on the morality of marriage
column4: and he is concerned for Christians who find their practice constrained by law. But he has also emphasized openness toward LGBT Catholics
column5: famously asking
column6: when queried about gay Catholics
column7: ‘Who am I to judge?’ ”

column1: In that way
column2: she writes
column3: Francis has
column4: at least until now
column5: shied away from directly engaging “the psychodrama of the American culture wars.”

column1: But by meeting with Davis privately
column2: the pope
column3: at the very least
column4: showed a willingness to take a stand on religious liberty
column5: even if it tarnished his message in the eyes of some Americans.

column1: “The news that Pope Francis met privately ... with Kim Davis throws a wet blanket on the good will that the pontiff had garnered during his US visit
column2: ” Francis DeBernardo
column3: executive director of gay and lesbian Catholic advocacy group New Ways Ministry
column4: told Reuters in an e-mail.

column1: At the same time
column2: some Americans said the visit may have helped humanize a polarizing figure in the struggle between deeply-felt religious beliefs and the equally deep desire by many gay Americans to marry.

column1: “Any time you get people talking and meeting and listening
column2: even if they don't agree
column3: as long as there is a dialogue
column4: I think we are better as a nation
column5: ” Judy Fitzpatrick
column6: a Catholic who describes herself as moderate Republican
column7: told a new Ipsos/Reuters poll
column8: after hearing about Francis meeting Davis."	REAL

column1: Study: Phytochemical Found In Broccoli And Cauliflower Attacks Prostate Cancer Cells	"in: Natural Medicine We all know that it’s important to eat our vegetables. At least
column2: that’s what most of us have heard since we were kids. What our mother’s told us as when we were young
column3: our doctors tell us as we get older. Sometimes though
column4: it helps to have a more specific reason than high cholesterol
column5: or even a motherly “because I said so.” Especially for people who aren’t big fans of eating organic greens. According to a study conducted at Oregon State University’s Linus Pauling Micronutrient Research Institute confirms that sulforaphane
column6: a phytochemical found in broccoli and related cruciferous vegetables
column7: such as cauliflower and cabbage
column8: have a natural ability to target and attack prostate cancer cells without harming neighboring cells [ 1 ] . Unconnected studies suggest it may have similar promise for breast cancer. The active chemicals found in everyday foods – such as broccoli – are often much more potent than people would imagine. If fact
column9: determining how to safely adapt these chemical ingredients for medical use is one of the biggest hurdles researchers face. Even edible plants that are considered “rich” in a given nutritional substance
column10: contain relatively low amounts of it by volume. The vast majority of these compounds may also become toxic to humans if taken in large enough concentrations. While a number of previous investigations have proven that sulforaphane is able to attack both benign and malignant cancer cells
column11: the Oregon State study is one of the first to prove that it is effective without disrupting otherwise healthy tissue. This gives researchers a tremendous tool for developing new
column12: low-risk treatment options
column13: and is likely to encourage additional research into the healing potential of other seemingly mundane edible plants. Realistically
column14: it could be some time before these findings are applied to any sort of drug development or cancer treatment in a traditional hospital setting. Meanwhile though
column15: the researchers behind the study recommend that we all eat more organic cruciferous vegetables. Besides broccoli
column16: a number of readily available cruciferous vegetables contain naturally large amounts of sulforaphane. Some good examples of foods high in this important phytochemical include mild and spicy radishes
column17: turnips
column18: watercress
column19: cabbage
column20: arugula
column21: kale
column22: chard
column23: and most other leafy greens. Unrelated studies also suggest a variety of other cancer-fighting compounds may be present in other herbs and garden vegetables. Celery and parsley
column24: for instance
column25: are especially rich in apigenin – a substance that has shown remarkable promise for fighting breast cancer. Trace amounts of apigenin are also found in oranges
column26: apples
column27: and some tree nuts. The problem is
column28: it’s very difficult for the body to effectively extract it from any of these foods on its own. References: Oregon State University. Study confirms safety
column29: cancer-targeting ability of nutrient in broccoli . News & Research Communications. 2011 June 9. Submit your review"	FAKE

The most hated President-elect ever will not be loved by the Congress she will confront. Even with a majority in the Senate--just possible--and in the House--not--prospects for a legislative agenda

column20: the Gold Sacks Mafia. They made her an offer she couldnt refuse. She wont attempt any closing of the inequality gap. That would entail clipping her base--Our Crowd of the Hamptons
column21: Palm Beach and Beverly Hills. She wont meddle with Sick Care--fool me once...--or

No need to do anything about Global Warming so long as you denounce it boldly at international meetings. Best leave the environment in the hands of those who can turn idle nature into money. Besides

Drudge, Koch, Soros, Bezos: These 4 non-politicians will determine the next president	"They’re approximately 20 percent accurate. While this list would have held water prior to the Supreme Court’s 2010 decision in Citizens United v. FEC
column2: The Hill places undue value on social media.

column1: “Twitter

column2: posts
column3: comments and shares” were a valid metric

column2: Donald Trump
