column1: The ability of nonprofits to accept unlimited individual donations to push a political agenda is far more important than whether or not the “money-losing” Huffington Post covers Trump under its “entertainment” or “politics” section.
So-called dark money
column2: in conjunction with a wide-reaching “mouthpiece
column3: ” paves the road to the Oval Office — and even a brilliant John Oliver expose can’t change that.

column1: Special interest groups — like the NRA — can scrounge up a good chunk of change for the candidate most likely to maintain the status quo
column2: but Super PACs are the best source of dark money.

column1: PACs have the added benefit of keeping their donors anonymous
column2: which is a nice feature for people who don’t want their tennis partners to know they bet on the wrong horse or
column3: worse yet
column4: backed Trump.

column1: As the face of the Koch Brothers — the infamous proprietors of libertarian-leaning Freedom Partners Action Fund — Charles Koch deals with the client-facing aspects of Koch PR.
In an interview with ABC on Sunday
column2: Charles Koch explained his and his brother David’s decision to withhold their much-coveted endorsement of the remaining candidates. In so doing
column3: Charles condemned what he called a “two-tiered system” (i.e. a regressive tax) and suggested Hillary Clinton might make a better president than Cruz or Trump.

column1: Koch’s Hillary support isn’t necessarily as out-of-left-field as it may seem
column2: considering the brothers’ recent embrace of criminal justice reform.

column1: Last spring
column2: Politico Magazine reported that “Koch had decided to help pull together a new coalition of left-right advocacy groups in Washington
column3: including the Hillary Clinton-aligned Center for American Progress” with an aim towards eradicating prison overcrowding.

column1: Among the major donors to the Center for American Progress is billionaire George Soros
column2: who’s given $7 million to the Hillary Clinton-endorsing Priorities USA Action Super PAC during the 2016 cycle.

column1: Soros was the top individual donor during the 2008 cycle as well
column2: giving $5 million to four 527 organizations. In 2012
column3: however
column4: he gave just $1 million to Obama reelection PAC
column5: Priorities USA. Soros has invested a relatively significant amount of personal money into this cycle
column6: and is likely to up the ante when the general election rolls around. There’s a limit to how far PAC money can keep a candidate afloat (e.g. Jeb! Bush and Li’l Marco Rubio). For lack of a less conspiratorial word
column7: every special interest needs a mouthpiece. Not a known political financier
column8: Amazon’s Jeff Bezos took a less direct route to political influence in purchasing the Washington Post in 2013. And though WaPo is a humongous organization
column9: editorial leanings in the media tend to have a top-down effect. Despite his nearly $55 billion net worth
column10: Bezos has donated relatively small amounts to Democrats ($28
column11: 000) and Republicans ($4
column12: 000). Some
column13: however
column14: claim he’s similar to other tech entrepreneurs who support a libertarian
column15: small-government platform. The Post hasn’t formally endorsed Clinton
column16: but its Editorial Board unmistakably condemned her primary opponent
column17: Bernie Sanders
column18: in a January article titled “Bernie Sanders’s fiction-filled campaign.” In the months since the Editorial Board’s unendorsement
column19: the Post has been accused of repeatedly parroting Clinton’s agenda. As the namesake of prominent news aggregation site
column20: Drudge Report
column21: Matt Drudge wields his right-wing influence through the careful curation of what appears on the site’s homepage. In their book
column22: “The Way to Win
column23: ” Mark Halperin and John F. Harris call Drudge “the single most influential purveyor of information about American politics” for his role in John Kerry’s loss in 2004. Drudge Report reader polls
column24: conducted after each televised debate this primary cycle
column25: consistently declared Trump the winner. And a when asked who they’re supporting for the presidency
column26: participating Drudge readers voted overwhelmingly in favor of Trump (60% to second place Ted Cruz’s 19%). And though these polls are decidedly unscientific
column27: they did capture the intensity of Trump’s support — the real story of the GOP campaign — and people are starting to give Drudge more and more credit as the Trump train chugs towards Cleveland. In a radio interview earlier this month
column28: Cruz complained that Drudge Report “has basically become the attack site for the Donald Trump campaign.” “By all appearances
column29: Roger Stone now decides what’s on Drudge
column30: and most days they have a six-month-old article that is some attack on me
column31: ” Cruz added. “Whatever the Trump campaign is pushing that day will be the banner headline on Drudge.”"	REAL

column1: The Other Way of Knowing	"By Lilian Na’ia Alessa / culturalsurvival.org
Western science and Indigenous worldviews are often seen as incompatible
column2: with the Indigenous view usually being far less valued by society at large. But an inside look at Indigenous ways of knowing shows that they offer unique and dependable insights
column3: in precisely the areas where Western science is often weakest.

column1: I grew up in a family where Bible study was mandatory. Yet
column2: despite the firm Christian branches that shaded my home
column3: there were traditional roots that anchored daily life. My grandmother spoke no English and went about her tasks singing. She sang to things I couldn’t see
column4: to stones and water. She spoke to the breezes that came off the sea. This was not odd to me. No question of sanity or need of counseling entered my mind. It was simply the mechanics of living
column5: of praise to God
column6: to the Creator. She wove fibers into amazing patterns
column7: placing them in water while singing. When she finished singing
column8: the coarse strands would be soaked and pliable and she would sing again until the pattern was done. Her songs
column9: I came to realize
column10: were timers for different tasks. She had no watch
column11: knew no math
column12: indeed had been denied the opportunity to get the education that became the currency of the world in her adulthood and old age. Instead
column13: she had acquired a sophisticated methodology to transform the resources that yielded to her hand
column14: and her hand only. There were no power tools
column15: no mechanical devices to ease her work. There was only an elegance of skill that no machine could replicate. As a child
column16: she was magic to me
column17: and at her deathbed the shock of her mortality severed my faith in these songs. I turned to the precision of Western learning
column18: so that such a fate would never befall me. So I would know the world
column19: and in that knowledge
column20: somehow control it.

column1: My desire to shun those things that had no firm margins grew as I came to learn the beauty and remarkable perfection of the universe through the eyes of those scholars who
column2: like the elders of my youth
column3: had discovered these things before. As I sat in uncomfortable chairs in lecture halls
column4: a number in a sea of students
column5: and despaired at the pain of examinations in those same chairs
column6: a profound awe of the very molecules that composed my body and everything surrounding me settled. When I realized that the ability to pursue this learning fell squarely on my ability to navigate a system of hard edges
column7: I panicked. I had been raised in a home swirling with soft fluidity of being.

column1: And now
column2: my learning rejected these things.

column1: But numbers sing
column2: too. Their words are clear and distinct
column3: and their combinations were refrains of certainty. The slow draining of the deep convictions of my upbringing and generations of women who had sustained children with their hands became a steady flow. Here lay the solution: I could understand all things by measuring them
column4: and in knowing those words I felt I could rewrite the song.

column1: The profound awe I felt as a student failed me when I took a job as a faculty researcher at a university. I came to realize that Western science hummed the words much of the time. I could see it coming: there were too many failures
column2: too many times when it was apparent that politics
column3: egos
column4: and cliques were the white noise that drowned out the song. Like the death of my grandmother
column5: it was a sound blow.

column1: Western science as a way of knowing has precision and discipline
column2: and unlike most other ways of knowing
column3: it can be faithfully replicated (most of the time) and understood by practitioners around the world
column4: regardless of their language. But I was led to believe that it could explain more than it really could. Its limitations could be found not only in the over-simplification of the world but also in the murky stupidity of politics
column5: greed
column6: and hubris. And so
column7: in my 30s
column8: I found my faith in Western science fall away like a rock cast off a mountain for the second time in my life. In my rush to compose
column9: rather than hear
column10: the song
column11: I was missing the synergy of the wisdoms of two worlds: one called “traditional” and the other called “Western.”

column1: The phrases “traditional ecological knowledge
column2: ”“traditional local knowledge
column3: ” and “folk knowledge” are often associated with “fuzzy knowledge
column4: ” the kind that comes from funneling information through a human instrument
column5: whereas “Western science” suggests an absolute objectivity
column6: immune from human bias. In order to discern between the two
column7: one must understand how different cultures
column8: including the “knowledge seekers” of both
column9: come to exist
column10: survive
column11: and thrive in their worlds. The bottom line is that both address knowing the world using different
column12: yet ultimately similar
column13: approaches. Western science excels at unraveling the unseen—our medical technology a testament to this precision—while traditional knowledge reveals the dynamics of larger systems
column14: particularly animals
column15: plants
column16: and habitats
column17: and the wisdom of our place among them.

column1: In general
column2: Western science and traditional knowledge are usually perceived as two separate
column3: distinct
column4: and somewhat incompatible entities. Why is this? In part
column5: it is simply stubbornness and fear on both sides. In practice they are very similar
column6: and in results they are highly complementary
column7: because one works well at small scales and the other at large scales. But in their origins they differ. Western science is relatively new and evolved from the philosophies of Aristotle and Bacon that sought to standardize information so that it could be used by groups of people who did not necessarily live in the same region. People who moved from one region to another relied on this information to aid the growth of their crops
column8: the health of their livestock
column9: and the survival of their young
column10: not to mention the development of weaponry
column11: defenses
column12: and trade. Aristotle stated that humans were separate from the rest of the “natural” world (this including animals
column13: plants
column14: and the places they lived). This was a pivotal time in history: medicine was advancing and people were making connections between cleanliness and protecting food sources from competing interests
column15: such as rats
column16: which also spread disease.

column1: Government   were providing security for more and more people
column2: most of whom had descended from tribes that survived by hunting and gathering and competing for these resources with neighboring tribes through conflict and
column3: less often
column4: fragile treaties of cooperation. With this shift from conflict to more and more centralized organization came more time to observe the components of the world not directly related to survival. While not new speculations
column5: a class of “observer” started documenting the way humans behaved with each other and other curious habits of the species. This class of observer was more often than not composed of members of religious sects
column6: such as the clergy
column7: and likely evolved from the strong shamanic heritage of their ancestral traditions. As these observations amassed and humans were ideologically “cleansed” of their socially offensive ties to the animal world
column8: human nature sought to explain the observations. Tied into this desire was an increasing belief that the surrounding world was less and less a living
column9: interacting system and more and more a source of resources
column10: composed of “parts
column11: ” each of which could be isolated
column12: understood
column13: and manipulated
column14: usually for the benefit of humans. At this point
column15: any oral histories that linked societies to their environments were rapidly being relegated to the outlying villages and remnants of nomadic peoples. In other words
column16: the “uneducated.” So the “observers” or “scholars” had isolated themselves from their environments and were increasingly reliant on a hierarchy of workers to support their existence and lifestyles
column17: distancing them from the lands and waters that sustained them. Could this be the point where Western science and traditional knowledge diverged as two distinct socially constructed approaches to “knowing?” That remains to be studied
column18: but perhaps one can link this early form of systematic observation and explanation to the relatively recent process called the “scientific method” which is often invoked to settle information-dependent conflicts.

column1: It is my opinion that an important distinction must be made between scales of knowledge with respect to the scientific method and traditional knowledge. Tech­nologies such as microscopes and antibodies have given us insights into the unseen worlds of micro-scale processes that we would otherwise never have acquired. As you increase the level of space (for example a cell in the body) and time
column2: you increase the level of complexity
column3: or how many things interact with each other at any given time. By the time you arrive at ecosystems
column4: the interactions of organisms and their habits
column5: you have accumulated an enormous amount of complexity. It becomes increasingly difficult to resolve what is causing which effect. As a consequence
column6: the scientific method and the Western approach to “understanding” is more tenuous
column7: and it is at this intersection of time and space that traditional knowledge is most apparent as another approach. By necessity
column8: Western science must simplify things to develop testable hypotheses about how they work
column9: which is both precise and useful at smaller scales. In the process
column10: however
column11: it eliminates details
column12: many of which are considered “descriptive” and either not important to understanding or too confounding. A hallmark of traditional knowledge is that details are exquisitely noted and communicated in such a way that the user can detect small changes and respond accordingly.

column1: This approach to traditional knowledge has existed as long as we have as a species. The act of residing
column2: surviving
column3: and thriving in a place means that the resident must “know” her environment in such a way as to repeatedly have a high likelihood of regularly acquiring necessary resources
column4: whether they are physical or not
column5: on a regular basis. The consequence of failure is not the ridicule of one’s peers or the failure to get a research grant; it is sickness
column6: suffering
column7: and death. One could say that the stakes in traditional knowledge are much higher
column8: and hence so is the precision. Traditional knowledge requires something that
column9: with few exceptions
column10: Western science has failed to accomplish: long periods of observation in the same place and the transmission of these observations to others in that place so that they can use them practically and often
column11: from a young age.

column1: Some Western schools of thought romanticize traditional knowledge and perceive that somehow possessing it brings ultimate harmony of the user with his world. No mistakes will be made because there exists a magical link where all things are known. This is part of the devalidation of traditional knowledge because it fails to acknowledge that it
column2: like the scientific method
column3: is a process where information is accepted or rejected based on receiving knowledge continuously
column4: both directly from the system and from one’s colleagues
column5: friends
column6: family
column7: and mentors
column8: usually to benefit the community and future generations.

column1: It should not be surprising that somebody suggests that the approach of traditional knowledge is not limited to humans. We have only recently become aware that elephants have very calculated ways of using and moving through their environments. They will find their food
column2: raise their young
column3: interact
column4: and bury their dead in ways that are distinct to their clans
column5: locations
column6: and preferences and they will transmit this information from one generation to the next using a complex subsonic language. My grandmother told me similar stories about ravens
column7: that we were really not that different
column8: and that if we searched our memories really hard
column9: we could actually see someone we knew in those brilliant
column10: wise
column11: winter eyes.

column1: Lilian “Na’ia” Alessa is of Salish ancestry. She received a doctorate in cell biology from the University of British Columbia and now works in the area of adaptive resource management in Alaska
column2: using tools from both traditional and Western ways of knowing. This article is adapted from Alessa’s chapter
column3: “What is Truth? Where Science and Traditional Knowledge Converge
column4: ” in The Alaska Native Reader
column5: edited by Maria Sháa Tláa Williams and published in 2009 by Duke University Press. For more information
column6: go to the Duke University Press website at www.dukeupress.edu [1] . 0.0 ·"	FAKE

column1: Obama and Putin outline competing visions on Syria	"President Obama and Russian President Vladimir Putin laid out sharply competing visions Monday about how to tackle the ongoing conflicts in Syria and elsewhere in the Middle East
column2: with each blaming the other for the region’s turmoil even as they signaled a willingness to address it together.

column1: In speeches to the U.N. General Assembly less than two hours apart
column2: each leader said he embraced a foreign policy approach that respects international norms that are essential to global stability. Later in the day
column3: the two met privately to hash out their differences and to see whether there was room for cooperation. The closed-door session lasted more than an hour and a half
column4: ending just before Obama was scheduled to host a reception for delegates.

column1: After the session
column2: Putin left for Moscow. In brief remarks to Russian reporters
column3: he described relations between the two countries as “regretfully at a rather low level” due to U.S. resistance but said that “we now have an understanding that our work needs to be strengthened
column4: at least on the bilateral basis. We are now thinking together on the creation of appropriate mechanisms.”

column1: A White House official
column2: who spoke on the condition of anonymity to discuss the private meeting
column3: said that while it gave Obama “clarity on their objectives
column4: ” the two sides continued to disagree on Syrian President Bashar al-Assad’s role in the conflict and his future.

column1: Russia’s “objectives are to go after ISIL and to support the government
column2: ” the official said
column3: using an acronym for the Islamic State. Administration officials have expressed concern that new Russian deployments in Syria would bolster Assad’s fight against his opponents rather than degrade the militants.

column1: In his speech
column2: Obama took direct aim at Russia’s military buildup in Syria as well as its support for Ukrainian separatists
column3: saying
column4: “We are told that such retrenchment is required to beat back disorder
column5: that it’s the only way to stamp out terrorism
column6: or prevent foreign meddling.

column1: “But I stand before you today believing in my core that we
column2: the nations of the world
column3: cannot return to the old ways of conflict and coercion. We cannot look backward. . . . And if we cannot work together more effectively
column4: we will all suffer the consequences.”

column1: [For Obama
column2: a week that showed the world as he wants it
column3: and how it really is]

column1: Putin
column2: for his part
column3: charged that attempts by Western nations to impose democracy — including in Iraq and Libya — were responsible for upheaval in the Middle East and North Africa. While people in those regions clearly wanted and deserved change
column4: “the export of revolutions
column5: this time so-called democratic ones
column6: ” he said
column7: had resulted in “violence and social disaster” instead of a “triumph for democracy.”

column1: Then Putin had a question. “I cannot help asking those who have forced this situation
column2: do you realize now what you have done?” he said in remarks that never mentioned but were clearly directed at the United States. “Policies based on self-conceit and belief in one’s exceptionality and impunity have never been abandoned.”

column1: Beyond the barbs
column2: the two raised the prospect of cooperating more closely on fighting Islamist terrorists and brokering a political solution in Syria
column3: where war has raged for 4 years. Obama and Putin — who opened their first extended
column4: formal meeting in two years with a stiff handshake before the cameras — remain divided over Assad
column5: whom Obama wants ousted and Putin continues to back.

column1: “The United States is prepared to work with any nation
column2: including Russia and Iran
column3: to resolve the conflict
column4: ” Obama said in his 42-minute speech. “But we must recognize that there cannot be
column5: after so much bloodshed
column6: so much carnage
column7: a return to the prewar status quo. . . . And so Assad and his allies cannot simply pacify the broad majority of a population who have been brutalized by chemical weapons and indiscriminate bombing.”

column1: Putin
column2: by contrast
column3: insisted that “no one but Assad’s forces­ and militias are truly fighting the Islamic State.” He said it would be an “enormous mistake to refuse to cooperate with the Syrian government and its armed ­forces.”

column1: Russia has directly challenged U.S. military and diplomatic dominance in the region and the U.S.-led coalition air campaign against the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria. Over the past month
column2: Putin has expanded Russia’s long-running provision of weapons to Assad with deployments of tanks and aircraft. Over the weekend
column3: Russia and Iraq announced that they would establish a rival anti-militant coalition in Baghdad to include Iran and Syria.

column1: In his speech before U.N. delegates
column2: Iranian President Hassan Rouhani echoed Putin’s comments
column3: saying that while the United States was responsible for the current tumult in the Middle East
column4: his government was willing to help bring “democracy” to Syria.

column1: Russia maintains that Western intervention in Syria is a violation of international law.
Putin proposed creating a “broad international coalition” that he compared to the “anti-Hilter coalition” during World War II.
Russia
column2: the current chair of the U.N. Security Council
column3: has called for a meeting next month to discuss how to better combat extremism. Moscow has also proposed a meeting among itself
column4: the United States and the governments of Iran
column5: Syria
column6: Saudi Arabia
column7: Turkey and Egypt on coordination over Syria.

column1: The Obama administration has not yet responded to the latter proposal
column2: and it remains unclear whether Saudi Arabia
column3: the most powerful Sunni Arab state opposed to Assad
column4: and Iran
column5: the Syrian leader’s other main backer
column6: would agree to cooperate on any Syrian initiative.

column1: Leading European members of the U.S.-led coalition
column2: which has been conducting air attacks against the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria over the past year
column3: have indicated that they believe the idea — and some cooperation with Russia — is worth exploring.

column1: French President François Hollande
column2: who last week authorized his country’s first air attacks in Syria
column3: said Monday that “today
column4: the moderate opposition is weak
column5: Bashar al-Assad is weak
column6: and ISIL is strong.”

column1: “We can’t stick to our original enemies
column2: ” he said in a morning session with reporters. “We have to gather everybody together.”

column1: “If Saudi Arabia and Iran can find agreement on the future of Syria
column2: then there can be an ­answer
column3: ” Hollande said.

column1: In comments last week
column2: British Prime Minister David Cameron and German Chancellor Angela Merkel appeared to be softening their position toward Assad
column3: at least temporarily. “We have to speak with many actors; this includes Assad
column4: but others as well
column5: ” Merkel said. “Not only with the United States of America
column6: Russia
column7: but with important regional partners
column8: Iran
column9: and Sunni countries such as Saudi Arabia.”

column1: European views have been influenced not only by the stagnation in the Syrian conflict and the Islamic State’s expansion in Iraq
column2: but also by the hundreds of thousands of refugees — many of them from Syria — who have been pouring into their countries.

column1: U.N. Secretary General Ban Ki-moon praised those European countries that have provided asylum but urged them to do more. “After the Second World War
column2: it was Europeans seeking the world’s assistance
column3: ” Ban said.

column1: Brazilian President Dilma Rousseff
column2: who was the first world leader to address the General Assembly on Monday
column3: drew applause when she noted that her country has already provided shelter to many Syrian refugees. Brazil loosened restrictions two years ago and has issued more than 7
column4: 000 visas to Syrian refugees at this point — more than any other country in Latin America.

column1: “We have our arms open to welcome refugees
column2: ” she said. “We are a multi­ethnic nation.”

column1: Obama and Putin also offered differing accounts of what had transpired in Ukraine
column2: where Russia has annexed Crimea and backed separatists in the country’s southeast.

column1: Although Putin devoted the bulk of his speech to Syria and terrorism
column2: he repeated Russia’s charge that the overthrow of Ukraine’s government early last year was “orchestrated from outside.” He said Russia would adhere to the Minsk agreements
column3: once they gave adequate representation to the legitimate demands of eastern Ukraine separatists that Moscow has backed.

column1: Obama
column2: however
column3: said the West would continue to impose economic sanctions on Russia unless it reversed course. “We cannot stand by when the sovereignty and territorial integrity of a nation is flagrantly violated.”

column1: While relations with Russia rank highest on Obama’s priority list during this visit
column2: his agenda includes other major bilateral meetings and working sessions. The president met privately Monday with Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi
column3: pressing him to adopt a more stringent target for cutting India’s carbon emissions in the coming decades
column4: and he convened a summit on bolstering U.N. peacekeeping forces.On Tuesday
column5: the president will sit down with Cuban President Raúl Castro and Kazakhstan President Nursultan Nazarbayev.

column1: Indian officials say they will announce their post-2020 climate target later this week. While they have indicated that they will embrace an ambitious goal for expanding renewable energy sources
column2: they have balked at the idea of committing to cutting their overall carbon output in the near future.

column1: Obama has privately pressed Modi to do more as part of the run-up to U.N. climate talks in December
column2: dispatching a senior adviser
column3: Brian Deese
column4: to New Delhi this month to discuss the matter. After their meeting Monday
column5: the president said
column6: “And what I indicated to the prime minister is that I really think that India’s leadership in this upcoming conference will set the tone not just for today but for decades to come.”

column1: Modi
column2: meanwhile
column3: reiterated his country’s commitment to install 175 gigawatts of renewable energy by 2022. “The president and I share an uncompromising commitment on climate change without affecting our ability to meet the development aspirations of humanity
column4: ” he said."	REAL

column1: Is the GOP losing Walmart?	"(CNN) As goes Walmart
column2: so goes the nation?

column1: Everyone from Apple CEO Tim Cook to the head of the NCAA slammed religious freedom laws being considered in several states this week
column2: warning that they would open the door to discrimination against gay and lesbian customers.

column1: But it was the opposition from Walmart
column2: the ubiquitous retailer that dots the American landscape
column3: that perhaps resonated most deeply
column4: providing the latest evidence of growing support for gay rights in the heartland.

column1: Walmart's staunch criticism of a religious freedom law in its home state of Arkansas came after the company said in February it would boost pay for about 500
column2: 000 workers well above the federal minimum wage. Taken together
column3: the company is emerging as a bellwether for shifting public opinion on hot-button political issues that divide conservatives and liberals.

column1: And some prominent Republicans are urging the party to take notice.
Former Minnesota Gov. Tim Pawlenty
column2: who famously called on the GOP to ""be the party of Sam's Club
column3: not just the country club
column4: told CNN that Walmart's actions ""foreshadow where the Republican Party will need to move.""

column1: The Republican Party will have to better stand for"" ideas on helping the middle class
column2: said Pawlenty
column3: the head of the Financial Services Roundtable
column4: a Washington lobbying group for the finance industry. The party's leaders must be ""willing to put forward ideas that will help modest income workers
column5: such as a reasonable increase in the minimum wage
column6: and prohibit discrimination in things such as jobs
column7: housing
column8: public accommodation against gays and lesbians.""

column1: Walmart
column2: which employs more than 50
column3: 000 people in Arkansas
column4: emerged victorious on Wednesday. Hours after the company's CEO
column5: Doug McMillon
column6: called on Republican Gov. Asa Hutchinson to veto the bill
column7: the governor held a news conference and announced he would not sign the legislation unless its language was fixed.

column1: Walmart's opposition to the religious freedom law once again puts the company at odds with many in the Republican Party
column2: which the company's political action committee has tended to support.

column1: It has been a gradual transformation for Walmart.
It's easy for someone like a Chick-fil-A to take a really polarizing position
column2: said Dwight Hill
column3: a partner at the retail consulting firm McMillanDoolittle. ""But in the world of the largest retailer in the world
column4: that's very different.""

column1: Hill added: Same-sex marriage
column2: ""while divisive
column3: it's becoming more common place here within the U.S.
column4: and the businesses by definition have to follow the trend of their customer.""

column1: The backlash over the religious freedom measures in Indiana and Arkansas this week is shining a bright light on the broader business community's overwhelming support for workplace policies that promote gay equality.
After Indiana Gov. Mike Pence
column2: a Republican
column3: signed his state's religious freedom bill into law
column4: CEOs of companies big and small across the country threatened to pull out of the Hoosier state.

column1: The resistance came from business leaders of all political persuasions
column2: including Bill Oesterle
column3: CEO of the business-rating website Angie's List and a one-time campaign manager for former Indiana Gov. Mitch Daniels. Oesterle announced that his company would put plans on hold to expand its footprint in Indianapolis in light of the state's passage of the religious freedom act.

column1: NASCAR
column2: scheduled to hold a race in Indianapolis this summer
column3: also spoke out against the Indiana law.

column1: What we're seeing over the past week is a tremendous amount of support from the business community who are standing up and are sending that equality is good for business and discrimination is bad for business
column2: said Jason Rahlan
column3: spokesman for the Human Rights Campaign.

column1: National Republicans are being forced to walk the fine line of protecting religious liberties and supporting nondiscrimination.
By the end of the week
column2: Indiana will be in the right place
column3: Bush said
column4: a reference to Pence's promise this week to fix his state's law in light of the widespread backlash.

column1: Others in the GOP field are digging in. Sen. Ted Cruz of Texas
column2: the only officially declared Republican presidential candidate
column3: said Wednesday that he had no interest in second-guessing Pence and lashed out at the business community for opposing the law.

column1: Meanwhile
column2: former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton
column3: who previously served on Walmart's board of directors
column4: called on Hutchinson to veto the Arkansas bill
column5: saying it would ""permit unfair discrimination"" against the LGBT community.

column1: Jay Chesshir
column2: CEO of the Little Rock Regional Chamber of Commerce in Arkansas
column3: welcomed Hutchinson's pledge on Wednesday to seek changes to his state's bill. He said businesses are not afraid to wade into a politically controversial debate to ensure inclusive workplace policies.

column1: When it comes to culture and quality of life
column2: businesses are extremely interested in engaging in debate simply because it impacts its more precious resource -- and that's its people
column3: Chesshir said. ""Therefore
column4: when issues arise that have negative or positive impact on those things
column5: then the business community will again speak and speak loudly."""	REAL

column1: Supreme Court Decides to Weigh in On Transgender Rights	"By Adalia Woodbury on Sun
column2: Oct 30th
column3: 2016 at 11:31 pm On Friday
column4: the Supreme Court decided to weigh in on transgender rights in the case of Gloucester County School Board vs. G.G. This gives the right wing another chance to take civil rights away from people they don’t like. Plain and simple. Share on Twitter Print This Post

column1: On Friday
column2: the Supreme Court decided to weigh in on transgender rights in the case of Gloucester County School Board vs. G.G . This gives the right wing another chance to take civil rights away from people they don’t like. Plain and simple.

column1: At issue is whether a transgender student who identifies as a boy has a right to use the bathroom that corresponds with the gender he identifies with.
Last summer
column2: the court granted the school board’s request to put a lower court ruling in the student’s favor on hold until the board filed its petition for review by the Supreme Court. Justice Breyer joined the conservative justices in that ruling as a courtesy.

column1: The Virginia school board established a policy mirroring “bathroom police” laws in red states like North Carolina that required students to use rest rooms and locker rooms to correspond with the gender they were assigned at birth.
In this case
column2: the district court ruled against G.G. by relying on a 1975 regulation allowing schools to provide “separate toilet
column3: locker room and shower facilities based on sex” provided those facilities are comparable to those provided to the opposite sex.

column1: In January 2015
column2: the Department of Education’s Office of Civil Rights issued a letter opining that if schools separate students in restroom and locker rooms based on their sex a “school must treat transgender students” in a manner consistent “with their gender identity.”

column1: Because of that letter
column2: the U.S. Court of Appeals for the 4th Circuit reversed the lower court ruling in favor of G.G. It relied on a 1997 Supreme Court decision that courts generally should defer to an agency’s interpretation of its own regulation.

column1: In reality
column2: the right wing hopes to achieve two political objectives with this case. First
column3: this is about denying basic rights and dignity to people who are transgender
column4: which is consistent with their ideological opposition to rights for women
column5: POC and members of the LGBT community. Second
column6: the right wing is hoping to weaken Federal Agencies by attacking their ability to interpret their own regulations."	FAKE

column1: If Hillary Clinton Is Charged With Obstruction Of Justice She Could Go To Prison For 20 Years	"Archives Michael On Television If Hillary Clinton Is Charged With Obstruction Of Justice She Could Go To Prison For 20 Years By Michael Snyder

column1: In the world of politics

column3: and now Hillary Clinton’s cover-up of her email scandal could send her to prison for a very
column4: very long time. When news broke that the FBI has renewed its investigation into Hillary Clinton’s emails
column5: it sent shockwaves throughout the political world . But this time around
column6: we aren’t just talking about an investigation into the mishandling of classified documents. I haven’t heard anyone talking about this
column7: but if the FBI discovers that Hillary Clinton altered
column8: destroyed or concealed any emails that should have been turned over to the FBI during the original investigation
column9: she could be charged with obstruction of justice. That would immediately end her political career
column10: and if she was found guilty it could send her to prison for the rest of her life.

column1: I have not seen a single news report mention the phrase “obstruction of justice” yet
column2: but I am convinced that there is a very good chance that this is where this scandal is heading. The following is the relevant part of the federal statute that deals with obstruction of justice …

column1: Whoever knowingly alters
column2: destroys
column3: mutilates
column4: conceals
column5: covers up
column6: falsified
column7: or makes a false entry in any record
column8: document
column9: or tangible object with the intent to impede
column10: obstruct
column11: or influence the investigation or proper administration of any matter within the jurisdiction of any department or agency of the United States or any case filed under Title 11
column12: or in relation to or contemplation of any such matter or case
column13: shall be fined under this title
column14: imprisoned not more than 20 years
column15: or both.

column1: If Hillary Clinton is sent to prison for 20 years
column2: that would essentially be for the rest of her life.

column1: I have a feeling that the FBI is going to find a great deal of evidence of obstruction of justice in Huma Abedin’s emails. But unfortunately there is not likely to be a resolution to this matter before November 8th
column2: because according to the Wall Street Journal there are approximately 650
column3: 000 emails to search through…

column1: As federal agents prepare to scour roughly 650
column2: 000 emails to see how many relate to a prior probe of Hillary Clinton ’s email use
column3: the surprise disclosure that investigators were pursuing the potential new evidence lays bare building tensions inside the bureau and the Justice Department over how to investigate the Democratic presidential nominee.

column1: Metadata found on the laptop used by former Rep. Anthony Weiner and his estranged wife Huma Abedin
column2: a close Clinton aide
column3: suggests there may be thousands of emails sent to or from the private server that Mrs. Clinton used while she was secretary of state
column4: according to people familiar with the matter. It will take weeks
column5: at a minimum
column6: to determine whether those messages are work-related from the time Ms. Abedin served with Mrs. Clinton at the State Department; how many are duplicates of emails already reviewed by the Federal Bureau of Investigation; and whether they include either classified information or important new evidence in the Clinton email probe.

column1: Of those 650
column2: 000 emails
column3: an inside source told Fox News that “ at least 10
column4: 000 ” would be of interest to the investigation.

column1: At this point
column2: FBI officials have not even begun searching through the emails
column3: because a search warrant has not been secured yet. The following comes from CNN …

column1: Government lawyers haven’t yet approached Abedin’s lawyers to seek an agreement to conduct the search. Sources earlier told CNN that those discussions had begun
column2: but the law enforcement officials now say they have not.

column1: Either way
column2: government lawyers plan to seek a search warrant from a judge to conduct the search of the computer
column3: the law enforcement officials said.

column1: But the FBI is reportedly already searching a laptop that was co-owned by Anthony Weiner and Huma Abedin
column2: and no warrant was necessary for that search because Weiner is cooperating with the FBI.

column1: Many have been wondering why FBI Director James Comey would choose to make such a bold move just over a week until election day. Surely he had to know that this would have a dramatic impact on the election
column2: and it is unlikely that he would have done so unless someone had already found something really big. In addition
column3: Comey was reportedly eager to find an opportunity to redeem himself in the eyes of his peers at the FBI. The following is an excerpt from a Daily Mail article that was written by Ed Klein
column4: the author of a recently released New York Times bestseller about the Clintons entitled “ Guilty As Sin “…

column1: ‘The atmosphere at the FBI has been toxic ever since Jim announced last July that he wouldn’t recommend an indictment against Hillary
column2: ’ said the source
column3: a close friend who has known Comey for nearly two decades
column4: shares family outings with him
column5: and accompanies him to Catholic mass every week.

column1: ‘Some people
column2: including department heads
column3: stopped talking to Jim
column4: and even ignored his greetings when they passed him in the hall
column5: ’ said the source. ‘They felt that he betrayed them and brought disgrace on the bureau by letting Hillary off with a slap on the wrist.’

column1: According to the source
column2: Comey fretted over the problem for months and discussed it at great length with his wife
column3: Patrice.

column1: He told his wife that he was depressed by the stack of resignation letters piling up on his desk from disaffected agents. The letters reminded him every day that morale in the FBI had hit rock bottom.
So what happens next?
In the most likely scenario
column2: the FBI will not have time to complete the investigation and decide whether or not to charge Hillary Clinton before the election. This means that we would go into November 8th with this scandal hanging over the Clinton campaign
column3: and that would seem to be very good news for Donald Trump.

column1: However
column2: it is possible that once the FBI starts searching through these emails that they could come to the conclusion very rapidly that charges against Clinton are warranted
column3: and if that happens we could still see some sort of announcement before election day.

column2: we could actually see Hillary Clinton forced out of the race before November 8th.

column1: Once again
column2: this appears to be very unlikely at this point
column3: but it is still possible.

column1: If Clinton was forced to step aside
column2: the Democrats would need to come up with a new nominee
column3: and that process would take time. In an article later today on The Most Important News I will reveal who I believe that nominee would be.

column1: In such a scenario
column2: the Democrats would desperately need time to get their act together
column3: and so we could actually see Barack Obama attempt to delay or suspend the election . The legality of such a move is highly questionable
column4: but Barack Obama has not allowed a little thing like the U.S. Constitution to stop him in the past.

column1: This week is going to be exceedingly interesting – that is for sure.
The craziest election in modern American history just keeps getting crazier
column2: and I have a feeling that even more twists and turns are ahead.

'Top secret' emails on Clinton server discussed drone program, may reference classified info	"The two emails on Hillary Rodham Clinton's private server that an auditor deemed ""top secret"" include a discussion of a news article detailing a U.S. drone operation and a separate conversation that could point back to highly classified material in an improper manner or merely reflect information collected independently
column2: U.S. officials who have reviewed the correspondence told The Associated Press.

column1: The sourcing of the information could have significant political implications as the 2016 presidential campaign heats up. Clinton
column2: the front-runner for the Democratic nomination
column3: agreed this week to turn over to the FBI the private server she used as secretary of state
column4: and Republicans in Congress have seized on the involvement of federal law enforcement as a sign that she was either negligent with the nation's secrets or worse.

column1: On Monday
column2: the inspector general for the 17 spy agencies that make up what is known as the intelligence community told Congress that two of 40 emails in a random sample of the 30
column3: 000 emails Clinton gave the State Department for review contained information deemed ""Top Secret/Sensitive Compartmented Information
column4: one of the government's highest levels of classification.

column1: The two emails were marked classified after consultations with the CIA
column2: which is where the material originated
column3: officials said.

column1: The officials who spoke to the AP on condition of anonymity work in intelligence and other agencies. They wouldn't detail the contents of the emails because of ongoing questions about classification level. Clinton did not transmit the sensitive information herself
column2: they said
column3: and nothing in the emails she received makes clear reference to communications intercepts
column4: confidential intelligence methods or any other form of sensitive sourcing.

column1: The drone exchange
column2: the officials said
column3: begins with a copy of a news article that discusses the CIA drone program that targets terrorists in Pakistan and elsewhere. While a secret program
column4: it is well-known and often reported on. The copy makes reference to classified information
column5: and a Clinton adviser follows up by dancing around a top secret in a way that could possibly be inferred as confirmation
column6: they said. Several officials
column7: however
column8: described this claim as tenuous.

column1: But a second email reviewed by Charles McCullough
column2: the intelligence community inspector general
column3: appears more suspect. Nothing in the message is ""lifted"" from classified documents
column4: the officials said
column5: though they differed on where the information in it was sourced. Some said it improperly points back to highly classified material
column6: while others countered that it was a classic case of what the government calls ""parallel reporting"" -- different people knowing the same thing through different means.

column1: The emails came to light Tuesday after Sen. Chuck Grassley
column2: R-Iowa
column3: reported that McCullough found four ""highly classified"" emails on the unusual homebrew server that Clinton used while she was secretary of State. Two were sent back to the State Department for review
column4: but Grassley said the other two were
column5: in fact
column6: classified at the closely guarded ""Top Secret/SCI level.""

column1: In a four-page fact sheet that accompanied a letter to Clinton supporters
column2: Clinton spokeswoman Jennifer Palmieri stressed that Clinton was permitted to use her own email account as a government employee and that the same process concerning classification reviews would still be taking place had she used the standard ""state.gov"" email account used by most department employees. The State Department
column3: meanwhile
column4: stressed that it wasn't clear if the material at issue ought to be considered classified at all.

column1: Still
column2: the developments suggested that the security of Clinton's email setup and how she guarded the nation's secrets will remain relevant campaign topics. Even if the emails highlighted by the intelligence community prove innocuous
column3: she will still face questions about whether she set up the private server with the aim of avoiding scrutiny
column4: whether emails she deleted because she said they were personal were actually work-related
column5: and whether she appropriately shielded such emails from possible foreign spies and hackers.

column1: Clinton says she exchanged about 60
column2: 000 emails in her four years as secretary of state. She turned over all but what she said were personal emails late last year. The department has been making those public as they are reviewed and scrubbed of any sensitive data.

column1: The State Department advised employees not to use personal email accounts for work
column2: but it wasn't prohibited. But Clinton's senior advisers at the State Department would have been briefed upon basic protocol for handling classified information and retaining government records. In Clinton's time
column3: most officials saved their emails onto a separate file or printed them out when leaving office. Only recently has the department begun automatically archiving the records of dozens of senior officials
column4: including Secretary of State John Kerry.

column1: In the emails
column2: Clinton's advisers appear cognizant of secrecy protections.

column1: In a series of August 2009 emails
column2: Clinton aide Huma Abedin told Clinton that the U.S. point-man for Afghanistan
column3: Richard Holbrooke
column4: and another official wanted ""to do a secure"" conversation to discuss Afghan elections. Clinton said she could talk after she received a fax of a classified Holbrooke memo
column5: also on a secure line. Later
column6: Abedin wrote: ""He can talk now. We can send secure fax now. And then connect call.""

column1: But other times
column2: the line was blurred. Among Clinton's exchanges now censored as classified by the State Department was a brief exchange in October 2009 with Jeffrey Feltman
column3: then the top U.S. diplomat for the Middle East. Both Clinton and Feltman's emails about an ""Egyptian proposal"" for a reconciliation ceremony with Hamas are marked B-1.4
column4: classified for national security reasons
column5: and completely blacked out from the email release.

column1: A longer email the same day from Clinton to former Sen. George Mitchell
column2: then Mideast peace envoy
column3: is also censored. Mitchell responds tersely and carefully that ""the Egyptian document has been received and is being translated. We'll review it tonight and tomorrow morning
column4: will consult with the Pals (Palestinians) through our Consul General
column5: and then I'll talk with Gen. S again. We'll keep you advised."""	REAL

column1: Miracles Man: Metaxas Vs. Closed Minds And A Closed Universe	"Last Christmas
column2: Christian apologist
column3: Eric Metaxas published an article in the opinion section of the Wall Street Journal about a ‘miracle’
column4: or perhaps I should say 'the miracle’ -- the origin of the universe. That article
column5: Science Increasingly Makes the Case for God went on to become
column6: if not quite a miracle
column7: at least a sort of wonder. It was shared via email and social media more than any other opinion article in the history of the Wall Street Journal. That’s really saying something
column8: since the Journal is known to have one of the most popular op/ed pages in the world. Former editor Robert Bartley quipped that his was the only opinion page in journalism that actually sold papers.

column1: Metaxas certainly tapped into something. As of this writing this morning
column2: that article has over 470
column3: 000 Facebook shares and well over 9
column4: 000 comments. The wonder is not the article itself
column5: but the phenomenon that in an age of angry pop atheism and sloppy ‘God-is-dead’ scientific journalism
column6: intelligent
column7: well-educated people
column8: the kind of people who read the Wall Street Journal
column9: still have minds which are open to the idea that the universe is not closed; that there is something (or Someone) beyond it who can intervene into it
column10: Who started it whirling into existence in the first place.

column1: I sat down across a Skype line with Metaxas recently to discuss the paperback release of his book
column2: Miracles: What They Are
column3: Why They Happen
column4: and How They Can Change Your Life. The first third of the book deals with philosophical issues: Are miracles possible? What are they exactly? And why are philosophical objections to them not quite as final or decisive as they purport to be?

column1: The rest of the book is actual miracle stories
column2: stories from history and stories from Metaxas’ circle of acquaintances. The latter are more persuasive than one might expect. We’ve all seen the toupee’d theurgist circuses of Christian television
column3: hawking Jordan river water and magic oils to the gullible. But the people Metaxas describes in this book are a little harder to write off: Educated
column4: well-read
column5: accomplished leaders. The charming little story of Gregory Alan Thornbury and his wife and the miracle of the car keys packs a little extra power when you realize that Dr. Thornbury is a highly accomplished philosopher. I’m not saying that it’s right that secular elites in this country should write-off the testimony of people from trailer parks
column6: I hate that contempt. But I am saying that if class and IQ are your excuses to not listen to people’s miracle stories
column7: then Miracles takes away at least that excuse.

column1: One of the most important features in the book is that miracles are not just intervention
column2: they are information. I found myself wanting more along this line than the book offered. The koine Greek word for miracle is teras
column3: and the word for sign is semeion
column4: which is etymologically related to ‘sign’. Miracles are a form of communication. Modern materialists and those believers who live in reaction to materialism seem to think that the message of miracles is that God exists (or gods exist) and that this world is not the only world. The problem with that is that the miracles of the New Testament appeared in a world in which materialism was very rare
column5: almost unknown outside upper class Romans. Jesus’ disputes with the religious leaders were not about whether God existed
column6: they were about who God approved of and who He did not. In information science terms
column7: miracles have 'entropy’ departures from the expected deterministic route
column8: conferring signal or
column9: as my friend George Gilder would say it
column10: ‘surprise’.

column1: Below you can find a partial transcript of the interview (which has been edited for clarity)
column2: and if you want the whole thing you can listen here.

column1: JERRY BOWYER:  Eric Metaxas is our guest.  He's the author of Miracles: What They Are
column2: Why They Happen
column3: and How They Can Change Your Life
column4: which has just been published in the paperback edition.

column1: Eric
column2: thanks for joining us today.

column1: ERIC METAXAS:  Well
column2: it is my pleasure.  Thanks for having me.

column1: METAXAS:  Well
column2: that's not so easy to answer.  I would say that there are two answers; they're equally true
column3: because it depends on what your definition is.  And I kind of go with both in the book.  One definition is anything that is an injection into the material world
column4: into the universe of time and space
column5: from outside of that world.  So anytime anything happens in this world
column6: and you say this isn't possible to explain naturalistically
column7: that can be a miracle.

column1: The parting of the Red Sea was not a coincidence.  Jesus walking on water was not a hallucination.  If those things actually happened
column2: you can say those are miracles.

column1: But also -- well
column2: let me put it this way.  I say that those kinds of miracles are God's way of speaking to us
column3: trying to get our attention.  And so that's a particular kind of miracle.  So most of us
column4: when we say something is a miracle
column5: that's what we're talking about.  We're not just talking about something amazing; we're talking about something amazing that actually involves God.

column1: But alternatively
column2: when we're talking about
column3: let's say the creation of the universe
column4: the Big Bang
column5: when you look at the details of it -- and the first part of my book deals with faith and science -- the scientific details of it
column6: the more we know from science
column7: the scientific details of it are so staggering that you can't help but think this had to have been something that God did.

column1: So on one level
column2: everything
column3: all of creation
column4: partakes in the miraculous; if you believe that God is involved on any level
column5: every electron spinning around every nucleus of every atom is somehow miraculous.

column1: But basically
column2: when we're talking about miracles
column3: we're not talking about that.  We're typically talking about
column4: you know
column5: I prayed for Uncle Jimmy and suddenly he could walk again.  You know
column6: that's the kind of a miracle typically we're talking about.  And most of the miracles in the book are those kinds of miracles.  And the thirty miracle stories at the end of the book are definitely those kinds of miracles.

column1: BOWYER:  So your definition of miracle does not include
column2: say
column3: the act of creation.  That might be a wonder
column4: because it's not an intervention into an existing set of physical laws; it's the origin of that existing set of physical laws.

column1: METAXAS:  That is extremely heavy.  I wasn't prepared for that.  I would have gotten the coffee before the interview.  That is a brilliant
column2: wonderful observation and clarification.  And I'm not used to this
column3: Jerry
column4: so thank you for doing that.

column1: I would actually say that the act of creation is a miracle
column2: but it is -- as I meant to clarify earlier
column3: it's a different kind of miracle
column4: because there was no one there to observe it happening.  Although
column5: in retrospect
column6: through science
column7: we can see what happened
column8: and we can be staggered retroactively
column9: or retrospectively
column10: we can be staggered.  The more you look at the origins of the universe
column11: the more you look at what was necessary for the universe to come into being
column12: the more you say this simply could not have happened
column13: that makes no logical sense.  Occam's razor says it's much easier to say God did it
column14: than to say
column15: you know
column16: a thousand things had to line up perfectly
column17: and
column18: oh by the way
column19: coincidentally
column20: they did.  That makes infinitely less sense; it's infinitely less plausible.

column1: BOWYER:  All right.  So just a quick aside for nonphilosophical listeners and readers
column2: Occam's razor refers to the principle that all other things being equal
column3: the simpler the explanation which explains all the observations
column4: the more likely that explanation is to be true.

column1: METAXAS:  Yeah.  When you're talking about science
column2: sometimes people are so put off by the idea that God created the universe that they come up with these baroque
column3: really hilarious alternative explanations.  Like
column4: they say oh
column5: there's an infinity of universes; by the way
column6: we can't see them and we have no evidence for them
column7: but there has to be.  And of all of those infinite universes
column8: one of them got everything perfectly right.  And guess what
column9: we just happen to be living here right now… It's just swell.  Now
column10: to me
column11: when people say that
column12: I think that's actually less scientific than saying a creator created the universe.

column1: BOWYER:  Because by definition
column2: there is no possible observation of multiverses.  They were completely hermetically sealed off from us.

column1: METAXAS:  Right.  And this is what people -- people who advocate for so-called multiverse theory
column2: themselves
column3: say that there's no evidence for them.  So it's a really tremendous speculation that makes believing in the God of the Bible look infinitely scientific in comparison."	REAL

column1: Obamacare Premiums Spike an Average of 25%!	"Print

Some worrisome news is breaking across the nation where most Americans are now preparing to deal with a major spike in their already astronomical healthcare costs. The AP is reporting that healthcare premiums are about to rise an average of 25% across the country
column2: even as many American families are already struggling to pay their current premiums.

column1: Premiums will go up sharply next year under President Barack Obama’s health care law
column2: and many consumers will be down to just one insurer
column3: the administration confirmed Monday. That’s sure to stoke another “Obamacare” controversy days before a presidential election.

column1: Before taxpayer-provided subsidies
column2: premiums for a midlevel benchmark plan will increase an average of 25 percent across the 39 states served by the federally run online market
column3: according to a report from the Department of Health and Human Services. Some states will see much bigger jumps
column4: others less.

column1: Moreover
column2: about 1 in 5 consumers will only have plans from a single insurer to pick from
column3: after major national carriers such as UnitedHealth Group
column4: Humana and Aetna scaled back their roles.

column1: “Consumers will be faced this year with not only big premium increases but also with a declining number of insurers participating
column2: and that will lead to a tumultuous open enrollment period
column3: ” said Larry Levitt
column4: who tracks the health care law for the nonpartisan Kaiser Family Foundation.

column1: Fox News took the time on Monday to hammer House Minority leader Nancy Pelosi (D-CA) for her lies that Obamacare would make it easier for most Americans to get healthcare and that it would keep prices more “affordable.”
Pelosi’s definition of affordable seems to be the exact opposite of what it actually means
column2: because instead of slowing our rising healthcare costs
column3: prices have actually been climbing higher
column4: faster !

column1: Administration officials are stressing that subsidies provided under the law
column2: which are designed to rise alongside premiums
column3: will insulate most customers from sticker shock. They add that consumers who are willing to switch to cheaper plans will still be able to find bargains.

column1: “Headline rates are generally rising faster than in previous years
column2: ” acknowledged HHS spokesman Kevin Griffis. But he added that for most consumers
column3: “headline rates are not what they pay.”

column1: Senator Ben Sasse (R-NE) wants to hear the Obama administration and their Democrat allies apologize for the disastrous plan
column2: because thus far it seems to have hurt the average American far more than its helped. “We’ve reached this point because ObamaCare is built on the lie that Washington’s bureaucrats are smart enough to plan health care for millions of Americans. At every turn — whether it’s CO-OPs collapsing
column3: premiums skyrocketing
column4: or big insurers bailing — the American people have paid the price. More spin won’t solve this — it’s time for the White House to admit that this law isn’t working.”

column1: The people of Arizona woke up to even scarier news on Wednesday when they learned that their premiums would be rising by 116% this year!
However
column2: in Arizona
column3: unsubsidized premiums for a hypothetical 27-year-old buying a benchmark “second-lowest cost silver plan” will jump by 116 percent
column4: from $196 to $422
column5: according to the administration report…

column1: Sen. John McCain
column2: R-Ariz.
column3: called the Affordable Care Act a “failure.”

column1: “Arizona families are demanding affordability
column2: accessibility and choice when it comes to their health care – not the expensive
column3: restrictive and poor quality care that has been forced upon them by Obamacare
column4: ” McCain said in a statement. “Until President Obama and Congressional Democrats wake up to the law’s failure
column5: and until we repeal and replace it with solutions that encourage competition and put patients back in charge
column6: the Washington-knows-best approach will continue to unfairly burden the Arizona families it was supposed to help.”

column1: Meanwhile
column2: it seems that Hillary Clinton hasn’t gotten the memo about how bad Obamacare has been or about how much it’s hurt our economy
column3: because she’s still out there running victory laps for the abysmal failure. ""You know
column4: before it was called Obamacare
column5: it was called Hillarycare."" #DemDebate pic.twitter.com/TfalVkgAgO

column1: — Hillary Clinton (@HillaryClinton) February 12
Somebody should probably tell her that the majority of Americans hate Obamacare and would prefer seeing it repealed.
In a summer that saw many insurers drop out of the Affordable Care Act’s health insurance exchanges
column2: Americans’ support for the healthcare law continues to be slightly more negative than positive. Now
column3: 44% of Americans support the law
column4: also known as Obamacare
column5: and 51% disapprove of it — similar to what Gallup measured last November.

column1: 51% disapprove of Obamacare (or Hillarycare if you prefer)

column1: Hopefully

Collective Consciousness – The Individual is Gone	"Waking Times
“In the middle of all the brain-research going on
column2: from one end of the planet to the other
column3: there is the assumption that the individual doesn’t really exist. He’s a fiction. There is only the motion of particles in the brain. Therefore
column4: nothing is inviolate
column5: nothing is protected. Make the brain do A
column6: make it do B; it doesn’t matter. What matters is harmonizing these tiny particles
column7: in order to build a collective consensus
column8: in order to force a science of behavior.” ~The Underground
column9: Jon Rappoport

column1: Individual power. Your power.
It stands as the essence of what the founding documents of the American Republic are all about
column2: once you scratch below the surface a millimeter or so.

column1: Therefore
column2: it stands to reason that colleges and universities would be teaching courses in INDIVIDUAL POWER.

column1: As soon as I write that
column2: though
column3: we all fall down laughing
column4: because we understand the absurdity of such a proposition. Can you imagine Harvard endowing a chair in Individual Power?

column1: Students would tear down the building in which such courses were taught. They’ve been carefully instructed that the individual is the greatest living threat to the planet.
If you can’t see that as mind control
column2: visit your local optometrist and get a prescription for glasses.

column1: So we have this astonishing situation: the very basis of freedom has no reflection in the educational system.
You can say “individual” within certain limited contexts. You can say “power
column2: ” if you’re talking about nuclear plants
column3: or if you’re accusing someone of a crime
column4: but if you put “individual” and “power” together and attribute a positive quality to the combination
column5: you’re way
column6: way outside the consensus. You’re crazy. You’re committing some kind of treason.

column1: In order to spot the deepest versions of educational brainwashing
column2: YOU HAVE TO HAVE SOME STANDARD AGAINST WHICH YOU CAN COMPARE WHAT IS COMING DOWN THE PIPELINE INTO THE MINDS OF STUDENTS.

column1: If you lack that standard
column2: you miss most of the action.

column1: If you lack that standard
column2: you have already been worked over by the system.

column1: And in this case
column2: the standard is INDIVIDUAL POWER.

column1: Clean it off
column2: hose off the dirt
column3: polish it
column4: look at it
column5: think about it
column6: remember it.

column1: Then you’ll see some Grade-A prime mind control. Everywhere. Because schools either don’t mention it
column2: or they discredit it.

column1: Back in the days when I was writing on assignment for newspapers and magazines
column2: I pitched a story about individual power to an editor. I wanted to trace its history as an idea over the past ten years.

column1: He looked at me for a few seconds. He looked at me as if I’d just dropped some cow flop on his desk. He knew I wasn’t kidding and I had something I could write and turn in to him
column2: but that made it worse. He began to squirm in his chair.

column1: He laughed nervously.
He said
column2: “This isn’t what we do.”

column1: For him
column2: I was suddenly radioactive.

column1: I had a similar experience with a high-school history teacher in California. We were having lunch in a cafe in Santa Monica
column2: and I said
column3: “You should teach a course in individual power. The positive aspects. No group stuff. Just the individual.”

column1: He frowned a deep intellectual frown
column2: as if I’d just opened my jacket and exposed a few sticks of dynamite strapped to my chest. As if he was thinking about which agency of the government to report me to.

column1: Now
column2: for the schizoid part. The movies. Television. Video games. Comics. Graphic novels. They are filled to the brim
column3: they are overflowing with individual heroes who have considerable power. These entertainment businesses bank billions of dollars
column4: because people want to immerse themselves in that universe where the individual is supreme. They want it badly.

column1: But when it comes to “real” life
column2: power stops at the front door and no one answers the bell.

column1: Suddenly
column2: the hero
column3: the person with power is anathema. He’s left holding the bag. So he adjusts. He waits. He wonders. He settles for less
column4: far less. He stifles his hopes. He shrinks. He forgets. He develops “problems” and tries to solve them within an impossibly narrow context. He redefines success and victory down to meet limited expectations. He strives for the normal and the average. For his efforts
column5: he receives tidbits
column6: like a dog looking up at his master.

column1: If that isn’t mind control
column2: nothing is.

column1: Once we enter a world where the individual no longer has credibility
column2: a world where “greatest good for the greatest number” is the overriding principle
column3: and where that principle is defined by the elite few
column4: the term “mind control” will have a positive connotation. It will be accepted as the obvious strategy for achieving “peace in our time.”

column1: At a job interview
column2: a candidate will say
column3: “Yes
column4: I received my PhD in Mind Control at Yale
column5: and then I did three years of post-doc work in Cooperative Learning Studies at MIT. My PhD thesis? It was titled
column6: ‘Coordination Strategies in the Classroom for Eliminating the Concept of the Individual.’”

column1: From Wikipedia
column2: “Cooperative Learning”:

column1: “Students must work in groups to complete tasks collectively toward academic goals. Unlike individual learning
column2: which can be competitive in nature
column3: students learning cooperatively can capitalize on one another’s resources and skills…Furthermore
column4: the teacher’s role changes from giving information to facilitating students’ learning. Everyone succeeds when the group succeeds.”

column1: That is a towering assemblage of bullshit.

“Everyone succeeds when the group succeeds.” You could use that quote on the back cover of Orwell’s 1984 or Huxley’s Brave New World . Everyone does not succeed—because the individual never finds out what he can do on his own. That avenue is cut off. He only knows what he can achieve in combination with others. He only knows what he can understand when he borrows from others. He may never glimpse what he truly wants to do in life.
This is a tragic situation
column2: but the tragedy is concealed
column3: because the memory of shifting from individual independence to group dependence is gone. There is no such memory. A child is brought up without independence. Therefore
column4: how can he recall losing it?

column1: He only knows the group and the team and the participation and the praise. He only knows the organizing of his life within a synthetically produced context.
He is taught that this is good and necessary.
So
column2: one day
column3: when a bolt comes out of the blue and he recognizes he is himself
column4: what will he use to grasp that revelation and build on it?

column1: Yes
column2: there are productive groups and teams
column3: and one is always working with others
column4: to some degree. But the core and the starting point is one’s self. That is where the insight and the magic begin. That is where the great decisions and commitments are made. That is where the world is born
column5: every day.

column1: I see no end of writing about this magic
column2: because civilization has been turned upside down by treacherous people who have been fabricating a counter-tradition that will sink the ship. About the Author

column2: THE MATRIX REVEALED
column3: EXIT FROM THE MATRIX
column4: and POWER OUTSIDE THE MATRIX

column8: writing articles on politics
column9: medicine
column10: and health for CBS Healthwatch
column11: LA Weekly
column12: Spin Magazine

column14: and other newspapers and magazines in the US and Europe. Jon has delivered lectures and seminars on global politics
column15: health
column16: logic
column17: and creative power to audiences around the world. You can sign up for his free emails at NoMoreFakeNews.com or OutsideTheRealityMachine .
