Obama on gun control: His emotional evolution	"But on one issue -- guns -- President Barack Obama lets the public mask slip
column2: revealing the ire boiling within.

column1: Before the cameras
column2: moved by the massacres of innocents that have punctuated his presidency
column3: Obama has wept
column4: his voice has cracked
column5: he's visibly shaken with frustration
column6: he's lashed out at lawmakers he sees as cowards and even led a congregation in ""Amazing Grace.""

column1: On Tuesday
column2: as he faced a room filled with parents and relatives of victims of gun violence
column3: he stopped speaking
column4: grew silent and wiped away the tears that began to fall when he recalled the first graders killed in a Connecticut elementary school three years ago.

column1: Every time I think about those kids
column2: it gets me mad
column3: Obama said in the East Room of the White House.

column1: At times
column2: the President has questioned the nation he leads
column3: asking why no other advanced country seems so blighted with regular killing sprees and wondering aloud why Americans will not choose to stop the bloodshed.

column1: Evolving through a cycle of sadness
column2: poleaxing grief
column3: frustration and outright fury
column4: Obama has even offered hints of self-recrimination at his own earlier failure to touch the perfidious politics of gun control himself.

column1: But so far
column2: all the emoting
column3: anger and frustration have added up to little. Despite an expansive flexing of his executive powers
column4: Obama
column5: hampered by a Republican Congress and wary Democrats
column6: has failed to significantly tighten gun control laws.

column1: We are not inherently more prone to violence. But we are the only advanced country on Earth that sees this kind of mass violence erupt with this kind of frequency. It doesn't happen in other advanced countries. It's not even close
column2: Obama said. ""Somehow we become numb to it and we start to feel that this is normal. And instead of thinking about how to solve the problem
column3: this has become one of our most polarized
column4: partisan debates
column5: despite the fact that there's a general consensus in America about what needs to be done.""

column1: He added
column2: ""We do have to feel a sense of urgency about it. In Dr. King's words
column3: we need to feel the fierce urgency of now -- because people are dying.""

column1: He will also press for public support on the issue at a live town hall meeting hosted by CNN on Thursday night -- making gun violence a priority of his final year in office
column2: days before his valedictory State of the Union address.

column1: Obama insisted Tuesday that he merely wants to enact a few common-sense gun safety measures. But the gun lobby is mobilizing and Republicans
column2: led by 2016 front-runner Donald Trump
column3: insist Obama is out to make it impossible for people to buy guns.

column1: From the campaign trail to Tucson to Aurora
Obama's often demoralizing and politically radioactive experience with the politics of gun control started when he first set eyes on the White House and have confounded him ever since.
He got off on the wrong foot with Second Amendment advocates with an offhand remark during his 2008 campaign
column2: when he said people in Midwest communities hit hard by economic blight ""cling to guns or religion.""

column1: That seemed to many critics as disdainful of lawful firearms owners themselves
column2: a slip his foes have used again and again to warn the president is coming to get their guns.

column1: Obama also appeared to underestimate the potency of the gun lobby and National Rifle Association back then as well.
What we have to do is get beyond the politics of this issue
column2: Obama he said at a 2008 Democratic debate in Philadelphia.

column1: But when he took office
column2: gun control seemed far from his mind. With a financial crisis raging
column3: and other priorities like health care reform demanding political capital
column4: Obama was absent on the issue while Democrats controlled both chambers of Congress.

column1: And to be fair
column2: there were few Democrats -- especially those in red states -- who would have welcomed tough votes on gun control.

column1: At a memorial service
column2: a saddened Obama comforted relatives and cracked hearts when he hoped the youngest victim
column3: nine-year-old Christina Taylor Green
column4: was jumping ""in rain puddles in Heaven.""

column1: But he used the tragedy
column2: not to make the kind of outspoken call for gun control that would become familiar in later years but to call on Americans to cleanse their poisoned politics.

column1: Rather than pointing fingers or assigning blame
column2: let's use this occasion to expand our moral imaginations
column3: to listen to each other more carefully
column4: he said.

column1: In the months to come
column2: Obama would be called upon to react to more shootings

column1: What Scientists Found Inside This 800-Year-Old Pot... Is Changing History!	"Share on Facebook In 2008
column2: on a dig in the First Nation’s Menominee Reservation in Wisconsin
column3: archaeologists made a small but stunning discovery: a tiny clay pot. Though it might not have seemed very impressive at first glimpse
column4: this little piece of pottery was determined to be about 800 years old. And inside that pot? Something that changes how we're looking at extinction
column5: preservation
column6: and food storage
column7: as well as how humans have influenced the planet in their time on it. It's amazing to think that a little clay pot buried in the ground 800 years ago would still be relevant today
column8: but it's true! It's actually brought an extinct species of squash that was presumed to be lost forever. Thank our Indigenous Ancestors! Even they knew what preservation meant. They knew the importance of the future
column9: Is it not amazing that they are affecting our walks of life even to this day? Here it is! The pot was unearthed on the Menominee Reservation in Wisconsin
column10: where it had laid buried for the past 800 years. Inside
column11: archaeologists found a stash of seeds. The seeds were probably buried in the pot as a method of storing food supplies. They were determined to be an old
column12: now-extinct species of squash. Now
column13: seven years after making this stunning discovery
column14: students in Winnipeg decided to plant the 800-year-old seeds… to everyone's amazement
column15: something grew! The squash was named Gete-Okosomin. It means “cool old squash” in the Menominee language. (Respect to the science people for respecting the indigenous people who's land this was found on
column16: we see your good nature!) Now
column17: they're working to cultivate the squash so that it doesn't go extinct… again. It may be just a humble squash
column18: but it's also a symbol of first nations' community and history
column19: as well as a fascinating look into how amazing plants can be. It just goes to show you that plants can be pretty incredible… and that sometimes
column20: history has a funny way of coming back around. The Wheel of Life really stands out in this instance of history. Our Indigenous roots are strong and very much tied to the land. I was taught once that the people of Turtle Island were keepers of the land
column21: not owners. I feel like this Squash is proof of that teaching. Check out the original story & the role of White Earth Land Recovery Project (where seed keepers tend to these seeds) or Winona LaDuke (who named the squash)! Related:"	FAKE

column1: The Clock Is Ticking And Republicans Still Have No Serious Obamacare Alternative	"Republicans keep saying they’ll be ready to act if the Supreme Court upholds the big legal challenge to Obamacare
column2: thereby wiping out financial assistance for millions of people in two-thirds of the states.

column1: With the clock ticking down to a ruling
column2: it’s gotten awfully hard to take the GOP’s vows seriously.

column1: Most experts expect the court to rule on King v. Burwell
column2: as the case is known
column3: on or around June 29
column4: which is the last official day of its term. A victory for the plaintiffs would cut off tax credits that residents in Florida
column5: Texas and 32 other states now use to pay for health insurance they obtain through Healthcare.gov
column6: the federally operated marketplace.

column1: The ranks of the uninsured would swell by more than 8 million
column2: according to an estimate by the Urban Institute. The loss of so many customers would likely force insurance companies to raise premiums and withdraw altogether from some markets
column3: affecting even those customers buying directly from insurers rather than through Obamacare's marketplaces.

column1: Under Supreme Court rules
column2: an order would typically take effect within 25 days of its announcement from the bench. In theory
column3: the court could issue a stay delaying its impact. In practice
column4: legal experts consider such a move both unlikely and of questionable significance
column5: given the tight deadlines that insurers and state regulators face for setting next year's premiums.

column1: Infographic by Alissa Scheller for The Huffington Post.
Leaders of the Republican Party have cheered on the lawsuit
column2: in some cases filing formal friend-of-the-court briefs in support of it. They have also promised -- in op-eds
column3: speeches and interviews -- to craft a “transitional” plan
column4: or some kind of “off-ramp
column5: ” if the lawsuit is successful. The goals of such plans
column6: Republican leaders have said
column7: would be to minimize disruption for the people who now depend upon Affordable Care Act tax credits for their insurance
column8: while crafting a long-term replacement scheme that would serve the public better than President Barack Obama’s health care law has.

column1: Rep. Paul Ryan (R-Wis.) was among those who made that promise back in early February
column2: shortly after he took over as chairman of the Ways and Means Committee. “We have to have a contingency plan
column3: ” Ryan said. “We think we need to have an option
column4: a plan
column5: for these states that might find themselves in this difficult position.”

column1: Ryan’s committee
column2: arguably the most powerful in the House
column3: has direct jurisdiction over health care financing. So how many hearings has it held about these contingency plans?

column1: Zero.
Over in the Senate
column2: Ron Johnson (R-Wis.) has introduced actual legislation and it has nearly 30 co-sponsors
column3: including Mitch McConnell (R-Ky.)
column4: who is the majority leader. But the bill is at best a first draft at legislation and
column5: so far
column6: neither the Finance Committee (which has the most power over health legislation) nor the Health
column7: Education
column8: Labor and Pensions Committee (which also has some jurisdiction) has sought testimony or scheduled a hearing -- about either the Johnson bill specifically or
column9: more generally
column10: what to do if the Supreme Court stops the tax credits in those 34 states.

column1: No
column2: in the six months since the Supreme Court announced it would hear King v. Burwell
column3: Republicans in Congress have held exactly one formal hearing that focused on the subject. It took place last week
column4: before the Senate Small Business and Entrepreneurship Committee. But the Small Business Committee is among the least powerful in Congress and it has virtually no jurisdiction over health care financing issues. That may explain why it attracted very little interest -- even from committee members
column5: only a handful of whom bothered to show up.

column1: A generous takeaway from that hearing -- and lack of others -- is that Republicans are thinking about and working on health care plans much more intensely behind the scenes. Brendan Buck
column2: Ryan’s spokesman
column3: pointed out to The Huffington Post that Republican leaders have convened a working group to craft a post-King contingency plan -- with Ryan among its leaders. That group is now meeting three times a week
column4: Buck said: “They’re informal
column5: but it’s an active group.”

column1: In addition
column2: several high-profile conservative intellectuals have been talking and writing actively about how Republicans ought to react if the court takes their side -- and what kind of health care plan Republicans should be proposing as an alternative to the Affordable Care Act
column3: regardless of how the justices rule. Avik Roy
column4: the Manhattan Institute scholar and Forbes columnist now working with former Texas Gov. Rick Perry’s political action committee
column5: has been outspoken on the need for an alternative. Philip Klein
column6: longtime writer on health care and now managing editor of the Washington Examiner
column7: has written a whole book on the subject.

column1: But there's a reason that congressional Democrats spent literally years holding hearings on health care reform and then
column3: focusing intensely on legislation for several months. The hearings were sometimes acrimonious and
column4: for reform advocates
column5: the media coverage that testimony and questions generated was a source of never-ending grief. At the same time
column6: these hearings
column7: before the committees that actually had jurisdiction on the issues
column8: were necessary to craft a solution that could accomplish the reform’s main goals and then rally enough support to make it through Congress.

column1: The kinds of plans Republicans seem to have in mind would require making equally difficult trade-offs and uniting even more fractious groups. Johnson’s bill
column2: for example
column3: would limit enrollment in plans only to those who already have them
column4: and it would eliminate the individual mandate -- the requirement that people get coverage or pay a fine -- in all of the states. That would force insurers to raise premiums or maybe exit markets altogether.

column1: Other Republicans have discussed altering the Affordable Care Act's regulation on premiums
column2: so that insurers could charge less to younger people. But reducing premiums for the young means raising them for the old
column3: which might be hard for Republicans to pull off given that older voters are now their political base.

column1: Johnson's bill has gone to the Congressional Budget Office for a formal estimate on its impact
column2: a Johnson spokesperson confirmed. That's meaningful -- and more than can be said of most proposals that Republicans have floated on op-ed pages recently. But if Republicans were serious about crafting a proposal that's capable of avoiding disruption and passing Congress
column3: they would have started hashing out these arguments months ago.

column1: Of course
column2: the absence of a public effort to match the public rhetoric matters only if Republicans are actually serious about passing a plan. They may not be. Their real goals may be purely cosmetic -- to insulate the party from a political backlash should millions of people suddenly lose health insurance and
column3: more immediately
column4: to ease the anxiety of Chief Justice John Roberts and Associate Justice Anthony Kennedy
column5: either of whom might hesitate to issue a ruling with such potentially devastating consequences to so many people.

column1: The lack of hearings obviously doesn’t prove that Republican leaders have such ulterior
column2: cynical motives. But it makes that theory a lot more plausible."	REAL

Cleveland, Justice Department Reach Policing Deal	"Cleveland has reached a settlement with the Department of Justice over a pattern of excessive force and civil rights violations by its police department
column2: and it could be announced as soon as Tuesday
column3: a senior federal law enforcement official said.

column1: The official
column2: who wasn't authorized to speak publicly about the settlement before the formal announcement
column3: spoke Monday on the condition of anonymity.

column1: News of the settlement came days after a white police officer was acquitted of manslaughter for firing the final 15 rounds of a 137-shot police barrage through the windshield of a car carrying two unarmed black suspects in 2012.
The suspects' backfiring vehicle had been mistaken for a gunshot
column2: leading to a high-speed chase involving 62 police cruisers. Once the suspects were cornered
column3: 13 officers fired at the car.

column1: The case prompted an 18-month Department of Justice investigation into the practices of the police. In a scathing report released in December
column2: the department required the city to devise a plan to reform the police force.

column1: The specifics of the settlement were unavailable. Messages left for a Department of Justice spokeswoman and the Cleveland Police Department seeking comment weren't returned.
The Department of Justice's report spared no one in the police chain of command. The worst examples of excessive force involved patrol officers who endangered lives by shooting at suspects and cars
column2: hit people over the head with guns and used stun guns on handcuffed suspects.

column1: Supervisors and police higher-ups received some of the report's most searing criticism. The report said officers were poorly trained and some didn't know how to implement use-of-force policies. It also said officers were ill-equipped.
Mobile computers that are supposed to be in patrol cars often don't work
column2: and
column3: even when they do
column4: officers don't have access to essential databases
column5: the report said.

column1: Police Chief Calvin Williams said in December that while it wasn't easy to have to share the federal government findings with his 1
column2: 500-member department he was committed to change.

column1: The people of this city need to know we will work to make the police department better
column2: Williams said.

column1: The investigation marked the second time in recent years the Department of Justice has taken the Cleveland police to task over the use of force. But unlike in 2004
column2: when the department left it up to local police to clean up their act
column3: federal authorities this time have been negotiating a consent decree designed to serve as a blueprint for lasting change among police. Several other police departments in the country now operate under federal consent decrees that involve independent oversight.

column1: The Department of Justice in the last five years has launched broad investigations into the practices of more than 20 police forces
column2: including in Ferguson
column3: Missouri
column4: where a white police officer shot and killed unarmed black teenager Michael Brown
column5: and in Baltimore
column6: where another black man
column7: Freddie Gray
column8: suffered a spinal cord injury in police custody and later died. The Brown and Gray cases spawned protests that sometimes turned violent.

column1: Saturday's bench verdict on the manslaughter charge against Cleveland patrolman Michael Brelo led to a day of mostly peaceful protests but also more than 70 arrests.
Two other high-profile police-involved deaths still hang over Cleveland
column2: a predominantly black and largely poor city: a 12-year-old boy holding a pellet gun fatally shot by a rookie patrolman and a mentally ill woman in distress who died after officers took her to the ground and handcuffed her."	REAL

column1: Physicists Say Consciousness Should Be Considered A State of Matter: The “Non Physical” Is Real	"advertisement - learn more It’s been more than one hundred years since Max Planck
column2: the theoretical physicist who originated quantum theory
column3: which won him the Nobel Prize in Physics
column4: said that he regards “consciousness as fundamental
column5: ” that he regards “matter as a derivative from consciousness
column6: ” and that “everything we talk about
column7: everything that we regard as existing
column8: postulates consciousness.” He is basically saying that the immaterial ‘substance’ of consciousness is directly intertwined with what we perceive to be our physical material world in some sort of way
column9: shape or form
column10: that consciousness is required for matter to be
column11: that it becomes after consciousness….and he’s not the only physicist to believe that. “It was not possible to formulate the laws of quantum mechanics in a fully consistent way without reference to consciousness.”– Eugene Wigner
column12: theoretical physicist and mathematician. He received a share of the Nobel Prize in Physics in 1963 Scientists have been urging the mainstream scientific community
column13: which today is littered with scientific fraud and industry influence as well as invention secrecy
column14: to open up to a broader view regarding the true nature of our reality. “The day science begins to study non-physical phenomena
column15: it will make more progress in one decade that in all of the previous centuries of its existence.”– Nikola Tesla advertisement - learn more Not long ago
column16: a group of internationally recognized scientists came together to stress this fact and how it’s overlooked by the mainstream scientific community. It’s ‘post-material” science
column17: an area of study dealing with the ‘non-physical realm
column18: and it’s challenging the modern scientific worldview of materialism that’s dominated mainstream science. The idea that matter is not the reality is finally starting to gain some merrit. The summary of this report presented at the International Summit On Post-Materialist Science can be found HERE . “The modern scientific worldview is predominantly predicated on assumptions that are closely associated with classical physics. Materialism—the idea that matter is the only reality—is one of these assumptions. A related assumption is reductionism
column19: the notion that complex things can be understood by reducing them to the interactions of their parts
column20: or to simpler or more fundamental things such as tiny material particles.”– Manifesto for a Post-Materialist Science MIT’s Max Tegmark
column21: a theoretical physicist at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology in Cambridge
column22: is one of the latest to attempt explaining why he believes consciousness is a state of matter. He believes that consciousness arises out of a certain set of mathematical conditions
column23: and that there are varying degrees of consciousness – just as certain conditions are required to create varying states of vapor
column24: water
column25: and ice. As PBS emphasized
column26: “understanding how consciousness functions as a separate state of matter could help us come to a more thorough understanding of why we perceive the world the way we do.” ( source ) Tegmark describes this as “perceptronium
column27: ” which he defines as the most general substance that feels subjectively self-aware and this substance should not only be able to store information
column28: but do it in a way that form a unified
column29: indivisible
column30: whole. “The problem is why we perceive the universe as the semi-classical
column31: three dimensional world that is so familiar. When we look at a glass of iced water
column32: we perceive the liquid and the solid ice cubes as independent things even though they are intimately linked as part of the same system. How does this happen? Out of all possible outcomes
column33: we do we perceive this solution?”– Tegmark ( source ) This new way of thinking about consciousness has been spreading throughout the physics community at an exponential rate within the past few years. Considering consciousness as an actual state of matter would be huge
column34: considering the fact that modern day definitions of matter require a substance to have mass
column35: which consciousness does not have. What it does have
column36: however
column37: is some sort of effect on our physical material world
column38: and the extent of this effect and how far it goes is the next step for science.

column1: The quantum double slit experiment is a very popular experiment used to examine how consciousness and our physical material world are intertwined. It is a great example that documents how factors associated with consciousness and our physical material world are connected in some way.
One potential revelation of this experience is that “the observer creates the reality.” A paper published in the peer-reviewed journal Physics Essays by Dean Radin
column2: PhD
column3: explains how this experiment has been used multiple times to explore the role of consciousness in shaping the nature of physical reality.

column1: The study found that factors associated with consciousness “ significantly” correlated in predicted ways with perturbations in the double slit interference pattern. ( source ) “Observation not only disturbs what has to be measured
column2: they produce it. We compel the electron to assume a definite position. We ourselves produce the results of the measurement.” (source) For a physicist to brush off the fact that understanding consciousness is necessary for the advancement and understanding of the nature of our reality is not as common as it used to be but
column3: despite the empirical success of quantum theory
column4: even the suggesting that it could be true as a description of our reality is greeted with harsh cynicism
column5: incomprehension and even anger.

column1: R.C. Henry
column2: Professor of Physics and Astronomy at Johns Hopkins University wrote in a 2005 publication for the journal Nature:

column1: According to [pioneering physicist] Sir James Jeans: “the stream of knowledge is heading towards a non-mechanical reality; the Universe begins to look more like a great thought than like a great machine. Mind no longer appears to be an accidental intruder into the realm of matter… we ought rather hail it as the creator and governor of the realm of matter.” . . . The Universe is immaterial — mental and spiritual. Live
column2: and enjoy.

column1: (“The Mental Universe”; Nature 436:29

column1: Juan Williams: My bets on Trump, Clinton vice presidential picks	"Editor's note: The following column originally appeared in The Hill newspaper and on The Hill.com. For more
column2: click here.

column1: I’m not one to gossip but…
There is a flood of early talk in political circles about who will get the vice presidential nods from Donald Trump and Hillary Clinton.
The strategy for picking a running mate this year is wildly different from anything seen before.

The textbook on picking a VP calls for a heavy focus on adding swing-state support for the top of the ticket. The book also advises finding a running mate seen by voters as plausibly able to take over as president.
Well
column2: throw out the textbook.

column1: No one believes that any running mate is going to tip this year’s electoral map. And no strong
column2: silent type fits the bill at a moment when voters want to shake up the system.

column1: When Sen. Elizabeth Warren (D-Mass.) paid a visit to Clinton just days after she claimed the nomination
column2: speculation kicked into overdrive.

column1: And phone lines got hot when former Speaker Newt Gingrich (R-Ga.) and Sen. Jeff Sessions (R-Ala.) were overheard in a TV green room telling each other that the other one is the best choice to run with Trump.

The dynamics that frame the selection of a VP this year were evident in a Washington Post/ABC poll released last week. It found that nearly 70 percent of Americans have an unfavorable of view of Trump
column2: a 10-point increase since he entered the race last summer. According to the same poll
column3: Clinton also reached a new personal high in her unfavorable rating at 55 percent.

column1: Clinton’s trouble is dwarfed by Trump’s trouble. He is viewed negatively by 94 percent of blacks
column2: 89 percent of Latinos and 77 percent of women.

column1: Picking a dazzling candidate as his running mate is one move that has the potential to change the way the world sees him.

The last attempt to dazzle and distract with a vice-presidential pick was in 2008. GOP nominee Sen. John McCain (R-Ariz.) got off to a good start with his surprise pick of little-known Alaska Governor Sarah Palin. She is beautiful
column2: high energy and
column3: that year
column4: she had the potential to attract women disappointed that the Democrats had selected a black man over a woman as their nominee.

column1: But the sparkle wore off quickly when Palin began to look uninformed and inept. Questions were raised about McCain’s judgment. Palin’s family life also became a staple of the gossip columns.
Palin’s selection looked especially bad in contrast with Democrat Barack Obama’s pick of Sen.Joe Biden (D-Del.). Biden was experienced and known to be a good guy
column2: while his selection took the edge off the risk of putting a first-term senator in the Oval Office.

column1: This time
column2: Trump and Clinton need running mates combining the qualities of Palin and Biden.

column1: The Trump campaign went nuts last month when Ben Carson said that Trump’s shortlist included Palin. Sens. Marco Rubio (Fla) and Ted Cruz (Texas)
column2: and two governors
column3: Chris Christie of New Jersey and John Kasich of Ohio
column4: were purportedly also on the list.

column1: Palin’s downside is obvious; a desperate-looking Christie won’t do either. And Trump can’t afford to extend an offer to Rubio
column2: Cruz or Kasich because he can’t risk being turned down.

column1: That problem is getting worse by the minute as Trump lags farther and farther behind Clinton in the polls. Any dazzling vice-presidential pick has to think about his or her own political future. What will happen to them if Trump suffers a Barry Goldwater-style blowout loss in November?
Gingrich remains a serious contender to be Trump’s number two. He is a well-known personality and an ace with a TV soundbite who is also accustomed to dealing with controversy over his personal life.
But Gingrich sharply criticized Trump for his attacks on New Mexico Governor Susana Martinez and Federal Judge Gonzalo Curiel.
Trump then did an impromptu poll on possible running mates. He asked the audience at a rally in Tampa to pick from Gingrich
column2: Sessions or former Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice. Rice got the biggest applause from the crowd.

column1: Rice is a dazzler but the odds that she is willing to sign on are low to non-existent.
Meanwhile
column2: on the Democratic side
column3: Clinton needs a star to bring young
column4: energetic supporters of her primary rival
column5: Vermont Sen. Bernie Sanders
column6: back into the fold.

column1: That means Clinton can’t bring on a centrist pick. Moderate Democrats with close ties to corporate America like Sens. Joe Manchin of West Virginia or Mark Warner of Virginia
column2: or former Sen. Evan Bayh of Indiana
column3: would anger the liberal base of the party.

column1: She is left to choose among Warren and other left-of-center Democrats such as Sens. Sherrod Brown (Ohio) and Tim Kaine (Va.).
Warren
column2: however
column3: has powerful detractors. Critics say she lacks foreign policy experience and note that she has never run a city
column4: state
column5: cabinet agency or business.

column1: “I think she will not pick somebody that she feels in her heart isn’t ready to be President or Commander-in-Chief
column2: ” former Pennsylvania Governor and DNC Chairman Ed Rendell recently told a Philadelphia radio station. “I think Elizabeth Warren is a wonderful
column3: bright
column4: passionate person
column5: but with no experience in foreign affairs and not in any way
column6: shape or form ready to be commander-in-chief.”

column1: Clinton could find dazzle by naming the first Latino vice-presidential candidate. But no one doubts she will win Latino voters energized by Trump's insults regardless. If she still wants that option
column2: then Housing and Urban Development Secretary Julian Castro is the leading candidate. Labor Secretary Tom Perez and California Congressman Xavier Becerra have come on strong in the last few weeks.

column1: When all the talk ends
column2: Trump has few options. His best bet to dazzle is Gingrich. Clinton has a wider range
column3: led by Kaine
column4: Castro and Warren.

column1: Juan Williams is a co-host of FNC's ""The Five
column2: where he is one of seven rotating Fox personalities.

column1:
REAL														
How Trump And Clinton Are Framing Their Closing Arguments	How Trump And Clinton Are Framing Their Closing Arguments
With less than two weeks to go before Election Day
column2: Donald Trump and Hillary Clinton have each framed a closing argument to voters. Each is also focusing on battleground states in ways that reveal different paths to victory — earning 270 electoral votes on election night. (You can read more about the state of play here.)

column1: Here
column2: we lay out what voters will see from each candidate in the final days of the 2016 presidential campaign.

column1: Trump has ridden a wave of anti-Washington sentiment all year
column2: and in the final weeks of his campaign he's trying to crystallize that message.

column1: Trump recently rolled out a reform package he's referring to as ""draining the swamp."" Trump wants to pass a constitutional amendment setting term limits for lawmakers. He's also calling for a hiring freeze on non-military federal employees
column2: lobbying restrictions
column3: and a sharp reduction in federal regulations.

column1: Trump is now citing these proposals at every rally
column2: along with a long laundry list of other priorities for the first hundred days of a Trump administration. Those include:

column1: The Trump campaign has been running this ad in heavy rotation to draw a contrast between the Republican and Democratic nominees
column2: to show how he will ""Make America Great Again.""

column1: There's a problem Trump continues to create for himself: These policy proposals are often lost in the headlines created when Trump dwells on grievances against his perceived enemies in the media
column2: government and other ""elite"" power structures.

column1: Take Trump's recent speech in Gettysburg
column2: Pa.
column3: which was billed as the roll-out of his agenda for the first 100 days of a Trump administration. Trump began the speech by promising to bring legal action against women who have accused him of sexual assault and harassment. This new threat — and not the repackaged proposals he had spoken about before — became the day's news.

column1: Trump spent several minutes at a Monday rally in St. Augustine
column2: Fla.
column3: railing against the media. ""They're almost as crooked as Hillary
column4: he said. ""They may even be more crooked than Hillary
column5: because without the media
column6: she would be nothing.""

column1: In Trump's telling
column2: the FBI is in league with the Obama administration in its decision not to bring charges against Hillary Clinton for her private email server. And the press is in league with Clinton's campaign.

column1: Trump has said polls showing him trailing Clinton are ""phony"" and that fact-checkers are ""crooked as hell"" — which fits his brand as the ""anti-everything
column2: as NPR's Mara Liasson has framed Trump's approach. This resonates powerfully with the GOP nominee's core supporters
column3: but it's unclear how strong that appeal is beyond Trump's base.

column1: On the stump these days
column2: Clinton continues to highlight her policy agenda
column3: often circling back to issues she's been discussing on the campaign trail for months
column4: such as college affordability and equal pay for women. She's also keen to talk about climate change and job investments.

column1: Clinton is a policy wonk
column2: and she's leaning into that in these final weeks. At the same time
column3: she's increasingly willing to nod to the historic nature of her candidacy. She explicitly tied her policy goals to her gender this way on Monday:

column1: I do have a lot of plans
column2: I do. And I get criticized for having so many plans
column3: Clinton said. ""Maybe it's a bit of a women's thing because we make lists. We do
column4: we make lists
column5: and we try to write down what we're supposed to do and then cross them off as we go through the day and the week. And so
column6: I want you to think about our plans as our lists — our lists as a country.""

column1: Clinton often ties all of her ideas back to one central theme — that the decisions the next president makes will affect the kind of country America's children inherit. She's trying to drill home the idea that her campaign is focused on ""kids and families.""
This is about more than winning an election; it's about the kind of country we want for our kids and grandkids
column2: Clinton told voters at a rally in Manchester
column3: N.H.
column4: on Monday.

column1: In two new ads the campaign released this week
column2: those closing arguments are reinforced as voters are encouraged to think about the future they want for their children.

column1: Clinton is trying to convince voters that Donald Trump is mounting an ""an unprecedented attack on our democracy.""
Since the final debate in Las Vegas last week
column2: she's hitting Trump on his reservations about saying he'll respect the results of the election.

column1: That is a direct threat to our democracy
column2: Clinton told a crowd of a few thousand on the campus of Saint Anselm College in Manchester on Monday. ""I'm not going to try to call it anything else
column3: because that's what it is. All this talk about the election being rigged
column4: trying to stir up people who are supporting him at his rallies
column5: that is a direct threat to our democracy.""

column1: To quote the late Tim Russert
column2: Donald Trump's election strategy can be boiled down to ""Florida
column3: Florida
column4: Florida."" Tuesday marked the third straight day Trump spent in the state. There's a good reason for that: Trump has no plausible path to the White House if he doesn't carry Florida's 29 electoral votes.

column1: Florida is must-win
column2: and I think we're winning it
column3: Trump told Fox News on Tuesday morning.

column1: In addition to campaigning all over the state
column2: Trump has focused a substantial amount of advertising dollars on Florida.

column1: But Florida isn't enough. Trump has to basically sweep the battleground states in order to win. Other states where Trump is buying television ads — and making repeated visits — include North Carolina
column2: Ohio and Pennsylvania.

column1: Trump will hit two of those states — Ohio and North Carolina — later this week.
In yet another indication of how Trump has blended a presidential campaign with personal business
column2: he's taking time off the campaign trail Wednesday morning to attend a grand opening ceremony at his new Washington
column3: D.C.
column4: hotel.

column1: While Trump does that
column2: running mate Mike Pence is campaigning in deeply conservative Utah. That's something the GOP ticket needs to do this year
column3: due to a collapse in support from Utah Republican leaders and serious apathy toward Trump from Mormon voters. Those two interrelated factors have opened the door for independent conservative candidate Evan McMullin to run neck and neck with Trump in Utah.

column1: Trump is also defending a number of other traditionally red states
column2: including Arizona
column3: Georgia and Texas
column4: where Clinton is challenging his lead.

column1: This week
column2: Clinton is focused on swing states where large numbers of people have already begun voting. That includes places like Florida (where she's campaigning Tuesday and Wednesday) and North Carolina (which she'll visit Thursday with first lady Michelle Obama). The campaign estimates some 60 percent of Floridians will cast their ballots by Election Day.

column1: Florida
column2: Nevada
column3: Iowa
column4: North Carolina — these are all states where we expect a majority of people will have voted before Election Day
column5: said Clinton spokeswoman Jennifer Palmieri.

column1: Democrats have a staffing advantage that could help with turnout in some of these early voting states — for the presidential race and for the competitive Senate races many are seeing.
The multipronged offense is focused on states Trump needs more than Clinton to reach 270 electoral votes. Florida tops the list. On Thursday
column2: Clinton will campaign in North Carolina
column3: a state that went for the Republican presidential candidate in 2012
column4: and on Friday she'll be in Iowa
column5: a state where most of the polls have shown Trump with an edge — though polling has been relatively scarce there in recent weeks.

column1: Clinton's campaign has not ruled out the idea of campaigning in traditionally Republican states
column2: such as Arizona
column3: where she seems to be in a statistical tie with Trump.

column1: She has plenty of backup
column2: too. Michelle Obama and Massachusetts Sen. Elizabeth Warren have gotten lots of attention for their rebukes of Trump on the campaign trail. And President Obama is expected to campaign heavily in the next two weeks. That means Clinton's campaign can simply cover a lot more ground ahead of Nov. 8."	REAL

column1: Scott Walker and questioning Obama’s faith	"When Scott Walker pronounced himself agnostic about President Obama’s patriotism and Christian faith
column2: it must have seemed like a clever formulation. “I’ve never asked him
column3: so I don’t know
column4: ” he said. And about Obama’s Christianity: “I’ve never asked him that.”

column1: Walker quickly found his pitch unequal to the presidential big leagues. His argument can’t be generalized into a rule. I have never met Billy Graham
column2: for example
column3: but I’m pretty sure what he believes. As political attacks go
column4: this one is particularly heavy-handed — the equivalent of saying: As far as I know
column5: my opponent is not a swindler and a degenerate. A politician who tried this form of passive aggression before also got criticized for it. During the 2008 Democratic primary fight
column6: Hillary Clinton said that Obama was not a Muslim “as far as I know” — sounding more like one of the wackier speakers at a CPAC convention.

column1: For Walker
column2: this is more of a paper cut than a chest wound. But for the Republican Party
column3: which some Americans associate with religious exclusivity
column4: it can’t be good for a front-runner to sound religiously exclusive.

column1: Walker’s Baptist upbringing — he is the son of a pastor — does put a particular emphasis on the personal acceptance of Christ. It was another Baptist governor
column2: Jimmy Carter
column3: who elevated the idea of being “born again” into the realm of presidential politics. For evangelicals in general
column4: there is no such thing as a birthright Christian. Faith requires a conscious and highly consequential decision — a choice that some do not make.

column1: But here Obama has been as forthright as anyone could be. “I am a Christian
column2: and I am a devout Christian
column3: ” he said in a 2008 Christianity Today interview. “I believe in the redemptive death and resurrection of Jesus Christ. I believe that that faith gives me a path to be cleansed of sin and have eternal life. But most importantly
column4: I believe in the example that Jesus set by feeding the hungry and healing the sick and always prioritizing the least of these over the powerful. I didn’t ‘fall out in church’ as they say
column5: but there was a very strong awakening in me of the importance of these issues in my life. I didn’t want to walk alone on this journey. Accepting Jesus Christ in my life has been a powerful guide for my conduct and my values and my ideals.”

column1: Questioning this affirmation involves a serious charge — an accusation of the worst sort of cynicism. And it is simply not the role of a Christian layman to publicly dispute the self-identification of other Christians
column2: especially in a political context. It is a practice that can lead down ugly alleys of sectarianism.

column1: Some
column2: of course
column3: will find the whole idea that human beings can make profoundly consequential religious choices to be foreign. And they may find proselytization — the necessary correlate of religious choice — to be offensive. But here a little patience might be in order. In many cases
column4: adult converts have come through low points of addiction
column5: humiliation or crisis. They believe they have found
column6: past the limits of their own strength
column7: something extraordinary and undeserved
column8: which they can only describe as grace.

column1: You may find such converts to be deluded or annoying
column2: but there is little doubt that they have had a profound experience that defies adequate metaphor. They feel they have been washed by water or refined by fire. They have heard a voice in the night or a melody above the noise. Things previously thought important — status or wealth — appear vanishingly insignificant. They can say
column3: with G.K. Chesterton:

column1: And all these things are less than dust to me
Because my name is Lazarus and I live.
In such cases
column2: people amazed by grace are wont to talk about it. But this motivation is the opposite of self-righteous judgment. It is gratitude. I have known people who
column3: after a single moment of transforming trust
column4: have spent the rest of their lives in astonished and vocal thankfulness.

column1: But this type of faith
column2: by definition
column3: is unlikely to publicly judge the faith of others. It is founded on recognition of personal limits and failure. In the New Testament
column4: grace often moves in stealthy and unexpected ways — lavished on lepers
column5: Samaritans and tax collectors. Perhaps the modern equivalents would be people with HIV/AIDS
column6: illegal immigrants and . . . tax collectors.

column1: In any case
column2: Christians should not look to the powerful for definitions of orthodoxy — or be proud of an unmerited gift.

column1: Read more from Michael Gerson’s archive
column2: follow him on Twitter or subscribe to his updates on Facebook ."	REAL

column1: What Is Hillary’s Greatest Accomplishment?	"“If you want to stump a Democrat
column2: ask them to name an accomplishment of Hillary Clinton
column3: ” Carly Fiorina quipped at Wednesday’s Republican debate. The line got hearty applause—but it also cut to the core of one of the defining lines of attacks against the former first lady and Democratic presidential frontrunner. After nearly forty years in public life
column4: what exactly has she accomplished?

column1: It’s a question that even
column2: at times
column3: has tripped up Clinton herself: During her 2014 book tour
column4: when ABC’s Diane Sawyer asked her about her “marquee achievement
column5: ” Clinton changed the subject and she fumbled over a similar question during a women’s forum in Manhattan last year. “I see my role as secretary—in fact leadership in general in a democracy—as a relay race. You run the best race you can run
column6: you hand off the baton. Some of what hasn’t been finished may go on to be finished
column7: ” she told Thomas Friedman. “I’m very proud of the [economic] stabilization and the really solid leadership that the administration provided that I think now leads us to be able to deal with problems like Ukraine because we’re not so worried about a massive collapse in Europe.”

column1: The question Fiorina posed has also tripped up members of the Obama administration. When State Department spokesperson Jen Psaki was asked last year to “identify one tangible achievement” accomplished through one of Hillary Clinton’s key projects as Secretary of State—the first-ever audit of the department—Psaki punted
column2: “I am certain that those who were here at the time
column3: who worked hard on that effort
column4: could point out one.”

column1: Hillary’s supporters have been stumped too. When Bloomberg Politics’ Mark Halperin asked a focus group of Iowans this summer about Hillary Clinton’s accomplishments
column2: one Democratic supporter said
column3: “I honestly can’t say I followed along [with] everything that was going on.”

column1: So is Fiorina right? Are Democrats really unable to defend Clinton’s record on the merits? To find out
column2: Politico Magazine on Thursday asked the nation’s top Democratic leaders and thinkers to name Hillary Clinton’s biggest accomplishment.

column1: What is the most impressive item on Clinton’s record? Which legislative or policy triumph from her many years in office will be most important on the campaign trail? Not surprisingly
column2: those surveyed all came up with an answer to defend their party’s likely presidential nominee. Whether these count as “marquee
column3: ” “significant
column4: ” or “tangible”? You be the judge.

column1: ‘It’s kind of hard to pick one accomplishment’
By Bill Burton
column2: former senior strategist for Priorities USA Action
column3: a super PAC in support of President Barack Obama.

column1: It’s kind of hard to pick one accomplishment for Hillary Clinton. Personally
column2: I’m sure she’d say her daughter and grandchild are her greatest accomplishments. Professionally
column3: how about these three?

column1: 1. Her China speech on women.
2. Her role in killing Osama bin Laden.
3. Management of the State Department during which time we saw a 50 percent increase in exports to China
column2: aggressive work on climate (particularly at Copenhagen)
column3: and the effort to create and implement the toughest sanctions ever on Iran—helping to lead us to the agreement currently on the table.

column1: ‘The sanction on Iran that brought them to the table’
Howard Dean is the former governor of Vermont and the former chair of the Democratic National Committee.
Hillary Clinton was the principal author of the sanction on Iran that brought them to the table. We cannot afford any Know Nothings like Carly in the White House.
‘Nearly every foreign policy victory of President Obama’s second term has Secretary Clinton’s fingerprints on it’

American foreign policy was stronger when Hillary Clinton left the State Department than when she arrived. She took the reins from a Bush administration that had left America’s reputation deeply damaged and planted the seeds for the foreign policy successes we see today. From the agreement to prevent Iran from obtaining a nuclear weapon
column2: to the landmark normalization of relations with Cuba
column3: nearly every foreign policy victory of President Obama’s second term has Secretary Clinton’s fingerprints on it.

column1: Her accomplishments extend to health care
column2: as well. As First Lady
column3: she helped create and guide through Congress Children’s Health Insurance Program
column4: a key program that brought health care coverage to millions of children. As a Senator
column5: she worked across the aisle to provide full military health benefits to reservists and National Guard members.

column1: Secretary Clinton was also an outspoken champion for women around the world. She set records for travel while leading the State Department and used every trip to empower the women of the 112 countries she visited. She made gender equality a priority of U.S. foreign policy. And she created the ambassador at large for global women’s issues
column2: a post charged with integrating gender throughout the State Department.

column1: ‘The SCHIP program … which expanded health coverage to millions of lower-income children’
After universal health care failed in 1994
column2: the Clinton Administration was reluctant to go anywhere near healthcare again—Democrats lost the Senate and the House in 1994
column3: and losing the house was for the first time in 40 years. Then-First Lady Hilary Clinton ended up being the White House ally and inside player who worked with Ted Kennedy and Orrin Hatch to create the SCHIP program in Clinton's second term
column4: which expanded health coverage to millions of lower-income children. She has other accomplishments but this one made a huge difference
column5: and came at a time when politically the Administration was cutting deals with Newt Gingrich on the budget and not necessarily all that enthusiastic about revisiting health care.

column1: This obviously isn't her only accomplishment but it is meaningful because she took a political battering after the failure in 1994 but came back to fight again
column2: and was able to work on a bipartisan basis during a very polarized time to get this done. Seems relevant!

column1: ‘Clinton is one of the most accomplished people ever to run’
By Chuck Schumer
column2: U.S. Senator for New York
column3: Democratic party.

column1: Hillary Clinton is one of the most accomplished people ever to run for the Presidency. I’m lucky enough to have seen those accomplishments up close from her time as Senator from New York and as Secretary of State. Hillary Clinton was instrumental in helping secure $21 billion in federal aid to help New York rebuild after 9/11. She fought tooth and nail to protect the first responders who rushed into danger when the towers collapsed and was pivotal in the passage of legislation that helped those first responders who got sick get the care and treatment they deserved. She worked night and day to protect and create jobs in New York
column2: whether that was at the Niagara Falls Air Force base or the Center for Bioinformatics at the University of Buffalo. She also led the charge on the Lilly Ledbetter Pay Equity Act
column3: which is now the law of the land.

column1: As Secretary of State
column2: Secretary Clinton was not only inspirational figure for billions of women around the globe
column3: she also did much to restore the shattered credibility of the United States
column4: which had lost so much influence following the failed foreign policies of the previous administration. She negotiated the cease-fire in Gaza that stopped the Hamas from firing rocket after rocket into Israel. She helped secure the START treaty’s ratification
column5: and has advanced women’s rights in countries around the globe. That’s just a snapshot of what Hillary Clinton has accomplished over a lifetime of public service to New York and the country. If you really want to stump a Democrat
column6: you should ask them which of Hillary’s accomplishments is your favorite—there are too many to choose from

column1: ‘Rebuilding America’s leadership and prestige overseas after the Bush years’
Bill Richardson is a former secretary of energy and governor of New Mexico.
As Secretary of State
column2: Hillary Clinton was key in rebuilding America’s leadership and prestige overseas after the Bush years. She restored our alliances with the EU and key Asian allies as well as key relationships in Africa and Latin America.

column1: By Chris Dodd
column2: former U.S. Senator for Connecticut
column3: Democratic party.

column1: Having worked with her in the Senate and on the HELP Committee
column2: the first thing that came to mind was her authorship of the Pediatric Research Equity Act. This law requires drug companies to study their products in children. The Act is responsible for changing the drug labeling of hundreds of drugs with important information about safety and dosing of drugs for children. It has improved the health of millions of children who take medications to treat diseases ranging from HIV to epilepsy to asthma. Millions of kids are in better shape and alive because of the law Senator Clinton authored.

column1: By Paul Begala
column2: political analyst for CNN and counselor to President Bill Clinton.

column1: Easy: Iran sanctions. Sec. Clinton accomplished the nearly impossible mission of getting China
column2: Russia
column3: the European Union and the civilized world on board with crippling sanctions against Iran. This is what brought Iran to the negotiating table.

column1: Ms. Fiorina may not see that as an accomplishment
column2: since while she was CEO of Hewlett-Packard the firm sold hundreds of millions of dollars of computer products the the terrorist regime in Tehran
column3: evading US sanctions."	REAL

column1: Sanders, Trump easily win West Virginia primary; Trump picks up Nebraska too	"Sen. Bernie Sanders of Vermont easily won the Democratic primary in West Virginia on Tuesday
column2: the first of a string of potentially strong showings this month that may drag out
column3: but not block
column4: front-runner Hillary Clinton’s march toward the Democratic nomination.

column1: Additionally
column2: Donald Trump won Republican primaries in West Virginia and Nebraska — virtually foregone conclusions given that he was the only Republican remaining in the race.

column1: “It is a great honor to have won both West Virginia and Nebraska
column2: especially by such massive margins
column3: ” Trump said in a statement Tuesday night. “My time spent in both states was a wonderful and enlightening experience for me.”

column1: Heading into Tuesday
column2: Clinton held a formidable lead in delegates
column3: and because delegates will be awarded proportionally
column4: Sanders’s West Virginia victory was not expected to make much of a dent in that lead. However
column5: his enduring popularity
column6: large rallies and insistence on staying in the race until the Democratic convention in July have highlighted some of Clinton’s weaknesses and prevented her from fully turning her attention to a general-election contest against Trump.

column1: “West Virginia is a working-class state
column2: and like many other states in this country
column3: including Oregon
column4: working people are hurting
column5: ” Sanders said at a rally in Salem
column6: Ore.
column7: Tuesday night. “And what the people of West Virginia said tonight
column8: and I believe the people of Oregon will say next week
column9: is that we need an economy that works for all of us
column10: not just the 1 percent.”

column1: Sanders’s advantage over Clinton in West Virginia was clear in preliminary exit polling. According to data published by CNN
column2: roughly 1 in 3 Democratic voters identified as an independent
column3: a group that Sanders won by nearly 40 points. Just over 1 in 4 wanted the next president to continue President Obama’s policies
column4: less than half the share who said this across previous primaries this year. Clinton has promised repeatedly to continue to build on many of Obama’s policies and has consistently performed best among voters who support his agenda.

column1: Sanders also benefited from support among Democratic primary voters who said they would favor Trump over Clinton or Sanders in a general election. Roughly 1 in 3 primary voters said they would back Trump in the general election over Clinton
column2: and Sanders won two-thirds of their votes.

column1: Clinton was weighed down by her own troubles. Three in 10 Democratic primary voters said they or a family member were employed in the coal industry
column2: and Sanders won those voters by more than 20 percentage points. Ahead of the primary
column3: Clinton was forced to reckon with comments she made earlier in the campaign about putting the coal industry “out of business.”

column1: Sanders used the West Virginia victory as a rationale to stay in the race “until the last vote is cast.” Less than 15 minutes after the polls closed
column2: Sanders sent out an email to supporters declaring victory and asking for money to help him in the next two contests in Kentucky and Oregon.

column1: Recent polls show Sanders likely to perform well in a string of primaries this month in Oregon
column2: Kentucky and Washington — states with smaller minority populations where Clinton may face similar challenges as in the West Virginia electorate.

column1: Nevertheless
column2: Clinton may have found a purpose to these contests in addition to trying to improve her performance against Sanders: to connect with the working-class white voters who may be crucial in a general-election match-up against Trump.

column1: In the run-up to West Virginia’s primary
column2: Clinton toured the state
column3: holding small
column4: intimate meetings with voters — including some detractors who challenged her on the comments she made about coal miners.

column1: Clinton proposed tax changes that would assist families with the cost of child care — a contrast with Trump’s lack of a specific policy agenda.
Among other details
column2: Clinton said she would limit child-care costs to no more than 10 percent of a family’s income.

column1: “It just doesn’t make sense
column2: ” Clinton said at a stop in Lexington
column3: Ky.
column4: of the cost of high-quality care for young children and the struggles of working parents to pay for it. “It’s the most important job that any of us can do
column5: and we’re making it really hard and really expensive.”

column1: Bill Clinton was expected to tour Kentucky on Thursday.
The Clinton camp also sought to hold Trump to a tax platform that they called “risky
column2: reckless and regressive
column3: ” anticipating that Trump may attempt to walk back some of those policies
column4: including tax cuts for the wealthy.

column1: “Donald Trump has put forward a tax plan that paces him squarely on the side of the super wealthy and corporations at the expense of the middle class and working families
column2: ” said Jake Sullivan
column3: a senior Clinton policy adviser
column4: in a call with reporters Monday.

column1: Trump became the presumptive nominee after Sen. Ted Cruz (Tex.) and Ohio Gov. John Kasich dropped out following his victory in the Indiana primary last week. He has maintained a lighter schedule than usual since effectively securing the nomination. He visited West Virginia last week — only to ask Republican primary voters not to bother voting for him Tuesday.
“Save your vote for the general election
column2: okay? Forget this one. The primary is gone
column3: ” Trump told a massive crowd in Charleston last week. He later made a swing through Oregon and Washington — continuing to target upcoming primary states while also
column4: like Clinton
column5: reaching out to white voters who are expected to play a big role in November.

column1: Trump has also stepped up his attacks on Clinton. He has given her the nickname “Crooked Hillary” and has sharpened his attacks on her judgment
column2: for instance on foreign policy
column3: international trade deals and her vote for the Iraq War. He has also characterized her as an “enabler” of her husband’s indiscretions.

column1: Once a Clinton stronghold
column2: West Virginia’s political preference has shifted dramatically since she won by a landslide against Obama in the 2008 presidential primary.

column1: Win or lose in the remaining contests
column2: she is likely to maintain a significant lead over Sanders in both the votes and delegates necessary to clinch the Democratic nomination.

column1: Sanders
column2: in vowing to fight on
column3: is eyeing the Democratic primary in California
column4: where a huge delegate prize potentially awaits the winner on June 7. Sanders campaigned in Sacramento to a crowd of thousands on Monday. He rallied in Oregon Tuesday
column5: and he was scheduled to campaign later in the week in South Dakota
column6: which also votes in June.

column1: “The political establishment is getting nervous
column2: ” Sanders said Monday. “They should be getting very nervous because real change is coming.”

column1: Sanders made a pair of trips to West Virginia during the two weeks leading up the primary
column2: where he emphasized jobs lost to trade deals and the persistent poverty in the state.

column1: During his most recent trip
column2: Sanders devoted a speech last week to the latter subject
column3: staged at a food bank in McDowell County
column4: where nearly half the children live in poverty. Sanders also touted a $41 billion plan to transition ailing coal workers into new industries.

column1: In the lead-up to the West Virginia primary
column2: Sanders also aired television ads in the state
column3: something Clinton did not do.

column1: Heading into Tuesday’s contest
column2: Clinton held a formidable lead of 290 pledged delegates over Sanders
column3: according to a tally by the Associated Press. Once superdelegates are factored in
column4: Clinton’s lead stands at 774 delegates.

column1: Clinton won the Democratic primary in Nebraska on Tuesday
column2: but it was an “advisory” primary that followed caucuses in March at which Sanders won the majority of the delegates.

column1: The more delegates Sanders accumulates between now and the Democratic convention in July
column2: the more leverage aides say he will have in shaping the party’s platform. If he is not the nominee
column3: Sanders has said
column4: he would like to push Clinton to adopt his position on issues including universal health care and raising the minimum wage.

column1: Sanders has continued to insist that he has a narrow path to the nomination that involves catching — or at least coming close to — Clinton in pledged delegates
column2: which are allocated based on performances in primaries and caucuses. Sanders needs to win nearly two-thirds of the remaining pledged delegates to do that.

column1: Gearan reported from Louisville and Lexington
column2: Ky. Scott Clement
column3: Jose A. DelReal and Emily Guskin contributed to this report."	REAL

column1: Clinton, Sanders to Face Off in 1st Democrat Debate	"LAS VEGAS  The Democratic presidential candidates are holding their first debate Tuesday night in Las Vegas.
It marks the first time frontrunner Hillary Clinton and her main challenger so far  socialist Sen. Bernie Sanders
column2: I-Vt.  will appear on the same stage in this campaign
column3: along with the other three candidates.

column1: This campaign was expected to be a cakewalk for the former first lady
column2: but it hasn't turned out that way.

column1: One big reason seems to be the story that just won't away: how she used a private email server to conduct government business. It's fed a perception that she can play by a different set of rules.
Even so
column2: Clinton still has a decent lead nationally over the socialist senator from Vermont
column3: but Sanders is coming on strong. He's beating her comfortably in the key state of New Hampshire and is close in Iowa
column4: too.

column1: Plus
column2: Sanders is the one drawing tens of thousands of people to his events. Democratic voters seem to be listening intently to his populist messages.

column1: With the threat from Sanders a reality
column2: Clinton is now trying to reposition herself a little more leftward. Just recently she came out against President Barack Obama's big Trans-Pacific Partnership free trade agreement.

column1: That's a reversal because while serving as secretary of state
column2: she was for it. This new position puts her more in line with the liberal base of her party.

column1: As of today
column2: I am not in favor of what I have learned about it
column3: Clinton said. ""I don't believe it's going to meet the high bar I have set.""

column1: So
column2: tonight the drama will center on how much Sen. Sanders and the other Democrats confront Clinton directly on the debate stage.

column1: Expect former Maryland Gov. Martin O'Malley to be an instigator. He's trying to get traction and has taken some shots at Clinton over the last few months.
As for Clinton herself
column2: she's trying to avoid a repeat of 2008 when she went in as the heavy favorite
column3: then ran into a buzz saw called Barack Obama.

column1: This time around the buzz is growing for Bernie Sanders."	REAL

column1: Utah. It is one of
column2: if not the most conservative states in the nation
column3: largely thanks to the Church of Jesus Christ Of Latter Day Saints
column4: aka the Mormons. And as such it is usually a solid
column5: bright red state on the electoral maps. Utah has gone for the Democratic presidential candidate exactly once in the past 64 years — in the anti-Goldwater wave of 1964. But this year it is possible that Utah will not be in the Republican column when the votes are added up. That is
column6: at least not in the Republican column headed by Donald Trump
column7: who is largely being rejected by voters in the Beehive State.

column1: Many Utah voters with strong religious beliefs are not happy with Trump
column2: and unlike many Christian evangelical leaders who have decided to stay hitched to his wagon despite the allegations of improper sexual conduct
column3: Utahans are bolting
column4: putting the state in play. The Young Turks sent Michael Shure to the state to find out what was on people’s minds
column5: and what many of them had to tell him was quite clear — they don’t think Trump is a good representative of their Christian beliefs.

column1: None of the young Utahans Shure spoke to said they planned to vote for Trump. Some said they would vote for Gary Johnson. One college student indicated that he would consider a vote for Hillary. But the name that seemed to come up more than any others was Evan McMullin.
McMullin is the Republican who is running an independent campaign for president. He is also a Mormon
column2: which gives him a huge advantage in Utah. Some recent polls of the state have McMullin polling even with Clinton
column3: but still trailing Trump. But as Benjamin Morris notes at FiveThirtyEight
column4: there are questions about the methodology of those polls that could mean McMullin’s support in Utah is even greater than he is getting credit for.

column1: Whether McMullin wins in Utah or whether Trump is able to squeak out a razor thin victory
column2: one thing is certain: unlike many of their traditional “Christian” counterparts in the deep south and the rest of the Rocky Mountain region
column3: many Mormons want no part of Trump or his policies
column4: which some of them were quite willing to tell Shure that they considered to be un-Christian. Not only will a loss of Utah further hurt Trump’s slim chances of winning the White House
column5: a McMullin win there would make him a footnote in future history books as the first third-party candidate since George Wallace in 1968 to win electoral votes.

column3: 500 miles.”

column1: The new bill would boost the number of permits to 8
column2: 000 by 2023 and also create an enforcement team to sniff out violations.

column1: Since 1983
column2: the number of street-food vending permits has remained steady at 4
column3: 235. But there are likely more carts than that on the streets
column4: as some vendors simply open shop without a license and work until they are caught.

column1: Schiff argued any increase in the number of food carts needs to come with regulations stipulating that the carts operate in a more environmentally friendly manner.
City Councilman Mark Levine (D-Manhattan)
column2: who is sponsoring the bill to increase the permits
column3: wondered if this was already the case. “We have laws in the city about air quality that currently stipulate that any food establishment has got to have a hood over a grill
column4: ” Levine said. “Is that not currently the law?”

column1: Schiff
column2: however
column3: said there are no such laws regulating the carts as she suggested the proposals be delayed to ensure better pollution safeguards.

column1: “We really see this as an opportunity to work with the council to think through how we might use this modernization act to improve air quality
column2: ” she said. “The current laws don’t actually control the emissions that we’re concerned about.”

column1: Business-improvement districts and residents throughout the city also pushed for delays on increasing vendor permits
column2: saying there are too many already in some neighborhoods
column3: but welcomed increased enforcement.

column1: “The enforcement idea is a great idea
column2: ” said Ellen Baer
column3: co-chair of the NYC BID Association. “Let’s see if this works
column4: let’s see how it works
column5: let’s see if it’s sufficiently funded
column6: let’s see how many resources they need — before we start adding to the chaos.”

column1: But street vendors argued they’ve waited too long for reforms that would allow them to transition from operating illegally to legally.
Sean Basinski
column2: director of the Street Vendor Project
column3: described the bills as “far from our dream
column4: ” but said he supports most of what they call for. “It is a reasonable compromise
column5: ” he said. “Vendors have been waiting 35 years for this change . . . We certainly welcome a study being done
column6: but we don’t think that should delay the progress that needs to be made. The time for reform is now.”

column1: Before the hearing
column2: some vendors rallied outside
column3: demanding that city officials and police stop harassing them and treating them like criminals . The bill will remain before the committee while members discuss possible changes."	FAKE
