column1: New evidence that the legal immigration system discriminates against Latin Americans	"People who don't believe that unauthorized immigrants in the US should be given legal status tend to emphasize that it would be unfair to immigrants who are in the US legally — because they deserve a reward for settling in the US ""the right way.""
But what if the legal immigration process is itself unfair?

A new study by researchers at MIT and Brown University suggest that might be what's going on — unintentionally. They looked at applications for employment-based green cards among immigrants who were already in the US. What they found was that
column2: in the standard approval process
column3: Latin American immigrants were much less likely than average to get approved — and Asian immigrants were more likely. But when the government went through a slower but more complete approval process
column4: the disparities disappeared.

column1: For this study
column2: the researchers (Emilio J. Castilla of MIT
column3: and Ben A. Rissing of Brown) evaluated the phase in an application for an employment-based green card where the US Department of Labor has to approve or deny the immigrant's ""labor certification"" for a particular job. These applications get filed when a company decides to take an immigrant who's (almost always) already in the country on a temporary visa — like a work visa or student visa — and sponsor him or her for a green card
column4: which would let him or her stay in the US permanently and eventually apply for citizenship. So this is the phase in the process where temporary immigrants can get approved to become permanent ones.

column1: Technically
column2: this is supposed to be evaluating the immigrant's would-be employer
column3: not the immigrant him- or herself. In order to get the immigrant ""labor certified"" for a green card — or any work visa — the would-be employer has to prove that they tried to find a US citizen to fill the job
column4: but failed.

column1: One thing that isn't supposed to be a factor in the application is the immigrant's country of origin. But even when the researchers controlled for as many variables as they could — from the temporary visa that an immigrant held in the US when he filed the green-card application
column2: to the skill level of the job — they found that approval rates varied widely from one nationality to the next. 90.5 percent of Asian immigrants were approved for labor certification. But only 66.8 percent of Latin American immigrants were.

column1: The regional disparity even showed up in immigrants applying for the same type of job. ""Immigrants from Asia seeking employment as restaurant cooks are 41.6 percent more likely to be approved than immigrants from Latin America
column2: all else being equal
column3: the researchers write. It's a problem for high-skilled workers
column4: too: Asian immigrants weren't any more likely than Canadians (for example) to get approved to work as computer software engineers
column5: but Latin American immigrants were over 25 percent less likely.

column1: The biggest problem with the study: the government agents looking over immigrants' applications could see each immigrant's educational background
column2: but the researchers couldn't. That could be a huge factor explaining the variation: maybe Latin American immigrants are simply less educationally qualified for the positions they're applying for.

column1: But the study indicates that can't be the whole story. For example
column2: the researchers looked at immigrants who were already on H1-B high-skilled visas (99 percent of whom have a bachelor's degree or higher) but were applying to upgrade to green cards. Among that group
column3: Asian immigrants were still 11 percent more likely than Canadians to get approved for green cards — and H1B-holding Latin American immigrants were 20 percent less likely.

column1: There's also previous research showing that government officials profile immigrants based on their countries of origin. In one study
column2: in which officials were asked to look over fictional visa applications
column3: the author said that region of origin was being used strongly as a ""criterion of a visa applicant's desirability.""

column1: Most of the time
column2: the DOL makes decisions based on basic information about the immigrant
column3: the job
column4: and the employer
column5: as well as evidence of the employer's failed attempt to recruit US citizens. 90 percent of those cases get approved
column6: and they're typically approved or denied in under 4 months. But in a few cases — thanks to a process that is partly random
column7: and partly not — applications are ""audited
column8: and agents take a more in-depth look at an immigrant's background
column9: and the requirements for the position. In those cases
column10: only 57 percent of applications are approved — and it takes about 2 years to come to a decision.

column1: According to the new study
column2: audited applications had one big advantage over non-audited ones: the disparities in approval rates between immigrants from different regions disappeared. That might indicate that whatever is happening to favor Asian immigrants and disfavor Latin American ones in the quicker process is unintentional
column3: since government officials don't appear to think there's good reason to be more suspicious of Latin American applicants.

column1: The study's authors suggest an easy fix: making it impossible for an official to see an applicant's country of origin
column2: just like officials aren't allowed to see applicants' ages or sexes. If this really is a significant problem
column3: however
column4: it's not something that changing the process in the future will be able to fix.

column1: If the government is really making it harder for Latin American immigrants currently in the US legally to get green cards through their employers
column2: they're unfairly forcing Latin American immigrants to make the difficult choice between leaving the country they've been living in for years
column3: and staying in the US after their visas expire. In other words
column4: the government's approval-rate problem might be driving more legal Latin American immigrants to become illegal."	REAL

column1: America Might Not Deserve Trump, But Dems and Hillary Deserved To Lose	"Tweet Widget by BAR managing editor Bruce A. Dixon

President Donald Trump? How did such a thing happen? A competent and purposeful Clinton campaign should have beaten Donald Trump. How did Hillary Clinton and one-percenter Democrats snatch defeat from the jaws of certain victory? America Might Not Deserve Trump
column2: But Dems and Hillary Deserved To Lose by BAR managing editor Bruce A. Dixon

column1: It’s over. The crotch-grabbing racist con man beat the lying corporate warmonger. Donald Trump is president-elect of the US.
It didn’t have to happen that way. Trump’s winning 58 million votes were a hair fewer than Clinton’s popular vote
column2: a million or two less than Republican losers McCain in 2008 and Romney in 2012
column3: six and ten million behind Obama’s 2012 and 2008 numbers. The buffoonish Trump was elected with such a low turnout because Hillary Clinton’s campaign was even less competent and credible. To borrow the condescending language Barack Obama deploys before black audiences
column4: Hillary’s campaign never gave Cousin Pookie much reason to get up off the couch and vote.

column1: Republican and Democratic parties are alike owned by their one-percenter investor/contributors. Democratic party shot callers decided they’d risk losing with Hillary Clinton rather than winning with Bernie Sanders. So Democratic party leadership
column2: their media allies and the entire black political class got behind Hillary Clinton and helped collude and conspire to eliminate VT Senator Bernie Sanders
column3: the Democrat with the best chance against any Republican opponent.

column1: Once Bernie Sanders was eliminated Hillary waged a lazy and ineffective campaign
column2: playing a hand with just three cards.

column1: The first was the broken record of how unthinkable and unprecedented a disaster a Trump presidency would be… a clownish sexual predator who pronounced climate change a hoax and would criminalize abortion
column2: open concentration camps
column3: repeal Obamacare
column4: legalize stop and frisk
column5: build a wall
column6: appoint neanderthals to the Supreme Court
column7: deport six or ten million immigrants instead of Obama’s paltry two million and who might be in hock to the Russians. Except for the thing about the Russians
column8: it’s roughly the same picture Democrats have drawn of every Republican presidential candidate since Nixon. A story told that many times just gets old. Party leaders counted on it anyway
column9: and it wasn’t enough. That was incompetence.

column1: A second and relatively weak card Democrats played was conjuring up an Imaginary Hillary Clinton
column2: a defender of womens’ and human rights who held hands with the moms of killer cop victims
column3: and occasionally mumbled about black lives mattering and the need to reform the criminal justice system. But Hillary’s decades-long record as a tool of banksters
column4: billionaires and one-percenters was so well established in the public mind that Imaginary Hillary was a difficult sell
column5: not credible.

column1: The one-percenter Democrats’ third card
column2: on which they staked a lot was the early and unconditional endorsement of Hillary Clinton by   and Michelle. This had proven effective in Chicago in 2011 and 2015 where Obama’s blessings in 2011 and 2015 were key to fastening Rahm Emanuel on the city’s jugular vein after a half century of Daley rule. The entire black political class got behind Hillary too
column3: from civil rights icons who ruminated on how they hadn’t seen Bernie Sanders back in the day to some other wise heads who assured us a vote for the Green Party’s Jill Stein and Ajamu Baraka was an act of “ narcissism ” or maybe white privilege . But at the end of  ’s time in office
column4: the Obama endorsement didn’t carry the clout it used to.

column1: Thanks to two generations of lazy Democrats who refused to try to consolidate the victory of the 1965 Voting Rights Act the Supreme Court in 2013 nullified its key provisions
column2: enabling a constellation of laws and practices aimed at limiting access to the ballot on the part of students
column3: minorities
column4: the elderly and constituencies likely to vote Democratic. In the 2016 election cycle these practices stripped another few million Democratic voters from the rolls.

column1: All in all
column2: Democrats were the authors of their own defeat this presidential election. Hillary couldn’t campaign against the one percent because her party is a party of the one percent. Hillary Democrats including Bernie himself after the convention could no longer acknowledge joblessness
column3: low wages
column4: lack of housing
column5: permanent war or the high cost of medical care or they’d be campaigning against themselves.

column1: Donald Trump didn’t win because of some mysterious upsurge of racism and nativism. He won because Hillary Clinton’s campaign was even less inspiring and less competent than his own
column2: and worked hard to snatch its own defeat from the jaws of victory. America might not deserve President Donald Trump. But Hillary Clinton didn’t deserve to win
column3: Bruce Dixon is managing editor at Black Agenda Report and co-chair of the GA Green Party. He lives and works near Marietta GA and can be reached  "	FAKE

column1: Media turn blind eye to Hillary Clinton’s glaring mistakes	"When Hillary Clinton can study up
column2: work out her one-liners
column3: figure out the best way to deflect questions and fence with inquisitors she does well. She thrives
column4: therefore
column5: in a debate or as a witness. She is the quintessential “A” student. No one will cram harder before the big exam than she.

column1: Left to her own devices
column2: however
column3: she is consistently her own worst enemy. Before she worked out her lines
column4: spontaneous answers about her finances (“We were broke”) or her initial stance toward the Benghazi scandal (“What difference does it make . . .?) disastrous. Refusing to take scandals seriously
column5: her first attempts at brushing back the press come across as evasive
column6: haughty and just plain false. In supposedly friendly settings
column7: with her guard down
column8: she winds up saying ludicrous things that come back to haunt her.

column1: If not for Jeb Bush’s self-immolation this week
column2: more attention would have been paid to yet another clueless Clinton moment. Asked about the Veterans Administration scandal in a softball MSNBC interview
column3: she argued that “it’s not been as widespread as it has been made out to be.” She claimed Republicans were exploiting the situation and wanted the VA to “fail.” Her instinct to cast blame and attack political opponents renders her entirely tone deaf at times.

column1: As you will recall
column2: the scandal first uncovered in Phoenix turned into a nationwide investigation
column3: forcing out the secretary and prompting new legislation. (From the Arizona Republic: “The Office of Inspector General concluded that hundreds of thousands of patients were subjected to unacceptable delays in care
column4: and many died while awaiting appointments; wait-time records were falsified or inaccurate at 70 percent of the VA facilities nationwide; and department leadership was contaminated by bullying
column5: reprisal and a lack of accountability. The public furor forced out VA Secretary Eric Shinseki and other administrators
column6: while prompting the largest reform in department history.”)

column1: It is incomprehensible that she would want to downplay the suffering of vets. A series of officials at veterans groups decried her comment. Stars and Stripes reported:

Veterans groups lobbed criticism at Clinton this week for being out of touch with veterans issues. The conservative group Concerned Veterans for America charged Clinton with downplaying and ignoring the VA’s problems. Paul Rieckhoff
column2: CEO of Iraq and Afghanistan Veterans of America
column3: called her comments on the VA a “head-scratcher.” The VA scandal that began last year with an agency cover-up of health care delays “was so widespread it has its own Wikipedia entry
column4: ” Rieckhoff tweeted Tuesday.

column1: And lawmakers on both sides of the aisle lashed out. Sen. Jeff Flake (R-Ariz.) said he was “appalled.” Rep. Ann Kirkpatrick (D-Ariz.) declared
column2: “The problems we’ve seen at the Phoenix VA are devastating and real. The VA scandal has nothing to do with partisan politics and everything to do with systemic failure
column3: negligence and lack of accountability.” Sen. John McCain (R-Ariz.) blasted her
column4: observing that Sen. Bernie Sanders (I-Vt.)
column5: whose Senate committee investigated the VA
column6: was better on veterans issues than Clinton.

column1: Her campaign tried to assure us she understands how “systematic” the problem is. No apology or correction from her was forthcoming.
[Opinion: Republicans are right. We in the media do suck.]
Now imagine if Republicans had said
column2: well “Democrats are just exaggerating the impact of Hurricane Katrina.” The mainstream hardly blinked when it was Clinton
column3: fresh from passing her endurance test at the House select committee on Benghazi.

column1: The Republican opposition research team America Rising later put out a devastating ad
column2: recounting one news report after another detailing the abuses
column3: corruption and ensuing deaths. It ends with McCain saying
column4: “She doesn’t understand veterans
column5: she doesn’t understand what they need
column6: and she is politicizing the issue. Shame on her.”

column1: This episode reminds us of Clinton’s severe limitations as a candidate. It also should prompt Republicans to recognize the media is back in Clinton-rooting mood. Her outlandish statements will become headlines like: “Republicans try to exploit…” The media will shrug its collective shoulders at her inaccuracies and outright deceptions. This is all the more reason to find a superbly skilled nominee
column2: one who can focus on her liabilities and cut through the media chatter.

column1: At the recent debate and in subsequent interviews
column2: Sen. Marco Rubio (R-Fla.) used his time in the spotlight to focus on the evidence that immediately after the Benghazi attack she told family members and the Egyptian prime minister it was a terrorist attack while the administration perpetrated a false cover story for weeks.

column1: Republicans cannot repeat often enough evidence of her ethical lapses and shoddy record. The press sure isn’t going to dwell on it."	REAL

State Department admits to deliberately cutting briefing footage on Iran deal	"State Department spokesman John Kirby told reporters Wednesday that an unknown U.S. official made a request over the phone to delete several minutes of a December 2013 video of the exchange between reporters and a State Department spokeswoman. The State Department routinely posts on its site the briefing that it holds nearly every day with the diplomatic press corps.
Kirby said the department technician who made the edit could not recall who requested it.

The deleted portion of the video involves questions about a previous press briefing in 2012 in which then-State Department spokeswoman Victoria Nuland denied secret talks between the U.S. and Iran about a potential nuclear deal were taking place.
After it was revealed in December 2013 that secret talks between the U.S. and Iran actually had taken place
column2: then-spokeswoman Jen Psaki admitted the administration lied in order to protect the secret negotiations.

column1: Earlier this month Deputy National Security Adviser Ben Rhodes acknowledged to The New York Times that the administration was deceptive about the talks
column2: creating a ""narrative"" that they did not take place. When James Rosen of Fox News -- who asked the original questions of Psaki -- tried to refer back to the video last month
column3: he found the exchange had been deleted. Kirby
column4: who originally called the deletion a ""glitch
column5: said Wednesday that he asked State Department lawyers to look into the matter after being notified about the omission. ""They learned that a specific request was made to excise that portion of the briefing. We do not know who made the request to edit the video or why it was made
column6: Kirby said. Another senior State Department official said the technician found the request ""unusual"" and consulted her supervisor before making the edit. The supervisor
column7: who also could not remember the name of the person who called
column8: approved the request because it came from someone ""from a certain level and credibility"" in the Department of Public Affairs. ""Although this person did not remember the person who called her
column9: or the person they were calling on behalf of
column10: she remembers it was not (Jen) Psaki
column11: this official said. ""Jen did not request it
column12: did not know about it and had nothing to do with it."" Psaki
column13: who now is the White House communications director
column14: tweeted Wednesday that she was unaware of the episode: ""I had no knowledge of nor would I have approved of any form of editing or cutting my briefing transcript on any subject while @StateDept."" Kirby noted that the full briefing transcript
column15: including the exchange on Iran
column16: had always been available on the State Department website and that the omitted video has since been replaced with a complete version that had been archived with the Defense Department. He said that was the only instance he was aware of in which briefing videos were edited
column17: though he couldn't be sure there weren't others. He announced a new policy Wednesday in which every video would be posted immediately with all edits disclosed. ""To my surprise
column18: the Bureau of Public Affairs did not have in place any rules governing this type of action
column19: he said. ""Therefore
column20: we are taking immediate steps to craft appropriate protocols on this issue
column21: as we believe that deliberately removing a portion of the video was not and is not in keeping with the State Department's commitment to transparency and public accountability."" Because such rules weren't previously in place
column22: Kirby said he found ""no reason"" to press forward with a more formal investigation."	REAL

column1: U.S. Economy Added 271,000 Jobs In October, Beating Expectations	"In a jobs report that may influence the Federal Reserve's decision on interest rates
column2: the Labor Department says that 271
column3: 000 jobs were added in October. The unemployment rate fell slightly to 5 percent
column4: according to the report from the agency's Bureau of Labor Statistics.

column1: It's the biggest one-month jobs gain in all of 2015
column2: according to Bloomberg News
column3: which adds that the strong result is one of the positive signs the Fed's economists ""are looking for as they consider a year-end boost in borrowing costs.""

column1: Friday's announcement tops economists' consensus expectations
column2: which had forecast a modest gain of about 180
column3: 000 jobs.

column1: Speaking in Congress this week
column2: Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen left open the possibility of an interest rate hike
column3: while also saying it would be ""very gradual."" Citing good economic results
column4: Yellen said there is a ""live possibility"" that policymakers might raise rates when the Fed meets in mid-December.

column1: Last month
column2: the Labor Department reported that only 142
column3: 000 jobs were created in September
column4: with unemployment holding at 5.1 percent. With today's announcement
column5: the BLS said the job-creation number was being revised to 137

column1: October's job growth occurred ""in professional and business services
column2: health care
column3: retail trade
column4: food services and drinking places
column5: and construction
column6: the Bureau of Labor Statistics says.

column1: As for wages
column2: the month also brought a 9-cent rise in the average hourly earning rate
column3: with workers on private nonfarm payrolls now making an average of $25.20
column4: according to the BLS
column5: which adds that for the group
column6: ""hourly earnings have risen by 2.5 percent over the year.""

column1: The agency also says that the number of people who are ""involuntary part-time workers"" due to reduced hours or the difficulty of finding a full-time job ""edged down by 269
column2: 000 to 5.8 million in October."""	REAL

column1: Hillary Clinton narrowly wins Kentucky, a state Bernie Sanders needed by huge margins	"For weeks
column2: Hillary Clinton has looked for the knockout blow that finally forces Bernie Sanders out of the Democratic primary.

column1: She may have gotten it tonight in Kentucky.

Sanders has to start winning every state by a landslide victory to have even a mathematical chance of catching Clinton's nearly 300-delegate lead. Kentucky was called for Clinton as an ""apparent winner"" at around 9:30 pm by NBC and after 10 pm by Kentucky's secretary of state
column2: who called her the ""unofficial winner.""

column1: Sanders has maintained that he'll stay in the race until the end of voting
column2: and we don't have any new reason to believe he'll fly the white flag after Clinton's victory tonight. And his hard-line response to the Democratic Party over this weekend's events in Nevada certainly doesn't suggest he's ready to call it quits.

column1: But Sanders needed to win Kentucky to maintain an increasingly far-fetched path to the Democratic nomination. The fact that he lost tonight — albeit by what appears to have been a very small margin — will only dramatically increase the calls for him to exit the race.
The loss is particularly tough for Sanders's campaign given that Kentucky was one of the more favorable states for him remaining in the race.
Given the West Virginia results
column2: I think Sanders is probably favored
column3: said Kyle Kondik of the University of Virginia's Center for Politics in an interview Tuesday morning
column4: before voting began. ""Sanders has a very good chance in Kentucky.""

column1: Sanders will probably face steeper odds in the upcoming contests in California and New Jersey
column2: where have polls have Clinton leading by as much as double digits. Polling from Kentucky was scarce
column3: but the state's largely white and rural voters were widely expected to break for Sanders — as they have throughout the country.

column1: Kentucky has a large number of registered Democrats who are much more conservative than the rest of the party
column2: a group that has in other states backed Sanders in part as a ""protest vote"" against the party's establishment
column3: according to Kondik.

column1: More than half of Kentucky’s registered voters are signed up with the Democratic Party
column2: even though the state’s election results have hewed decidedly Republican in recent years
column3: wrote the polling firm Morning Consult in a preview of tonight's contest ""That’s an indication of the rightward shift of downscale whites
column4: especially in once union-heavy Coal Country; those are voters who used to call themselves Yellow Dog Democrats.""

column1: These voters broke for Sanders by a big margin in West Virginia
column2: and they very well may have in Kentucky as well. But even if they did
column3: it does not appear to have been enough to offset the big difference between Kentucky and West Virginia: diversity.

column1: African-American voters are far more numerous in Kentucky — in part because of its cities
column2: like Louisville and Lexington. (Kentucky's 2008 primary electorate was 9 percent black
column3: compared to just 3 percent in West Virginia.)

column1: Black voters have rescued Clinton's campaign since her first big win in South Carolina in February. And
column2: tonight
column3: they may have helped push her opponent out of the race.

column1: Correction: A previous version of this story incorrectly said Kyle Kondik works for the Center for Responsive Politics
column2: rather than the University of Virginia's Center for Politics."	REAL

column1: No, it's not 'World War 3'	"Timothy Stanley is a historian and columnist for Britain's Daily Telegraph. He is the author of the new book ""Citizen Hollywood: How the Collaboration Between L.A. and D.C. Revolutionized American Politics."" The opinions expressed in this commentary are solely those of the author.

(CNN) Obama has called the Islamic State the ""face of evil"" but he's now under pressure from those who say he's not doing enough to beat it. Some insist that an attack on France was an attack on NATO and that it's time to go to war.
But only a fool would confuse caution for weakness. On the contrary
column2: to defeat the enemy we have to fully understand who the enemy is
column3: what they want and what kind of conflict we're involved in here. There are good reasons to proceed cautiously.

column1: To clear something up: We are effectively at war with ISIS right now. A U.S.-led coalition has been bombing targets in Syria and Iraq for over a year
column2: and in recent months Russia has been doing the same. How well it's worked is disputed: Obama has rhetorically shifted his objectives from crushing Isis to containing it.

column1: Nevertheless
column2: late last week there were signs of success. The Kurds took Sinjar
column3: a strategically significant area in northern Iraq. Mohammed Emwazi
column4: a vicious killer and propagandist
column5: was likely killed in a drone strike.

column1: Paris has obviously eclipsed the news of these breakthroughs.
Who or what are we fighting? ISIS is different from al Qaeda
column2: the group behind 9/11. The latter operated as an alliance of cells spread across the world; ISIS
column3: by contrast
column4: seeks to create a geographic space within which to build a caliphate. This shift in strategy perhaps explains why ISIS has been even more successful than al Qaeda at hitting so many different foreign targets with so many different methods -- from Sinai to Beirut to Paris.

column1: ISIS' caliphate offers a haven for tens of thousands of foreign jihadists: They come
column2: they train and then many return home to create havoc. The caliphate also provides money and the moral encouragement of having an earthly ""paradise"" to fight for. In his groundbreaking essay on the motivations behind ISIS
column3: Graeme Wood describes an ISIS recruiter calling it ""a vehicle for salvation.""

column1: Its fighters are obsessed with recreating Islam in its earliest form ( or as they interpret it to have been
column2: because the early caliphate was far kinder ) and believe that most other Muslims have fallen from the standard -- one that includes the uses of crucifixion and slavery. Whereas al Qaeda limited itself to comparatively rational political objectives
column3: like expelling Westerners from the Arab peninsula
column4: ISIS wants to bring on the apocalypse. It is not nihilist. It is deeply — if distortedly -- religious and we need to learn to take its brand of religion seriously.

column1: The good news is that ISIS is isolated. Applying the phrase ""world war"" here is unhelpful because it conjures images of rival
column2: equally sized nation states engaged in total war. But while ISIS' reach is global
column3: it does not command sizable support beyond its shifting boundaries. Meanwhile
column4: the alliance against it is one of the largest and most diverse in history
column5: including America
column6: Britain
column7: France
column8: Russia and Iran.

column1: Saudi money may well have once supported it but the Saudi state is now opposed. Indeed the exceptional evil of ISIS leads us to view many of the regional political agendas in a different light. Iran
column2: for instance
column3: certainly is exporting its theocratic government to other countries. But it doesn't desire the end of the world. The regime is murderous and must be contained. But it can be engaged.

column1: The complexity of Islamic world politics highlights another aspect of this conflict: It cannot be resolved entirely by force of arms. ISIS has exploited Sunni dissatisfaction with the Shia-dominated government in Baghdad. This may mean Iraq as a whole has to be split up to work. Turkey probably has to accommodate Kurdish desires for a homeland . And
column2: most importantly of all
column3: Bashar al-Assad
column4: the dictator of Syria
column5: will have to depart the stage.

column1: There can be no constructive government of Syria until there is law
column2: order and democratic elections that legitimize proper opposition parties. If we give rebels the impression that the West wants to force Assad on them again
column3: they will resist us
column4: too.

column1: Finally
column2: there is the question of how we handle the Islamic presence within Europe itself. This is partly a matter of improving security measures and making sure returnees from Syria don't just disappear into the crowd. There's also a refugee crisis to confront. But while the demographic pressures and security problems of allowing hundreds of thousands of people to cross Europe have to be addressed in a firm way
column3: there's no escaping the fact that a large
column4: settled part of the EU's population is now Islamic.

column1: And how we respond to ISIS has consequences for interfaith relations.

Some American politicians have suggested a religious test for refugees seeking access to the United States. This kind of prejudiced rhetoric adds to that false sense that this is a world war-style clash between conservative Muslims on one side and Christian democracies on the other. It is also unChristian and cruel. Moreover
column2: while Americans might fear Islamification as an existential concept
column3: we here in Europe have actual experience of living with Muslims -- and I can report that the living is easy.

column1: Muslims are our friends
column2: family and co-workers. They fear and despise ISIS as much as anyone else. And those of us in the center-ground of European politics are determined not to alienate
column3: or discriminate against

column1: Extreme rhetoric helping Cruz, Trump, Duke leaders say	"The use of extreme rhetoric by presidential candidates has sparked nationwide debates about American political polarization.
Republican presidential candidates Donald Trump and Sen. Ted Cruz have been the center of media attention for their use of inflammatory language
column2: notably when Trump referred to Mexican immigrants as rapists and drug traffickers and when Cruz called for the carpet-bombing of the Islamic State group. Although news coverage of candidates’ rhetoric may be polarizing Americans and deepening the partisan divide
column3: it has also arguably contributed to the current success of Trump and Cruz in the presidential race
column4: explained Duke faculty and student leaders.

column1: “There’s a kind of anxiety in the air probably across the country
column2: but certainly with certain populations in the U.S. that Cruz and Trump are tapping into
column3: ” said Frederick Mayer
column4: professor of public policy
column5: political science and environment. “Both of those candidates have found a way to frame their message that’s really resonating with the anxieties about American decline
column6: threats from terrorists abroad and at home
column7: perceived threats to the American way of life.”

column1: In last Tuesday’s State of the Union address
column2: President Barack Obama assured Americans that the country is not in decline
column3: despite inflammatory claims.

column1: “I told you earlier all the talk of America’s economic decline is political hot air
column2: ” he said. “Well
column3: so is all the rhetoric you hear about our enemies getting stronger and America getting weaker. Let me tell you something—the United States of America is the most powerful nation on Earth
column4: period.”

column1: Mayer noted that factors such as low unemployment
column2: low crime levels and fewer instances of terrorism on American soil should also ease the anxiety of Americans.

column1: “It’s ironic because you can make the claim that we have less to fear today than just about any people in any time in history
column2: ” he said. “All these factors that should make us feel good.”

column1: Junior Adam Lemon
column2: president of the Duke College Republicans
column3: said that extreme rhetoric was necessary for the success of Trump and Cruz in a field of more than 15 candidates
column4: where standing out in any way was imperative. He also noted that cable news has used stories about Trump to boost ratings.

column1: “I think part of the reason that [Donald Trump] is polling so high is that his name is just so ubiquitous through all of the news media
column2: ” said freshman Steve Hassey
column3: communications director for Duke Democrats. “Him being such a polarizing figure makes the mass coverage of him even more polarizing.”

column1: Both Lemon and Mayer discussed how news can have a negative impact when it focuses on polarizing comments.
However
column2: Mayer said he was optimistic that bipartisan reform is possible and will occur on certain issues. On campus
column3: there have been a few bipartisan discussions
column4: such as the Battle of the Brains debate between college Democrats and Republicans hosted by Duke Student Government last November in which students discussed issues ranging from racial discrimination to the national debt.

column1: Although there have been bipartisan discussions
column2: Lemon noted that there are barriers to fostering discussion between students of opposing political parties on campus.

column1: “There are a lot more liberals on campus than conservatives
column2: ” Lemon said. “Liberals tend to talk amongst themselves. Conservatives are afraid to express their opinions
column3: so they don’t really talk and neither side is really willing to engage too much.”

column1: Mayer attributed the polarization and the lack of engagement between the two sides to something more than just extreme rhetoric.
“At some deep level
column2: many of the problems we’ve been talking about are really manifestations of a loss of trust in each other
column3: in our institutions and the like
column4: ” he said. “This whole dysfunction is a trust problem. We stopped trusting institutions. We don’t trust politicians. A world where you have very little trust is a much less functional world.”"	REAL

column8: Madame Secretary
column9: but the ambassador did not
column10: ” Gowdy asked with much gravity.

column1: Gowdy’s implication – that Stevens either lacked access to Clinton or that Clinton prioritized her communications with Blumenthal – was flagrantly false
column2: and Gowdy knows it was false. Stevens had access to Clinton through a variety of means and could have been in touch with her at a moment’s notice if he’d wanted. But Gowdy used the frequency of email communication – and only email communication – to give the impression that Blumenthal was in the loop while the ambassador was not.

column1: This theme was picked up on by his Republican colleagues
column2: who weren’t nearly as subtle in their dishonesty as Gowdy was. Rep. Mike Pompeo grandiosely asked Clinton if Stevens had had Clinton’s cell phone number
column3: fax number
column4: or home address
column5: and if he’d ever “stopped by your house.” After Clinton said no to all these things
column6: Pompeo went in for what he thought was the kill: “Mr. Blumenthal had each of those and did each of those things. This man who provided you so much information on Libya had access to you in ways that were very different from the access that a very senior diplomat had to you and your person.” If you’re the sort of thick-headed dolt who thinks the ambassador was at a disadvantage because he couldn’t send the Secretary of State a postcard or pop in on her every Sunday afternoon
column7: then this point was probably quite compelling.

column1: While the Republicans were wasting their time trying to portray Clinton as a tool of Sid Blumenthal
column2: the Democrats used their time to make clear just how pointless they believe the entire investigation is and allowed Clinton her opportunities to offer sanitized and carefully worded defenses of the Libya intervention. At least one member of the committee used the hearing to pose useful and interesting questions about issues that arose from the Benghazi attack: Rep. Tammy Duckworth (D-IL). She asked Clinton about policies for outsourcing security to local militias and security contractors
column3: which has caused problems for the State Department and other government agencies. All in all it was a bust for Gowdy and the Benghazi committee
column4: to the point that conservative pundits were griping about how poorly the Republicans fared against Clinton. Anyone who doubted that the committee was a partisan exercise in Clinton-bashing came away free of doubts. The only sliver of good news for the Republicans is that it likely won’t matter. The notion that Barack Obama and Hillary Clinton engineered some sort of evil Benghazi cover-up is already assumed to be true in the minds of conservatives and Republican voters. The fact that Gowdy and crew spent the day stepping on rakes and scoring own-goals in a failed attempt to “prove” it won’t change their minds. And the House GOP won’t put the brakes on the investigation because the committee’s utility as a vehicle for strategic press leaks outweighs the bad press it’s enduring at the moment. The Benghazi committee will grind on
column5: performing much the same role it always has."	REAL

column1: Obama seeks global climate pact in Paris, amid resistance at home	"President Obama set out Monday to help seal a global climate pact at the opening of a major summit in Paris

2 deaths possibly linked to 'superbug' at UCLA hospital after 7 infected, 179 exposed	"UCLA reported Wednesday that nearly 180 patients were exposed to a potentially deadly ""superbug"" on contaminated medical instruments that infected seven patients and may have contributed to two deaths.
A total of 179 patients at Ronald Reagan UCLA Medical Center were exposed to antibiotic-resistant carbapenem-resistant Enterobacteriaceae
column2: or CRE
column3: during endoscopic procedures between October and January
column4: the university said in a statement. The bacteria may have been a ""contributing factor"" in the deaths of two patients
column5: the university said. Those who were exposed are being sent free home-testing kits that the university will analyze.

column1: Similar outbreaks of CRE have been reported around the nation. They are difficult to treat because some varieties are resistant to most known antibiotics. By one estimate
column2: CRE can contribute to death in up to half of seriously infected patients
column3: according to the national Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.

column1: The bacteria can cause infections of the bladder or lungs
column2: leading to coughing
column3: fever or chills. CRE infections have been reported in every state except Idaho
column4: Alaska and Maine
column5: according to the CDC.

column1: UCLA said infections may have been transmitted through specialized endoscopes used during the diagnosis and treatment of pancreatic and bile-duct problems. The instruments are inserted into the patients' throats. The outbreak was discovered late last month during tests on a patient.
The two medical devices may have carried the bacteria even though they were sterilized according to the manufacturer's specifications
column2: UCLA said.

column1: The devices have been removed
column2: and decontamination procedures upgraded
column3: the university said.

column1: We notified all patients who had this type of procedure
column2: and we were using seven different scopes. Only two of them were found to be infected. In an abundance of caution
column3: we notified everybody
column4: said Dale Tate
column5: a University of California
column6: Los Angeles spokeswoman.

column1: On Thursday
column2: the U.S. Food and Drug Administration issued an advisory warning doctors that even when a manufacturer's cleaning instructions are followed
column3: infectious germs may linger in the devices. Their complex design and tiny parts make complete disinfection extremely difficult
column4: the advisory said.

column1: National figures on the bacteria are not kept
column2: but 47 states have seen cases
column3: the CDC said.

column1: A similar outbreak occurred in Illinois in 2013. Dozens of patients were exposed to CRE
column2: with some cases apparently linked to a tainted endoscope used at Advocate Lutheran General Hospital. The hospital later changed its sterilization procedures.

column1: A Seattle hospital
column2: Virginia Mason Medical Center
column3: reported in January that CRE linked to an endoscope sickened at least 35 patients
column4: and 11 died

column4: as Clinton speaks

Your dog probably has better healthcare than you do	"Below is a short email that my friend Sam posted this morning to his Facebook page about his surprisingly positive experience with the US healthcare system.
I thought it a fantastic read
column2: and I wanted to pass it along to you:

column1: I had to run to the emergency room today for what may be a neurological issue. Dizziness
column2: staggering
column3: loss of balance
column4: that kind of thing.

column1: I’m in San Diego
column2: one of the most expensive cities in the world
column3: and I have no insurance. I figured I was screwed.

column1: But instead
column2: the experience was unreal.

column1: I got seen immediately. I didn’t even have time to sit down
column2: they just whisked me into an examination room.

column1: The doctor and nurse were ON IT
column2: and they took their time with the exam and consultation.

column1: The visit ultimately involved staying the whole day for observation
column2: all kinds of tests
column3: sedation and reversal
column4: blood pressure check
column5: a full blood panel work up (results tomorrow
column6: yes TOMORROW keep your fingers crossed) and having both ears cleaned and flushed.

column1: The bill was a mere $374.63.
Do I have some insane insurance plan? Nope.
Am I being super-subsidized by the rest of America? Nope.
Am I a privileged politician with a special “bosses only” healthcare plan? Don’t make me laugh.
It turns out that the care was for my dog
column2: not for me. And we didn’t go to a ‘people’ hospital– I obviously took my dog to an animal hospital.

column1: She and I are both biological machines
column2: mammals made mostly of water (though she sheds more than I do).

column1: The only other real difference is that the government is regulating the hell out of healthcare for people
column2: while (relatively speaking)
column3: leaving healthcare for animals alone.

column1: And that
column2: my friends
column3: is the reason Obamacare has flopped
column4: and why your healthcare costs will keep going up.

column1: It’s not greed. It’s not the drug companies. It’s not anything other than the application of government intervention in what should be a free market.
Simon again.
It’s not exactly controversial these days to suggest that the US healthcare system is in bad shape.
According to data collected by numerous independent agencies like the Institute of Medicine
column2: Commonwealth Fund
column3: and Kaiser Family Foundation
column4: the US still ranks dead last among advanced economies in overall quality of its healthcare system.

column1: In fact
column2: the US healthcare system has the worst record in the number of deaths caused by mistakes or inefficient care.

column1: And wait times in the US for urgent care and primary care visits rank lower than every other developed nation.
Americans pay at least 50% more for healthcare in terms of annual spending than people in other advanced nations
column2: yet they receive less care as measured by the number of doctor visits.

column1: Sure
column2: it’s great that there are fewer uninsured people than ever before in the US
column3: but this is a measure of QUANTITY
column4: not a measure of QUALITY.

column1: Undoubtedly the US is home to some of the finest medical professionals in the world.
But they’ve been buried under an expensive
column2: over-regulated bureaucracy that continues to erode overall quality in the system.

column1: A 2015 report from the National Academy of Sciences summed it up by stating
column2: “For Americans
column3: health care costs and expenditures are the highest in the world
column4: yet health outcomes and care quality are below average by many measures.”

column1: But instead of trying to understand WHY the system is so slow
column2: bureaucratic
column3: and expensive to begin with
column4: politicians try to ‘fix’ it by creating more regulations.

column1: It’s as if they believe they can legislate their way to a quality
column2: efficient medical care system
column3: just as they believe they can legislate their way to a better education system or economic prosperity.

column1: This almost never works.
After all
column2: the people who come up with these rules are notoriously unqualified and have rarely ever held a job outside of their giant government bureaucracy.

column1: So despite what may be some very good intentions to fix the system

column1: Historic firsts fill evening at Democratic National Convention	"Shattering the glass ceiling wasn't the only way historic firsts took the floor in Philadelphia Tuesday night
column2: when the Democratic Party named Hillary Clinton as its presidential nominee.

column1: Democratic presidential nominee Hillary Clinton addresses the Democratic National Convention via a live video feed from New York during the second night at the Democratic National Convention in Philadelphia on July 26
With Vermont Sen. Bernie Sanders on the mic
column2: addressing the crowds that thronged the Democratic National Convention hall in Philadelphia
column3: history was made.

column1: “I move that Hillary Clinton be selected as the nominee of the Democratic Party for president of the United States
column2: ” Senator Sanders said. The crowd roared
column3: the delegates ‘ayed
column4: ’ and Mrs. Clinton officially became the first woman to be nominated by a major political party for the position of president of the United States.

column1: Appearing on video from New York later Tuesday night
column2: after a montage of the 43 men who have presided over the Oval Office filled the large screen overhead
column3: Clinton thanked her party and the delegates for their role in helping her make “the biggest crack in that glass ceiling yet.”

column1: Calling out to the American viewers
column2: she said: “If there are any little girls out there who stayed up late to watch
column3: let me just say: I may become the first woman president
column4: but one of you is next.”

column1: Clinton’s nomination comes 240 years into the existence of the United States of America and nearly a century after the Constitution was amended in 1919 to give women the right to vote. There were still state restrictions that continued to make it difficult for women (and men) of color to exercise that right into the 1960s.

Her nomination was not the only precedent-setter at the convention. Tuesday night held echoes of both Clinton’s past roles and of the milestones reached by women in politics since they gained suffrage.
The convention itself is being chaired by Ohio Rep. Marcia Fudge
column2: who has shattered her own share of glass ceilings. Ms. Fudge was both the first African-American and first female mayor of Warrensville Heights
column3: Ohio
column4: a position she held from from 2000 to 2008. She is joined at the helm of the convention and the party by two other African-American women. Rev. Leah Daughtry
column5: former chief of staff for the party's committee
column6: is the chief executive officer of the convention for the second time
column7: while Donna Brazile is the interim Democratic National Committee chair after Debbie Wasserman Schultz resigned last week
column8: following an email scandal. Ms. Brazile became well-known in the party as Al Gore's campaign manager
column9: the Washington Post reports.

column1: In an interview with NBCBLK in November
column2: Reverend Daughtry said that this year’s convention
column3: now underway
column4: would be ""the most diverse and the most forward-looking convention that we've had in recent history.""

column1: The speaker line-up last night also included a fair share of ground-breakers. One of the senators who nominated Clinton during the state roll call was Maryland Sen. Barbara Mikulski
column2: who said she was acting on behalf of ""all women who have broken down barriers for others."" Senator Mikulski herself was the the first Democratic woman to be elected to the Senate in 1987. Clinton held the role of senator for New York State between 2001 and 2009; the two women are among the group of 46 women to have ever held the role of US senator.

column1: Another of the evening’s speakers was Madeleine Albright. A distinguished diplomat
column2: Ms. Albright was the country’s first female secretary of State
column3: a position that Clinton held under Barack Obama
column4: when she was the third woman in the job. Albright was selected for that role in 1996 by former President Bill Clinton.

column1: Mr. Clinton himself would break ground
column2: were his wife to be elected to his former office
column3: as both the first man in the role traditionally referred to as ""first lady"" and the first former president to hold that place. Mr. Clinton was the keynote speaker last night
column4: offering a personal portrait of his wife to counter the narrative of corruption and scandal that has at times ensnared the campaign.

column1: Emphasizing his wife's history of activism
column2: not just for women
column3: but for socioeconomic and racial equality
column4: Mr. Clinton called her the ""best darn changemaker I've met in my entire life."" She ""had done more positive change before she was 30 than many politicians do in a lifetime in office.""

column1: The theme of “firsts” will continue Wednesday night
column2: on point for a party that distinguishes itself from the competition with a progressive agenda.

column1: This evening
column2: President Obama
column3: the first African-American president
column4: will offer his support of Clinton. On Monday
column5: she received the support of another historymaker
column6: one who occupies another role Clinton herself once held: Michelle Obama
column7: the nation's first African-American first lady.

column1: Will a No-Fly Zone Help the People of Aleppo?	"Email
Media coverage has recently been saturated with distressing scenes showing the humanitarian crisis in Aleppo
column2: where aerial bombardment has led to a heavy loss of civilian life. The severity of the crisis instinctively makes us want to help – scores of protesters gathered outside the seat of the British prime minister on Saturday holding signs calling on the government to “Save Aleppo” and impose a “No-Bomb Zone Now”. While the anger is understandable
column3: the way it is being channeled reflects a circumscribed policy debate – there are other options than a No-Fly Zone
column4: which should be avoided as it would harm rather than help efforts to alleviate the suffering of Syrian civilians.

column1: In any area of policy
column2: the mainstream debate revolves around policy alternatives that reflect establishment divisions. For example
column3: in economics
column4: ‘there is no alternative’ to neoliberalism
column5: at least there wasn’t until Keynesianism was rediscovered by some elites after the 2008 crisis. The debate over what is to be done over Syria revolves around two policy alternatives: the hawks
column6: including likely next U.S. president
column7: Hillary Clinton
column8: advocate a NFZ and the doves
column9: including the current U.S. administration
column10: maintain that the sanctions regime should be increased. This effectively reflects a division within the establishment on how to proceed. Serious policy alternatives are not discussed. In particular
column11: discussion of increasing aid and support to refugees
column12: surely the most obvious way of directly helping civilians in Syria
column13: and what the UN has called on industrialized countries to do
column14: is curious by its absence.

column1: This circumscribed debate does not logically follow from its supposed pretext – stopping civilian loss of life. In fact
column2: a NFZ is a policy that would unavoidably lead to civilians dying. Enforcing a NFZ means destroying air defenses
column3: which are located to defend cities – i.e. they are located in areas where there are many civilians. Even the flagbearer for the hawks
column4: Hillary Clinton
column5: has admitted privately that with a No-Fly Zone “you’re going to kill a lot of Syrians”; such intervention will “take a lot of civilians”. This realization would seem inconsistent with the often-used humanitarian pretext
column6: but it makes sense given Hillary Clinton’s recent admission that her top priority in Syria is removing Syrian President Assad.

column1: There is a clear parallel with the imposition of a NFZ in Libya
column2: which prolonged the conflict and worsened the situation for civilians. NATO bombing directly led to scores of civilian deaths and facilitated the overthrow of the regime by rebel militias that have killed
column3: and are continuing to kill
column4: thousands. Particularly repugnant was the ethnic cleansing of black people
column5: including through public lynching . In a 2013 paper
column6: Alan Kuperman
column7: a Harvard academic
column8: argued that NATO intervention extended the war by a factor of 6 and increased the death toll 7 to 10 times; given that Libya is now a failed state
column9: torn apart by warlords
column10: we can safely say that these estimates were too conservative. President Obama privately calls the situation in Libya a “ shit show ”. Only last month a report from the Foreign Affairs Committee of the British Parliament found that the humanitarian justification was an insufficient pretext and based on falsehoods
column11: the supposedly limited intervention led “ineluctably” to regime change
column12: and that the (British) government
column13: and by implication other participating Western powers
column14: did not seriously consider diplomatic alternatives to military action.

column1: Regardless
column2: the mantra of Western foreign policy is “it will be different this time” – unlike all recent Western military interventions this one will be limited
column3: successful and won’t leave a worse humanitarian situation in its wake. Although
column4: if the dire humanitarian situation in Aleppo necessitates immediate action
column5: then why are there not equally loud calls for action for civilians facing similar situations? U.S. bombing in Manbij and Kobane in Syria and Ramadi and Fallujah in Iraq has resulted in thousands of civilian deaths and flattened entire neighbourhoods ; more than a third of US and UK backed Saudi airstrikes in Yemen have hit civilian sites
column6: including schools
column7: hospitals
column8: weddings and funerals .

column1: Talking about this is not meant as a distraction or relativization; the fact that the U.S. and Saudi Arabia are engaged in similar activities does not make the bombing of Aleppo less objectionable. However
column2: it does raise questions about the motives of those pushing so hard for a no-fly zone. If western foreign policy actors
column3: and their allies in press
column4: were motivated by humanitarian concerns
column5: then surely stopping these atrocities should appear on the policy agenda – especially given that the action required is easier and does not risk war with Russia.

column1: If humanitarian considerations were really the important factors in the foreign policy debate
column2: then there would be discussion on the legitimacy of aerial bombardment of cities and towns
column3: given that this invariably leads to civilian deaths. International agreements have been successful in making chemical and biological weapons illegal
column4: a prohibition which is generally followed ( though not always ). The first well-publicized use of aerial bombardment
column5: the Nazi bombing of Guernica in 1937
column6: caused righteous
column7: popular outrage. Tragically
column8: however
column9: its use became normalized during the Second World War and a ban on aerial bombing of cities was not included in the post-war international settlement. The fact that this seems so hopelessly idealistic reflects the fact that it is geopolitics
column10: not humanitarian considerations
column11: that govern international relations and foreign policy discussion; human suffering is nothing more than a useful pretext for whatever actions you want to take in order to secure geopolitical advantage. The U.S. and its allies want to remove Syria from Russia’s orbit
column12: so therefore the dictator there must go
column13: but airstrikes to support the dictator in Yemen are fine
column14: because the dictator there is a friend of close U.S. ally Saudi Arabia.

column1: There is an added complication with the NFZ in Syria in that it marks a return to Cold-War era brinkmanship and possible armed confrontation with Russia. The logic of brinkmanship runs that to make geopolitical gains
column2: one must escalate to a level that will make the other side back down
column3: partly by convincing your enemy you are ready to commit irrational acts. There is an inherent danger in this game: both states are nuclear armed and the consequences of a spiral of escalation could be devastating .

column1: Syria hawks
column2: or what close Obama aide Ben Rhodes called the “ pro-stupid shit ” caucus
column3: argue that a NFZ will lead Russia to effectively back down: for example
column4: Clinton argued that it will “give us leverage in our conversations with Russia”. (Interestingly
column5: in the exchange this quote from Clinton indicated the war goal: a NFZ will make Russia “put the Assad future on the political and diplomatic track” – i.e. Russia will be forced to accept regime change.) After all
column6: despite the panic in the press
column7: Russia is actually a feeble successor state to a superpower
column8: and would come off worse in a direct conflict with the preeminent might of North America
column9: or so the logic runs.

column1: However
column2: ‘dovish’ Western foreign policy actors point to the danger that advanced Russian materiel support to Syria poses to the enforcement of a NFZ. Unlike other recent U.S. military adventures
column3: enforcing a NFZ in Syria could lead to significant
column4: and politically unpalatable
column5: American casualties – pilots will be shot down. This realization means that saner establishment figures are opposed to a NFZ. For example
column6: U.S. Army General Carter Ham
column7: who oversaw the NFZ in Libya
column8: said a NFZ is a “violent combat action that results in lots of casualties and increased risk to our own personnel”.

column1: Instead
column2: relative doves like current Secretary of State John Kerry advocate intensifying the sanctions regime against Syria and Russia. Again
column3: this does not seem to be seriously about helping civilians. A leaked UN report has revealed that the existing Western sanctions regime is preventing humanitarian aid and creating a humanitarian disaster that threatens to rival that caused by the Oil-for-Food program in Iraq during the 1990s. The history of sanctions tends to show that the costs are borne by civilians
column4: and a Petersen Institute study of all sanctions incidents since WWII shows that sanctions failed to achieve their goals in about ⅔ of cases
column5: and are even less successful when applied against enemies and autocrats.

column1: So
column2: what is to be done? What should people in the West and globally push for to help the people of Syria? Unfortunately
column3: there do not seem to be any quick fixes – the situation in Syria is complex and involves diverse actors
column4: with competing interests. Immediate relief to the refugees fleeing the conflict should be a priority. In terms of foreign policy
column5: campaigning for de-escalation and diplomacy against constant militarism remain the best solutions for the Syrian people
column6: and humanity generally."	FAKE

column1: Experts Recommend Breaking Down Crushing Defeats Into Smaller, More Manageable Failures - The Onion - America's Finest News Source	"Experts Recommend Breaking Down Crushing Defeats Into Smaller

column1: SANTA BARBARA
column2: CA—Offering advice to those who feel overwhelmed at the thought of becoming massive failures
column3: a group of experts reported this week that the best way to approach a crippling defeat is to break it down into a set of smaller and more manageable setbacks. “The key to failing on a monumental scale is to take life one small misstep at a time
column4: ” life coach Jack V. Royce told reporters
column5: emphasizing that people who hit absolute rock bottom seldom get there overnight. “Just start with a couple of minor fuckups and then build off that. It’s all about working through your long
column6: humiliating downward spiral in workable increments: botch this
column7: flub that
column8: make a wreck of something else—and then
column9: before you know it
column10: you’re well on your way to being totally screwed.” Royce added that it’s also helpful every now and then to stop
column11: take stock of your situation
column12: and really beat yourself up about it. Share This Story: WATCH VIDEO FROM THE ONION Sign up For The Onion's Newsletter

War on Drugs Heading in Wrong Direction?	"License DMCA My guest today is Maya Schenwar
column2: Truthout's editor-in-chief
column3: author of Locked Down
column4: Locked Out: Why Prison Doesn't Work and How We Can Do Better
column5: and co-editor of Who Do You Serve
column6: Who Do you Protect? Police Violence and Resistance in the United States . Joan Brunwasser: Welcome back to OpEdNews
column7: Maya. We last spoke back in January
column9: I'd like to discuss your recent piece: Death Penalty for Heroin Dealers? More Proof the Drug War Is Not Over . Who thought the drug war was over in the first place and why? - Advertisement - Maya Schenwar: There has been a shift in mainstream politics toward condemning the drug war
column10: and for good reason. It has done nothing to stem drug misuse
column11: and meanwhile it has resulted in the criminalization and incarceration of millions of people
column12: overwhelmingly Black and Brown people. With countless studies demonstrating its ""failure"" (I put this in quotes because I don't think the drug war was actually devised to help people in the first place)
column13: politicians who defend it end up looking pretty bad. So the current line is to say it's in the past
column14: and that we have a new approach to drugs going forward. The Obama administration
column15: many state governments
column16: and even conservative politicians (including the ""Right on Crime"" crowd) have said that we need to leave behind the old war on drugs. In February
column17: Eric Holder said the drug war is ""over
column18: and Obama increasingly talks about treating drug-related issues as ""public health problems"" instead of criminal problems. JB: How does that change anything: the disproportionate numbers of minority members locked up for possession
column19: more single moms incarcerated for the same
column20: families split up and minors left with no parent at home? Are they
column21: then
column22: opening the prison gates and saying
column23: ""We were wrong. This was all a big mistake; it didn't work and we diverted and wasted billions of dollars that could have been used to good purpose. And we ruined your lives for nothing. Oops. Sorry.""? MS: No
column24: no one is opening the prison gates
column25: unfortunately! There are some limited steps being taken toward scaling back drug-war-related incarceration. For example
column26: Obama has issued hundreds of commutations to people serving super-long drug sentences. Some states have taken steps to reduce some very low-level drug offenses to misdemeanors instead of felonies
column27: which means people are a lot less likely to be incarcerated for them. (California's Proposition 47 is an example of this
column28: although the emphasis on ""low-level offenses"" has actually entrenched the idea that people should be severely punished for ""higher-level offenses.) - Advertisement - Obviously
column29: in a number of states
column30: marijuana is being decriminalized
column31: and some are legalizing it. However
column32: that doesn't mean there are no longer marijuana arrests -- in fact
column33: an ACLU study released recently showed there were more marijuana possession arrests last year than arrests for all violent crimes. The study also showed that Black people are still disproportionately arrested in far greater numbers than white people
column34: despite using marijuana at about the same rate as white people. JB: How do we understand this
column35: Maya? Beyond being convinced that the whole penal system is seriously screwed up
column36: what's the point of increased marijuana arrests? Is this a last gasp effort or at least partly to fill up jail cells and local or private prison coffers? MS: There wasn't an increase in marijuana arrests overall last year; there was a decrease. But obviously it was a small decrease
column37: given that there was a larger number of possession arrests than all violent crime arrests. I don't think it's about filling private prison coffers. Ultimately
column38: prisons are expensive for states
column39: and I don't actually see money as a primary motivator to incarcerate people. Until we challenge criminality itself -- and challenge the white supremacy that underlies the US's version of criminality -- we won't be done with large-scale incarceration. We have to understand incarceration by looking at how people are being labeled as disposable and as ""dangerous
column40: and how those things are racialized. Whether it's marijuana possession or something else
column41: there will always be a convenient ""crime"" with which to charge Black and Brown people unless white supremacy itself is confronted. We also have to think about ableism
column45: capitalism -- really confronting the structures that make it possible for our society to lock millions of people in cages. If we look at the drug war through this lens
column46: we understand that's it's not some stand-alone entity; it's one tool deployed by a larger power structure that continually targets marginalized people in order to keep itself going. JB: Good point. Does the fact that the penal dysfunction is part of a larger overarching dysfunction make it easier or harder to improve it? And what's ableism? I don't know that I'm familiar with that term. MS: I think the fact that it's part of an overarching structural problem means that it can't really been improved
column47: per se -- it really has to be uprooted. I wouldn't say that can happen extremely easily; it's more a goal to move toward while making incremental changes. Ableism is the structural oppression against and devaluation of people with disabilities. One of the ways it plays out in relation to prison is the extremely high level of incarceration of people with psychiatric and intellectual disabilities. 'Locked Down
column48: Locked Out: Why Prison Doesn't Work and How We Can Do Better' by Maya Schenwar(image by Berrett-Koehler Publishers) License DMCA JB: Quite true. I believe much of that shift occurred when President Reagan ""reallocated"" resources
column49: closing many state mental hospitals and dumping the patients onto the streets and the unprepared public. And we've been paying the price
column51: ever since. What haven't we talked about yet? MS: There's of course much more to talk about
column52: but we have to end things somewhere
column53: right? One thing I'd caution people against is assuming that the automatic alternative to incarceration for people convicted of drug offenses should be drug treatment. First of all
column54: most people arrested for drug offenses aren't dependent on drugs (most people who use drugs are not dependent on them); there are safe ways to use drugs and we have to challenge laws that stigmatize their use."	FAKE

column1: The Middle East Crises Trump Inherits Could Still Suck Him in	"Here's something interesting from The Unz Review... Recipient Name Recipient Email =>
‘Make America Great Again’ was the slogan of Donald Trump’s election
column2: but the immediate impact of his victory is to make the US less of a power in the world for two reasons: American prestige and influence will be damaged by a general belief internationally that the US has just elected a dangerous buffoon as its leader. The perception is pervasive
column3: but is not very deeply rooted and likely be temporary
column4: stemming as it does from Trump’s demagogic rants during the election campaign. Those about relations with foreign countries were particularly vague and least likely to provide a guide to future policy.

column1: More damaging in the long term for America’s status as superpower is the likelihood that the US is now a more deeply divided society than ever. Trump won the election by demonising and threatening individuals and communities – Mexicans
column2: Muslims
column3: Latinos – and his confrontational style of politics is not going to disappear. Verbal violence produces a permanently over-heated political atmosphere in which physical violence becomes an option. At the same time
column4: the election campaign was focused almost exclusively on American domestic politics with voters showing little interest in events abroad. This is unlikely to change.

column1: Governments around the world can see this for themselves
column2: though this will not stop them badgering their diplomats in Washington and New York for an inkling as to how far Trump’s off-the-cuff remarks were more than outrageous attempts to dominate the news agenda for a few hours. Fortunately
column3: his pronouncements were so woolly that they can be easily jettisoned between now and his inauguration. Real foreign policy positions will only emerge with the formation of a Trump cabinet when it becomes clear who will be in charge.

column1: But
column2: if future policies remain unknowable
column3: super-charged American nationalism combined with economic populism and isolationism are likely to set the general tone. Trump has invariably portrayed Americans as the victims of the foul machinations of foreign countries who previously faced no real resistance from an incompetent self-serving American elite.

column1: This sort of aggressive nationalism is not unique to Trump. All over the world nationalism is having a spectacular rebirth in countries from Turkey to the Philippines. It has become a successful vehicle for protest in Britain
column2: France
column3: Germany
column4: Austria and Eastern Europe. Though Trump is frequently portrayed as a peculiarly American phenomenon
column5: his populist nationalism has a striking amount in common with that of the Brexit campaigners in Britain or even the chauvinism of President Recep Tayyip Erdogan in Turkey. Much of this can be discounted as patriotic bombast
column6: but in all cases there is a menacing undercurrent of racism and demonisation
column7: whether it is directed against illegal immigrants in the US
column8: asylum seekers in the Britain or Kurds in south east Turkey.

column1: In reality
column2: Trump made very few proposals for radical change in US foreign policy during the election campaign
column3: aside from saying that he would throw out the agreement with Iran on its nuclear programme – though his staff is now being much less categorical about this
column4: saying only that the deal must be properly enforced. Nobody really knows if Trump will deal any differently from Obama with the swathe of countries between Pakistan and Nigeria where there are at least seven wars raging – Afghanistan
column5: Iraq
column6: Syria
column7: Yemen
column8: Libya
column9: Somalia and South Sudan – as well as four serious insurgencies.

column1: The most serious wars in which the US is already militarily involved are in Iraq and Syria and here Trump’s comments during the campaign suggest that he will focus on destroying Isis
column2: recognise the danger of becoming militarily over-involved and look for some sort of cooperation with Russia as the next biggest player in the conflict. This is similar to what is already happening.

column1: Hillary Clinton’s intentions in Syria
column2: though never fully formulated
column3: always sounded more interventionist than Trump’s. One of her senior advisers openly proposed giving less priority to the assault on Isis and more to getting rid of President Bashar al-Assad. To this end
column4: a third force of pro-US militant moderates was to be raised that would fight and ultimately defeat both Isis and Assad. Probably this fantasy would never have come to pass
column5: but the fact that it was ever given currency underlines the extent to which Clinton was at one with the most dead-in-the-water conventional wisdom of the foreign policy establishment in Washington.

column1: President Obama developed a much more acute sense of what the US could and could not do in the Middle East and beyond
column2: without provoking crises exceeding its political and military strength. Its power may be less than before the failed US interventions in Iraq and Afghanistan following 9/11
column3: but it is still far greater than any other country’s. Currently
column4: it is the US which is successfully coordinating the offensive against Isis’s last strongholds in Mosul and Raqqa by a multitude of fractious parties in Iraq and Syria. It was never clear how seriously one should have taken Clinton’s proposals for “safe zones” and trying to fight Isis and Assad at the same time
column5: but her judgements on events in the Middle East since the Iraq invasion of 2003 all suggested a flawed idea of what was feasible.

column1: Trump’s instincts generally seem less well-informed but often shrewd
column2: and his priories have nothing to do with the Middle East. Past US leaders have felt the same way
column3: but they usually end up by being dragged into its crises one way or other
column4: and how they perform then becomes the test of their real quality as a leader. The region has been the political graveyard for three of the last five US presidents: Jimmy Carter was destroyed by the consequences of the Iranian revolution; Ronald Reagan was gravely weakened by the Iran-Contra scandal; and George W Bush’s years in office will be remembered chiefly for the calamities brought on by his invasion of Iraq. Barack Obama was luckier and more sensible
column5: but he wholly underestimated the rise of Isis until it captured Mosul in 2014. (Reprinted from The Independent by permission of author or representative)"	FAKE
