column1: Donald Trump and Hillary Clinton confronted their key weaknesses in a televised national security forum
column2: with the Republican defending his preparedness to be commander in chief despite vague plans for tackling global challenges and the Democrat arguing that her controversial email practices did not expose questionable judgment.

column1: Mr. Trump also renewed his praise of Russian President Vladimir Putin and his disdain for President Barack Obama
column2: saying that the Russian enjoyed an 82 percent approval rating. ""The man has very strong control over a country
column3: Trump said. ""It's a very different system and I don't happen to like the system
column4: but certainly
column5: in that system
column6: he's been a leader
column7: far more than our president has been a leader.""

column1: Speaking to reporters in Laos
column2: Obama said Thursday that Trump confirms his belief that Trump isn't qualified to be president ""every time he speaks"" and added: ""The most important thing for the public and the press is to just listen to what he says and follow up and ask questions to what appear to be either contradictory or uninformed or outright wacky ideas.""

column1: Trump and Mrs. Clinton spoke back-to-back Wednesday night
column2: each fielding 30 minutes of questions. While the candidates never appeared on stage together
column3: the session served as a preview of sorts for their highly-anticipated presidential debates.

column1: By virtue of a coin flip
column2: Clinton took the stage first and quickly found herself responding at length to questions about her years in government. She reiterated that she had made mistakes in relying on a personal email account and private server as secretary of State and in voting for the 2003 invasion of Iraq as a senator. But she defended her support for U.S. military intervention to help oust a dictator in Libya
column3: despite the chaotic aftermath.

column1: I'm asking to be judged on the totality of my record
column2: said Clinton
column3: who grew visibly irritated at times with the repeated focus on her past actions.

column1: Clinton
column2: who has cast Trump as dangerously ill-prepared to be commander in chief
column3: tried to center the discussion on her foreign policy proposals. She vowed to defeat the Islamic State group ""without committing American ground troops"" to Iraq or Syria. And she pledged to hold weekly Oval Office meetings with representatives from the Pentagon and Department of Veterans Affairs to stay abreast of health care for veterans.

column1: Trump did little to counter the criticism that he lacks detailed policy proposals
column2: particularly regarding the Islamic State group. He both insisted he has a private blueprint for defeating the extremist group and that he would demand a plan from military leaders within 30 days of taking office.

column1: But he was also harshly critical of the military
column2: saying America's generals have been ""reduced to rubble"" under Obama. Asked to square his request for military options with that criticism
column3: Trump said simply: ""They'll probably be different generals.""

column1: Trump stood by a previous comment that appeared to blame military sexual assaults on men and women serving together
column2: but added he would not seek to remove women from the military. And for the first time
column3: he opened the door to granting legal status to people living in the U.S. illegally who join the military.

column1: I think that when you serve in the armed forces
column2: that's a very special situation
column3: Trump said. ""And I could see myself working that out.""

column1: The Republican also repeated an incorrect claim that he was opposed to the war with Iraq before the invasion. That assertion is contradicted by an interview Trump did with Howard Stern in September 2002 in which he was asked whether he supported the invasion. He replied
column2: ""Yeah
column3: I guess so.""

column1: With just two months until Election Day
column2: national security has emerged as a centerpiece issue in the White House race. Both candidates believe they have the upper hand
column3: with Clinton contrasting her experience with Trump's unpredictability and the Republican arguing that Americans worried about their safety will be left with more of the same if they elect Obama's former secretary of State.

column1: This event – and the upcoming presidential debates – could be particularly important in the closing days of this election. As The Christian Science Monitor reports
column2: this year an unusually large percentage of the electorate says it hasn’t made up its mind
column3: or will vote for a third-party candidate. That’s a big chunk of folks who might swing in one way or another when the pressure of choosing on Election Day actually nears.

column1: For instance
column2: Wall Street Journal/NBC polling shows 13 percent of voters undecided in 2016. The corresponding figure from this time in 2012 was 8 percent.

column1: “We are seeing a historically high number of potential voters who aren’t committing to either major party candidate at this point
column2: ” writes Middlebury College political science professor Matthew Dickinson on his“Presidential Power” blog.

column1: While GOP candidates are often seen by voters as having an advantage on military and national security issues
column2: Trump is far from a traditional Republican. He has no military experience and has repeatedly criticized the skill of the armed forces.

column1: A flood of Republican national security experts have instead chosen to back Clinton
column2: helping bolster her case that Trump is broadly unacceptable. Earlier Wednesday
column3: former Defense Secretary William Cohen joined the list of GOP officials supporting Clinton.

column1: Ahead of the forum
column2: Trump rolled out a new plan to boost military spending by tens of billions of dollars
column3: including major increases in the number of active troops
column4: fighter planes
column5: ships and submarines.

column1: His address earlier in the day included plans to eliminate deep spending cuts known as the ""sequester"" that were enacted when Congress failed to reach a budget compromise in 2011. Republicans and Democrats voted for the automatic
column2: across-the board cuts that affected both military and domestic programs
column3: though the White House has long pressed Congress to lift the spending limits.

column1: Trump expressed support for the sequester in interviews in 2013 — even describing them as too small — but seemed to suggest at the time that military spending should be exempt.
Associated Press writers Jill Colvin and Erica Werner in Washington and Jonathan Lemire in New York contributed to this report."	REAL

column174: and was instrumental in waging a terror war against Nicaragua by employing drug-running mercenary terrorists called “Contras.” When the Church Committee investigated the agency in the mid-70s
column175: lots of dirty laundry was aired. The agency was reined in for a time. Assassination was made technically illegal. In the 1980s
column176: the CIA fought a proxy war against the Soviet Union in Afghanistan by funneling money and arms to radical Islamic Jihadists – like Osama bin Laden – and creating an intelligence/military monster in Pakistan
column177: known as the ISI. With untold billions of dollars of US tax money
column179: the Pakistanis were propped up as a central hub for militant groups to operate throughout the region. Pakistan is where Osama bin Laden allegedly ended up living for the last decade of his life
column180: half a mile from the Pakistani military academy. The CIA today is instrumental in the blitzkrieg of terror across Syria. It funnels arms and money to radical Islamic Jihadists

column1: The immigration swamp	"“This was not a subject that was on anybody’s mind until I brought it up at my announcement.”
Not on anyone’s mind? For years
column2: immigration has been the subject of near-constant
column3: often bitter argument within the GOP. But it is true that Trump has brought the debate to a new place — first
column4: with his announcement speech
column5: about whether Mexican migrants are really rapists
column6: and now with the somewhat more nuanced Trump plan.

column1: Much of it — visa tracking
column2: E-Verify
column3: withholding funds from sanctuary cities — predates Trump. Even building the Great Wall is not particularly new. (I
column4: for one
column5: have been advocating that in this space since 2006.) Dominating the discussion
column6: however
column7: are his two policy innovations: (a) abolition of birthright citizenship and (b) mass deportation.

column1: If you are born in the United States
column2: you are an American citizen. So says the 14th Amendment. Barring some esoteric and radically new jurisprudence
column3: abolition would require amending the Constitution. Which would take years and great political effort. And make the GOP anathema to Hispanic Americans for a generation.

column1: And for what? Birthright citizenship is a symptom
column2: not a cause. If you regain control of the border
column3: the number of birthright babies fades to insignificance. The time and energy it would take to amend the Constitution are far more usefully deployed securing the border.

column1: Moreover
column2: the real issue is not the birthright babies themselves
column3: but the chain migration that follows. It turns one baby into an imported village.

column1: Chain migration
column2: however
column3: is not a constitutional right. It’s a result of statutes and regulations. These can be readily changed. That should be the focus
column4: not a quixotic constitutional battle.

column1: Last Sunday
column2: Trump told NBC’s Chuck Todd that all illegal immigrants must leave the country. Although once they’ve been kicked out
column3: we will let “the good ones” back in.

column1: On its own terms
column2: this is crackpot. Wouldn’t you save a lot just on Mayflower moving costs if you chose the “good ones” first — before sending SWAT teams to turf families out of their homes
column3: loading them on buses and dumping them on the other side of the Rio Grande?

column1: Less frivolously
column2: it is estimated by the conservative American Action Forum that mass deportation would take about 20 years and cost about $500 billion for all the police
column3: judges
column4: lawyers and enforcement agents — and bus drivers! — needed to expel 11 million people.

column1: This would all be merely ridiculous if it weren’t morally obscene. Forcibly evict 11 million people from their homes? It can’t happen. It shouldn’t happen. And
column2: of course
column3: it won’t ever happen. But because it’s the view of the Republican front-runner
column4: every other candidate is now required to react. So instead of debating border security
column5: guest-worker programs and sanctuary cities — where Republicans are on firm moral and political ground — they are forced into a debate about a repulsive fantasy.

column1: Which
column2: for the Republican Party
column3: is also political poison. Mitt Romney lost the Hispanic vote by 44 points and he was advocating only self-deportation. Now the party is discussing forced deportation.

column1: It is not just Hispanics who will be alienated. Romney lost the Asian vote
column2: too. By 47 points. And many non-minorities will be offended by the idea of rounding up 11 million people
column3: the vast majority of whom are law-abiding members of their communities.

column1: Donald Trump has every right to advance his ideas. He is not to be begrudged his masterly showmanship
column2: his relentless candor or his polling success. I strongly oppose the idea of ostracizing anyone from the GOP or the conservative movement. On whose authority? Let the people decide.

column1: But that is not to say that he should be exempt from normal scrutiny or from consideration of the effect of his candidacy on conservatism’s future. If you are a conservative alarmed at the country’s direction and committed to retaking the White House
column2: you should be concerned about what Trump’s ascendancy is doing to the chances of that happening.

column1: The Democrats’ presumptive candidate is flailing badly. Republicans have an unusually talented field with a good chance of winning back the presidency. Do they really want to be dragged into the swamps — right now
column2: on immigration — that will make that prospect electorally impossible?

column1: Yes
column2: I understand. The anger
column3: the frustration
column4: etc.
column5: etc.
column6: that Trump is channeling. But how are these alleviated by yelling “I’m mad as hell” — and proceeding to elect Hillary Clinton?

column1: Read more from Charles Krauthammer’s archive
column2: follow him on Twitter or subscribe to his updates on Facebook."	REAL

column1: Blame government, not markets for monopoly	"Blame government
column2: not markets for monopoly Corporate mergers and “hostile” takeovers can promote economic efficiency By Ron Paul - November 1

column1: When Time-Warner announced it planned to merge with another major communications firm
column2: many feared the new company would exercise near-total monopoly power. These concerns led some to call for government action to block the merger in order to protect both Time-Warner’s competitors and consumers.

column1: No
column2: I am not talking about Time-Warner’s recent announced plan to merge with AT&T
column3: but the reaction to Time-Warner’s merger with (then) Internet giant AOL in 2000. Far from creating an untouchable leviathan crushing all competitors
column4: the AOL-Time-Warner merger fell apart in under a decade.

column1: The failure of AOL-Time-Warner demonstrates that even the biggest companies are vulnerable to competition if there is open entry into the marketplace. AOL-Time-Warner failed because consumers left them for competitors offering lower prices and/or better quality.

Corporate mergers and “hostile” takeovers can promote economic efficiency by removing inefficient management and boards of directors. These managers and board members often work together to promote their own interests instead of generating maximum returns for investors by providing consumers with affordable
column2: quality products. Thus
column3: laws making it difficult to launch a “hostile” takeover promote inefficient use of resources and harm investors
column4: workers
column5: and consumers.

column1: Monopolies and cartels are creations of government
column2: not markets. For example
column3: the reason the media is dominated by a few large companies is that no one can operate a television or radio station unless they obtain federal approval and pay federal licensing fees. Similarly
column4: anyone wishing to operate a cable company must not only comply with federal regulations
column5: they must sign a “franchise” agreement with their local government. Fortunately
column6: the Internet has given Americans greater access to news and ideas shut out by the government-licensed lapdogs of the “mainstream” media. This may be why so many politicians are anxious to regulate the web.

column1: Government taxes and regulations are effective means of limiting competition in an industry. Large companies can afford the costs of complying with government regulations
column2: costs which cripple their smaller competitors. Big business can also afford to hire lobbyists to ensure that new laws and regulations favor big business.

column1: Examples of regulations that benefit large corporations include the Food and Drug Administration’s (FDA) regulations that raise costs of developing a new drug
column2: as well as limit consumers ability to learn about natural alternatives to pharmaceuticals. Another example is the Dodd-Frank legislation
column3: which has strengthened large financial intuitions while harming their weaker competitors.

column1: Legislation forcing consumers to pay out-of-state sales tax on their online purchases is a classic case of business seeking to use government to harm less politically-powerful competitors. This legislation is being pushed by large brick-and-mortar stores and Internet retailers who are seeking a government-granted advantage over smaller competitors.

Many failed mergers and acquisitions result from the distorted signals sent to business and investors by the Federal Reserve’s inflationary monetary policy. Perhaps the most famous example of this is the AOL-Time-Warner fiasco
column2: which was a direct result of the Fed-created dot.com bubble.

column1: In a free market
column2: mergers between businesses enable consumers to benefit from new products and reduced prices. Any businesses that charge high prices or offer substandard products will soon face competition from businesses offering consumers lower prices and/or higher quality. Monopolies only exist when government tilts the playing field in favor of well-connected crony capitalists. Therefore those concerned about excessive corporate power should join supporters of the free market in repudiating the regulations
column3: taxes
column4: and subsides that benefit politically-powerful businesses. The most important step is to end the boom-bust business cycle by ending the Federal Reserve."	FAKE

column1: 'America is already strong': Obama continues Democrats' optimism	"President Obama offered enthusiastic support for Hillary Clinton at the Democratic National Convention Wednesday as he painted a hopeful picture of the country.
U.S. President Barack Obama (L) and Democratic presidential candidate Hillary Clinton wave to the crowd after the president spoke at the Democratic National Convention in Philadelphia
column2: Penn.
column3: on July 27

column1: President Obama described an optimistic
column2: hopeful picture of America in a speech Wednesday night at the Democratic National Convention
column3: pointedly diverging from the more foreboding tone of the previous week's Republican event.

column1: Mr. Obama offered an enthusiastic endorsement of Hillary Clinton
column2: saying “nobody [is] more qualified” to be president
column3: and galvanized delegates at the convention in Philadelphia by drawing a sharp contrast with the dark portrait of the country described by Republican nominee Donald Trump.

column1: I am more optimistic about the future of America than ever before
column2: Obama said as delegates cheered at the Wells Fargo Center. ""America is already great. America is already strong
column3: he said
column4: referring to Mr. Trump's promise to ""make America great again.""

column1: And I promise you
column2: our strength
column3: our greatness
column4: does not depend on Donald Trump
column5: the president added.

column1: As Mrs. Clinton
column2: formerly secretary of State and first lady
column3: became the first woman to gain the presidential nomination of a major party on Tuesday
column4: a sense of looking forward to the future emerged as a theme of the party's convention: largely hopeful
column5: but with sharp criticism of a potential Trump administration.

column1: Our convention is going to be optimistic
column2: it’s going to be hopeful
column3: and it’s going to be talking about specific plans
column4: Clinton campaign manager Robby Mook told reporters Monday morning. As The Christian Science Monitor’s Amanda Paulson reports:

column1: And so far
column2: that’s largely been the case
column3: even down to the signs distributed for delegates to wave on the floor: “Love Trumps Hate.” “Stronger Together.” “Rise Together.” If Trump titled his book “Crippled America” and declared himself the “law-and-order candidate
column4: ” the only one who can fix a rigged system and “make America great again
column5: ” the themes echoed by speaker after speaker in Philadelphia have been ones of togetherness
column6: diversity
column7: and an emphasis on American values of inclusion rather than a need to close off borders.

column1: But despite the optimism evoked by many speakers
column2: including first lady Michelle Obama and Sen. Cory Booker of New Jersey
column3: Democrats could face an uphill battle. Trump’s narrative of an America divided along class and racial lines
column4: and his accusations that the system is “rigged” against people still struggling economically
column5: tap into many Americans' growing sense of distrust
column6: particularly of political leaders in Washington.

column1: Trump’s message also reveals a divide on optimism that exists along both partisan and racial lines
column2: Ms. Paulson notes. A poll conducted by the Atlantic and the Aspen Institute last year found that less than half of white Americans believe the country’s “best days” lie ahead of it
column3: compared to about 80 percent of African Americans
column4: she writes.

column1: On Twitter
column2: Trump waved off Obama's depiction of the country.

column1: On the convention’s third day
column2: many speakers focused on Trump’s own record
column3: with vice presidential nominee Tim Kaine noting the businessman’s lack of political experience
column4: calling him “a one-man wrecking crew” who could not be trusted in the White House.

column1: Attention now turns to whether Clinton
column2: who is set to speak on the convention’s final day Thursday
column3: can make a convincing argument for staking out her own path while also delivering on promises to continue Obama’s legacy
column4: the Associated Press reported.

column1: She has focused on addressing income inequality
column2: student debt
column3: tightening gun control and reigning in Wall Street
column4: seeking to woo supporters of Sen. Bernie Sanders
column5: who mounted a strong challenge to Clinton by focusing particularly on a sense that many Americans are struggling economically. On Monday
column6: Senator Sanders offered an enthusiastic endorsement of Clinton
column7: saying he was ""proud to stand with her.""

column1: Some Clinton delegates say the Democrats’ optimism also offers a counterbalance to Trump’s focus on looking backward.
“I think there are solutions
column2: moving forward solutions
column3: and I don’t want to go back to the 1950s
column4: thank you very much
column5: ” Bear Atwood
column6: a lawyer from Mississippi
column7: told the Monitor earlier this week. “Where’s the perfect moment? I think it’s ahead of us.""

column1: This article includes material from Reuters and the Associated Press."	REAL

Why the DNC's mysteriously hacked oppo file on Trump is a big yawn	"First we were told that a Russian hacker had broken into the Democratic National Committee’s computers and gotten hold of its oppo file on Donald Trump.
Now someone who goes by 'Guccifer 2.0
column2: ' a nod to the shadowy Romanian hacker
column3: is claiming credit for putting the Trump file out there. Gawker and the Smoking Gun both published the report yesterday.

column1: But what I find so amusing is that the opposition research file is hardly filled with secret stuff
column2: the product of private eyes digging up dirt or hired-gun sleuths poring over documents. This supposed treasure trove
column3: submitted in December
column4: consists mainly of published articles and televised segments.

column1: In other words
column2: it’s all out there. You can Google it. Any reasonably sentient media consumer would know this stuff. It’s what we in the journalism racket call a clip job.

column1: “Trump is Loyal only to Himself.”
“Trump’s Business Have Gone into Bankruptcy Several Times.”
“He Has Devalued and Demeaned Women Repeatedly Throughout His Career.”
“Out of Touch/Hand-Outs for the Wealthy at the Expense of the Middle Class.”
And the sources? Wall Street Journal
column2: AP
column3: Politico
column4: Washington Post
column5: Forbes
column6: etc.

column1: Trump
column2: for his part
column3: isn’t buying the DNC explanation that this is the work of some nefarious outside hacker. “Much of it is false and/or entirely inaccurate
column4: ” he says in a statement. “We believe it was the DNC that did the ‘hacking’ as a way to distract from the many issues facing their deeply flawed candidate and failed party leader. Too bad the DNC doesn’t hack Crooked Hillary’s 33
column5: 000 missing emails.”

column1: Now that sounds far-fetched as well. Not only is there nothing new here
column2: but no one can absorb 200 pages at once. Why not dribble out the attacks
column3: package them as talking points
column4: put them in attack ads
column5: rather than create a bogus hacking story and dump it all out there? Or dress it up with some narrative and release it as a report?

column1: What we have here
column2: whether it was done by Guccifer 2.0 or whoever
column3: is a 21st-century Watergate. Instead of burglars breaking into DNC headquarters
column4: a crime that led to the downfall of Richard Nixon’s presidency
column5: we have cyberwarfare against DNC computers
column6: only aimed at the de facto Republican nominee
column7: and winding up in the now-bankrupt
column8: sex-tape-publishing Gawker rather than the Washington Post.

column1: Simply vacuuming up negative material on a candidate doesn’t work in today’s cluttered media environment. Trump has been awash in negative media reports since he got into the race one year ago. The trick to getting traction is by packaging some of the stuff in a way that it sticks—as the Democrats successfully did to Mitt Romney
column2: and the Republicans to John Kerry.

column1: Instead
column2: the oppo file itself has become news—in a fleeting way that guarantees it will quickly become non-news.

column1: Howard Kurtz is a Fox News analyst and the host of ""MediaBuzz"" (Sundays 11 a.m. and 5 p.m. ET). He is the author of five books and is based in Washington. Follow him at @HowardKurtz. Click here for more information on Howard Kurtz."	REAL
Hillary Clinton: ‘No role whatsoever for American soldiers on the ground’ in Iraq	"HAMPTON
column2: N.H. -- Hillary Rodham Clinton said Friday that she sees ""no role whatsoever for American soldiers on the ground to go back"" to Iraq as the Islamic State terrorist group makes gains.

column1: The remarks by Clinton -- who has disavowed her own 2003 vote for the Iraq war as a senator -- come amid growing fervor among Republicans to send ground forces back to Iraq in some capacity to assist the Baghdad government in its battle with Islamic State
column2: which earlier this week overran the city of Ramadi.

column1: The Democratic front-runner made her comments during a brief news conference here at a brewery following a roundtable discussion with small-business leaders.
I think it's a very difficult situation and I basically agree with the policies that we are currently following
column2: Clinton said. ""And that is
column3: American air support is available. American intelligence and surveillance is available. American trainers are trying to undo the damage that was done to the Iraqi army by former prime minister Maliki
column4: who bears a very big part of the responsibility for what is happening inside of Iraq today.""

column1: But she said ""this has to be fought by and won by Iraqis. There is no role whatsoever for American soldiers on the ground to go back
column2: other than in the capacity as trainers and advisers.""

column1: The large field of Republicans vying for the 2016 nomination has set a hawkish tone and all have called on the United States to do more in Iraq
column2: with varying degrees of specificity. Sen. Lindsey Graham (R-S.C.)
column3: who is running mostly on national security issues
column4: has called for sending 10
column5: 000 U.S. troops into the country
column6: and others -- including former Texas governor Rick Perry and pediatric neurosurgeon Ben Carson have advocated for an unspecified number."	REAL

column1: Donald Trump: The key to his success (Opinion)	"It seems almost quaint
column2: really
column3: to go back to the start of this presidential campaign when the question du jour was whether Chris ""just-sit-down-and-shut-up"" Christie was too much of a bully to become president. Temperament
column4: it seems
column5: was a requirement.

column1: Or even go back to Hillary Clinton's 2008 derision of Barack Obama as not ready to be president and take that 3 a.m. phone call about a national security crisis. Experience and depth of knowledge was also an issue.
But that's ancient history. Somehow
column2: the notions of temperament and experience have been overtaken by the desire -- at least according to the polls so far in the GOP race -- for what passes as a show of strength
column3: unbound by convention and unattached to complexity. Donald Trump
column4: the undisputed frontrunner
column5: reigns supreme
column6: no matter what the half-formed solutions. As in: Muslims are trying to kill us
column7: so let's keep them out. Illegal immigrants are ""raping"" and taking our jobs
column8: so let's keep them out. Civility -- now called political correctness -- is ruining our national conversation
column9: so let's abandon it.

column1: The cliché is that presidential elections are about change
column2: and that's true. Only this one may be about sea-change.

column1: This is not something that comes from nowhere
column2: out of the blue. Americans are
column3: with good reason
column4: truly afraid. According to our CNN polling
column5: nearly two thirds believe an act of terrorism is likely in the homeland -- and that poll was taken before the carnage of San Bernardino. Eighty-one percent are convinced that the terrorists are here
column6: living among us -- a completely rational conclusion.

column1: Even more important -- and here's the key to Donald Trump's kingdom -- voters believe the political system
column2: including (and maybe most of all) the President
column3: have completely and utterly failed to get a handle on
column4: or even appear to have a strategy for
column5: security. And why would anybody blame anyone for thinking that? Sixty-eight percent say America's response to ISIS has not been tough enough
column6: and a slightly smaller number say that when we do take action (in Iraq and Syria
column7: ) we fail. And that's not just among Republicans: Majorities in both parties say the United States has been ineffective in its response to the terror threat. This is not a new storyline. So this particular election-year story has all of the following: Disaffected and frustrated voters. Ineffective president. A level of public fear that has been rising steadily for at least a handful of years. Throw in anger at the collapsing political system
column8: the establishment and the media
column9: and Trump appears onstage like a vision emerging out of the clouds: the dark knight of our politics. Donald Trump is no fool. He's an experienced opportunist. He knows full well that he has stepped into a leadership vacuum that exists in American politics
column10: and has been around for some time: Why should the American public have any respect at all for its institutions when they have been failing? When Congress can't legislate
column11: or even behave? When the President -- elected with such high hopes -- fails to inspire or connect or even explain strategy? When others running for president often look like they're made of the same torn fabric
column12: just with different holes? Trump flouts the conventions
column13: and plays to fears. But for now
column14: at least
column15: it doesn't matter. In a large field of GOP candidates
column16: Trump's solid core of support among one-third of Republicans -- a minority -- is enough to keep him on top
column17: and any Republican running would like to have his numbers. His latest gambit -- a vague proposal to keep Muslims out of the country until ""our country's representatives can figure out what's going on"" is pure bombast
column18: delivered to rally the faithful -- and he'll probably get a bump in the polls out of it. Jeb Bush calls it ""unhinged."" His fellow Republicans also punch at it
column19: to varying degrees. But
column20: for now at least
column21: they're just punching jello. And hoping he doesn't break the mold."	REAL

column1: For First Time, Trump Shrinks In Spotlight; Fiorina Steals Show	"For First Time
column2: Trump Shrinks In Spotlight; Fiorina Steals Show

column1: Donald Trump was once again at center stage at Wednesday night's debate hosted by CNN — the second debate among the GOP candidates for president This time
column2: however
column3: he had a harder time holding the spotlight.

column1: Again and again throughout the seemingly interminable three-hour spectacle
column2: the attention of the audience migrated to the the smallest figure on the set: Carly Fiorina.

column1: It could be lost on no one that Fiorina was the only woman in the cast of 11 hopefuls
column2: nor that she had been admitted to the group only after CNN altered its original rules to take note of her recent surge in the polls. Even with this upgrade
column3: propelled by her standout performance in the August debate among the lesser candidates
column4: Fiorina has been languishing in the low single digits in most national polls.

column1: That could be about to change. Any leveling off in Trump's astonishing trajectory will create a need for new storylines
column2: and Fiorina seems poised to provide.

column1: The other outsider phenomenon
column2: Ben Carson
column3: did not shine as brightly in the CNN event as he had on Fox in August. Soft-spoken and mild-mannered
column4: the neurosurgeon disagreed with Trump about vaccines and autism but shied from any real conflict with him on the issue. At other times he seemed vague in explaining his 2003 Iraq War position and his willingness to de-emphasize armed conflict.

column1: Fiorina
column2: however
column3: was a picture of decisiveness and to-the-point presentation. Like the consummate sales professional she is
column4: Fiorina came armed with pithy
column5: precise answers. She had neatly anticipated nearly all the questions thrown her way — including the ones she seized in the general scramble for air and camera time.

column1: She was ready with the exact dimensions of the larger military she wanted
column2: and the specifics of rebuttal to attacks on her stewardship of Hewlett-Packard. Trump made repeated
column3: rather clumsy thrusts at Fiorina's executive history. She whipped them back at him with replies that cracked in the air.

column1: The Trump show in general did not seem as dominating as in the first debate
column2: or in the many news cycles since
column3: when anything and everything he said made headlines. Wags soon dubbed the night ""Lady and the Trump
column4: but that was not the whole story
column5: either.

column1: Trump was also set upon by a pack of his opponents
column2: several of whom seemed to have boned up on his history of casino bankruptcies. He fended these off with breezy references to the way business works
column3: but these did not seem to be working as well as in the past. Jeb Bush
column4: though still a bit ill at ease
column5: made his arguments with dignity and seriousness and jousted in his own restrained way with Trump (as well as with Rand Paul and others).

column1: Much has been written and said about Trump's capturing the imagination of the white
column2: older
column3: working-class voters within the Republican electorate. This he has done
column4: but not by himself. He has had an assist from the wide-eyed media
column5: promoting the ""Summer of Trump"" with wonder and hunger for more. At times
column6: on this night
column7: there were signs that this dynamic was losing some of its energy
column8: that the shtick might be beginning to wear thin.

column1: This impression crept in despite the effects of the CNN debate format
column2: which allowed any candidate mentioned by name to respond to that mention. As most of the candidates were
column3: in varying degrees
column4: gunning for Trump
column5: moderator Jake Tapper was continually turning to The Donald for replies. Intended or not
column6: this device kept the billionaire the center of attention even when Tapper was trying to distribute the airtime more equitably.

column1: Still
column2: there was more than enough running room for Marco Rubio and Ted Cruz. The senators from Florida and Texas fired the broadsides against both the Obama administration and the masters of the Senate that have been their stock-in-trade since the Tea Party movement first sent them to Washington.

column1: Both did well at connecting with hardcore conservatives who agree the GOP leaders in Congress are useless. Rubio did so with more human appeal
column2: however
column3: using his remarkably empathetic facial appeal. Cruz seemed intent on softening his image
column4: tossing verbal bouquets to his wife and his parents.

column1: Chris Christie also seemed to thrive in the mix on this occasion. This in part because he interrupted the Trump-Fiorina fussing over who had done what in business. ""The 55-year-old construction worker who's out of a job doesn't care about your careers
column2: Christie scolded. And he reinforced the point in an eloquent closing statement about refocusing national policy to benefit ordinary Americans.

column1: John Kasich
column2: the governor of Ohio
column3: once again offered a mix of high-level resume and aw-shucks Americana
column4: tossing out more numbers than any of his data-happy rivals but still managing to be more boyish than wonkish. Kasich surely has the credentials to be legitimate in this race
column5: but he remains the credential candidate in an anti-establishment and even anti-credential year.

column1: Among those getting the short end of the attention supply was Scott Walker
column2: the governor of Wisconsin. Walker had his lines down as well as anyone
column3: but they all seemed to go back to Madison in 2011 and the massive protests against his first budget. Walker has raised eyebrows in the past by saying his facedown of these protests proved he could tame ISIS
column4: Vladimir Putin and the ayatollahs of Iran. But he was back on that theme again Wednesday night.

column1: Rand Paul provided multiple moments of dissent
column2: opposing not only the Iraq War of 2003 but also the proposals to intervene in the Middle East today. Mike Huckabee was reliable on the issue of religious liberty
column3: which he defined as including the right of Kentucky county clerk Kim Davis to defy the Supreme Court and deny marriage licenses to same-sex couples.

column1: One final note about the ""happy hour"" debate that preceded the main event. Both Louisiana Gov. Bobby Jindal and Sen. Lindsey Graham of South Carolina turned in sharp performances
column2: with Jindal stressing harsh anti-Obama rhetoric and Graham a grim assessment of threats to national security — replete with a pledge to return more ""boots on the ground"" to the Middle East. The difference was that Graham mixed in a strong dose of sly Carolina humor
column3: eliciting chuckles and even guffaws for things like a pledge to have ""more drinking"" in Washington.

column1: As the Fiorina promotion this time around proved so worthwhile
column2: perhaps in the future the GOP and sponsoring media will see fit to elevate the unofficial winner of each ""undercard debate"" to participate in the main event in the next round. It could become a kind of tradition. Provided of course that the undercard debate survives another round in this campaign."	REAL

column1: Black Lives Matter and the TPP
And now the TPP has become even more toxic
column2: since the Black Lives Matter (BLM) social-justice movement has endorsed the anti-TPP position. Politico Pro has this (sub. required; my emphasis):

column1: Obama’s latest TPP foe: Black Lives Matter By Andrew Hanna Monday
column2: Oct. 31

column1: The Obama administration will face an unexpected adversary as it gears up for what could be a blockbuster lame-duck fight over the Trans-Pacific Partnership: the Black Lives Matter movement.
The group — best known best for its protests of police shootings of African-Americans — has joined the fray over the Asian Pacific trade deal as part of its growing focus on economic issues
column2: contending the pact would lead to greater racial injustice . It ties past trade deals to the closures of factories that have hurt black workers disproportionately and increased black poverty .

column1: Its involvement could influence the votes of a handful of wavering Democrats
column2: should Congress tackle TPP during the lame duck.

column1: “There are groups that are going to pay a lot of close attention to what they say
column2: especially the Congressional Black Caucus
column3: ” said Bill Reinsch
column4: a fellow at the Stimson Center and close trade-vote watcher.

column1: Only a small band of 28 House Democrats voted to give the president fast track authority to complete TPP
column2: including three members of the Congressional Black Caucus: Reps. Gregory Meeks (D-N.Y.)
column3: Eddie Bernice Johnson (D-Texas) and Terri Sewell (D-Ala.). A fourth black caucus member
column4: Republican Mia Love of Utah
column5: also voted for fast-track authority.

column1: With anti-trade fervor whipped into a fever pitch by the presidential election campaign
column2: their votes are considered key to passage of the pact — and all are under increasing pressure to abandon the president should the pact come to a ratification vote.

column1: The pretend reason
column2: of course
column3: for TPP support is support for a major legacy “want” by the first black president. The pro-Clinton members of the Democratic Platform Committee
column4: for example
column5: resisted to the end any explicit language about TPP on the grounds that the Party must support its president.

column1: Democrats Prioritize Party Unity Over Including Stand Against TPP In Platform
Members of the Democratic National Convention Platform Committee shot down an attempt to include specific opposition to the Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP) trade deal in the platform
column2: despite the fact that both Democratic presidential candidates have taken positions against the TPP.

column1: The attempt failed because members appointed by Hillary Clinton and DNC Chairwoman Debbie Wasserman Schultz claimed it was improper to oppose the TPP when President Barack Obama fervently believes in the agreement. However
column2: by putting party unity before taking a firm stand against the trade agreement
column3: the door was left open for Clinton to go back to supporting the TPP
column4: which was the case when she was secretary of state.

column1: “It is hard for me to understand why Secretary Clinton’s delegates won’t stand behind Secretary Clinton’s positions in the party’s platform
column2: ” Democratic presidential candidate Bernie Sanders said….

column1: Even platform committee chair
column2: Representative E.J. Cummings [normally progressive on trade issues]
column3: chose to vote against the resolution. He
column4: too
column5: bragged about not voting for trade agreements.

column1: “I don’t want to do anything as he ends his term to undercut the president of the United States. I’m just not going to do it. And that’s where I stand
column2: ” Cummings proclaimed.

column1: That’s the pretend reason — supporting the first black president — for most of them anyway. The real reason is different and not unexpected — money and everything money can buy. The Democratic Party as it’s currently configured exists to enable the fire hose flow of corporate and big-wealth dollars into its coffers. Opposing that flow gets you the “Sanders treatment
column2: ” but I’m not spilling any new beans in saying that.

column1: This move by Black Lives Matter takes away the pretend reason and thus puts some careers at risk. BLM has high visibility at the moment. It will be worth watching the result
column2: the actual TPP vote
column3: as this plays out later.

column1: What to Watch For in the Lame Duck
Once the Democrats figure out how many Republicans will defect from their leadership in each house of Congress (there were 50 House Republican defections last time plus six not voting
column2: and five Senate defections plus two not voting)
column3: they’ll know how many Democrats will have to “take one for the team” — vote Yes on TPP so others with reputations to protect (like Chuck Schumer and Nancy Pelosi ) don’t have to.

column1: The numbers needed to pass TPP in the Senate have changed this time. Only 51 votes are needed there now (that’s part of what “fast track” means). Finding 50 No votes in the Senate is not an impossible task
column2: but it’s a very high bar — depending on the way Republicans vote
column3: as few as four “Democrats” like Ron Wyden could guarantee passage.

column1: So the greatest vulnerability for TPP is in the House . Can Democrats again muster something like 28 pro-corporate votes? Which Democrats will chose to take the fall a second time? Corporatists like Ron Kind will eagerly comply. But will Earl Blumenauer ( bow-tie bicycle guy )? Will CBC members Sewell and Johnson
column2: with BLM lobbying hard against them? Or will other House Democrats be needed (and willing) to take the fall so Pelosi can move TPP across the line?

column1: Again
column2: Fast Track passed the House with zero votes to spare. What if the Republican opposition — including the opposition to Speaker Ryan in the wake of the Trump debacle — swells to more than 50? This could be a very close vote.

Pete Kimberley"	FAKE
Let’s Make 2016 the Last Endless American Election	"Enough Is Enough
If we really want to do something about the worst effects of our electoral process
column2: let’s start by simply having less of it.

column1: You might think that Hillary Clinton has been running for president for
column2: well
column3: ever — but technically she began her campaign on April 12th last year
column4: 18 months ago. Donald Trump launched his bid for the White House a more restrained 15 months ago. But if you want a real contrast
column5: cross the Atlantic. I once ran elections in the UK
column6: where the typical length of a campaign is not 18 or 15 months but four or five weeks.

column1: Look
column2: I get it about the constitution
column3: free speech and all that. Believe me: As a recent(ish) immigrant
column4: living in Silicon Valley
column5: having taught at Stanford and started a business here
column6: I have all the zeal of the convert. I truly think that America is the greatest nation on earth
column7: and I feel profoundly lucky to be able to be part of it.

column1: But can we just talk about the election process for a moment? Is there a single person in this country who feels better able to choose between Trump and Clinton today than a year ago? What have we learned about these candidates that we couldn’t have discovered over the course of the nine weeks since Labor Day? Nine weeks is double the length of a general election campaign in the UK. I’m not saying British democracy is perfect
column2: not by a long way. But at least the flaws aren’t inflicted on the population on a continuous basis.

column1: The most common thing I hear people saying about the election right now is “Please let it be over!” Of course
column2: you could argue that the reason is not so much the length of the process but the uniquely polarizing nature of the major party nominees this time
column3: and the fact that unusually
column4: they were both well-known to the American people before they even entered the race. If two relatively obscure candidates had been nominated
column5: perhaps the cries of pain from the public wouldn’t be quite as anguished.

column1: There’s more to this question
column2: though
column3: than familiarity with — or contempt for — any individual politician at any given time. The length of election campaigns in America causes real
column4: structural problems throughout our democratic system
column5: regardless of who the candidates are.

column1: First
column2: the relentless posturing involved in near-permanent campaigns contributes to the hyper-partisanship that makes reasonable debate on public policy issues increasingly difficult. An environment where any half-thoughtful comment can almost instantly find its way into an overnight online attack ad is one that incentivizes politicians to put ‘messaging’ ahead of problem-solving
column3: and that’s not good.

column1: For example
column2: I agree with Hillary Clinton’s emphasis on the importance of early intervention and parenting support as one of the best ways to tackle poverty and inequality. But if elected
column3: I expect her administration would approach this priority in a disastrously old-fashioned
column4: top-down
column5: bureaucratic way that would end in failure.

column1: No candidate of either party could say that: it’s too nuanced a position. With most members of Congress literally starting their next election campaign the day after this one has ended
column2: you won’t see any of them move beyond yelling platitudes like “nanny state” or “war on women.”

column1: For a start
column2: it means that it’s harder for people who are not wealthy to run for office. Who has the time and the resources to take two years off work to get elected? Rich people
column3: that’s who. It’s no surprise that the proportion of millionaires in Congress is at an all-time high.

column1: More than that
column2: the cost of lengthy political campaigns is a direct factor in the systemic corruption that is such a notable feature of American democracy. In fact
column3: if you look at what actually happens in Congress and in state legislatures
column4: it is difficult to argue that America is in any meaningful sense of the word a democracy at all. It is a donocracy
column5: where the funders of election campaigns literally buy the outcomes they want from the political system.

column1: Look too at the role of organized labor
column2: providing campaign infrastructure
column3: volunteers
column4: get out the vote operations. None of that would be touched by campaign finance reform. And then look what the unions get in return: in my home state of California
column5: budgets that increase compensation for corrections officers while cutting spending on public schools and state universities. Way to go
column6: progressives!

column1: The truth is that even if Clinton wins
column2: and by some miracle enacts some version of campaign finance reform
column3: the assorted lobbyists
column4: bloodsuckers
column5: sleazebags and other hangers-on in Washington DC will breathe a huge sigh of relief because they know that for them
column6: life in our nation’s capital will go on as corruptly as before.

column1: No
column2: if we really want to do something about the worst effects of our electoral process
column3: let’s start by simply having less of it. Think of it like pollution control: it doesn’t make the problem go away
column4: but it does make the world a bit less toxic. Radically shortening election campaigns is no more a silver bullet than changing the law on political donations. But it would make a big difference
column5: and has the advantage of being easier to implement."	REAL

Going Back to the Future in 2016?	"(CNN) Who among the nascent field of 2016 contenders represents the future? For half of Americans
column2: it's Hillary Clinton.

column1: Asked in a new CNN/ORC poll whether seven possible candidates better represent the future or the past
column2: 50% said Clinton evoked the future
column3: more than said so of any other candidate. By contrast
column4: Joe Biden and Jeb Bush
column5: whose names have been in the political conversation even longer than Clinton's
column6: were each seen as representing the past by 64% of Americans.

column1: Even some relative newcomers to national politics are more closely linked to the past than the future. Half said New Jersey Gov. Chris Christie represents the past
column2: while 43% said he represents the future. On Kentucky Sen. Rand Paul
column3: 49% thought he represented the past
column4: 41% the future. And 42% thought Wisconsin Gov. Scott Walker represented the past
column5: 39% the future.

column1: Overall
column2: across the field of seven
column3: just two were deemed more ""future"" than ""past
column4: and both were women: Clinton (50% future
column5: 48% past) and Massachusetts Sen. Elizabeth Warren (46% future
column6: 37% past).

column1: Both Clinton and Warren prompt significant gender gaps
column2: with women more likely than men to call each a representation of the future. Among men
column3: 53% see Clinton as a representation of the past
column4: while 55% of women see her representing the future. On Warren
column5: women see her as more future than past by a 50% to 32% margin
column6: while men split evenly
column7: 43% on each side.

column1: Democrats generally see their own possible presidential contenders as representative of the future. Among Democrats and Democratic-leaning independents
column2: 74% called Clinton a candidate who represents the future
column3: 61% said so of Warren and 51% of Biden.

column1: Last month
column2: Mitt Romney bowed out of the presidential race with a nod to his party's future
column3: saying he hoped ""one of our next generation of Republican leaders
column4: one who may not be as well-known as I am today"" would wind up better prepared to beat the eventual Democratic candidate.

column1: But Republicans don't see the field as particularly future-oriented. Of the four Republican candidates tested
column2: a majority of Republicans and Republican-leaning independents rated two of them as more representative of the future than the past
column3: Walker (55%) and Paul (53%). Fewer saw Christie (49%) or Bush (47%) that way.

column1: Walker gained ground among Republicans in the race for the party's presidential nomination
column2: the poll showed
column3: while Christie and Bush both faltered. The shuffling field also saw a double-digit gain in support for former Arkansas Gov. Mike Huckabee
column4: who now tops the field with 16%. The national survey found Huckabee closely followed by Bush at 14% (down 9 points)
column5: Walker at 11% (up 7 points) and Paul at 10%. Ben Carson lands in fifth with 8% and Chris Christie at sixth with 7% (down 6 points). No other candidate tops 5%.

column1: Walker's gains are concentrated among older voters. He leads the field among those age 65 or up with 22%. Among Republicans under 50
column2: Huckabee and Paul fare better than they do among their 65 and over counterparts.

column1: Among conservative Republicans
column2: it's a three-way tie: 15% each say they'd be most likely to support Bush
column3: Huckabee and Walker
column4: with 10% each behind Carson and Paul.

column1: The poll finds less change on the Democratic side. Clinton still leads the field with 61%. Her next closest competitor
column2: Biden
column3: has gained six points since December and stands at 14%. Warren follows at 10%. Vermont Sen. Bernie Sanders
column4: former Virginia Sen. Jim Webb and former Maryland Gov. Martin O'Malley all remain in the low single digits.

column1: As overseas turmoil riles President Barack Obama's approval ratings for handling foreign affairs
column2: terrorism now joins the economy at the top of voters' priority lists as the 2016 contest kicks off. Forty-two percent called terrorism an extremely important issue in their presidential vote
column3: on par with the 41% calling the economy that important. Education (40% extremely important) and health care (39% extremely important) also rank near the top.

column1: Sharp partisan divides in priorities emerge outside the economy and health care. On terrorism
column2: 87% of Republicans and Republican-leaning independents say it's extremely or very important
column3: compared with 78% of Democrats and Democratic-leaning independents. Republicans are more likely than Democrats to call illegal immigration an important issue (74% among Republicans vs. 55% among Democrats)
column4: while Democrats are more apt to prioritize the income gap (75% among Democrats vs. 45% among Republicans) and global warming (63% among Democrats vs. 23% of Republicans).

column1: The CNN/ORC International poll was conducted February 12-15
column3: and interviewed 1
column4: 027 adult Americans
column5: including 436 Republicans and independents who describe themselves as Republican
column6: and 475 Democrats and independents who describe themselves as Democrats. Results for all adults have a margin of sampling error of plus or minus 3 points. For results among Republicans or Democrats
column7: it is 4.5 points."	REAL

column1: A bad night for front-runners and a good night for governors	"It was a tough night for front-runners in New Hampshire and a good night for governors.
Marco Rubio hit a wall named Chris Christie. Donald Trump couldn’t put down an aggressive Jeb Bush. And Ted Cruz had to issue a public apology to Ben Carson.
Christie was the relentless prosecutor. Bush was knowledgeable and
column2: in contrast to some earlier performances
column3: tough and direct. Ohio Gov. John Kasich carved out space as a candidate ready and willing to work across party lines.

column1: Given the timing and the state of the Republican nomination contest
column2: few debates have had the potential to shape the order of finish in a primary campaign more than Saturday night’s forum at Saint Anselm College. Trump holds a big lead. But the competition underneath him is fierce
column3: and the outcome Tuesday likely to be consequential. Those with the most to lose were the ones who tried to make the most out of their time on stage.

column1: No one had a rockier night than Rubio
column2: the senator from Florida whose strong third-place finish in Iowa made him the candidate on the rise in the Republican presidential race. But under a blistering attack from Christie
column3: who characterized him as a politician with no notable accomplishments who had run away from the immigration reform bill he had co-sponsored
column4: Rubio faltered.

column1: Rubio knew the attacks were coming
column2: but instead of answering them directly
column3: he sought to change the subject. Once
column4: twice
column5: three times he offered a quick counterpunch and then slid off the criticisms to turn to an attack on President Obama
column6: repeating his language almost word for word and drawing boos from the audience.

column1: When he accused Christie of having to be shamed into going back to New Jersey to deal with the recent snowstorm
column2: Christie came roaring back. “That’s what Washington
column3: D.C.
column4: does
column5: ” Christie said. “The drive-by shot at the beginning with incorrect and incomplete information and then the memorized 25-second speech that is exactly what his advisers gave him.”

column1: What was most striking was the fact that Rubio played directly into the criticism that
column2: while he is a gifted and natural communicator
column3: he is overly scripted and returns to his standard stump speech as quickly as he can.

column1: The strategy has worked for him in past debates
column2: but repetition got the better of him on Saturday. Rubio wanted to debate Obama and Hillary Clinton
column3: warning time and again that the president has deliberately led the country in the wrong direction and that Clinton would extend those policies. Those kinds of attacks bring cheers at his campaign rallies but were far less effective during Saturday’s debate.

column1: In the later stages of the debate
column2: Rubio seemed to regain his footing both on foreign policy and on a question about abortion in which he talked about the balance between a woman’s right to make her own decisions and the right of an unborn child to live.

column1: Even when Bush drew a distinction with Rubio over whether there should be exceptions for rape
column2: incest and life of the woman
column3: which Bush favors
column4: Rubio said he would sign a bill as president that included those exceptions but that he still stood by his personal convictions. Rubio said he would rather lose an election than be wrong on the issue.

column1: Trump struggled when the subject of eminent domain
column2: a hot-button issue for many conservatives who dislike government
column3: was introduced. The billionaire builder initially offered a ringing defense of the practice of government taking private property for such projects as roads and bridges.

column1: Bush countered
column2: initially agreeing that eminent domain is necessary for the public good but then attacking Trump for attempting to use the practice to take property from an elderly woman in Atlantic City
column3: N.J.
column4: for the purpose of a parking lot for one of his casinos.

column1: Trump reverted to attacks he has long leveled at Bush — that he lacks strength or energy. “He wants to be a tough guy
column2: ” Trump said dismissively.

column1: But Bush came right back at him: “How tough is it to take away a property from an elderly woman?” he said sarcastically.
When Trump told Bush to keep quiet
column2: the audience let out another round of boos
column3: to which Trump said
column4: “That’s all his donors and special interests.”

column1: Cruz
column2: who won the Iowa caucuses
column3: had two difficult moments at the start of the evening. The first came over criticism Cruz leveled at Trump earlier in the week
column4: saying
column5: “I don’t know anyone who would be comfortable with someone who behaves this way having his finger on the button.”

column1: Trump was given the first word and defended himself. He reminded everyone that he had opposed the war in Iraq
column2: adding
column3: “I’m not the one with the trigger.”

column1: “Other people up here
column2: believe me
column3: would be a lot faster
column4: ” he said.

column1: When Cruz was asked to explain why he thought Trump lacked the temperament to be president
column2: he ducked. “The assessment the voters are making here in New Hampshire and across the country is they are evaluating each and every one of us
column3: ” he said.

column1: Reminded by ABC News anchor David Muir that he had not explained why he had made the earlier comment
column2: Cruz ducked again.

column1: Trump responded: “He didn’t answer your question. And that’s what’s going to happen with our enemies and the people we compete against. . . . People back down with Trump. And that’s what I like
column2: and that’s what the country is going to like.”

column1: That didn’t end the early hazing for Cruz. He was asked why his advisers had called Iowa volunteers on the night of the caucuses to say that Carson might be quitting the race and to encourage voters to back the senator from Texas.

Cruz blamed the problem on what he said was a misleading news report on CNN that he said was not corrected for several hours. But he also apologized to Carson and said he had done so the day after the caucuses.
Carson
column2: in his typically quiet way
column3: accepted the apology but not the explanation. “In fact
column4: the timeline indicates that initial tweet from CNN was followed by another one within one minute that clarified that I was not dropping out
column5: ” he said.

column1: More than in other previous debates
column2: this one turned into governors against the others. The three share common experiences
column3: and when they talk about one another
column4: it’s clear there is mutual respect
column5: though they are in a battle in which they cannot all survive. And whether by design or accident
column6: the three seemed to reinforce one another in taking down the candidates who finished first
column7: second and third in Iowa.

column1: Christie delivered one of the strongest performances of the campaign
column2: clearly determined to knock down Rubio
column3: whom he described this past week as “a boy in the bubble.” Fighting for his political life
column4: he was merciless in attacking Rubio for lacking the courage to fight for the immigration reform legislation that passed the Senate but faltered in the House.

column1: Rubio countered by attacking Christie’s record in New Jersey
column2: noting that the state has gone through repeated credit downgrades during his two terms. The audience seemed to side with Christie. Whether voters will do the same is the test for the next three days.

column1: Kasich was the happy warrior
column2: a governor who stressed jobs
column3: the economy and dealing realistically with issues
column4: not on the basis of pure ideology. Bush has tried for many months to make his record in Florida the centerpiece of his candidacy. Only now in these closing days has he appeared more comfortable as a candidate.

column1: Saturday’s debate here offered a last opportunity for candidates to make a persuasive argument before a primary election likely to winnow the field of realistic hopefuls to four at most.

The New Hampshire electorate is famously fickle for upending front-runners and defying conventional wisdom and turning its back on winners in Iowa. A more charitable description is that this is a state where voters keep their options open as long as possible.
While it’s true that many voters have been locked in for weeks or months
column2: a sizable number are spending these last few days shopping and pondering. They are at every rally on this final weekend
column3: looking for that connection that tips them firmly in one direction or another.

column1: That makes pollsters nervous and campaigns hopeful. The candidates know lightning can strike
column2: and they grasp for every sign that it is happening to them. In the days after Iowa
column3: there has been some movement in the polls but nothing definitive yet.

column1: What makes this year’s GOP primary distinctive from past campaigns is the number of candidates on this final weekend who still think they have a chance to move on to succeeding rounds of primaries and caucuses. Saturday’s debate underscored both the sense of possibility and the sense of urgency that surrounds the last days of campaigning here."	REAL
How public funding of elections makes politics even more polarized	"Public funding of elections — that is
column2: relying on tax revenue more than private donations to fund candidate campaigns — is a popular campaign finance reform proposal
column3: if one that many Americans don’t fully embrace.  Public funding is often thought to free candidates from the burden of fundraising and reduce the influence of wealthy donors and special interests.  That all sounds good.  Who likes “special interests
column4: ” after all?

column1: Now
column2: new research shows that public funding has an unexpected consequence: increased polarization.  That is
column3: public funding makes it harder
column4: not easier
column5: to elect moderate candidates.

column1: That is the conclusion of political scientist Andrew Hall.  He focuses on state legislative elections and compares trends in the five states that implemented robust public funding programs — Arizona
column2: Connecticut
column3: Maine
column4: Minnesota
column5: and Wisconsin — to trends in other states.  Here is what he finds:

column1: Below is a graph showing the distribution of ideology (“NP scores”) in legislatures in states that implemented public financing (the “treated” states) and those that did not (the “control” states).  The first group of states became more polarized after the implementation of public financing.  But no such change occurred during this time in the states that didn’t implement public financing.
In a more elaborate statistical analysis
column2: Hall examines the gap between Republican and Democratic legislators representing similar districts.  In a polarized legislature
column3: a Republican and a Democrat will tend to vote in very different ways even though they represent essentially the same constituents.  Hall finds that public financing increases this gap between the parties by 30 percent.

column1: Why does public financing appear to have this effect?  Hall argues that public financing weakens the influence of a maligned
column2: but moderating
column3: force in elections: access-oriented interest groups.  Public financing reduces the funding supplied by these groups by over $20
column4: 000 per race
column5: on average.  The problem is that these groups give relatively little to ideologically extreme legislators and much more to moderates.  Individual donors
column6: however
column7: have no such preference.

column1: This leads to a broader point about campaign finance and polarization.  Much of the debate over campaign finance is based on distinctions between “good” donors and “bad” donors.  Good donors are taxpayers
column2: in a public financing system.  Or
column3: in a privately funded system
column4: good donors are ordinary citizens
column5: sometimes called “small donors.”  Bad donors are political party organizations
column6: wealthy people
column7: political action committees
column8: and interest groups.

column1: The problem is that if you want to reduce polarization
column2: this way of thinking about donors gets things exactly backward.  Small donors are a polarizing influence
column3: as Adam Bonica has shown.  Meanwhile
column4: wealthy people tend to be a moderating influence.  The same is true of many political action committees and interest groups.  The same is true of political party organizations
column5: as Brian Schaffner and Ray La Raja argue in this post.

column1: That’s not to say that there aren’t good reasons to favor public financing or small donors.  But favoring those things may also mean living with the trade-off: a more polarized
column2: and probably less functional
column3: politics.

column1: Note: For a response
column2: see this follow-up post by Seth Masket and Michael Miller."	REAL

column1: The Anatomy of Crisis and the Decline of US Empire	"The Anatomy of Crisis and the Decline of US Empire Submitted by Danny Haiphong on Tue
column2: 11/08/2016 - 12:18 Tweet Widget by Danny Haiphong

column1: There are multiple dimensions to the crisis that afflicts U.S. imperialism. The latest election is evidence of a crisis of legitimacy for the ruling parties. Americans are estranged from a government that spies on every one its citizens – and on the rest of the world
column2: too. “Unemployment
column3: poverty
column4: racist state repression
column5: and war are all the system has to offer.” Unable to escape a 40-year economic slump
column6: the U.S. instead plots the destruction of its rivals. The Anatomy of Crisis and the Decline of US Empire by Danny Haiphong

column1: “ The vast majority of oppressed communities
column2: particularly Black workers
column3: have seen their labor become disposable in a post-industrial society.”

column1: Whether one analyzes the economic
column2: military
column3: or political spheres of US imperialism
column4: one thing is abundantly clear. The very fabric of the United States is in deep crisis. The crisis is largely misunderstood by the vast majority of working and oppressed people living under it. But a specter haunts the US and it isn't anything like Hollywood's scary movies. That specter is the possibility that the people will become a conscious force of opposition to the crisis and seek to dismantle the system of capitalist empire that governs it.

column1: Crises are genuinely thought of in economic terms. The economic base of capitalism is indeed suffering from protracted economic crisis. The US capitalist economy
column2: and thus the world capitalist economy pegged to its hip
column3: entered a period of stagnation in the mid to late 1970s. What followed was a slowdown in production facilitated by the increased monopolization
column4: financialization
column5: and increased technological capacity of the system. Capitalism's source of profit
column6: labor
column7: was now being exploited by an apparatus too big to expand the profits of the system without intensified exploitation. The aftermath of capitalism's periodic collapses from overproduction and under consumption have been characterized ever since by a complete and total assault on all workers.

column1: “Wages have declined or remained stagnant for nearly four decades.”
The conditions of the crisis speak for themselves. Workers in the US
column2: and the entire Western world for that matter
column3: have seen conditions rapidly deteriorate as the capitalist system has sought to maximize profits in the face of productive slowdown. Free trade agreements such as NAFTA have given corporations the freedom to eliminate production domestically in order to seek a better deal internationally. Wages have declined or remained stagnant for nearly four decades . Unemployment has become a permanent fixture of life for millions and nearly one of two people in the US are considered poor or ""near poor.""

column1: At this time
column2: the US is a low-wage capitalist economy dominated by service oriented
column3: precarious employment. Racism has played a large part in the disparity inherent under these conditions. The wealth gap between Black America and White America is larger than it was in the Civil rights era. Not only has Black America been the target of racist housing policies from predatory lenders leading up to the 2008 crisis
column4: but the burden of privatization and austerity has been directly aimed at Black families. Hedge funds
column5: for example
column6: have used working class Black communities as the guinea pig to test the effectiveness of massive school closures and teacher layoffs as well as the expansion of charter schools. Thousands of Black teachers have lost their jobs as a result to the mostly white demographic of Teach for America corps members.

column1: “ The wealth gap between Black America and White America is larger than it was in the Civil rights era.”
However
column2: it is not enough to understand the crisis of capitalism through an economic lens. The crisis possesses many forms. Repressive state activity has become more pronounced
column3: especially in the aftermath of the War on Terror. Racist repression in particular has intensified as the vast majority of oppressed communities
column4: particularly Black workers
column5: have seen their labor become disposable in a post-industrial society. Nearly 1100 Black Americans are killed every year by law enforcement all over the country. The war on Black and indigenous peoples that laid the foundation of the United States has only become more severe
column6: as evidenced by the fact that one of every eight prisoners in the world is a Black American. The Dakota Access Pipeline struggle has shown that not even the concentration camps forced upon indigenous people are safe from the profit-seeking tentacles of the crisis-ridden system.

column1: And every American can guarantee that civil liberties are a thing of the past. The NSA
column2: FBI
column3: and the rest of the intelligence community possess access to the entire population's mail and phone devices. A massive surveillance dragnet accountable to no one but the ruling class allows the US state to keep tabs on whoever resists the conditions of the crisis. War at home is ultimately a reflection of the broader war being waged around the world. The US capitalist system is a global system with the largest military state in human history. War has thus played a critical role in the response to system crisis.

column1: The US military acts as the enforcement arm of neo-colonialism and capitalist exploitation around the world. It has expanded into nearly every African state through the US African Command (AFRICOM). The US military state continues to support fascism in Ukraine and fundamentalist Islam in places like Saudi Arabia and Qatar. It has destabilized a number of nations in the last decade alone
column2: including Iraq
column3: Afghanistan
column4: and Libya. The US has collaborated with NATO
column5: Israel
column6: and Turkey to militarily encircle Russia and China militarily and sponsor terror groups responsible for the massacres in Syria.

column1: “The US imperialist system is predicated on the expansion of global capital by any means at its disposal
column2: including the use military force to clear the way for corporate plunder.

column1: But the US military is in crisis too. It is plagued by a disillusioned rank and file and the inevitability of a global confrontation with Russia and China if it continues on the current course. The demands of a stagnating global capitalist economy and the ever-increasing exploitation of masses of working people offer no potential for a reversal of fortune. The US imperialist system is predicated on the expansion of global capital by any means at its disposal
column2: including the use military force to clear the way for corporate plunder. The US military state has grown both in size and in violence in order to prevent the global shift of power currently underway.

column1: Russia and China have become the number one challengers to US global hegemony. China's economy will soon surpass that of the US and Russia's recovery from post-Soviet collapse has propelled the Putin-led nation back onto the global scene as a major factor in world affairs. These two powers are becoming increasingly close both economically and militarily. This has made the US ruling class increasingly nervous in the midst of economic decline. To maintain hegemony
column2: the US military state set the world ablaze through endless war in every region of the world that dares to seek ties with Russia and China.

column1: At this point
column2: the US imperialist system cannot peacefully compete in any way with its so-called rivals to the East. The contradictions of the system have become unmanageable. Unemployment
column3: poverty
column4: racist state repression
column5: and war are all the system has to offer. Another economic collapse is on the horizon. Crisis is built into the global capitalist system's constant drive to accumulate profit in the face of global misery. The decline of US imperialism and empire will not change regardless of the election. What is sure to change is the mass reaction to the decline as life becomes more and more unbearable under the grip of empire. Danny Haiphong is an Asian activist and political analyst in the Boston area. He can be reached at [email protected]"	FAKE

column1: WITH YOUR SECOND CUP OF COFFEE…

column2: litigious world

column1: CHANGES TO THE IOWA STRAW POLL LOOK GOOD FOR CANDIDATES
