column1: CAN CAMERON COME OUT AHEAD IN U.K. KERFUFFLE?

Voting is in full swing in Britain and polls won’t close until 5 p.m. ET. What will happen? No one seems to know except that result will be messy as either of the two major parties are likely to need the help of at least one smaller group – liberals
column2: Scottish separatists
column3: anti-European Unionists
column4: etc. – to build a majority coalition. Lacking an executive branch
column5: Britain’s system gives control of the entire government to the party which wins a vote equivalent to the vote for speaker of the House of Representatives in the U.S. With polls showing neither the Labour nor Conservative parties likely able to win the 326 seats necessary to win an outright majority
column6: control of the government for America’s most important ally will hinge on deal making with the niche parties. Can Prime Minister David Cameron and his Tories cling to power? Will Scots have their revenge by helping Ed Miliband and Labour topple the current ruling coalition? It is quite likely to be a mess. Lucky for you then that SkyNews will have all of the details.

column1: Bibi survives with last-minute deal - AP: “Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu on Wednesday completed the formation of a new coalition government
column2: reaching a last-minute deal with a nationalist party just before a midnight deadline. The late-night deal saved Netanyahu from the unthinkable scenario of being forced from office. But it set the stage for the formation of a narrow coalition dominated by hard-line and religious parties that appears to be on a collision course with the U.S. and other allies.”

column1: BUT THE CAUCUSES WERE REALLY SOMETHING
Reuters: “The Australian Sex Party
column2: a tiny party known for its salacious name and election day antics
column3: said on Thursday that it had been deregistered after the country’s election watchdog ruled it did not have enough activists. Co-founder Robbie Swan said in a statement that the party would ‘vigorously’ appeal a decision handed down by the Australian Election Commission (AEC) that removed its official status following a review of its membership. Under Australian law a political party must have either an elected representative in the federal parliament or 500 members to keep its registration. The Sex Party has one lawmaker in the Victoria state legislature
column4: but none at federal level.”

column1: Obama says world should address ‘grievances’ that terrorists exploit	"President Obama defended his administration’s approach to the terror threat at a White House summit Wednesday
column2: standing by claims that groups like the Islamic State do not represent Islam -- as well as assertions that job creation could help combat extremism.

column1: Obama
column2: addressing the Washington audience on the second day of the summit
column3: said the international community needs to address “grievances” that terrorists exploit
column4: including economic and political issues.

column1: He stressed that poverty alone doesn’t cause terrorism
column2: but “resentments fester” and extremism grows when millions of people are impoverished.

column1: “We do have to address the grievances that terrorists exploit including economic grievances
column2: ” he said.

column1: He also said no single religion was responsible for violence and terrorism
column2: adding he wants to lift up the voice of tolerance in the United States and beyond.

column1: Obama’s address came as Republican lawmakers and others criticized the administration for declining to describe the threat as Islamic terrorism.
State Department spokeswoman Marie Harf has also come under fire for suggesting several times this past week that more jobs could help address the terrorism crisis.
On Tuesday

column4: told Fox News: ""They get paid to cut off heads -- to crucify children
column5: to sell slaves and to cut off heads and I don't think that a change in career path is what's going to stop them.""

column1: Obama also called on Muslim leaders to “do more to discredit the notion that our nations are determined to suppress Islam
column2: that there is an inherent clash in civilizations.”

column1: Obama acknowledged that some Muslim-Americans have concerns about working with the government
column2: particularly law enforcement
column3: and that their reluctance “is rooted in the objection to certain practices where Muslim-Americans feel they’ve been unfairly targeted.”

column1: He said it was important it make sure that abuses stop and are not repeated and that “we do not stigmatize entire communities.” He also said it was vital that “no one is profiled or put under a cloud of suspicion simply because of their faith.”
Although Obama called for a renewed focus on preventing terrorists from recruiting and inspiring others

column1: “He was meandering

column3: ” said Richard Grenell

column1: Sen. Ted Cruz
column2: R-Texas

column1: I don't think it's too much to ask the president to stay in the current millennia

column1: Recent Fox News polling showed most voters think Obama should be tougher on Islamic extremists. It showed 68 percent think Obama should be tougher; only 26 percent said he's being tough enough.
The poll of 1

column1: Leaders from 60 different countries traveled to Washington for the summit this week.
Community leaders from Boston

column1: 7 Ways To Prepare For An Economic Crisis	"Bill White November 7
column2: 2016 7 Ways To Prepare For An Economic Crisis

column1: Using the past economic collapses as an example
column2: we can see that people’s lifestyles changed dramatically. Even those who managed to keep their jobs and businesses have to make radical adjustments in their lies
column3: just to be able to survive.

column1: There is no reason for us to think that things will be any different here in the United States
column2: than they were in Argentina; in fact
column3: they could very well end up being worse.

column1: The reason I say it could be worse is that there will be nobody to bail out the United States
column2: as has been done with other countries. We know from the 2009 housing collapse that anything negative that happens in the U.S. economy has a worldwide effect.

column1: Since other countries will end up suffering as well
column2: there is no way that they will be able to help us.

column1: Liberals have touted the idea of redistributing the wealth of the wealthy in order to take care of our country’s woes. I’m not going to discuss the morality or ideology of that right now; but I will say this: if you were to take all the wealth of the 100 richest people in the United States and add it together
column2: it wouldn’t pay our federal government’s bills from January 1 st till tax day.

column1: Of course
column2: since their wealth isn’t really in cash
column3: but rather in ownership of properties and companies
column4: there’s no way of using it to pay the government’s costs or debts.

column1: The other thing that could make the collapse worse here in the United States is that most Americans aren’t prepared to live without all of our comforts. If you go to other countries
column2: people are more accustomed to doing things themselves
column3: instead of expecting society to do them. They know how to do basic things like slaughter a hog and pluck a chicken ; things that the average American hasn’t had to do for generations.

column1: Here are a number of lifestyle changes which can help your family to be ready to survive the meltdown:
Pay off Your Home
Home mortgages are dangerous in a financial crisis . If you don’t have enough income coming in to make the payment on your home
column2: then you could very easily lose it. No matter how prepared you are
column3: if you don’t have your home
column4: you’re going to be in trouble.

column1: There are a number of strategies around for paying off your home mortgage early. I won’t go into them here
column2: because this really isn’t a book about personal finances.

column1: You can find the necessary information on how to pay off your home early in a number of places. I highly recommend looking into Dave Ramsey’s teachings on the subject.
Another option you may want to consider is downsizing. By selling your existing home and moving into something smaller
column2: you might be able to reduce your mortgage payments or even the length of your mortgage. That would help you to get rid of your mortgage sooner.

column1: In the case of the financial crash coming before you manage to pay it off (which is very likely)
column2: your payments will be smaller
column3: making it easier for you to keep making those payments.

column1: Pay off All Other Debts
Any debt is a liability
column2: enslaving your family’s finances to others. By paying off your outstanding debt
column3: you eliminate the risk of lenders coming to take what you have. While other debt is not as important as your home mortgage
column4: paying it off can make it easier to pay off your mortgage quicker.

column1: Paying off your debt also reduces your monthly cost of living
column2: freeing up more money for use in preparing for the pending crash or some other activity your family wants to do.

column1: The vast majority of Americans have too much debt
column2: which greatly limits their options and the decisions that they can make.

column1: Learn to Do Things without Electricity
So much of our modern lifestyle depends upon electricity. We are used to using it for literally everything; from preserving our food to entertaining us. However
column2: loss of electricity is a common problem during times of economic meltdown.

column1: Oh
column2: the electricity probably won’t go out and stay out
column3: but you can count on a lot of service interruptions.

column1: When service is lost
column2: many of the things which we take for granted are lost as well. Our ability to store and cook food is compromised
column3: as well as our ability to work. Lighting is gone
column4: as well as most of our communications. For many people
column5: the loss of electricity means the loss of being able to work as well.

column1: For everything you use in your life that is electric powered
column2: you need an alternative. That means having something that you can use to do the same job
column3: should the power go out. In some cases
column4: you might be able to do without that thing
column5: but you need to analyze that and make that determination
column6: not just accept it as an assumption.

column1: Re-do Your Budget
Probably one of the best things you can do to prepare for a financial meltdown is to re-do your budget
column2: establishing a more frugal lifestyle. Chances are
column3: when the economic collapse happens
column4: you’re going to have to be living that more frugal lifestyle.

column1: By establishing it ahead of time
column2: you not only train yourself and your family to be more careful of how you use your money
column3: but you also save money which you can then use to buy and stockpile necessary supplies .

column1: Many people today live from paycheck to paycheck. That doesn’t mean that they’re using their money wisely though. Their budget may include eating out three times a week
column2: spending $400 per month on their cell phones and another $300 per month on entertainment. Yet they complain about not having enough money to buy some basic emergency supplies.

column1: There are a lot of places where the average family spends more than they need to. Buying new cars is another one. Banks and the auto industry make a lot of money off of families who are making payments on two cars at a time. For some
column2: their combined car payments are higher than their house payment.

column1: While reliable vehicles are a necessity
column2: having two car payments every month isn’t. It would be better to buy older cars and not have those high payments to make.

column1: Eat Healthy
How can eating healthy be part of preparing for a financial meltdown? Easy; the most expensive things that most of us eat are junk food. As a nation
column2: we spend a fortune on prepared foods
column3: snack foods and sweets.

column1: When the financial meltdown comes
column2: you probably won’t be able to afford all that junk. You’ll end up eating much simpler foods
column3: which carry more nutrition.

column1: At the same time
column2: eating all that junk food is not good for your health. Medical expenses can be extremely high
column3: especially for those who have ignored eating healthy.

column1: While it may sound a bit extreme
column2: eating healthy can make the difference between life and death
column3: by helping protect you from a life-threatening medical problem.

column1: Get in Shape
This one goes hand-in-hand with eating healthy. People who are in good physical condition are much less likely to have medical problems
column2: especially high blood pressure
column3: diabetes and high cholesterol; all of which can become life-threatening.

column1: However
column2: there’s another part to this as well. That is
column3: preparing your body for the physical rigors of survival.

column1: Living without all the modern conveniences requires much more physical work than living with them. That’s why so many of us are out of shape. We’ve become accustomed to allowing machines to do the things that we used to do ourselves. We’ve become softer.
Many of us can’t do the physical work necessary for surviving without all those modern machines.
Find Like-Minded People
Many experts on survival and preparedness recommend banding together with other like-minded people and forming a prepping community . The idea is that in the wake of a disaster
column2: the community would gather in one place to live and work together. Each member of the team would have their assigned area of responsibility
column3: based upon their unique skills.

column1: There are many advantages of working together in a prepping community. The right community can increase your chances of survival.
However
column2: the wrong one can cause severe problems
column3: with people leaving the group and taking most of the supplies with them.

column1: Be careful what group you join
column2: investigating the morals and personalities of the people first
column3: to make an informed decision about whether the group will stick together to help each other
column4: or become selfish and steal from each other.

column1: Our ancestors survived harsh times and their secrets can help you survive during the most treacherous conditions if the world is struck with a tragedy.
Bill White for Survivopedia. 155 total views
column2: 155 views today"	FAKE

column1: Press must share the blame: The shallow, ratings-obsessed media is as responsible for Trump as the GOP	"“I’m going to walk away with it and win outright. I’m going to get in and all the polls are going to go crazy. I’m going to suck all the oxygen out of the room. I know how to work the media in a way that they will never take the lights off of me.” – Donald Trump
Donald Trump’s blend of bombast
column2: amorality and media savvy has carried him to the Republican nomination. He’s proven that an ability to dominate coverage and dictate the narrative is sufficient in today’s political climate. None of this is surprising: Trump’s a TV man with a gift for self-promotion. His entire career has been preparation for this moment
column3: this campaign. He saw our broken
column4: perverted process with clear eyes and he’s exploited it with aplomb.

column1: You have to give him credit for that.
While the Republican Party is ultimately responsible for Trump (they welcomed him into their big tent
column2: after all)
column3: the media is equally culpable for the calamity that is his candidacy. Every American is entitled to be as undiscerning and uncritical as they like. There’s nothing in the social contract that demands voters educate themselves. A democracy
column4: for the most part
column5: can tolerate its share of credulous citizens. But the media has a special obligation in a free society. It’s the only profession protected by the U.S. Constitution for a reason: it’s a check on power and a gadfly for crooked politicians and abusers of power.

column1: The media has failed spectacularly this election. “It [Trump’s campaign] may not be good for America
column2: ” said Les Moonves
column3: the CEO and executive chairman of CBS
column4: “but it’s damn good for CBS..Man
column5: who would have expected the ride we’re all having right now? The money’s rolling in and this is fun. I’ve never seen anything like this
column6: and this is going to be a very good year for us. Sorry. It’s a terrible thing to say. But
column7: bring it on
column8: Donald. Keep going.” This is the plundering reaction Trump expected. “They will never take the lights off of me
column9: ” he famously said to Republican officials two years before announcing his candidacy.

column1: Importantly
column2: Trump also understood how to navigate the process without engaging issues that matter. To call his campaign substance-free is too generous. It’s been a cavalcade of insults and ethno-nationalist dog-whistling
column3: punctuated by populist platitudes. If we had a functional media
column4: Trump would be challenged by journalists and anchors. Instead
column5: they’re too busy monitoring the ratings to notice he’s using them to prop up his campaign.

column1: Part of the problem
column2: as Columbia journalism professor Todd Gitlin notes in The Washington Post
column3: is that Trump has “cracked the campaign reporters’ code.” Gitlin writes: “Trump regularly runs circles around interviewers because they pare their follow-up questions down to a minimum
column4: or none at all. After 30-plus years in the media spotlight
column5: he knows how to wait out an interviewer
column6: offering noncommittal soundbites and incoherent rejoinders until he hears the phrase
column7: ‘let’s move on.’ He takes advantage of the slipshod
column8: shallow techniques journalism has made routine
column9: particularly on TV – techniques that
column10: in the past
column11: were sufficient to trup up less-media-savvy candidates – but that Trump knows how to sidestep.” Examples of this abound. Gitlin cites interview after interview in which Trump rope-a-dopes reporters when they ask questions he can’t answer or when they suggest
column12: however passively
column13: that he’s wrong or lied about the record. “Trump is a master of darting from slogan to slogan
column14: ” Gitlin writes. “That’s why interviewers must do their homework and be prepared to go at least 2-3 questions deep on any issue.” Great idea
column15: but it’s difficult to dive deep when interviewers are forced to shoehorn serious questions in limited time between competing toothpaste commercials. Trump gets away with this because of the mutually beneficial relationship he has with the press. He knows people like Moonves are interested in selling penis pill ads
column16: not informing the electorate. Voters
column17: for their part
column18: are happy to project whatever they want onto the empty vessel that is Trump. Meanwhile
column19: the truth is an afterthought and the whole sordid circus continues unimpeded. Gitlin urges journalists “to honor the good name of their profession and take off the kid gloves.” Sound advice
column20: but I’m not holding my breath."	REAL

column1: 14 Days to Do 14 Things, If Hillary’s Indicted-Extreme Violence Expected	"
UPDATE: HILLARY CLINTON IS AGAIN UNDER INVESTIGATION BY THE FBI. IF SHE IS INDICTED
column2: HER PEOPLE WILL UNDOUBTEDLY LAUNCH A CYBER ATTACK ON THE ELECTIONS AND BLAME THE RUSSIANS. HILLARY HAS TIPPED HER HAND MANY TIMES. IF THIS HAPPENS
column3: YOU MUST HASTEN YOUR PREPARATIONS. IF HILLARY SKATES
column4: AGAIN
column5: WE STILL ONLY HAVE A SHORT WINDOW TO ALL HELL BREAKING LOOSE. PLEASE PREPARE NOW!

column1: The Common Sense Show issued an alert yesterday with regard to the likelihood of widespread violence
column2: regardless of who wins the election. The violence may not be dramatic on November
column3: but I believe that a crescendo will be reached by the holidays. There are literally dozens of troop movements and a number of martial law events taking place as I write these words. The bottom line is
column4: half of the country hates the other half of the country and pressure valve is ready to blow. And if Trump wins
column5: the violence factor will escalate exponentially as evidenced by the firebombed GOP building in North Carolina.

column1: When these events come to fruition
column2: it could potentially paralyze this nation and bring the economy to a standstill. Subsequently
column3: the grocery store shelves could be empty within two days and food riots would likely commence by sundown of the second day. All Americans would instantly be in danger. Local law enforcement would be overwhelmed. What would be your chances of survival? Yesterday
column4: I wrote about the fact that FEMA has conducted research studies on America’s level of preparedness and the news is not good. FEMA concluded that 72% of all Americans are not prepared to survive what is coming In other words
column5: when society begins to fragment
column6: you and your fellow preppers are outnumbered by a 3 to 1 margin.

column1: Are you prepared for 3 out of 4 of your neighbors climbing through your windows in search of life-saving supplies?
The FEMA Preparedness Reports In response to concerns about strengthening the nation’s ability to protect its population and way of life (i.e.
column2: security) and ability to adapt and recover from emergencies (i.e.
column3: resilience)
column4: the President of the United States issued Presidential Policy Directive 8: National Preparedness (PPD-8).

column1: PPD-8 is a directive for the Department of Homeland Security to coordinate a comprehensive campaign to encourage Americans to practice national preparedness. Despite efforts by FEMA and other organizations to educate American citizens on becoming prepared
column2: growth in specific preparedness behaviors has been limited. Government programs to this end are nearly nonexistent.

column1: I have spent the past week illustrating how a coming economic collapse is unavoidable and how the elite have conspired to steal as many of your assets as possible prior to the collapse. This article presents some common sense things one can do which could increase the chances of surviving a major societal meltdown resulting from an economic collapse. If you have any doubts as to what is coming
column2: I strongly encourage you to read what I have written about on this topic over the past several months. Even Ray Charles could see that our economy will not be around much longer in its present form.

column1: It is always best to prepare for the worst and hope for the best. For the purposes of this article
column2: it is possible that society will not totally collapse even if the dollar does. However
column3: large segments of societies always collapse when an economic collapse happens. Surviving the worst case scenario is the purpose behind what will be covered here.

column1: We have about 14 days to do the following 14 things: 1. The Creation of a Pseudo-Identity It may be necessary to become invisible in the event you think you believe that your name could be on a (Red) list because roundups will usually occur in dire situations. Therefore
column2: the creation of a pseudo-identity could become very important.

column1: 2. It Takes Money to Prepare If you have read the articles at the above links
column2: you should have concluded that it is the height of stupidity to leave your life savings in an institution that is planning to steal from you. You need to divert your cash
column3: other than the ability to pay basic bills
column4: in preparation for what is coming.

column1: Getting your money out of the bank has become an art form and you need to be careful. There is a barrier to your ability to procure some of these life-saving and life-extending supplies. Right now
column2: you do not have full access to your money.

column1: As you move to withdraw the bulk of your money
column2: there are three federal banking laws that you should be cognizant of
column3: namely
column4: Cash Transaction Report (CTR)
column5: a Suspicious Activity Report (SAR) and structuring.

column1: Cash Transaction Reports Federal law requires that the bank file a report based upon any withdrawal or deposit of $10
column2: 000 or more on any single given day.The law was designed to put a damper on money laundering
column3: sophisticated counterfeiting and other federal crimes.

column1: To remain in compliance with the law
column2: financial institutions must obtain personal identification
column3: information about the transaction and the social security number of the person conducting the transaction.

column1: Before proceeding with the planned withdrawal of your money
column2: I would strongly suggest that you read the following federal guidelines as it relates to CTR’s as produced by the The Financial Crimes Enforcement Network (FinCEN). All the federal regulations contained in this article are elucidated in this series of federal reports.

column1: Structuring and SAR There will undoubtedly be some geniuses whose math ability will tell them that all they have to do is to withdraw $9
column2: 999.99 and the bank and its protector
column3: the federal government will be none the wiser. It is not quite that simple. The bank is required to file a Suspicious Activity Report (SAR) which serves to notify the federal government of an individual’s attempt to structure deposits or withdrawals by circumventing the $10
column4: 000 reporting requirement.

column1: Structuring transactions to prevent a CTR from being reported can result in imprisonment for not more than five years and/or a fine of up to $250
column2: 000. If structuring involves more than $100
column3: 000 in a twelve month period or is performed while violating another law of the federal government
column4: the penalty is doubled.

column1: Enforcement Much like the enforcement of our tax laws
column2: the federal government’s enforcement of its banking laws as it relates to CTR’s
column3: SAR’s and subsequent structuring is quite draconian. Civilian asset forfeiture laws come into play. The government can seize your bank accounts while it determines if a crime has been committed. The government can literally seize your assets in perpetuity without an order of the court. Of course
column4: you could try and sue but you will be up against the deep pockets of the federal government and the case could take years. By the time your case is decided
column5: the financial banking crisis that you are so desperately trying to avoid by withdrawing your money
column6: could be over. So
column7: proceed with caution.

column1: Withdrawing Your Money From the Bank The best way to avoid getting your money caught in the bank in the midst of a bank run would be to not let the lion’s share of your money ever cross the bank. The simplest way to accomplish this is to prevent any form of deposit from going automatically into your account
column2: as much as it is possible.

column1: Secondly
column2: you need to begin to pay cash for everything. Let’s say that every 30 days
column3: Bob cashes his check at the bank from his work worth $5
column4: 000 net pay. Bob leaves just enough in the bank to be able to conduct normal banking business. Bob walks out of the bank every month with the majority of the cash from his check. Bob should begin to pay cash for as much as he can
column5: such as eating out
column6: paying the electric bill (pay the bill in person)
column7: buying groceries
column8: etc. When it becomes necessary to make a “big ticket” purchase
column9: Bob could temporarily leave more in the bank to cover the writing of a check.

column1: You would also be wise to open multiple banking accounts ranging from the big five megabanks to your local credit unions. You could withdraw much smaller amounts until the sum total of your accounts is greatly diminished and is in your possession. To open the accounts
column2: simply write a personal check from your home bank. Of course
column3: in these cases
column4: the bank could hold the check for 15-30 days.

column1: I cannot promise you that if you become the target of federal investigators
column2: that you will not have your every financial move scrutinized and the feds will eventually discover the aggregate patterns of withdrawal. People who I interviewed told me that they believe that the federal government is in the process of getting the banking computers to “talk” to each other in a way that would reveal structuring
column3: but that technology is not yet online.

column1: If you ever become the target of a federal investigation
column2: do not
column3: under any circumstances
column4: allow yourself to be interviewed by federal officials without an attorney present. In many cases
column5: people go to jail and pay huge fines
column6: not because they have committed a federal crime
column7: but because federal officials state that they have lied or misled them. And if you do not have an attorney present
column8: it is your word versus the federal government. There are other sources besides banks that you can tap into for money which can be used to prepare for what is coming.

column1: 4o1K’s
column2: IRA
column3: et al If you were 100% convinced of an imminent crash
column4: you would be foolish not to take your money out. However
column5: the prepayment penalty of 50% is steep if you withdraw your funds before you are 59.5 years old.

column1: If you are retiring soon
column2: take the lump sum option and convert all of these retirement monies to survival supplies and gold which you will need as the world emerges from the crash.

column1: The moral of the story is to become as liquid as possible
column2: from a cash perspective. Getting access to your money is only the first part of being prepared to survive an economic crash.

column1: 3. Make a List Buy a good prepper book. Holly Deyo is an excellent source for this information (www.standdeyo.com). In the interim
column2: procure your food
column3: water
column4: guns
column5: ammo and home security adjustments. If you do not have a big dog
column6: consider obtaining a pair. These animals will be your companion
column7: home security system and ally if someone attempts to breach your home with bad intent. Of course
column8: you will have to store dog food as well.

column1: Sit down and construct a list of what you will need after reading a good prepper book.
Make all of you purchases in cash! You do not want to let the wrong people know what you are up to.
4. Rural Vs. Urban We have to live our lives for today and it may not be possible to move to a rural area because of your job. However
column2: one survivalist that I was speaking with estimates that the rate of survival for a country in economic chaos would be 10 times higher for rural residents as opposed to urban residents. Consider buying a place in an isolated area and commuting to work in the interim.

column1: 5. Pay Off Your Mortgage and Car Loans If you have a CD
column2: a 401k or any other long-term investment
column3: you might want to consider taking the penalty and executing a withdrawal and apply what’s left of the principal
column4: usually about 50% of the original value
column5: and paying down your major debts.

column1: After an economic collapse
column2: you most likely will not have a job and your retirement and savings will likely be wiped out and confiscated. That is why it would be wise to pay down your debt while you can afford to do so because after the collapse
column3: there will still be foreclosures and repossessions and if you and your family survive
column4: you could be on the street if you cannot pay your bills.

column1: 6. Buy Gold and Silver While You Can Afford It Goldman Sachs has been shorting gold. The elite have been hording gold as have the BRICS. These entities are telling you
column2: by action
column3: what medium of exchange is going to be of value following the collapse that is coming.

column1: Storing gold and silver is an economic survival strategy which will pay dividends after the smoke begins to clear in the post-collapse era.

7. Practice Austerity Before Austerity Is Imposed On You It is critical to immediately eliminate all unnecessary expenses. Give yourself some operating capital. You may be able to purchase a bug-out residence in a rural area. You will certainly be able to afford more survival gear.
In order to increase your immediate cash flow
column2: start an at-home business. Start a business which has virtually no upfront and startup costs. Even if you are not able to generate much income
column3: you will create a legal tax evasion strategy in which you can legally deduct many of your present activities and expenses (e.g. mileage
column4: the purchase of any office supply
column5: etc.) including survival gear.

column1: 8. Create and Store Your Own Food With regard to storing food
column2: you need to do so immediately. I recommend storing two years worth of food. However
column3: you need to master the art of growing food inside your home. There are plenty of resources which can teach you how to do that. However
column4: you would be wise if you would create a hiding place in which you can store food and water safely in a hidden location . If you are ever robbed
column5: you will not have exhausted your food supplies. You are most likely to be robbed by FEMA or one of their mercenary groups (e.g. Academia) during the beginning of the crisis because food and water will be used as weapons to control you. I am personally aware of FEMA going to selected homeowners to catalogue their reserve food and water supplies. Remember
column6: water is sunlight and temperature sensitive. There are plenty of prepper manuals that you can consult for instructions on how to meet these needs. The time to do these things is yesterday.

column1: The biggest threat to survival is death due to dehydration and starving to death. Contaminated water will also pose a threat. There are plenty of places to purchase large drums and obtain water tablets for water purification purposes. Obtain a pair of water filters in case you have to go mobile to survive.
Finally
column2: learn to grow your own food within your residence. Your garden will likely be raided by humans and hungry animals alike. There are plenty of prepper manuals which can teach you how to accomplish this task.

column1: 9. Personal Supplies Of course you will need toothpaste
column2: toiletries
column3: eating utensils
column4: feminine hygiene supplies
column5: etc. For a complete list of personal items see Steve Quayles list on his website .

column1: 10. Horde Medicines and Medical Supplies If you or your family has a chronic health condition
column2: it is critical that you have 6 months to a year in medicine. Also

column1: How the confidence deficit is impacting the 2016 election	"First Read is a morning briefing from Meet the Press and the NBC Political Unit on the day's most important political stories and why they matter.
A week out from Election Day
column2: here's the only thing we're sure of after Friday's bombshell political news that the Federal Bureau of Investigation is one again looking at Hillary Clinton's emails: Another U.S. institution -- the FBI -- has taken a hit. (It's especially true after all of the obvious leaks coming from the FBI and Justice Department.) And that news isn't good for the country's democracy. Back in 2014
column3: our national NBC/WSJ poll looked at Americans' confidence in 15 different institutions and industries
column4: and majority had confidence in just two of them.

column1: So this lack of confidence in American institutions was taking place BEFORE this presidential election
column2: and you can only imagine what the situation is going to look like afterwards. As for Comey and his decision to make his announcement 11 days before an election
column3: we understand he was in a lose-lose situation. (If he withheld this information before the election
column4: it could have been equally damaging.) But the problem was how vague Comey's letter to Congress was
column5: as well as the fact that it was sent before the FBI even had access to the emails. It's hard to reconcile Comey being so transparent with a July press conference and then testimony to Capitol Hill -- over a matter where there were no charges -- and then so opaque in a letter to Congress just days before the election.

column1: Team Trump deals with its share of negative stories
While the Clinton campaign is still dealing with the fallout from Friday's news
column2: Halloween night saw several tough stories aimed at Team Trump. There was the New York Times report on new tax documents showing Trump ""used a legally dubious method"" to avoid paying taxes; NBC News reported that the FBI ""has been conducting a preliminary inquiry into Donald Trump's former campaign manager Paul Manafort's foreign business connections""; and Mother Jones reported that a veteran spy gave the FBI information alleging a Russian operation to cultivate ties to Trump.

column1: Today in Pennsylvania
column2: meanwhile
column3: Trump and running mate Mike Pence will deliver a policy speech to ""repeal and replace"" Obamacare. It's a smart move for the Trump camp to focus on policy when everyone is paying attention. A Trump aide previews the speech to NBC's Peter Alexander: ""The speech will be delivered along with several of those congressional leaders who the Trump Administration will work with to immediately repeal and replace it. What's even more powerful is that we'll have Gov. Pence there to address how he has successfully navigated Indiana through this mess and created a model for other states to follow.""

column1: This week's NBC|SurveyMonkey tracking poll has Clinton ahead by 6 points over Trump in the four-way horserace
column2: 47%-41% -- which is exactly where it was last week. Moreover
column3: that six-point 47%-41% lead was identical in interviews before the Comey news (Monday through Friday) and after (Saturday and Sunday). More from the poll: ""Likely voters were split on whether they thought the controversial announcement by the FBI was an important issue to discuss or more of a distraction to the campaign. A slight majority of likely voters nationwide—55 percent—said it was an important issue. Forty-four percent said the news was more of a distraction to the campaign."" Now the national Washington Post/ABC tracking poll has Trump up a point
column4: though that's in contrast to the other tracking polls we've seen after the Comey news.

column1: The Comey Surprise might not have hurt Hillary Clinton's presidential chances. But it might have hurt downballot Democrats
column2: who were counting on a large Clinton margin over Trump. ""While FBI Director James Comey's email bombshell is unlikely to dent her White House chances
column3: Democrats fear it might shorten her coattails and threaten their prospects of retaking the Senate
column4: NBC's Alex Seitz-Wald writes. ""'It's certainly not helpful
column5: ' said Missouri Democratic Party Chairman Roy Temple. 'It kind of pollutes the Democratic brand in a way that's unnecessary
column6: simply because it doesn't actually involve any new information
column7: which is why the frustration at Comey is so high right now.'"" More: ""'The slightest breeze in any direction can really push these races one way or another
column8: ' said Ian Prior of the Senate Leadership Fund
column9: a deep-pocketed GOP Super PAC. 'All you need is need is .01 (percent) in a [close race].'"" By the way
column10: a Monmouth poll from yesterday showed a tied race in Indiana's Senate race
column11: which isn't good news for Democrats' bid to retake the Senate.

column1: Burr says gun owners may want to put a ""bullseye"" on Clinton

But this story won't help Republicans in the key North Carolina Senate race. CNN: ""Sen. Richard Burr privately mused over the weekend that gun owners may want to put a 'bullseye' on Hillary Clinton… The North Carolina Republican
column2: locked in a tight race for reelection
column3: quipped that as he walked into a gun shop 'nothing made me feel better' than seeing a magazine about rifles 'with a picture of Hillary Clinton on the front of it.'"" Burr apologized. ""The comment I made was inappropriate
column4: and I apologize for it. But the audio CNN obtained also contained this other sound from Burr
column5: in which he said he'd work to keep Clinton from filling the vacant Supreme Court seat. ""[I]f Hillary Clinton becomes president
column6: I am going to do everything I can do to make sure four years from now
column7: we still got an opening on the Supreme Court.""

Strickland has committed his fair share of unforced errors

column1: Anonymous hacker Deric Lostutter faces 16 years in prison, while Steubenville rapists walk free	"Anonymous hacker Deric Lostutter faces 16 years in prison
column2: while Steubenville rapists walk free Please scroll down for video

column1: Deric Lostutter was part of the group affiliated with Anonymous who exposed the rapists of an underage girl in Steubenville
column2: Ohio. While his actions eventually helped to highlight the terrible crime against the young woman and helped to bring the perpetrators to justice
column3: he has received no thanks from law enforcement who have instead elected to put him on trial for felony hacking. If he is found guilty
column4: he will face up to sixteen years in prison. Incidentally
column5: the rapists who were also found guilty at trial have already completed their exceptionally short detention sentences. Steubenville hacker indicted for bringing rapists to justice

column1: The sobering details of the Steubenville rape case were detailed heavily in 2013 when the perpetrators came to trial. Members of a local football team gang raped a high school girl and posted pictures
column2: and social media posts are bragging about they had done to her. Only two of the perpetrators were ever arrested on charges of rape and kidnap
column3: Trent May and Ma’Lik Richmond
column4: both of whom received far more local support then their victim.

column1: Initially
column2: local authorities showed a reluctance to prosecute any of the perpetrators of this senseless and violent act owing to their privileged place in local society. This led to international outrage and eventually a group called KnightSec
column3: which is affiliated to Anonymous decided to step in. They hacked into the Steubenville High School sports fan website and exposed the cover-up by school administrators and the identities of the girl’s attackers. They also posted a video of several students making light of the rape victim. They threatened to expose more individuals associated with the cover-up if the rapists did not come forward and confess. Eventually
column4: two young men did come forward and were convicted of the rape of a minor. Ma’Lik Richmond served a paltry ten-month spell at the juvenile detention facility
column5: and Trent May served two years .

column1: According to Tor Ekeland
column2: a lawyer speaking for Lostutter
column3: he and his client were both incredibly surprised that he had been targeted by the FBI about this hacking. He said; “I don’t understand why they are prosecuting somebody who helped expose the rape of a minor… This is not a situation where somebody
column4: you know
column5: hacked a hospital or took down a nuclear power plant. This was an act of political protest against the rape of a 16-year-old girl.”

column1: Now Lostutter must wait and see whether he will face the full sixteen years in prison that his ‘crime’ can carry. Naturally
column2: his supporters are appalled. “You get 16 years for forcibly entering your way into a computer
column3: but you get one year for forcibly entering your way into a woman. I think that’s the precedent the government is setting here
column4: ” said Ekeland.

column2: while Steubenville rapists walk free) is free and open source. You have permission to republish this article under a Creative Commons license with full attribution and a link to the original source on Disclose.tv Related Articles"	FAKE

column1: ROMNEY’S TIMELY TRUMP TROLLING
Donald Trump argues that Mitt Romney is in no position to be asking for the 2016 Republican frontrunner’s tax returns on the grounds that Romney lost the 2012 general election. Romney is also
column2: Trump wrote
column3: a “dope.”

column1: But Romney is arguably the very best Republican to be asking Trump about his tax returns given how successfully Democrats exploited Romney’s filings to alienate potential voters. Democrats essentially called Romney a tax cheat for his low rates and the attack stuck. And it is a line
column2: in some form or another
column3: which Democrats will be sure to repeat against the billionaire Trump if he becomes the Republican nominee.

column1: Romney began releasing his tax returns amid pressure from his rivals in early Republican primaries in 2012. But because Trump’s rivals have neglected to actually attack the frontrunner very much
column2: Trump is only just now being pressed on this crucial general election issue.

column1: Romney’s troll timing is perfect. Trump is either less than a week away from starting to put the Republican nomination in the bag or facing lengthening odds in his unlikely but so-far successful quest. He is also facing tonight what promises to be his most challenging debate yet.
Trump’s detractors to this point have mostly knocked Trump for insufficient conservativeness
column2: or flip flopping
column3: or being of poor character. But voters primarily interested in conservative orthodoxy and personal virtue are probably not part of Trump’s long-term coalition. Trump’s voters don’t seem to care about his politics. They just want a winner.

column1: What few have hit the frontrunner on are his business failures and the unhappy chapters of his career. His business troubles and his finances have been a long-running part of Trump’s media feuds in the past but have oddly not been part of the political discussion. It is particularly odd given how much of a focus Romney’s relatively tame business record was four years ago.
Romney’s mischievous speculation is using Trump’s tactics against Trump. When the celebrity billionaire speculated about Sen. Ted Cruz’s nativity
column2: Sen. Marco Rubio’s sweat glands
column3: or Ben Carson’s gifts as a teenaged knife fighter
column4: he was doing exactly what Romney is doing now.

column1: Whether Trump can manage to lock up his party’s nomination – which could come as soon as March 15 – without divulging his tax returns will depend on the press and his competitors. Neither has shown themselves to have much snap in their noodles when it comes to taking on Trump so far
column2: but the hour is late and the stakes are high.

WITH YOUR SECOND CUP OF COFFEE

In a coral reef near Tahiti one photographer set out to capture as many species as he could in a single photograph. Smithsonian has the story: “What if you sifted through every last little organism that lives or passes through a single cubic foot of space in a day? On a coral reef? In a forest? How many species would you find? This was the question that [photographer Michael] Liittschwager wanted to answer—and photograph. He came up with the idea of a biocube; his proposed standard for sampling biodiversity. A 12-inch cube that he would set in one place and observe long enough to catalog everything within it. He started on Mo’ore’a [an island off Tahiti]
column2: but has since brought his biocube method to many locations around the world.”

column1: Like a “Concentration Camp” Police Mark DAPL Protesters with Numbers and Lock Them in Dog Kennels	"By Claire Bernish
On Thursday
column2: police from no less than five states sporting full riot gear and armed with heavy lethal and nonlethal weaponry
column3: pepper spray
column4: mace
column5: a number of ATVs
column6: five tanks
column7: two helicopters
column8: and military-equipped Humvees showed up to tear down an encampment of Standing Rock Sioux water protectors and supporters armed with … nothing.

column1: Under orders from the now-notorious Morton County Sheriff’s Office
column2: this ridiculously heavy-handed standing army came better prepared to do battle than some actual military units fighting overseas.

column1: But the target of their operation — a group of slightly more than 200 Native American water protectors and supporters opposing construction of the Dakota Access Pipeline — never intended to do battle with the armed
column2: taxpayer-funded
column3: corporate-backed
column4: state-sponsored aggressors.

column1: Reports vary
column2: but no less than 141 people were arrested Thursday
column3: and — according to witnesses — police marked numbers on arrestees’ arms and housed them in cement-floored dog kennels
column4: without any padding
column5: before they were transported as far away as Fargo.

column1: “It goes back to concentration camp days
column2: ” asserted Oceti-Sakowin coordinator Mekasi Camp-Horinek
column3: who
column4: along with his mother
column5: was marked and detained in a mesh kennel
column6: reports the Los Angeles Times.

column1: Although Thursday’s incident remained relatively peaceful for some time
column2: with only shouts
column3: chants
column4: and occasional attempts by water protectors to convince this standing army to examine its motives and reconsider
column5: clashes nonetheless broke out — solely because of gratuitous police aggression.

column1: After facing off for a couple hours
column2: these militant cops began closing in on the water protectors to shut down the Treaty of 1851 camp — in reference to the Fort Laramie Treaty of that year
column3: which established a large parcel of land designated exclusively Native American territory not to be disturbed by the U.S. government. Prior to his arrest
column4: Camp-Horinek had established the camp
column5: stating
column6: as cited by Indigenous Rising :

column1: Today
column2: the Oceti Sakowin has enacted eminent domain on DAPL lands
column3: claiming 1851 treaty rights. This is unceded land. Highway 1806 as of this point is blockaded. We will be occupying this land and staying here until this pipeline is permanently stopped. We need bodies and we need people who are trained in non-violent direct action. We are still staying non-violent and we are still staying peaceful.

column1: Despite the water protectors’ commitment to nonviolence
column2: the militarized police response went as would be expected — horribly awry.

column1: “A prayer circle of elders
column2: including several women
column3: was interrupted and all were arrested for standing peacefully on the public road
column4: ” stated a press release from Indigenous Environment Network . “A tipi was erected in the road and was recklessly dismantled
column5: despite law enforcement statements that they would merely mark the tipi with a yellow ribbon and ask its owners to retrieve it. A group of water protectors was also dragged out of a sweat lodge ceremony erected in the path of the pipeline
column6: thrown to the ground
column7: and arrested.”

column1: Claims to the contrary by Morton County Sheriff Kyle Kirchmeier aside
column2: Native American and Indigenous water protectors and supporters have refrained from violent acts on the whole
column3: preferring instead peaceful prayer vigils and acts of civil disobedience.

column1: No matter how peacefully the opposition acts
column2: armed defenders of Big Oil interests seem determined to brutalize
column3: disrespect
column4: and generally incite and inflict violence against those who desire unsullied water for generations to come.

column1: In fact
column2: at the beginning of September
column3: a private security firm hired by Energy Transfer Partners
column4: the company responsible for pipeline construction
column5: indiscriminately unleashed vicious attack dogs on water protectors
column6: press
column7: and supporters — for reasons as yet unknown.

column1: During the savage attack
column2: a pregnant woman
column3: young girl
column4: and many others suffered serious dog bites thanks to the ineptitude of the dogs’ handlers. Afterward
column5: a warrant for inciting a riot was issued Democracy Now! journalist Amy Goodman — for doing her job
column6: filming events as they happened — though charges were subsequently thrown out.

column1: Although ETP and some law enforcement officers defended the barbarous actions of the private security mercenaries
column2: the Guardian now reports that — because the guards lacked proper licensing — they could now face criminal charges. On Wednesday
column3: the Morton County Sheriff’s Office made the determination that “dog handlers were not properly licensed to do security work in the state of North Dakota.”

column1: Bob Frost
column2: owner of Ohio-based Frost Kennels
column3: told the Guardian
column4: “All the proper protocols … were already done. I pulled my guys out the next day because we weren’t there to go to war with these protesters.”

column1: Frost insisted he had cooperated with authorities investigating the incident — but the sheriff’s department disagrees. Seven handlers and dogs were deployed to the scene in early September
column2: allegedly in response to reports of trespassers; but
column3: according to the Guardian
column4: police have only managed to identify two people.

column1: The sheriff’s department claims Frost has not provided necessary information
column2: and unnamed security officials cited in the report said that “there were no intentions of using the dogs or handlers for security work. However
column3: because of the protest events
column4: the dogs were deployed as a method of trying to keep the protesters under control.”

column1: In a statement cited by the Guardian
column2: Morton County Captain Jay Gruebele said
column3: “Although lists of security employees have been provided
column4: there is no way of confirming whether the list is accurate or if names have been purposely withheld.”

column1: Water protectors
column2: in the meantime
column3: are left to deal with absurdly disproportionate state violence — and the altogether unacceptable
column4: disrespectful
column5: and demeaning insult of being relegated to dog kennels after being arrested for exercising their rights.

column1: As Lakota Country Times editor
column2: Brandon Ecoffey
column3: wrote in an editorial Thursday

column1: Over the course of the last several months the abuse of detainees by Morton County Law Enforcement has overstepped every boundary guaranteed by the American constitution. Water protectors have been seen being bound and hooded by police. People are being stripped searched and abused within their jail for misdemeanor crimes. And police have employed the use of mass surveillance through drones on the protector camps. This isn’t a war zone this is North Dakota.
Claire Bernish writes for TheFreeThoughtProject.com
column2: where this article first appeared . Share:"	FAKE

column1: You Can't Be Intersectional While at the Same Time Being Elitist and Exclusionary	"By Djuan Wash / filmsforaction.org

column1: A sharpened debate: Is it ethical to not vote this year for president?	"The most controversial presidential campaign  in modern American history has sharpened a long-standing debate: Is it ethical to not vote?
More than 92 million Americans who were eligible to vote four years ago didn't cast ballots. But politics in the Age of Trump has prompted editorial writers
column2: Democratic partisans and even some Republicans to argue that Donald Trump is so unacceptable as a potential commander in chief that citizens have a heightened duty to show up to cast their ballot against him.

column1: Some Trump supporters
column2: presumably including those who chant ""Lock her up!"" at GOP rallies
column3: feel the same way about Hillary Clinton.

column1: Let's be clear: Elections aren’t just about who votes
column2: but who doesn’t vote
column3: first lady Michelle Obama said last week at a Clinton campaign rally at La Salle University in Philadelphia
column4: with a cautionary message aimed at Millennials. ""And if you vote for someone other than Hillary
column5: or if you don’t vote at all
column6: then you are helping to elect Hillary’s opponent.  And the stakes are far too high to take that chance
column7: too high.""

column1: Some among the anti-Hillary brigades have decided
column2: in deference to their exquisite sensibilities
column3: to stay at home on Election Day
column4: rather than vote for Mrs. Clinton
column5: she wrote in Friday's The Wall Street Journal. But she warned
column6: ""Her election alone is what stands between the American nation and the reign of the most unstable
column7: proudly uninformed
column8: psychologically unfit president ever to enter the White House.""

column1: On Team Trump
column2: New Jersey Gov. Chris Christie and former New York mayor Rudy Giuliani are among those who argue it is Clinton whose election would pose a threat to the republic. And some Republicans who oppose Trump make the case for sending a message by supporting a third-party candidate or not voting at all.

column1: Former Florida governor Jeb Bush
column2: vanquished by Trump in the GOP primaries
column3: told reporters Thursday after delivering a guest lecture at Harvard University that he planned to vote
column4: but not for Trump or Clinton. ""If everybody didn't vote
column5: that would be a pretty powerful political statement
column6: wouldn't it?"" he said.

column1: Trump's temperament — criticism of Muslim-American Gold Star parents
column2: a late-night Twitter storm against a former beauty queen — and policy views that include skepticism of the NATO alliance and admiration for Russian President Vladimir Putin have fueled alarm even among some life-long Republicans about whether he should be trusted with the nation's highest office. Former president George H.W. Bush and 2012 presidential nominee Mitt Romney are among those who have said they won't vote for Trump.

column1: But concerns about Clinton
column2: including questions about her honesty and trustworthiness
column3: have complicated the calculations by some voters about just whom to support. All that has boosted Libertarian candidate Gary Johnson
column4: whose 7.3% level of support in the RealClearPolitics average of recent nationwide surveys is higher than any third-party candidate on Election Day since Ross Perot in 1996.

column1: When both major-party candidates get negative ratings from most Americans
column2: will more voters just stay home?

column1: Inspirational contenders tend to do best in drawing voters to the polls. The highest rate of turnout since World War II was 63.8% of the voting-eligible population in 1960
column2: when a youthful Massachusetts senator John F. Kennedy narrowly won the White House. After decades of more-or-less steady decline
column3: it spiked again to 61.6% in 2008
column4: when Illinois senator Barack Obama was elected the nation's first African-American president.

column1: But scholars say fear can be as compelling as hope.
Fear is a pretty big motivator
column2: just as is enthusiasm
column3: says Michael Dimmock
column4: president of the non-partisan Pew Research Center
column5: which has studied voters and non-voters. Turnout in presidential elections tends to dip in years such as 1996 and 2000
column6: when voters don't see the stakes as particularly high or the differences between the two major candidates as particularly sharp.

column1: Neither factor would apply this time. And high levels of interest this year may signal higher turnout.
In a Pew study released this summer
column2: more than eight in 10 said they were following news about the candidates closely
column3: the highest level of interest in a quarter century. Eight in 10 said they had thought ""quite a lot"" about the election. Three of four said it ""really matters"" who wins.

column1: That said
column2: two-thirds called the tone of the campaign too negative
column3: and only four in 10 were satisfied with their choices
column4: the lowest level in two decades. Just one in 10 said either candidate would make a good president. Four in 10 said neither would.

column1: We've never had candidates like this for president
column2: says Michael McDonald
column3: a political scientist at the University of Florida who heads the United States Elections Project. He turns to Senate races for comparison
column4: citing the 2010 Delaware contest when Democrat Chris Coons crushed Republican Christine O'Donnell. She was a controversial Tea Party-backed contender who
column5: among other things
column6: aired a TV ad denying she was a witch.

column1: Despite a contest that wasn't seen as competitive
column2: turnout in the First State was among the highest in the country last year.

column1: My guess is people are going to be activated to vote against these candidates
column2: McDonald says. ""They may not like their particular candidate ... but they certainly don't like the other party's candidate.""

column1: It's not: 'How much do I like these people?'"" says Jan Leighley
column2: an American University professor and co-author of Who Votes Now? Demographics
column3: Issues
column4: Inequality and Turnout in the United States. ""It's: 'Does it make a difference between this person I do not like opposed to that person I do not like?'""

column1: This year
column2: Trump has heightened that issue with rhetoric that seems ""outside the scope of reasonable conversation or respectable public dialogue
column3: she says. If he continues to do that
column4: she says the question for voters could be this: ""Is one being irresponsible by not casting a ballot?""

column1: In the first
column2: tentative clues about turnout this year
column3: McDonald says requests for absentee ballots in congressional districts in Iowa
column4: Maine and North Carolina likely to favor Clinton have been running slightly ahead of requests at this point four years ago. Requests in districts in those three states likely to favor Trump have been running slightly lower.

column1: Most Americans think there's an obligation to vote
column2: says Jason Brennan
column3: a Georgetown University professor and author of The Ethics of Voting
column4: though the percentages may be inflated because they think that's what they're supposed to say. He doesn't agree
column5: likening it to a lottery
column6: when an individual ticket or vote isn't likely to make a difference.

column1: That said
column2: he generally does vote himself.

column1: A look at the demographics of those least likely to vote explains why Democrats are more focused on turnout efforts than Republicans. A majority of eligible Latino voters and of voters under 30 didn't go to the polls in 2012. Both groups support Clinton over Trump
column2: and they make up significant blocs in some battleground states — Millennials in Colorado and Virginia
column3: Hispanics in Florida and Nevada.

column1: Clinton has vowed to encourage 3 million new Americans to register to vote before Nov. 8. She and her top campaign surrogates increasingly are focused on registering voters before state deadlines loom and encouraging supporters to cast early ballots.
That said
column2: Trump has done well among another group of voters not inclined to cast ballots: Those who don't have a college education. Only a third of eligible voters who don't have a high school diploma voted in 2012
column3: and less than half of those with only a high school education did so.

column1: Most non-voters stay away from the polls not because they are making an ideological statement but because they say they are too busy
column2: or they don't like either candidate
column3: or they don't think it matters if they vote. As a group
column4: they are younger
column5: less educated and less affluent than voters. They express less interest in politics and public affairs
column6: although a USA TODAY/Suffolk University poll of unlikely voters in 2012 found two-thirds of them said they were registered.

column1: They are much more likely than voters to favor an activist government; eight in 10 said the government plays an important role in their lives. And the USA TODAY survey found they supported Obama over Romney by more than 2-1
column2: a far wider margin than those who cast ballots.

column1: Get-out-the-vote efforts
column2: a standard part of presidential campaigns for decades
column3: have started earlier than ever this year
column4: in part because of the rise in early voting. An estimated four in 10 voters will have cast early or absentee ballots before the polls open on Nov. 8. The GOTV campaigns also have taken on a fiercer intensity than
column5: say
column6: when the choice was between Barack Obama and Mitt Romney.

column1: I agree with the premise of The Arizona Republic

column7: urging voters to go to the polls to support someone else.

column1: We Are About To Witness A Once In A Century Event But don’t let that obscure the bigger reality. While gold could fall a bit more in coming days and weeks
column2: the table has been set for the next act in a massive – perhaps once-in-a-century – bull market in the metal

column1: America’s plans for infrastructure will likely be followed by similar efforts within the E.U.

column2: however

column1: Speaking of Europe

column4: in the process granting the U.S. major trade partners. Many still speak with wonder at the scope of that plan. The Chinese analog

column9: by some estimates 12 times the size of the Marshall Plan. Its goal is to connect more than 60 countries
column10: which together have 4.4 billion inhabitants and currently account for nearly 40 percent of the world’s economy . And OBOR is just the start of development in the East.

column1: OBOR and the ongoing economic activity it will foster will utterly dwarf the impact China’s development already has had on the global economy. China today is the largest consumer of just about all major commodities. Multiply Chinese consumption today by many-fold and you get the long-term message of the past week’s unprecedented stock market turbulence.
With zigs and zags

column9: indeed
column10: within sight.

column2: as the U.S. spends perhaps $1 trillion to repair its crumbling bridges
column3: its ancient water pipes
column4: its highways

column8: in which China leads the world) that allow China to generate power it can transmit to countries ranging from Germany to Japan to India. This electricity will be needed to power electric cars and provide lighting in dense urban areas that have yet to be built. Wang Min

column12: indeed
column13: meaningless.

column1: Attorney general nominee offers careful backing of Obama policies	"Attorney general nominee Loretta E. Lynch carefully backed the Obama administration’s policies on immigration and drug enforcement Wednesday

column1: Instead
