column3: “I don’t see any reason to doubt the reasonableness of those views.”

column1: Sen. David Vitter (R-La.)
column2: who has said he plans to vote against Lynch
column3: said he was “very disappointed and frustrated” with her responses.

column1: “I have a huge concern regarding what I think is the president’s illegal
column2: unconstitutional executive amnesty
column3: and I have a huge concern of the fact that you think it is within the law
column4: ” Vitter said. Sen. Jeff Sessions (R-Ala.) agreed with Vitter and said after the hearing that he will vote against Lynch.

column1: Lynch is the first Obama Cabinet nominee to face a confirmation hearing since Republicans took over the Senate this year. The department she has been selected to oversee has been a regular target of Republicans’ ire on a range of issues
column2: including investigations into the Internal Revenue Service and the attacks in Benghazi
column3: Libya
column4: and a botched gun-trafficking operation run by the Bureau of Alcohol
column5: Tobacco
column6: Firearms and Explosives.

column1: Sen. Charles E. Schumer (D-N.Y.) asked his colleagues not to “turn this exceptional nominee into a political point-scoring exercise” by badgering her on immigration and the controversy over the investigation into the IRS.
He described Lynch as “one of the keenest legal minds that our country has to offer
column2: someone who has excelled at every stage of her education and her career
column3: while cultivating a reputation as someone who was level-headed
column4: fair
column5: judicious and eminently likable.”

column1: Holder — whose six-year tenure overshadowed Wednesday’s hearing — had a particularly rocky relationship with Congress. Lynch has chaired the Justice Department committee that advises him on policy decisions.

Among the points of contention between the administration and Congress has been the Justice Department’s policy on marijuana in response to the legalization of the drug in Colorado and Washington state. The department announced that it would not challenge those state laws and said that in prosecutions it would prioritize marijuana offenses­ such as distribution to minors.
Asked about her own views on marijuana
column2: Lynch said she does not support legalization.

column1: Sessions asked Lynch whether she agreed with a remark made by President Obama — and published last year in the New Yorker magazine — that the drug was no more dangerous than alcohol.
“I certainly don’t hold that view and don’t agree with that view of marijuana
column2: ” Lynch said. “I certainly think that the president was speaking from his personal experience and personal opinion
column3: neither of which I’m able to share.”

column1: When pressed on the legality of the National Security Agency’s controversial surveillance programs
column2: Lynch replied that she believed they were “constitutional and effective.”

column1: If Lynch is confirmed as the 83rd attorney general
column2: she will take the reins of the Justice Department at a moment of high tension between law enforcement and minority communities across the country.

column1: In her testimony
column2: she emphasized her strong bonds with law enforcement and her desire to heal the rifts between police and the communities they are tasked with protecting.

column1: One of her priorities
column2: she said
column3: will be to work to strengthen “the vital relationships between our courageous law enforcement personnel and all the communities we serve.”

column1: “In my career
column2: I have seen this relationship flourish — I have seen law enforcement forge unbreakable bonds with community residents and have seen violence-ravaged communities come together to honor officers who risked all to protect them
column3: ” Lynch said. “As attorney general
column4: I will draw all voices into this important discussion.”

column1: Lynch was accompanied by her husband
column2: Stephen Hargrove; her father
column3: the Rev. Lorenzo Lynch
column4: who traveled from Durham
column5: N.C.
column6: and sat behind her; and her only surviving brother
column7: Leonzo Lynch
column8: who is a preacher in Charlotte. Her other brother
column9: Lorenzo Jr.
column10: a former Navy SEAL
column11: died in 2009. She placed his Navy SEAL trident pin on the witness table in front of her while she testified.

column1: A group of two dozen of Lynch’s fellow U.S. attorneys from across the country were in Washington
column2: watching the hearing together on television from the Justice Department building. In the audience at the hearing was a group of Lynch’s Delta Sigma Theta sorority sisters
column3: dressed in bright red.

column1: Lynch told the committee about her family and the values instilled in her by her parents
column2: both from North Carolina.

column1: “My mother
column2: Lorine
column3: who was unable to travel here today
column4: is a retired English teacher and librarian for whom education was the key to a better life
column5: ” Lynch said. “She recalls people in her rural community pressing a dime or a quarter into her hands to support her college education. As a young woman
column6: she refused to use segregated restrooms
column7: because they did not represent the America in which she believed.”

column1: “She instilled in me an abiding love of literature and learning
column2: and taught me the value of hard work and sacrifice
column3: ” Lynch said.

column1: Lynch’s father
column2: a fourth-generation Baptist preacher
column3: opened his Greensboro church in the early 1960s to those planning sit-ins and marches­
column4: standing with the protesters while carrying her on his shoulders.

column1: “As I come before you today in this historic chamber
column2: I still stand on my father’s shoulders
column3: as well as on the shoulders of all those who have gone before me and who dreamed of making the promise of America a reality for all and worked to achieve that goal
column4: ” Lynch said. “I believe in the promise of America because I have lived the promise of America.”"	REAL

column1: The end of white Christian America is nigh: Why the country’s youth are abandoning religious conservatism	"There’s been a lot of media attention recently to the changing demographics of the United States
column2: where
column3: at current rates
column4: people who identify as “white” are expected to become a minority by the year 2050. But in many ways
column5: the shift in national demographics has been accelerated beyond even that. New data from the American Values Atlas shows that while white people continue to be the majority in all but 4 states in the country
column6: white Christians are the minority in a whopping 19 states. And
column7: nationwide
column8: Americans who identify as Protestant are now in the minority for the first time ever
column9: clocking in at a mere 47 percent of Americans and falling.

column1: The most obvious reason for this change is growing racial diversity. Most Americans still identify as Christian
column2: but “Christian” is a group that is less white and less Protestant than it has been at any time in history. The massive growth in Hispanic Catholics
column3: in particular
column4: has been a major factor in this shift in the ethnic and religious identity of this country. White Catholics used to outnumber Hispanic Catholics 3 to 1 in the 2000s
column5: but now it’s only by a 2 to 1 margin.

column1: But another major reason religious diversity is outpacing the growth of racial/ethnic diversity is largely due to the explosive growth in non-belief among Americans. One in five Americans now identifies as religiously unaffiliated. In 13 states
column2: the “nones” are the largest religious group. Non-religious people now equal Catholics in number
column3: and their proportion is likely to grow dramatically
column4: as young people are by far the most non-religious group in the country. This isn’t some kind of side effect of their youth
column5: either. As Adam Lee has noted
column6: the millennial generation is becoming less religious as they age.

column1: These changes explain the modern political landscape as well as any economic indicator. While not all white Christians are conservative
column2: these changing numbers definitely suggest that conservative Christians are rapidly losing their grip on power. And while some non-white Christians are conservative
column3: their numbers are not making up for what the Christian right is losing. And whether conservative leaders are aware of the exact numbers or not
column4: it’s clear that they sense that change is in the air. Just by speaking to young people
column5: turning on your TV
column6: or reading the Internet
column7: you can sense the way the country is lurching away from conservative Christian values and towards a more liberal
column8: secular outlook. And conservative Christians aren’t taking these changes well at all.

column1: To look at the Christian right now is to see a people who know they are losing power and are desperately trying to reassert dominance before it’s lost altogether. The most obvious example of this is the frenzy of anti-abortion activity in recent years. Anti-choice forces have controlled the Republican Party since the late ’70s
column2: but only in the past few years have they concentrated so singlemindedly on trying to destroy legal abortion in wide swaths of the country. In 2011 alone
column3: states passed nearly three times as many abortion restrictions as they had in any previous year.

column1: None of this is a reaction to any changes in people’s sexual behavior or reproductive choices. It’s not like there was a spike in abortions causing this panic. In fact
column2: the abortion rate has been declining. And despite continuing media panic over adolescent sexuality
column3: the fact is that teenagers are waiting longer to have sex
column4: on average
column5: than in the past. Despite this
column6: not only are you seeing a dramatic increase in attacks on legal abortion
column7: the Christian right has expanded its attacks to contraception access
column8: suggesting that something has worked them into a panic they believe can only be resolved by trying to reassert their religious and sexual values.

column1: That something isn’t changes in sexual behavior
column2: but it’s reasonable to believe it’s because of changes in sexual values. People might not be having more sex
column3: but they are feeling less guilty about the sex they are having. Since Gallup first started polling people in 2001 on moral views
column4: acceptance of consensual sex between adults has skyrocketed. In a decade’s time
column5: acceptance of premarital sex swelled from 53% to 66% of Americans and acceptance of gay Americans grew from a mere 38% to a majority of Americans. Even polyamory has become more acceptable for Americans
column6: rising from being accepted by 5% of Americans to 14%. The fact that these changes in attitude are rising alongside the growth of irreligiosity is not a coincidence. More perhaps even than the 1960s
column7: Americans are in a period of questioning rigid sexual and religious mores
column8: and concluding
column9: in increasing numbers
column10: that they are not down with guilt-tripping people for victimless behavior and demanding conformity for its own sake. Some of them–now a whopping 22% of Americans!–are leaving religion entirely. Some are continuing in their faith but choosing to interpret their values differently than Christian conservatives would like. And so we see Christian conservatives cracking down in a desperate bid to regain control. They claim that they’re being oppressed by increasing tolerancefor religious diversity. They have latched onto
column11: with some success
column12: the claim that “religious freedom” requires giving Christians the right to oppress others. The Republican Party is in complete thrall to the religious right
column13: to the point where giving the Christian right one go-nowhere symbolic bill instead of another one created a major political crisis. The irony is that this panic-based overreach is just making the situation worse for the Christian right. One of the biggest reasons the secularization trend has accelerated in recent years is that young people see the victim complex and the sex policing of the Christian right and it’s turning them off. And they’re not just rejecting conservative Christianity but the entire idea of organized religion altogether. In other words
column14: the past few years have created a self-perpetuating cycle: Christian conservatives
column15: in a panic over changing demographics
column16: start cracking down. In reaction
column17: more people give up on religion. That causes the Christian right to panic more and crack down more. In the end
column18: Christian conservatives are going to hasten their own demise by trying to save themselves. Not that any of us should be crying for them."	REAL

column24: one can test and further improve nuclear weapons without a physical explosion
column25: and North Korea would need to switch to methods of mathematical analysis."" ""What will determine the economic development of North Korea - Sangun or reforms?"" ""Reforms
column26: definitely. Sangun - the policy of the supremacy of the army - appeared in the mid-1990s
column27: when the country was in dire straits. The country was forced to unite as a military camp and create the mobilization economy. Sangun made it possible to overcome a very difficult period in the history of North Korea
column28: and the country continued its development

column1: Hacking Accusations Against Russia Are Sign of Washington's Desperation	"Hacking Accusations Against Russia Are Sign of Washington's Desperation
With Putin winning across the board
column2: Washington is struggling to contain its humilitation Originally appeared at Strategic Culture Foundation

column1: The Obama administration is now accusing Russia of cyber-crime and trying to disrupt the US presidential election. The claim is so far-fetched
column2: it is hardly credible. More credible is that the US is reeling from Putin’s stunning humiliation earlier this week.

column1: Since June
column2: US media and supporters of Democrat presidential contender Hillary Clinton have been blaming Russian state-sponsored hackers for breaking into the Democratic party’s database.

column1: It is further alleged that Moscow is stealthily trying to influence the outcome of the election
column2: by releasing damaging information on Clinton
column3: which might favor Republican candidate Donald Trump.

column1: Russia has vehemently denied any connection to the cyber-crime charges
column2: or trying to disrupt the November poll.

column1: Now the Obama administration has stepped into the fray by openly accusing Russia. «US government officially accuses Russia of hacking campaign to interfere with elections»
column2: reported the Washington Post.

column1: This takes the row to a whole new level. No longer are the insinuations a matter of private
column2: partisan opinion. The US government is officially labelling the Russian state for cyber-crime and political subversion.

column1: Predictably
column2: following the latest allegations
column3: there are calls among American lawmakers for ramping up more economic sanctions against Russia. While US intelligence figures are urging for retaliatory cyber-attacks on Russian government facilities.

column1: Vladimir Putin’s spokesman Dmitry Peskov derided the US claims as «rubbish». He noted that the Kremlin’s computer system incurs hundreds of hacking attempts every day
column2: many of which can be traced to American origin
column3: but Moscow doesn’t turn around and blame the US government for such cyber-attacks.

column1: There are several signs that the latest brouhaha out of Washington is a bogus diversion.
As with previous Russian-hacker claims by the Democrats and US media
column2: there is no evidence presented by the Obama administration to support its grave allegations against the Russian government. Assertion without facts does not meet a minimal standard of proof.

column1: When reports emerged in June – again through the Washington Post – that the Democrat National Committee (DNC) was hacked by Russian agents
column2: the allegation relied on investigations by a private cyber security firm by the name of CrowdStrike. The firm is linked by personnel to the NATO-affiliated
column3: anti-Russian think tank Atlantic Council. Again no verifiable evidence was presented then
column4: just the word of a dubious partisan source.

column1: Back then the Russian scare story
column2: for that’s what it was
column3: served as a useful diversion from far more important issues. Such as the 19
column4: 000 emails released from the DNC database showing that the party chiefs had preordained Clinton’s presidential nomination over her Democrat rival Bernie Sanders. Much-vaunted «US democracy» was exposed as a fraud
column5: and so the Washington establishment quickly went into damage-limitation mode by smearing Russia.

column1: It was the whistleblower site Wikileaks
column2: run by Australian journalist Julian Assange
column3: that released the embarrassing emails. It had nothing to do with Russia. Assange has since hinted that his source was within the Democrat party itself.

column1: This is where it gets really explosive. Assange has vowed to release more emails that will prove that Clinton as Secretary of State back in 2011-2012 masterminded the supply of weapons and money to Islamist terror networks in Libya and Syria for the objective of regime change. Furthermore
column2: Assange says that the emails prove that Clinton lied under oath to Congress when she denied in 2013 that she was had any involvement in facilitating arms to the jihadists.

column1: Assange has said that Wikileaks is going to publish the incriminating emails on Clinton’s alleged gun-running to terrorists this month. If the evidence stands up
column2: Clinton could be prosecuted for perjury as well as treason in aiding and abetting official terrorist enemies of the US.

column1: The exposure of an American presidential candidate as being involved in state sponsorship of terrorism while serving as a top government official is a powerful incentive for the Obama administration to find a lurid diversion.
Hence
column2: the latest charges by the US government against Russia as perpetrating cyber-crime and of trying to subvert American democracy.

column1: This is just one more illustration of how irrational and unhinged the US government has become.
Day by day
column2: it seems
column3: leads to more damning revelations of Washington’s complicity in illegal wars
column4: covert subversion of foreign states
column5: and systematic collusion with terrorist networks which have inflicted thousands of deaths on American citizens
column6: among many more thousands of other innocent civilians around the world.

column1: In addition to exposure by sources like Wikileaks
column2: much of revelation about US criminality and state-sponsored banditry has emerged from Russia’s principled military intervention in Syria. Russia’s intervention has not only helped salvage the Syrian nation from a foreign conspiracy of covert war for regime change. Russia’s intervention has also brought into clear focus the systematic links between Washington and its terrorist proxy army working on its behalf in Syria.

column1: Washington’s mask of moral and legal superiority has been ripped from its face. And what the world is seeing is the vile ugliness beneath.
Such is Washington’s ignominious fall from pretend-grace to its grim
column2: odious reality that Vladimir Putin this week was empowered to speak from the moral high ground.

column1: In announcing Russia’s unilateral suspension of a 2002 accord with the US for the disposal of nuclear-weapon-grade plutonium
column2: Putin went much
column3: much further. He gave Washington a list of ultimatums that included the US ending its trumped-up sanctions against Russia
column4: with financial compensation
column5: as well as the scaling back of NATO forces from Russia’s border.

column1: In other words
column2: the Russian leader was talking truth to American power in a way that megalomaniac Washington
column3: with all its ridiculous delusions of «exceptionalism»
column4: has never ever heard before.

column1: American pretensions of greatness are eroding like a castle built on sand. Washington’s criminal enterprises and specifically the complicity in terrorism for the supreme crime of foreign aggression are being glaringly exposed.
And now with due contempt
column2: Russia is putting manners on Washington. It must be excruciating the humiliation for the narcissistic American tyrant to be treated with the disrespect that it deserves and which is long overdue.

column1: Moreover
column2: the humiliation is not just in the eyes of the world. The American people can see the true ugly nature of their rulers too. When a giant banner declaring «Putin a peacemaker» was unfurled off Manhattan bridge in New York City this weekend
column3: the popular enthusiasm went viral.

column1: Washington is reeling from Putin’s righteous courage to call it out for what it is. The truth-telling is hard to take for this unipolar unicorn. Its deluded myth-making about its own virtues are being stripped bare.
What’s going on here is a world-class
column2: historic exposure of American power as a nefarious excrescence on humanity.

column1: The reaction is understandable: foaming-at-the-mouth
column2: desperate
column3: hysterical and panicked. Accusing Russia of hacking into the American «democratic process» is a wild attempt to divert from the paramount issues: Washington’s exposed descent into a vile morass of its own making; the emperor is a criminal; the people know it; and a genuine world leader like Vladimir Putin has the temerity to lay it on the line to this has-been."	FAKE

Why conservatives refuse to believe Obama is Christian	"The percentage selecting “Muslim” is notably higher than in other polls conducted on this topic. This difference likely depends on how the question is phrased. Previous survey questions about Obama’s religion tend to sound like a pop quiz — such as “do you happen to know the religious faith of Barack Obama?” But by asking “what Obama believes deep down?” I was intentionally granting respondents license to stray from the pesident’s self-reported Christian faith. This reveals a prevalent willingness to distrust this pesident or categorize him as “the other” in terms of religion. Of course
column2: respondents could also be “cheerleading” — using a survey question to express their general dislike of Obama rather than a genuine view about his religious faith. But
column3: if these results were largely driven by anti-Obama cheerleading
column4: we should expect more respondents
column5: especially Republicans
column6: to choose the very unpopular category of “atheist.” Relatively few do so.

column1: Previous ruminations on the Obama-is-a-secret-Muslim theme have suggested various sources for it: ignorance

column1: Theodoridis’ post was inspired by Wisconsin Governor Scott Walker’s remarks that he didn’t know whether Obama is a Christian. But do other elected Republicans suggest that Obama is not only not a Christian

column3: of course
column4: and the number of constituents who actually listen to these speeches is infinitesimal. But if elected Republicans aren’t afraid to question Obama’s religious commitments for the permanent record
column5: think of what they might say to constituents in smaller settings
column6: or the well that they are drawing from when they make remarks in Congressional sessions for which they receive no pushback
column7: and in fact receive encouragement.

column1: Republicans drew from recent conservative complaints that Obama refuses to say that Islamic State and other terrorist groups are “Islamic
column2: ” that he doesn’t take the threat of terrorism seriously
column3: and he is insufficiently protective of American exceptionalism.

column1: On February 24
column3: Rep. Mark Walker (R-NC) said on the House floor that his constituents “shared with me their frustration at the ambiguous language from this administration in describing the evils of radical Islamist terrorism
column4: ” and that he himself has “grown weary at the timidity” of Obama
column5: who “continues to be defensive
column6: at best.” He went on:

column1: At first glance
column2: the silence appears to be passive or poor leadership. But I am inclined to believe that the President’s posture is not one of weakness but
column3: rather
column4: an intentional directive in both rhetoric and action. It appears that his promise to take our country in a fundamentally new direction is being played out in realtime. Instead of defending our liberty and our way of life
column5: which is the most charitable in the world
column6: our President seems to scoff at the belief that our country has been uniquely blessed by God. I would be remiss today if I did not pause and remember our Egyptian Christian brothers in the recent barbaric attacks in Libya. ISIS murdered innocent husbands and fathers who clearly died for their faith and their beliefs. Just this morning
column7: we hear further reports out of Syria that Islamic State militants have abducted dozens of Christians
column8: including women and children. Weeks prior
column9: the President chastised the Christian community for getting on their judgmental high horses. Yet
column10: in describing our martyred brothers from Egypt
column11: the President refused to even utter the word
column12: “Christian.” The undermining of our beliefs has become an issue with this President.

column1: Contrary to Walker’s statement
column2: which echoes a claim circulating in conservative circles that Obama did not identify the Coptic victims of the Islamic State massacre as Christians
column3: at last week’s summit on countering religious extremism
column4: Obama noted that that Islamic State’s “slaughter of EgyptianChristians in Libya has shocked the world.” Notice
column5: in Walker’s speech
column6: the juxtaposition of the statement that Obama “seems to scoff at the belief that our country has been uniquely blessed by God” (i.e.
column7: he’s not a Christian) with his own remembrance of the murdered Egyptian Christians “who clearly died for their faith and their beliefs.”

column1: Some of the floor statements come from ardent Christian supporters of Israel
column2: who contrast Obama negatively with Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu. In a February 5

column8: worse

column11: in February 2
column12: 2015 floor remarks
column13: asked

column17: added

column20: under their watch

column28: adding

column31: after laying out a litany of Obama’s alleged sins in failing to recognizing “that radical Islam is a threat to our very existence and way of life
column32: ” Gohmert delivered a brief lecture on how Christians are supposed to act (and govern): I have Christian friends that say: Yes
column33: but as Christians

column1: Why Donald Trump is beating Fox News -- and GOP rivals	"Mel Robbins is a CNN commentator
column2: legal analyst
column3: best-selling author and keynote speaker. In 2014
column4: she was named outstanding news talk-radio host by the Gracie Awards. The opinions expressed in this commentary are solely those of the author

column1: (CNN) If you understand nothing else about Donald Trump
column2: understand this:

column1: He has a particular mindset we see all the time in business -- he's ""the disrupter.""
The disrupter is someone whose entire ""brand"" is to break the mold
column2: to turn the way we do things on its head. Amazon did this with retail
column3: Uber did it with taxi services
column4: Airbnb did it with travel
column5: Tinder did it with dating
column6: Slack is doing it with email
column7: Spotify is doing it with music
column8: peer-to-peer lending is changing banking.

column1: Disrupters don't fix what's broken because they don't innovate from inside the system. They break the mold
column2: change our thinking about the mold and then hand us the new rules for how things work.

column1: Just look at the Big Five companies that drive the Internet economy -- all disrupters -- Apple
column2: Microsoft
column3: Google
column4: Amazon and Facebook. They were early movers
column5: they played by their own rules. First they disrupted how we do business online
column6: and now they define it. And they control it. Apple just reported its highest earnings ever. Looks like disruption is working.

column1: Today every taxi company in America could band together
column2: and they still would not stop the power of Uber. That is because when you gain enough momentum
column3: you dominate the market and the conversation.

column1: In his effect on everything from Fox News to the Koch Brothers to the newspapers that endorse candidates
column2: Trump has disrupted every single aspect of the game of politics and created new rules -- and based on the polls
column3: what he's done is working.

column1: And so far
column2: most of the political establishment has been wrong about what this all means. They said he wouldn't last and now he's leading in the polls. They said he wouldn't disclose his financial information or quit reality TV and he did both. They said that every insulting
column3: ridiculous
column4: inaccurate and offensive thing that Trump has said would hurt him. No sign of this. They said no network would bow to his demands for shorter debates -- but they did.

column1: Who knows what will happen when the Republican National Committee has to officially pick its candidate for president
column2: but -- holy cow -- it sure will be interesting to watch. And who will we be watching? Trump.

column1: We can call Trump the carnival barker or the political side show
column2: but discrediting the one who is wielding new power is what we do when we lose control of the negotiation. It's not politics
column3: it's business -- as usual. This is why Trump understands that he can ignore it.

column1: He also understands something powerful: leverage. He is above Fox News
column2: because he IS the news. And he knows that what he says AND where he goes is the story and therefore it is the business asset. So he is keeping control of that asset.

column1: The establishment can't play by the disrupter's rules
column2: because the rules are designed to destroy it.

column1: The Republican establishment has already lost. Trump will be the party's next nominee no matter how many times he says he won't call Megyn Kelly a bimbo. It doesn't matter how many backroom meetings the Koch brothers organize or what Reince Priebus does to rally RNC delegates. It's over.
The newspaper endorsements are also irrelevant
column2: as are the fringe politicians and reality stars who are lining up to endorse Trump. They are all too late.

column1: The only thing that can beat Donald Trump now is the one thing he doesn't control: Americans who don't want his services as president of the United States.
And the only way they will make a difference if there are enough of them -- enough liberals
column2: Democrats
column3: independents
column4: and yes
column5: even some Republicans and conservatives -- who can appreciate the appeal of a disrupter
column6: but don't want one to lead the country."	REAL

column1: Election 2016 and the Weaponization of the American Public	"Waking Times
With the election behind us
column2: and the cloud of 24/7 candidate propaganda lifting
column3: some deep truths about the state of American society are becoming evident
column4: and the slow-coming
column5: but predictable effects of social engineering are more visible than ever.

column1: Decades of fear programming
column2: dumbing down
column3: authoritarian leadership
column4: violence entrainment
column5: divisiveness
column6: crooked economics
column7: moral subterfuge
column8: and physical pollution have changed the social fabric of the nation. The result is escalating madness
column9: tension
column10: chaos
column11: violence
column12: and mindless self-destruction as people unleash their frustration
column13: hate and rage onto their neighbors
column14: burning their own communities to the ground.

column1: How is it that hundreds
column2: thousands
column3: even millions of Americans can be triggered to hit the streets in violent protest over soft social issues
column4: while life and death matters such as war are completely left off the register
column5: going entirely unchallenged by the public? How is it that in 2016 the main issues driving people to action are the socially divisive ones pitting Americans against each other along race
column6: gender and political beliefs? Why are we so willing to hurt each other
column7: yet so unwilling to confront the machine? Predictive Programming – A Snapshot of the Future

column1: In the climactic scene of the 2014 film
column2: Kingsman: The Secret Service
column3: the hero is in a church among a congregation of people being whipped into a frenzy of hate by a bigoted pastor. Then
column4: a signal is transmitted from the film’s villain to all the smartphones in the building
column5: and everyone enters a trance. A mindless rage of murderous violence ensues
column6: and no one has any idea why they are killing each other.

column1: While it passes for entertainment
column2: it’s impossible to ignore the parallels in today’s real world. Take
column3: for example this scene from the children’s restaurant
column4: Chuck E. Cheese’s:

column1: Social media makes it possible to trigger many people in an instant
column2: and now we can easily record acts of stupidity and mob violence and share them with the world. Violence against real human beings is now just as entertaining as scripted Hollywood violence. All some people need is the right signal and they’ll go nuts.

column1: This is happening right now around the nation as the political left refuses to accept the outcome of the election
column2: staging protests
column3: beating people in the streets and threatening to kill Trump supporters.

column1: Meanwhile
column2: people on the extreme right are harassing and abusing immigrants around the nation
column3: as though a Trump victory implies a holocaust is in order. Students in this high school chant ‘White Power’ while walking down the halls.

column1: White students at this middle school scream ‘Build the Wall’ during lunchtime:
The fact that children and America’s youth are engaging in such mindless stupidity is terrifying
column2: but it’s a direct result of the condition of their parents
column3: and the American family has been under attack for generations. Here’s a sickening look at how some are transferring their rage and confusion onto the budding generation: Pawns Fighting Pawns on the Grand Chessboard

column1: We are in the throws of a cultural revolution engineered by the likes of billionaire George Soros who uses his wealth to finance social unrest in America and in Europe.
Our lives are being manipulated by the powerful
column2: and our frustrations with this corrupt
column3: authoritarian matrix are skillfully directed onto issues that will only cause further public division
column4: never onto the problems created by the elite themselves . It is to their advantage that we hurt each other
column5: as it prevents us from challenging their rule while giving them license to crack down evermore.

column1: Take for example the antiwar movement. Before the invasion of Iraq
column2: millions of people around the world furiously protested the invasion. The media did its best to pretend like resistance was nil
column3: and the bombs were unleashed anyway. In the years that followed
column4: the Patriot Act gave us free speech zones
column5: and the war on terror gave a freshly militarized police the mandate to unleash official brutality onto any who threatened the establishment in any meaningful way.

column1: The net effect is that almost no one bothers objecting to war.
The media does
column2: however
column3: cover protests over social issues that divide us all
column4: and so people vent their frustrations in the these arenas instead
column5: mobilizing for softer social issues like gender bias and offensive language
column6: with the target of blame being other Americans. Government even offers assistance for these types of protests as we see in places like Portland
column7: Oregon where police are aiding anti-Trump rallies
column8: and in California where students are being permitted and encouraged to skip school to protest the fair democratic election of Trump.

column1: In other words
column2: we’ve been trained to complain about getting our feelings hurt and blame each other
column3: and trained to shut the fuck up about the big crimes of the state.

column1: In the game of chess
column2: pawns are the expendable masses. Their role is to serve as an advance force to draw the opponent into a predictable and controllable conflict. They are used by and dispensed of by royalty as tools in pursuit of a larger conquest.

column1: We are being weaponized against ourselves
column2: and our rulers couldn’t be more pleased. For how much longer will we consent to being their pawns? Read more articles by Dylan Charles . About the Author

column1: Democratic debate: Fact-checking the candidates	"Washington (CNN) The Democratic candidates for president gathered in Las Vegas for their first debate Tuesday
column2: and CNN's Reality Check team spent the night putting their statements and assertions to the test.

column1: The team of reporters

column1: Reality check: Martin O'Malley says U.S. has ""failed"" to invest in overseas human intelligence
O'Malley said
column2: ""We have failed as a country to invest in the human intelligence that would allow us to not only make better decisions in Libya
column3: but better decisions in Syria today. It's a huge national security failing.""

column1: Given the opacity of the available data
column2: it is difficult to issue a verdict on O'Malley's statement
column3: but it is possible to provide some context to what he claims.

column1: The National Intelligence Program requests congressional funding for the intelligence-gathering activities of six federal departments
column2: the Central Intelligence Agency and the Office of the Director of National Intelligence.

column1: As a matter of policy
column2: the government does not disclose information about the budget of the NIP beyond the aggregate
column3: or ""top-line"" amount requested and the amount approved by Congress.

column1: The most recent year for which data on the approved congressional appropriation for the NIP is available is FY 2014. The aggregate amount approved for the year ending March 2015 was $50.5 billion. This amount represents a 3% increase over the previous year
column2: which saw an annual NIP appropriation of $49.0 billion
column3: partially due to reductions associated with the sequester.

column1: The amount appropriated in FY 2012
column2: the year during which the attack took place on the U.S. consulate in Benghazi
column3: was $53.9 billion
column4: the second-highest appropriation during the decade 2005-2014.

column1: In August 2013
column2: The Washington Post obtained documents from former National Security Agency contractor Edward Snowden regarding the previously undisclosed $52.6 billion FY 2013 budget
column3: and providing a level of detail that had never been released on a previous U.S. intelligence budget. The documents indicated that the United States has 107
column4: 035 employees in the intelligence community. Of these
column5: the largest employer of civilian intelligence officials is the CIA
column6: which had the equivalent of 21
column7: 459 full-time civilian employees.

column1: According to the leaked documents
column2: in FY 2013
column3: ""human intelligence operations
column4: consisting of ""clandestine acquisition"" of documents and other material
column5: ""collection by personnel in diplomatic and consular posts"" and ""official contacts with foreign governments"" comprised an annual budget of $3.6 billion.

column1: While specific data on human intelligence operations is not available for other years
column2: CNN military analyst Lt. Gen. Mark Hertling notes that the government has cut human intelligence operations relative to other forms of intelligence collection
column3: fueling a major debate in the intelligence community since the 1990s.

column1: An additional obstacle to effective human intelligence gathering is the lack of racial diversity within the CIA's own ranks
column2: according to CIA Director John Brennan. Minorities make up less than 24% of the CIA workforce
column3: and only 10.8% of its top senior intelligence service. Brennan noted that
column4: in many of the countries that are the focus of the CIA's current work
column5: it is harder for white employees
column6: and easier for many minorities
column7: to operate covertly.

column1: This TPP sets the gold standard in trade agreements to open free

column5: Clinton said at an event in Australia in 2012. ""And when negotiated

column1: Nearly three years have passed

column3: it is reasonable for Clinton to claim that the deal has changed since she supported it and was involved in its negotiation.

column1: However
column2: in some ways
column3: the deal has strengthened over the years in areas that Clinton has cited as key concerns.

column1: Clinton now says the deal doesn't do enough to address currency manipulation. But the deal didn't include clear language on that topic in 2013 either
column2: when critics in Congress were calling for it to be added.

column1: She also says she is concerned about the benefits the deal gives to pharmaceutical companies -- which are strengthened under TPP
column2: but less than they would have been under the deal in its 2013 state.

column1: VERDICT: Clinton's claim she said she ""hoped"" TPP would be the gold standard is false. She said it was the gold standard and fully supported the negotiations. Her broader point about the deal changing since she left office is True
column2: but Misleading. The deal has changed in the past three years
column3: but in some instances those changes have improved the very deficiencies she cites.

column1: Hillary isn't winning over many pundits, even on the left	"Hillary Clinton is clobbering Bernie Sanders—and yet getting negative reviews from some of the pundits.
How is that possible? The Democratic race is essentially over. President Obama is privately telling donors it’s time to get on the Hillary train
column2: the New York Times reports. A front-runner who wins in state after state usually basks in a winner’s aura as the party coalesces around her
column3: and draws glowing profiles of how she and her team did it.

column1: Sure
column2: Hillary was always expected to beat Bernie. It’s also true that Clinton has never been beloved by the press
column3: and the feeling is mutual.

column1: But the larger problem is the outlook as the commentary class looks ahead to the fall.
Until the last couple of weeks
column2: the conventional wisdom was that a Trump nomination would all but assure a second Clinton presidency. After all
column3: she’s the former senator and secretary of State with an awesome political machine
column4: and he’s the untested billionaire with a penchant for divisive rhetoric. Plus
column5: Democrats have an Electoral College edge and have won the popular vote in five of the last six campaigns.

column1: But some commentators see troubling signs in Clinton’s performance so far and wonder how she would withstand a Trump onslaught. The Donald has high negatives
column2: to be sure
column3: but Hillary does as well.

column1: An unsparing assessment comes from Joe Klein
column2: who has known the Clintons for a quarter century and mostly written sympathetically about them since his 1992 New York magazine cover story on Bill Clinton.

column1: Klein agrees with Hillary’s self-assessment that she is not a natural politician
column2: but goes much further in weighing a Trump matchup:

column1: “Clinton seems particularly ill equipped for the task. She is our very own quinoa and kale salad
column2: nutritious but bland. Worse
column3: she’s the human embodiment of the Establishment that Trump has been running against…

column1: “Indeed
column2: her real problem is that she’s too much of a politician. She still speaks like politicians did 20 years ago
column3: when her husband was President. This year
column4: the candidates who have seemed the most appealing–Trump
column5: Sanders
column6: John Kasich–don’t use the oratorical switchbacks that have been beaten to death since John F. Kennedy.”

column1: It’s no secret that Sanders has pushed Clinton to the left on trade
column2: immigration
column3: Wall Street and other issues. But Klein says that is often viewed as dissembling:

column1: “There is an odd new law of U.S. politics: You can lie
column2: as Trump does all the time
column3: egregiously
column4: but you can’t temporize. You can’t avoid a position on the XL pipeline or the Trans-Pacific trade deal
column5: as Clinton tried to do in the campaign. You can’t try to please too many people too much of the time. Raising your voice to make a point–which Clinton does all the time
column6: disastrously
column7: because it seems such a conscious act–won’t get you anywhere unless you’re really angry.

column1: “In the end
column2: I’m not at all certain that Clinton can beat Trump.”

column1: A note about her speaking style: When Clinton won five states on Tuesday night
column2: I tweeted that she was shouting her speech and that it would be more effective with the audience at home if she was more conversational. I didn’t say she was shrill
column3: I didn’t say she should smile
column4: and in the past I’ve criticized Sanders for shouting his way through debates.

column1: But I was hit with hundreds of tweets declaring me to be a horrible
column2: misogynistic sexist. Some of this was a wave powered by what others had said about her speech. Maybe my quick take was wrong. But I hope we’re not entering a period where any criticism of the presumptive Democratic nominee is treated as sexism.

column1: Other left-wing pundits
column2: driven in part by ideology
column3: fear the worst. This Salon headline boils it down:

column1: “Hillary Will Never Survive the Trump Onslaught: It’s Not Fair
column2: But It Makes Her a Weak Nominee.”

column1: Clinton’s largest problem
column2: in my view
column3: is her low polling marks on honesty
column4: a result of the email scandal and perhaps decades of scars of accumulated accusations
column5: some of them fair and some exaggerated.

column1: Veteran journalist Jeff Greenfield
column2: writing earlier in Politico
column3: spells out three reasons why Clinton could prove to be a weak candidate:

column1: “First
column2: Hillary Clinton commands little trust among an electorate that is driven today by mistrust. Second
column3: her public life—the posts she has held
column4: the positions she has adopted (and jettisoned)—define her as a creature of the ‘establishment’ at a time when voters regard the very idea with deep antipathy. And finally
column5: however she wishes it were not so
column6: however much she argues that she represents the future as America’s first prospective female president

column1: Clinton still embodies the past
column2: just as she did in 2008 when she lost to Barack Obama. The combination of those three factors is already playing out in the Democratic primary
column3: where younger voters are turning away from her and embracing a geriatric
column4: white-haired alternative in droves.”

column1: When Clinton recalibrates
column2: says Greenfield
column3: “she always embraces the politically popular stand.”

column1: However lukewarm the Democratic base may be about Hillary
column2: she enjoys broad support within the party and most Bernie backers should have no trouble shifting their allegiance to her. The same can’t be said for Trump
column3: who is weathering a Republican revolt against the likelihood of his winning the nomination.

column1: We’ll know Hillary is solving her enthusiasm problem when she starts getting better reviews from journalists on the left.

column1: 3. Trump vs. Cruz: The fight that didn't happen
They've bashed each other on the campaign trail in recent days

column3: win in South Carolina -- and his campaign's strategy largely relies on racking up delegates in Southern states with March primaries.

column1: Trump's answers were revealing in their own way

The Cruz campaign's actions the night of the Iowa caucuses had nothing to do with CNN's reporting. The fact that Senator Cruz continues to knowingly mislead the voters about this is astonishing.""

column1: Lawmakers caught in battle between House ethics cops	"WASHINGTON —Two Capitol Hill panels that police the ethics of members of Congress appear to be battling about which has authority over 10 lawmakers accused of unwittingly accepting improper travel and gifts from the state oil company of Azerbaijan.
A Washington Post story published Wednesday detailed the contents of a confidential Office of Congressional Ethics (OCE) investigation of a 2013 trip to Azerbaijan
column2: a former republic of the Soviet Union in Central Asia.

column1: The OCE was created in 2008 to vet ethics cases and recommend action to the Ethics Committee. The Ethics Committee retains sole authority to judge whether members have broken the rules and to mete out punishment. The committee apparently asked the OCE to drop this case. There is no evidence the committee has ever made such a request before.
The OCE report indicated that 10 members of Congress had improperly accepted travel and gifts from the state-owned oil company of Azerbaijan
column2: which secretly paid for the trip and not the non-profit groups that purportedly sponsored it. The lawmakers said they had no idea the non-profits were not the true sponsors of the trip
column3: and apparently neither did the Ethics Committee
column4: which approved the members' travel in advance.

column1: The report found no evidence that the lawmakers made any effort to aid an Azeri pipeline project that the state-owned oil company was pushing at the time.
Rep. Gregory Meeks
column2: D-N.Y. — one of the lawmakers involved in the case — said the Ethics Committee asked the OCE to stop its investigation of the trip because the committee had started one of its own. OCE declined
column3: however
column4: the Post reported.

column1: Such a refusal is ""pretty outrageous
column2: said Chris DeLacy
column3: a partner at the law firm Holland & Knight who represents lawmakers in ethics cases. ""It's like we've generated two separate Ethics Committees and OCE has gone rogue.""

column1: The OCE report indicates that Meeks did not cooperate with its investigation
column2: according to the Post
column3: but Meeks' office says that is not true.

column1: Meeks gave OCE ""documents and other information in response to its request
column2: said spokeswoman Sophia Lafargue
column3: but OCE did not tell him that the Ethics Committee had asked it to end its review despite House rules requiring it do so.

column1: This is why he would not be interviewed by OCE
column2: and this is why OCE said in the leaked report that he 'declined to cooperate
column3: ' "" Lafargue said. ""Congressman Meeks is committed to cooperate with the Ethics Committee in its review of this matter.""

column1: The 2008 House resolution that created the OCE states that when it is notified that the Ethics Committee is investigating a case
column2: ""the board shall refer such matter to the committee and cease its preliminary or second-phase review ... and so notify any individual who is the subject of the review.""

column1: OCE's own rules
column2: however
column3: state it will stop its investigation when the Ethics Committee starts ""an investigatory subcommittee"" — the committee's rarely used formal investigative process. The committee makes a public announcement when it creates those subcommittees and has not announced one for the Azerbaijan trip.

column1: OCE may ""draw a lot of flak"" for the Azerbaijan case
column2: but the process worked as it should except for the leak
column3: said Craig Holman
column4: government affairs lobbyist at the liberal-leaning watchdog group Public Citizen.

column1: The OCE investigated and reported to the committee
column2: Holman said
column3: adding that if the committee ""prevailed upon the OCE to not do a report
column4: (the case) probably would have been buried."" The report shows a real concern
column5: Holman said: the use of bogus non-profits by a foreign government to circumvent congressional travel rules.

column1: Holman said the dispute between the two bodies is reminiscent of the early days of the OCE
column2: when the two publicly feuded repeatedly over jurisdiction and the rules of investigations. But he said
column3: ""I do not see it escalating to the point we saw in the very beginning.""

column1: The case also involves the first leak of a full OCE report before its public release
column2: which has led lawyers who defend lawmakers to call the entire process unfair.

column1: There have been more ethics case since OCE started
column2: DeLacy said
column3: a trend for which the office deserves some credit. But if the intent of the law was to spur for Ethics Committee investigations
column4: and the committee has launched a probe in a case
column5: there is no reason for OCE to keep investigating.

column1: Earlier this year
column2: the House changed its own rules to give lawmakers a new defense against ethics investigations. The language stated that the two ethics bodies ""may not take any action that would deny any person any right or protection provided under the Constitution of the United States
column3: an apparent reference to long-simmering concerns that the OCE does not allow the subjects of investigations to see the evidence against them. At the time
column4: Elliot Berke
column5: a lawyer who has defended several Republicans in ethics cases
column6: said
column7: ""from Day One of the OCE's existence
column8: there have been serious concerns about lack of due process.""

column1: The OCE report apparently found that the 10 members who traveled to Azerbaijan — Meeks; Jim Bridenstine
column2: R-Okla.; Yvette Clarke
column3: D-N.Y.; Danny Davis
column4: D-Ill.; Rubén Hinojosa
column5: D-Texas; Sheila Jackson Lee
column6: D-Texas; Leonard Lance
column7: R-N.J.; Michelle Lujan Grisham
column8: D-N.M.; Ted Poe
column9: R-Texas
column10: and then-congressman Steve Stockman
column11: R-Texas — were unaware that the trip was improperly funded by a foreign government. Nevertheless
column12: in similar past cases
column13: the Ethics Committee has required lawmakers to pay back the costs of travel
column14: which for this trip would total thousands of dollars for each traveler. In past cases
column15: lawmakers have been allowed to use campaign money instead of their personal funds to pay these costs.

column1: Airfare for the members and their spouses totaled more than $110
column3: the Post reported."	REAL

column1: New O'Keefe Video: Clinton Campaign, DNC Coordinated With Organizations To Incite Violence At Trump Events	"A new video investigation released Monday by James O’Keefe’s Project Veritas Action shows how Democratic-aligned organizations used a tactic called 'bird-dogging' to incite violence and chaos at Trump rallies for media consumption. A key Clinton operative is captured on camera saying
column2: ""It doesn’t matter what the friggin’ legal and ethics people say
column3: we need to win this motherfucker.""

column1: In the video
column2: Democratic activists Robert Creamer and Scott Foval reveal their strategy to create a sense of ""anarchy"" in and around Donald Trump events over the course of the campaign. Foval tells an undercover operative: ""One of the things we do is we stage very authentic grassroots protests right in their faces at their own events. Like
column3: we infiltrate.""

column1: ""So the term bird dogging: You put people in the line
column2: at the front which means that they have to get there at six in the morning because they have to get in front at the rally
column3: so that when Trump comes down the rope line
column4: they’re the ones asking him the question in front of the reporter
column5: because they’re pre-placed there
column6: explains Foval. ""To funnel that kind of operation
column7: you have to start back with people two weeks ahead of time and train them how to ask questions. You have to train them to bird dog.”

column1: In another undercover interview
column2: Creamer tells Project Veritas that his organization
column3: Democracy Partners
column4: has daily check-ins with the Clinton campaign in order to coordinate efforts. “I just had a call with the campaign and the DNC
column5: every day at one o’clock
column6: ” says Creamer subordinate Zulema Rodriguez in the video.

column1: Foval explains to O'Keefe's undercover journalist how the web of Democratic organizations is designed to subvert laws preventing Super PACs and political action groups from organizing directly with campaigns: ""The campaign pays DNC
column2: DNC pays Democracy Partners
column3: Democracy Partners pays the Foval Group
column4: the Foval Group goes and executes the shit on the ground... Democracy Partners is the tip of the spear on that stuff.""

column1: ""We're consultants so we're not the official entity and so those conversations can be had between consultants
column2: Foval explains
column3: “The campaigns and DNC cannot go near [Democratic super PAC] Priorities [USA]
column4: but I guaran-damn-tee you that the people who run the Super PACs all talk to each other and we and a few other people are the hubs of that communication.”

column1: One event specifically mentioned by the Democratic operatives to have been 'bird-dogged' was the September incident in North Carolina where a 69-year-old woman was supposedly assaulted by a Trump supporter. In reality
column2: the woman was ""trained"" by Foval as part of his operation. “She was one of our activists
column3: ” he says.

column1: “I’m saying we have mentally ill people
column2: that we pay to do shit
column3: make no mistake
column4: ” says Foval in the video. “Over the last twenty years
column5: I’ve paid off a few homeless guys to do some crazy stuff
column6: and I’ve also taken them for dinner
column7: and I’ve also made sure they had a hotel
column8: and a shower. And I put them in a program. Like I’ve done that. But the reality is
column9: a lot of people especially our union guys. A lot of our union guys…they’ll do whatever you want. They’re rock and roll. When I need to get something done in Arkansas
column10: the first guy I call is the head of the AFL-CIO down there
column11: because he will say
column12: ‘What do you need?’ And I will say
column13: I need a guy who will do this
column14: this and this. And they find that guy. And that guy will be like
column15: Hell yeah
column16: let’s do it.”

column1: ""It doesn't matter what the friggin' legal and ethics people say
column2: we need to win this motherfucker
column3: Foval also said.

column1: We do not like trampolining, say hedgehogs	"We do not like trampolining
column2: say hedgehogs 10-11-16

column1: HEDGEHOGS have confirmed they do not like trampolining and children should not make them do it.
Britain’s hedgehogs attacked this year’s John Lewis Christmas advert
column2: featuring trampolining woodland animals
column3: warning that children would now try to kidnap hedgehogs and force them to bounce up and down.

column1: Hedgehog Roy Hobbs said: “I accidentally wandered across a trampoline once. I hated it and I wasn’t even bouncing up and down. It was just all wobbly underfoot. Made me queasy.
“The hedgehog in this advert is not real. It is an unnatural
column2: computer generated abomination.”

column1: Hobbs added: “Hedgehogs are very much ground-based creatures. We eat grubs and roll into a ball for protection.
“In our leisure time we watch stuff like Bake Off and Orange is the New Black . The most excitement we have is the occasional game of Buckaroo!.
“Anyway
column2: keep your brats on a leash or we’ll give them scabies.”

column1: Share:"	FAKE
President Putin Asks US To Stop Provoking Russia
cooperation is an essential part of this	 and we realise that cooperation is not always easy. We saw an example just before with the case of the transponders. The planes can still fly at least.

areas where innocent people’s lives are at stake. You mentioned recently the case of the Tsarnayev brothers. As far as I know	 Russia passed on information but no action was taken. Does this mean that practical cooperation in security is now in a critical situation?

if I recall correctly. Yes	 we passed information on the Tsarnayev brothers on to our American partners. We wrote to them but received no response. After we wrote a second time we got a reply that they are US citizens and so it was none of our business and they would take care of everything themselves. I told the director of the FSB to archive the file. The response we received is still there	 in the archives. Sadly	 a few months later	 the Boston marathon terrorist attack took place and people were killed.
but they do say quite rightly that this is essential for all of us	 especially in the fight against terrorism. In this sense	 we welcome all who declare such intentions.

the Americans have provided us with real help	 during the preparations for the Olympic Games in Sochi	 for example	 and we are grateful to them for this. Our cooperation was very efficient here	 on site and at the level of our intelligence service heads. There have been other good examples of cooperation too.

we have quite a good situation in this area with our European partners. We have open and professional contacts with the French intelligence services	 for example	 and exchange information. In general	 the situation is not bad	 but it could be a lot better.
and also emphasis on the roadmap that we saw in Russia	 for example	 in the media and in political debate. I think this was really a case of diverging interpretations of the results.

so as not to put anyone in a difficult position or interfere with the process itself. As you know	 the Minsk agreements	 which I think the experts have all read	 say in black and white: “Thirty days after the signing of the Minsk agreements Ukraine’s Rada must adopt a resolution outlining the geographical boundaries of areas where the law on the special status of these unrecognised republics would become effective immediately.” Because the only thing needed for it to work was the description of those geographical boundaries.

not by law	 but by a parliamentary resolution	 and the resolution was finally adopted	 even if past the deadline. So one would think that this law was to take effect immediately. It was passed	 I would like to remind you	 by the Parliament of Ukraine. The lawmakers voted for it	 and it was coordinated with the unrecognised republics	 which is very important	 and in this sense	 in my view	 makes it viable legislation and a key element of a political settlement.

Ukraine and its Parliament adopted an amendment	 a paragraph to Article 9 or 10	 which said the law would take effect only after municipal elections in these areas. That once again postponed the law’s enforcement. I repeat	 in our opinion	 that law is absolutely key to a political resolution to the crisis in southeastern Ukraine. Moreover	 that was done without even consulting anyone	 least of all the unrecognised republics.

as it was part of the Minsk Agreements and is	 in our view	 a key component. But the Ukrainian president said that this was not possible and everything ended up in a dead end. In this situation	 everything could have ended then and there a year ago in Paris	 but Mr Steinmeier	 the German Foreign Minister	 suddenly proposed a compromise.

temporarily	 and have it come into force permanently after the OSCE Office for Democratic Institutions and Human Rights recognises the elections as having taken place in accordance with OSCE rules. This was not at all what was set out in the Minsk Agreements	 but in order to get us out of the deadlock we were in	 I expressed my agreement and said we would settle the matter with Donetsk and Lugansk	 which we did.

the Ukrainian president suddenly also attempted to change this proposal	 already the result of a compromise. He went even further	 essentially renouncing the law’s implementation whatever the case. We thus found ourselves back in the same crisis we had in Paris a year before. But I want to note the Federal Chancellor’s role here. She found arguments to persuade everyone present that we could and should keep to the agreement we reached and said that it was not possible to change what we’d already agreed on a year later	 or we would never reach an agreement. But we agreed to bundle the nuances and details of how it would be implemented together with the concept you spoke about	 and which still has to be worked through.

really. But in principle	 a lot was accomplished in terms of ensuring security. We reached agreement on nearly every point. We made very little progress on humanitarian matters. These regions remain tightly blockaded and are in a very difficult situation. But the so-called civilised world prefers not to notice this. I do not want to get into debate on this matter now. As far as the [Normandy] format goes and whether it is useful or not	 we simply have no alternative.

the discussions proceed with difficulty	 and this is not very effective	 I agree	 but we have no other option	 and if we want to make progress	 we have to continue working in this format. As for the question of getting any other actors involved	 our position is that we are not opposed to the idea of others taking part	 including our American partners. But we have reached an agreement with all participants in the process that we will work in parallel with our American colleagues. My aide and Ms Nuland have regular meetings	 discuss these issues and look for compromise. This is not being done in secret though	 of course. All participants in the Normandy format meetings are informed and we take into account our American partners’ position too	 of course.

Russia recently withdrew from an agreement with the United States to dispose of weapons-grade plutonium	 but at the same time	 the Russian Government said that it would consider re-joining the agreement if three conditions were met: firstly	 that NATO troops should withdraw to the level that they were before 2000 in Europe; secondly	 the Magnitsky Act should be repealed; and thirdly	 that the sanctions imposed on Russia after the beginning of the Ukraine crisis should be lifted	 and Russia should be paid compensation for them.

I’m optimistic about that. Are we to understand	 in the United States	 that these three conditions would form the basis of an initial negotiating position on the Russian part with the American president	 when she re-establishes high-level relations with the Kremlin? Thank you.

they will tell you about the concept of ‘starting position’. As for our decision on the Plutonium Management and Disposition Agreement	 we did not withdraw from it. The United States withdrew from the missile defence treaty	 but we did not withdraw from the plutonium agreement	 we suspended it. Why did we do this? What were this agreement’s provisions? Under its terms	 both countries were to build facilities for disposing of the surplus weapons-grade plutonium that had accumulated in both Russia and the USA.

but said that it would not do so because of financial difficulties. As if Russia does not have financial difficulties of its own	 but we built our facility and are disposing of this plutonium using industrial methods. Without any prior coordination with us	 the United States made a unilateral announcement that they would not dilute this weapons-grade plutonium but would store it in some beds and so forth.

in other words	 the plutonium could be returned and re-enriched at any moment. But we are eliminating our plutonium using industrial methods. We built our facility and spent money on it. Are we wealthier than the United States? There are many issues it has become difficult to discuss with the current administration because practically no obligations are met and no agreements are respected	 including those on Syria. Perhaps we will be able to come back to this. We are ready	 in any case	 to talk with the new president and look for solutions to any	 even the most difficult	 issues.

my question is on Russian policy towards Asia. The emphasis today in Russian foreign policy is on the construction of a multipolar world. But do you also give some thought to the importance of a multipolar Asia? Both in your speech today	 and the general construction of the Russian foreign policy	 points	 I think	 to the growing	 deepening contradictions between the US and the West on the one hand	 and the Eurasian situation. But it’s also a fact that there are internal contradictions within Eurasia.
by its emphasis on a multipolar world	 is underestimating the dangers of a unipolar Asia	 and the need for great powers to work together to construct a genuinely democratic multipolar Asia?
but simply because life itself dictates this choice. Why do I say that life itself dictates that we expand these contacts?
and	 what’s more	 they are growing fast. With a sizeable part of its territory in Asia	 Russia would be foolish not to make use of its geographical advantages and develop ties with its neighbours.
we see that Asia is not unipolar and this is very evident.
and we are ready to work the same way with them all.
as well as in the civilian sector	 where we have many common interests with India	 China	 Vietnam and other countries in the region. These ties are extensive and promising.

at the Valdai Club	 you described the relations between Ukraine and Russia with the following sentence: “Two countries	 one people”. Today	 how would you describe the relations between the two countries? Thank you very much.

and still do today	 that Russians and Ukrainians are really one people. There are people who hold radical nationalist views both in Russia and in Ukraine. But overall	 for the majority	 we are one people	 a people who share a common history and culture and are ethnically close. First we were divided	 then we were set against each other	 but we are not to blame for this. We must find our own way out of this situation. I am sure that common sense will prevail and that we will find a solution.

before putting my question	 I would like to pass on my young students’ words. Two years ago	 you came to Shanghai on other important business and our students missed the chance to meet at the university with you and ask their question	 but they asked me to tell you that they would be happy to see you any time	 regardless of whether you have retired or not.

to what extent will future systems resemble past ones? What are the positive components we should emphasise in particular? Should we seek more universality or more diversity as far as principles go? What kind of combination of components would you prefer to see?
the West	 and China.
of course not. How is this possible? Does today’s China resemble the China of the 1960s-70s? They are two completely different countries	 and the Soviet Union is gone today too.

they are deeply mistaken. If we follow this kind of thinking	 we can expect very serious trials ahead. We already hear the talk about refugees and Syria. I saw today the news about the latest incident in the Mediterranean	 where the Italian coastguard rescued refugees from Africa. What has Syria got to do with this? Africa’s future and the world’s future are very serious issues. The same goes for relations in Asia	 where there are also many conflicts or potential conflict situations.

that the world really will become more multipolar	 and that the views of all actors in the international community will be taken into account. No matter whether a country is big or small	 there should be universally accepted common rules that guarantee sovereignty and peoples’ interests.

the United States	 America in general	 and the Asian countries	 we have a multi-vector policy. This is not just in virtue of our geographical location. Our policy with regard to our partners is built on the basis of equality and mutual respect.
