Will Clinton’s experience be a liability?	"Hillary Rodham Clinton’s tenure as secretary of state was supposed to be a central argument for her forthcoming run for president. Her globe-trotting record as the nation’s chief diplomat
column2: her role championing women’s empowerment and gay rights
column3: and her experience on tough national security issues were all supposed to confer credentials that none of her possible GOP opponents would possess.

column1: But over the past two weeks
column2: with back-to-back revelations that she was working with foreign countries that gave millions of dollars to her family’s charitable foundation and that she set up and exclusively used a private e-mail system
column3: that argument has been put in peril.

column1: Instead of a fresh chapter in which Clinton came into her own
column2: her time as the country’s top diplomat now threatens to remind voters of what some people dislike about her — a tendency toward secrecy and defensiveness
column3: along with the whiff of scandal that clouded the presidency of her husband
column4: Bill Clinton.

column1: That side of Hillary Clinton also plays directly into the main Republican argument against her
column2: that she is a candidate of “yesterday” — as Sen. Marco Rubio of Florida recently put it — who comes with decades of baggage the country no longer need carry.

column1: “Part of the reason the story is gaining traction is that it reminds people of what the Clinton White House was like
column2: ” said American University political science professor Jennifer Lawless. “It reminds people of the scandals
column3: the secrecy and the lack of transparency that were often associated with Bill Clinton’s eight years in Washington.”

column1: Clinton was already certain to face sharp questions during a presidential campaign about her handling of the deadly attacks on U.S. facilities in Benghazi
column2: Libya
column3: in 2012. She has never been shown to have any direct role in events leading up to the deaths of the U.S. ambassador and three other Americans
column4: but an inquiry that Democrats call a fishing expedition has been given new life by the revelation that her e-mails were not immediately given to Congress.

column1: Rep. Trey Gowdy (R-S.C.)
column2: who chairs a special congressional committee on Benghazi
column3: has subpoenaed Clinton’s e-mails and plans to call her as a witness once his investigation is further along. That will mean a showdown in the middle of a presidential campaign in which she will be trying to reintroduce herself to voters.

column1: “You do not need a law degree to have an understanding of how troubling this is
column2: ” Gowdy said in a news conference last week.

column1: Clinton has said nothing about the e-mail controversy beyond a tweet promising to seek to make the messages public. On Sunday
column2: Sen. Dianne Feinstein (D-Calif.) said Clinton needs to talk in more detail about the issue. “From this point on
column3: the silence is going to hurt her
column4: ” Feinstein said on NBC’s “Meet the Press.”

column1: Clinton’s problems at the State Department also make it easier for Republicans to connect her to what they see as President Obama’s shaky foreign policy and his broken promise to operate the most transparent administration in history.
Even the smallest things are being looked at anew. The iconic image of her at the State Department
column2: which she chose as her Twitter avatar
column3: shows her seated aboard a military transport plane
column4: reading something — perhaps e-mail — on her BlackBerry.

column1: Former Florida governor Jeb Bush
column2: who is weighing a 2016 bid
column3: cast her reliance on private ­e-mail as a serious security risk. “It’s a little baffling
column4: to be honest with you
column5: that didn’t come up in Secretary Clinton’s thought process
column6: ” the Republican said in a Friday radio interview.

column1: And while Clinton remains the overwhelming favorite for her party’s nomination
column2: some Democrats last week were more open about their misgivings about her candidacy. On Friday night in New Hampshire
column3: former Maryland governor Martin O’Malley
column4: who might run against her
column5: for the first time broke his silence on her use of the private e-mail account
column6: saying that “openness and transparency are required of governing in the modern age.”

column1: For Clinton
column2: the State Department years were a kind of protective cocoon from partisan politics
column3: even though she was a visible member of a Democratic administration that was doing regular battle with congressional Republicans.

column1: She was rarely called upon to take public positions on partisan issues. Her history as a politically active first lady
column2: senator and failed Democratic candidate for president were rarely mentioned in day-to-day news coverage of her trips and priorities as secretary.

column1: Clinton’s busy pace — she visited a record 112 countries — made it easy to deflect questions about the common assumption that she would make another run for the White House when her time at the State Department was over.
After leaving office
column2: she wrote a memoir of her time at the State Department that was published last year. The book
column3: “Hard Choices
column4: ” marked her unmistakable entry into the 2016 presidential race and amounted to a virtual campaign manifesto.

column1: “We have to use all of America’s strengths to build a world with more partners and fewer adversaries
column2: more shared responsibility and fewer conflicts
column3: more good jobs and less poverty
column4: more broadly based prosperity with less damage to our environment
column5: ” Clinton wrote.

column1: Clinton posted a Twitter message Wednesday night — two days into the e-mail controversy — saying she wants the public “to see my e-mails.” She said she has asked the State Department to review them for release.
That review could also establish whether she broke any rules about the handling of sensitive information.
The e-mail arrangement meant that Clinton’s work ­e-mails were being routed through a private server in her Chappaqua
column2: N.Y.
column3: home and were not being archived by the government as now required. She handed over 55
column4: 000 pages of e-mails upon the State Department’s request last year
column5: more than a year after she left her post.

column1: She has not explained the reason for the un­or­tho­dox arrangement
column2: and her husband declined to weigh in on Sunday. “I’m not the one to judge that. I have an opinion
column3: but I have a bias
column4: ” Bill Clinton said in response to a reporter’s question during a Florida appearance
column5: according to Bloomberg Politics. He added: “I shouldn’t be making news on this.”

column1: The White House has distanced itself from the growing controversy. Obama said in an interview with CBS on Saturday that he did not know about Hillary Clinton’s use of private e-mail until reading news reports last week.
“The president does have the expectation that everybody in his administration takes the steps that are necessary to be in compliance with the Federal Records Act and with the Presidential Records Act
column2: ” White House press secretary Josh Earnest said Friday. “And again
column3: that means using
column4: as often as possible
column5: using your official government e-mail when you’re conducting official government business.”

column1: White House officials communicated with Clinton on her private account
column2: and it is not clear that any White House official flagged the practice as a potential problem.

column1: The e-mail revelation came after the Bill
column2: Hillary and Chelsea Clinton Foundation acknowledged in February that it had accepted a foreign-government donation in 2010 without submitting it for an ethics review
column3: as required in a 2008 agreement with the Obama administration.

column1: The 2008 agreement had been reached to avoid the appearance of conflicts of interest while Hillary Clinton served as secretary of state. Under the agreement
column2: the foundation was to submit any donation from a foreign government that had not previously given money to the foundation.

column1: The goal was to allow ethics officers to analyze whether it might appear that the government was trying to influence U.S. policy with a donation to a charity so closely linked to the nation’s top diplomat.
The foundation told The Washington Post that it had failed to follow that process in the case of an unsolicited $500
column2: 000 donation from the government of Algeria to assist in earthquake relief in Haiti. The donation coincided with a spike in lobbying by Algeria
column3: which was defending its human rights record to U.S. officials.

column1: State Department spokeswoman Jen Psaki said the donation did not pose a problem because U.S. support for rebuilding efforts in Haiti was well known before the Algerian donation came in.
Prominent Clinton backers have dismissed the recent controversies as minor distractions unimportant to voters and blamed the e-mail flap on a Republican attack machine.
But other Democrats expressed exasperation at what they called a slow and ham-handed response to the e-mail controversy by her small group of advisers. There is no in-house
column2: campaign-grade rapid-response operation
column3: and outside defenders had little notice that a problem was brewing.

column1: “I’d be surprised to find a lot of Democrats who think this is going to have a lot of legs
column2: ” said one senior Democratic strategist who spoke on the condition of anonymity because Clinton is not yet a candidate. “But there is a level of angst and annoyance about how badly the thing has been mishandled.”

column1: Several Democrats said the controversy is being blown out of proportion and questioned whether Republicans are being subjected to the same level of scrutiny.
Rep. Loretta Sanchez (D-Calif.) said that Clinton has been aboveboard and that the controversy will quickly fade.
“She’s not trying to hide anything
column2: ” Sanchez said."	REAL

column1: Obama outlines plan to keep 5,500 troops in Afghanistan	"President Obama said Thursday that he will keep 5
column2: 500 U.S. troops in Afghanistan into 2017
column3: ending his ambitions to bring home most American forces from that war-torn country before he leaves office.

column1: The president’s decision came after an extensive months-long review that included regular discussions with Afghanistan’s leaders
column2: his national security team and U.S. commanders in the field. The move reflected a painful
column3: if predictable
column4: reality on the ground in Afghanistan
column5: where the Taliban has seized new territory over the past year as Afghan troops have taken over the vast majority of the fighting.

column1: “Afghan forces are still not as strong as they need to be
column2: ” Obama said Thursday morning from the White House
column3: explaining his decision. “. . . Meanwhile
column4: the Taliban has made gains
column5: particularly in rural areas
column6: and can still launch deadly attacks in cities
column7: including Kabul.”

column1: [The Islamic State is making these Afghans long for the Taliban]
Obama said he will also dramatically slow the pace of the reduction of American forces and plans to maintain the current U.S. force of 9
column2: 800 through “most of 2016.” The post-2016 force will still be focused on training and advising the Afghan army
column3: with a special emphasis on its elite counter­terrorism forces. The United States will also maintain a significant counterterrorism capability of drones and Special Operations forces to strike al-Qaeda and other militants who may be plotting attacks against the United States.

column1: The revised troop plans came after Afghan forces were driven from Kunduz
column2: the first major city to fall to the Taliban since the war began in 2001. Two weeks passed before the Afghans
column3: with some support from U.S. planes and Special Operations advisers
column4: took the city back from the Taliban. Militants are now threatening other cities. “The bottom line is
column5: in key areas of the country the security situation is still very fragile
column6: and in some places there’s risk of deterioration
column7: ” Obama said.

column1: The president praised the Afghan government
column2: under the leadership of President Ashraf Ghani
column3: as a willing partner
column4: and he lauded the Afghan troops
column5: who have taken significant casualties. Both were critical factors in his decision to keep U.S. troops in the country.

column1: “Every single day
column2: Afghan forces are out there fighting and dying to protect their country
column3: ” Obama said. “They’re not looking for us to do it for them.”

column1: The president insisted that his decision to abandon his plans to bring home U.S. troops was not a disappointment
column2: even as he acknowledged the nation’s war weariness after more than 14 years of fighting in Afghanistan and Iraq. “I do not support the idea of endless war
column3: ” he said.

column1: His decision to keep troops in Afghanistan follows the surprising collapse of much of the U.S.-trained Iraqi army last year under pressure from Islamic State militants. Republican critics have charged that Obama withdrew troops too quickly from Iraq
column2: precipitating the collapse of the Iraqi army and the rise of the Islamic State.

column1: The president did not mention the Iraqi failures in his statement from the White House. White House officials said that the Iraq setbacks did not influence Obama’s decision and that the two situations are not comparable
column2: because the Afghan government was eager to maintain a long-term U.S. presence. Such conditions did not exist in Iraq.

column1: Afghan officials on Thursday welcomed the move to keep 9
column2: 800 troops in the country. “It’s very positive in light of the continued problems that this region is facing
column3: ” said Mohammad Daud Sultanzoy
column4: a presidential candidate in 2014 who is now allied with Ghani. “Our security [forces] have shown the will and capability to fight
column5: but we still need the support of our allies
column6: especially the United States.”

column1: In Ghazni province
column2: where Afghan forces are locked in a bloody fight with the Taliban
column3: Gen. Sayed Malok called it a “good decision at the moment but a temporary solution.” He called for a more robust effort to train and equip Afghan forces.

column1: The decision is a significant departure from the exit plan that Obama announced in a White House Rose Garden speech in May 2014. In keeping with his promise to “turn the page” on the costly wars launched by his predecessor
column2: Obama said then that he would reduce the U.S. footprint to about 1
column3: 000 troops
column4: all based in Kabul
column5: by the end of 2016.

column1: It is also a stark illustration of how persistent militant threats have stood in the way of Obama’s promises to end the ground wars that have dominated U.S. foreign policy since the Sept. 11
column3: terrorist attacks.

column1: In addition to a resurgent Taliban
column2: al-Qaeda appears to have staked out new ground in Afghanistan
column3: far from the group’s mountain enclaves to the northeast. Last week
column4: U.S. forces began a major operation against al-Qaeda in Kandahar
column5: launching 63 airstrikes on militant training bases.

column1: David Sedney
column2: a former Pentagon official who is a senior associate at the Center for Strategic and International Studies
column3: said the 2015 fighting season was “the most massive
column4: fiercest” yet.

column1: “The Taliban are already signaling that next year’s offensive will be bigger and bloodier than this year’s. The Taliban are bad; Daesh is worse
column2: ” Sedney said
column3: referring to the emerging Islamic State presence in Afghanistan.

column1: Administration officials portrayed the decision as a natural extension of a strategy that was making progress
column2: rather than an indication that the president’s original plan had failed. “I don’t think anyone ever intended that the job
column3: so to speak
column4: would be finished” despite Obama’s time­table
column5: said Lisa Monaco
column6: a senior White House official. “We always said that we would continue to have a presence there.”

column1: [After Kunduz
column2: Taliban is now targeting other Afghan cities]

column1: Under the new plan
column2: the U.S. military will retain bases in Kabul
column3: as planned
column4: but also have forces at Bagram air base and at bases outside Kandahar and Jalalabad
column5: the largest cities in Afghanistan’s southern and eastern regions.

column1: Obama emphasized that Afghans would continue to take the lead role in the fighting
column2: with Americans providing advice and some counterterrorism support from bases outside Kabul. “These bases will give us the presence and the reach our forces require to achieve their mission
column3: ” he said.

column1: The larger force of 5
column2: 500 troops is projected to cost about $15 billion a year
column3: or about $5 billion more than the smaller
column5: 000-person Kabul-based force would have cost.

column1: Defense Secretary Ashton B. Carter
column2: speaking at the Pentagon
column3: said the next president will probably need to make decisions about the long-term position of U.S. forces­ in Afghanistan.

column1: “Is it going to be 5
column2: 500 forever?” he told reporters. “I can only say this: That is our best estimate now of what we should plan for and are planning for and budgeting for for 2017.”

column1: Although U.S. deaths have fallen off dramatically in recent years
column2: the change may also mean more U.S. casualties. This year
column3: 25 American service members and civilians have been killed in the country.

column1: Obama emphasized that the relatively small American military presence
column2: down from 100
column3: 000 at the war’s peak
column4: would not decide the war’s outcome
column5: and he emphasized that peace talks offered the sole viable solution to the long
column6: bloody civil war.

column1: “By now
column2: it should be clear to the Taliban and all who oppose Afghanistan’s progress
column3: the only real way to achieve the full drawdown of U.S. and foreign troops from Afghanistan is through a lasting political settlement with the Afghan government
column4: ” Obama said.

column1: Sudarsan Raghavan
column2: Sayed Salahuddin and Mohammad Sharif in Kabul contributed to this report.

Biden backers to naysayers: Not so fast	"Democrats loyal to Vice President Biden have a three-word response to the politicians and pundits who say Hillary Rodham Clinton’s performance in Tuesday’s Democratic debate makes a Biden campaign less likely: Not so fast.
Appearing eager to tamp down talk that the window of opportunity for the vice president to launch a campaign nearly closed after the debate
column2: loyalists are taking steps to assure potential supporters that there is still a path to the nomination
column3: however competitive and challenging
column4: if Biden decides to run.

column1: The clearest evidence came Friday as the International Association of Fire Fighters informed the vice president the union will endorse him if he enters the race
column2: according to a source familiar with the union’s thinking. That followed a letter e-mailed late Thursday to Biden’s political support network by former senator Ted Kaufman of Delaware
column3: who said a Biden campaign would be “optimistic
column4: ” “from the heart” and unscripted.

column1: “If he runs
column2: he will run because of his burning conviction that we need to fundamentally change the balance in our economy and the political structure to restore the ability of the middle class to get ahead
column3: ” Kaufman wrote.

column1: Even as initial polls showed a bump for Clinton after her performance
column2: Biden’s lingering shadow continued to leave a sense of instability over the Democratic race
column3: leading to questions on the subject for President Obama during a Friday news conference with the South Korean president. “I am not going to comment on what Joe is doing or not doing
column4: ” Obama said. “I think you can direct those questions to my very able vice president.”

column1: And in a television interview Friday
column2: Clinton declined to embrace a suggestion from John Podesta
column3: her senior campaign adviser
column4: that Biden must make a decision soon because the race is already engaged. “That’s up to Vice President Biden
column5: ” she said on CNN’s “The Lead with Jake Tapper.” “Certainly I’m not in any way suggesting or recommending that the vice president accept any timetable other than the one that is clicking inside of him. He has to make this decision.”

column1: Kaufman’s words were arguably less significant than the author behind them. The former senator — appointed to the seat after his ex-boss became vice president — is Biden’s longest-serving adviser
column2: bridging the divide between the generation of staffers who worked for Biden as a senator in the 1980s and a new crop of lieutenants who came up through the past decade of the family’s public service.

column1: More important
column2: Kaufman has been frequently portrayed as the most reluctant of the trio of inner-circle aides to the vice president to launch a bid and is known to be angry at the frequent portrayals of Biden as being on the brink of announcing his candidacy. A note from him to the alumni network is treated as having more credibility than any leak to the national press corps.

column1: The main issue
column2: still apparently unresolved
column3: remains whether Biden and his family feel ready for the rigors of a presidential campaign so soon after the death of his oldest son
column4: Beau
column5: in May. Nothing Biden has said publicly in recent weeks has suggested an affirmative answer
column6: but he has not addressed the issue directly since before Pope Francis’s visit to the United States last month.

column1: According to those tracking the vice president’s deliberations
column2: a decision could come at any time
column3: although the only certain timetable is the one set by the deadlines for qualifying for primary and caucus ballots throughout the country. Those deadlines began to take effect at the end of the month.

column1: Outside Biden’s tight circle of advisers
column2: many Democrats have long assumed that
column3: beyond personal and family considerations
column4: the biggest factor in the vice president’s decision-making involved Clinton’s political vulnerability.

column1: A month ago
column2: as controversy over her use of a private e-mail account while serving as secretary of state damaged her image
column3: she appeared seriously weakened. That prompted calls from nervous Democrats
column4: or those in the party never particularly partial to Clinton
column5: for Biden to jump in.

column1: [Family issues weigh heaviest on Biden as he considers a 2016 run]
But assessments of Clinton brightened considerably after she delivered an impressive performance in Tuesday’s debate with Sen. Bernie Sanders (I-Vt.)
column2: former Maryland governor Martin O’Malley and two other candidates.

column1: Biden loyalists have tried not to be swept up by shifting assumptions about the strength or weakness of the Democratic front-runner
column2: believing she was never as damaged as some were suggesting a month ago.

column1: At the same time
column2: they are not persuaded that this week’s debate fundamentally changed the race in her favor. There is outside evidence backing up that view
column3: including strong interest in Sanders on social media and the fact that the senator from Vermont raised more than $2 million in the 24 hours after the debate.

column1: In recent days
column2: Biden has kept in touch with leaders of key constituency groups
column3: including calls Friday morning. One recipient of a Biden call
column4: who requested anonymity to speak freely about the private conversation
column5: said the vice president actively discussed the emerging campaign strategy
column6: its structure and what constituencies he would win over. Biden believes he has a persuasive message for Democratic voters and would have the resources to run a competitive and potentially lengthy campaign
column7: the call recipient said. Moreover
column8: Biden’s view of the debate
column9: this source said
column10: was that it confirmed that Clinton’s current competition is subpar at best.

column1: Polls and other evidence suggest that if Biden was to enter
column2: the Democratic nomination campaign would quickly become a three-way contest. Clinton would remain the favorite
column3: but it is clear that Sanders has more than enough money to continue well beyond the four earliest states — Iowa
column4: New Hampshire
column5: Nevada and South Carolina.

column1: Biden has told those he has spoken with that he believes he
column2: too
column3: would have the money to remain in the race past those states. It remains unclear what other unions would follow the firefighters in endorsing Biden. “Any conversations I’ve had with the vice president would be private
column4: ” Harold A. Schaitberger
column5: general president of the International Association of Fire Fighters
column6: said in a telephone interview Friday night.

column1: None of the first four contests appears ready to tip to Biden
column2: although because he is not a declared candidate
column3: the polls are not reliable. But some of those partial to Biden have seized on a little-remembered fact from 1992 to offer hope that early defeats need not drive a candidate out of the nomination contest.

column1: [As Biden weighs a 2016 campaign
column2: does he want to be the anti-Clinton?]

column1: In that campaign
column2: Bill Clinton lost 10 of the first 11 contests
column3: from early February through the first days of March. He then secured a string of victories in western and Southern caucuses and primaries
column4: followed by wins in Illinois and Michigan that effectively broke the back of his opponents.

column1: Hillary Clinton’s next major event will be an appearance Thursday before the House committee investigating the deaths of four Americans in Benghazi
column2: Libya
column3: in September 2012
column4: along with her e-mail account. That highly charged appearance has taken a turn in her favor as a result of House Majority Leader Kevin McCarthy (R-Calif.) suggesting the goal of the committee had been to weaken her politically.

column1: Then on Oct. 24
column2: Clinton and other Democratic candidates will speak at the Jefferson-Jackson Dinner in Iowa
column3: a quadrennial proving ground for presidential hopefuls. Given the breadth of organizing that Clinton’s team has done in the Hawkeye State
column4: Biden’s advisers assume the event will give her an additional boost
column5: although Sanders will have plenty of supporters there
column6: too.

column1: All that would suggest that Biden could delay announcing a decision until after those two events.
There were many lines in Kaufman’s letter that suggested Biden still wasn’t ready to make a decision
column2: despite the encroaching deadlines.

column1: “I know in the daily ups and down of the political swirl
column2: we all get bombarded with the tactics. So sometimes it’s good to take a step back and get real again. Let’s stay in touch
column3: ” Kaufman wrote. “If he decides to run
column4: we will need each and every one of you — yesterday!”"	REAL

column1: Alabama Prison Officials Retaliate Against Prison Strike Leader By Cutting Water To Cell	"Advocates say prison officials at the Kilby Correctional Facility in Alabama turned off the water to Kinetik Justice Amun’s solitary cell after he initiated a hunger strike. Officials then transferred him to the Limestone Correctional Facility
column2: which has a “behavioral modification program” known among prisoners as a “hot bay” dorm in which prisoners are forced to live in pairs in hot and squalid solitary confinement cells.

column1: Kinetik
column2: also known as Robert Earl Counsil
column3: is the second leader of the Free Alabama Movement (FAM) to be transferred to Limestone. FAM is a group of incarcerated people and their families struggling to end prison slavery and shed light on inhumane conditions in Alabama’s prison system.

column1: James Plesant
column2: also known as Dhati Khalid
column3: was the first leader to be transferred. Melvin Ray
column4: also known as Bennu Hannibal Ra-Sun
column5: is the last remaining leader of FAM not to be transferred to Limestone.

column1: According to a statement released by the Ordinary People Society
column2: an Alabama-based human rights group for the incarcerated
column3: Kinetik refused meals upon arrival at the Kilby Correctional Facility on October 21. Before the transfer
column4: Kinetik spent three years housed in solitary confinement at the Holman Correctional Facility.

column1: As previously reported by Shadowproof
column2: Kilby is said to be a “ bully camp .” When one Alabama prisoner learned of Kinetik’s transfer to Kilby
column3: he explained the prison is where they send those that “they have to iron out with brutality.” He added
column4: “When they send you to Kilby
column5: that’s where they break your arms and break your legs.”

column1: Prison officials turned off the water to Kinetik’s cell in response to his hunger strike
column2: advocates say. “They are trying to kill him
column3: ” argued Pastor Kenneth Glasgow
column4: founder of the Ordinary People Society and an “outside” spokesperson for FAM. The Alabama Department of Corrections did not respond to multiple requests for comment.

column1: The Alabama Department of Corrections is currently facing a federal investigation into the rampant violence
column2: overcrowding
column3: and structural decay in its prison system. Kinetik believes his transfer was an act of retaliation by prison officials for his political activity
column4: and that they timed the transfer to prevent him from meeting with this lawyer.

column1: Kinetik is an outspoken advocate for the human rights of the incarcerated. Along with Dhati Khalid and Bennu Hannibal Ra-Sun
column2: Kinetik and the Free Alabama Movement were some of the people behind the call-to-action for the national prison strike against prison slave labor
column3: which began on September 9.

column1: Prominent human rights lawyer and executive director of the Equal Justice Initiative
column2: Bryan Stevenson
column3: announced he will work with Pastor Glasgow and look into Kinetik’s case.

column1: Bennu Hannibal Ra-Sun told Shadowproof the “behavioral modification” dorm or Hot Bay like the one at Limestone is “supposed to be a volunteer program where you volunteer to go into it
column2: but there’s no volunteer aspect. They’re just putting people in it.”

column1: “You don’t have to have anything specific that you’ve done. They’re not serving you any paperwork
column2: there’s not any kind of due process
column3: and they’re getting funding from it
column4: ” he said. “So to justify funding
column5: they have to have bodies.”

column1: “Really what they’re doing is they’re targeting individuals
column2: ” Bennu said. He noted there is a Hot Bay program at Donaldson
column3: where he is incarcerated. “That’s where James Plesant was originally. T hey framed him. They’re constantly framing and jumping on people in that Hot Bay.”

column1: In the Hot Bay
column2: prisoners are denied visitation
column3: religious services
column4: recreation
column5: and social services
column6: according to the Free Alabama Movement.

column1: “[The Hot Bay] is worse than solitary confinement because they take all of your property and you have a cell mate
column2: ” Bennu said. “So the one here at Donaldson is two men to a cell. You’re in the cell with another person for 24 hours a day
column3: 7 days a week. Y’all defecating with each other. Y’all urinating with each other
column4: passing gas
column5: burping
column6: sleeping
column7: waking up. Constantly
column8: you’re in the cell with the door locked 24/7 with someone else.”

column1: “They’re sending you up there
column2: they’re torturing people up there. People first got exposed to the Hot Bay program from Bibb County
column3: ” Bennu recalled.

column1: “There was a bunch of young guys in there. They tore the Hot Bay up
column2: ” he said
column3: referring to a July 2015 riot. “They made it where you couldn’t stay in it. They had to get everyone out of there. That’s how bad they are. That’s how bad it was.”

column1: “A lot of people think that when they say they put us in solitary confinement that it’s solitary confinement. In and of itself
column2: that constitutes the torture. It’s not just putting me in the cell. It’s the conditions that they put me in inside of these cells
column3: ” Bennu argued.

column1: He continued
column2: “They put us in contaminated cells. What they do is
column3: they have people in solitary and they be complaining about the plumbing or complaining about the lights or the ventilation or something. And they will put us in those cells.”

column1: “They already know there are issues—there’s plumbing issues
column2: there’s maintenance issues
column3: and they’ll put us in these
column4: what they call ‘black out cells’ or contaminated cells. The lights won’t work
column5: we’ll be in the cells in the dark trying to read
column6: ruining our eyesight. The mattress will be torn up
column7: sleeping on top of these concrete slabs. The water will be leaking
column8: running all over the cell. The vents and stuff are filthy. “

column1: “It’s all of these elements that are added on
column2: but that doesn’t show up in the paperwork
column3: and that’s what they’ve done to people like myself. They put me in an isolated cell. I’m on what they call
column4: ‘Walk Along Status.’ That means I cannot interact with anyone. I can’t be around another person. Same thing with Kinetik and James Plesant
column5: ” Bennu concluded.

column1: A prisoner previously explained to Shadowproof that Limestone is “where they send everybody and you have to spend one year in isolation.” That prisoner hoped Kilby was not a “layover” on Kinetik’s way to Limestone.
“If he doesn’t reach Limestone
column2: he’ll be okay
column3: ” the prisoner said at the time. According to the website for the Alabama Department of Corrections
column4: Kinetik is now incarcerated at Limestone.

column1: Genetically Modified Crops in U.S. Fail to Deliver Expected Yields	"Genetically Modified Crops in U.S. Fail to Deliver Expected Yields 10/31/2016
ALL GOV
The controversy over genetically modified crops has long focused on largely unsubstantiated fears that they are unsafe to eat.

But an extensive examination by The New York Times indicates that the debate has missed a more basic problem — genetic modification in the United States and Canada has not accelerated increases in crop yields or led to an overall reduction in the use of chemical pesticides.
The promise of genetic modification was twofold: By making crops immune to the effects of weedkillers and inherently resistant to many pests
column2: they would grow so robustly that they would become indispensable to feeding the world’s growing population
column3: while also requiring fewer applications of sprayed pesticides.

column1: Twenty years ago
column2: Europe largely rejected genetic modification at the same time the United States and Canada were embracing it. Comparing results on the two continents
column3: using independent data as well as academic and industry research
column4: shows how the technology has fallen short of the promise.

column1: An analysis by The Times using U.N. data showed that the United States and Canada have gained no discernible advantage in yields when measured against Western Europe
column2: a region with comparably modernized agricultural producers like France and Germany . Also
column3: a recent National Academy of Sciences report found “there was little evidence” that the introduction of genetically modified crops in the United States had led to yield gains beyond those seen in conventional crops.

column1: At the same time
column2: herbicide use has increased in the United States
column3: even as major crops like corn
column4: soybeans and cotton have been converted to modified varieties. And the United States has fallen behind Europe’s biggest producer
column5: France
column6: in reducing the overall use of pesticides
column7: which includes both herbicides and insecticides.

column1: One measure
column2: contained in data from the U.S. Geological Survey
column3: shows the stark difference in the use of pesticides. Since GM crops were introduced in the United States two decades ago for crops like corn
column4: cotton and soybeans
column5: the use of toxins that kill insects and fungi has fallen by a third
column6: but the spraying of herbicides
column7: which are used in much higher volumes
column8: has risen 21 percent.

column1: By contrast
column2: in France
column3: use of insecticides and fungicides has fallen 65 percent and herbicide use has decreased 36 percent.

column1: To Learn More:"	FAKE
The Fatal Expense Of American Imperialism	" The Fatal Expense Of American Imperialism
By Jeffrey D. Sachs
Boston Globe "" - THE SINGLE MOST important issue in allocating national resources is war versus peace
column2: or as macroeconomists put it
column3: guns versus butter. The United States is getting this choice profoundly wrong
column4: squandering vast sums and undermining national security. In economic and geopolitical terms
column5: America suffers from what Yale historian Paul Kennedy calls imperial overreach. If our next president remains trapped in expensive Middle East wars
column6: the budgetary costs alone could derail any hopes for solving our vast domestic problems.

column1: It may seem tendentious to call America an empire
column2: but the term fits certain realities of US power and how its used. An empire is a group of territories under a single power. Nineteenth-century Britain was obviously an empire when it ruled India
column3: Egypt
column4: and dozens of other colonies in Africa
column5: Asia
column6: and the Caribbean. The United States directly rules only a handful of conquered islands (Hawaii
column7: Puerto Rico
column8: Guam
column9: Samoa
column10: the Northern Mariana Islands)
column11: but it stations troops and has used force to influence who governs in dozens of other sovereign countries. That grip on power beyond Americas own shores is now weakening.

column1: The scale of US military operations is remarkable. The US Department of Defense has (as of a 2010 inventory) 4
column2: 999 military facilities
column3: of which 4
column4: 249 are in the United States; 88 are in overseas US territories; and 662 are in 36 foreign countries and foreign territories
column5: in all regions of the world. Not counted in this list are the secret facilities of the US intelligence agencies. The cost of running these military operations and the wars they support is extraordinary
column6: around $900 billion per year
column7: or 5 percent of US national income
column8: when one adds the budgets of the Pentagon
column9: the intelligence agencies
column10: homeland security
column11: nuclear weapons programs in the Department of Energy
column12: and veterans benefits. The $900 billion in annual spending is roughly one-quarter of all federal government outlays.

column1: The United States has a long history of using covert and overt means to overthrow governments deemed to be unfriendly to US interests
column2: following the classic imperial strategy of rule through locally imposed friendly regimes. In a powerful study of Latin America between 1898 and 1994
column3: for example
column4: historian John Coatsworth counts 41 cases of successful US-led regime change
column5: for an average rate of one government overthrow by the United States every 28 months for a century. And note: Coatsworths count does not include the failed attempts
column6: such as the Bay of Pigs invasion of Cuba.

column1: This tradition of US-led regime change has been part and parcel of US foreign policy in other parts of the world
column2: including Europe
column3: Africa
column4: the Middle East
column5: and Southeast Asia. Wars of regime change are costly to the United States
column6: and often devastating to the countries involved. Two major studies have measured the costs of the Iraq and Afghanistan wars. One
column7: by my Columbia colleague Joseph Stiglitz and Harvard scholar Linda Bilmes
column8: arrived at the cost of $3 trillion as of 2008. A more recent study
column9: by the Cost of War Project at Brown University
column10: puts the price tag at $4.7 trillion through 2016. Over a 15-year period
column11: the $4.7 trillion amounts to roughly $300 billion per year
column12: and is more than the combined total outlays from 2001 to 2016 for the federal departments of education
column13: energy
column14: labor
column15: interior
column16: and transportation
column17: and the National Science Foundation
column18: National Institutes of Health
column19: and the Environmental Protection Agency.

column1: It is nearly a truism that US wars of regime change have rarely served Americas security needs. Even when the wars succeed in overthrowing a government
column2: as in the case of the Taliban in Afghanistan
column3: Saddam Hussein in Iraq
column4: and Moammar Khadafy in Libya
column5: the result is rarely a stable government
column6: and is more often a civil war. A successful regime change often lights a long fuse leading to a future explosion
column7: such as the 1953 overthrow of Irans democratically elected government and installation of the autocratic Shah of Iran
column8: which was followed by the Iranian Revolution of 1979. In many other cases
column9: such as the US attempts (with Saudi Arabia and Turkey) to overthrow Syrias Bashar al-Assad
column10: the result is a bloodbath and military standoff rather than an overthrow of the government.

column1: WHAT IS THE DEEP motivation for these profligate wars and for the far-flung military bases that support them?
From 1950 to 1990
column2: the superficial answer would have been the Cold War. Yet Americas imperial behavior overseas predates the Cold War by half a century (back to the Spanish-American War
column3: in 1898) and has outlasted it by another quarter century. Americas overseas imperial adventures began after the Civil War and the final conquests of the Native American nations. At that point
column4: US political and business leaders sought to join the European empires  especially Britain
column5: France
column6: Russia
column7: and the newly emergent Germany  in overseas conquests. In short order
column8: America grabbed the Philippines
column9: Puerto Rico
column10: Cuba
column11: Panama
column12: and Hawaii
column13: and joined the European imperial powers in knocking on the doors of China.

column1: As of the 1890s
column2: the United States was by far the worlds largest economy
column3: but until World War II
column4: it took a back seat to the British Empire in global naval power
column5: imperial reach
column6: and geopolitical dominance. The British were the unrivaled masters of regime change  for example
column7: in carving up the corpse of the Ottoman Empire after World War I. Yet the exhaustion from two world wars and the Great Depression ended the British and French empires after World War II and thrust the United States and Russia into the forefront as the two main global empires. The Cold War had begun.

column1: The economic underpinning of Americas global reach was unprecedented. As of 1950
column2: US output constituted a remarkable 27 percent of global output
column3: with the Soviet Union roughly a third of that
column4: around 10 percent. The Cold War fed two fundamental ideas that would shape American foreign policy till now. The first was that the United States was in a struggle for survival against the Soviet empire. The second was that every country
column5: no matter how remote
column6: was a battlefield in that global war. While the United States and the Soviet Union would avoid a direct confrontation
column7: they flexed their muscles in hot wars around the world that served as proxies for the superpower competition.

column1: Over the course of nearly a half century
column2: Cuba
column3: Congo
column4: Ghana
column5: Indonesia
column6: Vietnam
column7: Laos
column8: Cambodia
column9: El Salvador
column10: Nicaragua
column11: Iran
column12: Namibia
column13: Mozambique
column14: Chile
column15: Afghanistan
column16: Lebanon
column17: and even tiny Granada
column18: among many others
column19: were interpreted by US strategists as battlegrounds with the Soviet empire. Often
column20: far more prosaic interests were involved. Private companies like United Fruit International and ITT convinced friends in high places (most famously the Dulles brothers
column21: Secretary of State John Foster and CIA director Allen) that land reforms or threatened expropriations of corporate assets were dire threats to US interests
column22: and therefore in need of US-led regime change. Oil interests in the Middle East were another repeated cause of war
column23: as had been the case for the British Empire from the 1920s.

column1: These wars destabilized and impoverished the countries involved rather than settling the politics in Americas favor. The wars of regime change were
column2: with few exceptions
column3: a litany of foreign policy failure. They were also extraordinarily costly for the United States itself. The Vietnam War was of course the greatest of the debacles
column4: so expensive
column5: so bloody
column6: and so controversial that it crowded out Lyndon Johnsons other
column7: far more important and promising war
column8: the War on Poverty
column9: in the United States.

column1: The end of the Cold War
column3: should have been the occasion for a fundamental reorientation of US guns-versus-butter policies. The occasion offered the United States and the world a peace dividend
column4:  the opportunity to reorient the world and US economy from war footing to sustainable development. Indeed
column5: the Rio Earth Summit
column7: established sustainable development as the centerpiece of global cooperation
column8: or so it seemed.

column1: Alas
column2: the blinders and arrogance of American imperial thinking prevented the United States from settling down to a new era of peace. As the Cold War was ending
column3: the United States was beginning a new era of wars
column4: this time in the Middle East. The United States would sweep away the Soviet-backed regimes in the Middle East and establish unrivalled US political dominance. Or at least that was the plan.

column1: THE QUARTER CENTURY since 1991 has therefore been marked by a perpetual US war in the Middle East
column2: one that has destabilized the region
column3: massively diverted resources away from civilian needs toward the military
column4: and helped to create mass budget deficits and the buildup of public debt. The imperial thinking has led to wars of regime change in Afghanistan
column5: Iraq
column6: Libya
column7: Yemen
column8: Somalia
column9: and Syria
column10: across four presidencies: George H.W. Bush
column11: Bill Clinton
column12: George W. Bush
column13: and Barack Obama. The same thinking has induced the United States to expand NATO to Russias borders
column14: despite the fact that NATOs supposed purpose was to defend against an adversary  the Soviet Union  that no longer exists. Former Soviet president Mikhail Gorbachev has emphasized that eastward NATO expansion was certainly a violation of the spirit of those declarations and assurances that we were given in 1990
column15:  regarding the future of East-West security.

column1: There is a major economic difference
column2: however
column3: between now and 1991
column4: much less 1950. At the start of the Cold War
column6: the United States produced around 27 percent of world output. As of 1991
column7: when the Dick Cheney and Paul Wolfowitz dreams of US dominance were taking shape
column8: the United States accounted for around 22 percent of world production. By now
column9: according to IMF estimates
column10: the US share is 16 percent
column11: while China has surpassed the United States
column12: at around 18 percent. By 2021
column13: according to projections by the International Monetary Fund
column14: the United States will produce roughly 15 percent of global output compared with Chinas 20 percent. The United States is incurring massive public debt and cutting back on urgent public investments at home in order to sustain a dysfunctional
column15: militarized
column16: and costly foreign policy.

column1: Thus comes a fundamental choice. The United States can vainly continue the neoconservative project of unipolar dominance
column2: even as the recent failures in the Middle East and Americas declining economic preeminence guarantee the ultimate failure of this imperial vision. If
column3: as some neoconservatives support
column4: the United States now engages in an arms race with China
column5: we are bound to come up short in a decade or two
column6: if not sooner. The costly wars in the Middle East  even if continued much less enlarged in a Hillary Clinton presidency  could easily end any realistic hopes for a new era of scaled-up federal investments in education
column7: workforce training
column8: infrastructure
column9: science and technology
column10: and the environment.

column1: The far smarter approach will be to maintain Americas defensive capabilities but end its imperial pretensions. This
column2: in practice
column3: means cutting back on the far-flung network of military bases
column4: ending wars of regime change
column5: avoiding a new arms race (especially in next-generation nuclear weapons)
column6: and engaging China
column7: India
column8: Russia
column9: and other regional powers in stepped-up diplomacy through the United Nations
column10: especially through shared actions on the UNs Sustainable Development Goals
column11: including climate change
column12: disease control
column13: and global education.

column1: Many American conservatives will sneer at the very thought that the United States room for maneuver should be limited in the slightest by the UN. But think how much better off the United States would be today had it heeded the UN Security Councils wise opposition to the wars of regime change in Iraq
column2: Libya
column3: and Syria. Many conservatives will point to Vladimir Putins actions in Crimea as proof that diplomacy with Russia is useless
column4: without recognizing that it was NATOs expansion to the Baltics and its 2008 invitation to Ukraine to join NATO
column5: that was a primary trigger of Putins response.

column1: In the end
column2: the Soviet Union bankrupted itself through costly foreign adventures such as the 1979 invasion of Afghanistan and its vast over-investment in the military. Today the United States has similarly over-invested in the military
column3: and could follow a similar path to decline if it continues the wars in the Middle East and invites an arms race with China. Its time to abandon the reveries
column4: burdens
column5: and self-deceptions of empire and to invest in sustainable development at home and in partnership with the rest of the world.

column1: Jeffrey D. Sachs is University Professor and Director of the Center for Sustainable Development at Columbia University
column2: and author of The Age of Sustainable Development."	FAKE

column1: Donald Trump Pushes Republican Party to Its Breaking Point	"Donald Trump has summoned a tornado of negative stories that threaten to rip his campaign from its foundation if he doesn't stop

column1: But hopes aren't high among Republican allies that Trump

column1: Within the GOP

column1: As Trump regularly reminds voters at rallies

column1: CNBC's John Harwood quoted an unnamed ally of campaign manager Paul Manafort on Tuesday night who called the mood ""suicidal"" and said Manafort was ""mailing it in"" after concluding that Trump was incapable of taking his advice.
Another source inside the campaign told NBC News that Harwood's account was ""all true"" and that the environment was ""way worse than people realize.""
Lending particular urgency to this week's chaos is Trump's declining position in the polls against Clinton
column2: who appears to be enjoying a major bump from last week's Democratic convention.

column1: Surveys indicate Clinton not only eliminating Trump's gains from his own convention
column2: but also regaining the solid lead she held before FBI Director James Comey's criticism of her email practices depressed her support.

column1: The most recent NBC News/SurveyMonkey poll puts him behind Clinton
column2: 50 percent to 42 percent
column3: with registered voters. A Fox News poll released Wednesday gave Clinton a 49 percent-to-39 percent lead.

column1: Convention bounces are sometimes fleeting
column2: but once the race settles
column3: there are few opportunities for candidates to make up ground
column4: making Trump's missteps especially dangerous.

column1: The Olympics begin this weekend
column2: making it harder for Trump to win free media for much of the month. He could make it up by buying TV time
column3: but the Clinton campaign and allied groups have reserved $98 million in ads through November — compared to less than $1 million on Trump's side.

column1: The less likely Trump looks to win and the more toxic he looks with key voting groups
column2: the more pressure Republican candidates in competitive races will face to denounce him.""

column1: If Trump wants us to make a choice between our senators and representatives and him
column2: it won't be him
column3: another GOP operative in a swing state told NBC News.

column1: But it's a delicate balance. If Republican candidates abandon Trump en masse
column2: party operatives warn
column3: depressed voters might stay home and leave federal and state candidates vulnerable to an electoral wipeout.

column1: While Republican candidates in some swing states have polled ahead of Trump by distancing themselves from his more controversial positions
column2: they still need conservatives to show up and split their ticket to prevail.

column1: So far
column2: few high-profile Republicans running for office have repudiated Trump — even Sen. Kelly Ayotte of New Hampshire is sticking by him
column3: despite Trump's recent insults and Ayotte's longtime discomfort with his rhetoric.

column1: The further Trump sinks
column2: however

column1: A veteran GOP strategist suggested that the party should be able to win competitive House and Senate races with smart campaigns if Trump is trailing Clinton by 1 to 5 points. But if he starts to trail by double digits in polls — as he did in Fox's survey — it could create a panic as Republicans rush to disavow his candidacy in the hope that they might survive the coming disaster.
Publicly

We've got to get back to these basic issues that got him this far

column2: but the country's railway operator said that no direct trains would depart for Western Europe

column1: A Reuters photographer estimated that up to 1

column3: Africa and Asia had poured into the Keleti railway station from the square outside. The photographer also reported that some people had stormed the first trains they could find and were trying to push themselves and their children into the carriages through the doors and windows.

column1: The Associated Press reported that announcements were made over the station loudspeakers in several languages
column2: including English

column1: Some reportedly banged on windows

column3: ""No camp
column4: no camp.""

column1: Some of the migrants had been forced to sleep in the streets of Budapest for two nights after Hungarian police closed the terminal to them Tuesday. At that time

column1: There was no immediate explanation from the police or other authorities about why the migrants were allowed to enter the terminal Thursday. The rail company said its stance was due to ""railway transport"" security reasons. Later Thursday

column1: How a $15 minimum wage went from ‘extreme’ to enacted	"What once was considered “pie in the sky” is slowly becoming law. In New York
column2: state legislators just agreed to raise the state minimum wage to $15 an hour
column3: with the full effect beginning in New York City by December 2018. California just passed a compromise raising the minimum wage to $15 an hour by 2022. New Jersey and the District are planning to move similar laws. After New York and California
column4: nearly 1 in 5 (18 percent) in the U.S. workforce will be on the path to $15 an hour.

column1: How did this reform go from being scorned as “extreme” to being enacted? Consensus politicians don’t champion it. Pundits and chattering heads tend to ignore it. Many liberal economists deride it as too radical. The idea moved only because workers and allies organized and demanded the change.
Three years ago
column2: fast-food workers walked off the job in what began the “fight for $15 and a union.” With the federal government as the largest low-wage employer
column3: federal contract workers demonstrated repeatedly outside the Pentagon
column4: Congress and the White House
column5: demanding executive action under the banner of a “Good Jobs Nation.”

column1: Progressive politicians added their voices. In Seattle
column2: Kshama Sawant
column3: an engineer and economist running under the banner of Socialist Alternative party
column4: won a seat on the city council in 2013. She made a $15 minimum wage a centerpiece of her campaign and pushed it when in office. The Service Employees International Union
column5: one of America’s largest unions; business leaders such as Nick Hanauer; and political leaders such as Seattle Mayor Ed Murray helped build the coalition needed to get it done. Now wages in Seattle are headed to $15. And in SeaTac
column6: the airport district that passed a $15 minimum wage in a referendum
column7: the wage is in effect now.

column1: In New York
column2: insurgent mayoral candidate Bill de Blasio made raising the minimum wage central to his campaign. He and the Working Families Party joined with striking low-wage workers
column3: labor and community groups
column4: and city council members. Zephyr Teachout’s surprisingly strong challenge to Gov. Andrew Cuomo (D) put pressure on him to act.

column1: At the national level
column2: Sen. Bernie Sanders (I-Vt.) and Congressional Progressive Caucus co-chairs Rep. Keith Ellison (D-Minn.) and Rep. Raúl M. Grijalva (D-Ariz.) joined with demonstrating contract workers. The CPC lobbied President Obama to use his executive power to raise wages for federal contract workers. The president responded with three historic executive orders
column3: lifting the minimum wage for contract workers to $10.10
column4: cracking down on wage theft and other workplace violations
column5: and extending paid leave to contract employees.

column1: Obstacles remain. Today
column2: 42 percent of American workers earn less than $15 an hour. And the right to a union has been trampled by relentless and at times lawless corporate resistance. The Republican leadership in Congress refuses even to allow a vote on raising the national minimum wage that
column3: at $7.25 an hour
column4: means full-time workers can’t even raise their families out of poverty.

column1: But now Christine Owens
column2: executive director of the National Employment Law Project
column3: says that “the Fight for $15 launched by underpaid workers has changed the nation’s economic trajectory
column4: beginning to reverse decades of wage inequality.”

column1: Contrary to the business lobby
column2: an analysis by economists at the University of California at Berkeley shows that New York’s increases will not lead to job losses. The higher wages will generate billions in new consumer spending; the increased sales will offset the costs to businesses. In Seattle
column3: the unemployment rate reached an eight-year low after the initial increases in the minimum wage last year.

column1: This movement continues to build. The Fight for $15 and Good Jobs Nation initiatives will ratchet up their walkouts and demonstrations this month. On Monday
column2: an interfaith coalition of religious leaders issued a call for “moral action on the economy.” They will press presidential candidates to pledge to “issue an executive order to make sure taxpayer dollars reward ‘model employers’ that pay a living wage of at least $15 an hour
column3: provide decent benefits and allow workers to organize without retaliation.” As Jim Winkler
column4: general secretary of the National Council of Churches
column5: summarized: “This election is fundamentally about whether the next president is willing to take transformative executive action to close the gap between the wealthy and workers.”

column1: Sanders has made $15 and a union a centerpiece of his campaign. He has urged Obama to take executive action and surely will sign the pledge. Hillary Clinton supports raising the minimum wage to $12.50
column2: allowing cities to go higher. Her position on the pledge is unknown. The Republican candidates — Sen. Ted Cruz (R-Tex.)
column3: Donald Trump and Ohio Gov. John Kasich — oppose raising the minimum wage and would likely repeal Obama’s executive orders on low-wage contract workers if elected.

column1: With inequality reaching record extremes
column2: childhood poverty the worst in the industrial world and more Americans struggling simply to stay afloat
column3: this country is desperately in need of bold reform. Yet bold ideas are repeatedly mocked as unrealistic and blocked by entrenched interests and conservative politicians. What the activists and low-wage workers have shown with their fight for $15 is that the changes we need will come if people organize and force them. Many commentators deride Sanders’s call for a political revolution
column4: but that may be the most realistic idea of them all.

column1: Read more from Katrina vanden Heuvel’s archive or follow her on Twitter."	REAL

Will Asia trade deal hurt US workers? Six tough questions answered.	"Critics of the Trans-Pacific Partnership trade deal – and the Senate bill to give the president fast track authority to negotiate it – say it will hurt American workers. Here is a look at some of those claims.
President Obama delivers remarks on trade at Nike corporate headquarters in Beaverton
column2: Ore.
column3: Friday. Mr. Obama pressed fellow Democrats to support his push for a trade deal with Asian countries.

column1: The Obama administration has a tough sell convincing Congress to grant it “fast track” trade negotiating authority so it can complete negotiations on the biggest regional trade deal in United States history – the Trans-Pacific Partnership agreement
column2: involving a total of 12 nations (though not China).

column1: The administration sees this as a tremendous opportunity for economic growth. It wants fast track – which would require Congress only an up-or-down vote on a final agreement – to help it secure the best deal it can. Opponents
column2: mostly Democrats but some Republicans
column3: too
column4: say fast track and TPP will cost America jobs. But supporters say their approach is “new and improved.”

column1: Below are some of the critics’ chief concerns
column2: and how fast track and TPP supporters respond:

column1: Critics say free trade kills jobs. Business says it creates them. However
column2: it’s not that simple.

column1: Most economists agree that broadening trade results in economic growth
column2: but benefits are shared unevenly.

column1: “Trade liberalization promotes overall economic growth among trading partners but … there are both winners and losers
column2: ” the nonpartisan Congressional Research Service said in an April 2015 report. It’s also extremely difficult to calculate how a trade deal affects job creation and loss “due to a lack of data and important theoretical and practical matters
column3: ” CRS said.

column1: In reviewing the 1994 North American Free Trade Agreement
column2: CRS found that ""NAFTA did not cause the huge job losses feared by the critics or the large economic gains predicted by supporters.""

column1: The Obama White House admits that while the overall benefits of trade expansion “may be large” they may also be “unevenly distributed.” Trade
column2: therefore
column3: “can also have adverse effects for some workers” the Council of Economic Advisers (CEA) said in “ The Economic Benefits of US Trade
column4: ” a report issued earlier this month.

column1: So the White House is arguing to members of Congress that policies the administration supports
column2: such as investment in infrastructure
column3: worker training
column4: and education
column5: can offset jobs lost as a result of trade deals.

column1: Assistance for the displaced: Is it enough?

Trade adjustment assistance (TAA) programs provide help beyond traditional jobless benefits for workers displaced by trade. Displaced workers get help to train for a new career. Without such extra help
column2: the thinking goes
column3: these workers might find new jobs but have to take a big cut in pay – or they might drop out of the job market entirely.

column1: The programs are also designed to boost chances of passing trade legislation
column2: drawing in some Democrats who might otherwise be in the ""no"" camp. In a separate bill
column3: TAA has been beefed up to raise benefits and to include service sector workers for the first time.

column1: Whether TAA works
column2: however
column3: is a matter of debate. One 2012 Labor Department study found that
column4: after four years
column5: participants had earnings comparable to a group of non-TAA job losers.

column1: That can be viewed as bad news (even with the help
column2: they aren't doing any better than other people recovering from joblessness). Or as good news (this is a particularly hard-hit group of workers
column3: who might have fared worse without the training).

column1: Politically
column2: “If TAA made even a relatively modest contribution to the ease of enacting free-trade policies
column3: the program’s benefits would outweigh its costs
column4: said the report.

column1: When countries such as China and Japan artificially lower the value of their currencies
column2: it costs Americans jobs because foreign imports become cheaper and US exports more expensive. So critics want language in the fast-track bill against currency manipulation.

column1: The bill’s supporters don’t dispute the dangers. That’s why
column2: for the first time
column3: fast-track legislation makes the issue a “negotiating objective” for the administration.

column1: But an enforcement mechanism is too strong a remedy to include in the bill
column2: the administration says
column3: claiming that it would derail trade negotiations. It could also endanger America’s ability to manage its own currency
column4: and lead to retaliation and trade wars
column5: US officials say. They point to modest success in recent years in pressuring China to increase the value of its currency.

column1: Sen. Charles Schumer (D) of New York
column2: who calls currency manipulation the “most significant trade challenge this country faces
column3: ” succeeded in getting a currency amendment in a related customs bill. It’s not yet clear what will happen to this measure or other attempts to address the issue.

column1: Don’t know what’s in the TPP? That’s because it’s “top secret
column2: ” criticizes Sen. Elizabeth Warren (D) of Massachusetts
column3: a vocal opponent of fast track.

column1: That was a complaint that her colleague
column2: Sen. Ron Wyden (D) of Oregon heard a lot at town halls. As a result
column3: “I really went to the mat on these secrecy issues
column4: ” Senator Wyden said at a recent Monitor breakfast.

column1: Senator Wyden
column2: who is the administration’s point man on trade in the Senate
column3: points out that with the fast-track bill
column4: the full text of the TPP and any other trade agreements will be public for the first time – 60 days before Congress starts voting on it. Under fast track
column5: any member of Congress can have access to classified negotiating texts. Members can attend negotiating rounds or be briefed by the administration on request.

column1: That’s not good enough for Senator Warren. She’s pushing a petition that tells US trade officials: “No vote on a fast-track for trade agreements until the American people can see what’s in this TPP deal.” Members of Congress also complain about restricted access for their staffs
column2: on whom they heavily rely.

column1: Critics are up in arms over the way corporations settle disputes over alleged violations of free-trade agreements. The investor-state dispute settlement
column2: or ISDS
column3: lets foreign countries sue governments in special tribunals
column4: rather than going through the country’s court system.

column1: The problem with this
column2: they argue
column3: is that the tribunals grant huge payments to corporations for the violations – such big payments that countries are then incentivized to change their regulations. Not only do supporters of labor object
column4: they worry that foreign companies will use the tribunals to force changes in US regulations and laws.

column1: The administration says it is writing safeguards into the TPP that will prevent this from happening.
President Obama also told Yahoo Politics: ""There is no chance
column2: zero chance
column3: that the US would be sued on something like our financial regulations
column4: and on food safety
column5: and on the various environmental regulations that we have in place
column6: mainly because we treat everybody the same."" He added
column7: ""We treat our own companies the same way we treat somebody else's companies.""

column1: For the first time
column2: a non-free-market economy such as Vietnam will be included in a broad trade deal involving the US
column3: and that’s a problem
column4: say critics. “Americans should not be forced to compete against desperately poor workers like those in Vietnam who make as little as 56 cents an hour
column5: ” Sen. Bernie Sanders (I) of Vermont
column6: wrote in a letter to to US Trade Representative Michael Froman last month.

column2: the US trade deficit with Vietnam was $19.6 billion.

column1: But supporters argue that fast track and the TPP are precisely intended to protect against this problem. The fast-track bill raises the bar for labor
column2: environment
column3: and human rights standards
column4: says Wyden. “Trading partners must adopt and maintain core international labor and environmental standards
column5: with trade sanctions if they do not comply
column6: ” he said in a statement last month.

column1: Staff writers David Cook and Mark Trumbull contributed to this report."	REAL

Pediatrician Jim Smith is thrilled with his new career as a professional Clown. He specializes in children’s birthday parties but has the skill set to perform at kindergarten graduations as well. “Leaving the hospital was the best thing I’ve ever done. Can I say that again?” said an elated Dr. Jim Smith.
Dr. Jim Smith first became interested in becoming a Clown after suffering from extreme burnout. Catalysts included helicopter Moms
column2: antivax Jenny Mccarthy supporters
column3: and the general stress of saving the world. After dealing with one particularly overbearing soccer mom
column4: he stormed out of the office ranting
column5: “**** this noise; I can’t take this horse**** anymore!” and never returned. Using obscenities for the first time felt nothing short of liberating.

column1: Dr. Jim Smith’s new lifestyle is entirely different from the clinic he used to work at. Previously
column2: he woke up at 6am sharp but now he rolls out of bed in the neighborhood of 11:30am to ensure he is prompt for lunchtime birthday contracts. “I take my responsibilities very seriously
column3: ” said Dr. Jim Smith proudly. After a solid hour of challenging work

column1: In spite of all the Clown perks

column3: the Doctor made $200
column4: 000.00 per year. Now he makes $17

column1: Dr. Jim Smith’s favorite part of the job is showcasing his balloon skills. “Even though the kids cry sometimes

column3: ” he stated enthusiastically. Creating these balloon animals has proved to be significantly more meaningful than diagnosing heart defects.

City, County Leaders Ask Court To Lift Injunction On Obama Immigration Programs	"WASHINGTON -- Leaders from more than 70 cities and counties
column2: some going against their states
column3: joined a legal brief filed Monday asking an appeals court to allow President Barack Obama's deportation relief policies to move forward.

column1: Continuing to delay implementation of the president’s executive action on immigration hurts our economy and puts families at risk
column2: New York Mayor Bill de Blasio (D)
column3: who spearheaded the effort with Los Angeles Mayor Eric Garcetti (D) as part of Cities United for Immigration Action
column4: said in a statement.

column1: Cities are where immigrants live
column2: and cities are where the president's executive action will be successfully implemented
column3: he continued. ""Our cities are united
column4: and we will fight for the immigration reform this nation needs and deserves -- whether in the courtroom
column5: in Congress
column6: or in our communities. Make no mistake about it: our voices will be heard.""

column1: Under the policies Obama announced in November
column2: as many as 5 million undocumented immigrants with longstanding ties to the U.S. may be able to stay and work temporarily.

column1: Twenty-six states
column2: led by Texas
column3: filed the lawsuit
column4: arguing the relief programs would cause them harm and violate the Constitution. They've won support from some Republican members of Congress and governors.

column1: But 14 states and the District of Columbia

column1: Garcetti and de Blasio spearheaded a similar brief in January and received about 30 signatures. The latest brief is backed by mayors

column6: North Carolina
column7: South Carolina
column8: Arizona
column9: Ohio
column10: Indiana
column11: Arkansas
column12: Wisconsin

column1: The brief argues the executive actions would be good for public safety and the economy in their cities and counties

column1: The Obama administration is seeking a ruling to allow the programs to move forward. The Justice Department filed an appeal last week asking the court to lift the injunction.
