column1: Democrats Clinton and Sanders pounce on Flint water crisis — and each other	"Hillary Clinton and Bernie Sanders clashed fiercely Sunday over jobs
column2: trade and Wall Street while agreeing that much more must be done to address a two-year-old water-contamination crisis that has paralyzed this majority-black city.

column1: The session included the sharpest exchange yet between the Democratic presidential candidates over their economic plans and records. It included a heated argument over the auto industry bailout
column2: which is of keen interest in Michigan
column3: where both Democrats and Republicans will hold presidential primaries Tuesday.

column1: Clinton emphasized the “hard choices” that lawmakers and President Obama made in 2009
column2: facing the prospect of a collapse in the auto industry
column3: and she noted that Sanders
column4: a senator from Vermont
column5: voted against a bailout measure.

column1: Sanders said he voted against forcing “hard-working” Americans to bail out “the crooks of Wall Street.”
“If everybody had voted the way he did
column2: I believe the auto industry would have collapsed
column3: ” Clinton said.

column1: Sanders angrily hushed Clinton as she sought to interject. “Excuse me
column2: I’m talking
column3: ” he said
column4: drawing gasps from the audience.

column1: “If you’re going to talk
column2: tell the whole story
column3: ” Clinton replied.

column1: “You’ll get your turn
column2: ” he snapped.

column1: The debate
column2: which aired on CNN
column3: was added to the Democrats’ schedule after Sanders emerged as a stronger-than-expected challenger. Flint was chosen as the site to highlight the water crisis
column4: which has become a focus of liberal anger.

column1: The episode began two years ago
column2: when state overseers who had taken over the city switched its water supply to the Flint River without treating the water to avoid corrosion of lead pipes. Lead leached into the water supply
column3: and although residents began complaining immediately
column4: the problems did not fully come to light until January
column5: amid revelations that state officials had spent much of 2014 and 2015 dismissing those complaints.

column1: Both Clinton and Sanders have said that the crisis would never have happened in a richer
column2: whiter city. The debate featured heartbreaking and harrowing stories about children who stopped growing
column3: lost their hair or were intellectually stunted by poisoned water.

column1: Sanders used his opening statement to repeat his call for the state’s Republican governor to resign over what he called a “dereliction of duty
column2: ” before shifting to his core message about economic inequality.

column1: For the first time
column2: Clinton agreed that Gov. Rick Snyder should “resign or be recalled.” Previously
column3: she had said that her approach was to try to solve the problem and that assigning blame could wait.

column1: “The state should also be sending money immediately to help this city. I know the state of Michigan has a rainy-day fund for emergencies
column2: ” Clinton said. “It’s raining lead in Flint.”

column1: Sunday’s debate opened with a moment of silence in honor of former first lady Nancy Reagan
column2: who died Sunday at 94. The session was the first Democratic debate since the Super Tuesday contests
column3: when Clinton emerged with a lead of nearly 200 pledged delegates over Sanders.

column1: She slightly expanded her delegate lead after a win in Louisiana on Saturday
column2: while Sanders claimed victories in Nebraska and Kansas. The debate had been underway for only a few minutes Sunday when Sanders’s victory in the Maine caucuses was announced.

column1: Sanders’s successes and his vow to remain in the race through the Democratic convention lent a new tension to the debate. Gone were the magnanimous and polite gestures each had offered the other in previous debates.
“Let’s have some facts instead of some rhetoric for a change
column2: ” Clinton said testily.

column1: “Let me tell my story
column2: you tell yours
column3: ” Sanders said at another point. “Your story is voting for every disastrous trade amendment and voting for corporate America.”

column1: Sanders mocked Clinton’s defense of the Export-Import Bank as helpful to small businesses. He would shutter the institution he called the “Bank of Boeing” for its efforts on behalf of the aircraft maker as it competes with rival Airbus.
Sanders’s opposition to the Ex-Im Bank put him at odds with the Democratic caucus in Congress — a fact that he embraced.
“I don’t want to break the bad news
column2: ” Sanders said sarcastically. “Democrats are not always right. Democrats have often supported corporate welfare. Democrats have supported disastrous trade agreements.”

column1: Both candidates have campaigned hard in Michigan. Tuesday’s vote here will serve as a test of Clinton’s institutional support from unions and of Sanders’s appeal with the working class.

It could also set the stage for a contentious fall election. Clinton has already begun shifting her focus on the campaign trail to a potential general-election matchup against the Republican front-runner
column2: Donald Trump
column3: although neither he nor the rest of the Republican field got much mention Sunday.

column1: “Donald Trump’s bigotry
column2: his bullying
column3: his bluster are not going to wear well with the American people
column4: ” Clinton said.

column1: Labeling Sanders a communist “was one of the nice things he said about me
column2: ” Sanders joked.

column1: Michigan is a swing state that both Republicans and Democrats see as a potential victory in November. Trump is favored to win here Tuesday
column2: and his tough-guy message on international trade has found an audience here.

column1: Over several days of campaigning here
column2: Sanders has focused squarely on jobs and trade
column3: accusing Clinton of backing international trade deals that stripped Michigan of good-paying jobs.

column1: He also stressed his long opposition to trade pacts such as the pending Trans-Pacific Partnership with Pacific Rim nations. Clinton had backed the TPP deal
column2: a signature initiative of President Obama
column3: when she was secretary of state. She announced last year that she opposes it
column4: which Sanders allies call an election-season conversion that she could reverse if elected.

column1: “I am very glad
column2: Anderson
column3: that Secretary Clinton has discovered religion on this issue
column4: ” Sanders said to moderator Anderson Cooper. “But it’s a little bit too late.”

column1: The Sanders campaign thinks that the primary map becomes more favorable to him as the race shifts out of the South
column2: but his window to overtake Clinton is narrowing.

column1: But with momentum from other primaries that featured large numbers of African American voters
column2: Clinton holds a comfortable lead in Michigan. She has focused her campaign here on black voters
column3: who were about a quarter of the primary electorate in 2008
column4: and on the Flint crisis.

column1: A Detroit Free Press-WXYZ poll released late Saturday shows her leading Sanders by 56 percent to 31 percent
column2: a gap that “suggests it may be too late for him to battle back to a victory here despite a strong effort in recent days
column3: ” the newspaper wrote.

column1: The poll had her in a statistical tie with Sanders on the question of trustworthiness and up three points on the question of who would be the “more progressive president.” Only 17 percent of those polled felt Sanders had the best chance of winning in November.
At a news conference before the debate
column2: Sanders acknowledged that he trails Clinton in Michigan
column3: in part because he has continued to struggle to reach African American voters
column4: who represented about 23 percent of the Democratic primary electorate in 2008.

column1: During the debate
column2: he fumbled a question about what “racial blind spots” he has by suggesting that only black people live in ghettos.

column1: “When you’re white
column2: you don’t know what it’s like to be living in a ghetto
column3: you don’t know what it’s like to be poor
column4: you don’t know what it’s like to be hassled when you walk down the street or when you get dragged out of a car
column5: ” he said.

column1: For her part
column2: Clinton misstated her own position on gun control
column3: a central issue in her campaign.

column1: “I think we have to try everything that works to try to limit the number of people and the kinds of people who are given access to firearms
column2: ” she said.

column1: That goes further than her official position that loopholes in existing gun-control laws should be narrowed and that people on the federal terrorist no-fly list should be prevented from buying guns.
Despite predicting a continued strong challenge from Sanders
column2: Clinton’s advisers hope that by April
column3: her delegate advantage will make it virtually impossible for Sanders to claim the nomination.

column1: The catastrophic failure represented by the Flint water crisis set the tone for the feisty debate
column2: with both candidates expressing outrage and promising action.

column1: “President Sanders would fire anybody who knew about what was happening and did not act appropriately
column2: ” Sanders said.

column1: Sanders also demanded a rebate for Flint residents who paid their water bills throughout the crisis
column2: something that has already been done. Snyder has obtained a $30 million appropriation to pay Flint water bills and give residents money back.

column1: “You are paying three times more than poisoned water than I pay in Burlington
column2: Vermont
column3: for clean water
column4: ” Sanders said.

column1: Clinton pledged to “get rid of lead everywhere” within five years if she is elected.
Elahe Izadi in Washington and Steve Friess in Flint contributed to this report."	REAL
Israel: 1984 Everlasting	"Photo by SarahTz | CC BY 2.0
Empty Declarations of Democracy… Vacant Boasts of humanity
For decades
column2: Israel has held itself out as being the lone “democracy” in the Middle East; a state where the rights of individuals could not and would not be held hostage to the autocratic whims of royalty
column3: but rather a full partner to a free and robust electoral process that guarantees not just meaningful input from the governed but the ability to challenge state policies as the winds of change blow from “the river to the sea.”

column1: Once again
column2: recent events have proven this to be just so much a perverse myth… empty rhetoric… second only to the brazen unfounded Israeli boast of having the “most humane army in the world
column3: ” even as the body count of Palestinian children grows in cemeteries and prisons that have become very much its own unique brand of 21 st century youth hostel.

column1: Recently
column2: Hagai El-Ad
column3: an Israeli and Jew
column4: who serves as executive director of B’Tselem (The Israel Information Center for Human Rights in the Occupied Territories)
column5: spoke before the UN Security Council urging it to take immediate action against Israel’s illegal settlements.

column1: Demagoguery and Inhumanity Exposed
Not quite 1400 words in its entirety
column2: one paragraph in particular of El-Ad’s testimony sums up life for millions of those captured by a democracy that sees day as night… pain as pleasure. Crushing
column3: despite its brevity
column4: the power and pain of these words could easily be part of an opening statement by a war crimes prosecutor at a tribunal called to hold Israel accountable for crimes unseen since the Nuremburg tribunals some 70 years ago.

column1: “What does it mean
column2: in practical terms
column3: to spend 49 years
column4: a lifetime
column5: under military rule? When violence breaks out
column6: or when particular incidents attract global attention
column7: you get a glimpse into certain aspects of life under occupation. But what about the rest of the time? What about the many “ordinary” days of a 17
column8: 898-day-long occupation
column9: which is still going strong? Living under military rule mostly means invisible
column10: bureaucratic
column11: daily
column12: violence. It means living under an endless permit regime
column13: which controls Palestinian life from cradle to grave: Israel controls the population registry; Israel controls work permits; Israel controls who can travel abroad – and who cannot; Israel controls who can visit from abroad – and who cannot; in some villages
column14: Israel maintains lists of who can visit the village
column15: or who is allowed to farm which fields. Permits can sometimes be denied; permits must always be renewed. Thus with every breath they take
column16: Palestinians breathe in occupation. Make a wrong move
column17: and you can lose your freedom of movement
column18: your livelihood
column19: or even the opportunity to marry and build a family with your beloved.”

column1: In a free democratic society these comments
column2: while perhaps controversial
column3: would certainly not constitute sedition. In an open
column4: healthy State these words would surely give reason to pause and reflect… but never serve as a rational trip-wire to strip their speaker of his birthright as an unbound citizen empowered to support his government for policies he finds just but condemn it for those that bear the star of tyranny. It is a distinction that Israel has failed to adopt or learn over the course of its 50 year subjugation of millions whose only crime is to be born Palestinian in occupied land with sign-posts everywhere that simply say “ Jews only.”

column1: Beating of Chests
Not long after El-Ad’s powerful speech before a world body entrusted with securing fundamental rights and liberty for all of its citizenry
column2: the hue and cry could be heard among Israeli political elite to silence such subversive talk. Thus
column3: Coalition Chairman MK David Bitan of the Likud Party undertook the first steps of reprisal by announcing he was considering submitting a bill to the Knesset that could remove the citizenship of Israelis who act against their country in international organizations. According to Bitan
column4: “El-Ad’s actions at the Security Council are a blatant violation of the trust citizens must have for their country
column5: so he should go find another country where he could be a citizen.”

column1: Alarming
column2: one might ask; no
column3: not at all… merely another in an endless daily stream of steps by a government second to none when it comes to autocratic
column4: indeed dictatorial
column5: control of every fiber of its citizens freedoms
column6: particularly their ability to access and exchange information without fear of retribution.

column1: Much is known and largely ignored about the thousands of Palestinian civilians that have been targeted and slaughtered by the Israeli military machine in occupied Palestine
column2: whether in Gaza or the West Bank. Indeed
column3: the killing fields of Gaza or execution alleys of back street Jerusalem no longer acquire more than a passing fancy or footnote in the evening news spread across a world now busy with outrages of more recent vintage. After 70 years of slaughter
column4: it’s just so much business as usual.

column1: So
column2: too
column3: we have seemingly become numbed to the reality that thousands of Palestinian political prisoners languish in isolation
column4: many sitting year after year
column5: some for decades
column6: in administrative detention cells of political prisons… uncharged
column7: undefended and untried
column8: tortured in ways that leave the spirits of those still roaming the now empty cellblocks of South Africa’s notorious Robben Island relieved their misery was ended quickly through state sanctioned executions by “suicide.”

column1: The Mighty Censor’s Sword

Closures of Palestinian news rooms and television stations are commonplace… yet no more remarkable than assaults by Israel upon Palestinian journalists that long ago moved into triple digits and show no sign of abating. The Palestinian Centre for Development and Media Freedoms ( MADA ) has documented a pattern of such attacks by Israel running
column2: for some time now
column3: at almost 400 per year. Although the exact number of Palestinian journalists killed or injured by Israel over just the last decade may never be known
column4: it has been documented that seventeen lost their lives in Gaza
column5: alone
column6: during the months of bombings which it endured in 2014.

column1: Dozens of Palestinian journalists and private bloggers have been arrested by Israel and held for violating vague administrative codes that typically come down to the application of entirely undefined prohibitions such as “incitement.” Dareen Tatour
column2: a 35-year-old poet and Arab-Palestinian citizen of Israel
column3: was arrested and placed under administrative detention on charges of inciting violence via her poetry which she posted on Facebook and which merely praises those who fight against Israeli domination. Also arrested and charged with criminal incitement was 19-year-old Anas Khateeb
column4: on the basis of her Facebook posts which included such alarming statements as “Jerusalem is Arab
column5: ” and “Long live the Intifada.”

column1: Recently
column2: Palestinian journalist
column3: Samah Dweik
column4: was released from prison having served almost six months for an alleged incitement charge which resulted from comments about the occupation she posted on her private Facebook account. For most of her sentence
column5: her family was banned from visiting or having any contact with her. She was but one of over 20 Palestinian journalists recently imprisoned by Israel for allegations of incitement
column6: along with hundreds of other Palestinian activists or bloggers who have been targeted for arrest and prosecution for nothing more than postings of political opinions about the Israeli occupation and Palestinian resistance on social media. Dweik’s release came not long after Israel and Facebook entered into an agreement to “work together” to monitor Palestinian posts.

column1: The Sword Cuts Deeper
Increasingly
column2: Palestinians are not the sole victims of an Israeli policy to silence “dissent” or to dramatically curb the nature and extent of information made available to its citizens… Jews and Arabs alike. For example
column3: not long ago
column4: Israeli Defense Minister Avigdor Lieberman confronted the military station director after Army Radio broadcast a documentary on the life of the leading Palestinian national poet
column5: Mahmoud Darwish
column6: saying that material like Darwish’s shouldn’t darken Israeli airwaves.

column1: In what can only be described as a systematic effort to control both journalists and citizens in their ability to read and write
column2: to access and exchange information
column3: and to reach informed opinions essential to a public and democratic dialogue about current and future Israeli policies
column4: its machinery of censorship has become the linchpin of the State’s view of what is appropriate knowledge and speech and what is not.

column1: Thus
column2: of late
column3: Israel has begun to demand of social media giants such as Facebook and Twitter that they have input
column4: if not control
column5: over what posts ultimately find their way into the stream of ideas and debate within the Israeli public at large. According to Quds Press
column6: Facebook and Twitter recently deleted thousands of posts
column7: pages and accounts as a result of demands made by the Israeli Ministry of Justice based upon little more than amorphous claims that the information posed a threat to the safety of Israel.

column1: On an even more ominous note
column2: the Knesset has begun to formulate legislation that would require foreign entities to actively monitor social media sites for information deemed to be offensive to Israel. Under the legislation
column3: content based liability could be found for material published by foreign nationals
column4: addressed to foreign nationals and posted on foreign websites thereby reducing the concept of free speech in Israel to one that is cast by the prevailing political winds of the day and little else.

column1: Recently the chief Israeli censor notified dozens of Israeli bloggers and social media activists that any material they might wish to publish in their personal blogs or social media accounts
column2: when dealing with a wide range of what was described as “security” related subject matters
column3: must be vetted. Although provided a generic and ambiguous catalog of those areas to be submitted for clearance
column4: the targets
column5: themselves

+ Letters to the editor on military or security matters;
+ Contacts with foreign countries;
+ Anything connected to the nuclear industry;
+ Information about official delegations abroad;

+ Immigration policies from “endangered” nations;
+ Use of foreign sources or material that touch upon any of these areas;
+ Detention of those suspected of security offenses;
+ Any information about military industries;
+ Appointments
column2: resignations
column3: firings
column4: rumors about IDF activities or commanders

column1: Finally
column2: in a readily transparent effort to maintain a democratic illusion of a free and uncensored flow of information in the market place of ideas
column3: pursuant to the censorship regulations there are complete prohibitions against leaving any blank spaces or other potential indicators in one’s writing or posts that might suggest or lead one to conclude that material has been deleted.

column1: For those disturbed over this censorship procedure
column2: it must be remembered that we are
column3: after all
column4: talking about a state that recently placed 101st out of 179 countries in the press Freedom index worldwide. Indeed
column5: this appalling placement for the Middle East’s sole democracy is significantly better than Israel has scored in the Freedom index for quite a number of years.

column1: For those wondering just how widespread
column2: indeed systemic
column3: Israel’s censorship procedures are
column4: it is a country with a military censor procedure that has banned
column5: outright
column6: publication of
column7: soon to be
column8: some 2000 articles and redacted various information from 15
column9: 000 others in recent history. That is thousands of articles professional journalists and editors decided were of public interest but which never saw the light of day. Imagine how many more events of public interest went uninvestigated
column10: or articles which were not written
column11: issues debated
column12: or challenges brought to bear for the Israeli body politic to consider because of self-censorship by journalists or editors too tired or principled to seek pre – approval of their body of work by government censors. Stories simply swallowed up and disappeared by an industry of censorship.

column1: Human Rights… Israel Wrongs
Although not yet law
column2: in what can only be described as an all-out onslaught against core democratic rights and values
column3: over the last several days consideration of a bill has begun in the Knesset that would empower the Defense Minister to detain a citizen without trial; to deny one the right to pursue or obtain employment in a field of interest; to limit access to various public places; and “to impose any other order or restriction necessitated by considerations of national security or public safety”.

column1: Earlier in January 2011
column2: the Knesset endorsed a right-wing proposal to investigate some of Israel’s best-known human rights organizations for “delegitimizing” its military. Among others was B’Tselem. The proposed investigations would entail inquiries into the funding of several human rights groups that have a history of criticizing Israeli policies. At the time
column3: the Association for Civil Rights in Israel described the proposal as a “severe blow” to Israeli democracy and critics labeled the policy as “ McCarthyist “.

column1: Recently a variation on that bill became law in Israel compelling non-governmental organizations (NGOs) that receive more than half of their funding from foreign state entities to declare so publicly. Ultimately
column2: the legislative criteria were tailored specifically to silence criticism of government policies by some 27 NGO’s… 25 of which
column3: including B’Tselem
column4: are considered to be left-wing… while the other two are non-affiliated. As intended
column5: the bill will have absolutely no impact upon right-wing and pro-settlement NGOs which are funded almost entirely by private donations from powerful Zionists and Zionist entities from outside of Israel.

column1: One can only imagine that upon returning home to the firestorm awaiting him
column2: following his speech before the UN
column3: Hagai El-Ad surely felt what it must have been like to be an activist leftist Jew in the United States during the dark days of McCarthy.

column1: On the other hand
column2: perhaps El-Ad should consider himself very fortunate indeed. On his twitter account
column3: Arab-Palestinian MK Ahmad Tibi mocked MK David Bitan’s call for El-Ad’s de-citizenship saying: “Why stop at removing citizenship? Why not destroy the home of the B’Tselem director-general? Why not bar his entire family from entering the country
column4: remove his land
column5: submit them to administrative detention
column6: and put checkpoints and closures in his neighborhood?”"	FAKE

NO
column2: SANDERS WOULDN’T BE A BETTER MATCH FOR TRUMP

column1: Bernie Sanders is looking a lot like John Kasich these days. And
column2: no
column3: not because of their hand gestures.

column1: In the final round of “Super Sloppy Double Dare” that was the GOP nominating process
column2: Kasich argued that he should be the nominee because he handily beat Hillary Clinton in hypothetical head-to-head matchups while now-presumptive nominee Donald Trump consistently lagged.

column1: Now
column2: Sanders who is
column3: as Kasich was
column4: out of the running for the nomination is asking his party to throw over the frontrunner for the sake of general election viability. And there’s data to back him up.

column1: In this week’s Fox News poll and the most recent NYT/CBS News poll
column2: Sanders outperforms Clinton against Trump. And it had been true for Kasich
column3: too.

column1: But it doesn’t really matter. First
column2: any Democrat without her enormous negative ratings would match up better with Trump than Clinton does. Throw Martin O’Malley or even an imaginary candidate (insofar as those are different concepts) in a poll
column3: and you might see a similar result.

column1: And that’s because those candidates haven’t been the target of millions of dollars in attack ads or even garnered much in the way of media scrutiny. These are not just hypothetical matchups
column2: they are
column3: in many ways
column4: hypothetical candidates.

column1: Head-to-head matchup polls in primaries can be useful if you’re talking about frontrunners and/or candidates who have been substantially defined in the minds of voters.
Then there’s the question of how the process shapes the product. Competing for your party’s nomination definitely can damage your reputation. Lordy day
column2: it can.

column1: But
column2: there is also a payoff at the end of the line
column3: as the party swings in behind its man or woman. So it’s not just that Sanders’ head-to-head matchups with Trump aren’t reflective of the general-election reality
column4: neither are Clinton’s.

column1: The current Trump bump is real. The NYT/CBS News poll tells the tale: Eight in 10 Republicans said that the party should unite behind him
column2: despite their disagreements. And in his battle with Clinton
column3: Trump is getting the same post-victory boost his predecessor
column4: Mitt Romney
column5: got four years ago.

column1: After a primary season of unrivaled acrimony
column2: the realities of the binary choice of the general election are setting in.

column1: The big question now is what Clinton’s bounce will look like.
It will certainly be there. Eighty percent of Democrats in the poll said that party unity was essential to victory and 83 percent said Clinton could do that. For Republicans
column2: just 63 percent said unity was essential to victory and just 64 percent believed Trump could deliver on that task.

column1: That discrepancy helps explain Trump’s deficit in this survey.

What we must wait to see is how big a boost Clinton will get – perhaps less than Trump considering that her party is already more united. We also can’t know whether the surge in partisan loyalty we see for Trump today will last
column2: or if the party’s underlying fracture will reassert itself.

column1: The answers to both sets of questions will depend on how well Clinton and Trump traverse the eight weeks until convention time.

column1: Georgia Abandons Ukraine's Anti-Russian Obsession - Archil Sikharulidze	"Your daily reality snack Georgia Abandons Ukraine's Anti-Russian Obsession
After a brief period in which both Ukraine and Georgia appeared to be united against Russia
column2: it now appears that the two nations are moving along very different paths Originally appeared at Russia Direct

column1: In October
column2: Georgia didn’t support any of Ukraine’s resolutions denouncing the Kremlin’s foreign policy within the Parliamentary Assembly of the Council of Europe (PACE). That is surprising
column3: given how many analysts had by now assumed that Georgia and Ukraine were on the same page when it came to Russia.

column1: The two resolutions deal with “the political implications of Russia’s aggression in Ukraine” and human rights abuses “on the occupied Ukrainian territories.” By supporting them
column2: PACE recognized the military conflict in Ukraine as “Russian aggression” for the first time and called on the Kremlin to withdraw its forces from the eastern part of Ukraine. Moreover
column3: it denounced the parliamentary elections
column4: recently conducted by Russia in Crimea .

column1: When the Georgian delegation in PACE didn’t support these resolutions
column2: the nation’s pro-Western parties reacted strongly. For example
column3: the United National Movement lambasted the Georgian government and accused the country’s former Prime Minister
column4: Bidzina Ivanishvili
column5: of supporting Russia. Moreover
column6: Mikheil Saakashvili
column7: the former Georgian president and now the governor of the Odessa region in Ukraine
column8: described such a stance as a “disgraceful” move.

column1: However
column2: an immediate response came from one of the members of the Georgian delegation in PACE
column3: Eka Beselia. She retorted that Tbilisi needed to defend its own national interests. Even though this statement seems to have alleviated the increasing conflict
column4: the video of Russian-Ukrainian journalist Matwey Ganapolsky
column5: who accuses Georgia of betraying Ukraine in favor of Russia
column6: fuelled the tensions. In contrast
column7: Russian pundits see the unwillingness of Georgia to vote for the PACE resolution as a sign of improvement in Tbilisi-Moscow relations.

column1: In reality
column2: the reluctance of the Georgian Dream
column3: the ruling party in Georgia
column4: to approve these resolutions is just the logical conclusion of complicated relations with Kiev. Since the start of the color revolutions in the post-Soviet space
column5: Georgia and Ukraine were largely in the same boat.

column1: After the success of the Rose Revolution in Tbilisi and the Orange Revolution in Kiev
column2: the newly elected governments were closely connected with each other and teamed up against Russia. This resulted from friendly relations between Ukraine’s former prime minister Yulia Timoshenko and former president Viktor Yushchenko on the one hand
column3: and Georgia’s Saakashvili on the other hand.

column1: However
column2: their relationship was rather pragmatic in its nature
column3: although officially Tbilisi recognized Ukraine as one of its closest allies. Since 2007 the democratic processes in the two countries have started moving in a reverse direction. Saakashvili’s penchant for conducting an aggressive policy as well as his authoritarian inclinations was increasing
column4: while Ukraine faced the corruption and the political rivalry between Timoshenko and Yushchenko.

column1: The more impact this had on the countries’ stability and development
column2: the more obvious became the fact that the ruling elites from both sides did not support democratic reforms
column3: but only the regimes that were friendly to them. Thus
column4: Georgian-Ukrainian relations could be seen as a form of cooperation between governments
column5: not between the people.

column1: And this trend became relevant until the 2010 presidential elections
column2: when Georgia’s civil society and population called on the government to support democratic processes and regime change in its “brother” country. From then on
column3: Georgia has been shying away from supporting the political regime in Ukraine and focusing more on the support of the country’s own population.

column1: However
column2: Ukraine refused to consider such tactics
column3: with its official representatives criticizing the Georgian Dream coalition for supporting Russia during the 2012 parliamentary elections. Moreover
column4: Kiev cooperated with Georgia’s United National Movement
column5: which was openly accused of building an authoritarian regime and egregious human rights abuses.

column1: Logically
column2: the new Georgian government under Ivanishvili cannot help paying attention to this fact. But it was relatively reticent and didn’t respond
column3: even when Georgian volunteers came to fight in Eastern Ukraine to support Kiev and accused Tbilisi of supporting Russia. That had some implications for the Georgian Dream: It was seen as a political force that is capable of defending the country’s national interests.

column1: Moreover
column2: Georgian voters also saw the fact that Saakashvili was appointed as the governor of the Odessa region as an unfriendly move from Ukraine
column3: as a slap in the face
column4: because the former Georgian president was legally prosecuted in his home country
column5: which meant that Ivanishvili couldn’t fulfill his pledges and restore justice [During the election campaign he promised to put Saakashvili in jail for corruption and the abuse of power — Editor’s note]. The problem was exacerbated when Kiev granted Saakashvili Ukrainian citizenship
column6: which made it impossible to imprison the former Georgian president.

column1: Saakashvili crossed the red line during the latest parliamentary elections in Georgia during the campaign. First
column2: his colleagues from the United National Movement visited Ukraine. Second
column3: he openly called for a coup d’état against the Georgian government
column4: which he sees as pro-Russian. In fact
column5: he threatened to conduct a new revolution in Georgia. This was the last straw for the Georgian Dream.

column1: It is safe to say that the current Georgian political elites started seeing Ukraine as a real headache and the shelter for dubious and controversial Georgian politicians from the United National Movement accused of different wrongdoings and legal violations.
However
column2: with the victory of the Georgian Dream in the 2016 parliamentary elections
column3: a lot has changed. Moreover
column4: the odds of the party of winning the constitutional majority are really high. It means that the influence of the party is growing in the Georgian parliament and even more could change.

column1: As a result
column2: the government won’t necessarily have to take into account the views of other political forces to take decisions. It can be pretty outspoken now that it won’t put up with anti-government moves and initiatives like the ones promoted by Saakashvili. Moreover
column3: the Georgian voters
column4: who are seeking to have those involved in the violations during Saakashvili’s tenure prosecuted. So
column5: in this regard
column6: the electorate supports the Georgian Dream.

column1: Thus
column2: all this indicates that Georgian-Ukrainian relations have always been more complex and nuanced than they seemed to be at first glance. During Saakashvili’s tenure
column3: there was cooperation between his government and the ones of Timoshenko and Yushchenko. However
column4: eventually
column5: Tbilisi shifted its priority from supporting top political officials to supporting society and people.

column1: Ukrainian politicians should keep in mind that the Russian factor is not the only one that determines the Ukrainian-Georgian agenda. Providing shelter to Saakashvili also does matter. So
column2: to improve the relations with Tbilisi
column3: Kiev should take into account its national interest and support the Georgian people instead of the country’s politicians."	FAKE

column1: Trump Vows To "Renovate" the Bill of Rights	"Topics: Politics
column2: Hillary Clinton
column3: Donald Trump
column4: 2016 Presidential Election
column5: President
column6: US Constitution Thursday
column7: 10 November 2016

column1: If anyone in this ""great"" land knows anything about renovation
column2: it may well be presidential hopeful Donald J. Trump. A veteran of the real estate industry for several decades now
column3: Trump surely has renovated his share of properties
column4: buildings and even golf courses. His latest project
column5: however
column6: could be his most ambitious: the Bill of Rights itself.

column1: Look at this thing
column2: The Donald said as he held a copy the seminal American document before a crowd of reporters. ""It's old. I mean
column3: it's old
column4: like really old. You hear what I'm saying? It is old.""

column1: When asked what his intentions for the document were
column2: Trump proposed a ""renovation"" of the foundational document ""just like he would any of [his] older buildings that didn't cut the mustard anymore. I mean
column3: Ivana wasn't cutting it anymore
column4: so I got Marla Maples. New is better. I think we all know that
column5: new is better. New equals better. Sometimes you have to tear something down to make something new
column6: right? And then it's all better.""

column1: When asked what he specifically meant by ""tearing down the document"" that is the basis of this country's inalienable rights
column2: Trump continued
column3: ""Hey look
column4: I don't know when this thing was written
column5: probably a long time ago
column6: like in the 1920's or something
column7: but it doesn't make any sense anymore. I have a real problem with an old
column8: stinky document telling me how to live my life. If we're gonna make America great again
column9: the first thing we have to do is make these document new again
column10: and that's what I'm gonna do on the first day in office. Bingo-bango
column11: new document for the new America. I mean
column12: really
column13: no one reads this stuff anymore.""

column1: The presidential hopeful was then asked how he planned to rejuvenate the Bill of Rights. ""First of all some of this spooky language needs to get cleaned up. Like how is a working-class guy like me
column2: the average citizen
column3: supposed to understand this stuff? The trial of all crimes (except in cases of impeachment
column4: and in cases arising in the land or naval forces
column5: or in the militia when in actual service in time of War or public danger) shall be by an Impartial Jury of the Vicinage
column6: with the requisite of unanimity for conviction
column7: the right of challenge
column8: and other accostomed [sic] requisites; and no person shall be held to answer for a capital
column9: or otherways [sic] infamous crime
column10: unless on a presentment or indictment by a Grand Jury; but if a crime be committed in a place in the possession of an enemy
column11: or… blah
column12: blah
column13: blah. Vicinage? That's not even a word
column14: is it? Unanimity? Impeachment? These aren't words like hammer
column15: dumptruck or bigly. They're talking in circles. That's right
column16: they're talking in circles. So that one's gone. Just out. Accostomed? Otherways? These Founding Father clowns can't even spell!""

column1: Trump's furor grew as he read more of the document. ""Freedom of religion? No one goes to church anymore. Who cares? That one's going too. All it does is protect these Muslims who blew up buildings. God forbid they blow up my towers. That's out. Freedom of speech? Freedom to lie
column2: that's what I call it. Freedom to lie
column3: like those bastards on CNN and Hillary over there. This seventh here
column4: that's a doozy. It says in ""all matters involving more than 20 dollars"". That's a joke. I tip 20 dollars at Starbucks when I get my coffee. That one's out. ""Due process of law"" … another joke. Out! This third one
column5: ""quartering soldiers
column6: what's that? I have waaaay too much respect for our soldiers to start chopping them up into quarters. I mean
column7: that's like serial killer stuff
column8: right? No
column9: absolutely not
column10: I will not chop up soldiers. On my first day in office
column11: I will find anyone who is trying to chop up American soldiers and make them pay.""

column1: When prompted that he may be misinterpreting the articles in the Bill
column2: Trump lashed back. ""Of course I am! Look at it some time. Who can understand this stuff? Of course I'm misinterpreting this stuff. Maybe this is how they talked in the 1920's
column3: but not now
column4: not in Trump's America. And the ideas are just stupid. Look at this fourth one. No illegal ""search and seizure""? If I can't walk into someone's house and arrest him
column5: how am I gonna maintain law and order? If I can't just take someone's stuff
column6: how am I gonna know what's going on in this country
column7: huh? You tell me. And this old piece of paper is trying to tell me when I'm president - not if but when - I'm gonna restore law and order. This fourth one
column8: how many shootings in Chicago happened because my police have their hands tied by this stupid fourth amendment. I mean
column9: that's what I'm gonna do
column10: starting on the first day of my term. The very first day. Here's another peach: no ""cruel and unusual punishment."" What's that? How else do you deal with terrorists? That's why we got soft. These terrorists knew they could come over
column11: bombs some buildings
column12: kill a bunch of people and know this piece of paper was gonna make sure they didn't get their precious feeling hurt. First day in office
column13: that one's out!""

column1: One reporter asked The Donald if he knew that the ""stinky
column2: old"" document he was holding was supposed to protect the American people from injustice
column3: and false legal claims. (He was also asked if he knew what ""quartered"" meant). ""Hey
column4: I'm not saying people don't have rights. People have rights. Of course people have rights. Sure they do. I'm just saying they don't need all this stuff. The first day I'm in office
column5: the very first day
column6: I'm gonna make a nice simple list of rights
column7: you know
column8: without all this fancy nonsense. It's outdated. We need something for 2016
column9: something nice and simple.""

column1: Trump then said he had to meet with his team of architects and engineers to draw up plans for a wall along the southern border of the US

column1: ‘People in Europe are full of fear’ over refugee influx	"The European Union’s sharpening divisions over a spiraling refugee crisis broke into the open Thursday with two leaders strongly disagreeing in public over whether the asylum-seekers were threatening “Europe’s Christian roots.”
That was the language used by Hungarian Prime Minister Viktor Orban as he warned Europe against allowing in mostly Muslim families. A day after a drowned Syrian toddler washed up on the Turkish coast
column2: another European leader retorted that Christian values demanded helping the less fortunate.

column1: The furious exchange — a rare breach of the E.U.’s buttoned-down decorum — came as Hungarian authorities apparently laid a trap for thousands of asylum-seekers who had packed Budapest’s central train station after days of worsening conditions outside the station. Police had blocked them from entering the station for days but allowed them in early Thursday.
But a refugee-packed train apparently bound for the Austrian border came to a halt just west of Budapest
column2: in a small town where dozens of police officers were waiting on the platform. They tried to force people off the train to take them to a migrant-processing center
column3: threatening their chances to make it onward to Western Europe.

column1: By day’s end
column2: there was a standoff
column3: with the packed train surrounded by police and the migrants refusing to budge. Some of the passengers received medical treatment on the platform.

column1: [European railways become ground zero for the migrant crisis]
Orban
column2: Hungary’s nationalist leader who has spearheaded attempts to turn back the migrants
column3: said Thursday that he had little choice but to seal his nation’s border with razor wire
column4: soldiers and a high fence.

column1: “We Hungarians are full of fear
column2: people in Europe are full of fear
column3: because we see that the European leaders
column4: among them the prime ministers
column5: are not able to control the situation
column6: ” he said in Brussels in a raw joint appearance with European Parliament President Martin Schulz. Orban and Schulz
column7: a veteran politician from Germany
column8: made no attempt to paper over their differences or their distaste for each other.

column1: The Hungarian leader blamed Germany for the crisis
column2: saying that its open-door policy toward Syrian asylum-seekers was propelling a wave of migrants to undertake dangerous journeys toward Europe’s heart. Germany expects 800
column3: 000 asylum-seekers this year
column4: and it has said that it does not plan to turn away Syrians.

column1: “The moral
column2: human thing is to make clear: ‘Please don’t come. Why do you have to go from Turkey to Europe? Turkey is a safe country. Stay there. It’s risky to come
column3: ’ ” Orban said.

column1: Hundreds of thousands of people fleeing war in Syria
column2: Iraq and Afghanistan have overwhelmed Europe’s capacity to respond in recent months
column3: opening stark divisions. Some leaders believe that the world’s largest economic bloc — a vast territory of 503 million residents — is more than capable of accommodating refugees. Others
column4: including Hungary’s Orban
column5: believe the continent’s population is in a far more delicate state.

column1: The divisions could threaten some of the most basic tenets of the E.U.
column2: an alliance built on the ashes of World War II in a bid never again to allow such destruction. German Chancellor Angela Merkel said this week that a Europe with no internal borders — a key achievement of European unification — could be in question if no solution to the refugee crisis is found.

column1: He warned that the splits emerging during the refugee crisis could do lasting damage to the 28-nation alliance
column2: which was founded on a spirit of consensus and burden-sharing.

column1: “This is a crucial moment for the European Union
column2: ” Schulz said. “A deeper split of the union is a risk we cannot exclude.”

column1: Orban’s fears are shared by many Eastern European nations
column2: which have pushed hard against any attempt to require them to take in asylum-seekers. Slovakia has said it will accept only Christians. In Estonia
column3: where fewer than 100 migrants have been resettled
column4: police on Thursday were investigating a suspicious early-morning fire at a dormitory that was housing victims of Syria’s war.

column1: [Britain takes in so few refugees from Syria they would fit on a subway train]
But the concerns also extend to Britain. There
column2: fewer Syrians than would fit in a London subway train have been accepted this year. British media reported Thursday that Prime Minister David Cameron would soon announce plans to take in “thousands” more Syrian refugees
column3: a striking turnaround for a leader who a day earlier had said that the answer to the crisis was not simply taking in “more and more” refugees.

column1: Elsewhere in Europe
column2: the refusals brought mounting anger from leaders who are more sympathetic to the growing crowds of asylum-seekers.

column1: “For a Christian
column2: it shouldn’t matter what race
column3: religion and nationality the person in need represents
column4: ” European Council President Donald Tusk said Thursday
column5: launching into Orban before the two met in Brussels. Tusk
column6: a former prime minister of Poland
column7: proposed resettling at least 100
column8: 000 refugees across Europe.

column1: In France
column2: President François Hollande said the death of the toddler is “a tragedy
column3: but it’s also a call to the European conscience. Europe is made of values and principles.” Images of the child’s body lying facedown and partly in the water on a Turkish beach evoked consternation around the world.

column1: Hollande said he had just reached an agreement with Germany on a proposal for mandatory quotas to more equitably spread refugees across the E.U. Some European countries “are not shouldering their moral obligations
column2: ” he said.

column1: Merkel
column2: meanwhile
column3: said she understood that not every nation was prepared to take on as large a burden as her country was doing. But she said it was impossible for Germany
column4: Sweden and Austria alone to continue taking in the vast majority of the incoming asylum-seekers.

column1: “The Geneva Convention does not apply only to Germany but also to every state
column2: ” she said
column3: referring to the international treaty that requires countries to take in refugees of war.

column1: Orban has vowed to seal Hungary’s borders by Sept. 15
column2: empowered by emergency measures expected to be approved by the country’s parliament in the coming days. The measures would give authorities broad powers to crack down on illegal migration.

column1: Outside Budapest’s elegant stone-and-glass-fronted station Thursday evening
column2: people living in tents and atop worn woolen blankets sprawled across a vast public plaza and into an adjacent subway concourse. Tourists carrying frame backpacks slipped into the station entrance past women cradling babies
column3: men pacing anxiously and children arguing over the few available toys.

column1: Refugees expressed a keen awareness that Hungary does not want them — and said the feeling is mutual.
“Hungary is a poor country. They can’t give us the life we’re looking for. They can’t even give us food or water
column2: ” said Yahya Lababidi
column3: a tank-top-wearing 21-year-old law student from the northern Syrian province of Idlib. “We want to go to the rich countries.”

column1: Lababidi said he had been traveling for a month
column2: passing along “the usual route” — through Turkey
column3: Greece
column4: Macedonia and Serbia — with a plan ultimately to settle in the Netherlands. But he said that when he tried to enter the train station in Budapest five days earlier
column5: police officers barred his path. Since then
column6: he’s been sleeping on the cold stone of the plaza.

column1: “I escaped from war
column2: ” he said. “I thought things would be better than this.”

column1: [As tragedies shock Europe
column2: a bigger refu­gee crisis looms in the Middle East]

column1: Hungarian leaders “have done all they can to stir up popular sentiment against immigrants and refugees
column2: ” said Marta Pardavi
column3: a co-chair of the Hungarian Helsinki Committee
column4: a group that offers legal advice to asylum-seekers. “This has become a totally divided issue. Friendships break up over this.”

column1: Critics of the European response said the continent’s 20th-century history of dictatorships and wars should instill in it more sympathy for others in need.
“We are facing a historical moment
column2: perhaps one of the biggest the E.U. has had to face over the last couple of decades
column3: ” said Yves Pascouau
column4: director of migration and mobility policies at the Brussels-based European Policy Center. “European citizens have fled dictatorships and wars. This is a part of our history. We’ve been able to be protected elsewhere in our countries.”

column1: Witte reported from Budapest. Karla Adam in London contributed to this report.

column1: Contrast this with the scandal of erstwhile Trump campaign manager Corey Lewandowski
column2: who allegedly yanked a female reporter’s arm in a boorish manner. That kept going and going because the allegations were very distasteful (assault!) and the mystery was interesting (did he really do it as claimed?). Every couple of days or so
column3: it seemed
column4: a new video emerged. It was an excellent dumb scandal.

column1: Plagiarism is one of those sins that doom journalists but not politicians or their wives. In 1987
column2: when running for president
column3: Joe Biden plagiarized vast passages from Labour Party politician Neil Kinnock
column4: which made for humiliating coverage. In 2008
column5: Barack Obama lifted passages from Massachusetts then-governor Deval Patrick
column6: a misstep that Obama smoothly batted away by saying Patrick had suggested the lines because of the two men’s shared philosophy. Both men did okay in the long run.

column1: So this will damage Trump a little but not much. The pearl-clutching is taking place in newsrooms
column2: not in America’s living rooms. It’s embarrassing
column3: but it plays into no popularly accepted narrative. (That Trump’s campaign is bumbling and chaotic in its operations is known to political buffs but not the broader public.) Tomorrow
column4: we’ll be arguing about some other snafu. And
column5: the way things are going
column6: we’ll have more than a few to choose from."	REAL

column1: Will the Comey bombshell really shake up the 2016 race?	"First Read is a morning briefing from Meet the Press and the NBC Political Unit on the day's most important political stories and why they matter.
After bombshell
column2: does the remarkably stable '16 race stay stable?

column1: There's no hyperbole in stating that the 2016 Hillary Clinton-vs.-Donald Trump presidential race has been the craziest we've covered. Consider all of the jaw-dropping moments: Mexican rapists. WikiLeaks. Vladimir Putin. The Access Hollywood video. Alicia Machado. Trump's visit to Mexico. ""Basket of Deplorables."" Birtherism. And the debates -- all of them. Despite them all
column2: however
column3: the race has been remarkably stable. Just look at the national NBC/WSJ poll numbers since Sept. 2015.

column1: But does that stability change after FBI Director James Comey's bombshell Friday that his organization learned of the existence of new emails that appear ""pertinent"" to its previous investigation into Clinton's email practices? One the one hand
column2: the polling we've seen -- so far -- suggests that voters remain in their partisan corners. According to this weekend's Washington Post/ABC poll
column3: 63% of voters said the FBI's review makes no difference. And among the 34% who say it makes them ""less likely"" to back Clinton
column4: those voters are disproportionately Republicans and GOP-leaning independents. What's more
column5: the post-Comey polls we've seen (here and here) haven't really budged
column6: at least not yet. On the other hand
column7: it has never been a positive for Clinton throughout this entire presidential race when the focus has been on her
column8: especially on the subject of emails. Eight days to go…

column1: The latest developments in the Comey Surprise
Meanwhile
column2: here are all of the latest developments in the Comey Surprise: The FBI obtained a warrant to search emails related to the probe of Hillary Clinton's private server that were discovered on ex-congressman Anthony Weiner's laptop... Also on Sunday
column3: Senate Minority Leader Harry Reid accused Comey of violating the Hatch Act
column4: which bars government officials from using their authority to influence elections... Former Attorney General Eric Holder wrote a ""scathing op-ed condemning FBI Director James Comey for his handling of the investigation into Hillary Clinton's use of a private email server. 'I fear he has unintentionally and negatively affected public trust in both the Justice Department and the FBI'""… And NBC's Ari Melber has a piece concluding that newly discovered emails -- even if they contain classified information -- would unlikely change the earlier conclusion not to charge Clinton.

column1: FBI's review of the emails could be quick
Additionally
column2: NBC's Pete Williams reports that it's possible the FBI's review of the emails could end quickly -- now that the FBI obtained a warrant to search them. ""They'll narrow them down to look at just those dating from the time Hillary Clinton was secretary of state. Then they'll weed out any that are not about government business. Agents will use automated software to search what's left for duplicates they've already found during the investigation of the Clinton e-mail server. Any that remain will be checked for classified information
column3: Williams reported on ""Today"" this morning. ""Officials say there's no way to tell how long that will take. But they say if it goes quickly
column4: and nothing classified is found
column5: the FBI could say so within the next few days. It largely depends on how many of the e-mails are duplicates and how many are new to the investigators.""

column1: NBC/WSJ/Marist polls: Clinton up in NC
column2: deadlocked race in FL

column1: Over the weekend
column2: we released brand-new NBC/WSJ/Marist polls of Florida and North Carolina (which were conducted before Friday's bombshell news). The numbers:

column1: The polls (conducted Oct. 25-26) also measure early voting in these two states. Among the 36% of likely voters in Florida who say they've already voted
column2: Clinton is ahead
column3: 54% -37%. Among those who haven't voted in the Sunshine State
column4: Trump is up
column5: 51%-42%. And Clinton leads by a 61%-33% margin among the 29% of North Carolinians who say they've already voted.

column1: It's amazing when news about Donald Trump -- no matter how controversial -- gets drowned out by other events. Still
column2: don't miss this Washington Post piece into Trump's charitable giving
column3: or lack thereof: ""For as long as he has been rich and famous
column4: Donald Trump has also wanted people to believe he is generous. He spent years constructing an image as a philanthropist by appearing at charity events and by making very public — even nationally televised — promises to give his own money away. It was
column5: in large part
column6: a facade. A months-long investigation by The Washington Post has not been able to verify many of Trump's boasts about his philanthropy. Instead
column7: throughout his life in the spotlight
column8: whether as a businessman
column9: television star or presidential candidate
column10: The Post found that Trump had sought credit for charity he had not given — or had claimed other people's giving as his own.""

column1: How violence and retaliation are constant themes in Trump's rhetoric
Also
column2: do read NBC's Benjy Sarlin on how violence and retaliation are common themes in Trump's rhetoric and in his events. ""In his eyes
column3: the world is an unforgiving place where cities are 'war zones
column4: ' where 'rapists' are streaming across the border and where jealous rivals are hatching plots to humiliate America and Trump personally. To prevail in such an environment
column5: he suggests
column6: the response to any slight must be swift and overwhelming. Dwelling on limits imposed by law or tradition is usually a secondary concern. This framework has expressed itself in policy
column7: in which Trump has extolled the use of torture
column8: threatened reprisals against the families of terrorists and pledged to jail Clinton
column9: a former senator and secretary of state. It has expressed itself rhetorically in vicious insults against critics and in his encouragement of violence by supporters.""

column1: First Read's downballot race of the day: Florida Senate
Marco Rubio rode to Republicans' rescue when he reversed his pledge not to seek re-election

column1: Rating Obama, 50% say he's been a success	"George Washington was the first President of the United States
column2: serving from 1789 to 1797. He also served as commander-in-chief of the Continental Army
column3: and he has the distinction of being the only President unanimously elected by the Electoral College.

column1: The second U.S. President
column2: John Adams
column3: served from 1797 to 1801. He was also the first vice president of the United States
column4: and he was the first President to reside in the White House
column5: moving in on November 1
column7: while the White House was still under construction.

column1: James Monroe (1817-1825) was the last of the Founding Fathers to be elected President. During his seventh State of the Union address
column2: he outlined a foreign policy that warned European powers against further colonization of or meddling in the Western Hemisphere. This was later known as the Monroe Doctrine.

column1: Andrew Jackson (1829-1837) was the only President to serve in both the American Revolution and the War of 1812. He is also the only President to have been a former prisoner of war: Jackson was 13 when became a courier during the Revolutionary War
column2: and he was later captured by the British.

column1: William Henry Harrison (1841) probably had only just finished unpacking his things at the White House when he died of pneumonia one month into his term. Harrison was the first U.S. President to die while in office
column2: and he had the shortest tenure ever of any commander-in-chief.

column1: John Tyler's term (1841-1845) saw several presidential firsts. He was the first vice president to succeed office after the President died
column2: he was the first to lose his wife while in office
column3: and he was the first to marry while in office.

column1: Zachary Taylor (1849-1850)
column2: aka ""Old Rough and Ready
column3: was a hero in the Mexican-American War. Mystery surrounds his actual cause of death from a stomach ailment. Did he just eat too many cherries
column4: or was it murder? The 1991 exhumation of his body proved it wasn't arsenic poisoning at least.

column1: Franklin Pierce (1853-1857) was the first President to not get his party's nomination for re-election. He signed the controversial Kansas-Nebraska Act
column2: which allowed the people there to decide whether to allow slavery. This worsened the tension between the North and South.

column1: Just four months into his term
column2: James Garfield (1881) was shot by a disgruntled lawyer who'd aspired to join the administration as a diplomat. The President was taken to the Jersey Shore
column3: where doctors hoped the ocean air would help him recover. He died two weeks later.

column1: Woodrow Wilson (1913-1921) was awarded the 1919 Nobel Peace Prize for proposing and creating the League of Nations. But he was never able to convince the United States to join. Although he was first opposed to a federal amendment allowing women to vote
column2: Wilson shifted his position during his second term and the 19th Amendment was ratified in 1920.

column1: Herbert Hoover (1929-1933) was inaugurated on the year of the stock market crash that sent the country into the Great Depression. Although Hoover pushed for money to be appropriated for large-scale projects
column2: he opposed federal relief payments directly to individuals. The national economy never recovered during his term
column3: and the shantytowns that developed were nicknamed ""Hoovervilles.""

column1: Franklin D. Roosevelt (1933-1945) was the only President elected to the office four times. During his 12 years as President
column2: he championed numerous social programs and measures
column3: including the creation of the Tennessee Valley Authority
column4: the Civilian Conservation Corps and Social Security. Roosevelt contracted polio at age 39 and never recovered the use of his legs.

column1: John F. Kennedy (1961-1963) was the first Roman Catholic President. He was assassinated in his first term
column2: which was marked by the signing of the Nuclear Test-Ban Treaty
column3: the creation of the Peace Corps
column4: the disastrous Bay of Pigs invasion
column5: and the beginning of military involvement in Vietnam.

column1: Jimmy Carter (1977-1981) brokered the 1978 Camp David Accords
column2: the agreement that led to a peace treaty between Israel and Egypt. At home
column3: Carter's presidency was plagued by inflation and unemployment
column4: and he lost his bid for a second term amid the hostage crisis in Iran.

column1: Ronald Reagan (1981-1989) was the only actor ever elected President
column2: and his talent as a speaker earned him the moniker ""the great communicator."" An affable Republican who wooed many Roosevelt Democrats
column3: the staunchly anti-communist Reagan is seen as having played a large part in the collapse of the Soviet Union.

column1: George H.W. Bush (1989-1993) was a former CIA director and served two terms as vice president under Ronald Reagan. His approval rating at home soared after he led an international coalition to oust Iraq from Kuwait
column2: and communism in Eastern Europe fell on his watch. But he lost his bid for re-election amid a sluggish economy and after reneging on a promise not to raise taxes.

column1: Bill Clinton (1993-2001) ran on the slogan
column2: ""It's the economy
column3: stupid."" Plagued by various scandals -- including accusations of sexual impropriety -- he was the second president to be impeached. He was acquitted in 1999.

column1: George W. Bush (2001-2009) is the son of former President George H.W. Bush. His presidency was largely defined by his response to the 9/11 terrorist attacks. In 2003
column2: he ordered the invasion of Iraq on suspicion that Saddam Hussein had weapons of mass destruction.

column1: Barack Obama (2009-2017) became the first African-American to hold the office of President. He took the oath of office amid the Great Recession
column2: the biggest economic challenge since the Great Depression. Under the Affordable Healthcare Act
column3: millions of uninsured Americans have gotten health insurance."	REAL

column1: The True Scandal of 2016 Was The Torture of Chelsea Manning     :	" The True Scandal of 2016 Was The Torture of Chelsea Manning By Jeremy Scahill
November 10
column2: 2016 "" Information Clearing House "" - "" The Intercept "" - A few days ago
column3: we learned that Private Chelsea Manning attempted to take her own life last month for the second time since being sentenced to 35 years at the U.S. military prison in Leavenworth
column4: Kansas. The whistleblower
column5: who provided the collateral murder video
column6: the Iraq and Afghan war logs
column7: and the hundreds of thousands of classified U.S. State Department cables to Wikileaks
column8: was convicted of espionage. As I waited to vote today
column9: I found myself thinking of her languishing in misery in isolation and incarceration.

column1: This election  particularly in its closing stages  has been dominated by controversies over emails
column2: classified documents
column3: and Wikileaks. Weve heard endlessly about Hillary Clintons private basement server
column4: her 33
column5: 000 deleted emails
column6: the phishing and leaking of John Podestas emails
column7: including parts of Clintons much discussed private speeches to Goldman Sachs. Trump
column8: for his part
column9: suddenly discovered a great love for Julian Assange
column10: though he does have trouble correctly spelling Wikileaks in his tweets of praise. Taken together with Trumps bizarre and consistent lauding of Vladimir Putin and leaks from the U.S. intelligence community
column11: the country has been treated to an odd flashback of Cold War propaganda
column12: including a fair dose of red-baiting from the Democrats. In the matter of Anthony Weiners computer
column13: his wife Huma Abedins communications and the potential implications for Clinton
column14: the FBI
column15: whose overreach had not previously been of much concern to Democrats
column16: suddenly became a deviant manipulator of the electoral process
column17: while Trump and his supporters alternately praised the agencys professionalism and denounced it as part of the rigged system.

column1: The U.S. public is now getting a taste of the way hacking
column2: phishing
column3: and an overwhelming dependence on fallible machines and networks can impact politics. But lets be clear: None of the disclosures in this campaign  not one thing in any of the hacked emails or those declassified and released from Clintons private server  has brought to light anything of greater importance than the documents Chelsea Manning provided to Wikileaks. She revealed war crimes
column4: including murder and torture
column5: dirty and duplicitous dealings of the U.S. and its allies
column6: exposed liars
column7: documented a secret history of Americas longest running war
column8: and forced a much needed debate about the U.S. role in the world. And for that
column9: she is being tortured.

column1: The double standards of our society dictate that a perjurer like the director of national intelligence
column2: James Clapper
column3: faces no consequences for his crimes. Gen. David Petraeus gets a slap on the wrist
column4: no jail time
column5: and prestigious positions at universities for sharing classified information with his mistress. Only Gen. James Cartwright may face the inside of a prison cell for discussing classified information with journalists  and he is a sacrificial lamb for the cause of exonerating Clinton and Petraeus from any true accountability by the Obama Justice Department.

column1: But Chelsea Manning
column2: whose motivation was noble
column3: whose actions made our country better
column4: faces the full wrath of the system. And it may end up killing her. When we talk about the high-tech scandals that marked this election
column5: at the top of the list should be the torture of Chelsea Manning."	FAKE

column1: OPEC sees oil prices exploding to $200 a barrel	"Right now the oil market is totally focused on finding a bottom for oil prices. However
column2: according to OPEC's Secretary-General Abdulla al-Badri we've already hit bottom. Not only that
column3: but he sees a real possibility that oil prices could explode higher to upwards of $200 per barrel in the future. He's far from the only one that sees a return of triple-digit oil prices.

column1: According to the Secretary-General
column2: speaking in London on Jan. 26
column3: the oil market doesn't need to look for oil prices to bottom as the market has already bottomed. Instead
column4: he offered quite bullish comments by saying
column5: ""Now the prices are around $45-$55
column6: and I think maybe they [have] reached the bottom and we [will] see some rebound very soon."" Now
column7: normally that type of remark would be just another layer of noise
column8: but this is coming from OPEC's Secretary-General so it comes with a lot of weight behind it.

column1: That said
column2: he's not saying that OPEC will come in and rescue the oil market by reversing its previous decision to hold steady on production. Instead
column3: he sees the signs that the oil market is self-correcting as oil companies have made deep cuts to spending
column4: which will eventually lead to lower production growth. Further
column5: the rig count in the U.S. is plunging
column6: which is usually a key to a bottom in oil prices. However
column7: in the midst of cutting back as the industry works through the current oversupply the Secretary-General is now warning that the industry is putting future oil supplies at risk by under investing today.

column1: The Secretary-General said that
column2: ""if you don't invest in oil and gas
column3: you will see more than $200"" when it comes to future oil prices. While he didn't give a timeframe
column4: he did note the correlation between investment and future production. This is because oil production naturally declines and oil companies need to invest in new production to not only replace this decline in production from legacy oil fields but to add new production to meet growing demand. However
column5: oil companies are reluctant to invest in new production as their cash flows decline.

column1: Over time this could become a problem as oil fields around the world naturally decline by an average of about 5% per year. In order to overcome this decline oil companies need to develop about 200 billion barrels of oil supplies over the next decade and a half just to meet demand.
These supplies will require the industry to invest $7-$10 trillion. However
column2: with the big capital budget reductions oil companies have announced this year it could make it harder for the industry to meet future supply needs. In fact
column3: the industry might defer up to $150 billion oil projects this year due to the collapse in crude prices. Many of these investments
column4: however
column5: wouldn't have yielded actual production for a couple of years due to the long lead time of major projects.

column1: As an example
column2: Chevron delivered first oil on two of its Gulf of Mexico projects late last year after beginning construction on the fields in 2011. Meanwhile
column3: another $6 billion project it just sanctioned at the end of last year won't produce any oil until 2018. It's these long lead time projects that are being delayed
column4: which is setting the world up for higher oil prices in the future as an under investment today has the potential to lead to a constriction in future supplies.

column1: OPEC's Secretary-General is calling the bottom in oil prices. While he's not the first to call a bottom
column2: he does lead the organization that currently controls the oil market so his comments do have a lot of weight. Further
column3: he's also suggesting that the cuts that oil companies are making could have a dramatic impact on future oil prices as the under investment has the potential to cause oil prices to rocket higher if demand grows faster than future supplies. That
column4: however
column5: would all be part of OPEC's plan as it purposely pushed for lower oil prices now so it could control market share once oil prices surged in the future. It's willing to endure short-term pain for the potential of a big long-term gain.

column1: The Motley Fool is a USA TODAY content partner offering financial news
column2: analysis and commentary designed to help people take control of their financial lives. Its content is produced independently of USA TODAY."	REAL
