column1: United States v. Texas, the biggest immigration case in a century, explained	"When it takes up the question of whether President Obama's 2014 immigration executive actions were constitutional
column2: the Supreme Court will throw out its typical playbook.

column1: United States v. Texas is one of the most — if not the most — important cases before the highest court this term. It's certainly the most important immigration case the Supreme Court has taken up in a generation (or
column2: arguably
column3: a century). And the Court is treating it accordingly.

column1: On Monday
column2: instead of splitting up 60 minutes of oral arguments between the two sides of the case
column3: as usually happens
column4: the Court will convene for 90 minutes — and bring in more parties to argue their case.

column1: Texas and the 25 other states suing will get 30 minutes. The federal government will get 35. But the Supreme Court has also given 10 minutes to a lawyer representing a group of immigrant women who'd benefit from Obama's executive actions. And that's not all — 15 minutes will go to the US House of Representatives (thanks to the Republican House majority)
column2: which has jumped in to support the states.

column1: The unusually complicated oral argument process reflects just how messy this case is. It's a case covering surprisingly narrow-sounding legal questions
column2: but its outcome carries broad implications for the relationship between Congress and the president
column3: and the relationship between the federal government and the states. Oh
column4: yeah — and it's a presidential election year
column5: and both immigration and the Court itself have become election issues.

column1: All this makes it something of a nightmare scenario for Chief Justice John Roberts
column2: who tends to be more anxious than the typical Supreme Court justice to present the Court's opinions as drawn purely from law rather than politics.

column1: As the justices hear oral arguments and consider the case before issuing an opinion (which they're expected to do in late June
column2: at the end of the term)
column3: Roberts and the other justices will have to work through legal questions that are both less contentious and more abstract than the broader immigration debate makes them seem.

column1: Then they'll have to figure out if there's any way they can cobble together a five-vote majority for a lasting opinion — or if the eight-person Court will deadlock
column2: putting the most important case of the Court's term in limbo and creating the opportunity for chaos.

column1: In November 2014
column2: President Obama issued a series of memos declaring executive actions on immigration. Two of those are at issue in this case.

column1: One memo expanded the existing Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals program
column2: or DACA
column3: which since 2012 had allowed immigrants who'd come to the US as children to apply for temporary protection from deportation and work permits.

column1: The other one added a new deferred action program — the Deferred Action for Parents of Americans program — which would have allowed millions of unauthorized immigrants who have US citizen or permanent resident children to apply for deportation protection and work permits as well.
The two 2014 actions are usually referred to as DAPA/DACA+. Since the states won in the lower courts
column2: both of them have been put on hold since the first ruling was issued in February 2015. The original DACA program from 2012
column3: however
column4: is still in place and isn't being challenged in this suit. (To prevent confusion
column5: I'll just refer to DAPA instead of DAPA/DACA+ when talking about the 2014 actions.)

column1: Federal immigration enforcement has totally transformed over the past 20 years. More people are eligible for deportation than ever before. The growth of the unauthorized population pre–Great Recession meant there were more people to deport. After 9/11
column2: the government got vastly more money and resources for deportation. And deportations escalated accordingly — from 183
column3: 000 in 1999 to a high of 400
column4: 000 during the first several years of the Obama administration.

column1: President Obama has spent most of his time in office trying to impose some sort of control on all of this — to make sure the government is choosing who's most important to deport
column2: rather than arbitrarily deporting anyone Immigration and Customs Enforcement agents get their hands on. His first attempts — setting high and low ""priorities"" for deportation and telling immigration agents to follow them — were something both sides in the current court case agree he could do but that rank-and-file immigration agents frequently ignored in favor of their own judgment.

column1: So in 2012
column2: President Obama created the first deferred action program
column3: DACA — allowing people to proactively apply for protection from deportation
column4: rather than simply hoping that ICE followed the memo not to deport them. It's been solidly effective. After comprehensive immigration reform stalled in Congress in 2013
column5: pressure grew on Obama to use the tool that had worked — deferred action — to protect other groups of low-priority immigrants
column6: and he did just that with DAPA and expanded DACA in 2014.

column1: DAPA was supposed to be the program that ensured Obama's legacy on immigration
column2: turning him from the ""deporter in chief"" of his first term to a man who brought immigrants out of the shadows. If the Supreme Court lets the program go forward
column3: that legacy is assured. If it strikes DAPA down
column4: Obama's legacy — and immigrants' attitude toward the Democratic Party — will be an ambivalent and disappointing one.

column1: United States v. Texas is political in its origins. That doesn't at all mean that the states that sued the Obama administration are wrong on the merits — it's just an acknowledgment of the circumstances around the case's genesis shortly after Obama announced the executive actions.
There wasn't a serious legal challenge to the original DACA program in 2012
column2: even though many of the criticisms of DAPA in this case would have applied to DACA as well. But in June 2012 the country was in the middle of a general election campaign
column3: and the Republican nominee was trying to run toward the center and appeal to Latinos. In November 2014
column4: on the other hand
column5: the relatively unpopular President Obama was responding to an electoral defeat in the midterm elections — including the loss of the Senate — with executive actions on an issue that mobilized the GOP base.

column1: The states on each side of the case have lined up along partisan lines. The Texas suit involves 23 states — all but three of them under unified Republican control — as well as four Republican governors (three of whom have Democratic attorneys general who wouldn't let the state officially join the case) and one Republican attorney general. The states that have filed briefs supporting the Obama administration
column2: meanwhile
column3: represent about two-thirds of the states with Democratic attorneys general.

column1: Texas is leading the coalition of states bringing the lawsuit for two reasons. One
column2: it's offered the most persuasive case for how DAPA could actually hurt the state (more on that later). Two
column3: it houses the Southern District of Texas
column4: which was the court the states chose to file their case in
column5: presumably because they knew they'd have a good chance there. (The administration and its allies have implied that this is unfair
column6: but it happens all the time.)

column1: They chose wisely. In February 2015 — just a few days before the government was scheduled to start accepting applications for expanded DACA — Judge Andrew Hanen issued an injunction
column2: preventing the government from moving ahead with the program on the logic that the states were ""likely"" to prevail on some of their claims. The Fifth Circuit Court of Appeals upheld the injunction. And in January
column3: the Supreme Court agreed to hear the case.

column1: As the case has made its way through the courts
column2: it's gotten much broader. Initially
column3: the injunction was based on a narrow claim that the Obama administration hadn't used the right procedure in instituting DAPA. The Fifth Circuit ruled that DAPA was also (or at least
column4: was likely to be) illegal on the merits. And now the Supreme Court has added a constitutional question: whether DAPA violates the ""take care"" clause of the Constitution.

column1: While this is theoretically still a ruling on the injunction
column2: the Supreme Court is dealing with the merits of the case — ensuring that if a majority of the Court's eight justices side with the Obama administration
column3: or with the states
column4: the case is finished (and DAPA is alive
column5: or dead) for the duration of Obama's time in office.

column1: The stakes have risen accordingly. The House of Representatives asked
column2: and was granted
column3: the chance to argue that DAPA violates laws that Congress has passed — something that isn't totally unheard of at the Supreme Court level but certainly raises the political temperature of the case.

column1: And on the federal government's side
column2: the argument on behalf of the ""Jane Doe"" immigrant women — not to mention the likely presence of many potential DAPA beneficiaries in the Supreme Court during the oral arguments — will inevitably remind the justices that this is a question of the balance and separation of powers
column3: and about immigrants themselves.

column1: Because immigration is such a divisive culture war issue — and because phrases like ""enforce the law"" get tossed around frequently as talking points — it sure seems like this case should be a massive legal dispute over what should happen to unauthorized immigrants in the US. But it's not. There are four questions at play in the case
column2: and all of them are
column3: given the importance of the case
column4: relatively narrow.

column1: 1) Is it even legal for Texas to sue the federal government to stop the DAPA program?
The states' case
column2: in one sentence: It costs the state government money to give subsidized driver's licenses to DAPA recipients who now qualify for them.

column1: The federal government's case
column2: in one sentence: If that were all it took for a state to sue the federal government over a policy it didn't like
column3: the courts would be clogged forever.

column1: The first question the Court has to address whether Texas and the other states had ""standing"" — whether they are legally able to bring the lawsuit at all. In order to show standing
column2: Texas has to show that implementing DAPA causes some direct harm to the state.

column1: Even if the substance of Texas's legal argument against DAPA is correct
column2: if it can't show that it had standing the whole suit gets dismissed — allowing DAPA to go into effect after all. (This route would give the Supreme Court some appealing options
column3: as we'll get to in a bit.)

column1: The Republican governors and state attorneys general on Texas's side of the case clearly think that allowing unauthorized immigrants to remain in their states is harmful for all sorts of reasons. But as is often the case with Supreme Court cases — and is definitely the case with this one — the actual argument being put forward in the courtroom is a lot narrower than the argument over whether unauthorized immigrants are good or bad for America that's happening around the case.
So far
column2: courts have found that the states have standing for a single reason: Texas driver's license costs. Under Texas law
column3: people who get deferred action are eligible for driver's licenses — and because fees only partially cover the cost of producing a license
column4: the state government covers the rest of the cost. DAPA would make hundreds of thousands of Texans eligible to apply for driver's licenses for the first time
column5: which would cost the state money.

column1: The Supreme Court now has to decide whether that's enough of a reason to allow Texas (and the other states) to sue the federal government over the entire policy.
The federal government argues it's not President Obama's fault that Texas law would allow DAPA recipients to get driver's licenses. Furthermore
column2: supporters of the federal government's side in this case argue there's a slippery slope: Allow the states to sue the government over a policy they don't like
column3: as long as they can show that it costs the state something (even if that cost is recouped)
column4: and the courts will be clogged with lawsuits left and right.

column1: They're hoping that possibility will scare Chief Justice Roberts (who dissented in a previous case about states suing the federal government
column2: Massachusetts v. EPA) into protecting the Supreme Court's legacy by remaining above the dispute.

column1: 2) Is DAPA a substantive new regulation — which the Obama administration didn't follow the proper procedure for?
The federal government's argument
column2: in one sentence: Nope
column3: it's just a general ""statement of policy
column4: and we do those all the time.

column1: The states' argument
column2: in one sentence: It sets pretty hard-and-fast standards for who qualifies for deferred action and work authorization; that seems pretty rule-like.

column1: This question also seems pretty narrow — it's a challenge about whether the Obama administration did DAPA the right way
column2: instead of whether it was the right thing to do. So it might not get a lot of the Supreme Court's attention. But this was actually the basis for the original ruling freezing DAPA
column3: issued in February 2015 by Judge Hanen of the Fifth Circuit.

column1: Under the Administrative Procedures Act
column2: the government can't just issue new regulatory ""rules""; it has to propose them and then allow a certain period for public response. (Hence the term ""notice and comment
column3: which comes up a bunch when people are discussing this aspect of the Supreme Court case.)

column1: The Obama administration didn't do this with DAPA. It argues it didn't have to
column2: because it wasn't a real rule
column3: just a general guideline. The states disagree.

column1: At root
column2: this is a disagreement about how the deferred action programs actually work: whether immigration agents actually have the leeway to reject applications for any reason (policy-like) or whether the Obama administration has dictated that anyone who meets the standards should get protection (rule-like).

column1: And because DAPA hasn't gone into effect yet
column2: this is really an argument about how the original DACA program is working — even though the existing deferred action program isn't being challenged in this case.

column1: 3) Is DAPA within the president's authority
column2: or does it encroach on parts of immigration law where Congress has already set down the rules?

column1: The federal government's argument
column2: in one sentence: DAPA is just a way to tell immigrants they're not being deported — something that both sides agree is legal.

column1: The states' argument
column2: in one sentence: DAPA goes beyond that
column3: by bestowing ""lawful presence"" and work permits on immigrants Congress didn't want to grant either one to.

column1: Legally
column2: this is the biggest question about DAPA: Does it violate US law by going beyond what the president is allowed to do on immigration? But again
column3: the disagreement between the two sides in the actual court case is a lot narrower than you'd think (given the general heatedness of the immigration debate).

column1: US immigration law gives the president a lot of latitude to make policy decisions — more than he gets in a lot of other areas. So the states in this case agree that President Obama (and the rest of the executive branch) have the latitude to choose whom to deport and whom not to deport. The states even say it would be okay if the Obama administration issued cards to people who were ""low priorities"" for deportation indicating that they were low priorities.
But they say DAPA goes beyond what the president is allowed to do
column2: and crosses into areas where Congress has set firm rules on immigration
column3: in two ways. It allows deferred action recipients to apply for work permits
column4: which the states argue violates Congress's intent not to allow unauthorized immigrants to work legally in the US. And
column5: they say
column6: DAPA deems people to be ""lawfully present"" in the US even though Congress has said it's illegal for them to be here.

column1: The phrase ""lawful presence"" is probably going to be thrown around a lot at Monday's oral arguments — it's become increasingly central to the states' argument. The federal government argues that the states are simply getting confused. ""Lawful presence"" isn't the same thing as ""lawful status"" in immigration law — it doesn't grant anyone the right to be in the US. (The federal government has started arguing that it's really more like ""tolerated presence."")
3) Is Obama abandoning his constitutional obligation to ""take care"" to enforce Congress's laws by implementing DAPA?
The federal government's argument
column2: in one sentence: Nope.

column1: The states' argument
column2: in one sentence: Yep.

column1: This question wasn't even considered in the lower courts — the Supreme Court added it to the case on its own. It centers on the Constitution's ""take care"" clause: ""He shall take Care that the Laws be faithfully executed.""
There isn't a lot of Supreme Court jurisprudence on what this phrase actually charges the president to do
column2: so it's interesting that the Court felt it was particularly appropriate here — though it's entirely possible that the justice interested in this was Antonin Scalia and the surviving justices don't have any interest.

column1: The answer to the ""take care"" question depends on whether DAPA violates US law to begin with. If the federal government is right
column2: and DAPA is within the president's legal authority
column3: then he's not abandoning his duty to execute the laws by implementing it. If the states are right
column4: and DAPA is illegal
column5: then Obama might be violating the ""take care"" clause in implementing it — but the program would be struck down in any event.

column1: For people who believe that President Obama is legally obligated to deport unauthorized immigrants under all circumstances
column2: the idea that he's violating the constitution by not ""taking care"" to enforce immigration laws has some appeal. But again
column3: neither side is actually arguing that in court.

column1: There are dozens of hypothetical possible answers the Court could reach to any of the four questions above. But in terms of the case's practical outcome
column2: there are essentially four options.

column1: Furthermore — and this is where things get really messy — the absence of a Supreme Court opinion could allow another circuit court to hear a case on DAPA and rule that it could go forward. How such a lawsuit would proceed is unclear; maybe some of the states that sided with the Obama administration could find standing. But it would create a situation in which DAPA was legal in some parts of the country and illegal in others.
It's entirely possible that the Supreme Court would go out of its way to avoid that level of chaos. That's why some analysts think the most likely outcome is this:
If the Court sides with the states
column2: nothing changes — programs that currently aren't in effect won't go into effect. But if the Court sides with the administration
column3: an estimated 4.5 million immigrants who are currently vulnerable to deportation will get three years of protection and the ability to work in the US legally.

column1: The effects this could have on the lives of those immigrants (and their families) could be huge.
The evidence from DACA
column2: which has protected about 700
column3: 000 immigrants for the past three and a half years
column4: is promising. Three-quarters of DACA recipients had been able to get better-paying jobs
column5: 30 percent had gone back to school
column6: and 59 percent said they could help support their families. There's evidence that DACA helps keep immigrants integrated into American life — instead of losing interest in school or career because they feel their immigration status holds them back.

column1: If the Supreme Court reinstates DAPA at the end of June
column2: the Obama administration will only have seven months left in office to process applications — and many of the community groups that would have been able to help people get those applications will be busy mobilizing for the election.

column1: Furthermore
column2: the election might discourage some immigrants from wanting to sign up to begin with — if they're worried that Donald Trump will be president come 2017
column3: they'll be much less inclined to turn over their personal information to the government.

column1: DAPA is an Obama administration initiative. There's nothing stopping the next president from ending the program and rescinding its protections
column2: even if the Supreme Court upholds it this year. Ted Cruz and Donald Trump have already promised to do just that in their first few days in office.

column1: That doesn't mean that the immigrants who have gotten deferred action so far would necessarily get deported. In fact
column2: that's the bigger decision that President Cruz or Trump would have to make: what to do with a database of hundreds of thousands of immigrants who are unauthorized but who by definition are well-educated
column3: speak English
column4: or at least have kids who are US citizens.

column1: A President Trump might start his mass deportation campaign by targeting the immigrants he can most easily locate: former deferred action recipients.
Some pundits have argued that this means the real immigration fight is what happens in November
column2: rather than what happens in the courts this spring. Insofar as the next president will choose whether to end deferred action
column3: that's true. But the Supreme Court decision could definitely shape what options a president has to expand it
column4: as both Hillary Clinton and Bernie Sanders have promised to do.

column1: Sanders has explicitly said that he'd protect some 8 or 9 million people using deferred action; Clinton has said she wouldn't deport immigrants who hadn't committed crimes
column2: but hasn't explained how she'd protect them.

column1: If the Supreme Court strikes down DAPA — or upholds it
column2: but articulates a limiting principle that clarifies that this is the most a president can do — both of those plans will be a lot harder to implement
column3: but a Democratic president would be under even more pressure to find a way to protect immigrants. That could create trouble.

column1: Conservatives siding with the states in United States v. Texas argue that if Obama wins this case
column2: there's no limit to who could be protected from deportation. They make a persuasive case.

column1: The Obama administration argues that while DAPA was legal
column2: it wouldn't have been legal to give deferred action to even more immigrants — say
column3: parents of DACA recipients. But their reasoning on this point is fairly weak (and it doesn't help that both candidates for their own party's presidential nomination are promising to do just that).

column1: This lack of ""limiting principle"" gives conservatives a lot of pause. A president could do whatever he likes on a whole host of issues — say
column2: refuse to enforce any environmental regulations
column3: or even declare a tax cut by executive fiat. (Vox's Andrew Prokop lays out some of the options.)

column1: Hypotheticals like these raise some valid concerns about the use of prosecutorial discretion generally. But these are issues with existing law
column2: and it's not clear that a ruling for the feds in this case would make them any worse.

column1: Many legal scholars believe that immigration law simply gives the president more discretion than other areas of law. So a ruling for Obama in this case wouldn't necessarily create a precedent for other issues.
If the president has historically had a lot of leeway to set immigration policy
column2: though
column3: a ruling for the states would effectively constrain that power.

column1: The states in this case aren't asking the Supreme Court to issue a broad ruling. But that doesn't stop the Court from doing so if it wants. And if the Court finds that it's illegal for the president to allow a large group of immigrants to apply for work permits
column2: that definitely calls the original DACA program into question — and raises questions for other uses of executive power on immigrations as well. (An extremely broad ruling against the president could even dictate that the executive branch can't declare immigrants ""low priorities"" for deportation
column3: though that's extremely unlikely.)

column1: But even a relatively narrow ruling for the states would have implications for other issues where the president didn't have as much leeway to begin with.
It's possible to imagine a Supreme Court ruling against Obama whose argument implicitly called into question other things he's done
column2: from delaying the employer mandate to modifying key provisions of No Child Left Behind (not to mention the original DACA program). It wouldn't automatically strike down any of these
column3: but it could open the door to future court challenges.

column1: What legal scholars who side with the administration are particularly concerned about
column2: though
column3: is what will happen if Texas and the other states are granted standing at all — even if the Court ultimately sides with Obama. They argue that this would essentially invite states to sue the federal government over any policy they don't like
column4: and then hunt down some way the policy harms them. (In an amicus brief
column5: for example
column6: law professor Walter Dellinger argues that states could start suing the IRS over which organizations are exempt from federal taxes.)

column1: To a certain extent
column2: this is what the states are doing anyway — no state has ever sued the federal government for doing something the state likes. But the Supreme Court has long tried to avoid becoming a way for states to challenge federal policy willy-nilly. That's the sort of politics it tends to want to stay out of.

column1: Then again
column2: the lesson of United States v. Texas may very well be that even if politics stop at the Supreme Court door
column3: the cases that come in — and what happens to decisions that come out — are political from start to finish."	REAL

The Middle East’s sick state	"Will the Middle East be as unstable 10 years from now as it is today? I posed that question this week to a class of students at Harvard University’s Kennedy School of Government. About half answered yes — that things will be as bad or worse
column2: no matter what the United States does.

column1: These graduate students sense what many Middle East experts are beginning to vocalize: The region is caught in a turbulent vortex of change that’s likely to continue for many years
column2: perhaps decades. The drivers are political
column3: social
column4: economic and demographic forces over which the United States and other outside powers have little control. For the next generation
column5: instability may be the rule in the Middle East
column6: rather than the exception.

column1: Predictions about the future based on current trends are always risky because analysts can’t foresee the unexpected “black swan” events that produce radical change. Nobody could have anticipated that a Tunisian fruit vendor’s self-immolation in 2010 would begin a cascade of revolution and civil war in the Middle East. Similarly
column2: we can’t forecast the process that may eventually restore balance.

column1: Economic and demographic data show a region already stressed by slow growth and high youth unemployment. These problems are compounded by refugee flows from wars in Iraq
column2: Syria
column3: Yemen and Libya — and worsened by falling oil prices that hinder Saudi Arabia’s ability to provide a buffer.

column1: The International Monetary Fund’s latest World Economic Outlook
column2: released this month
column3: presents a grim picture. Unemployment will top 13 percent in Egypt and Tunisia this year and reach nearly 12 percent in Algeria. Economies aren’t growing fast enough to provide enough jobs for young people: Growth this year is expected to be 1.3 percent in Iraq
column4: 2.5 percent in Lebanon
column5: 2.6 percent in Algeria
column6: 3.8 percent in Jordan and 4 percent in Egypt.

column1: Saudi Arabia’s growth forecast has been slashed more than 1.5 points to 3 percent this year and is projected to decline further next year because of oil prices. The Saudis are waging a bloody air war in Yemen
column2: apparently convinced that threats to their security are external. But the more intractable problems may be internal
column3: with the Saudi budget falling into what the IMF warns will be “substantial deficit” this year and next.

column1: “Tepid” growth and falling oil exports mean larger trade and budget deficits
column2: predicts the IMF. The region will suffer a cumulative current-account deficit of 1.9 percent of gross domestic product this year; even the oil-exporting countries will run a deficit of 1 percent. “Deepening conflicts and security disruptions in a number of oil-exporting countries could further undermine economic activity
column3: delay reforms and dampen confidence
column4: ” warns the IMF.

column1: The Middle East’s body politic
column2: enfeebled by these disorders
column3: has been ravaged by sectarian and civil wars. The International Rescue Committee estimated this month that 11.4 million Syrians
column4: or about half the population
column5: have fled their homes. The Syrian disaster has affected the whole region. To take just one example
column6: poverty has more than doubled in Iraqi Kurdistan
column7: according to a recent World Bank report.

column1: As weak governance structures have buckled across the Middle East
column2: extremist groups have become more powerful. The most potent is the Islamic State
column3: which exploded out of the remnants of al-Qaeda in Iraq. But many other groups across the region are fusing popular rage with sectarian and tribal bases of support. Even if the Islamic State
column4: also known as ISIS
column5: can be “degraded” in Iraq and Syria over the next three years
column6: as President Obama hopes
column7: the underlying disorder in the region could spawn ISIS 2.0
column8: or even 3.0.

column1: Observing the devastation in the Middle East is a bit like watching a hurricane pummel a vulnerable coastline. Outsiders can try to mitigate the destruction and provide humanitarian relief. They must also try to protect themselves from collateral damage. But they can’t stop the raging winds and surging tides from leveling fragile structures. As disaster-management experts have learned
column2: a big storm has to blow itself out before rebuilding can begin.

column1: Graham Allison
column2: who heads the Belfer Center here
column3: argues that the U.S. government should be careful about trying to fix problems in the Middle East until it understands them better. He contrasts the deadly Ebola virus with the ideological contagion of the Islamic State. We know what causes Ebola and how to stop it
column4: Allison wrote recently in Time magazine
column5: but there is no such clarity about how the Islamic State toxin spreads or how it can be cured.

column1: What we do know is that this extremist virus has taken root in a body that is already severely weakened and showing no signs of recovering soon.
Read more from David Ignatius’s archive
column2: follow him on Twitter or subscribe to his updates on Facebook."	REAL

column1: Physicists just found more hints of an elusive particle that’s its own antiparticle	"Matter and antimatter
column2: simultaneously. By BEC Crew

column1: Almost 80 years ago
column2: an Italian physicist proposed that a particle could exist as both matter and antimatter at the same time. Called the Majorana fermion
column3: this mysterious state of matter set off a decades-long hunt
column4: with scientists finding the first real evidence of its existence earlier this year .

column1: And now physicists in China have discovered that an elusive type of quasiparticle can behave just like a Majorana fermion
column2: and it could help us to finally understand this incredibly weird phenomenon.

column1: If you’re not familiar with the Majorana fermion
column2: it was first proposed by Italian theoretical physicist Ettore Majorana in 1937. He predicted that a type of particle called a fermion could act as its own antiparticle.

column1: In the standard model of physics
column2: every particle has an antiparticle. These antiparticles are usually an entirely separate particle
column3: with the same mass but opposite charge of their partner.

column1: Even electrically neutral particles have antiparticles
column2: such as the neutron
column3: which is made of quarks
column4: and the antineutron
column5: which is made of antiquarks.

column1: In very rare cases
column2: a particle with no mass and no charge can act as its own antiparticle
column3: and we’ve only identified a few examples of these so far – photons (light particles)
column4: hypothetical gravitons
column5: and WIMPs .

column1: Majorana fermions
column2: if they exist
column3: fall into this final category
column4: and if we can find them and harness them
column5: it would change everything about how we record and process information in the next generation of quantum computers.

column1: “The search for this particle is for condensed-matter physicists what the Higgs boson search was for high-energy particle physicists
column2: ” physicist Leonid Rokhinson from Purdue University noted back in 2012 . “It is a very peculiar object because it is a fermion yet it is its own antiparticle with zero mass and zero charge.”

column1: Unlike regular computers that use bits of 0 and 1
column2: quantum computers use quantum bits that can exist in a state of 0
column4: or a superposition of both.

column1: The problem with building a computer out of quantum bits (or qubits) is that it’s incredibly difficult to make a record of what state they previously held once they’ve been switched
column2: and there’s no point having a computer that can’t retain information.

column1: But physicists think Majorana fermions could be the key to solving all of that.
“Information could be stored not in the individual particles
column2: but in their relative configuration
column3: so that if one particle is pushed a little by a local force
column4: it doesn’t matter
column5: ” said Rokhinson .

column1: “As long as that local noise is not so strong that it alters the overall configuration of a group of particles
column2: the information is retained. It offers an entirely new way of dealing with information.”

column1: In April this year
column2: a team from the Oak Ridge National Laboratory in Tennessee discovered the first real proof of the existence of Majorana fermions in something called a quasiparticle.

column1: Unlike a regular particle
column2: which is a physical object that makes up an atom
column3: a quasiparticle is an entity that has some characteristics of a distinct particle
column4: but is made up of a grouping of multiple particles instead. Finding a Majorana fermion quasiparticle is one thing
column5: but the real goal is finding a Majorana fermion particle.

column1: Fast-forward to now
column2: and physicists from the Chinese Academy of Sciences say they’ve identified another type of quasiparticle that behaves just like a Majorana fermion
column3: called Majorana zero modes (MZMs).

column1: The team was able to synthesise these quasiparticles inside a quantum simulation
column2: and manipulate them in ways that would work within a quantum computer system. Most significantly
column3: they showed that they could retain information encoded in their Majorana zero modes
column4: even when errors and ‘noise’ were applied to the system.

column1: “[W]e demonstrate the immunity of quantum information encoded in the Majorana zero modes against local errors through the simulator
column2: ” they describe in their paper
column3: published in Nature Communications.

column1: If the team’s simulation can be replicated in experimental conditions
column2: it means we could have another candidate for Majorana fermion-like behaviours on our hands
column3: and another shot at something to build the quantum computers of the future with.

column1: In the meantime
column2: here’s more on those elusive Majorana fermions:

column1: Source: Science Alert

column1: Why Trump is still likely to fall 52 delegates short of nomination	"There’s nothing quite like playing in front of the hometown crowd to get your mojo back. And that’s exactly what Donald Trump did in the New York primary Tuesday
column2: winning 61 of 62 counties and all but one congressional district en route to scooping up 90 delegates.

column1: In the end
column2: Trump’s resounding victory may have been as vital to the tone of the race coverage as it was to his actual path to the Republican nomination. After a month of taking on water thanks to staff shake-ups
column3: organizing failures and a big loss in Wisconsin
column4: The Donald trounced his rivals in the media capital of the world.

column1: But it’s probably not enough as he tries to secure the 1
column2: 237 delegates he needs to clinch the nomination before reaching the GOP convention in Cleveland. The most likely scenario will have Trump getting about 1
column3: 185 delegates. Here’s why.

column1: New York marks a crucial geographic segue in the race
column2: as the calendar turns away from the Ted Cruz-friendly interior and into Trump’s mid-Atlantic wheelhouse. With 156 bound delegates at stake next Tuesday
column3: the test for Cruz and John Kasich will be how many they can pick off.

column1: You can start by penciling in 39 delegates for Trump as the likely statewide winner in Delaware
column2: Pennsylvania and Maryland. Exceeding the 50 percent mark in Connecticut would mean another 13 delegates who would otherwise be split among the field.

column1: And Trump can expect to win about half of Rhode Island’s 19 proportionally allotted delegates. The rest will be awarded to the respective winners of each congressional district.
The best delegate-poaching opportunity for Kasich comes in the affluent Maryland suburbs of Washington
column2: DC
column3: where polls show Trump dead last behind Cruz. Winning three or four districts between the Beltway and the Connecticut Gold Coast would be a big success. The best news for Trump opponents is that the single biggest trove of delegates will be the 54 unbound Pennsylvanians elected independently of candidate affiliation or obligation. While many have pledged to support the winner of the state or their district
column4: all would be in play in Cleveland
column5: a wrinkle that complicates Trump’s path.

column1: Trump would be wise to maximize his April opportunities. Other than New Jersey on June 7
column2: there are no more gimmes
column3: and few opportunities to reap a disproportionate share of delegates even from those states Trump might win. The Mountain West has been inhospitable terrain. The Pacific Northwest states split their delegates proportionally. And even West Virginia
column4: in the heart of Trump’s Appalachian sweet spot
column5: has a delegate system so complicated that he may come away shortchanged.

column1: The bellwether to watch will be Indiana. The criminally under-polled state holds promise both for Trump (open primary
column2: blue-collar sensibilities) and his opponents (affluent Indianapolis suburbs for Kasich
column3: grassroots conservatives and evangelicals for Cruz)
column4: and awards 30 at-large delegates to the statewide winner. If Cruz can reprise the Midwestern magic that carried him in Wisconsin
column5: he can stop the Trump offensive in its tracks. Short of that
column6: he and Kasich must peel away as many congressional districts as possible to prevent Trump from heading into June needing only a glorified chip shot to clinch.

column1: In the end
column2: the race will come down to California and its massive cache of 172 delegates in what will amount to 53 unpredictable mini-primaries across disparate terrain. Ninety delegates will be awarded in districts where President Obama received 60 percent or more of the vote. Two-thirds of those will be decided in seats where Mitt Romney won 30 percent or less
column3: including eight bona fide “rotten boroughs” where he couldn’t even crack 20 percent.

column1: Trump can hardly expect a New York-style romp here
column2: meaning he needs at least 1
column3: 100 delegates coming in.

column1: Cruz’s argument at an open convention will be stronger if he can claim more than 800 delegates while keeping the deficit to a minimum. The California endgame will hinge on what happens in Indiana. If Cruz can battle through the coming adversity for a Hoosier State victory
column2: the odds are we’re headed to Cleveland.

column1: Bottom line: Even if Trump wins Indiana and staves off Kasich in the ’burbs
column2: he’d probably end up just shy of what he needs — perhaps as close as 1
column3: 230 delegates. But it’s more likely that Indiana proves tougher for him and leaves him closer to 1
column4: 185 delegates — putting all eyes on Cleveland."	REAL

India's Stonehenge: 7,000-Year-Old Megalithic Site is Oldest Observatory in South Asia	"Print Email http://humansarefree.com/2016/10/indias-stonehenge-7000-year-old.html A remarkable 7
column2: 000-year-old megalithic site that served as an astronomical observatory has been found in Muduma village in Telangana
column3: India. The discovery has been hailed as one of the most significant archaeological findings in India over the last few decades.According to Times of India
column4: the team of archeologists described it as ""the only megalithic site in India
column5: where a depiction of a star constellation has been identified."" The ancient observatory dates to 5
column6: 000 BC and the researchers believe that it is the earliest astronomical observatory discovered in India and perhaps even in the whole of South Asia.The site consists of around 80 huge menhirs (standing stones)
column7: which are 3.5 – 4 meters tall. There are also about 2000 alignment stones
column8: which are 30-60cm tall.According to experts
column9: no other excavation site in India has so many menhirs concentrated in such a small area. The maximum concentration of menhirs is located in the central portion of the monument.One of the surprising details discovered at the site is a depiction of the constellation known as Ursa Major
column10: which is formed from small cup-sized pits carved into a standing stone. The group of about 30 cup-marks were arranged in the same shape in which Ursa Major can be observed in the night sky with the naked eye. The carving depicts not only the prominent seven starts
column11: but also the peripheral stars too. The large standing stones that form an observatory in Telangana
column12: India ( Satya Vijayi ) Moreover
column13: as ArcheoFeed.com reported: an ""imaginary line drawn through the top two stars point to pole star or the North Star.""Researchers believe that the site still holds many secrets. The next planned research will take a place in December led by archeologists from Korea.Numerous prehistoric observatories have already been discovered around the world
column14: including Peru
column15: Britain and Armenia. Thousands of years ago people were trying to understand the sky and were often using their observations to make predictions for agricultural and ceremonial purposes. The site Zorats Karer from Armenia dates back to the same period as the observatory from India. The constellation Ursa Major as it can be seen by the unaided eye ( public domain ) As Natalia Klimczak from Ancient Origins wrote :“Zorats Karer is also known as Carahunge
column16: Karahunj
column17: Qarahunj. It is located in an area of around 7 hectares and covers the site nearby the Dar river canyon
column18: close to the city of Sisan. The ancient site is often called the ""A rmenian Stonehenge
column19: but the truth of what it is may be even more fascinating. Related: Stonehenge is 5
column20: 000 Years Older Than Previously Thought According to researchers
column21: Zorats Karer could be among the world's oldest astronomical observatories
column22: and is at least 3
column23: 500 years older than British Stonehenge. The site was rediscovered in 1984 by a team led by researcher Onik Khnkikyan. After a few months of work
column24: Khnkikyan concluded that the site of Zorats Karer must have been an observatory. Moreover
column25: with time
column26: Armenian archeologists
column27: astronomers and astrophysicists found that there were at least two other ancient sites important for prehistoric astronomy in the vicinity: Angeghakot and Metzamor. A general view of the Karahunj site near Sisian
column28: Southern Armenia. ( CC BY-SA 4.0 ) In 1994
column29: Zorats Karer was extensively analyzed by Professor Paris Herouni
column30: a member of the Armenian National Academy of Science and President of the Radio Physics Research Institute in Yerevan. His expeditions revealed a great deal of fascinating information about the site. First of all
column31: his team counted 223 stones
column32: of which 84 were found to have holes.They measured the longitude
column33: latitude and the magnetic deviation of the site. The researchers also created a topographical map of the monumental megalithic construction
column34: which became the basis of further work. Finally
column35: the main treasure of the site was unearthed – a collection of many impressive and unique astronomical objects. The researchers realized that several stones were used to make observations of the sun
column36: moon and stars. They were located according to knowledge about the rising
column37: culmination moments
column38: and setting of the sun
column39: moon and specific stars. The stones are basalt
column40: somewhat protected by moss but smoothed by the rain and wind and full of holes and erosion. Many of the stones were damaged over time.In ancient times
column41: the stones were shaped and arranged in what are known as the north and south arms
column44: the separate standing system of circles and the chord. The stones are between 0.5 and 3 meters tall and weigh up to 10 tons. Some of them are related to burial cists."" By Natalia Klimzcak

column1: Which might be why about halfway through the debate

column2: journalists stopped short of calling Trump demagogic or racist
column3: despite the fact that he has often relied on false information about minorities to appeal to popular prejudices. At his campaign launch
column4: Trump called Mexican immigrants criminals
column5: drug dealers and ""rapists."" In November
column6: Trump tweeted out inaccurate homicide statistics suggesting that blacks were responsible for 81 percent of white homicides. FBI statistics for 2014 put the actual number below 15 percent.

column1: If this were racism and demagoguery
column2: the mainstream media was not quick to identify it as such. That may have been due
column3: at least in part
column4: to the unique nature of Trump's campaign. For a long time
column5: many journalists didn't take the former reality television star seriously. When he became the front-runner
column6: despite his incendiary remarks
column7: many were simply confounded by his ability to flout the conventional rules of American politics.

column1: I think the media has struggled to cover the dark side of the Trump phenomenon because political reporters do not have experience covering a major political figure who is both openly racist and -- let's be honest -- an extremely entertaining politician
column2: Lizza said.

column1: Trump's call for ""a total and complete shutdown of Muslims entering the United States"" changed all that.
The media began by covering Trump as a sideshow
column2: then grew more aggressive in challenging him on his 'facts'
column3: and now is more actively commenting on the character of his campaign
column4: said David Axelrod
column5: the chief strategist on Barack Obama's presidential campaigns and CNN senior political commentator.

column1: The new phase of Trump-media relations has ushered in an unusual moment in American politics
column2: said media experts.

column1: Frank Sesno
column2: director of the School of Media and Public Affairs at George Washington University and a former CNN Washington bureau chief
column3: said journalism ""has moved into the 'have you no shame' mode. There are thresholds and several have been crossed and that blows up so-called objective reporting. There are times when he-said she-said isn't enough.""

column1: Kelly McBride
column2: the vice president for Academic Programs at The Poynter Institute
column3: stressed that while some of the terms were appropriate
column4: it was important for journalists to put Trump's remarks in context.

column1: Rather than just calling him racist
column2: there's more journalistic value in pointing out why it's racist
column3: she said. ""So I like it when I see newsrooms making historical analogies. I like the editorials pointing out that he's dangerous and why.""

column1: The question now is
column2: what impact will the media backlash have
column3: if any?

column1: Trump has proven time and time again that incendiary remarks only bolster his support. Moreover
column2: his supporters harbor little respect for the American media
column3: and often give the candidate a standing ovation when he calls the media ""scum.""

column1: Frank Rich
column2: the New York Magazine columnist
column3: said the media's disdain would only ""enhance his support from his fans.""

column1: Rich Lowry
column2: the editor of National Review
column3: agreed. ""Media disdain is a badge of honor for Trump and his supporters
column4: he said. ""So this latest bout of criticism from the press won't hurt him.""

column1: Perhaps the only way the media could dent Trump would be to have him on TV less often and become less obsessed with him--but that's not going to happen
column2: Lowry added. ""Bottom line: Another Republican candidate is going to have to outmaneuver Trump or just flat-out beat him. It's that simple."""	REAL

column1: How To Reduce Stress	"Share on Facebook Share on Twitter The root cause of stress is fear
column2: as all fear is the threat of losing our attachments. If we’re attached to a desired outcome
column3: anything that threatens it will be something we fear. The fear of losing control underpins stress
column4: for example
column5: and creates frustration over what can’t be controlled. As desirable as it is to be in a position of control
column6: our attachment to it ultimately creates a fear that can manifest as stress
column7: worry
column8: anxiety
column9: and panic. advertisement - learn more Fear brings disorder into our experience when it is within us
column10: and it’s an energy that suppresses consciousness. Activation energy is the force required to get you from doing something when you’re on autopilot (such as habits
column11: routines
column12: procedural awareness
column13: or relaxing) to doing something new. It is a manifestation of willpower. When we are in a state of fear (stress)
column14: our activation energy is diverted toward doing things to ourselves that are primarily against our will. Running late for work and caught in a traffic jam? You can either become frustrated and upset because you fear arriving to work late (which brings you no closer to your goal of getting there on time)
column15: or you can accept the present moment and use it as a learning lesson to leave earlier next time. You can also choose to enjoy the unexpected free time in the morning and listen to a podcast or some music. There are many choices you can make in that space of time that can affect or degrade even the most minute increments of your personal development. Stress causes you to divert attention and willpower away from your initial goal
column16: bringing you no closer to it than when you began. In a state of stress and fear
column17: your willpower gets diverted toward the threat
column18: not the goal
column19: and this is against your own best interest. Time is currency
column20: so pay attention to what you spend your time on. advertisement - learn more Now of course there are valid situations where your willpower MUST be diverted toward dealing with the threat or there might not be any willpower left for you to use in the future! There are two types of fear: survival based fear and ego based fear. Ego fear includes fear of rejection
column21: failure
column22: humiliation
column23: loss
column24: uncertainty
column25: lack of control
column26: etc. These fears are not real
column27: but may feel so to you. Ask yourself
column28: what’s the worst that could happen? Is it death
column29: the loss of freedom
column30: a loved one suffering? If it’s none of those then you’re too attached to an outcome that is not essential to your wholeness. When we’re mindful of our awareness
column31: extraordinary things await us on the opposite side of fear. Believe. Believe in what? Yourself? A higher power? Both? Believe in the truth of your situation by first accepting everything that is happening. You can’t move forward in a state of denial because denial is resistance. Then think about what you’re afraid of (an outcome
column32: for example) and why it is making you feel afraid. What will you lose that is causing your anxiety? What is this thing that you’re holding onto that is vital to your security and wholeness? Fear should be an alarm
column33: not a program. An alarm alerts you of danger
column34: while a program controls and runs the show. When ALERTED by fear we can use the logic of our conscious mind to analyze if we are in any real danger
column35: rather than allowing the subconscious mind and its primal instincts to impulsively control us. Even if we don’t lash out during times of stress and frustration
column36: we may remain divided and chaotic internally
column37: throwing emotional temper tantrums no one else sees. Do your job to parent yourself and take control of the inner child embedded in your subconscious mind (we all have one). Fear is an insecurity
column38: and insecurity is the source of many malfunctions in the human condition. However
column40: we would never know who and what we really are. Fear is illusion. Life is designed to strip illusion from you by bringing you face to face with your fears again and again until you have no choice but to face them
column42: and become fearless. Once you become fearless you’re free from illusion because you have discovered the truth of what’s on the other side of your fear. We design our lives to run away from fear so we don’t have to feel it
column44: chasing us into the corner. It’s understandable why we do this but it’s not helpful because this daunting tool that keeps offering itself to us is the tool of our expansion
column45: the tool of truth if we are ready to accept it. You would be oblivious to yourself without fear
column46: which makes it one of the greatest tools of awareness. You shouldn’t feel ashamed of it; regardless of how tough you are
column47: every human being feels fear. People who suppress fear are glorified. Rather than suppress it
column48: feel it and come to terms with it. This way you won’t feel the need to suppress it because you have already gotten to its source: truth. And the truth will always wipe out fear. By suppressing fear you’re ignoring your personal lesson. We often ignore what our emotional guidance system is trying to tell us because we don’t think fear is valid. Fear is a red flag within us that we should pay closer attention to so we can dig deep and find the source of that fear. Suppressing it is only ignoring the shadow
column49: masking it as courage. We don’t examine the fear that we have; instead
column50: we try to focus on anything that decreases the level of fear that we experience. Sometimes fear is legitimate and sometimes it is not
column51: but we must always pay attention to it so we can get to the Truth of why it’s there. Fear of the unknown is also common. Since we know nothing about the unkown
column52: what we actually fear is whatever we ourselves project into it. We think we know what potential negative thing the unknown might hold for us and we are running from the projection of that potential pain. We fear what we project into the unknown based on our previous experiences (mostly from childhood) of uncertainty and discomfort. The reptile brain seeks comfort
column53: so anything that is uncomfortable alerts our primal survival drives. These red flags create anxious moments to our pleasure-seeking and pain-avoiding ego. When faced with the unknown
column54: the mind goes to work projecting its already acquired fears into the unknown so that it can predict what lies there. It’s those projections that we fear. It’s not the unknown of that experience that it fears
column55: it’s what it thinks it knows that experience will create. We need to be brave enough to face and admit to what we actually fear. This may sound counterintuitive
column57: regardless of how stupid or damaging it is for ourselves
column58: has a positive intention at its core. Anxiety responses aim to help us — usually to get us out of a situation
column59: to protect us. Every behaviour that we generate
column60: even if it’s detrimental to our long-term growth and happiness
column61: has a positive intention behind it
column62: and recognizing this will allow you to change the behaviour. Your subconscious mind wants to protect you but it doesn’t think long-term with respect to your growth and happiness; it reacts in the present moment
column63: and wants to deal with the perceived danger NOW. The subconscious is always thinking about what’s happening now
column64: and how to fix it now. It thinks
column65: “How do I get out of it? How do I survive it?” While your subconscious mind is intuitive
column67: and integral to the mind-body system
column68: it is also deeply irrational and has the cognitive capacity of a 10-year-old child. Ask yourself
column69: would you let a 10-year-old run your life? We need to educate and guide the subconscious mind using its own language and worldview. The subconscious mind’s job is to keep you happy
column72: so when you give it a way to understand that what it’s doing is hurting you
column73: it will stop the behaviour. If the subconscious mind has to choose between safety and happiness
column74: it will always chose safety. Self-preservation is its primary objective
column75: to protect you and keep you alive so you can move your genes forward. Do not justify your fear. While something could have happened to you that created the fear
column77: you must still move beyond it. It may be difficult
column78: but when you justify your fear
column80: you remain a prisoner to it. You give yourself a reason to hold onto the fear because you’re telling yourself that this fear is coming from the outside instead of its true source
column81: the inside. Once you become aware of something
column82: you have the choice and power to change it. Your belief systems determine your ability to overcome your fears. If you tell yourself
column84: ” you ensure this remains true. As long as you believe it
column85: it will be True in your reality. The perception we have of ourselves is greater than the perception other people have of us. Your perceptions will determine how you will react
column86: which in turn determines how long the fear will last in your life. Facing your greatest fears will be your greatest liberation. Your fears are your unresolved issues; once you get to the Truth of why they exist
column87: you can resolve those issues and stop feeding the fears. We must let go of and reexamine what we think is good and bad because our perspective shapes our fears.

Hillary’s No Slam Dunk in 2016	"Could Hillary Clinton be the next Richard Nixon? Now that’s a provocative question
column2: but it isn’t quite what you think.

column1: The other day
column2: I watched Hillary and Bill Clinton take in their close friend Terry McAuliffe’s inauguration as governor of Virginia. Neither Clinton spoke
column3: but their presence said it all: Virginia
column4: the Mother of Presidents long before it was a modern swing state
column5: will be seeing a lot of the Clintons—and now they have a ready-made home-away-from-home in the gubernatorial mansion that adorns Richmond’s Capitol Square.

column1: Every time you observe the Clintons
column2: you can’t help but ponder the long and winding road of their 40-year electoral saga
column3: beginning with Bill’s unsuccessful 1974 run for Congress in Arkansas. Their lives are so suffused with politics that it seems incredible to consider that Hillary might not run in 2016.

column1: After all
column2: with just one exception
column3: a Clinton has always tried for public office whenever a tantalizing opportunity presented itself. The rule-breaker was Bill’s aborted run for president in the 1988 cycle. On the eve of his expected candidacy announcement in July 1987
column4: with the national press gathering in Little Rock
column5: his long-suffering chief of staff
column6: Betsey Wright
column7: she later told PBS
column8: huddled with her boss and presented a list of women he was alleged to have been “seeing.” After a number of responses along the lines of “she’ll never talk
column9: ” Clinton belatedly awakened to the reality that he could self-destruct in the post-Gary Hart world—Hart had been forced out of the Democrats’ presidency sweepstakes just a couple of months earlier following allegations of adultery. The next day
column10: Clinton declined to run
column11: stunning the news media with the unconvincing excuse that he had decided to spend more time with his family.

column1: Nearly three decades later
column2: Hillary needs no cover story should she surprise us and spurn another White House tour. Now in her mid 60s
column3: she knows as much as any human being alive what an arduous journey lies ahead even for a heavily favored contender. Inevitably
column4: she will consider how much she wants
column5: or is able
column6: to keep going at a killer pace throughout her 70s and
column7: more important
column8: her chances of prevailing in November 2016.

column1: Much of it is out of her hands. Low job approval numbers for President Obama
column2: should they persist
column3: will make it difficult for any Democrat to win
column4: even with the party’s seeming Electoral College edge and growing demographic advantages among minorities and the young. Just ask John McCain how President George W. Bush’s unpopularity affected his 2008 White House bid. (Of course
column5: you can’t rule out the very real chance that the Republicans will rescue the eventual Democratic nominee by putting forward an out-of-the-mainstream nominee.)

column1: The Clintons are nothing if not shrewd
column2: and they’ve lived through the entire era of postwar American politics. So Hillary Clinton would be the last to believe what I have heard with increasing frequency: that
column3: in the end
column4: no one of real heft
column5: even Vice President Joe Biden
column6: will challenge her for the Democratic nomination she nearly won in 2008
column7: and she will steamroll over the minor contenders who do. Most frequently mentioned in the “minor” category are former Gov. Brian Schweitzer of Montana and Gov. Martin O’Malley of Maryland. (O’Malley also made a little-noticed appearance at the McAuliffe inauguration.) Sen. Elizabeth Warren of Massachusetts would be a major opponent should she run
column8: but she insists she will not. When California Gov. Jerry Brown also bowed out
column9: NBC News’s First Read called it “a reminder that Hillary Clinton will probably face little to no serious competition if she runs.”

column1: Possible? Sure. But history’s guide tells us otherwise. A consensus choice for a major-party presidential nomination is exceedingly rare—and this is where the Nixon comparison comes in.
Incumbent presidents often find their second-term nominations nearly unopposed
column2: though even in this rarefied group
column3: there are notable exceptions: Harry Truman
column4: Lyndon Johnson
column5: Jimmy Carter and George H.W. Bush. (Truman and Johnson withdrew in 1952 and 1968
column6: respectively
column7: partly because of intra-party opposition.)

column1: But when no incumbent was running
column2: the only precedent for a consensus choice in the entire post-World War II era is Richard Nixon in 1960. This impressive feat was nonetheless achieved with some difficulty and embarrassment. Nixon thought he had averted a serious GOP challenge when New York Gov. Nelson Rockefeller withdrew as a potential candidate in December 1959. But Nixon’s unappealing persona and substantial baggage from the political wars of the 1940s and 1950s worried many Republicans eager for a third consecutive White House victory. Rockefeller sensed it and reconsidered
column3: toying with a surprise candidacy on the eve of the 1960 Republican National Convention. At the last instant
column4: Rocky relented
column5: mollified by the so-called “Treaty of Fifth Avenue
column6: ” a series of concessions by Nixon negotiated in an all-night session and announced by the New York governor himself."	REAL

column1: AG Lynch told FBI Director Comey NOT to go public with the new Clinton email investigation	"Posted by Daisy Luther

column1: Gosh. I wonder if the same advice would have been given if it was Donald Trump who was being investigated by the FBI.

“We don’t ordinarily tell Congress about ongoing investigations
column2: but here I feel an obligation to do so given that I testified repeatedly in recent months that our investigation was completed. I also think it would be misleading to the American people were we not to supplement the record.”

column2: and considering this election
column3: that’s really saying something.

column1: This is from the New Yorker report
column2: emphasis mine.

column1: On Friday

column5: sent a letter to Congress saying that the F.B.I. had discovered e-mails that were potentially relevant to the investigation of Hillary Clinton’s private server. Coming less than two weeks before the Presidential election

column1: Comey’s decision is a striking break with the policies of the Department of Justice

column1: Of course
column2: when it’s her

column1: We do have a right to know. We absolutely have a right to know that a person who could be elected to know all of the secrets was careless when she only knew some of the secrets. column1: As Marco Rubio rises, GOP rivals are reluctant to take him on directly	"As Marco Rubio settles into his new role as a rising top-tier candidate
column2: most of his opponents in the Republican presidential race are showing a reluctance and even an unwillingness to engage him directly on the national stage.

column1: The spotlight on Rubio is intensifying in the media as journalists investigate the senator’s political record and background. But he otherwise is left facing relatively low hurdles for now
column2: bypassing the kind of heated personal clashes that have shaped the 2016 nomination race.

column1: For Rubio
column2: it is a return to the lofty status he had after he burst onto the national scene five years ago. Many Republican elites are once again celebrating him as the party’s golden boy
column3: if not its strongest general-election candidate
column4: and fear seeing him bruised too badly during the primary season.

column1: “He’s articulate
column2: attractive and young. His rivals don’t want him to win
column3: but no one wants to lose him
column4: ” said Vin Weber
column5: a prominent Jeb Bush supporter. “Of course
column6: politics is a rough-and-tumble sport
column7: and he’ll need to take a few punches. But at the end of the day
column8: this is a party that needs to find ways to appeal to Hispanic voters
column9: and having him on our side is an asset.”

column1: The other candidates have not figured out how to deal with what some are calling “the Marco moment
column2: ” hinting at critiques and possible anti-Rubio ads to come but hesitating to make Rubio their main target.

column1: [Dan Balz: Ten months in
column2: the GOP race has no obvious front-runner.]

column1: Donald Trump has castigated Rubio on the stump and in Twitter messages as a “total lightweight” who is “weak” on immigration. But under the prime-time glare of Tuesday night’s Republican presidential debate
column2: the outspoken mogul fell silent about the senator from Florida.

column1: When Sen. Ted Cruz (Tex.) tried to draw a contrast
column2: he did so only with a thickly veiled line about sugar subsidies
column3: something few voters could connect to Rubio.

column1: And although Bush’s campaign previewed a litany of possible attacks on Rubio
column2: the former Florida governor didn’t say a word in Milwaukee about his onetime protege.

column1: Bush sees Rubio as a direct competitor for the support of wealthy donors and party leaders. Bush’s campaign and its allied super PAC
column2: Right to Rise
column3: have signaled possible lines of attack: In a strategy presentation to donors a couple of weeks ago
column4: the Bush campaign branded Rubio disparagingly as a “GOP Obama.”

column1: In the candidates’ Oct. 28 debate
column2: Bush lunged at Rubio over his spotty Senate voting record
column3: even suggesting that he resign his seat. But the offensive backfired
column4: and in the two weeks since
column5: Bush has steered away from Rubio. The dilemma is further complicated by pressure from many of Bush’s Florida-based financial backers
column6: who also like Rubio and want Bush to go easy on him.

column1: Asked why Bush did not scrutinize Rubio during the Milwaukee exchange
column2: campaign manager Danny Diaz said the debate “was a serious one where important issues were discussed
column3: ” and he urged reporters to stay tuned for the next debate on Dec. 15. “We look forward to catching up with all our good friends in Las Vegas
column4: ” Diaz said.

column1: Bush’s surrogates indicated that more heat on Rubio would arrive in short order.
“It’s a long campaign
column2: ” Al Cardenas
column3: a Florida-based Bush supporter who also is close to Rubio
column4: told reporters in Milwaukee. “Everybody’s going to be scrutinized. Those who do well will get scrutinized more.”

column1: GOP strategist Ari Fleischer put it more bluntly: “The candidates will chop each other up if they thought it would help them. Every one of those candidates think it should be them
column2: and they can give you every reason why it shouldn’t be Rubio.”

column1: [Fourth GOP debate is more about party fault lines than personal attacks.]
The mostly substantive nature of Tuesday’s debate
column2: sponsored by Fox Business Network and the Wall Street Journal
column3: did not invite many personal skirmishes. In one exception
column4: Rand Paul went after Rubio for wanting to increase military spending. But in a tense exchange with the senator from Kentucky
column5: Rubio responded by articulating a hawkish worldview and portrayed Paul as championing an “isolationist” foreign policy.

column1: Trump described the debate’s atmosphere as lacking fireworks. “It was amazing
column2: because the lights went on and you never know what’s going to happen — are you going to be attacked and do you go for the kill
column3: right?” he said Wednesday on MSNBC’s “Morning Joe.” “That was not really necessary.”

column1: Trump’s campaign manager
column2: Corey Lewandowski
column3: said the billionaire contender will continue to talk about his differences with Rubio
column4: especially on immigration.

column1: “People are going to keep looking at Rubio’s record
column2: ” Lewandowski said. “They’re going to ask themselves if they really want another first-term senator as president
column3: someone who may not have the right experience. Those concerns aren’t going away.”

column1: Rubio’s advisers presented the lack of engagement Tuesday night as a sign of Rubio’s strength.
“The phrase where I come from is ‘There’s no education in the second kick of the mule
column2: ’ ” Terry Sullivan
column3: Rubio’s campaign manager
column4: told reporters. “I kind of feel like folks figured out that taking on Marco isn’t such a great idea. . . . I don’t think anybody’s really itching to take on Marco on the debate stage.”

column1: Perhaps the best encapsulation of Rubio’s good fortune came when moderator Maria Bartiromo asked him how his résumé stacks up against Democrat Hillary Rodham Clinton’s decades of service. Rubio could not help but grin. It was the softest of softballs — an opening for the 44-year-old senator to cast himself as the candidate of the future.
Eric Fehrnstrom
column2: who was an adviser to 2012 GOP nominee Mitt Romney
column3: said Rubio “has a gift of the golden tongue.”

column1: But he added: “I don’t think any candidate on that stage thinks that they’re somehow immune from political attacks. Rubio’s biggest vulnerability is immigration. While he did not address that at length [in Tuesday’s debate]
column2: I would expect when the attacks go up on TV that immigration will be in the mix.”

column1: Supporters of rival campaigns voiced surprise that Rubio was not drawn into the immigration discussion
column2: considering his leadership in 2013 on the Senate’s “Gang of Eight” pushing for comprehensive immigration reform. Rubio has since disavowed the legislation and has hardened his immigration positions overall.

column1: “There should be more scrutiny of Rubio
column2: no doubt about it
column3: ” said Bob Smith
column4: a former senator from New Hampshire who is backing Cruz. “It’s almost as if the media is ignoring his immigration record
column5: or at least not giving it much coverage. Conservatives up here
column6: however
column7: are well aware of it
column8: and my sense is that they’ll continue to vet Rubio on their own.”

column1: Dan Pfeiffer
column2: a former senior adviser to President Obama
column3: said other Republican candidates may be afraid of tangling with Rubio in a debate.

column1: “Rubio is skilled at delivering a scripted
column2: rehearsed counterpunch
column3: and they had to know he would be prepared
column4: ” Pfeiffer said. He added that Cruz seems to be “patiently waiting for his moment to make this attack. Cruz wants to see the whites of Rubio’s eyes before he fires his biggest guns.”

column1: Indeed
column2: Cruz has been laying the foundation for the contrast he hopes to make with Rubio if the nominating contest narrows to the two of them
column3: as some pundits predict. In debate after debate
column4: Cruz has positioned himself as a hard-line opponent of amnesty
column5: and more generally as a conservative purist.

column1: In his immigration comments Tuesday night
column2: Cruz did not single out Rubio. But his advisers did with reporters afterward.

column1: The freshman Texan “will draw contrasts on issues
column2: ” Cruz spokesman Rick Tyler said. “Senator Rubio was for the Gang of Eight. Senator Cruz wasn’t. Right now
column3: we’re just beginning that
column4: and we’ve got three months till Iowa.”

column1: Jose A. DelReal in Washington contributed to this report."	REAL

column1: The Dark Agenda Behind Globalism And Open Borders	"The Dark Agenda Behind Globalism And Open Borders   By Brandon Smith

When people unfamiliar with the liberty movement stumble onto the undeniable fact of the “conspiracy” of globalism they tend to look for easy answers to understand what it is and why it exists. Most people today have been conditioned to perceive events from a misinterpreted standpoint of “Occam’s Razor”— they wrongly assume that the simplest explanation is probably the right one.
In fact
column2: this is not what Occam’s Razor states. Instead
column3: to summarize

column1: The powers of financial capitalism had (a) far-reaching aim

column5: enslavement through widespread economic extortion. The end game for central banks is
column6: I believe
column7: the triggering of historic financial crisis
column8: which can then be used by the elites as leverage to promote complete global centralization as the only viable solution.

column2: it is directed by even more central global institutions like the International Monetary Fund and the Bank for International Settlements
column3: as outlined in revealing mainstream articles like “ Ruling The World Of Money “published by Harper’s Magazine .

… When the struggle seems to be drifting definitely towards a world social democracy
