column1: I could quote globalists all day long
column2: but I think you get the general idea. While some people see globalism as a “natural offshoot” of free markets or the inevitable outcome of economic progress
column3: the reality is that the simplest explanation (given the evidence at hand) is that globalism is an outright war waged against the ideal of sovereign peoples and nations. It is a guerrilla war
column4: or fourth generation warfare
column5: waged by a small group of elites against the rest of us.

column1: A significant element of this war concerns the nature of borders. Borders of nations
column2: states and even towns and villages
column3: are not just lines on a map or invisible barriers in the dirt. This is what the elites and the mainstream media would like us to believe. Instead
column4: borders when applied correctly represent principles; or at least
column5: that is supposed to be their function.

column1: Human beings are natural community builders; we are constantly seeking out others of like-mind and like-purpose because we understand subconsciously that groups of individuals working together can (often but not always) accomplish more. That said
column2: human beings also have a natural tendency to value individual freedom and the right to voluntary association. We do not like to be forced to associate with people or groups that do not hold similar values.

column1: Cultures erect borders because
column2: frankly
column3: people have the right to vet those who wish to join and participate in their endeavors. People also have a right to discriminate against anyone who does not share their core values; or
column4: in other words
column5: we have the right to refuse association with other groups and ideologies that are destructive to our own.

column1: Interestingly
column2: globalists and their mouthpieces will argue that by refusing to associate with those who might undermine our values
column3: it is WE who are violating THEIR rights. See how that works?

column1: Globalists exploit the word “isolationism” to shame sovereignty champions in the eyes of the public
column2: but there is no shame in isolation when such principles as freedom of speech and expression or the right to self defense are on the line. There is also nothing wrong with isolating a prosperous economic model from unsuccessful economic models. Forcing a decentralized free market economy to adopt feudal administration through central banking and government will eventually destroy that model. Forcing a free market economy into fiscal interdependency with socialist economies will also most likely undermine that culture. Just as importing millions of people with differing values to feed on a nation after it has had socialism thrust upon it is a recipe for collapse.

column1: The point is
column2: some values and social structures are mutually exclusive; no matter how hard you try
column3: certain cultures can never be homogenized with other cultures. You can only eliminate one culture to make room for the other in a border-less world. This is what globalists seek to achieve. It is the greater purpose behind open border policies and globalization – to annihilate ideological competition so that humanity thinks it has no other option but the elitist religion. The ultimate end game of globalists is not to control governments (governments are nothing more than a tool). Rather
column4: their end game is to obtain total psychological influence and eventually consent from the masses.

column1: Variety and choice have to be removed from our environment in order for globalism to work
column2: which is a nice way to say that many people will have to die and many principles will have to be erased from the public consciousness. The elites assert that their concept of a single world culture is the pinnacle principle of mankind
column3: and that there is no longer any need for borders because no other principle is superior to theirs. As long as borders as a concept continue to exist there is always the chance of separate and different ideals rising to compete with the globalist philosophy. This is unacceptable to the elites.

column1: This has led not so subtle propaganda meme that cultures that value sovereignty over globalism are somehow seething cauldrons of potential evil. Today
column2: with the rising tide of anti-globalist movements
column3: the argument in the mainstream is that “populists” (conservatives) are of a lower and uneducated class and are a dangerous element set to topple the “peace and prosperity” afforded by globalist hands. In other words
column4: we are treated like children scrawling with our finger paints across a finely crafted Mona Lisa. Once again
column5: Carroll Quigley promotes (or predicts) this propaganda decades in advance when he discusses the need for “working within the system” for change instead of fighting against it:

column1: For example
column2: I’ve talked about the lower middle class as the backbone of fascism in the future. I think this may happen. The party members of the Nazi Party in Germany were consistently lower middle class. I think that the right-wing movements in this country are pretty generally in this group. – Carroll Quigley
column3: from Dissent: Do We Need It?

column1: The problem is that these people refuse to confront the fruits of globalization that can be observed so far. Globalists have had free rein over most of the world’s governments for at least a century
column2: if not longer. As a consequence of their influences
column3: we have had two World Wars
column4: the Great Depression
column5: the Great Recession which is still ongoing
column6: too many regional conflicts and genocides to count and the systematic oppression of free agent entrepreneurs
column7: inventors and ideas to the point that we are now suffering from social and financial stagnation.

column1: The globalists have long been in power
column2: yet
column3: the existence of borders is blamed for the storm of crises we have endured for the past hundred years? Liberty champions are called “deplorable” populists and fascists while globalists dodge blame like slimy slithering eels?

column1: This is the best card the globalists have up their sleeve
column2: and it is the reason why I continue to argue that they plan to allow conservative movements to gain a measure of political power in the next year
column3: only to pull the plug on international fiscal life support and blame us for the resulting tragedy.

column1: There is no modicum of evidence to support the notion that globalization
column2: interdependency and centralization actually work. One need only examine the economic and immigration nightmare present in the EU to understand this. So
column3: the globalists will now argue that the world is actually not centralized ENOUGH. That’s right; they will claim we need more globalization
column4: not less
column5: to solve the world’s ailments.

column1: In the meantime
column2: principles of sovereignty have to be historically demonized — the concept of separate cultures built on separate beliefs has to be psychologically equated with evil by future generations. Otherwise
column3: the globalists will never be able to successfully establish a global system without borders.

column1: Imagine
column2: for a moment
column3: an era not far away in which the principle of sovereignty is considered so abhorrent
column4: so racist
column5: so violent and poisonous that any individual would be shamed or even punished by the collective for entertaining the notion. Imagine a world in which sovereignty and conservatism are held up to the next generation as the new “original sins;” dangerous ideas that almost brought about the extinction of man.

column1: This mental prison is where globalists want to take us. We can break free
column2: but this would require a complete reversal of the way in which we participate in society. Meaning
column3: we need a rebellion of voluntary associations. A push for decentralization instead of globalization. Thousands upon thousands of voluntary groups focusing on localization
column4: self reliance and true production. We must act to build a system that is based on redundancy instead of fragile interdependency . We need to go back to an age of many borders
column5: not less borders
column6: until every individual is himself free to participate in whatever social group or endeavor he believes is best for him
column7: as well as free to defend against people that seek to sabotage him; a voluntary tribal society devoid of forced associations.

column1: Of course
column2: this effort would require unimaginable sacrifice and a fight that would probably last a generation. To suggest otherwise would be a lie. I can’t possibly convince anyone that a potential future based on a hypothetical model is worth that sacrifice. I have no idea whether it is or is not. I can only point out that the globalist dominated world we live in today is clearly doomed. We can argue about what comes next after we have removed our heads from the guillotine.

column2: you can make a filter for an air conditioning unit.

column1: First
column2: get all of the supplies you can: a lot of baking soda and wood charcoal (not briquettes)
column3: piece of wood
column4: a scale (any kind)
column5: a large pot
column6: 2 pillow cases
column7: a plastic or metal box
column8: and duct tape.

column1: Pour the baking soda into a pot and weigh it. After recording the weight
column2: place on heat source and cook it for a few minutes. Remove and re-weigh
column3: then repeat. When the scale no longer shows change in weight
column4: pour the powder into a pillowcase and make more if necessary to fill to pillowcase about half way or more. This process converts the sodium bicarbonate into sodium carbonate (soda ash
column5: or activated carbon).

column1: Now pour the charcoal onto the pot and use a piece of wood to crush the charcoal into smaller pieces
column2: about the size of wheat grains. Pour into pillow case and make more if necessary to fill to pillowcase about half way or more. Some dust will fall out – let it.

column1: Now
column2: drill or cut two holes big enough to snuggly fit the air intake hose of your A/C unit into the plastic or metal box on the shorter sides. Place the bag of soda ash on one side
column3: the bag of charcoal on the other side. Seal with duct tape generously. Now attach the air intake hoses of your A/C unit on the unit with the air entering the charcoal first
column4: and the soda ash second. Duct tape generously on both ends.

column1: We built this last year when the ash and smoke from local wildfires were choking the air around us. We were supremely comfortable with filtered air. Will it work for chemical weapons? The soda ash is the same ingredient used in gas masks
column2: but I really don’t know. Works great for smoke and ash

column1: Parts Of Patriot Act Expire, Even As Senate Moves On Bill Limiting Surveillance	"Parts Of Patriot Act Expire
column2: Even As Senate Moves On Bill Limiting Surveillance

column1: It was a dramatic day on the floor of the United States Senate on Sunday. Unable to overcome parliamentary maneuvers by Sen. Rand Paul
column2: the body adjourned and let three controversial provisions of the Patriot Act expire at midnight.

column1: Trying to beat a midnight deadline during a rare Sunday session
column2: Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell tried to fast track a House bill that would overhaul the government's bulk collection of Americans' phone records.

column1: At around 7 p.m. ET
column2: the House bill cleared a key procedural hurdle
column3: but as the sun set on Washington
column4: it became clear that a Senate rule allowing for 30 hours of debate would force parts of the Patriot Act to expire at least temporarily.

column1: The Patriot Act will expire tonight
column2: Paul
column3: the Kentucky Republican who has led the charge against the government's bulk collection program
column4: said. ""But it will only be temporary. They will ultimately get their way.""

column1: Before this session
column2: Paul promised to use any parliamentary moves available to him to force any Senate vote on the measure to happen after the 12 a.m. deadline.

column1: He was warned by lawmakers on both sides of the aisle that he was putting the country at risk.
To go dark on this is a risk on Americans' lives
column2: Sen. Dan Coats
column3: an Indiana Republican
column4: said on the floor of the Senate.

column1: McConnell
column2: the senior Republican senator from Kentucky
column3: said that blocking this legislation should be ""worrying for our country."" McConnell said that even though he had vehemently opposed this bill previously — his chamber had also failed to move it forward earlier this week — he would attempt to pass it.

column1: We shouldn't be disarming unilaterally as our enemies grow more sophisticated and aggressive
column2: and we certainly should not be doing so based on a campaign of demagoguery and disinformation launched in the wake of the unlawful actions of Edward Snowden
column3: McConnell said.

column1: Paul fired back
column2: saying he worried that the House bill actually made the government better at collecting phone records in bulk. He said he couldn't trust the secret court tasked with interpreting the law and that he wanted to add amendments to the bill. He added that the U.S. is using fear to convince Americans of the need for these programs
column3: but the country already has the tools to fight terrorists. They could seek warrants
column4: he said
column5: instead of dragging Americans into what he said was an unconstitutional surveillance system.

column1: Mark my words
column2: he said
column3: ""the battle is not over.""

column1: At around 9:45 p.m. ET
column2: after a lengthy break
column3: McConnell took the floor again and admitted defeat. He offered several amendments to the House bill and adjourned until 12 p.m. ET on June 1
column4: guaranteeing that parts of the surveillance programs instituted by the U.S. after the terrorist attacks of Sept. 11 would end entirely at least temporarily.

column1: In a statement
column2: White House press secretary Josh Earnest said that the Senate had taken ""an important—if late—step forward tonight.""

column1: The White House has always supported HR 2048 — also known as the House's USA Freedom Act. The bill ends the bulk collection program as we know it. If passed
column2: the government would still have access to the data
column3: but it would now have to query databases kept by phone companies.

column1: We call on the Senate to ensure this irresponsible lapse in authorities is as short-lived as possible
column2: Earnest said. ""On a matter as critical as our national security
column3: individual Senators must put aside their partisan motivations and act swiftly. The American people deserve nothing less.""

column1: We'll live-blogged the Senate action as it happened. Keep reading if you want a play-by-play.
Update at 11:03 p.m. ET. The Most Dramatic Moment:
We'll leave you tonight with video of the most dramatic moment of the night. It happened as Sen. Rand Paul tried to get five minutes to speak. Here's the video via Real Clear Politics:
Paul
column2: by the way
column3: goes on to win the parliamentary tousle
column4: finally getting his five minutes.

column1: The Senate has adjourned. Three provisions of the Patriot Act will expire at least temporarily.
Update at 9:34 p.m. ET. Senate Still In Session:
The Senate is still technically in session. A senator suggested the absence of a quorum
column2: which has given the Senate time to figure out what will happen next.

column1: Update at 9:31 p.m. ET. Strong Support For 'Comprehensive Reform':
In a statement
column2: Michael Macleod-Ball
column3: acting director of the ACLU Washington Legislative Office
column4: said today's vote and the likely temporary end of the bulk collection program are a reflection of strong support for ""meaningful and comprehensive reform of the surveillance laws.""

column1: He added: ""Congress should take advantage of this sunset to pass far reaching surveillance reform
column2: instead of the weak bill currently under consideration.""

column1: Update at 8:16 p.m. ET. What To Expect?
So
column2: where do we stand right now? The Senate now has the ability to move on the House bill
column3: but senators can debate the bill for 30 hours.

column1: Manu Raju of Politico reports that Majority Leader McConnell ""plans to employ a prerogative Reid rarely used: Making senators actually debate in post-cloture time — or he'll continue process.""
Congressional Quarterly reports that a McConnell spokesman said there will "" 'likely' be no more votes tonight.""
This means three provisions of the Patriot Act are likely to lapse
column2: if only temporarily.

column1: Update at 8:00 p.m. ET. Bulk Collection Will Likely Lapse:
Wyden and Sen. Martin Heinrich
column2: a Democrat from New Mexico
column3: are still talking on the floor.

column1: It's worth noting that according to White House officials
column2: who briefed reporters last week
column3: it is now likely there will be a lapse in the government's bulk collection program.

column1: As we reported: While the statutory deadline is Monday
column2: June 1
column3: ""senior administration officials said they have to begin winding down their surveillance programs at 4 p.m. ET on Sunday. That process
column4: they said
column5: could be aborted as late as 8 p.m. ET.""

column1: We are now past that window.
Sen. Ron Wyden
column2: a Democrat from Oregon
column3: just finished a speech on the floor. Wyden has been a long-time critic of the bulk collection program.

column1: During his speech
column2: he reminded Americans that the administration had misled Congress in the past. He was specifically referring to a hearing in which he asked National Intelligence Director James Clapper if the National Security Agency collects ""any type of data at all on millions
column3: or hundreds of millions of Americans.""

column1: Clapper answered
column2: ""No sir
column3: before adding
column4: ""not wittingly.""

column1: Clapper ended up apologizing for that answer.
Wyden said that's why the Senate has to ask the ""hard questions.""
It is our job to ask the hard questions
column2: Wyden said.

column1: Update at 7:53 p.m. ET. What Does The House Bill Contain:
We've noted Paul's reservations about HR 2048 — or the House's USA Freedom Act.
From a previous post

With that
column2: Paul stepped off the floor. Here's a quick recap of what he said:

column1: Update at 7:28 p.m. ET. 'Bill Will Ultimately Pass':
Sen. Rand Paul took to the floor shortly after the cloture vote passed. He conceded that the House bill would ""ultimately pass
column2: but ""tonight begins the process of ending bulk collection.""

column1: His issue with the House bill
column2: he said
column3: is that Congress may just be replacing one bulk collection program with another.

column1: It's hard for me to have trust in the people who we are giving great power to
column2: Paul said.

column1: The senator from Kentucky said he would offer up amendments to the bill.
Update at 7:08 p.m. ET. Procedural Vote Passes By Large Margin:
The procedural measure to move onto the House bill ultimately passed by a large margin — 77 to 17.
It means the Senate has overcome a major procedural hurdle
column2: but any senator can still debate the measure for 30 hours.

column1: The votes are still coming in
column2: but the Senate has reached the 60 votes needed to limit debate and move on to the House bill.

column1: However
column2: Paul
column3: or any senator for that matter
column4: can force the Senate to debate the matter for another 30 hours before they can vote on the bill. That is of course many hours after the midnight deadline.

column1: The vote so far: 75 in favor of cloture
column2: 15 opposed.

column1: With a temporary extension off the table
column2: Sen. McConnell said he had only two options: One
column3: let the programs expire. Two
column4: try to pass the House bill.

column1: The first option
column2: he said
column3: is ""completely unacceptable."" So
column4: he said
column5: he would move forward with the reconsideration of the House bill.

column1: That motion passed with a voice vote and the Senate is now voting to limit debate and move on to the House bill. That's also known as a cloture vote.
As Fox's Chad Pergram reports on Twitter

column1: Update at 6:16 p.m. ET. McConnell Proposes To Extend Two Sections:
Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell took to the floor to propose a very limited bill — one that would extend Sections 206 and 6001
column2: the so-called roving wiretaps and lone wolf provisions.

column1: Just like that
column2: Paul objected
column3: and McConnell said that his objection should be ""very worrying for Americans.""

column1: The nature of the threat is very serious
column2: McConnell said; therefore
column3: we should not be ""disarming unilaterally.""

column1: The Senate has reconvened. Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell is on the floor.
Update at 6:05 p.m. ET. The Debate So Far:
While we wait for the Senate to reconvene
column2: here's a little recap of what we've heard on the floor so far: Democratic Sens. Harry Reid and Patrick Leahy made the case that the Senate should act quickly to pass the House bill.

column1: Leahy said that it had been passed by the House in bipartisan fashion
column2: and that it makes significant changes to the government's surveillance programs.

column1: Reid said that this is an important national security program. He said that CIA Director John Brennan and even Senate Republicans agree that allowing parts of this law to expire would ""threaten our national security."" In his words
column2: this is ""big time stuff.""

column2: Sen. Paul essentially scoffed at that notion.

Update at 5:56 p.m. ET. What To Expect:
Right now the Senate is in recess. Both parties are meeting to discuss how to go forward. When the Senate returns
column2: we expect a series of votes to reconsider HR 2048 — also known as the House's USA Freedom Act.

column5: but she buried it for her corporate pals and produced the phonebook-size monstrosity that was dead on arrival but reborn in another form years later as Obamacare. She killed single-payer then

column7: and does not propose it now. (Well
column8: she does admit in private that it’s the only thing that works
column9: as her husband essentially blurts out in public.) But Moore claims that because we didn’t create “universal” healthcare in the 1990s we all have the blood of millions on our hands
column10: millions whom Hillary would have saved had we let her.

column1: Moore openly fantasizes: what would it be like if Hillary Clinton is secretly progressive? Remember that Moore and many others did the exact same thing with Obama eight years ago. To prove Clinton’s progressiveness Moore plays an audio clip of her giving a speech at age 22 in which she does not hint at any position on any issue whatsoever.
Mostly
column2: however
column3: Moore informs us that Hillary Clinton is female. He anticipates “that glorious moment when the other gender has a chance to run this world and kick some righteous ass.” Now tell me please
column4: dear world
column5: if your ass is kicked by killers working for a female president will you feel better about it? How do you like Moore’s inclusive comments throughout his performance: “We’re all Americans
column6: right?”

column1: Moore’s fantasy is that Clinton will dash off a giant pile of executive orders
column2: just writing Congress out of the government — executive orders doing things like releasing all nonviolent drug offenders from prison immediately (something the real Hillary Clinton would oppose in every way she could).

column1: But when he runs for president
column2: Moore says
column3: he’ll give everybody free drugs.

column1: I’ll tell you the Clinton ad I’d like to see. She’s standing over a stove holding an egg. “This is your brain
column2: ” she says solemnly
column3: cracking it into the pan with a sizzle. “This is your brain on partisanship.” This entry was posted in General . Bookmark the permalink ."	FAKE

President Obama really really really really hates Maureen Dowd	President Obama's affection for the New York Times op-ed section is pretty well-documented at this point. David Brooks and Tom Friedman are regulars at Obama's occasional off-the-record conversations with columnists
column2: and attended one right before the start of airstrikes against ISIS
column3: along with fellow columnist Frank Bruni; Brooks in particular has been a longtime White House favorite.

column1: But according to David Axelrod's new memoir
column2: Obama reserves an intense loathing for their colleague Maureen Dowd. Here's how Axelrod remembers an encounter during Obama's campaign trip to Europe in the summer of 2008:

column1: Maureen Dowd
column2: the talented but tart columnist for the Times
column3: was traveling with us and was granted a brief interview with Obama. When we brought her to the front of the plane for the interview
column4: however
column5: Obama proceeded to blister her for a previous column she had written. No one got under Barack's skin more than Maureen
column6: whose penchant for delving into the psyches of her subjects was particularly irritating to the self-possessed Obama. Normally polite under any circumstances
column7: he was patronizing and disrespectful to Maureen in a way that I had rarely seen. This was not well received by Dowd who
column8: like most journalists
column9: was accustomed to firing off salvos
column10: yet decidedly uncomfortable when fired upon herself. After that awkward encounter
column11: she seemed to take particular delight in psychoanalyzing Barack and belittling him in print
column12: which only deepened his contempt. Maureen
column13: who is as gracious and loyal to her friends as she is rough on the high and mighty
column14: would become a friend of mine in Washington
column15: which became a minor source of tension with Obama. ""Why are you friends with her?"" he would demand after Maureen sent one of her acid darts his way.

column1: In an email to the Huffington Post's Michael Calderone
column2: Dowd denied that her writing was motivated by a desire to avenge Obama's slight
column3: writing ""The idea that I punished him for giving me his opinion is not true and plays into an unfortunate stereotype of women
column4: the Furies swooping down.""

column1: In any case
column2: Obama's certainly not the first person to lodge this particular complaint against Dowd
column3: that she is excessively interested in psychoanalyzing political figures while neglecting what it is they're actually advocating
column4: that
column5: in her own words
column6: she ""focuses too much on the person but not enough on policy."" In a 2005 profile by Ariel Levy in New York Magazine
column7: Dowd dismissed this criticism as sexist: ""All the great traumatizing events of American history— Watergate
column8: Vietnam
column9: the Iran/contra stuff — have always been about the president’s personal demons and gremlins. So I always thought that criticism was just silly … as if it was a girlish thing to be focused on the person.""

Clinton Takes First Step To Dispel Doubts About Candidacy	"Clinton Takes First Step To Dispel Doubts About Candidacy
Both of the leading Democrats probably helped themselves in their party's first debate of the 2016 presidential campaign
column2: held in Las Vegas and carried by CNN. But Hillary Clinton
column3: the candidate with the most to lose
column4: may have come away having gained the most.

column1: The longtime front-runner has been beset by controversy
column2: falling poll numbers and a brittle relationship with the media. A bad performance before this season's first national audience would have deepened doubts about her candidacy.

column1: At a minimum
column2: Clinton needed to hold her own and provide as little fresh ammunition as possible to her critics. She met this standard and far exceeded it
column3: performing more ably than in any major media appearance since her best debates and speeches in 2008. Her answers were substantive
column4: measured and confident. But even more important
column5: her demeanor was both relaxed and energetic. At times
column6: she even seemed to be enjoying herself.

column1: Her main challenger
column2: Vermont Sen. Bernie Sanders
column3: also had a good night. His strong views on the left bank of the American mainstream found a receptive audience in the partisan crowd. He even got applause for saying he could and would defend his philosophy by ""explaining what Democratic socialism is."" Questioned about his distaste for capitalism
column4: he turned the issue to income inequality and banks ""too big to fail.""

column1: Several of the ""focus group"" interviews conducted by news organizations found their participants liking Sanders the best of the group.
But Martin O'Malley
column2: the former governor of Maryland who has been running a distant third to Clinton and Sanders
column3: also had his moments of connection with the crowd. He made several appeals to environmentalists
column4: especially on climate change. And he told a moving story of parents from Colorado who lost a child in the Aurora theater shooting and then were denied a day in court suing the gun dealer who sold 4
column5: 000 rounds of military ammunition to the shooter.

column1: Less successful on balance were the debate's lesser-known entrants
column2: former Virginia Sen. Jim Webb and former Rhode Island Sen. and Gov. Lincoln Chafee. The latter
column3: a former Republican turned independent turned Democrat
column4: had trouble finding an angle of attack against his former Senate colleagues.

column1: In fact
column2: the entire proceeding was notable for its tone of collegiality. While the candidates disagreed about guns
column3: trade legislation
column4: the use of coal and the use of U.S. military power abroad
column5: they did so in a manner that was more than civil. Whether intentional or not
column6: their behavior contrasted with the rancor and personal confrontations that studded the first two presidential debates on the Republican side."	REAL

Why raising the Social Security retirement age really does hurt the poor the most	"On Wednesday
column2: I wrote about why raising the Social Security retirement age is a particularly cruel policy to people who hate their jobs and die young — a group that tends to be poor.

column1: On Twitter
column2: the very smart Marc Goldwein
column3: who works for the Committee for a Responsible Federal Budget
column4: took issue with the piece. Twitter is good for a lot of things
column5: but debating the distributional impacts of changes to Social Security isn't one of them. So let's move the debate here.

column1: In case you don't want to read the rest of this
column2: here's the short version of my response: a Social Security check means something very different to someone with no retirement savings than it does to someone with hefty retirement savings. Cutting 11 percent of the check someone lives on and 11 percent of the check someone barely notices are not the same thing. And
column3: finally
column4: cutting 11 percent of the check of someone who loves his job is very different from cutting 11 percent of the check of someone who desperately wants to retire.

column1: Goldwein's tweet uses a table from the Social Security administration showing that the cut lops a roughly equal percentage off the benefits of people at all income levels — and of course it does; raising the retirement age is an across-the-board cut. But a 6.5 percent cut to Social Security benefits for someone with no other income is much more harmful than an identical cut for someone with $100
column2: 000 a year in income from retirement savings.

column1: This debate is complicated a bit by the fact that there are actually two ""retirement ages"" for Social Security: the early retirement age
column2: which is the earliest age at which someone can begin receiving benefits
column3: and the full retirement age
column4: at which Social Security grants ""full"" benefits (though
column5: confusingly
column6: you can get still larger Social Security checks by retiring later than the full retirement age). Some proposals raise only the early retirement age
column7: some raise only the full retirement age
column8: and some
column9: like Chris Christie's plan
column10: raise both. But the Congressional Budget Office finds that increasing either retirement age — or both retirement ages — hurts the poor more than the rich.

column1: Here's what it says about raising the early retirement age:
Here's what it says about raising the full retirement age:
In both cases
column2: the basic effect is the same: raising the retirement age is manageable so long as you can continue working
column3: and want to continue working. But it's a much bigger problem if you can't continue working
column4: or you desperately want to stop working
column5: and were going to rely on Social Security to support you in retirement.

column1: Which is to say
column2: raising the retirement age is a cut that targets people who hate their jobs and want to retire
column3: but can't do so without Social Security.

column1: And then there's the fact that the poor live shorter lives than the rich. If we raised the early retirement age from 62 to 65
column2: then someone who lives until 80 would see their 18 years of retirement cut to 15 years — a loss of about 16 percent of their retirement. Someone who only lives until 73
column3: however
column4: would see their retirement cut from 11 years to eight — a loss of about 27 percent of their time in retirement.

column1: This speaks
column2: by the way
column3: to one of the main justifications given for raising the retirement age: that Americans are living longer lives these days. But as this chart from the Peter G. Peterson Foundation shows
column4: the recent increase in life expectancy has been much larger among the affluent.

column1: This is where we get into questions not of budget but of values: I think in a country as rich as ours
column2: it should be possible for people who hate their jobs to retire relatively young
column3: so they can spend a good portion of their adult life in retirement. I think it's easy for people who love their jobs to underestimate how soul-crushing it is to hate going into work every day. And so I prefer fixes to Social Security that don't force people who hate their jobs to spend longer in the workforce.

column1: Perhaps that would change if we didn't have other options for closing Social Security's shortfall — but there are so
column2: so many other paths that it baffles me why so many in Washington have fixated on this one."	REAL

column1: A new 9/11 memorial to Flight 93: ‘Our loved ones left a legacy for all of us’	"—Debby Borza stood before a wall of photos of 40 people who died here Sept. 11
column3: and gently tapped her daughter’s face on a computer touch screen
column4: not knowing exactly what to expect.

column1: “What do they have to say about my dear
column2: sweet daughter?” she said
column3: her face brightening as the screen filled with photos of Deora Frances Bodley
column5: at her high school graduation
column6: working as a volunteer reading tutor
column7: visiting Paris — an album of a promising young life cut short 14 years ago Friday
column8: when four al-Qaeda terrorists hijacked United Airlines Flight 93.

column1: Borza was among the family members given an early look at the $26 million Flight 93 National Memorial visitor center that opened this week
column2: remembering the legacy of the 9/11 attacks and honoring the courage of 40 passengers and crew members who fought back against their four hijackers
column3: preventing the plane from hitting its presumed target
column4: the U.S. Capitol.

column1: “It’s important to me that the visitor sees what these 40 people took on
column2: to take a stand for freedom
column3: to take the kind of stand that cost their lives
column4: ” said Borza
column5: whose daughter was the youngest female passenger on Flight 93. “Maybe there will be some special thing they see about Deora that will inspire them.”

column1: As Americans mark the 14th anniversary of the 9/11 attacks
column2: thousands will gather at long-established monuments at Ground Zero in New York
column3: at the Pentagon in Virginia and at other sites honoring the nearly 3
column4: 000 people who lost their lives in the deadliest terrorist attack in U.S. history. But those who come to the national monument in Shanksville
column5: to honor Bodley and the passengers who kept 9/11 from becoming even more catastrophic
column6: will find a work still in progress.

column1: The stunning concrete-and-glass visitors center and museum are finally open
column2: but landscaping and other finishing touches are still underway. Yet another structure
column3: the Tower of Voices
column4: a nearly 100-foot bell tower with 40 chimes
column5: is scheduled to be built during the next two years.

column1: A memorial plaza close to the crash site
column2: in a field that was once a strip mine
column3: was completed in time for the 10th anniversary in 2011.

column1: At the time
column2: former president Bill Clinton
column3: visiting the site with former president George W. Bush
column4: expressed frustration with the pace of the project.

column1: Clinton and Bush soon became personally involved
column2: speeding fundraising and development
column3: according to Gordon Felt
column4: president of Families of Flight 93.

column1: “President Clinton and President Bush both came through for us
column2: ” said Felt
column3: whose brother
column4: Edward Porter Felt
column6: died in the crash.

column1: Felt said the families were closely involved in all aspects of the complex development
column2: working with private donors and state and federal officials — as well as the National Park Service
column3: which operates the memorial — to raise money
column4: acquire land
column5: select a design and complete construction.

column1: “Our loved ones left a legacy for all of us
column2: ” Felt said
column3: noting that the plane
column4: which was traveling at 563 mph
column5: was less than 20 minutes of flying time from Washington. “If the Capitol building was destroyed that day
column6: just think how much more devastating an impact that day would have had on our country.”

column1: The legacy of Flight 93 might already have inspired others to stand up against terrorist attacks
column2: Felt said. Last month
column3: three Americans acted to avert a massacre on a train in France.

column1: “It’s important that we don’t forget the events of the day
column2: but the individual people who stood up to say no
column3: ” Felt said. “They could have sat back and let others dictate the end of their lives. But they fought back and became heroes in the process.”

column1: In the chill and rain
On Thursday
column2: several hundred people huddled under umbrellas in a heavy
column3: chilly drizzle for the official opening of the visitors center. Speakers remembered the passengers and crew of Flight 93
column4: who “changed the course of American history
column5: ” said Pennsylvania Gov. Tom Wolf (D).

column1: “They are modern-day heroes who represent the very best in us
column2: ” said Interior Secretary Sally Jewell
column3: who also quoted from Abraham Lincoln’s Gettysburg Address
column4: delivered on another remote Pennsylvania field: “We have come to dedicate a portion of that field as a final resting place for those who here gave their lives that that nation might live.”

column1: Alan Hantman
column2: the appointed architect of the Capitol from 1997 to 2007
column3: addressed family members in the crowd
column4: noting that he was in the building on the morning of Sept. 11
column6: and saying
column7: “I’m one of those who was saved by your loved ones.”

column1: Paul Murdoch
column2: the architect of the memorial
column3: said it is designed to highlight the power of the story of Flight 93.

column1: “In its raw severity
column2: we acknowledge their sacrifice. In its solemn darkness
column3: we acknowledge their loss. In its calm serenity
column4: we offer solace at their final resting place. And in its monumental scale
column5: we praise their heroic deeds
column6: ” Murdoch told the crowd.

column1: The visitors center and museum is set between two soaring concrete walls that rise 40 feet high
column2: one foot for each of those who died. It is set directly on Flight 93’s flight path
column3: with a black stone walkway indicating the precise route that the plane followed. On the valley floor below
column4: a large boulder marks the point of impact
column5: serving almost as a headstone in a place where very few human remains were recovered.

column1: The center presents the events of Sept. 11
column3: as they unfolded. The first display that visitors encounter features that morning’s Wall Street Journal; photos of local students entering an elementary school; a diagram showing that there were 4
column4: 500 planes in the air when Flight 93 took off at 8:42 a.m. from Newark on its way to San Francisco.

column1: The next display features video clips of a stunned Katie Couric telling viewers of NBC’s “Today” that a plane had struck the World Trade Center. There follows video of the second plane hitting
column2: the South Tower collapsing
column3: the voice of ABC News anchor Peter Jennings saying
column4: “My God.”

column1: Display cases are filled with tiny fragments of the plane; bits of metal and wire and electronics; a charred seat belt; a safety instruction card; bent metal spoons and forks; the Oracle employee identification card of passenger Todd Beamer; the New Jersey driver’s license of passenger Colleen Fraser; a Visa card that belonged to one of the hijackers.
At one display
column2: visitors can pick up a phone and listen to some of the 37 calls that were made from Flight 93 that morning
column3: some to 911 and some to family members. Those calls allowed passengers to understand that what they faced was not a normal hijacking
column4: and it also allowed them to say goodbye.

column1: “I just wanted to tell you I love you. We’re having a little problem on the plane. I’m totally fine. I just love you more than anything
column2: just know that
column3: ” Lauren Catuzzi Grandcolas says in a message on her husband’s answering machine.

column1: Passenger Linda Gronlund calls her sister and says: “I just love you and I just wanted to tell you that. I don’t know if I’m going to get the chance to tell you that again or not.”
Another wall is dedicated to a life-size photograph of a Boeing 757 cabin
column2: showing the plane as the passengers would have seen it after the hijackers forced them all to the back. When they decided to rush their attackers
column3: they had to move 100 feet to the front of the plane
column4: down an aisle 20 inches wide.

column1: Ed Root
column2: whose cousin
column3: flight attendant Lorraine Bay
column4: died in the crash
column5: stood in front of the photograph
column6: contemplating that daunting prospect.

column1: “We all ask ourselves
column2: ‘What would I have done if I was here?’ ” Root said. “What would you do? Would you have just stayed back there and hoped for the best? Or would you have reacted? Thankfully
column3: they did react.”

column1: While 9/11 is a defining event for America
column2: Root noted that it is getting to be “history” for younger Americans
column3: even those now in college.

column1: “We need them to remember
column2: ” he said. “This history is not over. This is a story that goes on.”"	REAL

column1: Fact checking the fourth round of GOP debates	"Fox Business News aired two GOP presidential debates Tuesday: a prime-time event starring eight candidates and an earlier debate featuring four second-tier contenders
column2: based on an average of recent polls.

column1: Not every candidate uttered facts that are easily fact checked
column2: but following is a list of 15 suspicious or interesting claims. As is our practice
column3: we do not award Pinocchios when we do a roundup of facts in debates.

column1: This was a great line by Rubio
column2: well delivered
column3: but it’s totally off base.

column1: The median wage of welders is $37
column3: according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics. The median wage for philosophy teachers is $63
column5: according to BLS.

column1: In fact
column2: the average first-year salary for a college graduate with a bachelor’s degree in philosophy is $42
column3: 200 — with a mid-career average of $85
column5: according to Payscale.com. For college professors
column6: the median salary is $89
column8: with the top 10 percent having a salary near $200

column1: By contrast
column2: the top 10 percent salary for welders is only about $58
column4: BLS says.

column1: Carson has a point
column2: but such a trend did not play out every time the federal minimum wage was raised.

column1: Our friends at PolitiFact have compiled a chart showing the years Congress raised the minimum wage
column2: and the months of job growth in the following one-year period. The chart shows that between 1978 and 2009
column3: raising the federal minimum wage did not always result in job loss or job growth. In fact
column4: it was split almost evenly; out of the 11 times the minimum wage was raised
column5: there was overall job growth six times
column6: and overall job loss five times.

column1: Still
column2: the Congressional Budget Office projected that raising the minimum wage to $10.10 from the current wage of $7.25 per hour would result in about 500
column3: 000 fewer workers having jobs — and possibly up to 1 million workers would be affected. Raising the minimum wage to $9 per hour could result in 100
column5: 000 jobs lost
column6: the CBO projected.

column1: However
column2: many more low-wage workers’ earnings would increase as a result of raising the minimum wage
column3: the CBO found. Under the $10.10 option
column4: 16.5 million workers with hourly wages less than the proposed minimum would see an increase in their earnings. Under the $9 option
column5: 7.6 million workers would see an increase.

column1: Conventional economic analysis may show that increasing the minimum wage reduces employment by increasing the cost to employers
column2: and by raising the cost of low-wage workers relative to other inputs like machines or technology
column3: the CBO wrote. But conventional economic analysis might not always apply
column4: according to the CBO: “For example
column5: when a firm is hiring more workers and needs to boost pay for existing workers doing the same work — to match what it needs to pay to recruit the new workers — hiring a new worker costs the company not only that new worker’s wages but also the additional wages paid to retain other workers.”

column1: Trump likes to cite this historical example to defend his plan to deport 11 million undocumented immigrants
column2: but never uses its now-politically-incorrect name
column3: “Operation Wetback.”

column1: As our colleague Yanan Wang documented in September
column2: this campaign dumped hundreds of thousands of Mexican migrants back into Mexico
column3: with few resources to fend for themselves: “Unloaded from buses and trucks carrying several times their capacity
column4: the deportees stumbled into the Mexicali streets with few possessions and no way of getting home. … After one such round-up and transfer in July
column5: 88 people died from heat stroke.”

column1: Moreover
column2: researchers now believe claims that more than 1 million people were deported to be highly exaggerated
column3: with the actual figure closer to 250

column1: A Brookings Institution report appears to confirm Paul’s claim. But at The Fact Checker
column2: we always warn readers against correlating the economic trends in a city or state to policy decisions of a single executive — or in this case
column3: his or her party.

column1: A study by the Brookings Institution ranked the top 10 and bottom 10 largest cities in the country by income inequality
column2: using 2012 Census data. PolitiFact rated Paul’s statement Half True
column3: based on this study.

column1: Among the 10 cities with the highest income inequality
column2: nine had Democratic mayors. Atlanta
column3: under a Democratic mayor
column4: had the highest inequality out of the nation’s largest cities. The other cities led by Democrats were San Francisco
column5: Boston
column6: Washington
column7: D.C.
column8: New York
column9: Oakland
column10: Chicago
column11: Los Angeles and Baltimore.

column1: PolitiFact found that seven of the 10 cities in the report with the least income inequality had Republican mayors: Oklahoma City; Omaha
column2: Neb.; Fort Worth
column3: Texas; Colorado Springs
column4: Colo.; Mesa
column5: Ariz.; Arlington
column6: Tex.; and Virginia Beach
column7: Va.

column1: The 10 cities with the least inequality obviously are smaller cities than the ones in the top 10. The range of income distribution is wider in larger cities with bigger populations.
This is stale statistic
column2: derived from a report published in 2014 by the Brookings Institution
column3: which studied Census Bureau data called Business Dynamic Statistics. Brookings analysts tracked data back to 1978 and found that starting in 2008
column4: business deaths exceeded business births through 2011.

column1: It soon became a favorite GOP talking point (Marco Rubio used it in the last debate). But that report is out of date. More recent data shows the trend shifted in 2012 and in the past two years
column2: business starts began to exceed business deaths.

column1: In saying he was against increasing the minimum wage
column2: Carson cited a figure for black teenage unemployment that seemed suspiciously high to some viewers. Apparently he meant to refer to the unemployment rate
column3: though it came out sounding like he was saying 80 percent were unemployed.

column1: But then a 19.8 percent unemployment rate sounded suspiciously low. Indeed
column2: the Bureau of Labor Statistics says that it stood at 25.6 percent as of October.

column1: The Carson campaign initially sent a 2013 report from the American Enterprise Institute that said the jobless rate for black male teens was 44.3 percent — but 19.8 percent for white male teens. Oops. Then we were sent a pair of studies that show the summer jobless rate for black teens was 19 percent. Seems like a shifting of the goal posts
column2: but apparently he was talking about summer employment. He just didn’t make that very clear.

column1: We note this comment because it is very puzzling. The Chinese are in Syria? The Carson campaign did not respond to a query. (Update: Spokesman Doug Watts sent links to blog posts from September 2015 speculating that China was in Syria and a 2012 article about possible Chinese participation in war games with Russia and Syria
column2: which noted the reports were unconfirmed.)

column1: But while there were reports in Middle Eastern media that China would fight alongside Russia in Syria
column2: that has been dismissed by the Chinese media as “speculative nonsense.” A newspaper tied to the ruling Communist Party noted
column3: “It’s not China that brought chaos to Syria
column4: and China has no reason to rush to the front lines and play a confrontational role.”

column1: This may have been true at the start of his campaign
column2: but it’s no longer valid though Trump loves to keep saying this line. In the third quarter of this year
column3: the Trump campaign received $4 million in unsolicited donations
column4: according to the campaign’s latest financial filing. Since launching the campaign
column5: Trump has spent about $2 million of his own money
column6: the filing said.

column1: Carson appears to cite the common statistic that 22 veterans commit suicide a day. At best
column2: this figure is a rough
column3: outdated estimate based on partial data.

column1: This statistic comes from the VA’s 2012 Suicide Data Report
column2: for which researchers analyzed death certificates of veterans from 21 states
column3: from 1999 to 2011. They took the percentage of veteran deaths identified as suicides
column4: out of all suicides from those states during that period. Then they applied that percentage to the number of suicides in the United States in a given year. That comes out to 22 suicides a day.

column1: But the sample size was fewer than half the states
column2: and did not include some states with the largest veteran populations (such as Arizona
column3: California
column4: Texas and North Carolina). Researchers who wrote this report provided a major caveat about their findings: “It is recommended that the estimated number of veterans be interpreted with caution due to the use of data from a sample of states and existing evidence of uncertainty in veteran identifiers on U.S. death certificates.” The Department of Veterans Affairs
column5: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
column6: and Defense Department have been working on a larger study to accurately quantify the suicide problem among veterans.

column1: Suicide is a serious concern among veterans
column2: and Americans at large. In fact
column3: suicides among veterans happen at a higher rate than Americans in general.

column1: Huckabee appears to be citing data from a flawed article that appeared in the tabloid Daily Mail in September. That one in five figure is simply wrong.
The U.N. High Commissioner for Refugees reports that of the nearly 800
column2: 000 refugees arriving by sea in 2015
column3: 52 percent are from Syria
column4: followed by 19 percent from Afghanistan and 6 percent from Iraq. (Nearly 3
column5: 500 people were dead or missing because of the sea journey.) Obviously
column6: both Afghanistan and Iraq are also war-torn countries.

column1: About 650
column2: 000 refugees arrived in Greece
column3: followed by nearly 150
column4: 000 in Italy.

column1: UNHCR also says there are nearly 4.3 million registered Syrian refugees
column2: with more than 2 million living in Turkey
column3: 1 million in Lebanon and more than 600
column4: 000 in Jordan.

column1: The former Arkansas governor gets this depressing factoid correct. In January of 2000
column2: there were 17.3 million manufacturing jobs in the United States
column3: according to government statistics. As of October this year
column4: there were just 12.3 million manufacturing jobs.

column1: Huckabee was also right to reach back to 2000
column2: during the Bill Clinton presidency
column3: as that was the high point for manufacturing in the past 20 years. Almost 5 million manufacturing jobs were lost during George W. Bush’s term in office — and the nadir was reached during President Obama’s term
column4: when the United States had only 11.5 million manufacturing jobs. Some of those jobs have been recovered
column5: but the total number of manufacturing jobs is still lower than when Obama took office.

column1: None of the Democratic candidates have said they would boost tax rates so high
column2: even on the wealthy.

column1: Sen. Bernie Sanders
column2: an independent from Vermont who is seeking the Democratic presidential nomination
column3: has not yet released a tax plan
column4: but he has repeatedly denied that he would increase taxes from the current marginal rate of 39.6 percent to as high as 80 or even 90 percent. (The marginal rate is what you pay on each additional dollar earned.) Sanders claims he would fund his $1 trillion plan to rebuild U.S. infrastructure by tapping corporate profits now stashed in overseas tax havens.

column1: The United States had a marginal tax rate of 90 percent in the Dwight Eisenhower administration
column2: and then John F. Kennedy proposed to reduce it to 70 percent. (The plan was approved by Congress after his assassination.) But even such rates would not take 90 percent of a person’s income.

column1: The crime rate has been decreasing for decades
column2: but you wouldn’t know it just listening to what Christie says about the rampant “lawlessness” in the country.

column1: The violent crime rate has been decreasing steadily since 1991
column2: despite overall population growth. The FBI Uniform Crime Report
column3: which compiles data from law enforcement agencies
column4: shows the violent crime rate decreased by 15 percent since President Obama took office in 2009. In 2011
column5: the violent crime rate was the lowest it had been since 1971.

column1: The murder rate also has been dropping in major American cities
column2: including in New York City. This has been the trend for the past decade
column3: even in cities that once were overrun by crime. This trend holds even despite a blip in some cities this summer.

column1: It’s not entirely clear where Santorum got his figure
column2: or how the father “living” at the time the child is born is an incentive not to marry the mother. Perhaps Santorum meant that the father was living in the home at the time the child was born
column3: leading to his argument about cohabiting.

column1: In any case
column2: a 2014 Pew Research Center analysis of 2013 Census data show that 46 percent of children younger than 18 years old are living in a “traditional” family — a home with two married heterosexual parents in their first marriage. According to the analysis
column3: 34 percent of children in 2013 were living with an unmarried parent
column4: and most of the unmarried parents were single. Four percent of all children were living with two cohabiting parents.

column1: Santorum may be referring to a report
column2: referenced in a 2014 Associated Press article
column3: by researchers at Harvard University and Cornell University that found found that at least half of mothers who were cohabiting when their child was born were still in relationships with the child’s biological father five years later. More couples are cohabitating
column4: and the trend likely will continue because many couples are postponing marriage until their finances are more stable
column5: according to the article
column6: citing research by the National Center for Health Statistics.

column1: The National Center for Health Statistics also found that nonmarital births increasingly are likely to occur among cohabiting couples
column2: though the rate of births of unmarried women has decreased since the peak in 2008.

column1: This is one of Jindal’s favorite boasts about his record
column2: but he takes too much credit for saying he “cut” the state budget 26 percent.

column1: The state budget in fiscal 2009
column2: Jindal’s first budget after taking office in 2008
column3: was $34.3 billion. In fiscal 2016
column4: the proposed budget was $25.1 billion. That is a $9.2 billion decrease
column5: or 26.8 percent.

column1: But this budget decrease was not due to his executive decisions alone. Federal funding also decreased by $10 billion during those eight years
column2: from $19.7 billion to $9.7 billion. Part of this decrease was due to waning federal funding for hurricane recovery
column3: according to the Times-Picayune."	REAL

column1: CLINTON CAMPAIGN COOPERATED WITH POLITICO ON ‘DEMYSTIFYING’ HUMA ABEDIN	"Home › MEDIA | POLITICS › CLINTON CAMPAIGN COOPERATED WITH POLITICO ON ‘DEMYSTIFYING’ HUMA ABEDIN CLINTON CAMPAIGN COOPERATED WITH POLITICO ON ‘DEMYSTIFYING’ HUMA ABEDIN 0 SHARES
[11/1/16] Asked to provide a quotation for a Politico profile of Huma Abedin in July 2015
column2: Clinton Campaign manager John Podesta wanted to use the phrase “wicked smart” instead of “bright
column3: ” and he emphasized Abedin’s “strategic sense.”

column1: Podesta also agreed with a campaign staffer’s suggestion to describe Abedin as “an integral part of the team.”
The Wikileaks email exchange
column2: dated July 2
column3: 2015 and released on Tuesday
column4: begins with Clinton’s press secretary Nicholas Merrill telling Milia Fisher
column5: Podesta’s aide
column6: that “Politico has been working on a profile on Huma that we are being what I’d call partially cooperative with.”

column1: Merrill said after consulting with Communications Director Jennifer Palmieri and Huma herself
column2: the campaign decided to have the reporter sit down with Huma “off the record.”

column1: “We think there is some value in demystifying her a bit in general
column2: and Politico isn’t a bad place to do it
column3: ” Merrill wrote to Fisher.

column1: Merrill asked Fisher to see if Podesta “would be willing to weigh in
column2: which I think would be good in the spirit of showing team unity.”

column1: “The piece will be about Huma’s evolution from body person to senior staffer
column2: so if he’s up for it
column3: maybe John could say something about her being a multi-faceted team player
column4: ” Merrill wrote. Then he offered a suggested quotation:

column1: “Like: I was there at the White House when Huma was a young intern
column2: and now she’s an integral part of the team. She’s as multi-faceted as she is bright
column3: and when you combine that with her humility
column4: you couldn’t ask for a better colleague.”

column1: Merrill tells Fisher
column2: “Feel free to tweak that
column3: put it in John’s voice
column4: or blow it up.”

column1: Fisher forwarded Merrill’s email to Podesta
column2: asking him if he’d be willing to provide a quote. “Comms (communications) thinks it might lend an air of community to the piece
column3: ” she wrote to Podesta.

column1: Podesta’s reply: “Change bright to ‘wicked smart’ and after humilty add ‘and strategic sense.'”
The complete email exchange
column2: as provided by WikiLeaks
column3: can be seen here :

column1: The July 2
column2: 2015 Politico profile of Abedin described her as “Clinton’s longest-serving aide.” It said that “like a mother monitoring her child on the playground

Final votes on Patriot Act
column2: trade deal bill set dramatic stage for Congress’ return"	"The Senate’s failure to extend the USA Patriot Act will bring the legislation on NSA phone-record collection and other key surveillance activities perilously close to expiring on June 1
column3: forcing senators to return early from recess for a rare Sunday session.

column1: The Senate vote was just one of two this weekend that set the stage for dramatic showdowns on Capitol Hill in the coming weeks and months.
The GOP-led upper chamber passed bipartisan legislation Friday night to strengthen President Obama's hand in global trade talks. However
column2: the legislation must now pass the Republican-led House
column3: with help from Democrats because some conservative members oppose the legislation.

column1: Speaker John Boehner supports the measure and says Republicans will do their part to pass it.
Dozens of House Republicans oppose the legislation either out of ideological reasons or because they are loath to enhance Obama's authority
column2: especially at their own expense.

column1: Senate and now House Democrats are showing little inclination to support legislation that much of organized labor opposes.
On the Patriot Act bill
column2: Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell says he will bring the upper chamber back into session on Sunday
column3: May 31 -- roughly 24 hours before the post-9/11 legislation expires.

column1: Meanwhile
column2: the National Security Agency is starting to winding down its bulk collection of domestic-calling records in preparation for the Senate voting again against the legislation
column3: according to the Justice Department
column4: which says the collection takes time to halt.

column1: The Senate went into the early hours on Saturday morning to vote on the legislation before leaving Washington for Memorial Day recess.
By the time senators broke for the holiday
column2: they had blocked a House-passed bill and several short-term extensions of the key provisions in the Patriot Act.

column1: The main stumbling block was a House-passed provision to end the NSA collecting the phone-call metadata and instead have the records remain with telephone companies subject to a case-by-case review.
McConnell warned against allows the NSA and other key surveillance programs under the act to expire.
However
column2: he and other key Republican senators oppose the House approach
column3: backed by officials who argued it is the best way for the United States to keep valuable surveillance tools.

column1: Fellow GOP Kentucky Sen. Rand Paul
column2: also a 2016 presidential candidate
column3: called the Senate's failure to allow the extension a victory for privacy rights.

column1: We should never give up our rights for a false sense of security
column2: Paul said in a statement. ""This is only the beginning -- the first step of many. I will continue to do all I can until this illegal government spying program is put to an end
column3: once and for all.""

column1: The White House has pressured the Senate to back the House bill
column2: which drew an overwhelmingly bipartisan vote last week and had the backing of GOP leaders
column3: Democrats and the libertarian-leaning members.

column1: But the Senate blocked the bill on a vote of 57-42
column2: short of the 60-vote threshold to move ahead. That was immediately followed by rejection of a two-month extension to the existing programs. The vote was 54-45
column3: again short of the 60-vote threshold.

column1: McConnell repeatedly asked for an even shorter renewal of current law
column2: ticking down days from June 8 to June 2. But Paul and other opponents of the post-Sept. 11 law objected each time.

column1: At issue is a section of the Patriot Act
column2: Section 215
column3: used by the government to justify secretly collecting the ""to and from"" information about nearly every American landline telephone call. For technical and bureaucratic reasons
column4: the program was not collecting a large chunk of mobile calling records
column5: which made it less effective as fewer people continued to use landlines.

column1: When former NSA contractor Edward Snowden revealed the program in 2013
column2: many Americans were outraged that NSA had their calling records. President Obama ultimately announced a plan similar to the USA Freedom Act and asked Congress to pass it. He said the plan would preserve the NSA's ability to hunt for domestic connections to international plots without having an intelligence agency hold millions of Americans' private records.

column1: Since it gave the government extraordinary powers
column2: Section 215 of the Patriot Act was designed to expire at midnight on May 31 unless Congress renews it.

column1: Under the USA Freedom Act
column2: the government would transition over six months to a system under which it queries the phone companies with known terrorists' numbers to get back a list of numbers that had been in touch with a terrorist number.

column1: But if Section 215 expires without replacement
column2: the government would lack the blanket authority to conduct those searches. There would be legal methods to hunt for connections in U.S. phone records to terrorists
column3: said current and former U.S. officials who spoke on condition of anonymity because they were not authorized to discuss the matter publicly. But those methods would not be applicable in every case.

column1: Far less attention has been paid to two other surveillance authorities that expire as well. One makes it easier for the FBI to track ""lone wolf"" terrorism suspects who have no connection to a foreign power
column2: and another allows the government to eavesdrop on suspects who continuously discard their cellphones in an effort to avoid surveillance.

column1: The Associated Press contributed to this report."	REAL
Don’t write Donald Trump’s political obituary just yet: Why surging Ben Carson looks like a flavor of the month	"Trump has been the leader for several months now
column2: but Carson appears to have broken through with key demographics
column3: particularly evangelicals. The CBS report sums up Carson’s advantages well:

column1: Carson has made gains across many key Republican groups. In a reversal from earlier this month
column2: he now ahead of Trump among women and is running neck and neck with him among men. Carson’s support among evangelicals has risen and he now leads Trump by more than 20 points with this group. Carson performs well among conservative Republicans and those who identify as Tea partiers.

column1: It’s not terribly surprising that Carson leads Trump among women and evangelicals: Trump is the misogynist par excellence and Carson is a proud religious fanatic – these are natural demographics for Carson. But Carson’s rising support among men and Tea Partiers
column2: relative to Trump
column3: is somewhat surprising.

column1: Tea Partiers don’t do policy. Their project is essentially negative
column2: which is why the GOP’s nihilism and obstructionism began in earnest when Tea Partiers were elected to Congress in 2010. Neither Carson nor Trump have anything resembling a platform or a plan. They’re outsiders with no political experience who want to disrupt the status quo – that’s a message that resonates with conservative men and Tea Partiers.

column1: If there’s a difference
column2: it’s that Trump is louder and more aggressively obnoxious than Carson
column3: which ought to endear him to these demographics. Evidently
column4: though
column5: Carson’s unhinged nice guy routine is working. His new campaign ad perfectly illustrates both his appeal and his vacuousness.

column1: In a 30-second TV spot
column2: Carson manages to hit all the right conservative notes without coming close to explaining what he’s going to do. “I’m Ben Carson and I’m running for president
column3: ” he says. “The political class and their pundit buddies say: ‘Impossible. He’s too outside the box.’ Well
column4: they do know impossible. Impossible to balance the budget
column5: impossible to get border security
column6: impossible to put aside partisanship…I’m Ben Carson
column7: I’m running for president
column8: and I’m very much outside the box.”

column1: If you’re waiting for the part where he says how he’s going to balance the budget or get border security or put aside partisanship
column2: you don’t know Ben Carson or the new GOP. Carson is basically doing the same thing as Trump: bashing the “political class” and promising to fix everything that’s broken – only Carson does so with a lukewarm smile whereas Trump pounds his fist on the table with Tri-State bravado. It doesn’t matter that neither candidate has a discernible plan to accomplish any of these things – the empty rhetoric is more than enough for Republican voters. One of the more interesting findings in the new CBS/NYT poll is that 55 percent of Trump backers say their support is firm
column3: while 80 percent of Carson supporters say they could change their minds. This is good news for Trump; it suggests Carson is far more of a flavor of the month candidate than Trump. Whatever the reason
column4: Trump has real staying power – he’s proven that. Carson
column5: however
column6: remains a question mark. He may well win in Iowa
column7: thanks to his support among evangelicals
column8: but the GOP’s last two Iowa winners – Santorum and Huckabee – lost the nomination. Trump
column9: moreover
column10: is well-positioned in the other early primary states like New Hampshire and South Carolina
column11: where he remains comfortably ahead of Carson. Carson’s boost in the polls will be a boon to his campaign
column12: but his long-term viability is still debatable. If this trend continues for another month or two
column13: however
column14: Trump might be in real trouble."	REAL

column1: Carmel Institute celebrates 5th anniversary with jazz concert	"Carmel Institute celebrates 5th anniversary with jazz concert October 27
column2: 2016 RBTH u.s.-russia relations
column3: jazz The Carmel Institute of Russian Culture and History celebrated its 5th Anniversary. Source: Press photo

column1: The Carmel Institute of Russian Culture and History celebrated its 5th Anniversary by hosting a standing room only concert at the historic Lincoln Theatre celebrating Cultural Dialogue and the Giants of Jazz. Over 1200 guests and students from all over the Washington DC metropolitan area thoroughly enjoyed this memorable concert celebrating the common language and mutual love of jazz that the United States and Russia share.
Source: Press photo
Said Carmel Institute Founder and Advisory Chair Susan E. Carmel
column2: “The Carmel Institute emphasizes shared values
column3: common interests and cultural dialogue. These are important qualities necessary to achieve cooperation
column4: mutual respect and to overcome pervasive stereotypes. I am honored and grateful to have two incredible cultural Ambassadors at our Fifth Anniversary celebration for the Carmel Institute. Igor Butman and Wynton Marsalis exemplify the best of cultural diplomacy and cultural dialogue
column5: and help us represent the Institutes' focus on enhancing greater cultural understanding through shared common interests and face to face interactions. By continuing to emphasize the importance of these qualities to our younger generations and future leaders
column6: we are making an investment into the future that will be paid back ten-fold over time.”

column1: Ambassador of the Russian Federation to the U.S. and Honorary Co-Chair of the Institute acknowledged the Institute’s milestone by saying
column2: “We would like to congratulate the Carmel Institute for Russian Culture and History and its leadership with the fifth anniversary and express our gratitude for their support and dedication. What started as a modest cultural initiative
column3: five years later has grown both in scope and scale. Far surpassing the initial plans
column4: it has now turned into an Institute that creates an opportunity to strengthen interest and knowledge of culture and history of Russia
column5: thus contributing to the increase of mutual understanding between the two nations.”

column1: Source: Press photo
According to jazz great Igor Butman
column2: “I am honored to contribute to the rich tradition of jazz diplomacy by performing with Wynton Marsalis at the fifth anniversary concert of the Carmel Institute of Russian Culture and History. It is an even greater honor to perform at the Lincoln Theater where so many giants of jazz have expressed themselves in the universal language of music. I wish the Carmel Institute many more years of success in its tireless campaign to promote culture as a medium of communication between two great cultures that have always achieved success through dialogue and cooperation.”

column1: Source: Press photo
Dr. Anton Fedyashin
column2: Director of the Carmel Institute of Russian Culture and History
column3: added
column4: “The Carmel Institute has become an integral part of American University’s commitment to an education that prepares students for global responsibilities in an increasingly complex and interconnected world. Without ignoring problems of which history provides so many examples
column5: our program emphasizes shared values
column6: common interests
column7: and cooperative achievement
column8: and always points towards the positive stages in the US-Russian relationship from which we hope that students can learn in order to guide their decisions as they emerge as global leaders."	FAKE
