column1: Raise the wage: Paul Krugman shatters the myth that we can’t afford to boost workers’ pay	"Three things are inevitable in this life: death
column2: taxes
column3: and conservative claims that we simply can’t afford to give low-wage workers a pay boost. Nobel Prize-winning economist takes on the latter inevitability in his New York Times column today
column4: seizing on recent developments to illustrate why arguments against wage increases don’t withstand serious scrutiny.

column1: Take McDonald’s announcement this week that it would pay its workers $1 above the minimum wage per hour at the 1
column2: 500 outlets owned and operated by McDonald’s itself. (The move
column3: which still falls well short of what workers and their advocates seek
column4: affects 90
column5: 000 workers
column6: but it doesn’t apply to the 750
column7: 000 workers employed by McDonald’s 3
column8: 100 American franchisees.) While modest in scope
column9: McDonald’s move — coming on the heels of similar wage boosts by bold-faced names like Walmart and Target — suggests that “[m]aybe it’s not that hard to give American workers a raise
column10: after all
column11: ” Krugman writes.

column1: While free market fundamentalists might retort that global competition will sink firms that boost worker pay
column2: Krugman responds by noting that most American workers are “employed in service industries that aren’t exposed to international trade.”

column1: What about technology? Isn’t it an unassailable maxim of modern economics that we can afford to pay larger wages only to highly skilled workers — ones who can’t be replaced by machines? As Mike Konczal wrote recently
column2: technology is but a small part of the larger inequality phenomenon. The key factors
column3: he pointed out
column4: include tax policy
column5: the financialization of the American economy
column6: deunionization
column7: and the conscious political choice not to raise the minimum wage.

column1: What’s more
column2: Krugman observes
column3: “Workers are people; relations between employers and employees are more complicated than simple supply and demand.” This truism is borne out in empirical evidence
column4: with comparisons of states that raised their minimum wages with neighboring states that didn’t showing that higher pay does not mean fewer jobs.

column1: Similar factors explain another puzzle about labor markets: the way different firms in what looks like the same business can pay very different wages. The classic comparison is between Walmart (with its low wages
column2: low morale
column3: and very high turnover) and Costco (which offers higher wages and better benefits
column4: and makes up the difference with better productivity and worker loyalty). True
column5: the two retailers serve different markets; Costco’s merchandise is higher-end and its customers more affluent. But the comparison nonetheless suggests that paying higher wages costs employers a lot less than you might think. And this
column6: in turn
column7: suggests that it shouldn’t be all that hard to raise wages across the board. Suppose that we were to give workers some bargaining power by raising minimum wages
column8: making it easier for them to organize
column9: and
column10: crucially
column11: aiming for full employment rather than finding reasons to choke off recovery despite low inflation. Given what we now know about labor markets
column12: the results might be surprisingly big — because a moderate push might be all it takes to persuade much of American business to turn away from the low-wage strategy that has dominated our society for so many years. There’s historical precedent for this kind of wage push. The middle-class society now dwindling in our rearview mirrors didn’t emerge spontaneously; it was largely created by the “great compression” of wages that took place during World War II
column13: with effects that lasted for more than a generation."	REAL

column1: Hillary Clinton should proactively set out ethics rules	"Richard J. Davis is a former assistant Watergate special prosecutor and assistant secretary of the treasury for enforcement in the Carter administration. The opinions expressed in this commentary are his.
(CNN) As we enter 2016
column2: things certainly are looking more positive for Hillary Clinton than they appeared six months ago.

column1: The email controversy
column2: while not gone
column3: is fading. The Benghazi House Committee has been exposed as more about politics than a serious examination of security failings. Vice President Joe Biden has decided not to challenge her in the primaries.

column1: This then may be the ideal time for Clinton proactively to take steps to minimize the potential damage to her candidacy from other sources of controversy: the Clinton Foundation and speaking fees earned by former President Clinton. Such steps need to include significant restrictions on who the foundation will accept donations from as well as on where the former president will speak for money.
Taking these steps now is particularly important for Hillary Clinton because one area where her poll numbers remain problematic is whether she is viewed as honest and trustworthy . And
column2: as demonstrated by a recent Washington Post article
column3: there remains media interest in the extraordinary amounts of money the Clintons have raised for their political and philanthropic activities.

column1: It is important to understand that the issue regarding the Clinton Foundation is not whether the foundation is (or was) a conduit for illegal bribes and it certainly is not about whether the foundation does truly humanitarian work. I am not aware of serious evidence that the former is the case. I am aware of many projects that the foundation has undertaken in the areas
column2: among others
column3: of global health and economic development
column4: particularly in places where children and their mothers are severely disadvantaged. (Full disclosure: I am not supporting a candidate in the election at this point; I did contribute to the draft Biden movement before he decided not to run.)

column1: The issue is how
column2: at a time when Americans have understandably become cynical about government
column3: and where money in politics is already out of control
column4: do we avoid adding to the impression that our government is for sale
column5: and how does this candidate demonstrate to an already super suspicious public that she truly is an honest person committed to ethical government.

column1: In thinking about the foundation and speaking fees we are not operating on a clean slate. Questions have already been raised about how the foundation operated while Hillary Clinton served as secretary of state. Donations in the hundreds of thousands and sometimes millions of dollars were accepted by the foundation from foreign governments and others when they had issues being considered by the State Department.
Where we are talking about a foundation run by the secretary of state's husband
column2: in both of these circumstances -- contributions to the foundation from those then having business before the department and the foundation doing business with the State Department -- the appearance of receiving favored treatment may be clearly present.

column1: Clinton cannot avoid having to respond to questions about foundation activities and speaking fees while she was secretary of state. History cannot be rewritten. She can
column2: however
column3: meaningfully address this controversy by announcing now that if she becomes President the foundation will not do business with the United States government
column4: and that neither the foundation nor her husband will accept fees or contributions either from foreign entities or from those doing business or seeking to do business with the government.

column1: One objection to this approach might be that such restrictions would make it difficult if not impossible for the foundation to operate
column2: or at least operate at its current level. The answer to this possible complaint is straightforward: No one is required to seek to become president of the United States
column3: but if you do
column4: you and your family simply cannot do certain things. And one of those things is accept fees or contributions that make it appear our government is for sale and that the way to influence U.S. policy is to contribute money to entities controlled by the President's family or pay huge fees to her husband.

column1: If fees or contributions were made to the spouse of the President of Zimbabwe or her foundation we would not tolerate it and
column2: indeed
column3: our government might well investigate such payments under the Foreign Corrupt Practices Act. We certainly should not tolerate it if such payments involve the family of the President of the United States. Hillary Clinton should act now to address this problem before it becomes a larger threat to her candidacy."	REAL

column1: Budgeting the Good War, for 75 Years	"Share This
Today we call it the status quo
column2: or endless war
column3: or we just don’t bother to notice it. Indeed
column4: now more than ever we don’t notice it. It’s barely part of the 2016 election
column5: even though we’re engaged in active conflict in half a dozen countries
column6: toying with a relaunch of the Cold War with Russia and
column7: of course
column8: hemorrhaging
column9: as always
column10: more than half our annual discretionary budget on “defense.”

column1: World War II has been going on for seven decades now and has no intention of ever stopping . . . of its own volition. But this year’s rocking electoral craziness – not just Hurricane Donald
column2: but the unexpected staying power of the Bernie Sanders campaign – may well be the harbinger of transcendence. Apparently there’s another force in the universe capable of standing up to the American
column3: indeed
column4: the global
column5: military-industrial status quo.

column1: Slowly
column2: slowly this force is organizing itself and taking human shape. This isn’t a simple process. After all
column3: the game of empire – the game called war
column4: the game of domination – has been coalescing political power for several thousand years now.

column1: But our current military budget was birthed by the wars of the 20th century. William Hartung
column2: writing recently at TomDispatch
column3: shows the fascinating connectedness of the wars that followed VE and VJ Days
column4: as the corporate beneficiaries of the Big War aligned with mainstream politicians of both major parties and coalesced into the Washington consensus. Over the decades they have engaged in an ongoing struggle to maintain military spending at breathtakingly high levels and avoid any sort of transition to something called peace.

column1: The two pillars of this consensus
column2: as Hartung points out
column3: are the ideology of “armed exceptionalism
column4: ” that a shifting array of enemies are out there itching to destroy us
column5: but we will persist in our mission to maintain order in every corner of the planet; and the “strategic placement of arms production facilities and military bases in key states and Congressional districts
column6: ” ensuring entrenched political power for the arms lobby.

column1: So World War II initially
column2: as we know
column3: morphed into the Cold War
column4: America’s crusade against communism
column5: which was set into motion in 1950 by a long-classified report (NSC-68) prepared by the State and Defense departments and the CIA
column6: urging the vigorous containment of Soviet expansion and the development of the hydrogen bomb.

column1: President Truman “was somewhat taken aback at the costs associated with the report’s recommendations
column2: ” according to history.com
column3: and “he hesitated to publicly support a program that would result in heavy tax increases for the American public
column4: particularly since the increase would be spent on defending the United States during a time of peace.”

column1: Peace! What a nuisance! But: “Thank God Korea came along
column2: ” as an aide to Secretary of State Dean Acheson put it at the time. The Korean War gave the militarists the enemy they needed and the nuclear arms race
column3: and so much else
column4: was born. The military budget was set for decades.

column1: As Hartung points out
column2: the next terrible hurdle the budget boys faced was in the wake of the Vietnam War
column3: which ended in 1975. That war
column4: and the universal draft that essentially pulled the whole country into a front-row seat for it
column5: spawned a passionate antiwar movement and
column6: ultimately
column7: a moldering national disgust for war
column8: known as Vietnam Syndrome. The Cold War continued
column9: but the U.S. military was confined to proxy wars for a while and had to rethink its strategy.

column1: Two things happened. The universal draft was ended
column2: removing most of the American middle class from a life-and-death stake in our military operations; and Saddam Hussein
column3: our ally
column4: was recast as Adolf Hitler. And in 1991
column5: President George H.W. Bush embarked on a month of war with Iraq known as Operation Desert Storm. Not only did the US“win” this war and kill over 100
column6: 000 Iraqis (and ultimately cause hideous health problems for American soldiers)
column7: but
column8: perhaps most importantly: “By God
column9: we’ve kicked the Vietnam Syndrome once and for all.” So the president proclaimed.

column1: Unfortunately for the war consensus
column2: the Soviet Union dissolved a short time later and the Cold War ended . . . and a “peace dividend” loomed. Hartung notes that Gen. Colin Powell
column3: then chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff
column4: expressed the situation thus: “I’m running out of demons. I’m running out of villains. I’m down to Castro and Kim Il-sung.”

column1: Would military spending be diverted to infrastructure repair
column2: free education
column3: universal health care?

column1: Well
column2: no. The Bill Clinton presidency found a few new demons. It fought a war in Kosovo and
column3: on the domestic front
column4: vastly expanded the prison-industrial complex. Meanwhile
column5: the neocon think tanks cogitated and one of them

column1: In fact
column2: Clinton’s positions are not that divergent from the policies of the current White House. Her hawkishness has been mostly displayed through rhetoric
column3: or by degree — though she has strayed from the president on a key issue
column4: stating that the Islamic State threat cannot be “contained
column5: ” as Obama has stated
column6: but rather must be “defeated.”

column1: Liberal Democrats who support Clinton have struggled to get Sanders supporters past her foreign policy record. At Netroots Nation
column2: the annual conference of progressives held this year in St. Louis
column3: Clinton’s campaign was nearly invisible. Foreign policy
column4: a focus of some past conferences
column5: was discussed only at a few crowded panels.

column1: Rania Khalek
column3: a journalist who has written critically of Clinton
column4: said the Democrat poses a more direct threat to the Muslim world than Trump.

column1: “People are not going to protest when she decides to put boots on the ground in Syria
column2: ” Khalek said. “People are not going to protest when she decides to give Israel more military aid. She has a record of killing people. Donald Trump doesn’t have that record
column3: yet.”

column1: Jennifer Miller-Smith
column2: a 50-year old Clinton supporter from Florida
column3: argued that some progressives subjected Clinton to tests they never demanded of Kerry or Vice President Biden — for example
column4: their support for the Iraq War.

column1: “Iraq was a long time ago
column2: and she’s learned since then
column3: ” Miller-Smith said. “We’ve all learned since then.”

column1: “Even I believed Colin Powell
column2: ” she said about the former secretary of state.

column1: Charles Khan
column3: a financial reform activist who was in seventh grade at the start of the Iraq War
column4: said that polling and politics might curb Clinton’s hawkish tendencies.

column1: “I think Hillary is smart and doesn’t want to do anything that is unpopular
column2: ” Khan said. “With a huge majority of Americans not wanting to be involved in another war
column3: that’s probably the stance she’d take.”"	REAL

column1: The GOP debate fear cauldron: According to the Republican candidates, you’re going to die	"Tuesday night’s Republican presidential debate was the first since the Islamic State-inspired terrorist shooting in San Bernardino
column2: California
column3: and not surprisingly
column4: most of the questions tossed out by CNN moderators dealt with national security and terrorism. In the days since San Bernardino
column5: public fears over terrorism have grown
column6: and President Obama has been doing what he can to tamp down anxiety and encourage people not to give in to the fear that terrorists work to inspire. But as the CNN debate made painfully clear
column7: the Republican presidential candidates have quite the opposite goal in mind: They want everyone to be scared witless by the looming terrorist menace and worried that they will be the next to die.

column1: New Jersey Gov. Chris Christie
column2: back on the main stage thanks to CNN’s expansive inclusion rules and his own improved poll numbers in New Hampshire
column3: did the most to actively scare the shit out of every person unfortunate enough to be watching. In his opening statement he announced that “America has been betrayed” by “the leadership that Barack Obama and Hillary Clinton have provided to this country.” As proof of that betrayal and treason
column4: Christie pointed to yesterday’s closing of the Los Angeles Unified School District “based on a threat.” He never got around to mentioning that the “threat” had long since been revealed as a hoax. But still Christie was worried about the “children filled with anxiety
column5: ” and the “mothers who will take those children tomorrow morning to the bus stop
column6: ” and the “the fathers of Los Angeles
column7: who tomorrow will head off to work and wonder about the safety of their wives and their children.” They live in terror
column8: these nameless gendered stereotypes
column9: because Obama couldn’t protect them from the threat posed by “madbomber@cock.li.”

column1: Asked what he would do to ensure that fear does not “paralyze” American in the aftermath of terrorism
column2: Christie explained that paralyzing fear is
column3: unfortunately
column4: “the new normal under Barack Obama.” “Everywhere in America is a target for these terrorists
column5: ” he said
column6: giving everyone a reason to be afraid always. Christie’s closing statement was a riff on 9/11. “Many of our friends and others in our neighborhood lost their lives that day.” Christie even offered himself as a menacing presence
column7: leaning forward and shifting back and forth behind his lectern like a rhinoceros sizing up a Jeep full of safari tourists. His message all evening was blunt and terrifying: you will die
column8: unless you vote for me.

column1: Not far behind Christie was Sen. Marco Rubio
column2: who made a point of spelling out in detail the menacing nature of the Islamic State. “This is the most sophisticated terror group that has ever threatened the world or the United States of America
column3: ” he warned. “This is a very significant threat we face. And the president has left us unsafe.” He made a special point of noting the Islamic State’s sophistication: “This is a radical jihadist group that is increasingly sophisticated in its ability
column4: for example
column5: to radicalize American citizens… This is not just the most capable
column6: it is the most sophisticated terror threat we have ever faced.” He warned about “the next time there is an attack on this country” while pushing for reinstatement of metadata collection provisions in the Patriot Act. Sen. Ted Cruz went a slightly different route
column7: linking Republican panic over Syrian refugees to both the San Bernardino terrorist attack (which had nothing to do with refugees) and the 2013 Senate immigration reform bill to score a bank-shot hit on Rubio: CRUZ: Because the front line with ISIS isn’t just in Iraq and Syria
column8: it’s in Kennedy Airport and the Rio Grande. Border security is national security. And
column9: you know
column10: one of the most troubling aspects of the Rubio-Schumer Gang of Eight Bill was that it gave President Obama blanket authority to admit refugees
column11: including Syrian refugees without mandating any background checks whatsoever. Now we’ve seen what happened in San Bernardino. When you are letting people in
column12: when the FBI can’t vet them
column13: it puts American citizens at risk. All in all it was a grim
column14: bleak
column15: and frightful debate that saw several leading candidates try to stoke heightened public anxiety over terrorism. There were no acknowledgements that acts of terrorism are exceptionally rare
column16: with just “45 Americans killed in jihadist terrorist attacks” since 9/11. (More Americans have died as a result of homegrown right-wing terrorism
column17: but that threat didn’t earn a single mention at the debate
column18: even though one such attack took place just days before San Bernardino.) This was more about resurrecting the national security politics of the Bush years
column19: when Republicans would conjure the threat of imminent terrorist slaughter on American soil to cast Democrats as weak and to justify the rollback of civil liberties in the interest of safety. A scared voter is a motivated voter
column20: and Republicans have every interest in keeping people as terrified as possible."	REAL

column1: Clinton holds narrow lead over Trump on eve of conventions	"On the eve of the two national political conventions that will shape the images of the major-party presidential candidates
column2: Donald Trump and Hillary Clinton are in a competitive contest nationally but with the presumptive Republican nominee facing deficits on key character attributes and issues
column3: according to a new Washington Post-ABC News poll.

column1: The survey shows Clinton leading Trump by 47 percent to 43 percent among registered voters. That represents a shift in Trump’s direction since last month’s Post-ABC poll
column2: which showed Clinton leading by 12 points. In the new poll
column3: Clinton leads by 10 points among all adults — 50 percent to 40 percent — compared with a 14-point lead among this wider group last month.

column1: Both candidates remain highly unpopular — the two most unpopular in the history of Post-ABC polling. By about 2 to 1 (64 percent to 31 percent)
column2: Americans view Trump unfavorably. Clinton’s numbers are not quite as negative — 42 percent favorable and 54 percent unfavorable. Half of all registered voters say they have strongly unfavorable views of Trump
column3: while 47 percent say they have strongly unfavorable views of Clinton — the highest ever in a Post-ABC poll for her.

column1: The survey also highlights the degree to which Americans are motivated by negative impulses rather than seeing the choice in positive terms. Almost 6 in 10 say they are dissatisfied with the choice of Trump vs. Clinton. Fifty-four percent of Clinton’s supporters say they are mainly voting against Trump
column2: while 57 percent of Trump supporters say they are mainly voting against Clinton.

column1: Given the dissatisfaction
column2: there is the possibility that candidates from minor parties will attract the support of disaffected voters. In a four-way matchup that also includes Gary Johnson of the Libertarian Party and Jill Stein of the Green Party
column3: the poll results are Clinton 42 percent
column4: Trump 38 percent
column5: Johnson 8 percent and Stein 5 percent.

column1: The new poll comes after a tumultuous two weeks that included the killings of five police officers in Dallas and deadly shootings by police in Louisiana and Minnesota. As the calling for the poll was closing came news of an apparent terrorist attack in Nice
column2: France. All these events have added to the tensions of a country on edge and heightened the importance of security and racial issues in the choice of a president.

column1: The poll also comes after Clinton was spared prosecution by the government for her use of a private email server as secretary of state. But while avoiding any criminal charge
column2: Clinton received a stern rebuke from FBI Director James B. Comey
column3: who said she and her aides had been “extremely careless” in their handling of sensitive classified material in their email exchanges.

column1: The previous Post-ABC poll showed Clinton with a larger lead than some other national surveys taken around the same time. Whether or how much the shift toward Trump in the current survey was affected by how the FBI investigation was resolved can’t be measured. Other recent polls show the difference in the race nationally to be in low single digits
column2: with Clinton generally enjoying the advantage.

column1: Republicans begin their nominating convention here in Cleveland on Monday and will conclude Thursday with the expected nomination of Trump
column2: with Gov. Mike Pence of Indiana as his running mate.

column1: The Democratic convention
column2: in Philadelphia
column3: will begin July 25
column4: with Clinton poised to become the first woman nominated for president by a major party. She is still mulling her vice-presidential choice and met with several contenders Friday.

column1: Trump hopes to produce a convention that helps to alleviate questions about his fitness to be president among many Americans
column2: but he begins with an enormous deficit on that issue. The Post-ABC poll found that nearly six in 10 registered voters say he is not qualified to serve as president — with 49 percent saying they strongly believe that. Meanwhile
column3: Clinton is seen as qualified to serve as president by 56 percent of voters.

column1: Among Republicans and Republican-leaning independents
column2: about 7 in 10 see Trump as qualified to be president — but almost one-quarter of that part of the electorate still questions the presumptive GOP nominee’s fitness.

column1: The survey highlights familiar fault lines in the electorate. Trump leads among men
column2: 49 percent to 41 percent
column3: while Clinton enjoys an even larger margin among women
column4: 52 to 38 percent. Voters ages 18 to 39 support Clinton 54 to 34 percent
column5: while those 65 and older back Trump 51 to 42 percent. Those between 40 and 65 are almost evenly divided. Trump leads by 15 percentage points among white voters
column6: while Clinton has a huge 52 percentage point lead among nonwhite voters.

column1: At this point
column2: the Democrats are slightly more united behind Clinton than Republicans are behind Trump. One goal of the Trump campaign is to leave Cleveland at the end of the week with the party more united and enthusiastic about the nominee. Currently
column3: 86 percent of Democrats back Clinton
column4: while 82 percent of Republicans back Trump.

column1: Independent voters lean toward Trump
column2: 47 to 41 percent
column3: although winning independents is no guarantee of winning the presidency. Four years ago
column4: Mitt Romney won among independents while losing to President Obama.

column1: Clinton enjoys the support of 8 in 10 self-identified liberals
column2: while 7 in 10 conservatives back Trump. Moderates go decisively for Clinton
column3: 52 to 36 percent.

column1: The contest between Clinton and Trump highlights one potential shift in the electorate that will be closely watched between now and November: the division among voters based on educational attainment.
Trump’s most important block of voters are whites without college degrees
column2: who support Trump by a margin of 60 to 33 percent. But college-educated white voters have been shifting toward the Democrats
column3: and the poll underscores that the competition for those voters will be hard-fought and potentially decisive in the election’s outcome. Republicans historically have carried the votes of whites with college degrees
column4: and Romney won the group by 14 points over Obama four years ago.

column1: The Post-ABC poll finds whites with college degrees are evenly divided — 43 percent Trump
column2: 42 percent Clinton
column3: with an outsize 10 percent volunteering support for “neither.” When gender is included in the analysis
column4: the poll finds that white women with college degrees narrowly support Clinton
column5: while white men with college degrees support Trump by a slightly larger margin.

column1: Of seven issues tested
column2: Clinton has double-digit advantages over Trump on three — race relations
column3: handling an international crisis and immigration. Clinton has smaller edges on looking out for the middle class and handling terrorism
column4: while Trump holds small edges on taxes and the economy.

column1: Across six attributes
column2: Trump has an 11-point margin among registered voters on the question of which candidate would do the most to bring needed change to Washington. By a margin of five points
column3: he is seen as more honest and trustworthy. Clinton has a similar edge on empathy with people’s problems and representing people’s values and holds double-digit edges on having better judgment and having a presidential personality and temperament.

column1: In an election that is likely to be framed as a choice of continuity with Obama’s policies vs. a change in direction led by a Washington outsider with no previous political experience
column2: a bare majority of voters say they prefer experience in politics to someone outside the establishment. That’s a narrower margin than earlier in the year
column3: when 59 percent said they favored a politically experienced candidate. The poll indicated there was growing support for an outsider among Republicans and independents.

column1: Clinton’s trust deficit is highlighted on another question in the poll: whether she is too willing to bend the rules. Seven in 10 Americans (72 percent) said she is. The poll also asked whether respondents saw Trump as biased against women and minorities. On that question
column2: 56 percent said yes. When people were asked which was the greater concern
column3: a plurality (48 to 43 percent) cited Trump’s possible bias.

column1: The Post-ABC poll was conducted July 11-14 among a random national sample of 1
column2: 003 adults reached on cellular and landline phones. Overall results have a margin of sampling error of plus or minus 3.5 percentage points; the error margin is 4 points among the sample of 816 registered voters."	REAL

column1: Kevin McCarthy announces he's a candidate for House speaker (+video)	"The California congressman has worked by John Boehner's side for the past year. Now
column2: he's actively seeking the top post.

column1: House Majority Leader Kevin McCarthy is officially declaring his candidacy for House speaker to replace John Boehner.
Boehner announced his resignation on Friday under pressure from conservatives.
McCarthy
column2: who is Boehner's No. 2
column3: sent a letter to GOP lawmakers on Monday pledging to fight for conservative principles — and asking for their support as the next speaker.

column1: If elected speaker
column2: I promise you that we will have the courage to lead the fight for our conservative principles and make our case to the American people
column3: McCarthy wrote in the letter to his House Republican colleagues. ""But we will also have the wisdom to listen to our constituents and each other so that we always move forward together.""

column1: McCarthy is strongly favored to get the job though he faces a challenge from Florida Republican Rep. Daniel Webster.
He is currently serving his fifth term in Congress and has been endorsed by Boehner.
The Christian Science Monitor detailed McCarthy's background and his short term as House majority leader.
In his tenure as the deputy
column2: McCarthy has been loyal to Boehner
column3: for instance
column4: “backing up the outgoing speaker's plan to remove a controversy over ""defunding"" Planned Parenthood from a stopgap spending bill that's needed to avoid a government shutdown next week. And he supported Boehner last year as one of only 28 Republicans to vote to raise the so-called debt limit without seeking concessions from Obama
column5: ” The Associated Press reports. After Boehner’s announced that he'll step down next month
column6: McCarthy issued a statement calling Boehner a leader and a mentor
column7: according to NBC News. ""It takes profound humility to step down from a position of power
column8: and John's depth of character is unmatched."" McCarthy said. ""Now is the time for our conference to focus on healing and unifying to face the challenges ahead and always do what is best for the American people."" According to the Boston Globe
column9: Republicans will hold their internal leadership elections Oct. 1 to avoid drawing out the process of electing a successor to Boehner. ""I'll tell Kevin
column10: if he's the next speaker
column11: that his No. 1 responsibility is to protect the institution. Nobody else around here has an obligation like that
column12: Boehner told reporters on Friday. ""Secondly
column13: I'd tell him the same thing I've just told you. You just do the right thing every day for the right reasons
column14: the right things will happen.""

column1: Material from Reuters was used in this article."	REAL

column1: AT&T-Time Warner Merger: Another Media Consolidation That Puts Profits Over Consumers	"Videos AT&T-Time Warner Merger: Another Media Consolidation That Puts Profits Over Consumers ‘The deals are driven by Wall Street’s insatiable desire for short-term growth at any cost
column2: ’ a media analyst at a consumer advocacy NGO wrote
column3: warning about the risks of the deal. | November 2
column4: 2016 Be Sociable
column5: Share!

column1: MINNEAPOLIS — Media analysts warn that a proposed merger between AT&T and Time Warner is more likely to enhance corporate bottom lines and pad the pockets of Wall Street investors than benefit consumers.
“Big mergers like this inevitably mean higher prices for real people
column2: to pay down the money borrowed to finance these deals and compensate top executives
column3: ” said Matt Wood
column4: policy director at Free Press
column5: an NGO that protects net neutrality and online press freedom
column6: in an Oct. 22 press release .

column1: The media first reported that AT&T was in “informal” talks to merge with Time Warner on Oct. 20 . By Oct. 24
column2: AT&T announced that Time Warner had agreed to be bought out by the telecommunications giant for $85.4 billion.

column1: Currently
column2: Time Warner represents one of a shrinking number of mass media conglomerates that increasingly control the vast majority of news available to Americans. AT&T is one of the world’s largest providers of mobile phone and landline services
column3: and
column4: as owner of DirecTV
column5: a major player in the television marketplace as well.

column1: Corporate executives have promised that the merger could make more content available to consumers
column2: offer new options for mobile viewing
column3: and provide alternatives to traditional cable TV. Representatives of both companies have also tried to mollify concerns that the deal would violate antitrust laws
column4: claiming it represents the “vertical integration” of two different markets
column5: rather than a merger of competitors.

column1: Many media experts have expressed concern and skepticism about these claims
column2: particularly in regard to the potential benefits to consumers. Wood suggested AT&T’s buyout of DirecTV
column3: which was completed in July 2015
column4: should serve as a warning about the possible effects of this new
column5: larger merger model. He warned:

column1: “The deals are driven by Wall Street’s insatiable desire for short-term growth at any cost. And just as AT&T’s recent purchase of DirecTV was quickly followed by price hikes
column2: there’s every reason to expect this potential tie-up would cost internet users and TV viewers dearly too.”

column1: Kevin Kelleher
column2: a reporter at Time magazine
column3: weighed in on Oct. 24. He wrote that the deal “makes sense for media executives
column4: less so for consumers
column5: ” as it’s unclear how bringing content creators and internet service providers together would actually benefit the end user. He continued:

column1: “For now
column2: concerns over the deal seem to be outweighing the benefits
column3: which could end up being negligible. For decades
column4: the pipes that streamed digital content remained largely independent from the companies that provided the content. And no consumers complained.”

column1: Meanwhile
column2: several senators have come out in opposition to the proposed merger
column3: citing concerns about the ultimate implications for consumers
column4: the role of Washington’s “revolving door” into the corporate world
column5: and what this buyout could mean for the future of media consolidation.

column1: On Sunday
column2: Al Franken
column3: a former TV actor and senator representing Minnesota
column4: told The New York Times’ media reporter Jim Rutenberg that the merger could increase prices and reduce the number of choices available to consumers.

column1: “When the company that controls the pipes
column2: so to speak
column3: owns this very
column4: very large content provider
column5: it can cause a whole bunch of different horribles for consumers
column6: ” Franken said.

column1: Elizabeth Warren
column2: a senator from Massachusetts known for her consumer advocacy
column3: objected to Christine Varney’s involvement in the deal. Varney
column4: an antitrust lawyer who has been hired to oversee the AT&T and Time Warner merger
column5: previously worked for the Obama administration investigating antitrust claims. On Monday
column6: Warren told Fortune:

column1: “Americans have had it with regulators like Varney
column2: who talk a good game about holding the bad guys accountable while counting down the days until they can collect a fat paycheck from the corporations they were supposed to regulate. The revolving door is out of control. If we want to hold corporate lawbreakers accountable
column3: we can’t ask their friends to do it.”

column1: Bernie Sanders
column2: the senator from Vermont and former 2016 Democratic presidential candidate
column3: also objected to the deal in an open letter published Wednesday on Medium. In addition to echoing the concerns shared by others like Franken
column4: he warned that the buyout could provoke future media mergers that would further consolidate an already limited market.

column1: “At a time when our telecommunications and media industries are already too concentrated
column2: we should be focused on opening those markets to more competition
column3: not less
column4: ” he wrote.

column1: In the case that the merger does go through
column2: AT&T’s ties to the national security state may also give rise to serious privacy concerns. A day after the AT&T-Time Warner merger was officially announced
column3: Kenneth Lipp
column4: a reporter at The Daily Beast
column5: revealed that AT&T is storing customer information and selling it for profit . That
column6: of course
column7: came more than three years after Edward Snowden leaked classified information which detailed the telecommunications giant’s close collaboration with the NSA to spy on millions of Americans.

column1: “Where you go
column2: what you watch
column3: text and share
column4: with whom you speak
column5: all your internet searches and preferences
column6: all gathered and ‘vertically integrated
column7: ’ sold to police and perhaps
column8: in the future
column9: to any number of AT&T’s corporate customers
column10: ” Democracy Now! host Amy Goodman and her frequent collaborator
column11: Denis Moynihan
column12: wrote in an editorial published on Thursday .

column1: “We can’t know if Alexander Graham Bell envisioned this brave new digital world when he invented the telephone. But this is the future that is fast approaching
column2: unless people rise up and stop this merger.” Be Sociable
column3: Share!"	FAKE

column1: Fall of the House of Bush: How last name and Donald Trump doomed Jeb	"For Jeb Bush’s campaign
column2: August was a cruel month. Donald Trump’s attacks on the former Florida governor as a ­“low-energy” politician were beginning to stick
column3: and the two were bickering over immigration. The issue before the Bush team was what to do about it.

column1: Some advisers argued for an aggressive response
column2: even to the point of challenging Trump to some kind of one-on-one confrontation. Others resisted
column3: believing Trump’s candidacy was unsustainable
column4: while some cautioned against getting “into a pigpen with a pig
column5: ” as one adviser recalled. Others described it as “trying to wrestle with a stump.”

column1: Those summer days crystallized the plight of a campaign that had begun with enormous expectations and extraordinary resources
column2: as the scion of one of America’s dynastic political families sought to follow his father and brother to the presidency.

column1: At what would become a crucial moment
column2: Bush’s team had no clear strategy for a rival who was beginning to hijack the Republican Party that the Bush family had helped to build
column3: other than to stay the course set months earlier of telling Bush’s story to voters.

column1: “There was no consensus
column2: ” senior strategist David Kochel said of the discussions about how to combat the threat of Trump’s candidacy. Other campaigns were wrestling with the same problems
column3: but as the front-runner in the polls at the time
column4: Bush would suffer more than the others.

column1: On Saturday night
column2: the candidacy that had begun with such promise ended quietly after a disappointingly weak fourth-place finish in South Carolina.

column1: Ever the gracious realist
column2: Bush announced in his concession speech that he would end his campaign as Trump continued to soar as the GOP front-runner. “I have stood my ground
column3: refusing to bend to the political winds
column4: ” he said.

column1: Whether Jeb Bush ever had a chance to win the Republican nomination in a campaign year that proved so ill fitting for a rusty politician who preferred policy papers to political combat is a question that will be debated long after the 2016 race has ended.
“Donald Trump channeled the worst fears
column2: frustrations and anxiety of voters
column3: but he also magnified those same feelings
column4: ” Sally Bradshaw
column5: Bush’s chief strategist and confidant
column6: said Sunday in an email. “It would be difficult for any solutions-oriented conservative to tackle Trump in this environment
column7: much less one who was seen as having been so much a part of the establishment. He was never going to be an angry guy — and voters wanted angry.”

column1: Mike Murphy
column2: the chief strategist for Bush’s super PAC
column3: Right to Rise
column4: explained what had happened this way on Sunday. “Our theory was to dominate the establishment lane into the actual voting primaries
column5: ” he said. “That was the strategy
column6: and it did not work. I think it was the right strategy for Jeb. The problem was there was a huge anti-establishment wave. The establishment lane was smaller than we thought it would be. The marketplace was looking for something different
column7: and we’ll find out how that ends when we have a nominee.”

column1: The result is one of the most startling failures in the modern history of American politics: the fall of the House of Bush. It is a human story about the struggles of one of the most successful former governors in America in his bid to become president
column2: like his father and brother
column3: set against the backdrop of one of the strangest political cycles the country has seen in years.

column1: Beyond underestimating the anger in the electorate
column2: three other problems led to Bush’s downfall. First
column3: the candidate and his team misjudged the degree of Bush fatigue among Republicans.

column1: Aides said an internal poll conducted last fall showed discouraging news: Roughly two-thirds of voters had issues with Bush’s family ties. “Bush stuff was holding him back
column2: ” said one aide who saw the polling data. “We obviously knew it was an issue
column3: but even still
column4: the gap between it and other issues — I don’t think we thought it would be that big.”

column1: [For Jeb Bush
column2: the challenge remains making it about ‘Jeb
column3: ’ not ‘Bush’]

column1: Second
column2: Bush and his team miscalculated the role and power of money and traditional television commercials in the 2016 race. During the first six months of 2015
column3: Bush raised more than $100 million
column4: most of it stockpiled in Right to Rise
column5: a strategy that seemed right at the time but came at the cost of not dealing with other pressing needs.

column1: “We didn’t use that time to introduce him as a unique brand
column2: ” said Vin Weber
column3: an outside adviser. “We used it to raise money. I don’t want to say they made an obvious and clear mistake
column4: but in retrospect
column5: it was a mistake.”

column1: The aggressive fundraising came to be known as “shock and awe
column2: ” an echo of the initial bombing of Iraq by U.S.-led forces before the 2003 invasion. In the campaign context
column3: it could be read as code to other potential candidates to get out of the way. But the prodigious fundraising of Bush’s broad network scared off no one. As the Bush campaign would learn
column4: every credible candidate today has a few billionaire friends who can enrich a super PAC. In the end
column5: all that money came to symbolize frustration rather than power.

column1: Third
column2: Bush ran a campaign that
column3: whether deliberate or not
column4: was rooted in the past
column5: managed by loyalists who admired Bush and enjoyed his confidence but who
column6: like the candidate
column7: found themselves in unfamiliar political terrain.

column1: His advisers were convinced from the start that the more voters learned about what Bush had done as governor of Florida from 1999 to 2007
column2: they would flock to him as their presidential candidate. Bush stubbornly held to that approach — even as evidence mounted that it was out of step with voters.

column1: Doug Gross
column2: a prominent Iowa Republican
column3: recalled meeting with Bush in July 2014 in Kennebunkport
column4: Maine
column5: to talk about the impending campaign. “He definitely wanted to run. He’s always had it in him and knew this was his last chance
column6: ” Gross said. “He was trying to figure out how to do it his own way. I was struck by his obstinate avoidance of any political discussion. . . . He wanted to do it his way or no way.”

column1: In contrast to the doldrums of August 2015
column2: July seemed a glorious time for the Bush team. Early that month
column3: Team Jeb gathered in Kennebunkport to celebrate that the campaign and two allied political committees had together raised nearly an unprecedented $120 million. The numbers were made public as nearly 300 major Bush fundraisers assembled to mingle with the Bush family and campaign advisers.

column1: Guests were transported in black-and-red trolleys to Walker’s Point
column2: the Bush family compound. The group gathered for a photo with former president George H.W. Bush and Barbara Bush.

column1: That evening
column2: Bush touted the team’s record fundraising as guests dined on lobster rolls and hamburgers at a luxury resort tucked among a forest of birch groves and balsam fir. “It was incredibly memorable to be there with several generations
column3: ” said Jay Zeidman
column4: a Houston-based investor who helped raise money from young professionals.

column1: The next day
column2: the donors got briefings from senior Bush aides including Bradshaw
column3: campaign manager Danny Diaz and finance director Heather Larrison. They laid out how the campaign planned to take on contenders such as Sen. Ted Cruz of Texas
column4: Sen. Marco Rubio of Florida and New Jersey Gov. Chris Christie. Throughout
column5: there was little mention of Donald Trump.

column1: [That time Jeb Bush invited 300 top donors to his parents’ house]
“None of us thought he would last the summer
column2: ” said one person who was in attendance.

column1: At that moment
column2: however
column3: Trump was already in the process of undermining Bush’s candidacy. If Bush had ever gone up against someone like Trump
column4: it didn’t show. Trump was a new and different kind of rival
column5: one given to personal insults rather than policy debates
column6: who monopolized media coverage and got away with provocative statements that would have sunk normal politicians.

column1: After marching in two July 4 parades on a rainy Saturday in New Hampshire
column2: reporters asked Bush about Trump’s claim that Mexico was allowing immigrants to illegally cross into the United States. It was one of the hundreds of times he would face such questions.

column1: Bush said “absolutely” he was offended by Trump’s rhetoric. “We’re going to win when we’re hopeful and optimistic and big and broad rather than ‘grrrrrr’ ” he said — literally
column2: growling – “just angry all the time.”

column1: That very night
column2: Trump attacked Bush as soft on immigration and took aim as well at Bush’s wife
column3: Columba
column4: who was born in Mexico and entered the country legally — retweeting and then deleting a disparaging comment about her.

column1: Nothing
column2: however
column3: cut as close to the bone as Trump’s claim that Bush was too “low-energy” to serve as president.

column1: The accusation was laughable — until it began to stick. Trump’s charge was in fact a proxy for a different and more difficult argument to combat: that Bush was neither strong nor edgy enough for a party seething with anger at the grass roots.
[Inside the Bush-Trump melodrama: Decades of tension and discomfort]
“Nobody tapped into it
column2: for all the polling
column3: all the focus groups
column4: ” said Theresa Kostrzewa
column5: a North Carolina lobbyist who raised money for the campaign. “The biggest thing they did was miss was just how angry the American electorate was and that Trump would be their Captain Ahab.”

column1: Bush’s advisers would contest that claim. They could see the anger
column2: they said. The issue was what to do about it. “Donors
column3: political operatives and big thinkers from around the country urged us to ignore Trump for months
column4: ” Bradshaw said. “There was no one in the news media or the operative class at the time who felt Trump would ultimately be a serious contender for the nomination.”

column1: At the same time
column2: others feared that engaging Trump was almost beneath Bush and would thrust the candidate into a never-ending game of charge-countercharge. “Jeb should be bigger than this
column3: ” another aide recalled thinking.

column1: Over at Right to Rise
column2: Murphy sent a clear signal: Trump is not our fight right now.

column1: “If other campaigns wish that we’re going to uncork money on Donald Trump
column2: they’ll be disappointed
column3: ” Murphy told The Washington Post in late August. “Trump is
column4: frankly
column5: other people’s problem.”

column1: At that moment
column2: the Bush team’s analysis showed that no Trump voters were likely to shift their support to Bush. On Sunday
column3: Murphy said that attacking Trump would only have benefited other candidates. Bush’s campaign needed to consolidate the establishment lane while hoping that Trump and Cruz would sort out the competition among the anti-establishment candidates.

column1: Bradshaw also dismissed complaints from some donors that she cut the candidate off from advice. Noting that Bush long has been active on email
column2: Bradshaw responded in a message by saying: “Donors constantly gave conflicting advice — attack Trump
column3: don’t attack Trump; smile more; smile less — you look like you are smirking. I didn’t tell people they were wrong — not my style — I did a lot of listening
column4: and I’m sure there were things we could have done better — but withholding info from the Governor simply did not happen in our campaign.”

column1: For much of the autumn
column2: Bush’s engagement with Trump was on-again
column3: off-again — skirmish
column4: then turning away. Not until late last year did he truly start a concerted and sustained series of attacks. Aides said Bush was particularly affected by the terrorist attacks in Paris and San Bernardino
column5: Calif.
column6: and felt
column7: as one adviser put it
column8: that it was “time to stand up to the bully.”

column1: “Jeb was the only candidate with the political courage at the time and frankly throughout the last six months to take on Trump directly for doing something that the governor felt was very harmful to the Party and to the country
column2: ” Bradshaw wrote. “There was no hesitation at that point given his comments about women
column3: about Hispanics
column4: his lack of knowledge on issues of national security and on and on.”

column1: Bush’s failure to come to terms with one of the downsides of his family name came to a head over a four-day period in May
column2: when he stumbled over the decision by his brother
column3: former president George W. Bush
column4: to go to war in Iraq.

column1: Changing his answer on a daily basis
column2: Bush came across as a flat-footed campaigner clearly uncomfortable articulating his views on the most critical moment of his brother’s presidency. But it also highlighted the ­double-edged nature of being a candidate named Bush.

column1: In a January Washington Post-ABC News poll
column2: nearly 6 in 10 Americans held an unfavorable view of Bush. He was the only Republican with a negative favorability rating: 44 percent said they had a favorable impression of the former governor while 50 percent rated him negatively. His rankings grew worse as the campaign progressed.

column1: A fundamental weakness
column2: supporters said
column3: was the lack of a coherent rationale for Bush’s candidacy and the failure to make inroads with activists on the right. “At the end of the day
column4: it wasn’t clear the name was ever surmountable
column5: ” said a Bush donor. “If the name was going to be surmounted
column6: it would have to be because there was a fresh set of ideas.”

column1: Bush offered ideas
column2: but in a campaign dominated by Trump
column3: they were ignored or lost to most voters.

column1: One of the biggest tactical advantages Bush appeared to have early on — a richly endowed super PAC — was not the invincible weapon his team thought it would be. It cut off his access to a key adviser
column2: Murphy
column3: whom he installed at the group’s helm.

column1: It also meant that during the first six months of last year
column2: nearly all of the coverage about Bush focused on how he was socking away millions into the super PAC
column3: all while maintaining that he had not decided whether to run. In an election brimming with anger toward the wealthy elite
column4: Bush seemed almost flippant about his pursuit of big dollars.

column1: Murphy was convinced that much of what was taking place was noise and that when the voters began to check in
column2: the super PAC’s financial might would be overpowering.

column1: First
column2: the committee would use it to lay out Bush’s biography. Then
column3: as necessary
column4: the group would turn its arsenal on his rivals. “Our job is just to amplify his story and what he’s saying and we banked enough cash that nobody’s turning our speaker off
column5: ” Murphy told Bloomberg Politics in October.

column1: Back at campaign headquarters
column2: the team hewed to that timetable and sensibility. Once the Bush record was burned into voters’ minds
column3: attitudes would shift
column4: Bradshaw said at the time. A Bush donor complained
column5: “Murphy had a timetable
column6: and nothing mattered until December and January.”

column1: By the end of January
column2: Right to Rise had raced through at least $95.7 million out of the $118.6 million it had collected
column3: according to Federal Election Commission filings. Almost $87 million went into a barrage of television ads
column4: online videos
column5: slick mailers and voter phone calls—to no avail.

column1: Mel Sembler
column2: a former Bush ambassador who helped raise money for the super PAC and served on its governance board
column3: said he believes the group’s strategy was sound.

column1: “We had confidence in Mike
column2: and I think we did the best we could in deploying of resources
column3: ” Sembler said. “That’s not where the problem is. . . . The timing was not right for Jeb. Our candidate was just not connecting with the electorate.”

column1: The final months were difficult for Bush. After a particularly weak performance during a debate in Boulder
column2: Colo.
column3: in October in which Rubio appeared to get the better of him
column4: there were suggestions that he might quit the campaign right then.

column1: Reporters who made inquiries about the possibility were brushed off. In the middle of it all
column2: Bush spotted a reporter who was a regular on the trail with him. “Hey — I didn’t drop out
column3: did I?” he shouted. “You know
column4: that kind of stuff really gets my juices going. I’m going to win this thing
column5: and when I do — you’re going to give me a big hug.”

column1: Through it all
column2: Bush attempted to keep both good humor and determination in the face of the inevitable.

column1: “I was stunned by how well he handled the last month of this campaign when the writing was on the wall
column2: ” said Tim Miller
column3: Bush’s communications director. “It is hard to go out there every day and put on a fake smiley face. He was in really high spirits and didn’t lash out at people in private throughout the last two months.”

column1: The final indignity in a campaign that had suffered through many came three days before Saturday’s primary
column2: when South Carolina Gov. Nikki Haley endorsed Rubio rather than a man she described as a friend and mentor.

column1: When it ended Saturday night
column2: Bush told saddened supporters: “We put forward details
column3: innovative
column4: conservative plans to address the mounting challenges that we face. Because despite what you might have heard
column5: ideas matter
column6: policy matters.”

column1: His final remarks as a presidential candidate were a reflection of the campaign he had constructed from the start
column2: one he had built to his unique specifications
column3: which nonetheless proved to be a mismatch for a political environment that caught him by surprise — and for which he paid a hefty price."	REAL

column1: Mitt Romney Fans Speculation Over Another White House Run	"There were several reports this month
column2: based on former and current aides
column3: that Mitt Romney is actively weighing another presidential run. The biggest sign yet comes from a recent interview with The New York Times
column4: where the former 2012 Republican nominee offered a less than Shermanesque response to the million-dollar question.

column1: This was the obvious opening for me to ask if there was a chance. Romney's response was decidedly meta — ""I have nothing to add to the story"" -- but he then fell into the practiced political parlance of nondenial. ""We've got a lot of people looking at the race
column2: he said. ""We'll see what happens.""

column1: Buoyed by good poll numbers and a wide-open prospective Republican field
column2: Romney went farther than his ""circumstances can change"" reply in August
column3: and certainly miles forward from the
column4: ""Oh
column5: no
column6: no
column7: no. No
column8: no
column9: no
column10: no
column11: no. No
column12: no
column13: no
column14: answer in January.

column1: If he does throw his hat into the ring for a third time
column2: the former governor of Massachusetts told the Times that he would employ a cameraman -- essentially his own tracker -- to follow him around in order to guard against statements that derailed his 2012 campaign. ""I want to be reminded that this is not off the cuff
column3: Romney said.

column1: Romney said the tactic could potentially prevent another ""47 percent"" incident
column2: which by his telling
column3: was nothing more than a problem of setting.

column1: My mistake was that I was speaking in a way that reflected back to the man
column2: Romney said. ""If I had been able to see the camera
column3: I would have remembered that I was talking to the whole world
column4: not just the man."""	REAL

column1: US Airstrike Kills Four Iraqi Troops Near Mosul	"Nine Others Wounded in 'Friendly Fire' Attack by Jason Ditz
column2: October 29
column3: 2016 Share This

column1: As Iraqi forces continue to struggle to get closer to the ISIS city of Mosul during the ongoing invasion
column2: a US friendly fire incident has been reported in the town of Tal-Kayf
column3: a town which fell quite some time ago and in which recent fighting hadn’t been reported.

column1: According to Iraqi military officials
column2: the US airstrikes against the town killed at least four Iraqi soldiers and wounded nine others . The details are still scant on what happened
column3: and the US has yet to comment on the incident at all.

column1: Iraqi officials are chalking it up as a mistake
column2: but it is unclear why the town would be struck by US planes in the first place
column3: as the Iraqi troops had been there for almost a week and there did not appear to be ISIS forces in the immediate vicinity.

column1: Iraqi forces confirmed the incident amid an announcement of more villages captured in the area west of Mosul. Many of the villages more than 5 km from the city have already fallen
column2: and ISIS appears to be only sparsely defending those that remain
column3: with the vast majority of their fighters hunkered down in Mosul itself
column4: prepared for a major battle. Last 5 posts by Jason Ditz"	FAKE

column1: ‘Tolerant’ Liberals Show Nothing But Contempt, Hatred Toward Nation’s Only Black Supreme Court Justice	"Pinterest
It’s been a quarter-century since Supreme Court Justice Clarence Thomas made history by becoming only the second black judge ever to serve on the nation’s highest court.
But you won’t see celebrations
column2: recognition
column3: or even acknowledgement of this feat – in fact
column4: the “Thomas-derangement
column5: ” as The Daily Caller calls it
column6: has not abated one bit.

column1: This despite the fact that the impact Thomas has had is unequaled. Thomas is one of the nation’s most influential lawmakers and has admirers from all legal corners.
Yet
column2: he is ridiculed
column3: belittled
column4: and assaulted with the type of disgusting comments usually reserved for common criminals and deviants.

column1: Writing in The New York Times
column2: Maureen Dowd referred to the Justice as “the creepy guy who acted pervy toward [Anita Hill] and won.

column1: This barrage of insults is not just among his legal and intellectual peers
column2: either. Thomas has been completely wiped clean from any mention in the new Smithsonian National Museum of African American History and Culture.

column1: His accuser Anita Hill
column2: however
column3: is given prominent display. The exhibit features testimonies trumpeting her courage and the surge of women’s activism that ensued
column4: while making only peripheral reference to Thomas.

column1: Despite these slights
column2: Thomas continues to speak out. At a speech at the Heritage Foundation
column3: the justice warned that we are “destroying our institutions.”

column1: “At some point
column2: we are going to have to recognize that we are destroying our institutions
column3: ” he said
column4: acknowledging that the Court might also partially be at fault. “What have we done to gain their confidence?” he asked. “Perhaps we should ask ourselves what we have done to not earn it or to earn it.”

column1: The court’s lone African-American justice also defended his view that even prior Supreme Court precedents must be bent or broken to comply with the Constitution — something most of his colleagues don’t believe.
“You’ve got lots of precedents out there that have been changed
column2: ” Thomas said. “I believe we are obligated to rethink things constantly.”

column1: Thomas ended with some positive words about former Justice Antonin Scalia
column2: who he affectionately referred to as “Nino.”

column1: The court has become evenly divided between liberals and conservatives
column2: a change that could become even more pronounced if Hillary Clinton wins the presidency and controls who will replace Scalia. But Thomas chose to dwell more on his friendship with “Nino” than ponder the future without him.

column1: “He was from the north
column2: and I was from the south
column3: but we wound up at the same place
column4: ” he said
column5: referring to their views on the paramount importance of the Constitution and individual freedoms. Scalia
column6: he said
column7: fretted over big principles as well as smaller things such as punctuation and syntax."	FAKE
